HEADLINE: Politics Entered Wildlife Refuges Long Ago

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Another G.O.P. Environmental Folly" (editorial, April 25):
You are right to condemn the so-called national wildlife refuge improvement bill now before the Senate. If enacted, this proposal will further weaken America's beleaguered preserves.
However, you are wrong to assert that the Interior Department has traditionally allowed commercial and recreational uses of refuges only to the extent that such uses do not conflict with wildlife conservation.
The refuge system has been compromised by political expediency for decades. 
 It began with hunting in the 1930's, when many refuge managers were encouraged to manipulate their precious scraps of habitat mainly to benefit waterfowl and other game animals.
It wasn't long before economic and recreational uses blatantly incompatible with wildlife preservation became the rule on refuges all around the country, from oil production on the Kenai Peninsula in Alaska and intensive cattle grazing in the Charles M. Russell Refuge in Montana to water-skiing and speed-boating on Ruby Lake in Nevada.
Special interests and their political agents called the shots; refuge managers and officials in Washington either buckled under or suffered the consequences.
The low point was reached during the Reagan years when Interior Secretary James G. Watt tried to make increased economic use the top priority on refuge lands.
How to safeguard this vulnerable system against such shenanigans?
Dump the potentially catastrophic wildlife refuge legislation and instead pass legislation that would give refuge officials the autonomy and power they need to fend off political pressure and do what is best for wildlife.
 
JIM DOHERTY
Washington, April 28, 1996
 
The writer is on the board of editors of Smithsonian Magazine.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Swiss Franc and German Mark Drop After Official's Comment

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against the Swiss franc and the German mark after Switzerland's Finance Minister called for a weaker franc.
The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen, recovering slightly from a two-day selloff. 
 Finance Minister Kaspar Villiger of Switzerland, in a speech in Zurich, said a strong franc was a severe hindrance to his country's flagging economy and called for a decline in the currency.
"The comments definitely served to weaken the Swiss franc," said Stephen Jury, chief dealer at Union Bank of Switzerland. "The market just got very excited."
The Swiss economy has fared badly in the last year, contracting in the fourth quarter for the first time in more than two years.
The Swiss franc's decline yesterday hurt the mark because the two currencies are tied closely, and because investors think Germany's central bank would also welcome a weaker mark to bolster its sluggish economy.
"The Swiss franc tends to move a little faster, but it's the same story for Germany," said Alex Sinclair, a commodity trading adviser in Twin Falls, Idaho, who invests in currencies. "They're scared."
The dollar rose as high as 1.2466 Swiss francs, its highest since Feb. 27, 1995. In late trading in New York, it settled at 1.2435 Swiss francs, up from 1.2372 Swiss francs on Monday.
The dollar climbed to 1.5310 marks, from 1.5265 marks, and to 105.13 yen, from 104.67 yen. The British pound traded at $1.5075, up from $1.5069.
Against the yen, the dollar fell in Asian trading on persistent concern that interest rates in Japan could soon rise, increasing the returns on yen deposits. Anticipated buying of dollars by Japan's central bank failed to materialize.
The dollar later erased its losses, helped by speculation that the Bank of Japan was still willing to help support the dollar against the yen.
"People have loaded up in the belief the dollar can't go down because the Bank of Japan would be there," said Varick Martin, manager of foreign exchange at Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company. "The fact that we're not seeing an even more substantial selloff is because of the belief they can't let it go forever."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
What Fuels Nasdaq Rise? A Handful Of Big Issues

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
It looks like heaven for smaller stocks these days. But in fact it is bigger stocks that are providing a lot of the action in the Nasdaq stock market.
Yesterday, for the ninth trading day in a row, the Nasdaq composite index set a record closing high. With yesterday's rise of 2.38 points, to 1,190.58, the index is up 6.2 percent in those nine sessions, a much better performance than either that of the Standard & Poor's 500 or the Dow Jones industrial average. [Page D8.] 
 This run is still a long way from setting a record for records. The peak string was 19 consecutive new high closes in 1979, but it is the longest in more than four years and has brought attention to the fact that many Nasdaq stocks have taken off since beginning the year with surprising weakness.
The move reflects an improved economic outlook and better earnings for many smaller stocks. But it also reflects a surge of investment in riskier mutual funds, which have tended to put cash into some of the largest companies in the Nasdaq market. As a result, it is the big Nasdaq names, many of them involved in technology, that have paced the market.
The latest surge in small-cap stocks began in mid-January. The Nasdaq composite index is up 20 percent since Jan. 15, vastly outperforming the Standard & Poor's 500 index of large stocks, which is up 9 percent.
In fact, small stocks are not doing nearly as well as that would seem to indicate. The Russell 2,000, an index of really small stocks -- ones not in the top 1,000 in market capitalization -- is up 15 percent since Jan. 15. That is good, but not nearly as exciting as the Nasdaq figure.
About 40 percent of the rise in the Nasdaq composite -- an index that includes more than 6,000 issues -- was caused by the movement of the 100 largest Nasdaq stocks. The Nasdaq 100 is up 25 percent in the period. And a full quarter of the rise in the Nasdaq composite can be traced to just eight large stocks: Microsoft, Intel, Cisco Systems, Oracle, Sun Microsystems, Worldcom, U.S. Robotics and America Online.
Why are the big little stocks rising so much faster than the littler stocks while the really big stocks do less well? One answer lies in the strength of the dollar, which has scared some investors regarding big international companies. The fear is that the stronger dollar will make them less competitive.
And Claudia Mott, the head of small-cap research for Prudential Securities, says that in part because the United States economy is now growing faster than many other economies, earnings of small-cap companies as a group are growing faster than those of larger companies for the first time in a couple of years.
But a bigger part of the answer would seem to lie where it has for much of the 1990's: in the decisions made by millions of mutual fund investors. And as a group, those investors are showing a willingness to take on more risk.
As interest rates have risen this year, the effect has been to scare some investors away from bond funds but not away from mutual funds. Some conservative investors who once put money in bond funds are now investing in conservative stock funds. Meanwhile, some who were once conservative stock investors have moved to aggressive-growth funds.
Such funds, the riskiest of diversified stock funds, took in $15.6 billion from investors in the first quarter, and the pace in April seems to have been greater. Not only was the quarter's performance a record -- up almost 25 percent from the previous peak, set in the third quarter of last year -- but it also amounted to more than 8 percent of assets in aggressive-growth funds, a very high figure by historical standards.
Adding to the upward pressure on stock prices, the managers of such funds grew cautious late last year and early this year; by Jan. 31 they had $18.5 billion in cash, a relatively high 9.3 percent of total assets. Two months later, they had spent $3.5 billion of that hoard, with cash down to a relatively low 7 percent of assets. The combination of big cash inflows plus the need to put previously unspent cash to work had a big impact.
That has also had the effect of sharply pushing up prices of computer technology stocks, which had sagged late last year after a period of stunning performance. Since Jan. 15, Microsoft is up 37 percent, Intel 26 percent and Cisco 54 percent. Some others have done much better. America Online has leaped 95 percent; U.S. Robotics, a maker of computer modems, is up 122 percent.
How long can this last? Many on Wall Street think it will continue for most of this year. They say that valuations of smaller stocks are not excessive, at least when compared with large-cap stocks, and add that they see no signs that the money will stop flowing in.
But there is one historic ratio that may suggest caution. That is the ratio of the Nasdaq composite to the Standard & Poor's 500. Back in the summer of 1983, the peak of small-stock popularity, and another time when technology stocks were soaring, Nasdaq became extremely popular, with the index 1.93 times as high as the S.& P. By the fall of 1990, the reverse had occurred. Tech stocks were hated, and large stocks had zoomed in value, relative to smaller ones. The ratio fell to 1.08.
Now, the ratio is back to 1.82. The Nasdaq composite has recovered about 85 percent of the ground it lost, on a relative basis, from 1983 through 1990. That suggests the party is well past the halfway point.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Pepsico's First-Quarter Net Rose 23%, to $394 Million

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday that it had strong first-quarter volume growth in its snack-food, soft-drink and restaurant businesses in a performance that analysts said presaged a return to the company's traditional double-digit increases in annual earnings.
The company, which was struggling to turn around its fast-food unit at the end of last year, registered a 23 percent jump in first-quarter net income, to $394 million, or 49 cents a share, from $321 million, or 40 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year. 
 "It's a good first quarter," said Emanuel Goldman, a securities analyst for Paine Webber, "that positions Pepsico not only for an excellent year but also for strong earnings-per-share gains over the next several years."
The first-quarter results, which equaled or exceeded many analysts' expectations, "mark the first time in three years that Pepsico has shown it can grow at a mid-teen clip," said Andrew J. Conway, a securities analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company.
Wall Street welcomed the news, as Pepsico shares rose $2.125 each, to $63.50, in trading on The New York Stock Exchange.
On the strength of the first-quarter figures, several analysts said they were expecting yearly earnings of at least $2.90 a share, up 17 percent from last year's $2.48.
The highlight of the first quarter was "the strength of the Frito-Lay snack-food business," said Martin Romm, a securities analyst for CS First Boston. "With the kind of tonnage growth it's getting, Frito-Lay is definitely going to accelerate the earnings performance."
More than a third of the poundage growth of the company's $5 billion snack-food business was driven by the unit's low-fat offerings, including its high-margin Baked Lays and Baked Tostitos snacks. A new, fifth production line for Baked Lays will expand output 25 percent this quarter, the company said in a conference call for analysts.
Pepsico said that snack-food volume grew 10 percent in the United States, a rate more than double that of the industry as a whole. But because of large investments in new products, distribution and production capacity, operating profit grew only 6 percent, the company said.
As for Pepsico's domestic beverage business, the company reported a sales growth of 6 percent, spurred by the unit's fountain business, which contributed to a profit growth of 17 percent. "There was a dramatic margin expansion of the United States beverage business, thanks to price increases and cost-cutting initiatives," Mr. Conway said.
Internationally, beverage volume grew only 3 percent despite strong beverage increases in Asia, China, India and Africa, which were offset by a 6 percent decline in the huge Latin American business, reflecting problems with the Mexican economy.
The company reported that its restaurant business was improving as well, as worldwide sales in its three fast-food units grew 6 percent, and were up 5 percent domestically. Same-store sales grew 8 percent at Pizza Hut and 7 percent at the company's KFC fast-food chains, while the Taco Bell fast-food unit continued to improve its struggling performance, reporting a same-store-sales decline of 1 percent.
That decrease is something of a positive since it's "the smallest decline out of the last six quarters," Mr. Goldman said.
The gains at Pizza Hut and KFC "were related to the stark realization that people don't bring calorie counters with them to a fast-food restaurant," Mr. Goldman added, referring to high-fat introductions like Pizza Hut's cheese-stuffed triple-decker pizza. By contrast, Taco Bell's low-fat line, Border Lights, had an underwhelming performance.

HEADLINE: Wages Climb 1% in Quarter; Pace Is Fastest In Five Years

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
After years of concern about wage stagnation, the Labor Department reported today that wages and salaries advanced 1 percent in the first three months of the year, the fastest pace since 1991.
While the increase was still modest, the report provided the first solid evidence that many workers are beginning to enjoy increases in pay that outpace the rise in the cost of living. 
 For business, the effect of the pay increase was blunted by a slight decline in the cost of providing medical and other fringe benefits, the first time such expenses have fallen since the Labor Department began compiling its Employment Cost Index in 1982.
Today's report also showed that white-collar workers further widened their advantage over those holding blue-collar jobs.
The change in total employment costs was in line with that of previous quarters, but some analysts warned that the increase in wages, coming at a time when oil and grain prices have jumped sharply, raises fears of a step-up in inflation that could prompt the Federal Reserve to keep a tight rein on credit.
In a separate report, the Conference Board, a business-supported research group, said that there was less apprehension about the job market in April than in previous months, with consumers showing "dramatically" increased confidence about what the coming months would bring. The improvement in consumer confidence followed two months of outsized gains in employment and an easing in the wave of announcements of layoffs by large corporations.
Other indications of a quickened economic tempo came from a stronger-than-expected report on economic conditions from the purchasing managers of companies in the Chicago area and another, somewhat slower, advance for an index of purchasers in the New York area.
Analysts say it has become increasingly clear that the economy has pulled back from what many regarded last winter as the brink of recession. But in the "good news equals bad news" environment that often prevails on Wall Street, some economists have begun to worry that faster growth and higher incomes might rekindle inflation.
"I think there's grounds for some unease," said L. Douglas Lee, economist at HSBC Washington Analysis, a research company. In contrast to the effects of higher commodity prices, which often dissipate before reaching consumers, "when wages creep up, that tends to get into everything," Mr. Lee said. Pay and benefits account for some 70 percent of business costs.
Joel L. Naroff, chief bank economist for the First Union Corporation, said in a report to clients, "It appears as if the low unemployment rates coupled with continued good economic growth are putting some additional pressures on wages and salaries." He said that benefit costs were unlikely to decline further, so "inflation could begin to tick up" if pay keeps accelerating without offsetting increases in productivity.
Other analysts, however, found only a minimal threat of inflation in today's figures on overall compensation, which showed an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent for the January-March period, the same as the average for the two preceding quarters.
Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch, said the increases in wages and salaries were "narrowly based," with wages in retailing up a sharp 2.1 percent while other industries, including manufacturing, were "far more restrained."
Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, said that labor costs were unlikely to spiral upward. "I just don't believe this is a harbinger" of serious inflation pressure, Mr. Kellner said.
Wayne Shelly, a Labor Department economist who works on the index, said the report found "some upturn" in wages from a long-established range as pay in private industry rose 3.3 percent over the latest 12 months compared with 2.8 percent for the 12 months through December and 2.9 percent for the year that ended in March 1995.
While reluctant to call the latest results a "trend," Mr. Shelly added that neither did they seem to be exceptional. "There's no reason to think this is an aberration," he said.
Financial markets reacted calmly to the reports, with both the bond and stock markets off only slightly.
The 1 percent rise in first-quarter pay for all civilian workers, including those in government and the nonprofit sector, was the biggest since a matching burst in the spring of 1991. It lifted the 12-month increase to 3.2 percent, from 2.9 percent at the end of last year, the report showed.
Benefit costs, which had jumped 1 percent in the final 1995 quarter, edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in the latest period.
Benefit costs usually rise sharply at the start of a year but "insurance companies just didn't raise premiums this year," Mr. Shelly said. Besides health coverage, other benefit costs to employers include bonuses, holiday and vacation time, shift differential and overtime pay, and premiums for life and unemployment insurance and for workers' compensation.
For the 12 months through March, total compensation for white-collar workers rose 3.4 percent compared with 2.2 percent for those in blue-collar and service occupations. The larger increases for white-collar workers continued a trend that has prevailed for most of the last 15 years, the department stated.
In the first quarter of this year, the white-collar rise was 1 percent compared with two-tenths of 1 percent for blue-collar occupations. This reflected twice as large a gain in wages and salaries -- 1.4 percent against seven-tenths of 1 percent -- and a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in white-collar benefits while blue-collar benefits fell seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Over the latest 12 months, compensation costs rose 3.1 percent for nonunion workers and 2.7 percent for union members, a pattern that held for goods-producing industries but not in services, where unionization made almost no difference.
As for consumer confidence, the Conference Board's index leaped to 105.3 in April, compared with 98.4 in March. The component that reflects attitudes toward the present situation advanced to 118.2 from 110 while the expectations component rose to 96.7 from 90.7.
"This month's improvement in consumer sentiment is largely attributable to less apprehension about employment," said Edgar R. Fiedler, vice president and economic adviser to the board.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Offers Plan to Nurture the City's New Industries

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Aiming to capitalize on surprising signs of growth in New York City's manufacturing sector, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a plan yesterday to try to encourage the new industrial enterprises like computer software, video production, recycling and cargo shipping that have emerged as economic bright spots in recent years.
The proposals, which include tax breaks, technical assistance, job training and zoning changes, would broaden the city's economic vision beyond Wall Street and the service economy that had once been held out as New York's salvation. The Mayor said the proposals would not only help preserve the 280,000 existing manufacturing jobs in businesses like apparel and printing, but would also provide incentives for the vibrant new companies sprouting up in what has been called Silicon Alley. 
 The proposals, reflecting the city's budget constraints, contained no huge windfalls for the business community, and some provisions, like the tax breaks, face an uncertain future. They are dependent on approval by the State Legislature as well as the City Council.
But in tone and tenor, the Mayor's speech outlining the proposals signaled that manufacturing, long treated as a fading sector of the economy, has pushed its way onto the policy agenda.
"We never thought in the past that you would start to see real growth in manufacturing again," Mr. Giuliani said in the speech to the Association for a Better New York. "The thought was: 'Manufacturing? Nah, you can't do manufacturing in New York City.'
"I really think that it's now time for us to set forth a policy and a program to re-establish manufacturing and industry in the city of new York."
The theme of Mr. Giuliani's speech, reflected in several recent independent studies of the city economy, is that the nature of manufacturing -- who does it, how and where -- has drastically changed in New York. The resonant image of old industry, of smokestacks, mass-production machines and unionized armies laboring in grimy fortresses, bears little relation to the smaller, leaner companies that have grown up in TriBeCa, SoHo and immigrant neighborhoods in Queens.
Much of apparel manufacturing, for example, which is the largest goods-producing industry in the city, employing 78,000 workers, now depends on skilled workers and short-term production runs that can be changed quickly to fit consumer demand. Many new industrial companies are minuscule by the old standards.
A study issued last week by the Urban Research Center at New York University said that the average young manufacturing company in New York has only three employees. Nearly 41 percent are owned by immigrants, compared with about 12 percent nationally, the study said.
A higher proportion have grown through investment by family members, and through serving tiny local community niches, than is usually the case elsewhere in the United States. One company cited in the study, the House of Spice, began as a retailer to the Pakistani residents of Jackson Heights, and now has production plants in the Bronx, opened in 1989, and in Queens, in 1992.
The new manufacturers include some older industries employing new methods of production, especially in garment manufacturing, to the high-technology loft shops of software makers in lower Manhattan and niche manufacturers serving immigrant neighborhoods.
But if yesterday's announcement marks a shift in policy, it will clearly be wrapped in the complications of politics as it moves forward. For example, the plan proposes zoning changes that would make it easier for a manufacturer in some industrial zones to expand a business. Another set of zoning proposals, however, which received much criticism at a public hearing at City Hall yesterday, would allow wider use of so-called big box or superstore retailing in manufacturing zones. Some city officials say they already see a conflict.
"Big box rezoning works against the stability of manufacturing," said the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger. "Given that fact, there's not enough coming back in the Mayor's plan for manufacturing that will strengthen them into the next century."
Many of the proposals in the Mayor's plan are also technical and incremental and, by the multimillion-dollar standards set by the city in retaining some big-name companies in the last few years, quite modest. The total bill for the tax changes envisioned in the report would be $49 million a year, said Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for Planning and Community Affairs.
Some are also speculative. The changes proposed in job training, for instance, would create a new link between the city and the manufacturing sector, with a kind of apprenticeship system in which new employees could be trained in part with public funds. But the Federal job training apportionment for New York, as for every other city, has been held up by the long budget impasse in Washington.
Some of the changes are administrative. One proposal would allow commercial cargo vans to use the Grand Central Parkway, which city officials say could speed and reduce the cost of air cargo shipments to and from LaGuardia Airport. The environmental licensing and permits process in Queens will will also be consolidated at a single one-stop location at the Department of Environmental Protection.
But unlike the giant packages meant to keep big employers in New York at a cost of millions, the new manufacturing plan would give something back to thousands of companies that have mostly been ignored in the past. One proposal would benefit 10,000 small companies, the plan said, by eliminating a tax provision that has encouraged companies to expand outside New York rather than within it.
Ms. Reiter said that, if nothing else, the manufacturing report underlines that New York's economy is more complicated and less predictable than it might have seemed either during the boom of the 1980's or the recession that followed in the late 1980's and early 1990's. The service economy is not the whole answer, she said, and neither is manufacturing, but neither can be ignored.
"The financial sector was where we really concentrated our resources," she said. "The city made a conscious decision that that's the kind of economy we wanted. It was foolish."

HEADLINE: U.S. Cites China for Failing to Curb Piracy in Trade

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration formally designated China today as the most egregious violator of agreements intended to combat the piracy of American products, a step that seemed to lay the groundwork for imposing long-expected sanctions against China in coming weeks.
In a report to Congress, the Administration said it was citing Beijing because of its blatant failure to rein in piracy of American videocassettes, compact disks, computer software and other products, despite an agreement last year to do so. 
 The Administration also said it would begin actions through the World Trade Organization against Portugal, Turkey, India and Pakistan for not complying with free-trade agreements on movies, music, software, books and other intellectual property.
In addition, it put eight trading partners on a priority watch list, saying they were at risk of failing to protect American copyrights and trademarks in some product categories or of failing to open their markets. Those placed on the list were Argentina, the European Union, Greece, India, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea and Turkey.
In the case of Japan, which has increasingly given way to China as the focus of American trade policy, the Administration said it was concerned about patent policies and the protection of trademarks, among other issues.
In still another area, involving procurement by foreign governments, the Administration said it was beginning proceedings under American law against Germany for discriminating against American companies including General Electric and Westinghouse.
The designation of China as a "priority foreign country" -- jargon for nations that are found to flout trade agreements and harm the interests of American businesses -- is largely symbolic. China is the only country to be given that designation this year, and the question of how to deal with China on a range of issues including trade, human rights and the spread of nuclear technology has become one of the Administration's most sensitive policy and political concerns.
Officials at the United States trade representative's office declined to give a timetable for a decision on sanctions. But the move appeared to narrow the Administration's options, if only by putting China in a category all its own. The Administration has been considering the imposition of sanctions on as much as $2 billion of Chinese imports into the United States.
"China has been given a very clear understanding of our concerns," a deputy United States trade representative, Ira Shapiro, said at a news conference. "We will not hesitate to enforce our trade laws."
Despite Chinese promises to crack down on the practice, "piracy remains rampant, and economic damage to U.S. industries continues to rise," the report said.
"Over all, China has made some progress in halting the retail trade in infringing goods," it said, "but has failed to stop illegal CD, video and CD-ROM production at some 31 plants operating in China, to prevent the export of infringing goods, or to honor its promise to grant market access for legitimate audiovisual products."
It added that "trade sanctions for noncompliance could be imposed at any time" after completion of an investigation in progress into China's trading practices.
The Administration has been constrained in its trade policy toward China by strong pressure from American business not to provoke the Chinese into further closing off their huge and potentially lucrative market or discriminating against American companies in favor of Asian and European competitors. The trade deficit with China last year was $34 billion, and is expected to grow this year.
In the next month, the Administration must decide whether to seek a renewal in Congress of China's most-favored-nation trading status. Although the Administration is expected to ask for a renewal, doing so is expected to bring sharp denunciations from legislators critical of China's human rights record. And it could give Senator Bob Dole, the presumed Republican Presidential nominee, an opening to criticize Mr. Clinton's record on China.
At the same time, the Administration is trying to decide what sanctions to impose against the Chinese for selling technology to Pakistan that could be used in developing nuclear weapons.

HEADLINE: The Success of a Small Company May Ultimately Be the City's Loss

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
If there is new hope for manufacturing in New York City, one place to look is the fourth-floor loft overlooking Union Square Park where Yee-Ping Wu, a concert pianist turned high-technology entrepreneur, has increased her company's work force to 60 from 5 since 1994.
Ms. Wu is co-founder and president of Music Pen Inc., which makes CD-ROMs, video games and interactive computer products for children. Music Pen is also part of a growing array of more than 4,000 embryonic companies in and around the city that are finding new ways to link computers to the arts, advertising, publishing and movies. 
 While most of these companies, which are called new media, are little more than struggling start-ups, Music Pen has turned the corner. Its best-selling products are being marketed by such industry giants as Microsoft, Viacom and Virgin.
But success for Music Pen could also be New York City's loss.
"Other places are offering to support us with investments in job training, research and development, and tax reductions," Ms. Wu said yesterday, after Mayor Giuliani announced several proposals to support small manufacturers like her company.
Among those that have come calling on Music Pen, she said, are several other states and at least one other country, which she declined to name. "I love New York, but government policy has to be made to work with us," she said.
In many ways the antithesis of the gruff, hard-bargaining men who have championed New York City manufacturing in the past, the 41-year-old Ms. Wu has nonetheless brought together many of the same strands of immigrant zeal, artistic accomplishment and personal ambition that have fueled the city's economic growth for more than two centuries.
Born into poverty in Shanghai, she was recognized as a brilliant classical pianist and she performed with the Shanghai Chamber Orchestra as a child before enrolling in Manhattan's Julliard School when she was 16 years old.
There she met her husband, Philip Y. F. Lui, a composer, mathematician and immigrant from Canada with whom she founded Music Pen in 1987. They began by running the company out of their 350-square-foot studio apartment, cramming it with two pianos, seven computers and two cats.
But Music Pen was formed at a precipitous time, joining the vanguard of technological innovation that would spawn the explosive growth of the Internet, CD-ROMs and educational software for young children. Backed by $1 million from a Swiss investment firm, Ms. Wu and Mr. Lui introduced their first product in 1993, the Lenny Musictoons computer product for children.
Since 1994, when it moved into its Union Square loft, the company has created computer products that have become household names to many parents with preschool children. Music Pen's products include Wiggins in Storyland and Scholastic's The Magic School Bus Explores the Human Body.
The company staff, mostly under 30 years old, includes writers, composers, animators, sound designers, computer programmers and musicians. Ms. Wu attributed part of Music Pen's success to New York City's vast supply of people skilled in both technology and the arts.
"This city is a tremendous source of creative talent," she said. "There is a critical energy and warmth in bringing people like these together in one place."
But for all its dynamism, she said, New York City "is just very expensive."
For city officials who hope to retain and attract companies like Music Pen, one risk is that the priorities of a small business can change when it becomes big business.
"Building a successful company is really my only concern, even if that means going to the moon or the South China Sea," Ms. Wu said.
Indeed, she said that paying for the future growth of her company could mean selling its stock to the public or merging with a larger corporation, either of which could create new pressure to find a cheaper location than Manhattan.
Nonetheless, she said, any help from City Hall would make a difference.
Although she had not reviewed all of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposals, and questioned when any of them would be adopted, Ms. Wu said she was particularly encouraged by the Mayor's plan to lower the commercial rent tax and sales taxes on businesses in the city.
"These things would make us happier about planning our growth in the city," she said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Aids Beef Industry In a Season Of Low Prices

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
President Clinton moved today to soften the economic blow to beef producers caused by a spring drought and slumping cattle prices, ordering the Agriculture Department to open millions of acres of environmentally sensitive land for grazing and to start buying beef for next year's public school lunch program now.
The White House announced the moves after the President met in the Oval Office this evening with Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman and lawmakers from agricultural states to discuss the effects of high feed costs and the lowest prices in a decade for cattle, the nation's single largest commodity source of farm income, with annual sales close to $40 billion. 
 It was the second day in a row that Mr. Clinton used his executive authority to intervene in the market for a politically sensitive commodity. On Monday, he ordered the sale of 12 million barrels of oil from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve in an effort to stop a recent surge in retail gasoline prices.
Mr. Glickman said that livestock producers would be permitted to graze cattle and cut hay on the nearly 36 million acres of land that the Government now pays private owners to keep idle for conservation and environmental reasons. Those who take advantage of the option would forgo 5 percent of the annual rental income the Government pays them.
At the same time, he said, the Agriculture Department will begin making beef purchases of up to $50 million toward its school lunch program for the academic year that begins in September and would consider further purchases if conditions warranted.
Speaking to reporters after the meeting, Mr. Glickman said it was unlikely that the beef purchases alone would increase prices significantly, but he said the Administration was "doing our best to keep the market from falling further" and to provide "a psychological boost" to the industry.
The President's decision was yet another sign that Mr. Clinton was determined to take aggressive steps to improve or maintain his standing, whether in the Great Plains states, which he did not carry in the 1992 Presidential election, or the mountain states, like Colorado and Montana, which he did win.
Dry weather, particularly in Texas and the Great Plains, has threatened grazing. Grain shortages have raised feed costs, while heavy slaughter of hard-to-maintain herds has caused a glut that is holding down beef prices.
Mr. Glickman also called for stepped-up promotion of beef exports, a survey of the credit needs of beef producers to see how they might be helped by easing Government restrictions and a meeting of producers and agribusiness leaders to discuss other options.
Earlier today, Representative Pat Roberts, the Kansas Republican who heads the House Agriculture Committee, urged similar action. "Without such forbearance, even the best and most efficient producers may not survive this financial emergency," he said.
Danny Klinefelter, a professor and agriculture extension economist at Texas A & M University in College Station, said that opening the land now in the Federal Conservation Reserve Program to grazing "could be a temporary fix to help farmers hang on where they are being forced to liquidate herds, or forced to buy grain at great cost."
"At least it buys time," he said. But he added, "There are very limited things the President could do right now," and he noted that the newly passed farm bill, which included a broad overhaul of farm subsidies, had "done away with some of these special disaster programs that would otherwise be available."
Alisa Harrison, a spokeswoman for the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, which represents a quarter-million beef producers nationwide, said the group strongly supported the President's efforts.
"We operate on a supply-and-demand free enterprise system, and we encourage minimal Government interaction in the marketplace," she said. "However, there are some programs out there intended to help in a crisis like this to keep some cattle producers from going out of business and those local economies growing."
The price of fattened cattle fell to the upper $50's per hundred pounds in April, compared with $62 and $63 in March and $77 in 1993. Today, though word of the President's proposals rippled through the markets, the price declined slightly, by 22 cents per pound, to $57.35 per hundred pounds.
At his daily briefing, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, took some needling over how the President could justify moving to buck up prices of beef just a day after complaining that gasoline prices were too high. Reporters wondered why low beef prices were not good for consumers.
"Well, they are -- may or may not be in the long term," Mr. McCurry said, adding that low prices could lead producers to sell off their herds, possibly creating shortages in the coming years. "Two or three years down the road, according to some of the analysis we've seen, there might be an artificial inflation in cattle prices as a result of the diminution of stocks now and some of the steps that ranchers are having to take, given the feed grain situation and given the weather situation in the Plains States. So not necessarily are short-term lower prices something that will be beneficial for the economy in the long run."
As an economic proposition, would not that same logic apply to gasoline prices? "Well," Mr. McCurry said to scattered laughter, "we've dealt with that issue yesterday."

HEADLINE: Republicans Push for Gasoline Tax Repeal

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Republicans began pitching the repeal of a 1993 tax on gasoline today with all the fervor of a political campaign, pledging rapid tax relief to drivers who they maintained had been saddled with higher pump prices by a tax-loving Clinton Administration.
Democrats, meanwhile, worked deftly all day to steal the issue from under their opponents' noses. 
 Capping three days of publicity that pushed gasoline prices to the top of the political agenda, Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader and presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, said today that he wanted to abolish the 4.3-cent-a-gallon tax by Memorial Day. The House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, predicted that a repeal bill would sail through the House, and some Republicans pushed for a Senate vote as early as Thursday.
Mr. Dole said the repeal would extend only until Jan. 1, but added that a permanent abolition would be written into budget legislation later this spring.
"We believe, with the skyrocketing prices of gasoline, jet fuel and other fuels, that the most certain way to give consumers relief is to repeal the gas tax," Mr. Dole said on the Senate floor.
Then he took dead aim at his likely opponent in the fall Presidential campaign, adding: "That was part of the 1993 $265 billion tax increase President Clinton proposed, which did not receive a single Republican vote in the House or Senate."
Mr. Dole had seemed to catch Democrats unawares when he first proposed repealing the tax increase last Friday. But today Democrats launched a counterattack directed at two perennial foes, the oil industry and Mr. Dole himself.
The Democratic leader in the Senate, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, went before microphones to charge that producers had been the main beneficiary of the recent rise in gasoline prices and would also gain the most from a tax repeal.
He and a parade of other Democrats predicted that oil companies would simply pocket the savings from a gas-tax repeal instead of lowering prices to consumers. And many Democrats called for an investigation of possible price gouging by the oil industry, suggesting that petroleum companies had deliberately created a gasoline shortage.
"We ought to know what the real problem is here," Mr. Daschle said. "We're looking at mega-profits of oil companies." The solution, he added, was not a tax decrease but "more competition, more oversight" in the petroleum business.
The Justice Department said later that it would designate a team of five Government lawyers and economists to investigate whether the recent gasoline price surge was caused by oil companies' engaging in collusion.
Initially, the inquiry will center on whether the price increases were caused by market fluctuations. If not, the Justice Department's spokesman, Carl Stern, said the antitrust division would seek to determine whether the companies had broken the law.
The Justice Department has been under pressure from some lawmakers, like Senators Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman, both Democrats of Connecticut, to make an inquiry. The investigation is separate from a report that President Clinton had sought from the Energy Department on the factors that led to the price rise last month.
Mr. Daschle also suggested that Mr. Dole and other Republicans were grandstanding on the tax issue, seizing on gasoline prices to divert attention from the Democrats' monthlong campaign to try to force a vote on raising the minimum wage.
Indeed, Mr. Daschle noted that Mr. Dole had voted to raise Federal gasoline taxes by five cents in both 1982 and 1990, increases that he repeatedly called the "Dole dime."
If Congress grants any tax reduction, he said, it should be used to offset college-education expenses, a White House priority.
"We only have so many tax cuts to go around this year," he said.
Democrats added the 4.3-cent-a-gallon tax to a 14-cent Federal gasoline tax three years ago as a deficit-reduction measure. Its repeal would cost the Treasury about $4.8 billion a year, and the Republicans have yet to say how they would make up that loss.
Republicans offered their own grandstanding charge, leveled at President Clinton's decision on Monday to sell 12 million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Mr. Clinton cast the sale as an attempt to halt the rise in gasoline prices, but Republicans argued that the sale was their idea, inserted into spending legislation last week to pay for programs the White House sought to preserve.
"This is merely another example of the Administration's shameless pandering," said Representative Bob Livingston of Louisiana, the chairman of the Appropriations Committee.
But it was clear that for both parties politics, which had reared its head in the gas-tax debate from the start, was not likely to go away any time soon.
In a statement issued jointly today, Mr. Dole and Speaker Newt Gingrich said that with gasoline prices at their highest level since the Persian Gulf War, repeal "is the least we can do for hard-working Americans whose pocketbooks are taking a major hit."
Adjusting prices for inflation makes that toll less apparent.
According to the American Petroleum Institute, regular unleaded gasoline dispensed from self-service pumps cost less last year than at any time since records have been kept, when it sold for $1.14 a gallon. By comparison, a gallon of gasoline in 1960 cost $1.60 in 1995 dollars and in 1980 a gallon of gasoline was $2.20 when adjusted for inflation.
Prices have reached an average national price of $1.273 for a gallon of unleaded regular at the pump.

HEADLINE: Small Businesses Urge Council to Stop Mayoral Plan for Suburban-Style Superstores

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
It was billed as an "informational session." But as soon as the City Council took up the topic of bringing suburban-style superstores to New York City yesterday, scores of protesters came out to fight the idea.
The opposition, while largely staged by lobbyists for small businesses, was vehement and clearly showed that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will face a fight as his proposed zoning changes move through community boards and toward a final vote before the Council in the fall. 
 The superstores are common in almost every other major American city but are still quite rare in New York, in part because large tracts of real estate to accommodate them are hard to find but also because owners of thousands of small businesses in the city are fighting them.
Under the Mayor's plan, as many as 57 new superstores that would be as large as 200,000 square feet -- roughly the size of five football fields -- could open in former manufacturing areas, mostly outside Manhattan.
Yesterday, small-business owners spoke of financial ruin if the large, warehouse-type stores opened near them. In addition, a neighborhood association ferried elderly homeowners to City Hall on school buses.
Cashiers at some small supermarkets were sent by store managers, just to fill seats at the hearing, some of them said. At first, some were a little unclear on the issue of the day. But after hearing consumer and retail experts testify, several said they started to fear for their jobs.
But administration officials said New Yorkers are eager to shop in these kinds of stores because they offer convenience, more variety and lower prices. Joseph B. Rose, the City Planning Commission chairman, cited the success of the large new Fairway market in Harlem and the Home Depot in Ozone Park.
"The city is simply losing the retail investment battle with suburban areas," said Mr. Rose, adding that the city loses an estimated $3.1 billion a year in retail sales, not including food, to nearby communities.
The Mayor's plan essentially repeals restrictions that the city imposed on manufacturing areas in 1974 in a failed attempt to keep industries and lure new ones into manufacturing areas. As industrial companies fled, city officials prohibited large retail stores in those areas because they feared that retail outlets would drive up property prices and discourage manufacturers from returning to the city. That approach was misguided, Mr. Rose said.
Chris Collett, executive director of the Forest Hills Chamber of Commerce in Queens, said small-business owners see the Mayor's proposal as an attempt to attract big retailers with no similar consideration for smaller operators. "Nobody's keeping out the giant boys if they really want to be here," he said.

HEADLINE: Telecommunications Talks Postponed as the U.S. Balks

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
A 53-nation negotiation in Geneva on opening telecommunications markets to international competition was saved from collapse yesterday by moving the deadline to next year. Last-minute objections by the United States had threatened to scuttle the effort to liberalize the $500 billion global market in telecommunications.
Although participants avoided an outright breakdown of the talks, the result represented another setback for the fledgling World Trade Organization, which oversees international commerce. 
 Last year, the group failed to win American backing for a deal freeing trade in banking and other financial services, and its efforts to free maritime transport are also in difficulty.
American negotiators in Geneva complained that the offers that other countries had made in telecommunications did not represent "the critical mass" needed, meaning that the market access offered was not sufficient to make it worthwhile for the United States to further open its own telecommunications market to foreign competition.
Last weekend, Washington withdrew international services and satellite communications from its offer of completely free access to the American market. That decision covered the handling of international traffic in and out of the United States, including planned international satellite phone linkups.
The Europeans said that election-year protectionism was the real villain. "I regret and deplore the fact that the U.S. has reached this conclusion," Europe's chief trade negotiator, Sir Leon Brittan, said. "I respect and understand that the requirements of domestic politics can make it very difficult to conclude an agreement in a pre-election year. But the multilateral system loses out as a result."
In a statement issued in Washington, the acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said: "Over 40 percent of world telecom revenues and over 34 percent of global international traffic are not covered by acceptable offers. We will not enter an agreement on these terms.
"While 10 countries, including Austria, Germany, New Zealand, Britain and Sweden, have made offers acceptable to the United States, a further 36 national offers -- including those of Australia, Belgium, Mexico, Thailand and Venezuela -- need improvement before the U.S. can make a deal."
Four countries, including Indonesia and South Africa, have made no offers.
Negotiators now have until Feb. 15 to conclude a deal. By then, the United States will have conducted a Presidential election and protectionist pressures in Congress may be more muted, proponents of the deal said.
"I see a strong will to save what has been accomplished up to now," Renato Ruggiero, the trade organization's Director General, said. "What is also important is that there is a strong will to save the implementation date," referring to the Jan. 1, 1998, deadline for all members to open their telecommunications markets to foreign competition.
But the talks have already been under way for two years. A failure would cast a major question mark on the organization's usefulness as a trade-liberalizing body, many officials said.
Last summer, the United States walked away from a parallel agreement on freeing trade in banking, insurance and other financial services, saying that other countries were not offering enough access to their markets. Instead, the United States said it would negotiate directly with individual countries to obtain liberalization deals to give its industry better access. So far, no such deals have been concluded.
Talks on freeing trade in maritime transport are in difficulty, too, as a June 30 deadline for agreement approaches. The Clinton Administration is reluctant to repeal legislation requiring that American ships move goods between American ports.
It is against this background, diplomats said, that Mr. Ruggiero has been pressing behind the scenes for a meeting of heads of government on trade next year to mark the 50th anniversary of the General Agreements on Tariffs and Trade, which preceded the World Trade Organization. The idea would be to inject some political momentum into the effort toward freer world trade.
Until Saturday, the omens for a deal in the global telecommunications industry had been looking reasonably encouraging. A meeting a little more than a week ago in Kobe, Japan, of four of the world's economic powers -- the United States, Canada, Japan and the 15-nation European Union -- ended on an upbeat note, with Ms. Barshefsky reporting "very important progress."
And yesterday, Sir Leon said the Europeans had been ready to make an improvement in their offer and sign a global deal.
But on Saturday, the United States put the negotiations into crisis by abruptly withdrawing its offer of completely free access to the American market in international services and satellite communications, complaining that other countries were not offering adequate reciprocity. Foreign companies would get access only if their home markets offered "equivalent competitive opportunities."
The European Union replied that an accord that excluded international services was unacceptable. And a senior Japanese trade negotiator said the United States position was "irresponsible, counterproductive, even threatening."
Under the most-favored-nation principle, which lies at the heart of the new system created around the World Trade Organization, countries must extend the same access they give one partner to all their trading partners.
The explanation for the American change of heart appears to lie in Congressional lobbying by companies like Motorola, with an interest in low-orbiting satellite telephone services. They are seeking protection against such foreign rivals as the London-based ICO Global Communications, in which Hughes Electronics of the United States, a unit of General Motors, is a shareholder and which Comsat of the United States wants to join.
Last week, four key Senators, including the majority whip, Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, and Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, wrote to President Clinton, demanding firmness in the Geneva talks.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Heartland Geopolitics

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
For the past few years Congress has been cutting the foreign aid budget, refusing to pay U.N. dues and closing embassies and consulates (almost 40 out of 275 posts since 1992) on the knee-jerk assumption that this was what the public wanted at the end of the cold war. There is this view in Congress that out there in the "real" America, people don't care about foreign policy and certainly don't want to pay for it now that the Soviets are gone. I beg to differ. What you find when you go to the heartland is that many people are keenly interested in foreign policy and open markets and are far more willing to contribute to them than are the know-nothing freshmen Republicans who claim to speak in their names.
Patrick Buchanan undoubtedly touched a chord with his arguments about job insecurity, but the fact is, Mr. Buchanan's isolationist-protectionist foreign policy prescriptions were utterly repudiated by Republican primary voters throughout the mid-American farm belt, where Bob Dole trounced him. I asked Minnesota's Republican Governor, Arne Carlson, for an explanation. 
 "You listen to [Lamar] Alexander and he complains that he never got his message out," says Mr. Carlson. "The problem with Buchanan is that he did get his message out, and there was a very quiet 'no' vote. Dole swept North Dakota, South Dakota and Minnesota. What you had here was a quiet understanding on the part of farmers that they benefited from Nafta. They want open, competitive relationships on the world market and while there might be some dissatisfaction with the question of equity, they were not willing to buy into the closed-door theory of Buchanan." It wasn't only farmers. Minnesota last year had $8.8 billion in exports. And with such companies as Honeywell, 3M and General Mills dominating the Twin Cities skyline, "you're not going to get anyone connected with the corporate structure who is going to be isolationist or anti-Nafta," said Governor Carlson.
"We as a state," he said, "rely very heavily on these consulates abroad. It means a lot when local business leaders are invited to the U.S. ambassador's home and can mingle with Minnesotans selling the Minnesota message. [The consulates] have the economic experts who can tell us when we are right and tell us when we are wrong. They set up the meetings. For Congress just to come and say 'no dice' is penny-wise and several pounds foolish. . . . They're going to regret it."
This isn't just about commercial diplomacy, argues Mr. Carlson. "The other piece is that we have to decide our moral obligations. Some of these minor conflicts have the potential for universal destruction. What are we going to do as a society in terms of third-world countries? If we don't learn to build bridges, to encourage investment and to encourage solutions we are going to seriously hurt ourselves. Look, as a state, we are in the prison-building business. But we are saying to the state, 'Well, you better also be in the prevention business because the prison business is very expensive.' Well, the war business is very expensive. It's a lot cheaper to build bridges."
Of course it makes sense to adapt, and even streamline, America's foreign policy apparatus in the wake of the cold war's end. But that doesn't necessarily mean shrinking it across the board. Japan, for instance, is increasing embassies and consulates around the world.
The neoconservative thinker Joshua Muravchik is just out with a book titled "The Imperative of American Leadership," which notes that polls consistently show that Americans think we spend 15 percent of the budget on foreign aid, and they think we should only be spending 5 percent -- when in fact we spend less than 1 percent. But instead of making that point, he argues, too many national politicians look to score cheap victories by accusing their opponents of a giveaway if they vote for a dime of foreign policy money. Foreign policy, argues Mr. Muravchik, "requires leadership from people who have traveled the world and understand our interests and responsibilities out there." Unfortunately, too many of those who should be leading on this issue have either abdicated or taken the easy way out by following the freshmen Republican herd. They are taking us over a cliff, and any governor from a supposedly hick, small Midwestern state can tell you that.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Designates China As Worst Copyright Violator
Washington designated China as the worst violator of agreements intended to combat the piracy of American videocassettes, compact disks, computer software and other products, a step that seemed to lay the groundwork for sanctions against Beijing.
Despite American business protests, the Administration has been considering placing sanctions on $2 billion of Chinese exports to the United States. [Page D4.]
 
Global Effort to Open Telecommunications Market Falters
Efforts by 53 nations to open their telecommunications markets to international competition nearly collapsed over last-minute American objections. The participants extended the deadline to early next year. American negotiators complained that the offers of other countries were not sufficient for a successful outcome. [D4.]
 
Rush to Repeal Gas Tax
Republicans rushed to repeal a 1993 tax on gasoline, of 4.3 cents a gallon, blaming the Administration for higher pump prices. Oil prices fell in futures markets in response to President Clinton's decision to tap the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. [A16.]
 
Beef producers were offered Government help from the economic blow caused by a spring drought and slumping cattle prices. [A16.]
 
Cable Channels to Multiply
The cable industry offered proof that it would start expanding the television dial. General Instrument said it would ship the first digital set-top boxes to cable operators in October. [D8.]
 
Pepsico Earnings Soar 23%
Pepsico earnings jumped 23 percent in the first quarter, benefiting from strong first-quarter growth in the snack-food, soft-drink and restaurant businesses. [D2.]
 
Dow Down; Nasdaq at Another High
The Dow Jones industrials rebounded from a moderate loss to end down 4.33, at 5,569.08. But the Nasdaq hit another record. [D8.]
 
Mesa Shareholders Protest
Dissident shareholders of Mesa accused the board of inflicting a nearly $150 million penalty on stockholders in order to sell control to the investor Richard Rainwater. [D2.]
 
Rockwell to Sell Printing-Press Unit
Rockwell agreed to sell its printing-press business to a group led by Stonington Partners for $600 million, to concentrate on electronics, aerospace and auto parts. [D19.]
 
China to Cut Interest Rates
China's central bank said it would cut interest rates for the first time since 1993, signaling its substantial success in bringing inflation under control while maintaining robust growth. [D5.]
 
Accountants and S.E.C. to Meet
The Financial Accounting Foundation plans to meet soon with the S.E.C. to resolve a heated debate over who should determine the nation's accounting rules. [D5.]
 
New Buyback at I.B.M.
I.B.M. announced plans to buy back $2.5 billion of its stock. In the last 15 months, it has bought back about $6.5 billion of its shares. [D8.]
 
A Promotion Aimed at Women
An ambitious program is under way at Chevrolet, Macy's East and Conde Nast magazines, in an effort to market to women. The centerpiece of the program is an eight-page booklet inserted in 750,000 copies of the June issues of Glamour, Mademoiselle and Vogue magazines. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
Breaks for City's New Industries
New York City is offering tax breaks and other inducements to further encourage enterprises like computer software and video production that have sprung up in recent years. [B1.]

LENGTH: 1349 words

HEADLINE: Who Trains Trainers? Everyone and No One

BYLINE: By NANCY STEDMAN 

 BODY:
ALIX REDMONDE, who teaches aerobics classes in Manhattan, is still haunted by a session with the personal trainer she hired five pears ago while preparing for an aerobics competition. One day the trainer, a substitute for Ms. Redmonde's vacationing coach, pushed her left leg too far into a stretch. "I felt my hamstring go off kilter," she recalled.
Ms. Redmonde, 36, believes she has never properly recovered from the injury. "I can kick my right leg really high, but my left leg can only reach four inches lower," she said. 
 As the number of personal trainers grows -- one f'tness association, the American Council on Exercise, has seen its active-trainer roster rise from 2,200 in 1990 to 15,423 in 1995 -- so do questions about their qualifications. Trainers are not required to be licensed in New York and virtually all other states, and what's more, they need not fulfill specific education requirements.
"Legally, all it takes to become an $80-an-hour personal trainer is a client willing to pay $80," said Jonathan Bowden, the head of the trainer certification program at the Equinox Fitness Training Institute in New York, part of the Equinox Fitness Clubs. For clients, this means that unless they are sure about their trainer's background, the person they hire may do their bodies more harm than good. Even experienced exercisers have been injured by inadequately trained trainers.
In place of gopernment licensing, dozens of national and local organizations -- at least 100 by one reliable estimate -- have arisen that give certification tests to personal trainers. The tests, which show a minimum level of competence, vary markedly in difficulty.
All have a written portion; a few require that the trainer physically demonstrate that he or she can help an exerciser use strength-training equipment. Almost all organizations also require the trainer to hold a valid certificate in cardiopulmonary resuscitation before taking the test.
There are no figures on the percentage of person'l trainers in the country who are certified. In New York City, the larger health clubs require their trainers to be certified, but independent trainers are less likely have certificates, said Brian Moss, a trainer and the owner of the Better Bod'es Cross-Training Center in Chelsea.
From the client's point of view, certification may be a less valid indicator of a trainer's competence than where and how he or she was educated. The first generation of trainers -- men and women who are now in their 30's and 40's -- were informally trained by mentors at their gyms. But younger trainers, usually recent college graduates or people making a career change, often undergo at least a little formal education before taking a certification test.
Education, too, varies widely. At the top is the four-year program pioneered by the University of Texas at Austin; next are a handful of two-year programs provided by a few schools, like the University of Californ'a at Hayward. New York City has two well-regarded, though short, programs. Equinox offers a six-day course, and Marymount Manhattan College has a 12-night program.
Most trainers pass certification examinations by using home-study materials provided by the testing organizations or, more often, by attending the organizations' weekend-long cram courses.
Amity Hall combined hands-on experience with formal education. Ms. Hall, 24, started exercising as a young child; three months ago she became a personal trainer at Bio Design Complete Fitness on East 24th Street. She came to New York last year with a degree in psychology and an urge to star in musical theater. Last November, she went to Rochester to learn how to be a one-on-one trainer in a five!day course run by the nonprofit Cooper Institute for Aerobics Research in Dallas.
Ms. Hall studied exercise physiology, nutrition and coronary risks. She learned how to test the fitness level of a client, how to create an exercise plan based on the individual's goals, how to lead a person through strength training and how to motivate a reluctant exerciser.
On the final day, she was given the certification test: she answered 100 mulpiple-choice questions, wrote up an exercise plan and completed a health assessment by measuring a fellow student's percentage of body fat, blood pressure and heart rate. After passing the test, she was deemed a "physical fitness specialist," what the Cooper Institute calls the personal trainers it certifies.
Ms. Hall now leads new members of Bio Design through orientation sessions on the exercise equipment. She also trains clients privately. But it is unlikely that any client will ever ask her to produce her certificate.
Mr. Bowden of Equinox said that he has never heard of a potential client who has inquired about certification. "You go on someone's recommendation," he said.
In health clubs, many people choose their favorite aerobics teacher as their trainer; some rely on looks. That's dangerous, experts say. "A trainer needs to know the bio mechanics of each joint," said Chris Fey, the director of the two-year fitness certificate program at the University of California at Hayward. "Shoulders are a big problem area. You are more likely to get hurt by mistakes done over and over again than by sudden trauma."
Sometimes these injuries end up in court. David Herbert, a Canton, Ohio, lawyer who specializes in liability cases, has catalogued hundreds of cases against health clubs and their personnel in the last 11 years. "These are mostly people injured on exercise machines or put into a program inappropriate to their fitness level," he said.
Some fitness experts believe certification is not enough to prove competence. "I see a lot of people with degrees in economics take a certifying exam and become a trainer," said Dixie Stan'orth, who teaches in the personal-trainer program at the University of Texas at Austin. "I would like to see the tests be more discriminating."
Much responsibility for assuring competence falls to health clubs. Debbie LaChusa, a vice president of the American Council on Exercise, one of the largest testing organizations, said, "The clubs, when they hire, have a responsibility to audition the trainers."
There is also a movement to make the tests more difficult. This month, the American College of Sports Medicine began testing for what it is calling "advanced personal trainer" certification, which involves extensive knowledge of sports-training psychology and techniques.
And some people, mostly professors, think that state licensing is the way to insure competence. Dr. Willibald Nagler, the chairman of the department of rehabilitation medicine at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, said, "Personal trainers can overstep their level of expertise and perform movements that a physical therapist should do."
But most organizations that certify trainers are opposed to licensing. So is Mr. Herbert, the lawyer, who said, "For all the people who engage in exercise at a health club, and for all the hours spent doing it, there are very few instances of people suffering untoward events."
Still, Ms. Fey of the University of California said, "Once you've gotten hurt, ydu may never be the same."
 
Brain First, Then Brawn
 
CHOOSING the right trainer calls for legwork and instinct.
"First, find out what the trainer's education is and what certifications he or she holds," said Jonathan Bowden, the head of the trainer certification program at the Equinox Fitness Training Institute in New York.
Also, ask about the trainer's experience and references. Typically, the more experienced the trainer, the higher the fee, said Chris Fey, who directs the fitness certificate program at the University of California at Hayward.
Then there are qualities that cannot be quantified. When you interview a potential trainer, you should see if you are "connecting or not," Mr. Bowden said. He added: "How do you know on a blind date if you want to see someone again? You want to feel that the trainer is on your side. You have to trust your intuition."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 2, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Living Section yesterday about the training of personal trainers described a course at Marymount Manhattan College incompletely. The college's 12-day personal trainer program is an advanced course that must be preceded by a yearlong certification program for basic fitness instructors.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Triage With an Eye on Society's Costs

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
At one point in tomorrow night's thoughtful documentary on PBS, George Strait makes a telling observation about television's treatment of medical matters. The subject is the birth of a very premature baby, about 24 weeks old. Mr. Strait, a medical reporter for ABC News, confesses that if he had been covering this story on his usual beat, the birth would have been celebrated as a miracle and left at that.
He would never have gone back to tell what sort of life the miracle baby faced, whether, as too likely, he turned out to be mentally retarded, blind, deaf or otherwise severely handicapped. And the reporter would also have ignored the cost to society of delivering this baby, with the odds so heavily against any sort of normal life, and of paying the millions of dollars for his medical needs should he survive. 
 It is the attention to costs and to odds that makes "Who Plays God?" so welcome at a time when America's health care is in the throes of a revolution that is battering customary expectations. But these two hours are far from merely calculating; recognition of the constraints on helping everyone who needs help makes the case histories here all the more moving:
*Two men await lung transplants; otherwise they will die. "Every day after a transplant is a gift," one says. But it is a very expensive gift; organs are scarce, operations costly, consequences uncertain. We are made privy to what goes into their decision to seek a transplant and into a hospital's decision to grant or deny one.
*Two women have terminal cancer. We hear them and their families weighing the high price in money and in strain of keeping them alive for another year or two, probably in a steadily deteriorating and demanding condition. The program asks whether a family's natural desire to cling to a loved one is a good enough reason for expending tens of thousands of dollars that might be used to help others with better prospects. A Blue Cross official points out, "Money is a scarce resource."
*The mother of that premature baby says, "I intend to give my miracle baby every chance." But she is not the one paying for it. Medicaid pays for the delivery (which cost $70,000), with the prospect of paying, too, for a lifetime of care, no matter what the quality of the child's life. Should that be the mother's decision? A doctor says, "You're almost trapped by technology."
*In rural Kentucky, a poor working family (not poor enough to qualify for Medicaid) struggles to obtain an emergency operation for their son. "My time is not free," says the family doctor who has turned them away, and the mother is forced to make a public appeal. In Washington, a hospital devoted to serving the poor is spending so much money on victims of shootings that it is forced to cut back on ordinary medical care and preventive medicine.
*A man who is dying of AIDS seeks assistance in ending his life when existence becomes unendurable and finds it is not easy to obtain.
Each of the program's five segments is followed by a brief panel discussion, in which Mr. Strait is joined by a health-care economist and two specialists in medical ethics. Although their comments tend to be a bit fuzzy and familiar, the tough realities and hard choices come through.
Could the enormous sums spent on sustaining the dying be better spent on improving the health of new mothers? Who is to decide the point at which medical care becomes futile and wasteful? Should society countenance assisted suicides? Should sick people have to wait in an emergency room for hours while losers in shootouts receive instant and costly surgery? Should the possibility of a transplant depend on how much health insurance a person has?
The issues are profound, but on one point the panelists agree. If the nation is to try to give at least basic health protection to everyone, some sort of rationing of resources is essential. The choices will not be made easier by television's habit of stirring sympathy for sad cases without regard to the price of care. And that makes this program especially welcome.
 
WHO PLAYS GOD?
 
Medicine, Money and Ethics in American Health Care
PBS, Friday at 9 P.M.
(Channel 13 in New York)
 
Larry Klein, executive producer; Jeff Bieber and Sharon Ferguson, producers; David McGowan, executive-in-charge. A production of WETA/Washington. Uwe E. Reinhardt, Ph.D., Joanne Lynn, M.D. and Glenn McGee, Ph.D., panelists; George Strait, host and moderator.
