HEADLINE: Essay;
The Biggest Election

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In 1975, when Indira Gandhi assumed dictatorial control of India and threw her opponents in jail, President Ford asked his U.N. delegate, Daniel P. Moynihan, what to make of that.
"Look at it this way, Mr. President," said Moynihan with a courtier's irony. "Under your Administration, the United States has become the world's largest democracy."
When Mrs. Gandhi later confidently stood for election, India's voters threw her out. Freedom was back, and the U.S. happily became the world's second-largest democracy.
This week, with dignity, honest balloting and relatively little violence, 400 million of India's citizens -- 65 percent of eligible voters, higher than here -- go to the polls to select candidates from 500 political parties. It is the most breathtaking example of government by the people in the history of the world.
Americans don't hear a whole lot about it. President Clinton is busy being campaign manager for the Labor party in Israel's May 29 election, in effect telling Israelis to vote for Shimon Peres or else.
When he is not intervening shamelessly in Israel's political affairs, Mr. Clinton is barnstorming with Boris Yeltsin, trying to help him defeat Yavlinsky's reformers and Zyuganov's Communists in Russia's June 16 election. Washington is also headquarters for the Clinton campaign for the U.S. Presidency, where he beefs up beef prices to consumers while pouring strategic oil on troubled motorists. But in all the campaigning, no mention is made of India, where voters outnumber those in Israel, Russia and the U.S. combined.
As a result of this uncharacteristic White House forbearance, television coverage here about the biggest election has been next to nil. Not only do Americans not know for which Indian candidate to root, but hundreds of millions of voters are forced to go to the polls ignorant of Mr. Clinton's preference.
Why? Do nearly 900 million Indians not matter? American lack of interest is not new; a former Foreign Minister of India, one of Nehru's acolytes, told a U.S. envoy: "We would far prefer your detestation to your indifference."
One reason is that India strikes a holier-than-thou diplomatic pose, remaining nonaligned when there is no longer one side to be nonaligned against. Year after year, India is near the top of the list of nations that consistently vote against the U.S. in the United Nations.
We're wrong to let that overly irritate us. China votes against us, too, and unbalances our trade and secretly ships missiles to rogue states and jails dissidents and oppresses Tibet and threatens Taiwan and (cover the children's eyes) pirates our CD's -- but we care more about what happens in China than what happens in India.
That's a mistake. Contrary to what all the new Old China Hands and other Old Nixon Hands tell you, India will draw ahead of China as a superpower in the next century.
Yes, China's economic growth rate has doubled India's, and China's Draconian control of births will see India's population exceed China's soon enough, to India's disadvantage. But China does not know what an election is. Despite the enterprise and industriousness of its people, despite the example of free Chinese on Taiwan and the inspiration of the dissident Wei Jingsheng, jailed in Beijing, China is several upheavals and decades away from the democracy India already enjoys.
Without political freedom, capitalism cannot long thrive. Already the requirements of political repression are stultifying the flow of market information in China, driving wary Hong Kong executives to Sydney. The suppression of dangerous data undermined technology in Communist Russia; it will hurt China, too.
Though more Chinese are literate, many more Indians are English-literate (more English-speakers than in Britain), and English is the global language of the computer. American software companies are already locating in Bangalore, India's Silicon Valley. Bureaucratic corruption scandals abound; India's free press reports and helps cleanse them, China's does not.
I'm rooting for Rao, the secular Prime Minister, who is more likely to move toward free markets than Vajpayee, his leading opponent. But whoever wins, it's a glorious week for the world's largest democracy.

HEADLINE: Kuala Lumpur Journal;
Malaysia Looks Down on World From 1,483 Feet

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

 BODY:
In the afternoons, their twin pinnacles are lost in the monsoon rain clouds. At night they twinkle like parallel columns of stars. Malaysia officially became home recently not only to the tallest but even to the two tallest buildings in the world, the side-by-side Petronas Towers.
For the first time in more than a century, the United States is not home to the world's tallest building. Perhaps it had to happen. And where else should the title go but to Asia, where national economies are growing faster than anywhere else in the world? 
 Chicago was left pointing desperately to the television antennas atop the 22-year-old Sears Tower, which would still make it taller than the Petronas Towers, but in vain. The Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat, the international arbiter of the world's skyscrapers, voted on April 13 that television antennas are irrelevant, and awarded the title of world's tallest to Petronas, by 33 feet.
It was a heady achievement for Malaysia, which yearns to become a player on the international scene, and the symbolism is apt. Perhaps no nation is remaking itself physically with more ambition than this one.
Dr. Lynn Beedle, director of the Council on Tall Buildings, declined to call this a sad moment for America. "No, no, no," he said. "There are still many great things about American buildings. Oh, many, many great things."
The Petronas Towers, the 1,483-foot-tall, 88-story home to Malaysia's national oil company, have risen on the site of the now-demolished Selangor Turf Club, a last vestige of the British colonial heritage that has been methodically erased since independence 39 years ago.
"I call this the shaking away of the colonial mantle," said Ken Yeang, a leading local architect who is a member of the Council on Tall Buildings. "You rediscover your identity and self-confidence."
Tall as they are, the $1.2 billion towers will be dwarfed in scope, if not height, by other building projects here, including an entirely new $8 billion capital city to be called Putrajaya, a $3.6 billion international airport and one of the world's biggest hydroelectric dams, the $8 billion Bakun dam in Sarawak, which will create a lake the size of the entire island nation of Singapore.
Only recently a poor country whose economy rested on exports of rubber and tin, Malaysia seems eager to develop the kind of urban mass that now horrifies many people in the developed world.
"One day, Kuala Lumpur, Putrajaya and our new airport will become one mega-city that can be compared to centers like Tokyo-Yokahama," said Prime Minister Mahathir Mohammad, the driving force behind his nation's development.
His goal is to turn Malaysia into a fully developed nation by the year 2020, and with an annual growth rate of 8 percent or more, it is well on its way. Construction projects that total $73 billion are on the books, including cities, ports, highways and mass transit systems.
The Petronas Towers were topped off in February, and tenants are scheduled to begin moving in by the end of this year.
This heady growth has its critics.
"We are on a building binge, and I think one can question the need for all these big mega-projects," said Gurmit Singh, a leading environmentalist. "They come out with these projects and then they try to justify them. They build this big building first, and then they try to fill it up."
But supporters say the symbolism itself is worth the cost of construction. "The twin towers are a symbol of Asia's dynamism and growth," said Razak Baginda, executive director of the Malaysian Strategic Research Center. "These towers will do wonders for Asia's self-esteem and confidence, which I think is very important, and which I think at this moment are at the point of takeoff."
He added, "This is not in any way to suggest that we are taller or better than the West, but it does have to do with that competition of growth."
People here may be careful not to gloat, but Chicago has been left only with consolation prizes: the Council on Tall Buildings, based in Bethlehem, Pa., says the Sears Tower is still the "world's biggest tall building," with 4.5 million square feet of space, and calls it home to the world's highest occupiable floor and world's highest elevator ride.
The highest occupiable floors in the Petronas Towers are 150 feet below that of the Sears Tower. But the Petronas Towers are crowned with 242-foot spires that the Council on Tall Buildings ruled are integral to their architecture in a way that Sears's television antennas are not.
Noelle Gaffney, the spokeswoman for Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago, stood by her town. "While there still is a dispute over what qualifies as the tallest building in the world," she said, "there is no disputing the fact that Chicago would still have the highest observation deck in the world."
There is still more symbolism in this drive to be big. The "American century," as measured by the world's tallest buildings, might be calculated at 111 years, since the completion of the first skyscraper, the 180-foot Home Insurance Building in Chicago, in 1885. Malaysia's moment will be more fleeting.
Even as architects in the West are favoring low-rise, decentralized construction in the new era of telecommunications, ever-taller skyscrapers are rising all around Asia -- in Singapore, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and China.
Malaysia is expected to lose its title before the decade is over, when the 1,509-foot World Financial Center is completed in Shanghai -- 259 feet taller than the Empire State Building, 59 feet taller than the Sears Tower and 26 feet taller than the Petronas Towers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With completion of the side-by-side Petronas Towers, Kuala Lumpur has offically become home to the two tallest buildings in the world. (David Portnoy for The New York Times)

Both structures will be eclipsed by the World Financial Center in Shanghai in a few years.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Increase for 2d Month

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
An index of future economic activity rose two-tenths of a percent in March, following a rise in February. The consecutive monthly gains are the first in more than a year and suggest that the economy may continue to strengthen.
The index of leading economic indicators for March, issued yesterday by the Conference Board, a business research group in New York, also represented the index's highest level in a year. It follows an increase of 1.3 percent in February and a revised drop of six-tenths of a percent in January. 
 Other signs of strength came from a purchasing executives' survey showing that manufacturing improved in April for the first time in nine months and a Government report that construction spending shot up in March.
The leading index is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance. The last time the index rose two consecutive months was November and December 1994. Economists see the index as a true indication of the economy's direction when it moves in the same direction for three straight months.
"There's an unmistakable message here that the economy is firming and economic growth in the two middle quarters of this year is going to be a lot stronger than many people want to believe," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
The report that had the biggest impact, at least on Wall Street, was the manufacturing index of the National Association of Purchasing Management. It improved to 50.1 percent in April from 46.9 percent in March, the first time since July 1995 it has risen above 50 percent.
The result was seen as encouraging, but not stellar. Readings above 50 percent represent expansion in manufacturing.
"What the data did indicate was continued slow growth in the manufacturing sector, some pickup, but not the pickup that had been feared," said Marilyn Schaja, money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Inflation concerns were eased, however, by the purchasers' report, which showed a decline in prices paid by manufacturers for raw materials.
In another report, the Commerce Department said that construction spending rose 3.1 percent in March, the biggest gain in four years. Residential, nonresidential and public outlays all posted sharp gains. The department said spending totaled a seasonally adjusted $548.4 billion annual rate, a record, up from $532.1 billion in February. It was the largest advance since a 3.5 percent surge in March 1992. The increase, the third in four months, was much larger than the gain of five-tenths of a percent that many analysts had expected.
The March gain in the index for leading indictors, which fell in line with Wall Street expectations of an advance of three-tenths of a percent, came amid recent signs that the economy was strengthening. For example, the Conference Board reported on Tuesday that consumer confidence surged in April. Worries over the ability to find jobs dropped to a six-year low, the research group found in that survey.
The leading index's March improvement also represented a validation of the prior month's gain, which was skewed by a big jump in the component measuring the factory workweek. The workweek was much longer than in January, when many people were kept home by winter storms.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Show Little Change On Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended little changed yesterday, retreating from early gains after the Treasury said it would sell some notes and bonds more often.
Bonds rose early in the session after a survey showed that prices paid by manufacturers rose less than expected. The report prompted a wave of short-covering as investors who had bet that bond prices would fall bought securities to limit their losses. In a short sale, an investor sells a borrowed security hoping to buy it back at a lower price, and thus profit from the difference. 
 But the announcement by the Treasury on the size of its auctions next week and its changes in the frequency of auctions heightened concerns about the market's ability to digest new supply, and prices fell back to their lows for the session.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond settled unchanged at 8819/32 , leaving its yield at 6.91 percent.
Volume for the day was average as many buyers remained on the sidelines waiting for tomorrow's employment report for April.
Market participants were encouraged in early trading by the prices-paid components of the the National Association of Purchasing Management's manufacturing index for April. The prices-paid component rose to 40.1 in April from 39.5 in March, but it was less than the 46 that had been expected, suggesting prices paid by manufacturers were rising more slowly than previously thought.
The association's manufacturing index rose to 50.1, compared with 46.9 in March, and in line with market expectations.
Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch & Company, said the purchasing managers' survey, along with two other reports yesterday -- on construction spending and on leading economic indicators -- showed that the United States economy remained on a modest growth path, with no evidence of a pickup in inflation pressures.
"So far, the industrial sector shows only faint signs of a pickup," he said, noting that the largest contributors to the rise in the purchasing managers' index came from production and inventory -- gains that might have been exaggerated by the end of a strike at General Motors.
Worries about new supply were rekindled by the Treasury's announcement that it would sell 10-year notes six times a year instead of four and would sell 30-year bonds three times a year instead of twice. The Treasury, however, did say that it might reduce the size of the auctions.
Still, the Treasury said that it would increase the size of an auction of three-year notes to $19 billion from $18.5 billion at the previous auction of the notes. The Government is also selling $14 billion of 10-year notes, the same amount as the previous auction, and $13 billion of cash management bills next week.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the 3-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.19 percent, and the 10-year note at a price to yield 6.69 percent.
In futures trading, Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research of Boston, said it was a very choppy market. "It's still making up its mind whether to sniff out a monthly low price at 1088/32 on the June bond contract and then rally to 113, or to dig deeper to perhaps as low as 104."
The June 30-year bond contract closed at 1094/32 .
In the municipal market, New Jersey's $820 million general obligation bond issue was the largest deal of the day.
The state sold $550 million in refunding bonds through Merrill Lynch at prices to yield from 4.1 percent for an issue due in 1998 to 5.4 percent in 2010, and $270 million in bonds representing new money through underwriters led by Prudential Securities. The bonds were priced to yield from 3.9 percent in 1997 to 5.5 percent in 2010.
Both series are rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA+ by Standard & Poor's. Dealers note that because New Jersey seldom borrows, the demand for its debt securities is always strong. The last time the state borrowed was in 1994.

HEADLINE: U.S. Hearing to Decide Rights of Women Who Flee Genital Mutilation

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
In a band of countries spanning Africa's midsection, more than 85 million women and girls have undergone genital mutilation and two million more are subjected to it each year, health experts estimate.
Halfway around the world, at the headquarters of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington, Clinton Administration officials have been trying to choose which of them, if any, should be given asylum here. 
 In a small courtroom in Falls Church, Va., today, the immigration service's general counsel, David A. Martin, aware of the large numbers, will try to convince the Board of Immigration Appeals that the dangerous rite should be grounds for granting asylum only in narrowly defined circumstances. He plans to argue that women who have already undergone it as children or who would be ostracized if they refused it would not qualify.
The issue of whether to grant asylum because of genital mutilation is before the board, the highest administrative tribunal hearing immigration cases, for the first time, in the case of Fauziya Kasinga, a 19-year-old who says she fled Togo to escape having a tribal elder "scrape my woman parts off."
Last August, an immigration judge denied her asylum and she appealed. She was detained for more than a year in a New Jersey detention center and Pennsylvania prisons until immigration authorities released her last week.
Worried that a broad ruling could provoke an unpopular surge of asylum seekers, Mr. Martin is asking the board to establish a framework that would deny asylum in most cases to women who had endured the practice as young girls "at a time when they consented or at least acquiesced." That would disqualify many if not most potential applicants, since the rite is typically performed on girls 4 to 10 years old.
He would also exclude women who face social and economic hardship for refusing to comply. "The home society persecutes if it forcibly subjects uncircumcised women to the knife," he says in his legal brief. "It does not necessarily persecute if it simply subjects such persons to ostracism or economic pressures."
Although Ms. Kasinga says her relatives would force her to undergo the procedure if she were sent back to Togo, the immigration agency's legal brief addresses the issue in general terms and does not argue for or against asylum in her case. Immigration officials say they want the board to set guidelines that a judge could follow in deciding Ms. Kasinga's case.
Advocates for refugees say Mr. Martin's vision would deny protection to many deserving girls and women. If a teen-ager's only choices were to undergo genital mutilation or to be a social outcast forced into a life of prostitution, she should be given asylum, they say.
"Instead of applying the Refugee Act to keep its impact limited, it should be interpreted in a way that fulfills its humanitarian promise," said Ms. Kasinga's lawyer, Karen Musalo, who heads the International Human Rights Clinic at the Washington College of Law, American University. "If that results in a large number of people eligible for relief, the United States should take a leadership position in negotiating with other countries for a form of burden sharing."
Ms. Musalo and other advocates point to the example of Canada, which in 1993 became the first country to make genital mutilation grounds for granting refugee status, and has found that only a small number of women have sought protection on those grounds. "We referred to it here as the floodgates argument," said David Austin, spokesman for the Canadian Immigration and Refugee Board. "It just did not happen."
Ms. Kasinga's case is expected to set a precedent that will strongly influence the handling of other such claims. The ruling of the board, 12 civil servants appointed for indefinite terms by the attorney general, will be binding on all United States immigration officials, including asylum officers and 179 immigration judges.
Typically, in genital mutilation, the clitoris and the labia minora are cut off with unsterilized equipment and without anesthesia. In some cultures, the vulva is also stitched together to cover the vagina.
The custom is observed by Muslims, Christians and followers of traditional religions, primarily in Africa. Studies cited by the World Health Organization have found that the reasons given to defend the practice are that it is thought to discourage a woman's promiscuity, to increase a husband's sexual pleasure and to enhance a woman's fertility and matrimonial prospects.
Ms. Kasinga's case has brought into sharp focus what Mr. Martin, a former University of Virginia law professor, describes as contradictory impulses in American immigration policy: one is to give sanctuary to the world's persecuted and the other is to control the flow of immigrants to this country.
Mr. Martin argues for a balancing of these conflicting goals to avoid a large increase in the number of asylum seekers that could stir a public backlash against refugees generally. "People are legitimately concerned about too expansive a doctrine leading to numbers that are too high in the views of the body politic," he said. The immigration service says it has drawn up its proposal regarding genital mutilation on its own, without consulting the State Department.
A question that looms over this debate is simply this: How many of those who have been subjected to genital mutilation, or who will be, would come here if they could successfully claim asylum?
Only a handful of such women have asked the United States for sanctuary in recent years, and such cases have remained a rarity even since last May, when the Immigration and Naturalization Service issued guidelines that recognized genital mutilation as one of several forms of violence against women that could be a basis for asylum.
Officials in the asylum program say women have been unlikely to request asylum for practical reasons: Usually, genital mutilation occurs when women are too young to escape. Those old enough to flee usually live in patriarchal societies where fathers or husbands control the money needed to buy a ticket on an international flight. Finally, many are ashamed to talk about such an intimate problem with a stranger in a foreign country.
"The sad thing is that women refugees don't have access to the American asylum system," said Phyllis Coven, director of the Office of International Affairs at the immigration service. She added, "It's not going to be a growth industry."
Ms. Kasinga said that women in her tribe are generally mutilated at age 15, but that she had been protected by her wealthy father, who opposed the practice, until he died suddenly when she was 16. A grown sister helped her escape mutilation and a forced polygamous marriage by getting her to an airport in Ghana and putting her on a midnight flight out of Africa, she said.
Faustina Annan, 24, who was granted refugee status in Canada last year, said her parents' first daughter died of a pelvic infection after being subjected to the ritual. Ms. Annan said her parents fled to a different part of Ghana and changed their names at the time of her birth to save her from the same fate.
As a young woman, she said, she rejected the marriage proposal of a police inspector's son. He and his friends later kidnapped her, raped her, discovered she had not been "circumcised" and said they were bringing in someone to do it. She said she managed to get away and fled to Canada with the help of her priest.
Khadra Hassan Farah and her 10-year-old daughter, of Somalia, were granted sanctuary in Canada in 1994. The mother said she would be unable to prevent her daughter from undergoing genital mutilation if they were sent home -- the kind of mutilation she suffered as an 8-year-old.
The mother said her own mother, aunts and other women had tied her arms behind her back, grabbed her legs and spread them apart, while one of the women took out a knife. The panel that heard Ms. Farah's claim quoted her written statement at length in their decision:
"She was holding the blade in her hand when she disappeared between my legs. She inserted her finger into my inside to search for my clitoris. She got a good grip of my clitoris and started to pull it out, and I felt the pain and started to scream. She cut off my clitoris with the blade and I screamed more and more. This did not deter her nor did it make her to stop cutting my body any further. She continued slicing away my labia minora, at which point I lost consciousness."
In immigration law, persecution generally means the punishment of a person because of race, religion, nationality, political opinions or membership in a social group.
But with genital mutilation, the society's intent is not to punish, but to follow a custom. Nonetheless, Mr. Martin said in his legal brief, when the custom itself "is so extreme as to shock the conscience of the society from which asylum is sought," it can be considered persecution.
Ms. Kasinga's lawyer, Ms. Musalo, is asking the board itself to grant her client asylum because she faces persecution as a member of a social group, women of her tribe who oppose genital mutilation and have no protection against it.

HEADLINE: Russia's New-Look May Day: Marching Is Out, Politicking Is In

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 1

 BODY:
The Soviet anthem blared through the loudspeakers. And the old Soviet flag was raised high, as the presidential candidate Gennadi A. Zyuganov sought to use Russia's May Day celebration to tap a wellspring of nostalgia for the Communist cause.
But Mr. Zyuganov was not the only candidate who took to the streets today. 
 Just a few blocks away, President Boris N. Yeltsin stood in a cold drizzle to read a speech to a rally of trade unionists, many of whom appeared openly uninterested.
Unlike Mr. Zyuganov, the 65-year-old President appeared without an umbrella or overcoat, an effort to demonstrate his vigor or to compensate for his aides' failure to anticipate the inclement weather.
Mr. Yeltsin also danced a slow jig with a Russian folk dancer. Displaying a touch of humor, he also tried to buy a doll of his political ally, Mayor Yuri Luzhkov of Moscow, only to learn that only traditional, nonpolitical dolls were available.
May Day in Russia has long been a time for marches and stolid patriotic themes. But with presidential elections set for June 16, today's holiday became a duel of rival political rallies and photo-ops.
With rampant rumors of Chechen terrorism, agitation by unspecified "provocateurs" and vivid memories of a 1993 clash between Communist demonstrators and the police, presidential aides took extensive precautions against disorder.
The Interior Ministry police seemed to be omnipresent. Police sharpshooters took up positions on the rooftops of nearby buildings before Mr. Yeltsin spoke.
But most of the city appeared to take advantage of the day off to relax, not engage in noisy marches. And today's demonstrations were largely without incident, which is not to say they were entirely without rancor.
Standing in front of a statue of Karl Marx, Viktor Anpilov, the leader of the Labor Russia movement, sought to whip up the crowd before Mr. Zyuganov's speech.
Shouting into the microphone, he vowed that the Communists would fight on "regardless of the election results."
Mr. Zyuganov warned the voters of dark plots by Mr. Yeltsin to steal the election, even as he engaged in friendly waves to the faithful.
Some in the crowd displayed hand-painted signs blaming Jews for Russia's financial problems. One placard warned that the creation of the stock market was a Jewish plot to "enslave" Russia. Anti-American themes were also common.
As the rally drew to a close, Mr. Zyuganov's aides asserted that their rally had drawn 200,000 to 400,000 supporters. But an Interior Ministry official said the crowed numbered no more than 10,000 and was probably thousands less.
Viktor M. Mudretsov, a 59-year-old veteran, typified much of the audience, which longed for a return to the security of a state-dominated economy. "I was brought up by Soviet power," he said. "It gave me my education and my apartment."
Mr. Mudretsov said private ownership should be allowed, but only within certain limits. Major communication, transportation and military-industrial enterprises, he said, should be owned by the state. Financial "speculation" should also be forbidden.
The posters honoring Stalin's memory was too much, however, for some in the crowd to bear. "So many people died because of him," said Tatyana, a pensioner, who declined to give her last name.
But she was angrily shouted down by a self-proclaimed group of Stalinists.
"Even if Zyuganov wins, nobody can do anything for us," she said quietly as she walked away. "I do not see anyone now who is worth the throne."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Republicans Choose Charity-Care Plan

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 1

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Republican legislative leaders agreed today on a new two-year plan to pay for hospital care for the uninsured. The plan would continue to rely on payroll taxes paid by employers and seek to move the state's uninsured into a managed care program.
But the plan, intended to end a five-month stalemate, is unlikely to get support from Democratic lawmakers. Democratic members of the Assembly Appropriations Committee walked out of the committee's meeting today, arguing that they had not had enough time to review the proposal, before their Republican colleagues voted 8 to 0 to support it. 
 The plan could also run into trouble in the Republican-controlled State Senate, where several Republicans remain opposed to any financing system that continues to use payroll taxes designated for the state's unemployment insurance fund to cover the cost of charity care.
As part of the new agreement, the state would abandon its ambitious subsidized health insurance program, called Health Access New Jersey, and would provide only enough money to continue health benefits for the 22,000 people now enrolled in the program. The proposal does not provide financing for any new enrollees this year, nor does it expand the program to include almost 100,000 uninsured children, as Governor Whitman requested in December.
The legislation directs the state health commissioner to implement a health care program that provides residents "with eligible charity care services on a managed care basis." Lawmakers were unable to explain how the plan would be carried out, and officials said it would probably require federal approval.
The Legislature and the Governor have been struggling for more than five months over how to pay for free medical care for the uninsured, because the state's authority to continue taking money out of the unemployment insurance fund to pay for charity care expired on Dec. 31. Since 1993, the state has paid for charity care with $1.6 billion in payroll taxes that had been earmarked for the unemployment fund.
Despite strong opposition from business leaders, the new plan would take another $660 million out of the unemployment fund over the next two years. The rest of the charity care bill would be paid with $56 million from the state budget.
To win support for the proposal from organized labor, the Assembly Appropriations Committee also voted on a separate bill today to take another $350 million out of the fund to extend unemployment benefits from 26 weeks to 39 weeks this year and to stop collecting employee payroll taxes for the fund through the end of next year. Governor Whitman said she needed to study the cost of extending unemployment benefits before deciding whether she would support it.
The plan would also reduce unemployment payroll taxes for employers by $300 million, but business leaders said today they were more concerned about the prospect of higher taxes in the coming years.
"We just don't see how the numbers add up," said Jeff Stoller, vice president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, which represents 14,000 businesses around the state.
Most representatives from the state's hospitals, which have continued to provide charity patient care without any reimbursement from the state since January, were relieved that state officials appeared to be moving toward a solution, even though they would receive $78 million less this year than last. The state distributed $388 million to 84 hospitals last year. Under the plan, $310 million would be distributed this year, and $300 million next year.
But many of the state's hospitals, particularly those in urban settings, are hoping that the state will begin sending out reimbursement checks soon. Several hospitals have been struggling to balance their books by delaying payments and by readying plans to close wards and lay off workers.
"I think it is progress," said Dr. Jonathan M. Metsch, president of Jersey City Medical Center, who has stopped construction and renovation at the hospital until the charity care issue is resolved. "It is time to get a bill passed."
But some hospital officials said privately that the hospital association was opposed to the legislation because managed care would mean less money for some suburban hospitals.

HEADLINE: Strong Auto Sales Point to Rising Confidence

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 1

 BODY:
Despite rising gasoline prices, two of the biggest auto makers reported strong April sales today that exceeded analysts' expectations, providing another sign that consumers' confidence is growing.
The General Motors Corporation said its sales rose 7.7 percent last month, compared with April 1995, despite a recent strike that crimped the production of some of its hottest sellers. 
 The Chrysler Corporation said its sales surged 33 percent, for its best April ever.
The Honda Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Corporation also reported double-digit gains, although the results at some other Japanese car makers were weaker.
The overall strength in April auto sales indicates that economic growth may have perked up considerably in the last several weeks after the economy seemed to nearly stall in late winter.
Other economic statistics released today, including the index of leading indicators for March, also pointed to a pickup in the economy. [Page D4.]
The auto sales seem especially strong because April 1995 sales were weak. But by any measure, last month's results were robust.
Gas-guzzling pickups, mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles remain top sellers, and so far, rising gasoline prices have not dampened sales, analysts and auto dealers agree.
That could begin to change as early as next month if gas prices stay high. "Demand might shift towards more fuel-efficient vehicles," said Scott F. Merlis, president of Merlis Automotive International, an independent research firm based in Westport, Conn.
General Motors sold 441,254 vehicles in April, for its 7.7 percent gain. Its car sales spiked up 12.1 percent, while its sales of light trucks rose just 1.3 percent, mostly because truck sales were slowed by the strike. There were 26 selling days last month and 25 in April 1995, so percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate.
General Motors expects its sales to heat up later this year. "We anticipate a more robust performance throughout May, June and July," said Ronald L. Zarella, vice president and group executive in charge of G.M.'s North American sales, service and marketing.
Chrysler sold 230,469 vehicles last month, with a good part of the 33 percent advance coming from its popular trucks and mini-vans.
"Over all, truck sales jumped 40 percent over last year, including double-digit increases for mini-van, pickup truck and Jeep truck sales," said James P. Holden, Chrysler's executive vice president for sales and marketing. "Car sales vaulted for the third consecutive month -- up 22 percent over year-ago totals."
The Ford Motor Company is scheduled to report its April sales Thursday, and they are expected to be flat or down slightly.
Among the Japanese auto makers, Honda sold 74,981 vehicles, up 21.2 percent from April 1995, while Nissan's sales rose 16.6 percent, to 57,105.
But Toyota's sales dipped two-tenths of 1 percent in April, to 89,397; Mazda's sales dropped 21.8 percent, to 22,321, and Mitsubishi's sales were nearly flat at 15,148.
Wall Street analysts were delighted with Chrysler's sales, which were higher than expected. The numbers "are just terrific," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto analyst at Lehman Brothers, adding, and G.M.'s were unexpectedly strong as well.
The analysts said the year was shaping up to be a strong one for the entire industry. "If you look at all of the economic variables -- confidence, income, even interest rates -- to me the signals are all green," said Mr. Phillippi, who predicted the industry could sell 15.2 million light vehicles this year.
G.M. reported its sales after the stock market closed; its shares ended at $54.50 each, up 25 cents. Shares of Chrysler, which announced its results earlier, rose 75 cents to close at $63.75.
Mr. Merlis, the analyst, said April's strong sales made him confident that annual car and light-truck sales would reach 15.2 million this year. "We were nervous that our estimate was too high at the beginning of the year, and we feel much more comfortable," he said.
Mr. Phillippi said G.M.'s sales were hurt by the 17-day strike at an Ohio brake factory in March. "Their numbers in trucks should be a whole lot better," he said.
Robert H. Moody, a River Falls, Wis., dealer who sells Chevrolet, Buick, Oldsmobile, Pontiac and Geo lines, said his showroom customers did not not seem too concerned by rising gasoline prices. "People that are buying a $30,000 to $35,000 Suburban -- if they have got to worry about gas prices, they shouldn't be buying it in the first place," Mr. Moody said.
Some auto dealers said they could not keep enough pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans on their lots.
Alan B. Helfman, a Houston Chrysler and Ford dealer, said April sales were so strong that he hoped they would stay at that pace "for the rest of eternity." People are in the mood to buy, he said, partly because they are getting their tax refunds and the economy is picking up. "You're just not hearing a lot of gloom and doom right now," he said.
Pickups, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans are strong sellers, and car sales have been helped by offers of rebates or underpriced leases, he said. People visiting his showroom were also not too concerned about the rise in gasoline prices, Mr. Helfman said.

HEADLINE: What Gasoline Crisis?

BYLINE: By Daniel Yergin; Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, is the author of "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power."

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
It is not surprising that this week's debate over gasoline prices is occurring in a Presidential election year. Furor over gas prices is part of the American political tradition. In 1923, just as the nation was becoming motorized, the Wisconsin Senator Robert La Follette launched Congressional hearings on rising prices at the pump.
"If a few great oil companies are allowed to manipulate oil prices," motorists would soon be paying a dollar a gallon, thundered Fighting Bob. In fact, gasoline prices went in the opposite direction, falling to 13 cents a gallon by 1927. 
 Ever since, any upward surge in the price of gas has set off a national political clamor. In response to today's public outcry, Senator Bob Dole has proposed rolling back the 4.3 cent-a-gallon gasoline tax. There have been Congressional calls to investigate price-gouging. And President Clinton has announced plans to sell off a small part of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.
These proposals, however, don't focus on the source of the increase. Gasoline prices are up because crude oil costs are up. In commodity markets -- and oil is very definitely a commodity -- prices go up and go down in response to market conditions.
A freeze in Florida brings sympathy for citrus farmers who nurse their groves through the cold night. The resulting higher juice prices are taken in stride. Corn and wheat prices are relatively high right now, but no one seems to be pillorying the American farmer. Newspapers have been raising their prices because of high newsprint costs. Some people may have canceled their subscriptions, but there are no calls to investigate alleged collusion between the paper industry and publishers.
Gasoline, however, is treated as a special case. First, it is the one commodity whose price has the ability to make people mad, really mad, even in nonelection years. It is the true in-your-face expense, the one that most consumers see every day, in big numbers, on the road to and from work. They can drink a little less orange juice or stop buying the Sunday paper, but they can't live without gasoline, especially for commuting.
Second, consumers have been suspicious of oil companies since the days of the muckrakers. In 1902, Ida Tarbell, the crusading journalist, exposed the ruthless market machinations of John D. Rockefeller and the Standard Oil Trust, revelations that helped lead to its historic breakup in 1911.
This distrust of the oil industry was replayed in the long gas lines of the 1970's. In 1974, Senator Henry Jackson led highly charged Congressional hearings on the energy crisis. Senior executives of the seven largest oil companies tried to explain, without much success, why their companies were reporting large increases in profits while the Arab oil embargo was still in effect.
Less well remembered is how Federal intervention in the market led to the lines at the pump. Price controls, imposed in 1971 by President Richard Nixon, and an irrational allocation system helped insure that gasoline would be amply supplied where it was not needed and in short supply where it was.
Since the 1970's, gasoline has changed from a regulated to a market commodity, and in the United States it has become one of the great bargains of the Western world. Over the last few years, prices, adjusted for inflation, have been as low as any time since World War II.
Even with the 20-cent increase since the beginning of February, gasoline, at about $1.30 a gallon, is still inexpensive. And it is exquisitely cheap when compared with the almost $5 a gallon that motorists pay in France, where the Government imposes high taxes at the pump.
The actual explanation for the American price run-up -- those fabled market forces -- does not do much to placate the public's anger. Three villains -- Old Man Winter, Asian economic growth and Saddam Hussein -- do bear significant responsibility. But they are unlikely to appear in an American court anytime soon.
 World demand for crude oil jumped in the last few months because of the unexpectedly cold weather across the Northern Hemisphere. At the same time, consumption is growing around the world, owing to economic growth, particularly in Asia, which has increased global demand.
 Meanwhile, the oil world has been waiting to see what would happen with Saddam Hussein's on-again, off-again "deal" with the United Nations to resume oil exports.
Iraq has been out of the oil market since its invasion of Kuwait almost six years ago, an absence that has cost Iraq about $80 billion in revenues. At various points over the last several months, Iraq has seemed close to accepting the terms of a United Nations resolution that would allow Mr. Hussein to resume limited oil exports under tight restrictions. The resumption of even limited exports could lead to a major drop in the price of oil.
That expectation in the first part of the year led refiners to reduce their already low inventories. No one wanted to be stuck with higher-cost oil when their competitors could purchase lower-cost supplies.
But so far there has been no deal between Iraq and the United Nations. Acceptance of the export restrictions, in Iraq's eyes, would taint its "sovereignty," especially since part of the revenues would go to the Kuwaitis, the Kurds and the United Nations.
Afew weeks ago, with demand strong and Iraq still out of the market, refiners found that they could no longer hold off buying crude oil. They needed to meet demand, and rushed into the market. When they all bought more or less at the same time, prices went up.
Added pressure comes from Wall Street commodity funds, which find it profitable to trade in oil (along with wheat, corn and anything else that shows volatility in prices).
So in those few weeks, the price of oil increased by about 25 percent, to almost $25 a barrel. Reflecting the lag that results from the logistics of transportation and manufacturing, gasoline prices have naturally gone up.
But markets move fast these days, faster than they did in the 1970's. The price of crude is already falling with the arrival of warmer weather and the anticipated buildup of new production from OPEC and non-OPEC members alike.
Barring the unexpected -- for instance, a surge in demand or turmoil in an oil-producing country -- prices for crude will continue to decrease along with prices for gasoline. How far they come down is pretty much up to Saddam Hussein, and whether he agrees to the United Nations export restrictions. But by the time Americans hit the road for summer vacation, gasoline prices should be lower.
In the meantime, as part of the American political tradition, politicians are trying to do something about gasoline prices. It is clear what should be done -- pretty much nothing. Repealing the gas tax or selling off small parts of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve will not have much impact. As things stand now, the market is already on the way to solving the problem. That's what markets often do.

HEADLINE: Gingrich Said to Vow Wage Vote Soon

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
Under unrelenting pressure from Democrats and facing increasing clamor within his own party, Speaker Newt Gingrich today promised House Republicans who support increasing the Federal minimum wage a vote on the issue within a few weeks, several of them said.
"One way or the other, it will be resolved this month," said Representative Christopher Shays of Connecticut. Mr. Shays, a moderate, is one of the leaders of a breakaway group of House Republicans who helped force Mr. Gingrich over the last two weeks to drop his resistance to a vote on raising the minimum wage, now $4.25 an hour. 
 Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader and his party's presumed Presidential nominee, has already suggested that he would allow the minimum wage question to come to a vote in the Senate, possibly tied to a measure to reduce the Federal tax on gasoline. It is widely agreed that there is enough support in both houses of Congress to pass an increase in the wage, something President Clinton has been advocating.
Conceding that Republicans were taking a political beating from Democrats over the minimum wage, Mr. Gingrich told House Republicans on April 17 that they should prepare for a vote on the issue. But today, in a 75-minute meeting devoted entirely to the issue, the Speaker went even further, saying he had decided to schedule a vote within two or three weeks on a measure to increase the wage to $5.25 over two years.
Several lawmakers who attended the meeting said Mr. Gingrich appealed to his 235 colleagues -- especially a bloc of 20 members who caught him off guard last month with their mass defection on the issue -- to hold off throwing their political lot in with the Democrats and give him time to come up with a bill that would win support from Republicans on both sides of the debate.
"We're going to vote for it," Mr. Shays said. "The next issue is, we can vote for it under terms written by Democrats or we can vote for it under terms written by Republicans as a team."
Democrats have proposed a "clean" bill -- that is, not attached to any other legislation -- that would raise the minimum wage to $5.15 over 15 months.
Representative James T. Walsh, a Republican from upstate New York who also is a strong proponent of raising the minimum wage, said Mr. Gingrich suggested that he might introduce the issue as an amendment to a legislative package that would include tax credits and other incentives for small businesses.
"Support is growing within the Republican conference for the minimum wage," said Mr. Walsh, who spoke at length in favor of an increase at today's meeting. "I am happy to see minds being changed."
The Federal minimum wage was last increased in 1989, when the legislation was passed by an overwhelming majority and survived a veto by President George Bush.
Informal surveys have shown that a majority of the members in both the House and the Senate support an increase in the minimum wage. But until recently Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich have been opposed to the idea. They maintain that an increase in the minimum wage would cost jobs.
As public opinion and the views among Democrats, and even those of some fellow Republicans, have turned against them on the wage issue, both the Senate leader and the Speaker have moved in recent days toward devising some face-saving compromise.
Republican strategists agree that Mr. Dole will be better off in his Presidential campaign if he can put the issue behind him. Mr. Gingrich has a more complicated problem: his powerful deputy, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader. Mr. Armey, a former economics professor, ardently opposes an increase in the minimum wage, a position held by about two-thirds of the Republican majority.
Both Mr. Armey and the Speaker oppose an increase, "but one believes it is going to happen and another believes he can stop it," Mr. Shays said. "There is going to be a vote on the minimum wage, let's face that fact, and every week that we delay it, the more politically painful the outcome will be."
Tony Blankley, Mr. Gingrich's spokesman, said it would be left to Mr. Armey to set a date for a vote. But Mr. Blankley added, "I would expect that we would move with some briskness."
In the three weeks since Congress reconvened after its spring break, hardly a workday has passed without Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, or some other Democrat speaking out on the wage issue on the Senate floor or trying to maneuver opposing Republicans into an embarrassing vote on raising the minimum wage.
"Sooner or later Republicans are going to have to come to the realization that they're not going to avoid that vote," Mr. Daschle told reporters today.
Democrats in the House surprised the majority last week by trying to amend a procedural rule that was on the floor to turn it into the vehicle for a vote on the minimum wage.
House Republicans narrowly fought off that attempt on a 220-to-200 vote that saw 13 Republicans desert their party's leadership. Democrats used a similar strategy today that ended with a similar outcome.
But still, today's vote of 219 to 203 was enough to give Republican leaders pause. Democrats put up the most solid front to date, with only one member, Representative Bill Brewster of Oklahoma, breaking rank and 12 Republicans, along with the lone independent in the House, Representative Bernard Sanders of Vermont, joining the effort to force a vote.
"We've been through this same chicanery before, just last week," said Representative Deborah Pryce, an Ohio Republican who was floor manager for the bill the Democrats tried to hijack.
The bill would allow the director of the United States Marshals Service to appoint marshals. Under current law, the President appoints marshals, subject to Senate confirmation. It was passed on a 351-to-72 vote, but not until gleeful Democrats had their fill of taking political potshots at the Republicans over the minimum wage.
"We have seen this Republican Congress attempt to eliminate the minimum corporate income tax, attempt to cut way back on capital gains for the large corporations, but when it comes to lifting from beneath the poverty rate of the lowest workers in this country, they constantly try to stifle us," said Representative Ron Klink of Pennsylvania, one of the last Democrats to take the floor in today's debate. "Somewhere between Abraham Lincoln and Newt Gingrich, this party has reversed its position on slavery."

HEADLINE: Mexico Happy With Response To New Bonds

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 1

 BODY:
Mexican officials crowed today about the response to a sale of a new 30-year Government bond, though market analysts gave more mixed reviews.
Mexico announced the results of an unusual offer to exchange two types of Brady bonds, which are partly backed by the United States Treasury, for up to $2.5 billion of the new 30-year global bonds, which are not backed by collateral. 
 It was the first major long-term bond offering the Government has made since the peso collapse of 1994, and finance officials regarded it primarily as a test of investors' slowly returning confidence in their policies. The challenge was all the greater because the sale followed two weeks of doubt and confusion in the bidding process determining the value of the bonds.
After receiving more than $3 billion in swap offers, Mexico said it would issue $1.7 billion in the global bonds. They will yield 12.4 percent to the investor, or 552 basis points above the comparable United States Treasury bonds. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
"This was a successful transaction," said Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz, who called reporters to convey his satisfaction. "The market spoke for itself."
Since the worst fear of Mr. Ortiz was that the bonds would be a market failure, he said he was not dismayed that they did not reach the $2.5 billion maximum the Government had projected. Some analysts took the considerably lower amount to be the measure of a tepid response.
The Government offered to exchange the new dollar-denominated bonds for the Brady bonds, in the process freeing up that collateral for other purposes. To induce investors to make the switch, Mexico had promised a yield of at least 4.25 percentage points above similar United States Treasury bonds.
Only about 25 percent of the new bonds went to Mexican banks, dispelling fears in the markets that the Government might have offered special privileges to Mexican investors to buy them.
The result of the global bond issue was good news for the Clinton Administration, which lent Mexico $12.5 billion last year as part of an international rescue package. Mexico has been paying down that loan on time.
Mexico said it expected to reduce its foreign debt by $1.25 billion as a result of the sales because it would use the proceeds to pay off some of its high-priced short-term debt.
Finance officials said they also expected to be able to finance the Government's debt on more favorable terms in the future.
Some analysts on Wall Street seemed to agree with Mr. Ortiz on the success of the bonds. Amy Falls, director of emerging markets fixed-income research at Morgan Stanley, called the bonds a good buy and said they signaled a vote of confidence in Mexico.
"The Mexicans have shown their commitment to issuing long-term debt in a market-sensitive way," she said.
Brady bonds lost much of their value in late 1994 and early 1995, in large part because of Mexico's economic crisis. They are named for the former Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, who developed a plan to overhaul Latin American debt. Repayment of the principal on Brady bonds is backed by United States Treasury bonds owned by the issuing country and held by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HEADLINE: Critics See Politics in Economic Policy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
For a President who professes faith in the free market, Bill Clinton has, in the view of some economists and business executives, been caught this week in some remarkable if politically unsurprising contradictions.
There he was on Monday, saying he knew how upset Americans were about the rapid rise in gasoline prices. So, to try to nudge them down, he announced that he would begin selling some of the Government's oil reserves, a decision his spokesman described as a "precise, prudent and modest step designed to move the market in the right direction." 
 A day later, Mr. Clinton met with legislators from agricultural states and heard them bemoan the low prices ranchers were getting for cattle. This time the response was aimed at "doing our best to keep the market from falling further," as Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said, helping farmers but potentially forcing consumers to pay more for meat.
Administration officials argued today that the actions on both gasoline and beef prices were good policy as well as good politics, even if they did try to push one set of prices up and another down.
But whatever political gain Mr. Clinton might reap in California, with its dependence on cars, and in the farm belt, his uncharacteristic market-intervention binge this week raised questions -- in Washington, in the business community and in the financial markets -- about the extent to which he would sacrifice economic principles to electoral calculus.
"The President's empathy with the pain of every special interest group might help in the election, but it undercuts his credibility with the business community on serious policy issues," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, an influential lobbying group.
Coming days after Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the presumed Republican Presidential nominee, proposed repealing a 4.3-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, and against a backdrop of a continuing debate over raising the minimum wage, some analysts said Presidential politics was rapidly pushing aside economic prudence among Republicans and Democrats.
While politics always plays a role in economic policy, especially in an election year, analysts said the issues were particularly sensitive now because they could call into question the commitment of both Presidential candidates to priorities like eliminating the Federal budget deficit.
"These moves scare me to death," said Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley, the Wall Street investment firm.
"I look in the last few weeks at the proposed hike in the minimum wage and at the intervention in the food and energy markets," Mr. Roach said, "and I see classic examples of how politicians cannot resist the desire to try and make things better through inappropriate policies. Politicians are always prepared to do whatever is necessary to get elected, so it's not unexpected, but it's discouraging to see it so early in an election year."
In that sense, analysts said, Mr. Dole is as guilty as Mr. Clinton, particularly in proposing the gasoline tax reduction without saying how he would make up the $4.8 billion revenue shortage it would create. Indeed, gasoline prices have risen rapidly in recent weeks, but they remain near their historical lows when inflation is taken into account, and far below what consumers in most other countries pay.
"The President is pandering to the electorate, but only because he's been provoked by even greater pandering by Senator Dole," said Robert D. Reischauer, a former head of the Congressional Budget Office who is now with the Brookings Institution.
Still, Mr. Dole's advisers were quick to attack Mr. Clinton for what they said was another instance of Democrats meddling in markets.
"I thought that the President announced the end to the era of big government," said Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, who serves as an informal economic adviser to Mr. Dole. "Today it looks like its business as usual when a liberal Democrat President relies on big government solutions to solve free market situations."
By adopting deficit reduction as a primary goal, however reluctantly, Mr. Clinton had eroded the traditional suspicion in the financial markets that Democratic presidents cannot be trusted to cut spending and keep inflation in check. And on the issue of layoffs and corporate responsibility, he has publicly acknowledged that some companies need to cut costs to remain competitive.
Today, facing questions about whether that credibility was being squandered on electoral politics, Administration officials said it was unjustified to read into the oil and beef decisions any change in economic approach. They said the back-to-back announcements -- timely and effective uses of existing policies -- was simply coincidence.
"We are doing what we think is appropriate in both of these cases," Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the Administration's chief economic policy adviser, told reporters today. "We are not undertaking new policies here."
Ms. Tyson said the sale of 12 million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve this year was mandated by Congress last week as part of an effort to raise more than $200 million for deficit reduction. By beginning the sale now, while oil prices are still relatively high, the Administration was maximizing the proceeds of the sale, while also giving a downward push to prices that might eventually show up at the gas pump, she said.
"If this was not a political season, we would have taken the same action and it would have been written about in a different way," Ms. Tyson said.
Just as the Administration was selling high in the oil market, she said, it was buying low in the beef market. By accelerating its purchase of at least $50 million worth of beef for school lunch programs while prices are depressed, the Government will be getting more beef for its money, Ms. Tyson said.
"This is a perfectly sensible time to buy," she said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Nasdaq Stocks Advance For 10th Straight Record
The Nasdaq composite index roared to its 10th consecutive record high close, matching a string of highs set in 1992. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.14 points, to 5,575.22, while the Nasdaq jumped 9.14 points to end at 1,199.66.
"It's a wonderful business climate for small companies," one economist said, and a market strategist said Wall Street was adjusting to stronger economic data. [Page D12.]
 
Signs of Gathering Strength
The index of leading indicators rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March, following a rise in February. The consecutive monthly gains were the first in more than a year. Meanwhile, a purchasing executives' survey showed manufacturing improved in April for the first time in nine months and construction spending shot up 3.1 percent in March. [D4.]
 
McAfee Gives Up a Fight
Facing a bitter war of wills between two chief executives, McAfee Associates has withdrawn its $1 billion proposal to acquire Cheyenne Software. The announcement sent shares of Cheyenne tumbling 17.7 percent. A merger would have created the nation's fifth-largest software company. [D3.]
 
$1.4 Billion Chemical Deal

HEADLINE: Immigrant Workers Aren't Stealing Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Roy Beck's claim that immigrants have been used to depress wages in fields like computer engineering is surprising (Op-Ed, April 30). I work in a Silicon Valley semiconductor company, and many of my engineering co-workers are immigrants. I wouldn't describe our wages as "depressed." In 14 years, my salary has grown 9 percent annually. Last I checked, this was significantly ahead of inflation. 
 The plant where I work also has a large number of immigrant line workers, yet hourly wages are higher than those of the mostly native-born operators outside California. Maybe Minnesota, for example, could use more immigrants, because their effect in California has been to drive wages up.
Immigrants at my company aren't "taking jobs away from Americans." Far from it. They are filling jobs that would otherwise go unfilled, and working hard once they get them.
 
MARC JACOBS
San Mateo, Calif., April 30, 1996

HEADLINE: PANEL URGES SHIFT IN HOW NEW YORK PAYS HEALTH BILLS

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
A mayoral advisory panel has recommended that New York City fundamentally change the way it pays for health care for the indigent, proposing that the government subsidize insurance for the uninsured rather than maintain the current system of subsidizing hospitals that treat the poor.
The seven-member panel, whose report is scheduled for release today, said its proposals were intended to "promote and encourage the use of primary and preventive care and minimize overreliance on an expensive hospital system." 
 The proposal for subsidizing insurance would cost $1.5 billion annually, with most of the money coming from a 2 percent tax on the fees of doctors, hospitals and insurers, a cost bound to be passed on to private customers through higher premiums. Although the report does not use the word "tax," the assessment it describes is just that. The word was apparently avoided to deflect criticism from insurers and providers who have been opposed to paying such surcharges and are likely to lobby against it if the Mayor embraces the panel's recommendations.
In a further effort to blunt opposition, the panel said the 2 percent tax, which would raise $900 million a year, would be levied against "the two private sector industries that will benefit most from the proposal: insurers and providers."
The insurers, the report notes, "gain a vastly expanded market of insurance eligible residents, while providers earn larger and more direct reimbursement for the care they provide to the indigent."
The panel's report comes at a time when cities across the country are grappling with ways to pay for health care for the uninsured, as hospitals are buffeted on one side by managed care companies demanding deep discounts and on the other by cuts in government reimbursement for Medicaid, the program for the poor, and Medicare, the program for the elderly and disabled.
In New York, the State Legislature is considering a plan by Gov. George E. Pataki to end most government regulation of the fees charged by hospitals. The Governor has said that allowing competition to determine rates would push down costs and encourage the growth of cheaper care outside of hospital settings.
The report on financing health care for the indigent -- parts of which were read to The New York Times -- is the second proposal put forth by the hand-picked mayoral panel. Last August, the panel recommended that the city abolish its public hospital system, saying that it delivered inefficient and low-quality care at its 11 hospitals and its network of clinics and nursing homes. The Mayor roundly endorsed the panel's findings.
But when he assembled the panel, the Mayor also asked it to tackle the thorny question of indigent care, a problem that would be made more acute if the city dismantles the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the agency responsible for the public hospital system. The agency each year provides care for hundreds of thousands of patients, most poor and many uninsured.
In addition to the tax on provider services, the panel also proposed in its latest report that $400 million of what the state currently pays to public and private hospitals to help cover care for the poor be redirected to pay for insurance, on the presumption that the need for such philanthropy would be diminished if more people had insurance coverage.
Under the current system, after the state sets the rate for what each hospital can charge insurers, it then adds on a surcharge that goes to defray the costs of charity care.
The report also says that by enrolling more Medicaid recipients into managed health care plans, and by including this new group of people in negotiations with insurers, the city would have leverage to get better insurance rates and the government will save $200 million that can help
pay for the panel's plan. About 800,000 of the 1.5 million New Yorkers who lack health insurance would get coverage under the panel's proposals. For those earning below 133 percent of the poverty level, the insurance premiums would be totally subsidized, while those with higher incomes could "buy coverage using their own resources according to a sliding scale."
The Giuliani administration would not comment yesterday on the panel's latest findings. A spokeswoman, Colleen Roche, said the administration preferred to wait until the report's official release today.
The New York State Health Commissioner, Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono, said yesterday that she had seen the report and she described it as "a preliminary attempt on the part of this panel to grapple with the very challenging issue of charity care."
"I applaud the efforts shown to care for indigent New Yorkers," Dr. DeBuono said. But she added that the report lacked many details and left her with concerns about the "financial mechanisms proposed and the distribution of these dollars," particularly given the Governor's extensive proposals to revamp health care financing.
She and other government officials agreed that virtually all of the panel's proposals for raising revenue for the plan would require approval by the State Legislature.
Some members of the Legislature said they were disturbed that the mayoral panel, which was headed by the Mayor's special adviser for health policy, Maria K. Mitchell, was prepared to issue its recommendations without having briefed people in Albany who will be critical in getting it implemented.
"No one on the Mayor's behalf has discussed this with the Legislature that I know of, even though months ago, I urged Maria Mitchell to do that and she said she would," said Assembyman Richard N. Gottfried of the Health Committee. "I have no idea what their plan includes. But it would be more likely to be something that the Legislature would support if we had been able to contribute some thoughts to it."
Many states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, already tax hospital and nursing home revenues to pay for, among other programs, charity health care. But if the panel's plan is adopted, New York would be among few places that tax insurers, hospitals and other health care providers specifically to raise money for buying insurance for the poor. Minnesota, for one, has a tax on doctors and hospital fees and insurance premiums to subsidize coverage for low income families who do not qualify for Medicaid.
Some economists and analysts who follow the health care industry said that New York City could expect to meet fierce resistance from doctors, hospitals and insurance companies if it tries to impose a new tax to finance care for the poor.
Chris Petersen, a vice president of the Health Insurance Association of America, a Washington trade group, said that New York "should be very wary of adding a tax on insurers that would drive up the cost" of premiums because it could result in other people dropping coverage.
But James R. Tallon, president of the United Hospital Fund, said the plan displayed a "thoughtful, positive, long term strategy" that represented a "more efficient way to deliver quality health care to the poor."
"This plans adds the specific and positive focus of an insurance subsidy strategy instead of an institution subsidy strategy for indigent care," said Mr. Tallon, whose group does research and philanthropy. "And secondly, it brings the Mayor into the Albany discussions as a significant player with a quality proposal that all parties would be well advised to take a look at."
Dr. Martin Cherkasky, a doctor and health care consultant who is on the panel, said that when the Mayor first explained what he wanted the group to accomplish, he "said he thought H.H.C. had outlived its usefulness and he wanted to assure that people who use the public hospitals as a provider of last resort would be covered by any plan."
He said this task was complicated by a climate in which there is "great uncertainty over the resources available to do this."
But recently, said Dr. Cherkasky, who would not specifically address the report, "I began to see a scheme emerging in our discussions in which I could see where the resources could come from."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Soars Against the Pound In Advance of British Elections

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply against the British pound and Swiss franc in thin trading yesterday. It posted more modest gains versus the German mark and Japanese yen.
The dollar set two-year highs against the pound, which was unsettled by speculation that Britain's ruling Conservative Party would suffer another humiliating setback in elections for local governments today. 
 "You've got selling pressure on the Swiss franc and on the pound," Anne Parker Mills, a currency analyst at Lehman Brothers, said. "So we ended up with the dollar higher against Europe and not much changed against the yen."
The dollar extended recent gains against the Swiss franc and the mark, hitting fresh 14-month highs at 1.2530 francs and 1.5382 marks, before trading volume nearly evaporated when London closed. Many European markets were closed for national holidays yesterday.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.2505 Swiss francs, up from 1.2435 on Tuesday, and at 1.5363 marks, up from 1.5310. The dollar also rose to 105.32 yen, from 105.13 yen.
The pound settled at $1.4915, down from $1.5075. It was the first time the pound had been traded at less than $1.4950 since May 1994.
The pound has been rattled several times in the last two years, ahead of previous local elections and special elections for vacant Parliament seats on concerns over the stability of the Government of Prime Minister John Major.
While the opposition Labor Party already dominates local government, an expected loss of 500 or more local council seats by the Conservatives would be seen as sharp blow to the ruling party.
A strong local showing by Labor could increase pressure for a general election. Polls show the Conservatives would be likely to lose their one-seat governing majority.
"A Labor victory is priced in at these levels," said Susan Stearns, a director of foreign exchange sales at Bank of Montreal.
The Swiss franc fell through important technical levels against the dollar on Tuesday, after Finance Minister Kaspar Villiger of Switzerland said a strong Swiss franc hindered economic growth and called for a decline in the currency.
Buying of the dollar against the Swiss franc continued despite remarks by the new president of the Swiss National Bank, Hans Meyer, suggesting that the bank did not seek to alter a strong Swiss franc policy.
