HEADLINE: Mexico's Leader Quietly Adopts A Warmer Approach to the U.S.

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 1

 BODY:
In a series of quiet policy changes, President Ernesto Zedillo has recently reversed some dearly held tenets of Mexico's historically prickly relationship with the United States.
For the first time, Mexico recently approved American requests for the extradition of two of its citizens to the United States. 
 Mexico also recently abandoned a long-held position rejecting international discussion of its human rights record, and in a separate move allowed Washington to begin airlifting illegal immigrants back to their hometowns deep inside Mexico.
Last week the Defense Minister approved a military agreement providing for training of Mexican soldiers at American bases and the provision of United States weaponry. It is the first pact on this scale since the 19th-century invasions that convinced Mexico that the United States was its principal enemy.
The Clinton Administration officials who have negotiated these policy changes, and who will discuss further cooperation when a senior delegation headed by Secretary of State Warren Christopher visits Mexico on Monday for annual meetings, have praised Mexico's more accommodating posture.
But in Mexico the changes have aroused debate over whether the country is slowly surrendering its sovereignty, continuing a trend that critics trace back to the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994, and that accelerated last year when Washington and Mexico worked closely in the effort to rescue the Mexican economy.
Mr. Zedillo's Government has seemed to avoid publicity for the recent shifts. But in an interview today, a senior Government official said Mexico's increasingly intimate ties with the United States showed the tremendous respect with which both Governments viewed each other and were signs of "the intelligent management of our bilateral relationship."
On the other hand, some Mexican academics and opposition politicians portrayed the changes as a symptom of their country's financial and political vulnerability.
"These shifts carry tremendous symbolic meaning," said Lorenzo Meyer, the author of a standard history of United States-Mexico relations. "In the end, this chain of events means we are losing the relative independence Mexico achieved for 50 years. The Government is weak, and the United States, sensing a power vacuum, is injecting itself into our affairs."
At least since the 1930's, successive Mexican presidents have overseen a foreign policy characterized by polite but distant relations with Washington and routine opposition to American interests in forums like the United Nations.
"For decades Mexico sought to defend itself by saying no," said Humberto Garza Elizondo, a professor at the Colegio de Mexico, "even sometimes to United States initiatives with which the Government was not really in disagreement."
The tectonic plates of Mexican policy first shifted during the previous administration, when President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, seeking approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement, reversed decades of economic protectionism and began seeking cooperation with Washington on a broad front.
Analysts described the recent changes as mini-earthquakes, still rattling to the surface in the wake of that strategic shift.
All embody an approach to United States relations by President Zedillo that has led analysts from both countries to describe him as more pragmatic and less doctrinaire than his predecessors.
Mr. Zedillo's aides point out that he has forcefully defended Mexican interests when he has felt them to be under siege by Washington. He has encouraged Mexican consular officials in the United States, for instance, to vigorously defend the rights of migrant workers, including those without documents.
"What we have sought, and are achieving, is a new class of communication, a new form of contact with the Government of the United States," Mr. Zedillo said last week in a speech in Tijuana, in which he responded to Mexican critics who have accused him of cooperating too submissively with Washington. "We cannot confuse diplomacy with machismo."
Throughout its history Mexico has declined to extradite its citizens. But on April 17, Mexican officials delivered Francisco Gamez Garcia, who fled to his homeland after being convicted in Arizona of sexually abusing a boy in 1993, to the United States authorities in Phoenix.
The Foreign Ministry said the extradition request had been granted because Mr. Gamez could not be tried in Mexico without violating the principle of double jeopardy.
On April 25, Mexico sent another of its citizens, Aaron Morel Lebaron, to Houston, where he is charged with the murder of four people, including a child. The ministry approved that request "taking into consideration the infamous nature of the crimes," as well as the fact that the United States Government says he is an American citizen.
The extraditions followed lengthy discussions with the Clinton Administration.
American officials say they are hopeful that Mexico will now turn over top drug traffickers it succeeds in arresting to the United States, especially in cases in which the suspect faces charges in the United States but not in Mexico.
Mexico delivered the reputed trafficker Juan Garcia Abrego to the United States authorities in January, but he was not extradited. Instead, the Government declared him to be an American and expelled him as an undesirable foreigner.
The senior Government official, while acknowledging that the two extraditions were the first in Mexico's history, denied that they represented any change in policy. His comments suggested that it was not at all certain that Mexican traffickers arrested in their homeland would be extradited to the United States.
"There has been no shift in our extradition laws, and we will in the future examine each situation on a case-by-case basis," the official said.
The recent thaw in military relations is also partly the result of United States pressure for heightened anti-drug efforts here.
Until the 1980's, Mexican military manuals portrayed the United States as the country's natural enemy.
Besides Cuba, Mexico has been the only country in the hemisphere to consistently keep the American military at arm's length, apart from the training of a trickle of officers at American military schools over the years and a purchase of American jets once in the 1980's.
But an agreement approved by Defense Minister Enrique Cervantes on April 24 in a meeting with Defense Secretary William Perry reverses course, setting up the immediate transfer of 20 UH-1H Huey helicopters to the Mexican Air Force, perhaps 50 or more additional helicopters next year and the training of Mexican soldiers in anti-narcotics tactics at Fort Bragg, N.C., as well as helicopter pilots and mechanics at other bases.
Helicopters previously provided by the United States have been transferred to the Mexican anti-drug police, not to the military.
"This is a major policy change by both Governments," said Roderic A. Camp, a Tulane University professor who studies the Mexican military.
Mexico has also markedly changed its political stand on human rights inquiries. For decades, like China, it held that international criticism of its human rights record amounted to unwarranted meddling by foreigners. But, continuing a recent trend toward more openness, Mexico announced in Washington on Monday that it had for the first time invited a fact-finding rights delegation from the Organization of American States to visit Mexico.
Such delegations, which broadly review human rights concerns, have visited nearly all other Latin American countries.
A sign of the evolution of Mexico's immigration policies came when Mexico agreed to a pilot program, financed by Washington, in which migrants who have been detained illegally crossing the border can elect to be flown back to central Mexico for return to their homes.
In four flights since April 3, 63 Mexicans have been ferried from San Diego to Guadalajara, and a United States spokesman estimated that 450 more would be flown home by July.
The United States is financing the program to get the illegals as far from the border as possible. Mexico is cooperating as a way to support would-be migrants who have spent their last pesos trying to get across the border.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Dole bill to revise tort law may lure some centrist Democrats.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THIS week or next President Clinton is expected to veto a bill that would limit punitive damage awards in product liability suits. In response, Senator Bob Dole plans to introduce a new bill to change tort law -- one even more ambitious than the full-blown makeover for civil justice proposed by Republicans last year.
This counterpunch will no doubt be interpreted as a pre-election reminder to corporate America where its bread is buttered. But the new bill also represents a sharp change in substance, and it may win over centrist Democrats. 
 The 104th Congress treated legal reform as a zero-sum game in which defendants' gains inevitably meant plaintiffs' losses. By contrast, the Dole-McConnell bill (for Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican) takes dead aim at the lawyers who, its proponents say, confound the process. "We now have a civil justice system that might as well have been invented by Kafka," said Michael Horowitz, a policy analyst at the Hudson Institute and a part of the brain trust behind the Dole-McConnell bill. "The core issue," he said, "is how to get more money into injured people's pockets, faster."
Civil justice revision, as conceived by business lobbies, would make it harder to win damages and limit the latitude of courts in making the punishment fit the transgression. The new Federal "loser pays" law, for example, deters securities fraud lawsuits by requiring the losing side to pay everyone's legal bills.
This approach pleases corporations more likely to see themselves as defendants than plaintiffs. It also fits the world view of conservative legal scholars, who argue that the courts have grown too willing to play Robin Hood. But it has made tort reform an easy target for trial lawyers, who have successfully tarred it as antipopulist.
Peter Kinzler, a former Congressional staff member who is now a partner in the consulting firm of Kinzler-Swab, notes that it wasn't always thus. "No fault" auto insurance, designed to compensate injury victims without expensive legal confrontation, was a liberal cause. "Mike Dukakis sponsored the first state no-fault law to pass," he noted.
But the coalition of consumer groups and labor unions backing no-fault broke up in the early 1980's after Ralph Nader took on all who dared restrict access to courts. And civil justice reform refocused on the issues that most concerned business. Now the pendulum is swinging back.
The Dole-McConnell bill resurrects no-fault auto insurance with some clever twists. "Auto-choice," invented by Jeffrey O'Connell of the University of Virginia Law School along with Mr. Horowitz, would require that insurers compensate their own policyholders for economic losses. Those who wish could maintain the right to be compensated for intangible pain and suffering by buying extra coverage from the insurers.
With no need to establish fault in court, the cost of insurance would fall sharply. Allan Abrahamse and Stephen Carroll, economists at the Rand Corporation, estimate that it would save one-third in premiums -- $40 billion in 1996 -- provided people chose to do without pain and suffering coverage. "Tort reform would be transformed from political broccoli to ice cream," Mr. Horowitz said.
The other big piece of the Dole-McConnell package would restrict contingency fees to cases in which plaintiffs' lawyers bear significant risk of working for nothing. "In most injury suits, settlements are virtually guaranteed and even the size of the settlement follows standardized guidelines," explained Lester Brickman, a professor at the Cardozo School of Law in New York.
Plaintiffs would be obliged to give defendants a chance to make a settlement offer before the lawyers had invested much in legal maneuvering. The plaintiffs would not be obliged to accept an early offer. But contingency fees, which now run to a third or more of judgments, could not be collected by their lawyers on any smaller sum.
Suppose a defendant's insurer offered $50,000 to settle an injury case after being notified of the suit. And suppose the victim turned down the offer and years later won a judgment for $60,000. The victim's lawyer could collect a contingency fee only on the last $10,000. He or she would be limited to an hourly fee for the routine work involved in soliciting the $50,000 early offer.
The likely savings? According to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress it would amount to "a significant portion of the over $45 billion in tort costs attributable to lawyers' fees."
The big lure here, Mr. McConnell argues, is the potential consumer savings. "This is the tax cut for the middle class both Republicans and Democrats want," he said.
Could any piece of this bill be enacted before the election? "This is not arcane legislation that is difficult to explain," Mr. McConnell allowed. "All things are possible."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 10, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
The Economic Scene column in Business Day on May 2, about Congressional moves to revise the civil justice system, misstated a provision of a new Federal law involving securities litigation. While the new law makes it somewhat easier for courts to impose penalties on lawyers who file abusive lawsuits, it does not include a "loser pay" rule that allows the winner of a lawsuit to collect legal fees from the loser.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Minnesota Mining Posts a Drop In Quarter's Net Income of 3.7%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, May 2

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, which is shedding a variety of businesses, said today that net income fell 3.7 percent in the first quarter but that profit from the operations it was retaining rose about 2 percent.
Sales increased in the United States and at a faster rate abroad, 3M said, but the stronger dollar reduced the size of the foreign increase. For all of 1996, 3M said it expected solid sales and earnings growth despite the strong currency. 
 The company announced last November that it would spin off its imaging and data-storage businesses, shut down its audiotape and videotape production and take some smaller steps. It will concentrate on its industrial and consumer group and its life-sciences sector, whose products include a wide variety of medical supplies. It plans the spinoff for July 1 and expects to close the tape businesses by the end of the year.
In reporting earnings today, 3M did not include the operations that are being discontinued in the results for the 1996 first quarter but did so in the results for the 1995 quarter.
Net income in the latest quarter equaled profit from continuing operations and stood at $362 million, or 87 cents a share. That was down from the net income of $376 million a year earlier, or 90 cents a share, which included $21 million, or 5 cents a share, from the discontinued operations. But it was up 2 percent from the 1995 profit from continuing operations of $355 million, or 85 cents a share.
The profit of 87 cents a share in the latest quarter matched the average forecast of nine analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. On the New York Stock Exchange today, 3M's shares fell by 50 cents, to $65.375.
Revenue rose 3.2 percent in the first quarter, to $3.47 billion from $3.36 billion.
"We achieved record sales and profits despite slow growth of major world economies, strengthening of the U.S. dollar and negative effects from raw material costs," Livio D. DeSimone, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.
He added, "While we saw solid growth in a number of business areas, including pharmaceuticals, consumer products, office supplies and personal-care products, demand was soft in the industrial markets." Demand was especially slow in the auto, furniture and textiles industries, the company said.
International revenue increased 4 percent in the quarter, lifted by sales in Japan, elsewhere in Asia and Latin America, 3M said. Unit sales rose 6 percent and prices rose 2 percent. The stronger dollar, however, pared the results.

HEADLINE: Business Group Sees Strong Job Creation

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Contending that public anxiety about job insecurity has been exaggerated, a major business organization argued yesterday in a new report that the economy was creating millions of higher-paying jobs and this "occupational upgrading" should in time ameliorate the fear over layoffs.
The report from the Committee for Economic Development, a research group financed mostly by major corporations, comes on the heels of a similar report by the National Association of Manufacturers. Together they constitute an endorsement by big business of the Clinton Administration's position, set forth in its own white paper last week. They also represent an unusual appeal to Republicans, usually closely allied with business, to resist attacks on the Administration that focus on the anxiety about corporate layoffs. 
 "We tend to agree with the Administration that some of the hand-wringing is inappropriate," said Van Doorn Ooms, the committee's research director. "Our message to Republicans is: Recognize that we need investment in education and training, so that people who lose jobs can move successfully to the better jobs that are being created."
Republican leaders say they are still debating how to approach the issue.
The Committee for Economic Development acknowledged that layoffs and concern about widespread income stagnation were powerful and closely linked national issues. But while big companies have eliminated millions of jobs, the report said, they create just as many as they destroy by cutting jobs in some departments and adding them in others.
Relying on available data, the committee's report said that the quality of these new jobs was rising. "Fifty-four percent of the net employment growth during 1983-1993 took place in occupations with above-average earnings," the report stated. It also found, however, "rapid job growth in the lowest-paying service occupations."
Like the committee, the Administration and the lobbying group representing manufacturers called attention to the anxiety about jobs so evident in anecdotal evidence and opinion polls. But Jerry Jasinowski, president of the manufacturers association, called the fear "less and less rational." And the Clinton Administration, in a white paper prepared by the President's Council of Economic Advisers, suggested that layoffs had declined since 1993 while steady improvement in the economy was translating into better jobs.
"The news about the quality of net job growth is encouraging, and bodes well for the future," the White House economists declared. "Although there is still much to be done, recent trends show that the labor market is on the right track."
Many Democrats, convinced that emphasizing the good news about job creation should have top billing in the coming election campaign, are lining up behind the new message.
Republicans are having a more difficult time sorting out their approach. Senator Connie Mack of Florida, the Republican chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, acknowledged in an interview that his party was divided over whether to emphasize job insecurity, an issue highlighted by Patrick J. Buchanan during his failed bid to win the Republican Presidential nomination. "We are in discussions on this in the Senate," he said, "but the discussions have not jelled yet."
But if the Administration and the two business organizations are embracing the evidence of robust job creation, some economists say the reports fail to explain why wages for most of the nation's work force, totaling 125 million people, have barely improved after five years of economic growth. Amid the job churning aimed at improving economic competitiveness, the median wage for all American workers, adjusted for inflation, has remained essentially unchanged through the 1990's. (The median means that half of all workers earn more and half less.)
The Administration's report focused only on the 8.5 million jobs added since Mr. Clinton took office, and examined in detail the net job growth of about four million between February 1994 and last February. The report concluded that two-thirds of the growth was in full-time employment at more than $480 a week, the nation's median wage.
Joseph E. Stiglitz, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, acknowledged in an interviewthat this was not the whole story. "We don't really know what is happening to wages," he said. "But it is better to have a balanced discussion based on available statistics, than to have one based on stereotypes and hysteria."
The White House paper examined a variety of occupation categories and found that most of the job creation was in the better-paying, higher-skilled categories. None were named, but the number of computer programmers and systems analysts, for example, grew to 1,486,000 in 1995 from 1,465,000 in 1994. Programmers and systems analysts earn more than the national median. But the statistics available to the council -- or to any researcher -- do not disclose much more.
Based on the available data, it cannot be determined whether those holding the 21,000 additional jobs were paid above or below the median wage for their categories. What is more, the report did not say whether the median for any of the categories studied by the council rose or fell in the two-year period or how many people moved from higher-paid to lower-paid jobs or vice versa.
"We don't have the data to address the angst that might result from losing a job without being able to find another at comparable pay," Mr. Stiglitz said. "Going from anecdotal evidence to statistical evidence is not easy, but we are going to try to do this eventually."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Drops by U.S. Stocks and Bonds Push the Dollar Down Broadly

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell broadly yesterday, following United States stocks and bonds lower.
The dollar slid from 15-month highs against the German mark, and also fell against the Swiss franc and Japanese yen. 
 The bond and stock markets tumbled after the United States Government reported that the country's gross domestic product grew by 2.8 percent in the first quarter, faster than expected and raising fears of inflation.
"You could use the argument the dollar came off with the bond market," said Jim Phoenix, director of foreign exchange sales at the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. "But if you did, then you clearly weren't aware of what's been going on the last several weeks, where the dollar has continued to climb on good numbers."
Strong economic reports have recently bolstered the dollar by indicating that interest rates would remain steady or rise. Higher interest rates typically bolster a currency by making deposits denominated in it more attractive.
But currency traders chose to focus yesterday on the effects of foreign investors selling American stocks and bonds and converting the proceeds into other currencies.
"When people are cashing out of North American markets they do that via the dollar into something else," said Kevin Harris, an international economist at MCM Currencywatch.
In early trading, the dollar continued its recent climb against the mark and Swiss franc. But after the strong G.D.P. report was released, United States bonds fell and the dollar soon followed.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.5283 marks, down from 1.5363 marks on Wednesday, and at 1.2440 Swiss francs, down from 1.2505 francs. The dollar fell to 104.35 Japanese yen from 105.32 yen.
The British pound, which fell sharply on Wednesday on concerns over the stability of the ruling Conservative Party, recovered to $1.5025 yesterday, up from $1.4915.
Anticipation of today's report on April employment in the United States may have accelerated the selling of dollars yesterday.
Stronger-than-expected payrolls data in February and March roiled the bond and currency markets and traders sought the safety of neutral positions ahead of the data.
"I'd say there was profit taking because the dollar has made new highs for the up cycle and we're coming into more significant data," Mr. Harris of MCM Currencywatch said.

HEADLINE: In a Sign of Changing Times, Shanghai Shelters Battered Women

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, May 2

 BODY:
In a country where family problems have traditionally remained behind closed doors, wife-beating has often been endured without relief or outside interference.
But untold side effects from China's deep economic and social change are bubbling up everywhere. The upside is Shanghai has opened its first shelter for battered women; the downside is that there appears to be a growing need for such a place. 
 Since early this year a slow trickle of women have made their way to the Nanfang Family Violence Protection Center, a collection of spartan rooms in a bare, concrete building on the outskirts of town. There are 20 beds and a friendly but untrained staff.
It is telling, too, that the shelter was established by a private entrepreneur, and not by the Government, which seems unable to cope with the array of problems that now yank at the corners of China's social fabric.
"Our society is changing so fast it creates pressures and problems that weren't there before," said Zhang Zhijing, the businessman who set up the center with $60,000 from his company, Zhijing Baoye Ltd. "Some men take out their frustrations at home, and I thought we should do something about it."
Mr. Zhang believes that the problem, still not as serious as in many Western countries, is getting worse. Yet no one keeps statistics on complaints of violence against wives in China, and part of the growing awareness of family violence comes from women who are shedding the age-old reluctance to openly discuss a problem that has always existed.
China Women's News recently reported that family violence is now cited as a cause of about one-quarter of the nation's divorces, which topped one million last year. In many cities and towns, neighborhood committees organized by the Communist Party, which once mediated, and intruded in, family disputes, are now receding.
In one city, Changsha in Hunan Province, the local government recently passed what appears to be China's first regulation specifically aimed at preventing violence against wives. The Constitution already bans the mistreatment of women, but the new regulation instructs the police to respond to complaints of wife-beating thoroughly and sympathetically.
Mr. Zhang said he got the idea of opening Shanghai's center last year when he read a newspaper report that among failed suicide attempts by women jumping off a bridge into the Huangpu River in Shanghai, two-thirds were women who said family troubles were too hard to bear.
"In America, there are more than 2,000 centers like this," Mr. Zhang said. "We should have at least one."
Whether his company will attract favorable treatment by the Government, such as tax relief, for its good deed, Mr. Zhang said, is unclear. But he said he welcomes support from individuals and foundations.
Most women who come to Nanfang -- hundreds of calls so far, a few dozen stay-overs -- do so because they have been beaten repeatedly. There are also a few unusual cases.
"Three schoolgirls came because they were afraid their parents would beat them since they'd done poorly on school exams," Mr. Zhang said. "We let them stay overnight and called their families the next day."
More typical is the case of Yin Jianqin, who said she had suffered violence at her husband's hand ever since they married 15 years ago, a union arranged by their mothers. "I tried to leave a couple of times, but my neighbors and family always urged me to go back," she said. "The women here are different. They say it's my own decision what I do."

HEADLINE: Market Place: Lowering the Bar For Corporate Earnings;
Does Wall St. Forecast Performance or Set the Pace?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
It all depends on what you expect. If a child comes home from school with nothing but C's on a report card, parental reaction may be outrage and anger. But if the preliminary indications had been for D's and F's, the reaction may be one of relief and even congratulations.
So it is now with Wall Street's view of corporate America's first-quarter earnings. "There has been a lot of talk about how great profits are and how they are so much better than expected," said Melissa Brown, the director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities. "But they are just better than recently reduced expectations." 
 In fact, by one measure, corporate America underperformed Wall Street's original expectations by the greatest amount in years. Not since the recession of 1990 have as few companies done better than Wall Street originally hoped.
Consider Compaq Computer. Last week, it announced first-quarter profits of 85 cents a share, better than the 82 cents that had become the Wall Street consensus, and the stock leaped up. But back in January, the Wall Street consensus was $1.04 a share. The company had talked that figure down, warning of pressure on profit margins.
Compaq's saga is an illustration of the expectations game on Wall Street, where forecasts change regularly and small investors can easily be baffled. Many companies now "pre-announce" earnings, causing the stock to rise or fall well before the actual release. When the real number does come out, it appears that the analysts had a good handle on what was happening, and what would have been bad news a month earlier can be perceived as positive.
In this year's first quarter, the slashing of earnings expectations was, in part, a result of fear that the economy was slowing and that earnings would be disappointing. But when actual earnings reports were released beginning last month, much of the commentary said they were better than expected -- that is, better than the lowered expectations -- and many stocks rose.
A composite earnings report of about 1,000 large companies would show first-quarter profits up about 8.5 percent from the similar period a year earlier, Ms. Brown said, or about three percentage points better than expected. "But estimates came down a lot in the month from March 15 to April 15," she added. "If you compare the actual profits to March 15 expectations, they were just about in line."
One data series that ignores such last-minute adjustments is kept by Tom Doerflinger, an analyst at Paine Webber. It takes the consensus estimate for 335 large companies one month into the quarter -- when it really is a forecast -- and compares that with what is actually reported.
With 273 of those companies having reported, Mr. Doerflinger said, only 11 percent have registered positive surprises, while 29 percent have registered negative surprises. A surprise is defined as actual earnings at least 10 percent above or below the estimate.
In many cases, of course, when those earnings are reported, they are viewed as being better than expected. "Expectations for earnings fell a lot over the three months starting in November," Mr. Doerflinger said, "and earnings are generally meeting lowered expectations."
But considering where expectations were before they were lowered, the numbers do not look good at all, though they are only a bit worse than the fourth quarter of last year, when the figures were 12 percent positive surprises and 27 percent negative surprises. The figures have generally been declining since peaking in the fourth quarter of 1994.
Not since the final quarter of 1991 had so many companies done worse than forecast; not since the final quarter of 1990 had so few done better.
The companies most likely to do better than had been expected have been primarily in two industries blessed by surprisingly good business conditions: Wall Street and oil. The oil companies are selling oil and gasoline for a lot more than anyone expected, to the consternation of President Clinton, among others. And Wall Street has basked in the profits from strong sales of new securities and rising stock prices, notwithstanding the fact that bond prices have fallen. A lot of utilities also did better than expected, probably thanks to cold weather bolstering sales.
But there were disappointments in many companies that specialize in commodities, from paper to chemicals, where strong gains in prices last year have come under pressure this year.
To be sure, there is nothing unusual about Wall Street earnings estimates coming down. Analysts usually start off overly optimistic about most companies, and then pare their estimates as the year goes on. Some cynics say that reflects the fact analysts are trying to sell stock, but it is more likely that they are reflecting the hopes of the companies they follow. The pattern is not unlike the optimism many students feel in September when the school year starts, with a tempering of expectations coming later.
Late last year, that tempering on Wall Street took an extreme form. With concern about a slowing economy, analysts shaved their 1996 estimates at a rapid rate. By late December, analysts were cutting two estimates for every one they raised, according to figures from IBES, which monitors brokerage house estimates.
In fact, as the Government reported yesterday, the first quarter's economic growth was stronger than many had forecast, and the earnings of many companies were not as bad as they had come to fear.
Now, with widespread talk of a relatively strong economy and concern that growth is so strong that the Federal Reserve may actually begin to tighten credit later this year, analysts are back in a happy mood. For the last two weeks, they have raised more estimates than they have cut.
Just as analysts went too far this winter in reducing expectations, it is possible to go too far in raising them as well, as some students have learned after bringing home report cards with mostly A's but one or two B's scattered in. If that happens on Wall Street, a quarter later this year could find companies reporting numbers that are in fact pretty good, but that nevertheless are deemed disappointing by investors.
 For when it comes to earnings, the reality can be less important than how they compare with the sometimes-arbitrary and often-changing expectations generated by the companies and the analysts who follow them.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "The Expectations Game: One Example" shows analysts' first-quarter earning forcasts and actual earnings for Compaq Computer from Jan. to April. "A Bad Quarter. . ." shows the percentage of large stocks whose earnings were at least 10 percent better or worse than the consensus forecast one month into each quarter from first-quarter 1994 to first-quarter 1996. ". . . That Began to Look Good" shows the ratio of the number of analysts increasing 1996 earnings estimates on companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 to the number decreasing them. LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Plunge On Signs of Strong Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Data indicating a strong economic expansion sent Treasury prices tumbling yesterday, pushing interest rates to their highest level in a year.
The selloff followed reports showing faster-than-expected economic growth in the first quarter and a drop in the weekly unemployment claims report that was larger than expected. The losses were exacerbated by a report showing a big increase in March factory orders. 
 The data sketched an economy that is taking its first strides toward a full-blown expansion, and thus raised concerns among investors that inflation -- which diminishes the value of fixed-income investments like bonds -- would soon accelerate.
Still, the selloff was somewhat surprising since the market had previously seemed to be in a holding pattern awaiting today's release of April employment data.
"Is the economy growing quickly enough to warrant serious concern about overheating?" asked James Padinha, an economist with MMS International. "The jobs report will help answer the question, at least the debt market thinks so."
Unless the employment numbers todaysubstantially revise the views of market participants, many traders and analysts now expect that the Federal Reserve will soon have to raise short-term interest rates to keep a damper on inflation.
"Given the widening spread between the Federal funds rate and the yield on a two-year Treasury note, the market clearly is building in a Fed tightening at some future point," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
The Federal funds target rate -- the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans and a sensitive indicator of the direction of interest rates -- stands at 5.25 percent, and the spread between it and the yield on the two-year note, 6.18 percent, widened to 93 basis points yesterday from 74 basis points the previous session. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended the day down 122/32 , to 86 30/32 . Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions from each other, and the selloff yesterday drove the yield on the 30-year bond -- a crucial benchmark for mortgages and other consumer rates -- up to 7.05 percent from 6.91 percent on Wednesday.
It was the highest the yield has been since May 4, 1995, when it was 7.16 percent. Bondholders lost about $16.88 for every $1,000 they invested in bonds.
Bonds began to tumble after the Commerce Department reported that the economy grew at an annual rate of 2.8 percent for the first three months of the year -- much faster than the market had expected.
"The economy's performance during the first quarter seems even more remarkable given the hindering effects of the Government shutdown, the blizzard, and the G.M. strike," Mr. Fine said, referring to labor strife afflicting the General Motors Corpration.
Signs of an expansion were also visible in other reports. Initial claims for unemployment insurance dropped last week to a rather low level of 348,000. And March factory orders rose 1.5 percent, aided in large part by a 2.5 percent surge in new orders for durable goods.
The gains in yesterday's reports made market participants even more jittery about today's employment report. The two previous monthly employment reports showed surprising strength in the job market, roiling the market both times.
Mr. Fine said that economists had forecast that the report today would show a rise in the number of jobs nationwide, anywhere from a small gain of 25,000 to a rather large one of 225,000.
"Any payroll gain in excess of 175,000 would very likely be viewed in an unfavorable light and continue to justify the bond market's decidedly negative tone," he said.
"Conversely, an increase of 100,000 or less would be constructive, but given the one-way nature of the recent spate of economic data, the market would likely view it more as an aberration rather than as a reason to change its collective view," Mr. Fine said.

HEADLINE: David Kennedy, Ex-Treasury Chief, Dies at 90

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
David M. Kennedy, who was Secretary of the Treasury in the first two years of the Nixon Administration, died Wednesday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 90, and had long suffered from a heart ailment.
Mr. Kennedy, whose career included a succession of Government and business posts, came to prominence as chairman of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company when it was Chicago's largest bank. As chairman, he was credited with reinvigorating it after a long malaise and establishing a strong overseas presence. 
 He was chosen by President-elect Richard M. Nixon in late 1968 for the top Treasury job, which he held until resigning in late 1970 under pressure from Mr. Nixon, who was unhappy with the nation's stagnant economy and rising inflation. Mr. Kennedy was succeeded by John B. Connally, a politically astute former Governor of Texas who had been Secretary of the Navy under President John F. Kennedy.
An early gaffe committed by David Kennedy even before being sworn in to his Treasury post was his refusal at a news conference to rule out the possibility that the Government might raise the price of gold, then fixed officially at $35 an ounce. Shortly afterward he caused another stir with a similar comment about imposing wage and price controls to curb inflation.
On leaving the Treasury, Mr. Kennedy was appointed Ambassador at Large, remaining in the Nixon Cabinet, and the President subsequently named him United States Permanent Representative on the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Mr. Kennedy was the son of a Utah rancher and legislator, working on the ranch in the summer and attending school in nearby Ogden in the winter. He frustrated his family's expectations that he would succeed his grandfather as president of the Bank of Randolph when, as a student at Weber State College in Ogden, he decided on a law career.
After a two-year mission in Britain for the Mormon Church, Mr. Kennedy came to Washington to work as a technical assistant in the Federal Reserve System. He later described this experience -- reopening and liquidating banks -- as having turned his interest to economics and banking, "and I became impressed with the cooperation possible between business and government."
He later rose to special assistant to Marriner Eccles, another native of Utah, then chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Kennedy also received a law degree after attending George Washington University at night.
In 1946, passing up an offer from a New York bank that would have paid him six times as much, Mr. Kennedy joined the bond department of Continental Bank. By 1955 he was named president, shortly after returning from a 14-month period in which he served as assistant to Treasury Secretary George M. Humphrey.
After leaving the Government, Mr. Kennedy developed a close business relationship with Michele Sindona, the financier who controlled Franklin National Bank in New York, which collapsed in scandal. Mr. Kennedy testified at a 1979 trial of three former Franklin executives that he had introduced Mr. Sindona to bank regulators and officials here and abroad, and had once borrowed $200,000 from the financier for a land venture in Arizona.
Mr. Kennedy held various lay positions with the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, including special representative -- a kind of international ambassador -- for the First Presidency, the top governing body of the Mormon Church.
Mr. Kennedy's wife, the former Lenora Bingham, died last fall. The couple had four daughters.

HEADLINE: At the Pumps, High-Octane Pain

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: McLEAN, Ill., May 2

 BODY:
Pulling his thirsty rig into the truck stop, Dave Morisset longed for the good old days of cheaper fuel -- about six weeks ago.
Then, it cost him $160 to fill his truck. Now it costs him $200. The worst of it, he said, is that it will cost him a chance to watch his son's track meet this weekend. 
 "I've had to add an extra trip every week," said the 38-year-old Minnesota trucker, "just to pay for the extra fuel costs." So Mr. Morisset, who is married and has four children, now spends six or seven days a week on the road, instead of the usual five.
"My boy's got another meet I'll have to miss," he said. "And now that it's starting to warm up, I'm going to want to go fishing with my girls. It really hurts."
Around the diesel pumps at the Dixie Trucker Home on the old Route 66 here, long a favorite among over-the-road professionals, there has been a lot of talk this week about the soaring gas prices -- and about who is responsible.
"You don't know exactly who to blame," said Bill Caddenhead, 45, a long-distance trucker from Houston who takes turns behind the wheel with his wife, Donna, 49. "And you can't drive any slower, or you won't get over the hills."
Across the nation, many Americans have begun to notice a hole in their pockets, and have reacted with a mix of outrage, suspicion, puzzlement and it-could-be-worse (and probably will be) fatalism.
Among farmers in the Mississippi Delta and cab drivers in Manhattan, plumbers in California, truckers in Wyoming and commuters in far-flung suburbs of Virginia, the increases are seen as a real threat, especially because people feel helpless.
"There are some things you can't do anything about," said Ray Makamson, 64, who raises cotton and soybeans in Greenwood, Miss. "You can't quit."
In the biggest increases since the Gulf War in 1991, diesel fuel prices have risen nationally by an average of about 17 cents, or 15 percent, in the past 10 weeks, and more than 5 cents in the past week alone. The price of gasoline also has increased, by about 10 percent, to an average of $1.27 for a gallon of regular. Oil companies say many factors, including a harsh winter and higher demand, are to blame.
Some trucking companies have tried to pass along some of the price increases. "You are probably going to see prices going up a little for everything from food to clothing," said Ed Pooser, the director of operations for the Florida Trucking Association.
Even the neighborhood ice cream vendor is feeling the pinch, and asking children to ante up a little extra.
Kirpal Chauhen, who drives a 5 Star Ice Cream truck in Santa Rosa, Calif., said he could not bear the rising gas prices alone.
"I had to do it," he said, defending the increase in the red, blue and white Superstar Stick to $1, from 75 cents.
But most businesses say they will be forced to absorb the extra costs. Al Degendorfer, whose plumbing business in Los Angeles has three vehicles and monthly fuel bills of $500, said the increases would surely cut into profits.
Mr. Degendorfer added that he was unhappy with Federal levies on gasoline. "We pay 18 cents a gallon in tax," he said. "That's ridiculous."
Some people said that most of the complaints were just talk. "We moan and we groan," said Frederick D. Smith, 44, who lives in Orange, Va., and makes the long commute to Washington, "but we still pay the price."
Nobody is expected to feel the price increases more keenly than truckers, at least those like Mr. Morisset who own their rigs and pay for their fuel.
As it is, many long-haul drivers sleep in their trucks, instead of motels, to cut costs. Mr. Morisset, who bunks in his cab and relies on truck-stop showers, said he could net as much as $40,000 a year if he was careful with expenses.
But the price of fuel, if it continues to rise, could virtually ruin an operator like Mr. Morisset, who is paid at flat rates that have not yet reflected the higher costs. He would like to see prohibitions against Iraqi oil sales removed.
"Without all of the Middle Eastern oil in the world supply," he said, "prices could really skyrocket."
Fuel prices have actually remained comparatively low in the past decade, especially when inflation is taken into account.
In the view of a German tourist on vacation in Florida, Americans may be making too big a fuss about the increases. "I think no German would change plans in the United States because of the price of the gasoline," said Ernst Zieringer, who noted that back home in Munich, gasoline costs the equivalent of $3.78 a gallon, largely because of taxes.
Even talk of such high fuel prices would be verboten in this country, of course. Americans tend to feel about cars much the same way they do about, say, oxygen.
And while some people have talked lately about car-pooling, bicycling and walking, the freeways do not seem any less crowded.
In some cases, angry words are directed at the oil companies, or at President Clinton, who gets more blame for successfully pushing for a 4.3-cent addition to the gasoline tax three years ago than credit for his recent decision to sell some oil reserves in an effort to keep prices down.
The President should be blamed for the higher prices, said a 42-year-old Illinois man who declined to give his name. "I'm the same age and size as Rush Limbaugh," the man said, "but not as liberal." He said he hoped the gas increases would send the economy into a tailspin, and doom Mr. Clinton's re-election chances against his likely opponent, Senator Bob Dole.
But more often, people did not seem to view the oil price as a partisan issue. "Clinton or Dole, I don't see where that's going to make any difference about what the pump reads," said Mr. Caddenhead, the trucker from Houston.
Skepticism about big oil companies has long run deep in American society, from resentments toward the old Rockefeller barons to anger over the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska.
"The oil companies are ripping us off again," said Steve Allen, 37, a contract administrator in Fairfax, Va., who drives 50 miles to work every day. "They're blaming it on cold weather. They haven't fooled me and they haven't fooled most people. It's profits."
Kwasi Ampadu, a New York taxi driver, also voiced suspicions. "Even during the gulf war, the increase was not so high," he said. "I don't get it."
In the view of Susan Sysler, a 53-year-old worker at a Jewish community center in Los Angeles, it all boils down to muscle and influence. And the average consumer does not have enough.
"I think it has to do with where the oil comes from, and who has the strongest lobby, and who has the most power," Ms. Sysler said.
A few people, but only a few, looked elsewhere for the culprit: into the mirror.
"This is all about supply and demand," said Walter Ossanna, a 36-year-old trucker from Bondurant, Wyo., who stopped at the Dixie truck stop for its $4.85 Mudflap Special of steak, eggs and hash browns. "Look at the way we're living, the way we consume, the way we waste our resources. The oil companies charge what the market will bear. It's not that complicated."
To be sure, Americans have once again become infatuated with gas-guzzlers, especially sport-utility vehicles. Three-car garages have become standard in many expensive new houses. And suburbia marches deeper into formerly rural America every year, raising commuting distances and gas consumption.
Mr. Ossanna offered that he would not win any popularity contests with his views. Anyway, he cheerfully confessed to being a hypocrite on the subject.
"I'm as guilty as anybody else," he said. "I seem to own one of everything that comes with a set of wheels."

HEADLINE: Paris Journal;
At Dinner Table, More Than Beef Falls From Grace

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 2

 BODY:
Mad cow disease may be changing menus and habits throughout Europe, but in France, beef is not the only thing that is disappearing from the table.
The French eat less daily bread and not even a quarter of them drink wine daily with meals any more, as their way of life becomes more hurried, more health-conscious, and, well, more like life everywhere else, including the United States. 
 And for all the 70 percent butterfat cheese the French still consume, health consciousness and weight watching have begun to change the way they look at eating meat. Making money used to be known as "earning your beefsteak." No longer.
Marc Nourry, wearing a white apron the other day in his Boucheries Reunies meat market, sees the changes every day. "We've been selling less and less red meat even before the crisis, but since March I've been selling less than half as much beef as I usually did.
"But all kinds of things are very different nowadays -- Sunday used to be our biggest day, but these days most people go away for the weekend, and everybody always seems to be on a diet."
Since Britain set off an international crisis by reporting a possible link between bovine spongiform encephalopathy in British cattle and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which destroys human brain tissue, beef has been piling up in freezers all over Europe. The European Union banned the export of British beef on March 27, but millions of European consumers no longer want beef or veal, no matter where it comes from, according to butchers here who fear the change will be permanent.
Mr. Nourry's meat market is the kind of place you picture when you think of the way people have traditionally done their food shopping in France -- often, still, at open-air markets, with separate stops at the butcher's, the baker's, the greengrocer's and, this being France, the local wine merchant's as well.
But 65 percent of the French buy most of their food in supermarkets these days, though some are having second thoughts, perhaps because they cannot ask a live butcher where the meat comes from.
"I never bought meat in supermarkets, and I wouldn't think of it now," said a customer making her way down the Rue des Belles Feuilles. "At least with butchers we have some guarantee that the meat really isn't British, but at the supermarket, who knows?"
Even before the "mad cow" scare, the French were consuming 17 percent less beef than they were in 1980, and 28 percent less veal, according to statistics gathered by the consumer division of the Finance and Economics Ministry.
But the bottom fell out of the French meat market with the British crisis in March. Since then, wholesale butchers' business has slipped 20 to 50 percent, trade groups say.
Consumption of fish and fowl has been rising here since the late 1980's, along with health awareness, but vegetarianism has not yet become as widespread in France as it is in the United States, despite such famous converts to the cause as Brigitte Bardot.
Even bread isn't sacred in France any more, according to the baking trade. Where the French ate a daily average of 20 ounces of bread per capita in 1960, last year they ate an average of 5 ounces of it.
Women eat even less, an average of barely 4 ounces of bread a day, according to the National Association of French Millers, and often the bread they eat is not the traditional crusty baguette but softer stuff sold prepackaged in supermarkets.
"Bread is a part of our identity," said Agriculture Minister Philippe Vasseur recently. The baking industry began a campaign last year to encourage more people to eat bread, with the slogan, "If we don't keep eating bread, one day there won't be any more."
At the Bechu Bakery on the Avenue Victor Hugo, where the words on the window advise window shoppers that bread is even better if people actually eat it, customers still line up on Sunday mornings to buy baguettes for lunch, but according to Roland Amon, the owner, "Younger customers buy a lot less than their parents did."
"Bakers are like winemakers -- we all use very simple basic materials, but everybody produces a product that tastes unique," he said. "It's uniformity that will kill us."
But today, if you think the French never sit down to a table without a bottle of wine, even rough vin ordinaire in plastic containers, marketing surveys done by the wine industry say you are wrong. Drinking wine with meals is no longer a daily habit for nearly 80 percent of the French people today. As recently as 1980, it was, for 41 percent of them, according to the Vinexpo Institute, affiliated with the principal wine trade organization in Bordeaux.
And the trend away from wine drinking is even stronger among people under 25, according to a poll of 4,000 people the institute commissioned last year.
Nearly 70 percent of 14- to 25-year-olds surveyed then said they never consumed any wine, compared with 48 percent in 1980, and 87 percent of young non-drinkers said the reason was that they did not like the way wine tastes. Fifteen years ago, nearly a quarter of all 25-year-olds in France said they drank wine regularly with meals. Last year, fewer than 5 percent did.
Colette Barbey, a widow in her 80's who lives in Neuilly, said: "I can't get over how my granddaughter cooks. She will fry a couple of crepes and maybe a bit of ham, with a salad, and call that dinner."
Describing herself as "part of a tradition dating from the 19th century, really," Mrs. Barbey said that family lunches 30 years ago at her house always consisted of four courses. "My husband always wanted a carefully composed meal at fixed hours, and we always had wine."
A survey by the Center for Research on the Study and Observation of Conditions of Life recently showed that 47 percent of the French now eat lunch outside of the home at least once a week. The noontime family meal at home used to be the only one at which meat was served, but the urban way of life of dual-income, commuting families has altered that tradition.
Surprisingly, most said their usual meal was often potatoes and vegetables. Only 5 percent admitted to eating hamburgers at restaurants.
Doing as the French do can have its advantages. According to the International Journal of Obesity, only 6.2 percent of men in France and 6.3 percent of women were classified as obese last year, compared with 32 and 33.5 percent in the United States.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The bottom has fallen out of the beef market in France, but on Rue de Rochechouart in Paris a butcher, Jean Louis Oliviera, has chosen to face the crisis with humor, advising on one sign, "Here, cows are mad-ly good!" (Paul Aiken for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mayor Keeps His Distance From New Insurance Plan

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani distanced himself yesterday from a report by an advisory board he appointed, which proposed that the city levy a surcharge on hospital fees and insurance premiums to subsidize health insurance for those without it.
Calling the recommendations a "very important beginning" in solving the problem of how to finance health care for the uninsured, the Mayor nevertheless said he was not ready to endorse them. 
 "It's a very thoughtful proposal and has a lot to it," Mr. Giuliani said at a City Hall briefing. But he added that he didn't want to be "locked into one way" of providing and paying for health care for the indigent.
Although the panel has been studying indigent care since August, the Mayor referred to its plan as a beginning and a vehicle for encouraging debate. Even though his chief health policy adviser, Maria K. Mitchell, headed the task force, he stopped short of embracing its findings.
"There's no one naive enough to think that this plan will get through in this form," Mr. Giuliani said.
The plan would involve a fundamental departure from the way the city now pays for medical care for people who don't have insurance, in which hospitals that treat them are subsidized and reimbursed.
The seven-member panel called the current system fragmented and inefficient, offering little incentive for people to seek primary care and forcing the uninsured to rely on emergency rooms.
The plan, which would subsidize insurance for 900,000 of the city's 1.5 million uninsured residents, would cost $1.5 billion annually. Most of the money would come from a 2 percent tax on the fees of hospitals and insurers. The rest would come from the state charity fund that now subsidizes hospitals treating the poor and from savings projected from the moving of Medicaid recipients into managed care plans.
Several administration officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that the Mayor's reluctance to embrace the plan stemmed from fear of the political repercussions if he supported a new tax.
"Call it what you want," said one City Hall official, "an assessment, a surcharge, whatever. It's a tax and taxes are not popular." Mr. Giuliani is expected to seek re-election next year.
The advisory panel's proposals drew mixed reactions from politicians and workers in the health care industry. While expressing pleasure that the group had focused attention on the question of how to help the uninsured, many analysts were doubtful about the financing proposals and their support among legislators and health care providers. They also said they were not sure how this plan could be reconciled with a proposal by Gov. George E. Pataki to overhaul the financing of hospital care, which would include an end to the state's setting of hospital rates.
"We're glad there's a recognition here that a system to protect the indigent needs to be set up," said Michael Clendenin, a City Council spokesman. "But we're going to have to take a harder look at the financing. Who would really be paying the tax? It's easy to assume it will be passed down to the consumer."
In a clear sign that Ms. Mitchell was working hard to encourage industry support of the plan, she invited the directors of two leading health care trade organizations to join her at the City Hall news conference: Kenneth Raske, executive director of the Greater New York Hospital Association, and Stephen I. Lewis, first senior vice president of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York and chairman of the New York State H.M.O. Council.
"It makes good economic sense and good health sense to re-enfranchise this disenfranchised population," Mr. Lewis said.
Mr. Raske called the report "an enormous leap forward as a statement." But financing it, he said, remains "a vexing issue for all of us."
Like the Mayor, Mr. Raske referred to the plan as a starting point; he called it a blueprint and a springboard. And he, too, stopped short of endorsing its recommendations for raising the necessary revenues.
Bill Gradison, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group in Washington, said he supported subsidizing health insurance for people who cannot afford it because it allowed people to get health care in appropriate settings: primary care in doctors' offices and clinics, and hospitalization when necessary.
But he said that taxing insurance premiums "would be counterproductive," because it would force insurers to raise premiums and would encourage employers to cut back workers' health insurance coverage.
One thing left unsaid in the report is how the plan would work if the administration succeeded in dissolving the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the agency that runs the city's 11 acute-care hospitals. In a report it issued in August, this advisory panel called on the city to dismantle the agency and sell off all the public hospitals, which each year serve hundreds of thousands of poor and uninsured New Yorkers.
John Ronches, executive director of the Committee of Interns and Residents, which represents the doctors-in-training who provide most of the front-line care at the city's public hospitals, criticized the panel's proposals, saying the public hospital system met the needs of the indigent "most efficiently and cheaply."

HEADLINE: Can Nashville Say No to N.F.L. Team? Maybe

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, April 30

 BODY:
For nearly a decade now, the status-hungry boomtowns of the South have sought instant membership in the major leagues through the relentless recruitment of professional sports teams. And in city after city, local governments have raided their treasuries to build expensive new stadiums, with barely a peep of protest from the taxpayers.
Now it is Nashville's turn. But unlike Charlotte (home to the N.F.L.'s Panthers and the N.B.A.'s Hornets) and Jacksonville (N.F.L.'s Jaguars) and Orlando (N.B.A.'s Magic) and St. Petersburg (where baseball's Devil Rays will play in 1998), a surprising degree of resistance has risen here to a May 7 referendum on building a publicly financed football stadium that would bring the Houston Oilers to middle Tennessee in 1998. 
 The anti-stadium movement has been stoked, leaders on both sides of the debate say, by an underlying sentiment that Nashville is growing too quickly. Although studies suggest that professional football would have negligible direct impact on the city's economy, many here see it as a symbol for progress that is not universally embraced.
After being repeatedly thwarted in efforts to get Houston to build a stadium to replace the aging Astrodome, the Oilers last year began making overtures to Nashville, the second-largest television market without a professional sports team.
No city without an N.F.L. franchise has ever rejected a team's offer to locate there.
But the Nashville referendum, said Mayor Philip Bredesen, has become "almost a cultural vote," not unlike the 1967 referendum that approved the sale of liquor by the drink.
"On one side are people who just really like the way Nashville was 20 years ago as a somewhat isolated, genteel Southern city," said Mr. Bredesen, who is leading the campaign to lure the Oilers. "And on the other side you've got people that want to be more like Jacksonville and Charlotte and Indianapolis and some of those kinds of frontline, growing cities."
Even if the referendum passes -- and a recent poll suggests that it will -- Nashville's anti-stadium heretics have managed to mount a challenge to the pro-growth theology preached so energetically by Sunbelt mayors and Chamber of Commerce officials.
After the Metro Council approved the $292 million stadium construction and team relocation plan earlier this year, opponents gathered 43,600 signatures on petitions in 20 days, more than enough to force a referendum. In the last two months, the anti-stadium forces have waged a spirited, David-versus-Goliath battle against the city's political and corporate establishment.
The coalition of opponents includes libertarians, who believe that government should play no role in financing the stadium, and liberals, who believe the city's money would be better spent on social programs. "It's not an appropriate priority for public funding," said David L. Kleinfelter, a member of the Metro Council. "We are not in a period when we need economic stimulation."
The stadium fight has been emotional. During a televised town hall meeting on Monday night, an audience member essentially told Michael McClure, the Oilers' executive vice president, that he was not welcome in town. After the event, a stadium proponent rejected a handshake offered by Mr. Kleinfelter.
Some families are deeply divided. Whenever Councilman Durward G. Hall has appeared on talk radio to explain his opposition to the deal, his son, Daron, has phoned in to tell him he is wrong. Mr. Hall's wife, Gayle, has planted a pro-stadium sign in their front yard.
"Will you be a witness at my divorce?" Mr. Hall asked in an interview.
Few would have thought such a brawl would break out in Nashville. Despite the renaissance of country music, it remains a triple-A town whose leaders are desperate to broaden their city's one-dimensional image and keep pace with the region's other aspiring Atlantas.
"This is a way for us to get noticed as something other than a small town with good country music," said Dick Darr, the chairman of Yes for Nashville, the pro-stadium campaign committee.
If the referendum fails, Oilers officials say they will take their team elsewhere. N.F.L. owners approved the move to Nashville this week.
The referendum is needed to approve the sale of $80 million in general obligation bonds for construction of the 67,000-seat stadium. The city's total contribution to the project would be about $150 million. The rest of the cost would be covered with state money and proceeds from the sale of licenses that permit fans to purchase season tickets.
Mr. Bredesen estimates that the city's annual debt service payments would be $8 million, less than 1 percent of its $900 million budget. Half of that amount would be collected by tapping surpluses amassed by Nashville's water utility, which charges some of the highest rates in the country. The rest would come from existing tax revenues.
Interestingly, Mr. Bredesen and Mr. Darr do not base their arguments for the referendum on the contention that professional football would inject millions of dollars into the local economy.
"I agree with the professors who say you can't justify building a stadium just on the direct economic benefits," Mr. Bredesen said, referring to numerous studies pointing out that professional sports primarily generate low-wage, part-time jobs. "It's a piece of it."
But in addition, Mr. Bredesen said, a pro team would help enhance the city's national presence, attract new businesses, keep young people from leaving town, and spur development of the east bank of the Cumberland River, where the stadium would be built. That area has long been an eyesore, dominated by aging factories, rusting barges and huge pyramids of sand.
Stadium opponents argue that public money should not be used to enrich a wealthy Texan, Bud Adams, the Oilers' owner. But they also pose questions about traffic and taxes and misplaced priorities in a metropolitan area where road and bridge and school construction has struggled to keep pace with 27-percent population growth over the last 15 years.
During that period, nonfarm employment in the eight-county metropolitan area has grown 65 percent. Violent crime in Nashville, while down 2 percent in the last year, is up 121 percent since 1980. The public school population, up 11 percent since 1985, has grown out of its buildings and now relies on 476 portable classrooms. Traffic flow on Nashville's interstates has increased by 40 percent in 10 years.
With the heavy support of downtown businesses, the Yes for Nashville organization has raised $399,000 in cash and another $60,000 in in-kind contributions. That is more than 20 times the money collected by Concerned Citizens for Nashville, the anti-stadium committee.
The pro-stadium group has advertised on television and radio and in newspapers, distributed 30,000 yard signs, made 16,000 phone calls and sent out three mailings. The anti-stadium group is so poor that it has asked volunteers to pick up postcards at headquarters and mail them at their own expense.
A poll published in The Tennessean this week showed that 56 percent of the 636 likely voters surveyed said they would vote for the referendum, with 34 percent opposed and 10 percent undecided.
But officials with both campaigns agree that anti-stadium voters are more committed to their cause and predicted that the vote would be closer than indicated by the poll.
And Mr. McClure, the Oilers vice president, said his team's history demonstrates the folly of predicting victory too early.
"Remember, I work for a football team that blew a 30-point lead not so long ago," he said, referring to the Oilers' second-half, 32-point collapse in its 1993 playoff game against Buffalo. "So I never feel comfortable until the final gun goes off."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economy Springs Back At a 2.8% Growth Rate
The economy revived in the first quarter, growing at an annual rate of 2.8 percent, the Commerce Department said. The report delighted the White House, where officials claimed credit for reviving an economic expansion that once seemed about to expire.
The gain would have been even greater if not for the blizzards in the East and a strike at General Motors. But the unexpected strength unnerved the financial markets. [Page A1.]
 
Business Optimism on Job Security
A business group contended that public anxiety about job insecurity has been exaggerated, saying that the economy was creating higher-paying jobs that in time should quiet the fears of layoffs. [D2.]
 
British Telecom Ends Merger Talks
British Telecom and Cable and Wireless ended their efforts to merge into a global giant after five months of talks. Regulatory hurdles were an important obstacle. [D5.]
 
Britain Blocks Power Mergers
Britain barred takeovers of its two biggest utilities, National Power and Powergen, thwarting a potential bid from Southern Company of Atlanta. A bid for National Power could have cost as much as $12 billion. [D5.]
 
Chairman Leaving RJR Nabisco
RJR Nabisco Holdings' chairman, Charles Harper, left, is retiring after leading the cigarette and food company through three turbulent years. Steven Goldstone, 50, who became chief executive in December, will take over as chairman. Some analysts say Mr. Harper let RJR's market share and stock price sag. [D4.]
 
Blow to Tobacco Ads on Billboards
Minnesota Mining, which runs the third-largest billboard advertising company, said it soon will stop taking cigarette ads. [A15.]
3M's net income fell 4 percent, to $362 million, but profit from operations rose 2 percent. The company is shedding some businesses. [D4.]
 
Clinton Vetoes Tort Bill
President Clinton vetoed a bill to limit the amounts that people injured by faulty products could win in lawsuits. [A1.]
 
Drag on Westinghouse Profit
Westinghouse reported a wider loss excluding gains and charges, mainly because of costs of its $5.4 billion purchase of CBS. [D4.]
 
HFS Adds Coldwell Banker
HFS, which has been in the residential real estate market less than a year, since it bought Century 21, agreed to buy Coldwell Banker, another well-known industry name. [D2.]
 
Big Loss at AST Research
AST Research, a maker of personal computers, said its loss ballooned to $115.7 million. It plans to cut 300 jobs. [D4.]
 
Giuliani Tests New Borrowing
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is to propose the creation of a public authority that would allow New York City to sidestep a state limit on the city's debt, officials said. [A1.]
 
American Express Courts Banks
American Express plans to ask banks to issue its cards. But if the banks agree, they would be competing with their own Visa and Mastercards. [D4.]
 
Film Division Hurts Turner
Turner posted a loss of nearly $10 million for the first quarter, mostly because of disappointing results at its Castle Rock film division, which produced "City Hall" and "Othello." Turner, which is being acquired by Time Warner, took a $60 million write-off for film losses. [D6.]
 
S.E.C. Takes Slap at Sulcus
The S.E.C. ordered Sulcus Computer not to use improper accounting methods to create phony profits. It contends that Sulcus improperly accounted for four acquisitions. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Victims Can Sue Gun Makers Over Sales, Judge Rules

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
In a novel Federal ruling, a judge in New York has held that victims of handgun violence may proceed with a lawsuit against the firearms industry to discover whether it failed to take adequate steps to prevent weapon sales to illegal buyers like teen-agers.
The ruling was announced in March by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn and elaborated on in court papers filed yesterday. It comes at the early stage of a lawsuit brought against 47 weapons producers by the families of two New Yorkers killed by handguns. 
 The decision also opens the doors for plaintiffs' lawyers to delve into the files of the world's biggest firearms companies to learn whether the industry has been negligent in preventing weapons from flowing into the vast illegal market for guns.
In the past, gun producers have been successfully sued for selling defective weapons and dealers have also been held responsible for selling their guns to illegal buyers, like people who were drunk. But several legal experts said the current case appeared to be the first that involves the industry's marketing practices.
"This is the first case that I'm aware of where someone has tried to hold the industry collectively liable," said Dennis Henigan of the Center to Prevent Handgun Violence, an advocacy group in Washington.
Under the Federal law, gun manufacturers distribute their weapons through dealers who are licensed by the Government to sell firearms. Still, a vast underground market for weapons has existed for years, often supplied by those who buy guns illegally or legally in states that have lax gun control laws for resale in places with tighter controls.
Richard Feldman, the executive director of the American Shooting Sports Council, a trade group based in Atlanta, said gun makers complied with all rules and regulations established by Congress and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco & Firearms, the Federal agency that oversees the gun industry.
"After a consumer purchases our product, we have no control over what happens to that product," Mr. Feldman added.
Still, the New York lawsuit comes at a time of mounting legal pressure against gun producers. Last year, a California state judge ruled that relatives and victims of a 1993 shooting that left seven people dead and six wounded in San Francisco could proceed with a lawsuit against Navegar, which produced the assault-style weapon used in the attack.
Last week, the owner of the Nevada pawn shop that legally sold the weapon used in those shootings reached a out-of-court settlement with plaintiffs, Mr. Henigan said.
The New York case was brought on behalf on the families of Njuzi Ray and David Johnstone, who were killed in separate shootings with legally obtained weapons. While Judge Weinstein denied efforts to turn the case into a class action, he has allowed plaintiffs lawyers to bring up to 28 more additional shooting victims into the case.
Elisa Barnes, a lawyer who represents the families of the two victims, said it was her intention to prove that gun manufacturers were aware of a booming illegal market for guns but did not take adequate steps to prevent illegal sales, like limiting the production of handguns.
"Their negligence is that they failed to distribute their products carefully," Ms. Barnes said. Manufacturers have denied the charge.
In March, Judge Weinstein initially denied a motion by manufacturers' lawyers to dismiss the case and ruled that it could proceed to trial, which is tentatively set for September. The court papers spelled out the reasons for his decision. Judge Weinstein noted, for example, that while firearms companies had pledged to sell weapons only to legitimate licensed retailers, the pledge did not appear to bind manufacturers to make sure that their distributors also adhered to it.
"At the heart of the plaintiff's theory, apparently, is the claim that defendant's negligence in methods of marketing handguns and flooding the handgun market has fostered the development of an extensive underground economy in handguns," Judge Weinstein wrote.
He also theorized that if the underlying cause of handgun violence was the growth of an illegal weapons market, then an appellate court might decide to divide responsibility among gun producers based on their share of the legal gun market.
Mr. Feldman, the trade group official, said he expected manufacturers to move again to have the case thrown out before it goes to trial.
"People are looking in the wrong direction by trying to use civil liability to solve a criminal problem," he said.
