LENGTH: 598 words

HEADLINE: Wisconsin's Bold, Risky Welfare Plan

 BODY:
Gov. Tommy Thompson has signed far-reaching legislation that, if he gets Washington's approval, would make Wisconsin the first state to end its welfare program. Under the law, the state would instantly stop giving cash aid to able-bodied applicants. Instead they would be put to work in private-sector jobs, subsidized if need be, or in community-service jobs.
There is much to admire in Wisconsin's forthright emphasis on work and support services. Mr. Thompson is one of the few Republican leaders who acknowledges the fact that welfare reform is expensive. The plan will initially exceed Wisconsin's current welfare expenditures by about $40 million a year, or 13 percent. The program would provide generous health and child-care subsidies to all working-poor families, not just those on welfare. That way welfare parents would no longer face the loss of these key benefits when they find work. The plan would also allow mothers to keep most of the child-support payments that are made by absent fathers. Individuals who are incapable of holding steady jobs could receive ongoing support for engaging in limited work and rehabilitation activities. 
 But there are troublesome provisions that are most easily seen by comparing the Wisconsin plan with President Clinton's welfare proposal. Mr. Clinton would have allowed welfare parents to spend up to two years in training or education programs. The Wisconsin plan provides for no training that is separated from work. This may steer some parents from intensive literacy and other needed training.
Mr. Clinton's plan would have imposed a two-year time limit on cash benefits, after which parents who obeyed the rules would be given a public-sector job if they could not find work on their own. The Wisconsin plan would impose no time limits on health or child-care benefits. But it would set a time limit of five years on job subsidies, without any commitment to extend the limit for parents -- perhaps half of those who start out in subsidized jobs -- who obeyed the rules but could not find unsubsidized work.
Mr. Thompson points out that, under his plan, the state would have the leeway of extending job subsidies beyond five years on a case-by-case basis. Guarantees, he says, muffle the welfare parent's incentive to find work and invite endless judicial challenge. That may be so. But his proposal exposes innocent children to risk. The record of states in creating public service jobs is poor. What happens when Wisconsin ends aid not tied to work, but fails to create the 40,000 jobs it might take to empty out its welfare rolls? What happens if Wisconsin's economy turns sour and the state cannot find money to cover health benefits for needy families?
Mr. Clinton's best response is to embrace the good parts of the Wisconsin plan without embracing all of its risks. He should insist that the plan be phased in slowly so that, for example, welfare benefits of large families would not, as proposed, be cut quickly. Wisconsin should be required to monitor its programs and publicize how many needy parents are thrown out of subsidized work. Mr. Clinton should also require a concrete commitment from Wisconsin that it will spend whatever it takes to provide the benefits it has promised.
Mr. Clinton's pledge to "end welfare as we know it" -- with its ironclad job offer for parents who obey welfare rules -- is better than Wisconsin's pledge to end welfare, period. But Mr. Clinton can nevertheless embrace Wisconsin's right to experiment as long as he insists that the state smooth the plan's harshest edges.

HEADLINE: Giuliani to Propose New Agency To Get Around Borrowing Limits

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will propose the creation of a public authority that would allow New York City to sidestep a state constitutional limit on the city's debt, increasing the amount of money the city could borrow to build or repair everything from schools to bridges, senior officials said yesterday.
The Mayor's aides insisted that they did not want to borrow more money immediately because of the city's nagging fiscal woes. In fact, they said, Mr. Giuliani would announce a $1 billion reduction in construction spending -- a 9 percent cut -- over the next four years when he unveils the capital budget today. 
 By proposing the new authority, however, the Mayor and his aides said they were creating a vehicle that could ultimately provide an enormous infusion of cash to repair the city's crumbling schools and build new ones. And that, they said, would give them room for negotiation with the City Council, whose Democratic leaders have vowed to make spending for school construction a make-or-break issue in this year's budget fight.
The Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, has proposed extending the city's temporary surcharge on the personal income tax -- used to pay for 6,000 new police officers since 1993 -- to raise $1.4 billion for school construction over the next four years. And Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson said yesterday that Mr. Vallone's idea had provided "a good seed" for the Mayor's proposal. But he added that the authority could raise even more capital dollars for schools and other projects without having to extend the tax surcharge, scheduled to expire in December.
"It allows us to do everything he had in mind," Mr. Dyson said.
Michael S. Clendenin, a spokesman for Mr. Vallone, responded cautiously, saying the Mayor's proposal did not in itself set aside the money that would be needed to rebuild the city's schools. "We're still missing a major infusion of school funds," Mr. Clendenin said, "but we'll work with them on it."
The proposed agency, to be called the New York City Infrastructure Financing Authority, would have the ability to raise billions of dollars for construction projects by selling bonds that would be repaid over a period of up to 30 years with a dedicated stream of revenues from the city's personal income tax, rather with money from the general coffer.
The authority, which would require the approval of the State Legislature, would thus greatly expand and broaden the city's means of borrowing money for capital projects at a time when it has virtually exhausted its ability to take on added debt under the limit established by the state's Constitution when it was last revised in 1937.
The debt limit, by law, restricts the city's outstanding general obligation debt to 10 percent of the city's full taxable value of real estate. It was included in the state's Constitution as a way to prohibit cities and counties from borrowing more money than they could realistically afford. For most localities, real estate property taxes are by far the largest source of revenue. But New York City collects a large portion of its revenue from income and business taxes.
Since the economic downturn that began in the late 1980's, New York City's property values have fallen drastically. That essentially lowered the limit even as the city scrambled to try to catch up on capital improvements to bridges, subways and other public works that had been deferred during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's.
The Mayor's budget director, Joseph J. Lhota, said that if the city continued to pay for capital construction projects at the current rate, it would reach the state's limit by fiscal year 1998 and exceed it by $900 million and then $2 billion in the fiscal years that follow.
The Mayor has cut spending on capital projects significantly since taking office nearly two and a half years ago. Officials said the Mayor would propose still more cuts in the capital budget unveiled today. That would help the city avoid hitting the debt limit and also reduce the spiraling costs of paying interest and principal on the city's outstanding debt, which now totals $25 billion.
"We are being hamstrung by our debt limit," Mr. Lhota said.
The state's limit applies to outstanding bonds -- or general obligation debt -- that are paid off from the city's general tax revenues. Since the city would repay bonds issued by the proposed authority with dedicated tax revenue, the authority's debt would not be subject to the limits.
The city's bond raters also responded cautiously. Robert A. Kurtter, vice president of Moody's Investors Service, said that the proposal clearly allowed the city to sidestep the debt limit but that the city would also need to find ways to pay for essential capital costs. He said it remained to be seen whether the Mayor would use the new authority to borrow more money and add still more costs in interest payments to an already strained budget.
"The city has a dilemma," Mr. Kurtter said. "They can't afford to borrow more, and they can't afford not to borrow more."
Richard J. Raphael, the executive managing director of Fitch Investors Services, another of the city's bond raters, expressed similar concerns, adding that the authority could prove an enticing way to greatly increase borrowing, even if the Mayor's aides are promising no immediate increase.
"We would be concerned if this type of financing vehicle, to the extent that it can bypass the debt limit, is an opening of the floodgates," Mr. Raphael said.
Under the Mayor's proposal, the new financing authority would raise money not only for schools, but also for bridges, highways, tunnels, ferries and mass transit. Last week, the Mayor reached an agreement with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to provide $500 million over four years for improvements to the city's subways and buses, in exchange for $250 million in cash.
Although Mr. Giuliani plans to announce a reduction in capital spending, the city's Board of Education is the only agency that does not face a cut in its capital budget, which totals $2.6 billion over four years.
Although he has not proposed a cut, the Mayor has responded tepidly to Mr. Vallone's proposal to use the income tax surcharge to pay for a significant increase in school construction, saying he did not believe the Board of Education would spend the money efficiently.
The Mayor and his aides suggested that the crucial factor would be how and by whom any school construction projects would be managed.
If the authority became a vehicle to provide new money for schools, the Mayor and the Council could restore a portion of the proposed reduction in capital projects and still reduce the city's overall total capital budget. The savings from that overall cut could replace the lost income from the personal income tax that would be needed to repay the bonds.
Mr. Lhota said the authority would simply supplement the city's current financing power and give the city flexibility to move ahead with projects in areas like education and mass transit. "There's no way we can impair moving forward with these basic governmental services," Mr. Lhota said.

HEADLINE: Orange County Creditors Said To Accept Plan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 2

 BODY:
The largest municipal bankruptcy in United States history neared a conclusion today with the announcement that the creditors of Orange County, Calif., appeared to have accepted a recovery plan.
Lawyers involved in the lengthy negotiations said that an informal tally of ballots filed by all the county's creditors, from bondholders to suppliers of office products, showed that they had approved the plan. That makes it likely, the lawyers said, that the Federal bankruptcy court would accept the plan at a hearing scheduled for May 15. The final count of the ballots will be ready on Monday or Tuesday, the lawyers said. 
 If the plan is accepted, the county is expected to emerge from bankruptcy at the end of June, nearly 19 months after huge losses in the county's investment portfolio caused a crisis that rattled the financial markets and pushed the largely affluent county, south of Los Angeles, into bankruptcy protection.
"Our count, based on a pretty careful look, is that when the final tally is completed, all classes of creditors will have accepted this plan," said Bruce Bennett, the county's lead bankruptcy lawyer. "I have no doubt that the court will then accept this plan."
Robert Moore, a lawyer representing the county's creditors, said he was pleased with the news, but remained cautious. "We believe this is a giant step forward," he said. "This is not the last hurdle in the race, but it is a good sign."
The substantial remaining step for Orange County is to sell about $800 million in new bonds to repay some of its existing creditors. That sale, which is expected to go ahead in the next few weeks, was virtually assured, investment bankers said, when the county received a form of insurance from a leading municipal-securities insurer, MBIA, this week.
Jan M. Mittermeier, the county's chief executive, said: "Although we don't have the official count of the creditors' acceptance of the county's plan, I am extremely delighted to hear the results of the preliminary tally. This is another important step along the path of our emergence from bankruptcy."
Initially, there had been concern that the financial shock of December 1994 could affect the municipal-securities markets for years. But the county's bankruptcy seems to have had a less drastic general impact, though it has earned huge sums for the lawyers involved and has taken a big bite out of social programs for many poorer people among the county's 2.6 million residents.
The bankruptcy was prompted by an estimated $1.6 billion in losses from a $7.4 billion investment fund run by Orange County's former treasurer, Robert L. Citron. The fund, actually a pool of money from numerous local government agencies and cities as well as from the county itself, was heavily invested in derivatives, fast-moving speculative securities that plummeted in value when interest rates shot up through much of 1994.
Since the collapse, the participants in the pool have received most of their money back. School districts got about 90 cents of each dollar invested; other agencies and municipalities received about 80 cents.
The county has filed suit against its lead securities broker, Merrill Lynch & Company, seeking more than $2 billion in damages. The agencies in the pool are to receive the rest of their money from anything the county might win in that suit, which Merrill Lynch is contesting.
The investors in county bonds and notes will receive all their money, plus interest, if the plan goes through and the new bonds are sold.
But there has been a cost. The county slashed about $180 million from its general budget almost overnight -- a cut of roughly 40 percent -- taking a big bite out of many programs for the poor. The county laid off more than 1,000 employees.
In addition, to repay its bondholders, the county is diverting a total of about $18 million a year from its transportation agency and from programs for parks, harbors, beaches and flood control.
But the economy is again growing, and with the recovery plan, the government is likely to begin to rebuild.
The sale of the new bonds could close on June 30, and the county may formally emerge from bankruptcy that day.

HEADLINE: South Africa Losing Battle to House Homeless

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: DIEPSLOOT, South Africa

 BODY:
A year ago, when Maureen Mkhize was brought to this field north of Johannesburg and given a spot for her shack, she was told she would have real housing within six months. Since then, hundreds of families have joined her -- brought here by the truckload from sordid urban squatter settlements, the flimsy bits of their old shacks dumped beside them so they can rebuild.
As far as the eye can see in a vacant section of this black township, small white stones mark off thousands of future plots. There are tractors busy making dirt roads in a grid pattern, and portable toilets and barrels of drinking water are set up at regular intervals. 
 Johannesburg officials insist on calling the development, known as Plot 139, a "temporary emergency measure." But there are no plans for improving it, and it looks like a slum in the making.
In its heady early days, President Nelson Mandela's Government promised 1 million new homes within five years. The political stakes could hardly be higher. South Africa has eight million homeless people, almost all of whom are black, live without running water, electricity or even chemical toilets, and vote for Mr. Mandela's African National Congress.
Two years later, only 11,000 houses have been built, and 23,000 more are under construction. Mrs. Mkhize, an enterprising grandmother whose arthritis cost her a job as a maid, no longer expects to leave her shack soon. She is hoeing the weeds from a bit of ground near a future bus stop where she hopes to put up a fruit stall. Plot 139 is far from anywhere she can find work -- but it's also far from any supermarkets for her new neighbors.
In some ways, the Government's housing plans were novel, a rejection of American and European models. Rather than build large scale housing projects, it wanted to give families up to $4,000 each, then help them get bank mortgages so they could own their own homes. Thus far, the idea is a failure.
Studies blame everyone from inept government bureaucrats processing applications to bankers and building contractors who refuse to cooperate because profit margins are low and they think the poor won't pay their debts. Refusing to pay rent and electric bills was a common way of protesting apartheid, and many have not lost the habit.
"The Government expects the private sector to solve all the problems," said Lance Edmunds, a spokesman for the Council of South African Banks. "But 45 percent of the population is unemployed. You can't expect the private sector to take all the risk."
William J. Cobbett, director of the Government housing program, says he still believes in the plan but that he's "fine-tuning" it -- offering banks guarantees against losses, considering building rental housing or simply buying wood, cement and tin for the poor and telling them to build their own homes.
Some housing experts sneer that this is just an echo of the apartheid Government's "toilets on the veld" policy -- a return to the days when blacks were given land in the middle of nowhere with a few water lines installed. They want the Government to do more.
"The starting point of the present policy is wrong," said Odette Geldenhaus, a housing expert at Witwatersrand University's Center for Applied Legal Studies. "You can't rely on the private sector here. There is no profit margin. The state has to play a bigger role. They have to start building housing."
The cities, meanwhile, are drowning in squatters like Mrs. Mhkize. For decades, they lived in shacks in black townships like Soweto, often paying huge rents to the occupants of the tiny government-owned houses who let them build in the yard. But in the late 1980's, when the Government stopped rigorously enforcing apartheid, thousands began slipping into the white cities, squatting on any vacant patch. Thousands more came in from rural areas.
In Johannesburg, there may be 250,000 people living in downtown parking lots, near highways, beside garbage dumps, on the banks of flooding rivers or on unstable mounds of mine tailings. Many have invaded land intended for low-income housing.
As a result, courts have ordered evictions, shacks have been burned, and groups of poor families have fought pitched battles over who will get housing, if it is ever built. Driven out, the squatters are constantly on the move. "Reception areas" like Plot 139 are being created to break that cycle.
"We are simply trying to respond to the crisis," said Tshepiso Mashinini, Johannesburg's director of urbanization. "While we have been busy transforming the national and local governments, the problem of housing did not stop growing. This just may give us some time."
But even some Government officials admit privately that vast squatter camps far from any job possibilities are potential disaster areas. "They are a very ugly business," said one who declined give his name. "They are simply a dumping ground for people the Government doesn't know what to do with. "
The irony is that many squatters like the arrangement. Years of living in fear that the police will evict them are over.
"If you are landless and homeless, then 80 square meters that you can stay on with toilets and water might seem pretty good," said Lindsay Bremner, who heads the urbanization committee of the Greater Johannesburg Metropolitan Council.
Mavis Moyo feels that way. The police tore down her last shack beside a highway in Bryanston, a rich suburb. Since then, she's been collecting wood for a new one. But when she was dumped here recently, she didn't have enough timber. She plans to use plastic tarpaulins to cover holes and make a roof. Even when she realized that the ground was full of termites, she only shrugged.
"I am happy today," she said, looking over the bleak landscape as at a promised land. "The Government is trying. There are too many of us."
Squatter settlements here hardly resemble the camps of the homeless under bridges or in parks in American cities. These squatters are not mentally ill or alcoholics or drug addicts. The settlements are usually collections of 30 to 300 families. One adult per household usually has at least part-time work, but at wages far too low to buy a house.
The camps are usually highly organized, with a leader and a rule-making committee. A camp called Newtown in downtown Johannesburg taxes every resident 25 cents a week for security and pays it to whomever stands sentry on weekends.
On the outside, the shacks are untidy looking heaps, built of scraps of wood, tin and plastic, but inside they are often meticulously maintained. Beds are curtained off with lace, mismatched dishes are neatly arranged on planks serving as kitchen counters, walls are carefully papered with newspaper.
But the new camps will bring together squatters from many different sites. There have already been clashes between factions.
Many of those taken to Plot 139 went unwillingly. Some had a week's warning that trucks would come for them. But none knew that they would be taken here, about a half hour from downtown and miles from the white suburbs where they had worked.
For the first two nights, Paulina Mashebe and her six children slept on strips of carpet around an open fire. By the third day her husband had largely rebuilt their shack. It had gone slowly because, although he had carefully saved all the nails when they were evicted, he had had to straighten the bent ones.
Mrs. Mashebe, who had been chased from five previous sites, was relieved to have permanence at last. But as she scanned the horizon, she sighed. As the family's only wage-earner, she makes about $180 a month. Her boss used to send the truck to pick her up. But he won't come this far and she now faces travel costs of $50 a month.
"When they came for us," she said, "I said no, we could not move. But they said we had to. There was no choice."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Life for many South African squatters is so hard that even the remote, spartan lots offered by the Government are a step up. In a squatter camp in downtown Johannesburg, a resident scavenged paper for a recycler. (Greg Marinovich/SouthLight, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Upbeat Data On Economy Hurt Markets

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Already in a jumpy mood, investors sent stock and bond prices tumbling yesterday after they were spooked by another report that showed the economy is stronger than was expected earlier this year.
The resulting selloff sent long-term interest rates over 7 percent for the first time in a year while the Dow Jones industrial average lost as much as 100 points before closing at 5,498.27, down 76.95 points. 
 The main villain yesterday was the Commerce Department's report that the economy grew at a 2.8 percent annual rate during the first quarter of the year. That pace exceeded even the most optimistic forecasts by private economists and exacerbated fears of an overheating economy.
Although the market rout was less severe, it was similar to the two that followed the release of unexpectedly strong employment reports for February and March. The report for April is due today.
While the one-day tumble added to the volatility that has characterized the stock market this year, the drop was not dramatic in percentage terms, shaving just slightly more than one percentage point off the Dow. "With bonds down almost 1 3/4 points and a 7 percent yield, the market could have been off 250 points," said Peter Anderson, senior vice president for investments for the American Express Financial Corporation. "It could have been a lot worse."
While strong growth can translate to higher corporate profits, which makes every stock investor happy by causing stocks to rise, investors are always on the lookout for the possibility of renewed inflation and higher interest rates. Inflation makes corporate profits look less impressive, while higher rates serve as a brake on the overall economy and can draw money away from the stock market.
Because financial markets tend to reflect investors' judgments about which force will prevail, growth that is perceived to be too fast can be seen as a threat to rising stocks.
"The market likes a little bit of good economic news but can't take too much of it," said Arnold Kaufman, the editor of Standard & Poor's Outlook newsletter. Yesterday's market drop represented "a little indigestion in this trade-off between earnings and interest rates," he said.
Investors most worried about inflation seemed to prevail yesterday. Even the hot Nasdaq composite index, which is composed mostly of smaller stocks and had been up about 14 percent this year, fell almost 2 percent. Only a few selected stocks -- those that directly benefit from a humming economy, like Intel or Caterpillar -- were left unscathed.
Contributing to the market's recent volatility is a muddy economic picture. It is anybody's guess about the economy's ultimate direction, and investors looking for guidance have found little in recent months. Earlier in the year, for example, some market analysts were predicting a recession. "It's been amazing how many people have been wrong about the economy this year," said Peter Canelo, a market strategist for NatWest Securities. "This finally puts an end to the silly idea that we're heading into a recession."
Current concerns are now focused on whether the Federal Reserve, in reaction to signs of nascent inflation -- like rising commodity prices and a strong economy -- will decide to raise short-term interest rates and bring everything to a halt, just as it did two years ago. Most forecasters think the Fed is unlikely to do so. "We do not see pressure developing on interest rates," said Alfred Goldman, the chief investment strategist for A. G. Edwards.
"The probability of an interest rate hike between now and November is minimal," agreed Mr. Canelo, who said the Fed did not have enough evidence to raise short-term interest rates right now and would rather not do so in an election year. He argued that the economy was clearly not as strong as it was in 1994.
But there is clearly some anxiety among investors that the Fed, which has been aggressive in its aim to tame inflation, might raise short-term rates anyway. "The Fed has tightened in election years," said David Schulman, the managing director of investment strategy for Salomon Brothers, who noted the Fed raised rates in both 1984 and 1988. While Salomon is not forecasting an increase in rates at the end of this year or in early 1997, Mr. Schulman thinks the market is factoring in the possibility of a quarter-percent increase.
The next economic report that could push interest rates higher and stocks lower is today's April employment report from the Labor Department. While Mr. Schulman thinks the report will be a nonevent unless job growth is negative or exceeds 200,000, investors will be examining it carefully for signs of how the economy appears to be faring.
If all the ingredients for a bull market -- low interest rates and benign inflation -- continue, investors should have little to worry about. But no one is expecting anybody to relax. Even Mr. Goldman, who considers yesterday's drop "a buying opportunity," acknowledges investors should be prepared for the bumpy ride to continue. While the volatility in the stock market is closer to its historical average, it is a sharp reminder that 1995 is unlikely to be repeated. "Last year was a one-way parade up," Mr. Goldman said.
While there are few strategists willing to bet that there is a ferocious bear market in the future, some are less than bullish about the market's possibilities, especially if long-term interest rates do not stabilize or start to head down once anxieties over the economy have been resolved. Since investors tend to move toward bonds or even money-market instruments when yields begin to increase, there could continue to be selling.
"It's been a while since the stock market looked at a 7 percent bond," noted Mr. Schulman. He predicted a choppy market with a downside draft that would leave the Dow somewhere around 5300, roughly 4 percent lower than yesterday but still 4 percent higher than where it started the year.
Fears of higher interest rates depressed financial stocks. Merrill Lynch fell 2 3/4, to 57 7/8; Freddie Mac fell 3 7/8, to 79 1/8; J. P. Morgan declined 1 5/8, to 82 7/8; Nationsbank lost 2 1/2, to 77 1/2, and American Express dropped 1 1/4, to 47 1/4.
Telephone stocks also came under pressure. Among the declinerss were AT&T, down 1 1/8, to 59 3/8; MCI, down 1 3/8, to 28 1/4; Nynex, down 1, to 47 5/8; Bell Atlantic, down 1 3/4, to 63, and BellSouth, down 1 3/4, to 38 1/8.
Among the stocks that bucked the downtrend was Sun Microsystems, up 1 3/8, to 57, as it continued to gain strength from investor optimism about its Java programming language.
And Quantum Health Resources rose 1 3/4, to 16 1/4, after Olsten announced Wednesday evening that it would buy Quantum Health for about $273.3 million in stock. Olsten's shares fell 1 7/8, to 29 1/8.

HEADLINE: ECONOMY REVIVED AT PACE OF 2.8% IN FIRST QUARTER

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
The economy sprang back to life in the first quarter of the year, the Commerce Department said today, growing at an annual rate of 2.8 percent after practically coming to a halt at the end of 1995. The Clinton Administration quickly took credit for reviving an economic expansion that once seemed about to expire.
The growth, which exceeded even the most optimistic forecasts by private economists, was strong enough that it immediately complicated the Presidential campaign of Senator Bob Dole. The presumptive Republican nominee and his supporters, citing the anemic growth rate of five-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter of last year, have been talking about the arrival of "the Clinton crunch," blaming higher taxes and government regulation for extinguishing economic growth. 
 And the gain -- which would have been even greater, economists said, had it not been for the January blizzard in the East and a strike at General Motors in March -- suggested that further advances were likely this spring and summer.
But what was good news to the White House was sobering to investors, who feared that the quickening of the economy posed a threat of higher inflation, rising interest rates and a tighter monetary policy by the Federal Reserve. In the bond market, traders dumped existing bonds, pushing interest rates on long-term Treasury securities to more than 7 percent for the first time in a year. On Wall Street, where investors feared that higher rates might make stocks less attractive, the Dow Jones industrial average fell nearly 77 points to close at 5,575.22. [Page D1.]
The 2.8 percent estimate issued today, an "advance" figure that is subject to revision up or down in coming months, was fueled by a 12 percent surge in the rate of investment by businesses, including a jump of nearly 50 percent in the pace of computer purchases. Consumer spending also soared after a slow Christmas, increasing at an annual rate of 3.5 percent. The only negative news was a great slowing in exports and a surge in imports. (All the figures are adjusted to try to eliminate the effects of inflation and seasonal variations.)
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, director of the White House's National Economic Council, called the revival of growth "more evidence that the President's economic strategy is paying off."
Mr. Dole's advisers declined to speak for attribution, but one of his economic strategists speculated that the figures would further force the Dole campaign to focus on issues of character, leadership and experience, rather than critiques of Mr. Clinton's economic record. For their part, Mr. Clinton's strategists said that while the signs of a reviving economy built a solid foundation for the campaign, they were hardly a guarantee at the polls in an era of job insecurity.
So just hours after members of the Administration paraded out to take credit for the economy's continued strength, Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary -- who has been used frequently to test themes for Mr. Clinton -- argued that the Administration now had to focus on workers left in the wake of economic transition.
"Even if we can't supply job security, we can supply some economic security," he said in pressing the Administration's agenda of tax credits for college tuition and worker training, among other programs. "There is still good reason for all that anxiety out there."
As one Administration official said today, explaining the strategy of talking about corporate downsizing and economic growth in the same breath: "If you only do good news and ignore the bad news, it just doesn't sound credible."
While today's numbers are extraordinarily good compared with expectations -- Merrill Lynch & Company, along with many other forecasters, predicted only a 1.5 percent annual growth rate for the quarter -- they are not particularly remarkable when viewed against other economic advances since World War II. And the figures still leave room for Mr. Dole and others to argue, as the conservative Heritage Foundation has recently, that more than a million new jobs would have been created and employee wages would be significantly higher had the Democrats not pushed through a tax bill three years ago.
But that is arguing a might-have-been, compared with Mr. Clinton's ability to refer to the here-and-now of more than eight million net new jobs added in the midst of an era of widespread corporate downsizing.
Until recently, one of the greatest fears at the White House was a rerun of 1992 in which the economy appeared to languish in the six months leading up to the Presidential election. Administration officials referred to this as the "Bush scenario." (Only later was it clear that the economy picked up steam that summer.) While economists and political strategists can argue the point of what Mr. Clinton could have done to help the economy further, he can campaign on numbers that give the promise of prosperity -- and hints that the wage stagnation of the last several years is slowly reversing.
"The Achilles' heel for this Administration is that the American workers are unhappy campers," Allen Sinai, the chief global economist of Lehman Brothers, said in a telephone interview from Boston today. But now, he added, "anecdotally and regionally almost all of the indicators are good. The result of this is that the economic card is a losing card for the Republicans."
While some economists suggested that the economy would slow down later this year, especially if bond yields remain above 7 percent, others guess that while growth may moderate, the economy is likely to meet or exceed the White House estimate of 2.2 percent for the year. "It's on track to something closer to two and a half," Mr. Sinai said.
For Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole, the remaining big issue is the second quarter. The "advance" figures for that quarter will be issued on Aug. 1, just before the Democratic and Republican conventions, and will be revised through the heart of the campaign. The first look at the third quarter will not come until Oct. 30, just days before the election.
What threw off the economic forecasts of the country's first-quarter performance so severely was the surge in business investment, particularly for factory equipment and computers, which rose 14.5 percent, compared with an increase of 4 percent in the fourth quarter of 1995. Nonresidential building grew 5.8 percent, compared with a meager nine-tenths of a percent.
For Mr. Clinton, perhaps the most damaging part of today's report is the evidence that exports are slowing down. That was one of the shining sectors of the economy, which Mr. Clinton has claimed as his greatest success. The slowing, while expected, creates an opening for Mr. Dole to say that some of the market-opening initiatives have failed to narrow the country's trade gap.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the first quarter of 1996 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Except Against Yen In Thin and Technical Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar reversed course and advanced against the Japanese yen yesterday but fell against most other leading currencies in a quiet session driven largely by technical factors.
Widely anticipated data on employment in the United States presented traders with mixed signals, as the nation's unemployment rate dipped to a 14-month low of 5.4 percent in April but job growth came to a meager 2,000. Job growth the prior two months had been powerful. 
 "Really, everybody's just sort of stymied right now and they're going back to a neutral posture," said Randolph Donney, director of research at the Pegasus Econometric Group.
Most of the dollar's movement did not reflect directly on the dollar but on the secondary effect of trades between the German mark and the yen, Mr. Donney said. That weakened the yen against the dollar, reversing the yen's strong gains a day earlier.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar stood at 105.05 yen, up from 104.35 yen Thursday, and 1.5245 marks, down from 1.5283.
The British pound, which tumbled on Wednesday on fears that the ruling Conservative Party would be trounced in local elections on Thursday, showed little change yesterday, after results indeed showed a resounding defeat for the party. In New York, the British pound traded at $1.5070, up from $1.5025.
The dollar fell sharply on Thursday, following American bond and stock markets. The markets tumbled after the Government reported that the country's gross domestic product grew by 2.8 percent in the first quarter, faster than expected and raising fears of inflation.
When the employment report pointed to moderate economic growth, currency traders rushed to buy dollars. The dollar moved immediately higher against the yen, with many traders reversing the positions they had taken a day earlier.
"I think it was overdone yesterday, quite honestly," said Stephen Jury, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Union Bank of Switzerland.
Against the German mark and other major currencies, the dollar was not able to hold on, turned lower and added to the previous day's declines. United States stock and bond prices, which initially rallied on the employment news, turned down later in the day and helped drag the dollar lower.
Traders hesitated to read too much importance into the day's action, as trading was thin and many people simply did not want to carry uncertain positions into the weekend.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Rises on Supply Concerns As Strike Seems Near in Norway

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as a strike threat by Norwegian oil workers and continued refinery problems raised concerns about supply at a time when supplies are low.
On other markets, copper jumped to a seven-month high, propelled by concern that a strike at the world's second-largest copper mine might be a prolonged one. Wheat and soybean prices were mixed. 
 The harsh winter, which left crude oil stocks unusually low, has overworked oil refineries and caused shutdowns for repairs, said Bill O'Grady, an analyst with A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
Concerns over shutdowns and prospects that Norwegian offshore oil workers would strike for an extended time sent crude oil for June delivery up 32 cents yesterday, to $21.18.
A strike would reduce Norway's oil output by half and gas production by more than one-third. Norway is the world's largest oil producer outside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. It produces three million barrels a day.
Workers have threatened to walk off the job today, and the Norwegian Government has said it will not intervene.
June unleaded gasoline rose 1.52 cent, to 69.92 cents a gallon.
The July copper contract jumped 2.15 cents, to $1.2220 a pound -- a seven-month high -- on the New York Mercantile Exchange on fears about the strike at the Chuquicamata mine in Chile -- the world's second-largest copper mine. The loss of production comes as the United States economy seems to be strengthening. An economic expansion would probably increase demand for copper, which is used in industry and construction.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, grain and soybean futures prices finished mixed, as traders shrugged off a new report that contained sharply reduced estimates of the winter wheat crop.
Prices rose modestly early after the Sparks Companies of Memphis, a widely respected private consultant, estimated the 1996-97 American wheat crop at 2.103 billion bushels, compared with last month's estimate of 2.415 billion bushels.
But the market already knew this year's wheat yield would be one of the worst in decades, said Mickey Luth, an analyst with the Laifa Group brokerage firm in Chicago.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Long-Delayed Power Plant Gets Go-Ahead in Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 3

 BODY:
The Government announced today that it had resolved financing and other difficulties that for four years have delayed construction of a $647 million electric power generating plant near the northern industrial city of Ciudad Juarez.
Construction of the Samalayuca II plant is to begin within a month, the Government said. 
 The project had been delayed for so long that some had dubbed it "Samala-nunca," or "Samala-never," and Government officials said today that their recent success in clearing away the hurdles was a breakthrough for the economy.
Samalayuca II is to be next to an already operating plant about 30 miles south of El Paso, and will generate power not only for Ciudad Juarez, a city of a million residents and more than 300 factories, but also for American customers under United States-Mexico electricity interchange agreements.
A consortium including the General Electric Company, the El Paso Energy Corporation, the International Generating Company of Boston (a joint venture between Bechtel Enterprises and PG&E Enterprises Inc.), and Emica, a Mexico City construction concern, will design and build the plant. They will lease it to Mexico's state-owned electric utility, the Comision Federal de Electricidad, for 20 years after the start-up, which is projected for 1998. Ownership will then transfer to the state utility.
Mexico's electricity demand is soaring, and President Ernesto Zedillo said in a ceremony today that before the year 2000, when his term ends, he hopes to assemble $9 billion in new capital for other power plants. "Certainly we will take this operation as a model for the coming years," Mr. Zedillo said.
The Government calls the project "Mexico's first large privately funded power project," which means that it is the first whose financing is not guaranteed by the Mexican Government, officials said.
The financing package, which took years to assemble, contemplates two parts. Construction will be financed with $132 million put up by the design and building consortium, led by GE Capital Services. And the Inter-American Development Bank and a group of private banks -- Citibank, a unit of Citicorp; Union Bank of Switzerland; ABN-Amro of the Netherlands, and Dresdner Bank of Germany -- will provide $515 million.
Once the plant becomes operational in the fall of 1998, the Export-Import Bank will take over $440 million of the private bank debt.
Glen T. Matsumoto, a vice president of the Export-Import Bank, said on a visit here that his bank, which is a dependency of the United States Government, became involved because "commercial banks are not quite comfortable with having long-term financial exposure in Mexico, not as of yet."
The contracts signed today guarantee that the plant will be able to generate sufficient electricity and revenue to repay and service the debt, Mr. Matsumoto said. "I'm comfortable that with the contracts signed today, they will be able to pay off the debt," he said.

HEADLINE: Look Who's Minding the Shop;
California Garment Makers Try to Police Workplace

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
In the latest crackdown on sweatshops in the nation's largest garment center, investigators working in teams of two stand watch outside sewing factories, noting the number of employees and their arrival times.
Then, moving inside, they split up. One inspector occupies the management, checking time cards, immigration work permits, tax forms and other documents. The other talks to workers on the floor, interviewing enough of them to insure that none can be singled out as a whistle-blower. 
 The investigators' reports, grading the workplace for compliance with state and Federal laws on safety and wages, can be damning. There is just one catch: these are not Government agents; they are employees of a private company, the Cal Safety Compliance Corporation. And their reports are not sent to law-enforcement officials, but rather to Cal Safety's clients, the big clothing makers who contract with the small sewing shops and are under pressure from the Federal Government to clean up their act.
In fact, the 52 inspectors who work for Cal Safety have instructions to introduce themselves as "manufacturers' representatives," so that the owners and their employees "will know we're not the Government," said Carol Pender, who founded the company in 1990.
So how effective can their efforts be? That is an important question in an industry that has thwarted numerous attempts over the years to eliminate the exploitation of its workers. Critics say the self-policing is doomed to failure because the interest of the big clothing companies to have clothes made cheaply runs counter to the Government's goal to end exploitation.
But the Labor Department thinks otherwise. With fewer than 800 labor standards inspectors to police American workplaces, a 19 percent decline over the last decade, it is the inspiration behind the private sector's involvement in the drive against sweatshop abuses.
[In Washington on Friday, the department issued its first-ever report on the nation's garment workers, showing that almost half of the sewing shops that were investigated had violated Federal labor laws. The largest number of enforcement actions, 86, taken in the six months ended March 31 were in California, while the total of back wages recovered for employees was greatest in New York, at $593,000.]
In November 1992, the Labor Department began invoking an obscure provision of the 1938 Fair Labor Standards Act that authorized it to confiscate "hot goods." It threatened manufacturers with the seizure of clothing produced by exploited labor, unless they could show they were making honest efforts to buy only from legitimate operators.
The effort got under way slowly but was bolstered last summer by the public furor over the discovery of a slave camp for Thai immigrants in El Monte, Calif. The police found nearly 70 workers locked inside a dilapidated garment factory surrounded by barbed wire and spiked fences. The prisoners had been forced to stitch together American brand-name clothes under threats of death if they tried to escape. Federal labor officials later notified more than a dozen large retailers that goods from the plant might have ended up in their stores.
[Two of the owners were sentenced to six years in prison last Monday, and five others are scheduled to be sentenced next Monday.]
Meantime, the Labor Department's threat to confiscate tainted merchandise from clothing companies has spawned a new industry concentrated in the Los Angeles area of private "sweatshop cops." These specialists are hired by the clothing manufacturers to audit the payroll practices and interview the employees of their subcontractors.
The biggest is Cal Safety, which has already signed up more than 100 garment makers, charging $200 for each quarterly audit it makes. Other inspection companies include Apparel Resources of Yorba Linda, Calif., which was founded in 1992 and has 40 clients, and Stonefield Josephson, an accounting firm in Santa Monica, Calif., which began offering the service to its clients 1992. In addition, many manufacturers say they themselves monitor their subcontractors.
Most clients receive detailed quarterly reports on their subcontractors, with failing grades given for violation of wage or safety laws or payroll discrepancies. Ms. Pender of Cal Safety said her auditors had inspected 90 percent of the state's 4,000 licensed contractors and had given so many low ratings that half had been cut off by at least one manufacturer.
The Los Angeles metropolitan area is the main battlefield of the Government's war on illegal sweatshops. Fed by an influx of immigrant labor from Asia and Latin America, the city's apparel industry has surpassed New York's to become America's biggest, with $15.2 billion in sales last year and one-quarter of the nation's million garment workers.
In industrial parks and decaying office buildings in Orange and Los Angeles Counties, they cut, stitch, knit, iron, trim and dye fabric for 4,000 registered sewing contractors and an estimated 1,000 underground ones. According to a survey by state officials conducted in 1994, just as the effort to enlist the private sector in policing the shops was getting under way, 90 percent of them worked in sweatshop conditions that flouted state and Federal wage and safety laws. Even sewing shops that stay within the law rarely offer their employees paid vacations or health benefits.
Given the low-tech nature of the sewing business, unscrupulous entrepreneurs can easily escape investigators -- whether those sent by government or the manufacturers -- by keeping duplicate books and shutting down a site one day and opening up elsewhere the next.
So far, the Federal Government's initiative has won scant support from any of the parties involved. Some California labor officials privately grumble that it is aimed more at placating public opinion than bringing about meaningful change. And representatives of both the sewing-factory owners and their workers question the wisdom of giving an enforcement role to clothing manufacturers. Patrick Cheung, president of the Northern California Chinese Garment Contractors Association, accuses the garment makers of hypocrisy for insisting that his members pay fair wages to their workers while simultaneously lowering the rates they pay the subcontractors for stitching work.
"They know it's not enough," Mr. Cheung said. He said 40 sewing shops closed in the Bay Area last year, and added that profit margins among his remaining 350 members had shrunk to 3 percent from 10 percent since 1988.
For their part, the unions representing garment workers decry the new monitoring system as a case of the fox guarding the hen house. "I can't say things have gotten better," said Steven T. Nutter, regional director of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees. For him, the only solution is more Government intervention. "You can't terrorize an industry when you have 15 people policing it," he said. "You hit every contractor once every seven years. They'll take that chance."
For all the doubts, there is some evidence that self-policing is doing some good. A new survey of the California garment industry by the state and the Federal Government shows that while abuses are still rampant, "companies with monitoring programs have a significantly better rate of compliance than nonmonitored companies," said Jose Millan, California's interim labor commissioner.
Mr. Millan said the survey turned up 20 percent fewer overtime violations than were found in a similar study two years ago, though little progress was made in meeting record-keeping, safety or minimum-wage requirements. "There's been slight improvement," he said. "It would be foolhardy to withdraw from the program now."
And while the big clothing companies are not happy about what they regard as another bureaucratic intrusion, they are at least going through the motions of leaning on their subcontractors to abide by Federal minimum-wage and safety laws. And Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, at least, is hoping for a long-term payoff.
"We've got to stop this exploitation, and we can't do it alone," Mr. Reich said in a recent interview.
Law-enforcement officials have had a few successes. Most big garment makers --including Guess Inc., Chorus Line and 43 other companies -- have signed a voluntary agreement with the Labor Department to shoulder responsibility for back pay owed to workers by their contractors. So far, the agency has recovered more than $7.3 million in back wages for more than 25,000 garment workers since 1993.
But some garment makers say the cost of policing their contractors puts them at a disadvantage to companies with overseas operations. "Our competitors can make goods anywhere in the world," complained Christopher L. Bryer, a vice president of Chazz, a unit of CMG Inc. that makes private-label apparel.
Since his company began monitoring its four sewing contractors, Mr. Bryer said, it has cut off one. But he wonders if the action did any good, saying the extra expense played a role in Chazz's decision last year to hire sewing contractors in Mexico.
Such protests fall on deaf ears in many quarters. Edna Bonacich, a sociology professor at the University of California at Riverside who specializes in the Los Angeles garment industry, said manufacturers were getting off easy. "The department's demands are minimalist," she said. "It's the language of compliance rather than a recognition of the industry's evil, exploitive practices."
Mr. Reich, meantime, is trying to extend the self-monitoring effort to retailers. In newspaper ads and radio commercials, his department is urging consumers to shop at stores that are on its "No Sweat" list of chains that keep close tabs on their suppliers.
Mr. Reich says it is the civic duty of big companies to lead the attack on worker exploitation. "It's a matter of corporate responsibility," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Jobless Rate Eased in April, Despite Steady Payrolls
The Government reported that the job market was lackluster in April, a day after reporting unexpectedly sharp growth in the economy in the first quarter. But even signs of modest growth failed to dissipate the inflation fears that rattled the financial markets on Thursday. The nation's unemployment rate eased to 5.4 percent in April from 5.6 percent in March and was at the lowest level in 14 months, even though there was no growth in business payrolls.
The results reduced chances that the Federal Reserve would find it necessary to tighten monetary policy soon. [Page 1.]
 
Car Sales Cool Down
Car and truck sales weakened in April to an annual pace of 14.6 million, seasonally adjusted, down from a sizzling 15.9 million in March. The slowdown reflected surprisingly weak sales at Ford and some shortages of General Motors autos, which were slow getting to dealers because of the strike. Ford sales dropped 2 percent below April 1995. [35.]
 
Merger to Form Insurance Giant
Royal Insurance and Sun Alliance plan to merge, forming Britain's second-largest publicly traded insurer and largest general insurer. The merger will result in annual savings of at least $262 million by 1998 for the combined company. [34.]
 
Viacom Earnings Firm
Viacom turned in a better performance than expected, helped in large part by its alliance with the Kirch Group of Germany. While earnings fell 61 percent, Viacom avoided the loss that Wall Street had forecast. Viacom, the owner of Paramount Pictures and Blockbuster Video, earned $27.8 million in the quarter, and cash flow was stronger than expected. [37.]
 
Mexico Power Plant to Serve U.S.
Mexico is ready to begin building a $647 million electric power generating plant 30 miles south of El Paso, having resolved complex financing issues. Construction is to begin within a month, according to the Government, which called the step a breakthrough for the economy. The plant will serve not only Ciudad Juarez, a city of a million residents and more than 300 factories, but also American customers. [34.]
 
Upjohn Operating Profit Up
Pharmacia & Upjohn said first-quarter operating earnings rose 8 percent, which was less than expected, on slow growth in pharmaceutical sales. Profits from operations increased to $229 million, but a big charge for integrating the two companies reduced net income to $50 million. [36.]
 
New Chief at National Semi
National Semiconductor named Brian Halla as its chairman, chief executive and president, succeeding Gilbert Amelio, who left in February to head Apple Computer. Mr. Halla, 49, had been executive vice president of LSI Logic. His appointment came a week after National Semiconductor warned of disappointing earnings because of decreasing sales of its electronic parts. [43.]
 
Transit Programs Halted in China
Qingdao, China, a port city eager to attract foreign investment, had planned to build a subway system, cross-harbor tunnel and a 10-mile bridge. But now all the projects have been suspended for lack of financing. Throughout China, basic transportation projects are being canceled or truncated. [3.]
 
Anger at British Cow Slaughter
Britain began slaughtering cows that are at risk of contracting mad cow disease but so far, the program has been a disaster for the beef industry: farmers are unsure of how they will get their backlog of animals slaughtered, and the $6.5-billion-a-year industry remains devastated by the export ban. [5.]
 
Strike Threat Lifts Oil Prices
Crude oil prices rose on a strike threat in Norway and tight supplies. Crude oil for June delivery climbed 32 cents, to $21.18. [32.]
 
Dollar Advances Against Yen
The dollar rebounded against the yen but fell against other leading currencies in a quiet session. The dollar rose to 105.05 yen, from 104.35 yen Thursday, while the British pound climbed to $1.5070, from $1.5025. [32.]

HEADLINE: William S. Brennen, 72, an Aide In Luring Business to New York

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
William Stuart Brennen, who helped the Beame and Koch administrations to lure businesses to New York City, died on Wednesday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 72.
He suffered a brief illness, said Mort Lawrence, a family friend. 
 Mr. Brennen also served Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller as First Deputy Superintendent of Banks for four years and was then chairman of the now-defunct Greenwich Savings Bank. At his death, he was a partner in Brennen & Stack, a law firm dealing with banking, international commerce and real estate.
Mr. Brennen first seemed headed for a career on the high seas. He graduated as a licensed ship's officer from the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., and served in the Allied landings in North Africa, Anzio, Italy, and Normandy, France, during World War II. After three and a half years of sea duty, he went on to graduate from Columbia College in 1947 and from Columbia Law School two years later. He then joined the state's Banking Department.
Starting in the late 1940's, he took part in politics as a member of the Young Republican Club, helping to map strategy for local and statewide campaigns.
He supported Mr. Rockefeller's bid for the gubernatorial nomination in 1958, and when Mr. Rockefeller moved into the Governor's mansion he promoted him to First Deputy Superintendent.
The Greenwich Savings Bank recruited him as senior vice president in 1963 and elected him president in 1969 and chairman in 1971. He retired 10 years later when the bank was merged into the Metropolitan Savings Bank.
While still at the bank in 1974, Mr. Brennen was asked by Mayor Abraham D. Beame to form the New York City Industrial Development Agency, which he served as volunteer chairman for 12 years. During that time, the agency approved more than $500 million in loans to companies wanting to do business in the city.
In 1983, Mr. Beame's successor, Edward I. Koch, called on Mr. Brennen to help revamp the city's economic apparatus, and he served successively as Commissioner of Business Development and Commissioner of International Business Development. He retired from city service in 1986 to practice law.
Mr. Brennen is survived by his wife of 45 years, Justine Bright Brennen; two sons, Stephen, of Chicago, and Robert, of Pearl River, N.Y., and a granddaughter.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Tribe to Invest Casino Profits in a Boatyard

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The old-salt maritime culture of New London, Conn., has appeared headed for the history books in recent years. The whaling fleets are faded memories, the submarine bays mere shadows of their cold war height.
Ten miles up the Thames River in Ledyard, the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe has surged from one triumph to another as owner of what is estimated to be the country's most profitable gambling enterprise, Foxwoods Casino. From hotels and golf courses to spas and gravel quarries, the tribe has poured its millions into the local economy, becoming the economic engine of the region and its largest private employer. 
 Yesterday, the two trajectories met.
The tribe, in an announcement at New London City Hall, said it would single-handedly return shipbuilding to New London. Tribal officials said a new subsidiary would begin building and selling ferryboats, first to be used to transport casino patrons across Long Island Sound, and after that for a national and international market that the tribe thinks will keep New London welders and pipe fitters at work well into the next century.
The boats will be designed to be among the fastest in the world. They will cost $11 million each and have a capacity of 330 passengers.
Although the Pequots spoke grandly of their desires to revive the New London maritime business, the plan would bring obvious benefits to the tribe. In the short run, the ferryboats would serve to bring more customers from New York City and Boston to the casino.
But more broadly, the shipyard would be the first part of an aggressive diversification program the tribe announced last year, in the belief that the Pequots' gambling bonanza would eventually wane because of growing competition from other casinos in the Northeast. They would build their conglomerate in their own backyard, tribal officials said, where they have lived for centuries, where their 12,000 employees live and where local investments, in the often hostile and jealous environment of local politics, also make for good public relations.
Building their own shipyard, a far costlier endeavor than would be necessary to supply their own needs for boats, is the first major step in that process, tribal officials said yesterday. In New London, they said, they will also get a skilled work force, as the Electric Boat submarine yard continues to lay off workers through the end of the century. There may also be Federal training money available, as former submarine workers are retrained in aluminum building techniques instead of steel.
"We are setting up a marketing company at the same time, and if we can sell these boats aggressively, it will be a new future," said Henry J. Sockbeson, a tribal lawyer and leader for the boat yard project.
"What this means," said the New London City Manager, Richard Brown, "is the return of shipbuilding to New London."
The Pequots do not do things in a small way. Since they opened their casino in 1992 on a wooded reservation that had, not too many years earlier, been reduced to a few trailers inhabited by people struggling at businesses like hydroponic gardening and pig farming, they do not appear to have failed at anything they have touched. Operating as a sovereign nation outside the reach of Federal and state tax collectors, the roughly 350-member tribe earned $600 million in gross revenues last year on slot machines alone, according to a spokesman.
The new boats are unlike anything in use in North America, tribal officials said. Designed two years ago by a British company, FBM Marine Group, there are only five of the boats in existence, crossing the straits between Hong Kong and Macao at a cruising speed of 47 knots, Mr. Sockbeson said.
"Fast enough to rip the contacts right out of your eyes," he said.
The boats will offer airline-style first- and second-class seating, and will be built by an initial crew of 60 people. They will work in the three bays of a bankrupt steel company that provided deck plates for the Navy's submarine fleet before going under in 1990.
The new tribal subsidiary will have an initial annual payroll of $2 million, but Mr. Sockbeson declined to disclose the total investment.
But there are barriers to the plan. Because the ferryboats are a new design for United States waters, featuring innovations like a computer-controlled foil to cut through waves for a smoother ride, the first hurdle, Mr. Sockbeson said, will involve approval from the Coast Guard. Consultants and engineers have been retained by the tribe, he said, to codify the construction plans and work with Coast Guard officials.
A second question, especially for the first four or five boats to be used by the tribe, is where they will be allowed to dock, especially in New York and Boston.
The Pequots' tribal chairman, Richard A. Hayward, said that part of the appeal of the project was how it combined elements of the past and future. Pequots earned their livelihood from the sea for centuries, he said, so the venture is a kind of psychological homecoming.
"In a sense, with us returning to the sea to carry out this enterprise, we are closing the circle," Mr. Hayward said.

HEADLINE: Mayor Unveils Reduced Capital Budget

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a capital plan yesterday that would cut spending by $1 billion even after accounting for revenues and savings that would require a reversal of a judge's ruling and an unlikely change in a state law.
In unveiling the $16.2 billion, four-year capital budget, Mr. Giuliani said the spending plan would be financed in part by the $1 billion he still expects from the sale of the city's water and sewer system. The Mayor's proposal last year to sell the system -- with the proceeds to be used for school construction and other projects -- collapsed in March when a state judge declared it illegal. 
 The Mayor's proposal yesterday also relies on more than $600 million in savings that would depend on a revision Mr. Giuliani has proposed in what is known as the Wicks Law. The state law, first passed in 1921, requires local governments to hire at least four separate contractors for any public works project costing more than $1 million.
Without the change in the law or the proceeds from the sale, the Mayor and his aides said, the city would have to make still deeper cuts than those proposed yesterday or to borrow more money to maintain even a reduced level of construction or repairs for buildings and highways.
The unveiling of the Mayor's proposal came a day after mayoral aides disclosed that Mr. Giuliani would propose the creation of a new public authority that would allow the city to circumvent the state's constitutional limit on the city's debt. At its present level of spending, the city will reach the limit within the next year or so.
In a news conference at City Hall, Mr. Giuliani said his capital budget proposal would insure that there was "no major interruption in the rebuilding of our buildings, our roads, our bridges, our highways, our schools and also our subways" after the drastic cuts during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's.
"That will continue, even though we've made reductions," he said.
But the Mayor's proposal faced sharp criticism from the Democrats who control the City Council and who will almost certainly fight for more spending as budget negotiations proceed in the weeks ahead.
The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said, in particular, that money for rebuilding the city's crumbling schools, which would stay about at current levels in the Mayor's proposal, should be increased. Mr. Vallone has proposed extending the city's temporary surcharge on the personal income tax to raise $1.4 billion for additional school construction over the next four years. He has said that extending the surcharge, which expires in December, would be a major priority for the year.
"We have no place to go but up," Mr. Vallone said of the Mayor's proposal. "It has no additional funding for education. It is certainly silent about what we have put down as our No. 1 priority, which is increasing spending for schools."
Mr. Giuliani said he needed to include the estimated savings from the Wicks Law change and the proceeds from the proposed water sale because he was lobbying in the State Legislature for the revision and appealing the judge's ruling against the sale.
The Mayor's proposed change in the Wicks Law would allow the city to reduce the cost of many of its construction projects by hiring one contractor instead of breaking each project over $1 million into separate contracts. While Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed exempting projects in New York City that cost less than $5 million, Mr. Giuliani has proposed raising the threshold to $20 million. He has argued, as have previous mayors, that the law unfairly saddled the city with higher construction costs and delays.
But various efforts to repeal or revise the law -- including a pitched battle three years ago led by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- have died in the face of lobbying by the construction trades that are the law's main beneficiaries. And the prospect that the revision will pass the Assembly or the Senate are bleak at best, officials on both sides said yesterday.
The Mayor's plan would cut capital spending in virtually every municipal agency over the next four years. Those reductions would result in the delay or cancellation of a number of construction projects for housing, courts, parks and highways.
One of the biggest reductions -- at $183 million -- would come in bridge repairs, including the delay of a renovation of the Brooklyn Bridge, scheduled to begin in 1998, until after the year 2000. The Mayor said it made sense to delay the project until the continued renovation of the Manhattan Bridge was finished, to avoid major tie-ups at two East River bridges.
The plan also includes sharp cuts in housing renovations that in part reflect the administration's efforts to put repossessed buildings in private hands rather than rebuild them with city funds.
The Mayor's proposal did include a $500 million increase to the city's subway and bus systems that Mr. Giuliani promised to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority last week in exchange for an immediate $250 million infusion in cash for operating expenses.
The city's school system was among the few areas that faced no reduction. The Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, expressed relief that school construction had been spared. At the same time, however, he said the system did not now have enough money for all the repairs and construction it needs and alluded in a statement to the Council's alternative proposal for more money.
"I am heartened," he said, "that the school system's numerous and urgent capital needs, the vast majority of which cannot be addressed at current funding levels, are recognized as a priority."

HEADLINE: Senators Parry on Gasoline Tax and Wages

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
Freed of all legislative burdens until Tuesday, the Senate today devoted the first day of its four-day weekend to politics -- and history.
On a more or less contemporary note, Senator Bob Dole attacked President Clinton over the 4.3-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax increase that was enacted in 1993 despite unanimous Republican opposition. Seizing on the recent rise in gasoline prices, Mr. Dole said, "Americans are overtaxed and need relief." 
 Then Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, outbid him by 32 years, marking the 35th anniversary of Mr. Dole's first vote against increasing the minimum wage.
"Bob Dole was wrong then," Mr. Kennedy said. "And he's wrong now" in opposing an increase in the hourly minimum to $5.15 from $4.25. "No one who works for a living should have to live in poverty," Mr. Kennedy said.
Mr. Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, appeared before the friendly Republican-majority Senate Finance Committee, which is considering his proposal to repeal the gasoline tax increase before the summer driving season begins in earnest on Memorial Day.
"This tax hike has not only hurt Americans who drive to work, school, worship or on vacation, it penalizes truckers and others who drive for their livelihood," Mr. Dole said. "Repealing this gas tax immediately will lower transportation prices, help to keep inflation in check and help to protect the jobs of millions of Americans who work in transportation-related businesses."
Democrats on the committee defended the tax increase as part of a package that had reduced the Federal budget deficit. "We need this revenue," Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York said of the nearly $5 billion that the 4.3-cent increase provides the Government in annual receipts. "I hope we keep it."
The next battleground was the minimum wage, where Senator Dole, as majority leader, has used a variety of parliamentary devices to prevent a vote for more than a month.
First the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, told a news conference that it appeared that Mr. Dole was trying to turn the Senate into the House, with "no votes, no amendments, no debate, no opportunity for real discussion about some of the more important issues we're facing, including the minimum wage."
Then Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and Senators Kennedy, Carl Levin of Michigan, Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont held another news conference, with a television commercial from John F. Kennedy's 1960 Presidential campaign as exhibit A. In that commercial, Kennedy criticized his opponent, Richard M. Nixon, for calling a 25-cent increase, to $1.25, "extreme."
"A number of Republicans," Mr. Leahy said, "tell us privately if it comes to a vote, they will vote with us." At least four of them have stated so publicly, so that, with the Senate's 47 Democrats, a wage increase now commands a majority.
Senator Kennedy and Mr. Reich answered Republican accusations that they neglected the issue when Democrats controlled Congress in 1993-94 and were bringing it up in this election year only for political reasons. Mr. Reich said the earlier, and ultimately unsuccessful, fight for universal health insurance coverage "took precedence." Mr. Kennedy, who said the cost of guaranteed health insurance would have been 40 cents to 50 cents an hour per worker, declared that workers had madeclear that they overwhelmingly preferred "a guarantee of good, quality health care" to a minimum-wage increase.
Mr. Kennedy said he did not think Republicans could continue to forestall a vote.
"This is a corruption of the process in terms of the United States Senate," he said. "They can do it for a period of time. But as a former heavyweight champion said, 'You can run, but you can't hide,' and there are not enough parliamentary tricks to preclude us from getting a vote on the Senate floor."
Then Mr. Dole appeared briefly on the floor and announced that he would seek to prevent any wage amendment from being offered during next Tuesday's legislative activity: consideration of a bill to reimburse discharged employees of the White House travel office for legal expenses. Mr. Daschle said the Democrats would filibuster.
