HEADLINE: Off-Duty Officer Kills Robbery Suspect

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 3

 BODY:
An off-duty New York City housing police officer shot and killed one of four men trying to rob his father's gasoline station here Thursday night, the Nassau County police said today.
The three other suspects, who were arrested shortly after the attempted robbery, told the police that the slain suspect had bragged about holding up the same Getty station on Pine Hollow Road a year ago. 
 This time, however, Joseph Capapano, a 23-year-old officer assigned to a police housing unit in Brooklyn, was working at the station, filling in for his father, Joseph Capapano Sr., who purchased the station only six weeks ago.
"He was helping his dad out, pumping some gas, when around 9:30 this fellow walks in and begins talking about maybe buying some cigarettes," said Detective Sgt. Robert Edwards.
"The fellow hung around for a few minutes and Joe asked if he wanted any help and he said he was waiting for his girlfriend," Sergeant Edwards said. "When Joe turned around to walk into the service bay, this fellow grabbed him from behind, put his arm around the neck in a choke hold, stuck a hard object into his back and said: 'All I want is your money. Don't do anything crazy and you won't be hurt.' "
At that point, Officer Capapano, who was dressed in mechanic's clothes but carrying his service revolver under his belt, grabbed his gun, turned and fired two shots into the robber, Sergeant Edwards said.
The police said they later determined that the slain suspect, Dwight Oliver, 33, of Glen Cove, L.I., was not armed and had apparently formed a fist and pressed a knuckle into the officer's back.
"There was no way for Officer Capapano to know that the suspect was not armed," Sergeant Edwards said. "The respone was instantaneous."
Sergeant Edwards said he did not believe that Officer Capapano had done anything wrong. Like Nassau County police officers, he said, Mr. Capapano was required to carry his service revolver while off duty.
Sergeant Edwards said another off-duty New York City housing police officer who worked with Officer Capapano in Brooklyn had witnessed the incident. He said the other officer, who was not identified, had brought a car in for repairs and was in the bay service area when he saw the attempted robbery.
The police said Mr. Oliver was unemployed and had an arrest record in Nassau for a robbery in 1995 and an illegal drug sale in 1993.
The three other suspects -- Kenneth Wilson, 19, Stan Ambles, 25, and Matt Laboy, 23, all of Glen Cove -- were arrested in a parking lot behind the gasoline station in a car that the police said had stolen license plates.
They were charged with conspiracy to commit robbery, and all pleaded not guilty at their arraignment this afternoon in First District Nassau County Court in Hempstead. Judge Leah Ruskin set bail for Mr. Wilson and Mr. Ambles at $25,000 each and for Mr. Laboy at $50,000, because of an arrest record. None of the suspects made bail, and they were remanded to the county jail. A hearing was scheduled for Tuesday.
Sergeant Edwards said that the four men had been drinking beer in their car when they decided to commit a robbery.
"One of them said he had done this station before," Sergeant Edwards said, "so they gave him a hooded pullover sweatshirt -- what they call a hoodie -- and he wore that into the gas station."
Police records showed that an unsolved robbery had occurred at the station a year ago. "And the description of the robber fits that of Dwight Oliver," Sergeant Edwards said.

HEADLINE: Rally in Dow Is Quashed By Nervous Bond Market

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Technology and speculative stocks rallied yesterday from Thursday's steep retreat. But an early rebound in the broader stock market quickly wilted as interest rates rose in the bond market, which remained nervous about inflation despite a weaker-than-expected April employment report.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.24 points to close at 5,478.03 after clinging to a modest gain most of the session. For the week, the gauge of blue-chip performance was down 89.96 points. 
 On Thursday, the Dow plunged nearly 77 points and broader indexes tumbled as mounting evidence of a revitalized economy compounded fears that yesterday's employment report would disclose the third consecutive big monthly increase in jobs. Investors have been worried that rising payrolls would create too much spending power and bring on inflationary pressures that would lead to higher interest rates.
But yesterday morning, the Labor Department reported that while the nation's unemployment rate dipped in April the number of payroll jobs increased by only 2,000.
Bonds rallied early on the smaller-than-expected increase in jobs, lifting the stock market. But the bond market's underlying worries about inflation soon became obvious as Treasury prices fell. Long-term interest rates, which on Thursday closed above 7 percent for the first time in almost a year, rose even higher, undercutting the recovery in the broader stock market.
Still, the Nasdaq market -- one of Thursday's biggest losers as investors locked in profits on the recent rally in technology and smaller-company shares -- rose 6.27, to 1,184.60. But that was down sharply from a gain of more than 15 points earlier in the session.
Other indicators dominated by more speculative issues also managed a gain for the day.
The Russell 2000 list of smaller companies, which had risen with the Nasdaq to 10 consecutive record closes before Thursday's selloff, rose 0.91, to 346.85. The American Stock Exchange's market value index rose 0.72, to 589.69.
But broader market indicators followed the Dow lower. The New York Stock Exchange's composite index fell 0.81, to 345.40, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.75, to 641.63.
Declining issues led advancers by a slim margin on the Big Board, where volume totaled 434 million shares as of 4 P.M., down from Thursday's session.
Speculative issues have been outperforming the blue-chip market for weeks on expectations that those businesses will benefit most from an improving economy.
The Government reported Thursday that the economy -- as measured by the gross domestic product -- expanded at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the first three months of the year.
In addition to increased spending on consumer goods, the G.D.P. report attributed much of the first-quarter growth to heavy spending for business computers. That news reinforced a series of strong earnings reports and other encouraging news in the technology sector, which was one of the few sectors to withstand some of Thursday's selloff.
Yesterday, technology shares rallied again. Among the Nasdaq's most active issues, Intel rose 11/16 , to 6811/16 , Cisco Systems gained 1/2, to 50 5/8, and Sun Microsystems rose 3/8, to 57 3/8.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Motorola gained 2, to 62 5/8; Compaq Computer rose 1 1/8, to 47 3/4, and Digital Equipment rose 3/4, to 57. I.B.M., a Dow component, rose 1/4, to 108 1/8.
Zenith Electronics continued to surge, gaining 2 3/4, to 15 3/4. The stock more than doubled this week after Zenith announced plans to enter the on-line business with two new modem systems.
Overseas, the Tokyo Stock Exchange was closed in observance of a Japanese national holiday. In Europe, Frankfurt's DAX index tumbled 1.8 percent and London's FT-SE 100 fell 0.7 percent.

GRAPHIC: Table: "The Favorite Stocks" shows performance of the 15 issues with the most shareholders.

HEADLINE: PAYROLL GROWTH WAS FLAT IN APRIL

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
A day after the Government reported unexpectedly sharp growth in the economy in the first quarter, the Labor Department said today that the job market during April was lackluster. But the signs of more modest growth failed to dissipate the fears of a rise in inflation that rattled the financial markets on Thursday.
The nation's unemployment rate eased to 5.4 percent in April -- an improvement from 5.6 percent in March and the lowest level in 14 months -- despite a meager growth in payrolls of only 2,000 jobs. 
 The bond market was initially pleased with the job data, which were accompanied by a Commerce Department report of moderate increases in incomes and spending. But bond prices subsequently skidded, pushing up interest rates, after investors found several things to worry about, including possible hints that wage pressures were beginning to mount. [Page 33.] Stock prices gave up early gains, and blue chips sank in late trading.
Unlike the two preceding months, when job growth far exceeded expectations and frightened inflation-wary securities markets, the April results reduced chances that the Federal Reserve would find it necessary to tighten monetary policy soon.
Fears that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates -- perhaps as early as this month -- mounted on Thursday, when the Government reported that the economy grew at a 2.8 percent pace in the first three months of the year, about double most predictions.
The Clinton Administration, quick to take credit for good economic performance, pointed to what is now 20 consecutive months with unemployment below 6 percent and to a rise in wages that it says is enough to help long-squeezed workers but not so much as to risk inflation. But it skirted over the lack of any significant increase of jobs last month.
"There's no sign of accelerating inflation in terms of wages pushing prices," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview. Mr. Reich also appeared at a White House briefing, joined by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and by Martin N. Baily, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, to trumpet economic gains.
For the Republicans, Senator Connie Mack of Florida, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, focused on the "disappointing" rise in April of 2,000 jobs, all of them in government, and on the fact that the two-tenths of a point decline in the unemployment rate was entirely a result of a contraction in the labor force.
The Republican National Committee finally joined the fray, contending that the economy today was weaker than in 1992, when Mr. Clinton was attacking President George Bush for presiding over the "worst economic performance in 50 years."
The committee said that "the Bush economy Clinton so shrilly attacked grew 4.7 percent" in the first quarter of the election year, not a "sluggish" 2.8 percent. And it added, "Even in the last quarter of Bush's Presidency, when Clinton's attacks had reached a fever pitch, the economy was growing at a rate of 4.3 percent -- more than half again faster than today's economy, about which Bill Clinton crows so loudly."
In contrast to today, more than five years into an economic expansion, the economy in 1992 was coming out of a recession and was plagued by unemployment that averaged two percentage points above last month's 5.4 percent rate.
The April job figures were particularly difficult to interpret, reflecting not just economic crosscurrents but unusually big adjustments for recurrent seasonal variations, like the surge each spring in construction jobs.
For example, today's report showed that the construction industry actually added 221,000 jobs in April. But because such jobs normally surge in April, the gain fell short of what the adjustment factor anticipated, resulting in a reported decline of 53,000.
In some parts of the country, the department reported, hiring was held down because workers were already in jobs as a result of unusually favorable winter weather. In others, poor April weather dampened activity and delayed hiring.
Over all, employer payrolls jumped 795,000 but they edged up by only 2,000 when adjusted for seasonality, far below the 120,000 or so that analysts had predicted.
The seasonal problem was compounded by the fact that there were four weeks between job surveys this year while in two of the two preceding years there was a five-week interval, a difference weighing heavily on the adjustment factor.
And the 17-day March strike at General Motors also muddied the statistics as 28,000 returning strikers limited the reported loss of factory jobs to 17,000, the second consecutive decline. The March loss, swelled by strikers, was 61,000.
Despite all the conflicting data and market fears, a top Federal Reserve official expressed satisfaction with the course the economy appeared to be following. "The basic message on the statistics that we've seen in recent months and recent days is that the economy continues on a fairly solid, moderate growth path with low inflation," Edward G. Boehne, president of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank, told Reuters. "I think if you look at several months running," added Mr. Boehne, who serves on the policy-making Open Market Committee, "we have a growth in employment of 166,000 on average per month, which is a number that's quite consistent with this moderate growth path."
The Labor Department's survey of households found the labor force shrank 294,000 in April, enough to push the unemployment rate down to the bottom end of the range of 5.4 to 5.8 percent within which it has fluctuated since October 1994.
The number of newly unemployed -- those idled for less than five weeks -- fell for the second consecutive month, consistent with other figures showing a decline in first-time claims for unemployment insurance.
Over all, private analysts tended to combine the April results with those of preceding months in concluding that the economy was showing solid but not runaway growth.
The job data from February and March "overstated economic strength," Edward S. Hyman and Nancy Lazar of the International Strategy and Investment Group told clients. "The April employment report probably overstates economic weakness."
For workers, the signs of higher hourly pay were welcome, but analysts said the markets seemed to focus their fears that inflation might heat up on the calculation that average hourly earnings jumped last month by 7 cents, to $11.75, after a 2-cent March rise.
Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, noted that the 12-month increase in hourly earnings was now 3.1 percent, close to what prevailed over the last year but "somewhat higher" than the experience from 1992 through early 1995. But others dismissed the latest jump as another example of how hourly earnings tend to surge in the first month of each quarter before settling back.
Geographically, the department reported that the jobless rate in the Northeast, which jumped six-tenths of a point in March, retreated five-tenths of a point in April to stand at 5.8 percent. Changes in the South, Midwest and West were limited in each case to a statistically insignificant one-tenth of a point.
Consumer spending rose six-tenths of 1 percent in March, just half the February pace, the Commerce Department said. Spending spurted in February after severe weather had curbed consumption.
The department also reported that personal incomes rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March, slower than the eight-tenths of 1 percent advance a month earlier. The February increase was the largest since a nine-tenths of 1 percent advance in January 1995.
The March increase in incomes would have been higher except for the widespread effects of the strike at General Motors, the report said.

Graph: "Personal Income" shows total personal income from Oct. 1994 to March 1996. (Source: Commerce Department)(pg. 35)

HEADLINE: 'Save the Whalers' Effort Is Extended for 2 Weeks

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 3

 BODY:
The Hart ford Whalers are not leaving Con necticut at least not yet. A campaign to "Save the Whalers" by selling 11,000 season tickets in a month has been extended two weeks, after the National Hockey League team reached 69 percent of that goal, team and state officials said today.
But as state leaders congratulated themselves on selling 7,601 season tickets thus far -- more than the Whalers sold last season -- Mayor Michael P. Peters warned that selling 3,400 additional tickets in less than two weeks would be difficult. 
 "It's a very tough order," Mr. Peters said. "I'd rather have the campaign go to September, but that's not going to happen."
The effort may be as much a campaign to save a linchpin of Hartford's economy as a bid to keep Connecticut's only major league sports franchise. The team, which plays in the Coliseum of the Hartford Civic Center, brings, on average, 13,000 people into the downtown area 43 nights a year. One restaurant owner, Michael A. Seaver, credits the Whalers for 20 percent of the business at his Chuck's Steak House.
State leaders have been trying to pitch the effort as a statewide campaign, and the Speaker of the House, Thomas Ritter, Democrat of Hartford, expressed frustration that southern Connecticut had not shown more support.
Mr. Ritter pointed out that several major corporations outside the Hartford area, like Union Carbide in Danbury and General Electric in Fairfield, had declined to subsidize their employees' purchases of tickets, as some Hartford companies have done.
"It's the rest of the state that will now determine the future of the Whalers," Mr. Ritter said. "Just as we in Hartford do positive things for the rest of the state, I think it's important for the rest of the state to step up to the plate."
At today's news conference, Gov. John G. Rowland joked, as he had before, about Fairfield County residents rooting for the wrong team -- the New York Rangers.
Some supporters are hoping that a promise the Whalers made today will help boost sales -- a pledge not to negotiate with any other cities while the ticket campaign continues.
Ticket sales may have been hindered by news stories and admissions by the Whalers' owners that they were looking at other cities. As recently as Tuesday, officially the last day of the campaign, the team's general manager, James E. Rutherford, said the Whalers had to begin looking at alternatives to Hartford.
But today the league's Commissioner, Gary Bettman, said: "The Whalers will not be exploring other alternatives. They will not be talking to other cities."
Still, the Whalers assert that if they sell anything less than 11,000 season tickets, they will be forced to consider moving. "If we stop short of 11,000, we run the risk of losing millions," Mr. Rutherford said.
The Coliseum seats 15,600 for hockey games, and with their 13,000-per-game average, the Whalers' attendance ranks 24th among the 26 N.H.L. teams this season. In the last two years, officials say, the team has lost $30 million.
In the meantime, the Whalers will begin negotiating more seriously with the state on revising their contract so that the team gets money from food concessions and parking -- another requirement for the Whalers to stay in Hartford.

HEADLINE: NBC Will Buy Rockefeller Center Space

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
They will not even officially take title to the property till later this month, but Rockefeller Center's new owners have already sold a huge chunk of one of the center's 12 landmarked buildings.
Yesterday NBC announced that it would pay $440 million for the 1.6 million square feet it has long occupied at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, the flagship building of the 63-year-old complex. 
 "This seemed the best way to insure our permanence in what we see as a premier facility with continuing cachet," said Michael Sherlock, an NBC executive vice president.
The sale raises the question of whether Rockefeller Center, which has been buffeted first by a highly publicized bankruptcy and then by bidding wars by several would-be investor groups, will now find itself parceled out.
The new owners vehemently deny that. "This is a long-term investment; we did not buy this to sell it," said Jerry I. Speyer, president of Tishman Speyer Properties, which along with Goldman, Sachs & Company and David Rockefeller, is acquiring the center's 12 buildings.
Indeed, most real estate people doubt that there would be much demand for office condominiums like the one that NBC will now own. But many do wonder whether, down the road, the temptation to sell entire buildings might prove irresistible. They note that Rockefeller Center sold 1251 Avenue of the Americas, the former Exxon Building, to Mitsui Fudosan in 1986, and that McGraw-Hill has always co-owned its Rockefeller Center building.
"They may all just decide they have too much commercial real estate space in their portfolio," said Stephen B. Siegel, president of the Edward S. Gordon Company, a big real estate service firm.
Others suggest that the new owners had to sell the space to finance the purchase of the center, much as the leveraged buyout specialists of the 1980's financed their takeovers of companies by selling off pieces of the businesses they acquired. But Mr. Speyer said such speculation was absurd. "We certainly had the internal equity to finance this purchase," he said. The sole reason for the sale, he said, was to insure that NBC did not leave the center and sublet the space to someone else. "We did this to insure NBC's continued commitment to the center," he said.
The new owners of Rockefeller Center are paying slightly more than $306 million, or $8 a share, to buy out the investors in the real estate investment trust that held the $1.3 billion mortgage on the center. The group will also assume about $845 million in debt and other liabilities. The sale of the center is scheduled to be completed when the group submits a plan of reorganization to the United States Bankruptcy Court later this month.
The sale of the space to NBC should not make much difference for tenants and visitors to Rockefeller Center. NBC has been a tenant since the center opened in 1933, and the purchase represents neither a consolidation nor an expansion of its space. The network will continue to broadcast the "Today Show" from space in a nearby center building, 10 Rockefeller Plaza, which it did not buy. "It's really not going to mean much change for anybody," Mr. Siegel said.
But for Rockefeller Center itself, the sale represents yet another fray in the fabric of what had once been viewed as the All-American building complex, a place on every tourist's must-see list in New York.
Indeed, Americans outside New York as well as within the city were surprised when the Rockefeller Group took 12 of the center's 16 buildings public, through a real estate investment trust that in effect allowed shareholders to hold a mortgage on the center. For many, surprise was followed by dismay when, in 1989, this quintessentially American property was suddenly in Japanese hands, as the Rockefeller family sold an 80 percent stake in the Rockefeller Group to the Mitsubishi Estate Company.
The public's worst fears about the transaction were not realized. Life, both for tenants and tourists, was not appreciably different at the center under Japanese rule. Mitsubishi's worst fears, however, were realized. The real estate investment trust's debt service on Rockefeller Center had been predicated on having the annual rents rise as high as $65 a square foot by the early 1990's; the center was lucky to get half that amount after the recession hit.
Last year Mitsubishi walked away from its investment in Rockefeller Center as losses mounted, and the Rockefeller Group filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for its 12 landmarked buildings. Four other buildings that are either co-owned, or owned by others and managed by Rockefeller Center, were not included in the bankruptcy. Since then, various groups -- including one in which General Electric, the parent company of NBC, would have been a partner with the Chicago investor Sam Zell -- have negotiated to buy it.
For NBC, buying the space is a good deal. The current lease, which was signed in the landlords' market of 1986, included a huge rent increase next year. The purchase will thus save NBC a good deal of money during the next decade, according to real estate brokers.
"NBC got a real good buy, especially in light of the bump," one real estate executive said, referring to the scheduled rent increase. "From a landlord's point of view they signed one of the last great leases of the 80's, so buying their space is clearly a huge savings to them."
NBC will not talk finances, but Mr. Sherlock, its executive vice president, insists that cost was not the driving factor. He said the company wanted the flexibility to install technology and otherwise move people and furniture around without constantly having to deal with the Rockefeller Center bureaucracy. "We still have to get everything approved by the owner, but now that owner is us," Mr. Sherlock said.
NBC also got options to renew the lease on the space occupied by the "Today Show" studios, which were not included in the sale. The current lease, which runs out in 2003, can now be renewed through the year 2022. The new deal also included revisions of various restrictions the television operation had faced. For example, under its old lease, NBC had to hook and unhook the camera kiosks "Today" used to interact with people on the street; now they can be left up permanently if NBC wants.
There may soon be more for the network to show at Rockefeller Center. Television City, a theme restaurant, is scheduled to move into space recently vacated by Lindy's, and Orvis, an outdoor clothing shop, is said by real estate brokers to be negotiating for space occupied by Herman's, the sporting goods chain that has just announced plans to liquidate its stores.

HEADLINE: SUNY: Grand Vision and Pragmatism Collide

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The vision was a grand one: a state university system to rival California's, offering inexpensive education to students from Buffalo to Long Island and training a skilled work force to attract business to the state.
But three decades after Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller pushed the establishment of the nation's largest public system from a patchwork of teachers colleges and specialized schools, representatives of a new Republican governor say that the State University of New York does not work. 
 The governing trustees appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki describe SUNY in terms that could apply to the East German steel industry, circa 1988: a centralized, overregulated system whose lackluster campuses have little incentive to improve.
"Central planning is counterproductive," said Thomas F. Egan, the chairman of the board since February. "It saps the vitality and the resourcefulness of an administrator to perform better."
In this, he and the six other trustees appointed by Mr. Pataki last winter are at odds with the six Cuomo-era appointees, who say the problem is a lack of state aid, not too much central control. The dispute led to the resignation of Chancellor Thomas A. Bartlett this week.
The Rockefeller vision resulted in a sprawling system of 64 campuses, but without a distinguished flagship, no Ann Arbor or Berkeley or Chapel Hill.
With campuses in almost every legislative district, the sprawl of the system has created its own political pork. Legislators, particularly upstate Republicans, oppose anything that threatens the SUNY economic engine in their districts.
The $4 billion SUNY budget, which must be approved by the Legislature, props up lesser campuses at the expense of those with more potential, the Pataki appointees say. Only the universities -- Binghamton, Stony Brook, Buffalo and Albany -- and a couple of specialized campuses, like the Industrial and Labor Relations School at Cornell or the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan, enjoy anything approaching national reputations.
The Pataki appointees -- one vote shy of a majority on the 14-member board, which has one student member -- propose a free-market approach to give campuses control over their finances.
Campuses could retain budget surpluses; any extra money now goes back to Albany headquarters. They could set their own tuitions, so Binghamton might charge several thousand dollars a year more than Cortland. And, they could set individual academic standards.
This approach, they argue, would free campuses from central restraints and force them to compete for resources and students. Though critics say that some campuses will wither, Mr. Egan contends that the system will be healthier.
"You've got to give them a little more flexibility and freedom," Mr. Egan said.
In this, he is at odds with the older trustees, most of them appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and many administrators who say the system is lackluster because the state has cut its share of SUNY operations by more than a third since 1988.
Both sides agree on the need for cuts, but they disagree on how to achieve them. The Cuomo appointees believe that central headquarters should engage the campuses in a deliberate planning process to decide whether to close campuses. They argue against leaving those decisions to the vagaries of the market.
Mr. Bartlett, who was hired by the Cuomo board 16 months ago, has argued with the Pataki trustees over their approach. He resigned on Tuesday and will leave June 15, or earlier if a replacement is found.
"What is at stake is the view of the future direction of the university and what is to be the meaning of mission of access and quality in the future," he said in an interview.
Time and again, the SUNY officials and trustees have asked the Legislature for help, either by giving them more money or by allowing them to do what most state universities have done -- eliminate weaker departments to protect or expand the stronger ones.
"You and your colleagues in the Legislature must make the decision about the future of the State University," Chancellor Bartlett told a group of legislators at a hearing this winter. "We can only go so far in cost cutting. Then the challenge becomes one of public policy."
 
Political Ties For Rural Areas
But legislative ties run deep. A case in point is the Agricultural and Technical College at Cobleskill. In farm country 30 miles west of Albany, it offers farming courses, like the management of dairy herds and repair of tractors, as well as teacher training, hotel management and medical lab techniques to about 2,400 students. It typifies the Rockefeller philosophy: access to higher education for students who might not be able to travel far from home.
"My parents would never have let me leave home for school, but they were O.K. about me commuting to Cobleskill," said Susan Reilly, an education major. "This way, I can be home when they need me to help at harvest time, but I'm also learning a skill so I can get a job somewhere else."
Last year, when Mr. Pataki proposed cutting SUNY's operating budget by $290 million, out of a $920 million appropriation, the trustees announced that they might have to close campuses. Reports circulated that Cobleskill and the five other agricultural and technical colleges would be the ones. It costs SUNY $400 more to educate each student there than at the system's 16 four-year colleges and university centers because of their small size and expensive technical programs.
But Cobleskill is in Senator James L. Seward's district. The campus employs 496 people from Schoharie and surrounding counties, and brings in $6 million a year for businesses.
"It's the core of the economy in that area," said Mr. Seward, a Republican who is the chairman of the energy committee and a member of the higher education committee.
After a long battle, with upstate Republicans protecting their campuses, the Legislature restored some of the SUNY cuts. Democrats oppose closures because they believe students from throughout the state should have campuses nearby and because of the political support they receive from SUNY unions, like the United University Professors.
 
Beyond Education For Some Regions
Republicans do not want to lose the jobs and prestige a campus provides their districts. "Many campuses are the economic and cultural center for a region," said Senator Kenneth P. LaValle, the Republican chairman of the higher education committee in the Senate. "Closing these institutions really isn't a possibility."
So when Mr. Pataki named new trustees for the university system and sent them to the Senate for confirmation, Mr. Seward and his colleagues made their position clear. "They found out there were a number of members of the Senate who didn't want to hear any more talk about closure of these campuses," Mr. Seward said.
The new trustees took that message to heart, and the administration is trying to improve the marketing of the agriculture and technical schools by creating an alliance to cut overall administrative costs and to offer more classes through computer networks linking campuses. One campus would offer, say, the dairy management course; students on other campuses could take it.
For the new trustees, it is another example of how they are trying to help campuses become more competitive with private colleges and with one another.
"You should encourage each of those campuses to go out and reinvent itself, or recreate itself, or sharpen its focus, or even alter its mission to be more responsive to what it perceives to be its market," Mr. Egan said. "It will get everyone working harder to try to please parents and students."
He argues that the goal is improvement and expansion, not scuttling campuses. "I would like to look back at my tenure as chairman and say that the State University better educated more students," he said this week.
Both sets of trustees acknowledge that the state can no longer support SUNY as it once did. They say it is inefficient to run 64 campuses, including 30 community colleges, with an average size of 5,000 students rather than the national average of 9,000.
Chancellor Bartlett, who presided over two systems, Oregon and Alabama, that cut programs, believes that closing a few campuses is preferable to eroding quality on all, or "thinning the soup."
"I would prefer to make the system smaller," Chancellor Bartlett said. "The legitimacy of our programs is one thing we cannot give away."
In 1988, the state contributed $1.2 billion, or 90 percent, of the system's operating budget. This year, the state's contribution is $733 million, or 49 percent, , and under Mr. Pataki's proposed budget for 1996-97, it would fall to $661 million.
In the same period, tuition has more than doubled, to $3,400 this year from $1,375 in 1988. Tuition will rise at least $250 next year and as much as $700 or $800, depending on the budget agreement being negotiated in the Legislature.
Enrollment across the system dropped by 10,000 students this year and applications are down 8.5 percent, which officials attribute in part to increased tuition.
"We're shifting the responsibility for public higher education in the state of New York from the state to the students and their families," said Theodore Sommer, a trustee from Binghamton, who led a board committee that examined tuition last fall.
New York State's investment in higher education -- including SUNY, the City University of New York, financial aid and subsidies for private institutions -- is the third largest in the nation, behind California and Texas. But its investment per capita is 47th in the nation. Higher education made up 4.4 percent of the total state budget in 1995.
 
New Round of Cuts, For Faculty Now
 Most campus presidents say that after years of coping with budget gaps by cutting maintenance or administration, they now need layoffs.
At the College at New Paltz, Alice Chandler, the president, said she needs to eliminate the physical education requirement and close the department, a savings of $300,000 from the dismissals of six faculty members and several adjuncts.
And SUNY wants to shed its three large teaching hospitals -- Upstate, Downstate and at Stony Brook, L.I. Years behind much of the health care industry, these hospitals have not been permitted to form doctors' networks or participate in health maintenance organizations. The new trustees want to turn them over to private management.
If the Legislature refuses to give SUNY budget authority for a free-market approach, some trustees say they will be unable to balance the books.
"This devolution plan is really the deliverance of SUNY," said Candace de Russy, one of the more vocal of the Pataki appointees. "Those who do not back devolution will be responsible for putting campus closure back on the table."
But SUNY traditionalists believe that closures are inevitable under the free-market plans, carried in a policy document the trustees wrote last fall called "Rethinking SUNY."
"Rethink SUNY means Downsize SUNY," said Edward C. Sullivan, a Democrat from Manhattan who is the chairman of the Assembly Higher Education Committee.
The trustees must manage an ever-shrinking budget without the freedom to treat the university as a business, unless the state chooses to add financial support.
"There's this notion that SUNY is very big and it is something that New York State can't afford," a former chancellor, D. Bruce Johnstone, said in a recent interview. "New York State may not choose to afford it, but that's not the same thing."

HEADLINE: Stupid Baseball Tricks

BYLINE: By Tom Friend; Tom Friend is the West Coast sports correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
THE MAN WHO WOULD SAVE baseball keeps Bazooka bubble gum in his front pocket. "Addicted," he says. He also has coins in his pocket, in case he stumbles upon an arcade. He isn't above racing with 14-year-olds to get to the best video games first, and he usually wins. "I kick kids out of the way," he says.
He also keeps a pen in his pocket, in case he sees a napkin. Sometimes he writes ideas on these napkins and files them under B -- for Brainstorms. "But, mostly, I doodle on them," he says. "Do it all the time. Pathetic. My wife thinks I'm mad. I tell her, 'If you think I'm mad, why'd you marry me?' " His hair is silver, his neckties are pink, his accent is Australian and, when he can't find a napkin, he writes on an easel that he carries from room to room.
A career counselor would spend 30 minutes with this 49-year-old man and assign him a most eccentric place. A place that tolerates surprise trips to the amusement park, napkin memos, an easel-on-wheels and jars of candy. A place that is insane enough to put baseball in its front pocket.
Fox Sports. 
 Fox, the network of the 90's, is about to take on the sport of the 50's. Rupert Murdoch will pay $565 million over the next five years to telecast the most selfish professional sport on earth, and the man leading the way -- David Hill, president of Fox Sports and occupant of a Sunset Boulevard office full of licorice -- fell asleep on his sofa last year during the fifth inning of a broadcast. The closest sport to baseball Hill has ever televised is cricket, which makes him about as qualified as . . . CBS.
Beginning in 1990, CBS paid $1.06 billion over four years to televise baseball -- and about five people watched. The network has itself, baseball owners, a recession and cable television to blame, but the essential fact is that baseball became terminally ill under CBS's watch. "Everyone at CBS who cared about the game felt like they went through hell with it," says Ed Goren, a former CBS executive who is now the executive producer of Fox Sports.
In its heyday, televised baseball had bonded grandfather, father and son. From 1953 to 1989, the Saturday-afternoon time slot for the Game of the Week had been written in granite at NBC. With little competition from local and cable television -- in the early 1970's, for instance, the Los Angeles Dodgers televised only their nine games up in San Francisco against the Giants -- ratings rose as high as 7.6 in 1978. (One rating point now equals roughly 954,000 homes).
But the Saturday afternoon ratings plummeted as the sport inundated local and cable television. By 1985, NBC's Saturday baseball ratings had sunk to 6.4 and by 1989, NBC's final year, the ratings had plunged to a subarctic 4.9. The ratings fell not only because baseball was overexposed; a new generation had taken over the remote, and basketball and football were now the preferred sports.
Neither CBS nor major league baseball had an antidote. CBS's ratings went from a 4.7 in its debut year of 1990 to a dismal 3.7 in its final year of 1993. By 1993, 30-second commercials were going for a minimal $15,000 to $20,000, and even the 55-and-over audience was scratching its head because CBS would show only an occasional Saturday Game of the Week. Viewers never knew when to tune in, and, by the tragic end, CBS had lost half a billion dollars.
"If you brought back Harry Coyle, Curt Gowdy, Tony Kubek, Vin Scully and Joe Garagiola as announcers," says Bob Costas of NBC, "the Saturday Game of the Week could still never get the same ratings as before."
SO, HOW LONG DID IT TAKE DAVID HILL TO agree to take on this foolish sport of baseball?
"A nanosecond," he says.
Fox executives, are arrogant to the core, and believe they could market even a game of pool. Reviving baseball is either the hip-retro thing to do or suicide, but Fox is diving in, assuming that baseball fans have no lawns to mow and that younger viewers have an attention span longer than 30 minutes. "We're the best marketers in all of sports -- us and Nike, that is," says a Fox executive. Of course, baseball has nowhere to go but up. If Fox fails, no one will blame the messenger; they will blame the game.
So, the master plan is to reach back into the 1970's and show Fox Saturday Baseball like clockwork, starting June 1 and ending the last weekend of the season. They will probably need a dramatic post-season to break even financially, and they can only hope Randy Johnson pitches every Saturday -- because all their pregame hyperbole won't help a bit once the games start.
Fox Sports had talked the same good game when it stole football from CBS. But its regular season ratings in 1994, its first year, were 6 percent worse than CBS's final season (12.1 for Fox versus 12.9 for CBS) and 3 percent worse in 1995. Of course, it may have taken the public some time to find Fox on the dial. But the point is, football is football, and Fox probably cannot reinvent baseball, either. "Actually, the game doesn't need that much," Goren says. "A tweak here, a tweak there."
Fox will televise four games regionally -- with few exceptions, the games will start at 1 P.M. locally -- and no other network (cable or local) will be allowed to show a Saturday afternoon game. Fox will then share the playoffs with NBC and ESPN, televise the World Series three times in five years, sell 30-second commericals for about $50,000 in the regular season and $300,000 in the World Series and try something baseball has never fully comprehended: promotion.
If ever a sport needed a personality transplant, it is baseball. The players do not always do interviews (witness Albert Belle of Cleveland, profanely trying to drive NBC's Hannah Storm from the dugout for no apparent reason before a World Series game). In 1994, they did not even do the World Series. They went on strike that summer, and when they finally returned last spring, attendance and ratings were down. Baseball was not so much a pastime as past its prime.
The sport has taken baby steps back, of course: Cal Ripken Jr.'s record for consecutive games played, the electric Yankee-Mariner playoff series and the usual ratings bonanza for the World Series. But Fox is about to ask people to stay indoors on a summer Saturday afternoon, and it is going to need a gimmick or Cal Ripken Jr. or both.
David Hill considered all of this during a January business meeting. He pulled out his black pen, could not find a napkin, settled for his daily planner and ended up drawing a microphoned base -- as in second base. The same network that invented the glowing hockey puck would now invent a base with ears. Does Roberto Alomar say, "Hey batter, batter . . . swing"? What does the runner at first say to the first baseman? Now we would know. David Hill sat in a daze that day, intending to turn baseball into another video game. Maybe this would get kids watching, and maybe it would keep him from snoring in the fifth inning.
He called his staff together and read them the rules. They would invent a new base; they would invent new music; they would make Albert Belle likable; they would hire announcers with famous announcer dads (or granddads); they would all watch "Field of Dreams" and "Bull Durham"; they would build their own Fox Field; they would be different for the sake of being different.
"And one more thing," Hill told his top executives. "If anybody talks about any dead guys during a broadcast, I'll sack 'em. I'm sick of dead guys! Whenever I turn on baseball, all I hear about is dead guys. If I hear a name, I'm gonna ask, 'Is he dead?' And if he is, you're fired. You're all fired!"
IT IS A MATCH MADE IN MAD MAGAZINE: baseball and Fox.
Baseball, for instance, cannot even get out of its own way. The men who run the game have no idea how to market it. Their idea of promotion is a stadium billboard saying, "Game Tonight."
"Yes, we've been conservative," says the acting commissioner of baseball, Bud Selig. "Does baseball have to lighten up? You bet we do."
Fox has several suggestions, and not one of them is a glow-in-the-dark baseball. Fox intends to aid the viewer in more subtle ways, like turning the base runner into a dot.
For instance, if a runner is on first, and the camera is zeroing in on the pitcher-batter confrontation, Fox's graphic department might place a miniature diamond in the bottom corner of the screen. And when the runner moves, he will be represented by a dot in that miniature diamond. So, if there is a single to right field and you want to know if the runner is rounding second, just follow the dots.
"Cool," says Tony Gwynn of the San Diego Padres. "Did you see ABC, NBC or CBS trying anything innovative like that? Heck no."
Of course, the graphic is not written in stone -- "How often do we put it up? And will it be distracting to the viewer?" asks George Greenberg, the creative director of Fox Sports -- but what is written in stone is Fox's baseball theme song.
"Guess what?" Greenberg says. "It's not 'Take Me Out to the Ballgame.' "
Greenberg put Hank Williams's music on ABC's "Monday Night Football" eight years ago and was urged in a frenetic phone call from Hill -- from an amusement park -- to put "Batman"-style music on Fox's football telecasts. "I want Batman plays football," Hill told him.
The baseball theme is a sort of "Tom Petty plays baseball." It has a lot of guitar, and will be accompanied visually by a 21st-century, robotic baseball player straight out of the video game Virtual Fighter.
The theme song will lead into an interactive pregame show that is an all-or-nothing attempt at romancing the 16-and-under population. Called "In the Zone," the show is part sitcom -- a teen-ager needs money to repair his VW bug, and forces his little brother to take a job as a Dodger Stadium vendor -- and part instructional. Kids will be taught how to steal a base, how to bunt and how to have their wishes come true. One segment, called Cyber-base, will invite kids to E-mail their fantasies, which Fox will then bring to life. Over Easter weekend alone, the network received 40 such requests, including one from a 13-year-old who wrote: "I want to take Ken Griffey to school with me. He could come to all my classes and even eat lunch with me."
There will also be segments called Away From the Plate (human interest stories about major-league players who, for instance, adopt children or who love to bowl), and the Hot Corner (a trendy round-up of baseball news and fashion, like whether to wear baseball caps backward this year). There is also the obligatory bloopers segment, and Fox executives nearly approved a feature called Hot Foot -- glorifying a prank of the week, like a player setting a teammate's cleats on fire -- until they realized that would set a poor example for their young audience.
Considering that the sport is failing to reach younger fans, this is baseball's rare chance to charm a new, impressionable generation. Atlanta's Cy Young Award winner, Greg Maddux, is scheduled to play Sega on the show -- which should help ratings -- and the hope is that these youngsters might just stay tuned for the adult pregame show at 12:30.
Not that the 12:30 show is designed for your grandfather. It will be staged in front of a stadium scoreboard and will showcase Steve Lyons, baseball's version of Terry Bradshaw. Lyons, who is known as Psycho, is the former Red Sox and White Sox player who once yanked down his uniform pants in front of 35,000 fans, so he had just the resume for Fox. With him will be Dave Winfield, the former Yankee who may finally get the last word on George Steinbrenner. The straight man will be Chip Caray, son of the Braves broadcaster Skip Caray and grandson of the legendary Cubs broadcaster, Harry Caray.
Fox's game analysts, meanwhile, are three extroverted former catchers -- Bob Brenley, Jeff Torborg and Tim McCarver -- and Ken Singleton, a former outfielder. It is a solid team, but traditional, one your grandfather would feel comfortable with. Baseball needs something more.
This is where the microphoned base comes in.
It is bound to be a contentious negotiation. Baseball would not dare let CBS put a mike in the bullpen, so the notion of a microphoned base seems implausible. Hill, who was to pitch the idea to Selig this spring, insists he is not doing it for gossip, but simply for the sounds of the game.
"I don't want to hear infielders," Hill says. "Because probably I lose our license."
On the other hand, it has been done -- sort of. In the 1970's Tommy Lasorda, then a Dodger third-base coach, was miked during several games and kept it fairly clean. During one conversation with Pete Rose, then the Reds' third baseman, Lasorda said, "Pete, our team just voted on who's the best-looking guy on your team."
"How'd I do?" Rose asked.
"You finished second," Lasorda said.
"Who's first?" Rose asked.
"The other 24 tied," Lasorda said.
Baseball fans adored it. Fox executives privately want to do it again -- 90's style -- but will have to win a unanimous vote of approval from the owners. "We're hopeful, but anyone can veto it," Goren says. But Fox also has baseball right where it wants it -- desperate -- so their innovations should win in a landslide.
"They have to trust us," Goren says of baseball. "We're not the enemy."
Selig agrees, up to a point. "You must remember there are some sensitive lines we can't cross. We can't disturb the game, but it's also in our best interest to listen. We can't be rigid in our thinking. We're in a new era, a new generation.
"One thing's for sure -- we can't do business the way we used to."
Fox seconds that emotion. The network has just hired the best play-by-play broadcasters nepotism can buy. They already had Caray in the studio, but now their lead game announcer will be Joe Buck, the son of the St. Louis announcer Jack Buck, accompanied by Thom Brenneman, son of the Reds announcer Marty -- and two more will be hired. "See, we're not rounding up the usual suspects," Goren says.
Of course, these sons and grandsons will do fine, as long as they remember the rule: no dead guys. "I'm only 27," says Buck. "How many dead guys could I have known?"
THE NETWORK THAT WOULD SAVE baseball first has to mingle with baseball.
It must make small talk with baseball the same way it did with football. The same way it persuaded Reggie White to sing "Amazing Grace" for Fox viewers on camera. The same way it cajoled Nate Newton, the rotund Dallas Cowboys lineman, into inviting a camera crew into his walk-in refrigerator.
They must also win over baseball's cabinet members -- Ken Griffey Jr. and Cal Ripken Jr., to name two.
Fox's marketing director, Tracy Dolgin, was assigned to Griffey. He flew down to spring training and (a day before breaking his arm skiing) extended his hand to the superstar. "Hi, I'm Tracy Dolgin."
"I'm George Griffey. . . . But don't call me that. Only my mom gets away with calling me George."
"O.K. Nice to meet you, George."
"You like your shins?"
Right away, Griffey and Fox were speaking the same language, so it was 1 down, 41 players to go: Fox's plan was to shoot promotional ads with 21 teams (two players from each) to extract some personality from the sport.
The key figure in Fox's marketing plan is Cal Ripken of Baltimore. He had broken Lou Gehrig's consecutive-game streak last summer -- which had helped revive the sport -- and Fox desperately needed to turn him into a comic.
Good luck, said Ripken's little brother, Bill. "I mean, the night Cal broke Gehrig's record, he went out and painted the town beige," he said.
Goren was assigned, nevertheless, to Cal. They met for breakfast in Beverly Hills, Goren handed him five scripts and Ripken shocked him by begging to do three of them. One commercial had Ripken being razzed by a mailman, who had never missed a day of work either -- even with barking dogs. Another revealed that Ripken set the record with the help of an evil twin, Hal Ripken, who lived in a trailer park. The third, a 60-second spot to be shown in movie theaters this summer, shows Ripken being run over by a speeding truck, hurtling 100 feet into a water fountain and still saying: "I can play tomorrow. It's just a scratch."
"We Wile E. Coyote him," Dolgin says.
To get an idea how much the spot meant to Ripken, he even took half a day off to film it.
All 42 players not only did the commericals for free, they also promised to stop by Hollywood this summer to check out Fox Field -- a portable diamond now under construction in a narrow, concrete alley adjacent to the studio. The field will be used on game days for television demonstrations and it will have a Green Monster, a pitcher's mound, a batting cage and -- if David Hill gets his way as usual -- grass.
"Well, as you know," says Greenberg with a wan smile, "Fox grass is purple."
 
Fox's Ad Campaign: An Attitude Adjustment
 
Commercial No. 1: Matt Williams, the Giants' third baseman, bald since high school, is backing out of his driveway in his 1969 Camaro convertible.
A chubby young fan asks him to stop. "Excuse me," the boy says, "aren't you Matt Williams?" The camera zooms in on Williams, who is wearing an enormous head of wavy black hair and black shades.
"You play third base for the Giants, right?" the chubby kid asks.
"I'm kind of in a hurry," Williams replies.
The fan looks at a baseball card of Williams in which he's bald, looks back at Williams and says, "Wait. . . . Something's different."
Williams says, "I really have to go."
The camera then focuses on the baseball card to show a close-up of Williams's shiny pate. "Ahh," says the kid, "wait a minute. . . . sunglasses."
Williams looks in the rearview mirror, slicks back his hair with both hands and zooms away.
The theme from "Miami Vice" kicks in. "Baseball on Fox. Same Game. New Attitude."
Commercial No. 2: Tino Martinez, the newest Yankee first baseman, is lying on a psychiatrist's couch and rambling. "You know, in Seattle, I was always 'that other Martinez,' " he says, referring to the Mariner designated hitter, Edgar Martinez. "I hit 31 homers last year, had 111 R.B.I., but it was always 'Edgar this,' and 'Edgar that.' "
The camera pans the psychiatrist's wall, on which hang pictures of Lou Gehrig and Don Mattingly, the legendary Yankee first basemen. "But, you know," he continues, "with the Yankees I'll have a chance to be my own Martinez, to not live under someone else's shadow."
The camera then shows the psychiatrist's note pad, which has a list of Yankee first basemen: Lou Gehrig. Don Mattingly. Tino Martinez????
The doctor nods at his patient and writes one last note: "Who's this guy kidding?" Rock-and-roll music kicks in. "Baseball on Fox. Same Game. New Attitude."
Commercial No. 3: Randy Johnson, the hard-throwing Cy Young Award winner for Seattle, has a paper route in his spare time, and no one knows why. From his station wagon, he's throwing newspapers onto people's front porches. One curves and breaks a window. Another is a fast ball that flies through a small window and hits a fat man in the shower.
It's evident that this isn't Johnson's first trip through the neighborhood. When they see him coming, people start running for cover. "Obviously, it's not for the money," Johnson says, casually talking to the camera while a man dives inside a front door. "I guess I just like people."
Music. "Baseball on Fox. Same Game. New Attitude."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 60; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Why the Best Doesn't Always Win

BYLINE: By Peter Passell; Peter Passell writes about economics for The Times. His last article for the Magazine, "The Rich: How They Spend It," appeared in November.

 BODY:
APPLE COMPUTER, THE COMPANY THAT BROUGHT YOU THE idiot-friendly Macintosh, is staring at bankruptcy. Meanwhile, the great army of technocrats at Microsoft, which only last year managed to reproduce the look and feel of a 1980's Mac, lumbers on, invincible.
A bad break for Apple? A rare exception to the Darwinian rules in which the best products win the hearts and dollars of consumers? No. Economists are finally beginning to acknowledge what others have long suspected: the best doesn't always win. Just as biologists are challenging the idea that natural selection drives evolution along "efficient" and predictable paths, economists are discovering the disorder that lurks in the shadows of their simple, elegant models of capitalist progress. Adam Smith's invisible hand, it seems, does not always assure that superior technology will survive the rough-and-tumble of the free market. 
 Recent wisdom on this subject dates back to 1985. That's the year Paul David, an economic historian at Stanford University, published an article about QWERTY in The American Economic Review. Q-W-E-R-T-Y, of course, are the first six letters on the upper left of the typewriter keyboard -- the universal standard since the 1890's. But why these? Why not one of half a dozen other keyboard layouts that are said to permit faster typing?
David's answer is that QWERTY was the solution to a fleeting technological problem, an arrangement that would minimize the jamming of keys in primitive typewriters. While this explanation has since been challenged, what matters is that one keyboard, chosen for reasons long irrelevant, remains the standard. For all their ingenuity, competing designs have made about as much headway against QWERTY as Esperanto has made against English. That's because a standardized layout allows typists to learn just one keyboard in order to use all. Once thousands of people had learned to type using QWERTY's merely adequate layout, the technology was effectively locked in. Keyboard design is thus the classic example of "path dependence," the idea that small, random events at critical moments can determine choices in technology that are extremely difficult and expensive to change.
In the typical path-dependence scenario, producers or consumers see one technology as slightly superior. This edge quickly snowballs into clear economic advantage: production costs fall with greater experience in manufacturing, and consumer acceptance grows with greater familiarity. And along the way, the weight of numbers makes the leading product more valuable than one based on competing technologies. With more MS-DOS computers around, it pays to write software to the Microsoft standard, which in turn makes it more useful to own an MS-DOS computer.
The most familiar example of path dependence is the triumph of Matsushita's VHS standard for videocassette recorders over Sony's Betamax. Betamax was first and, by most accounts, better. But Sony made two strategic marketing errors. To get the product out the door faster, it initially sold Betamax machines that played one-hour tapes -- too short for an entire movie. And to sell more Sony machines, the company chose not to license Betamax to competitors.
VHS, introduced a year later, in 1976, played two-hour tapes. And since Matsushita freely licensed the technology, half a dozen other brand-name VHS players hit the stores in a matter of months. Sony soon countered with a two-hour machine, but it was too late.
While VHS versus Betamax makes great fodder for business school seminars, the outcome hardly made the earth move. The stakes have been much higher in technologies that are now so entrenched it's hard to imagine the world without them. Take the automobile engine. At the turn of the century, gasoline was locked in a three-way race with steam and electric power. The Stanley Steamer was a technological marvel, setting a world speed record of 122 miles an hour in 1909. But the manufacturer priced the car as a luxury, never trying to achieve the economies of mass production and of "learning by doing" that might have made it the people's car.
Moreover, steam's economic problems were compounded by an outbreak of hoof-and-mouth disease in 1914 that briefly closed public horse troughs and denied steam cars a convenient source of water for their perpetually thirsty boilers. With better technology or simply many more steam cars on the road, this liability would have evaporated. But car buyers had little incentive to make a leap of faith when plausible alternatives were available. One of those alternatives was the electric car, whose weakness was a driving range limited by the storage capacity of its batteries. That problem seemed well on its way to solution around 1915. But innovators in the battery industry were distracted by the more immediate need to perfect a high-amperage battery to crank the new electric starters in cars with gasoline engines.
Apparently all the gasoline engine needed to triumph was a brief period in which its technological and price edge led to rapidly expanding sales. This cut production costs, which expanded sales even more -- and made it more convenient to fuel and service gasoline vehicles.
Today, of course, dependence on gasoline engines is a fact of life. While electric or steam vehicles would reduce air pollution and dependence on imported oil, it would take an investment of tens or even hundreds of billions of dollars to leap the technological chasm. Indeed, California, which has mandated the use of electric cars, is just now facing the reality that the existing technology is wretchedly inadequate to the task.
Robin Cowan of the University of Western Ontario offers a second cautionary tale of path dependence. The world is stuck with another functional, but environmentally problematic, technology: the "light water" nuclear reactor, whose momentary superiority over reactors that use inert gases led to the virtual abandonment of alternatives.
In the mid-1950's there was no particular reason to believe that light-water reactors were the cheapest to build and operate. But the Navy invested heavily in light water, which was seen as the most compact and reliable design for submarines and aircraft carriers. When Washington pressed for a quick scale-up to commercial nuclear power after the Soviet Union exploded a nuclear weapon, American manufacturers took the route of least technological resistance.
Later, Washington used subsidies for design and manufacturing to persuade the Europeans to switch to a light-water standard. And once light-water reactors were produced in quantity, the manufacturers learned-by-doing, cutting costs well below those of competing designs.
Perhaps light-water reactors would have prevailed in any event. But there is little doubt that a competing gas-graphite system was safer because it offered greater protection against catastrophic loss of coolant. With global warming now looming, the "lock-in" to atmospherically benign -- but widely feared -- light-water nuclear technology must count as an opportunity lost.
If path dependence is such a big deal, why are college freshmen unlikely to encounter the idea in Econ. 101? Brian Arthur, a pioneer in the field at Stanford in the early 1980's who now does research at the Santa Fe Institute, blames tradition-bound economists. Put it another way: the "technology" of modern economics is itself path dependent, because economists have so much invested elsewhere.
More important, free marketeers fear that path dependence will become a rationale for bigger government -- and is thus the Devil's work. If competitive markets do not guarantee that the best technologies survive, the thinking goes, surely sometime-liberals like Bill Clinton will be more tempted to try to pick winners.
The twist here is that the perspective of path dependence offers no succor to industrial-policy enthusiasts. It was Washington, after all, that locked in light-water nuclear reactor technology. And it was Tokyo that cursed its manufacturers with a high-definition television that was obsolete before the first receiver was sold.
But a world haunted by path dependence does cry out for a different sort of intervention. Government as the referee who makes everyone play by the same impartial rules is not quite enough.
The first goal is to get government to slow down and think twice before setting hard-to-reverse technological standards. The Federal Communications Commission was criticized for dragging its feet on setting standards for the new high-definition television. Because it dawdled, however, digital technology had a chance to prove itself before the F.C.C. got around to writing the final rules. But the lesson also applies to cases that everyone would rather forget, like Washington's premature decision to back recyclable space shuttles over throwaway rocket launchers.
The more controversial issue is antitrust -- think Microsoft. It often pays an individual company to set a standard by flexing its own marketing muscle long before a clear winner has emerged. And the risks of path dependence suggest that Washington would do well to slow such private standard-setting until competitors had a chance to strut their stuff.
The Government will no doubt be called on to take a stand on some looming path-dependence battles: all-purpose personal computers versus cheaper, appliance-like "network computers" that do one thing well; wireless personal communications versus high-capacity cable; Internet software built around Netscape's browser versus software that piggy-backs on the Microsoft Network.
Would Adam Smith approve of venturing where the invisible hand doesn't have a clue? Perhaps not. But then the old guy never had to worry about Microsoft's clumsy software chewing up a chapter of "The Wealth of Nations."

HEADLINE: Fresh Faces Are Making an Impact on the L.I. Landscape

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
ON the surface, Port Washington is a quintessential Long Island suburb, peopled by yuppie commuters clutching Starbucks coffee cups and bound for the next train to Pennsylvania Station.
Its Main Street is so prim that the locals are leery of sharing the sidewalk with McDonald's, but they have quietly made room for one bodega, two international money couriers, a Spanish-speaking domestic service and a pay telephone center where lonely immigrants squeeze into special booths to summon the sweet voices of home in El Salvador, Honduras and the Dominican Republic. 
 Off Main Street, its fortresslike stone Roman Catholic church, St. Peter's, is crowded on Sunday mornings with immigrants from El Salvador -- women who work as live-in maids for as little as $150 a week and men who struggle to pay rent and send money home to Central America on a landscaper's pay.
These are the new faces of Long Island, immigrants who made up more than a third of the people who moved to the island last year while a majority of people departing were native-born, many of them retirees or former military workers.
The trend is as visible as the restaurants selling pupusa meat pies in Hempstead, where the concentration of Salvadorans is so large that the Republic of El Salvador briefly opened a satellite Government office and some residents have nicknamed the area Little El Salvador.
According to March estimates by the Census Bureau, the net international immigration to Nassau County was 28,993, and 18,229 to Suffolk County. But Census experts consider the unofficial growth rate much higher because it does not count undocumented immigrants.
"We estimate that there are about 100,000 Salvadorans living in Hempstead, Freeport and Uniondale," said Miguel Ramirez, president of the Centro Salvadoreno, a Hempstead community organization for Salvadorans. "It's not growing as dramatically as it was before, mainly because it's more difficult for undocumented people to get a job. All these myths have been created that we're stealing jobs from U.S. citizens."
This is the season to spot the latest immigration trends, when the street corners of communities like Westbury and Franklin Square or Glen Cove and Inwood fill with immigrant day laborers in search of gritty work as landscapers and construction workers. Many are so new to the country that they need to use a special list of basic English expressions provided by a local community group. The list carefully spells out the phonetic pronunciations: "I want to work on the books!" and "I have rights, too."
Already, one community organizer, Omar Henriquez of the Workplace Project in Hempstead, has noticed the early signs of new immigration streams from other countries. "On some corners, there are more Hondurans now than Salvadorans," he said."In others, there are more Mexicans. I don't know what's happening in Honduras, but there must be something going on there with the economy. There's a lot more coming."
The new Census estimates do not give an ethnic breakdown of the newcomers, but anecdotal evidence indicates they are mostly Asian and Hispanic. Long Island's original immigrants were English Protestants, who squeezed out the native Indians and dominated the area from the colonial period to World War I.
The development of aircraft industries and suburban housing led to a new wave of immigration after World War II, and an influx of people of mostly Irish, Italian, Polish, German and Russian backgrounds.
And now, with yet a third wave of immigration, members of some of the earlier ethnic groups are watching with some dismay as a pattern unfolds that they experienced themselves. Since 1979, Salvadorans have come searching for the same kind of low-wage, unskilled jobs that drew Italian immigrants to Glen Cove decades earlier to work on the great estates of the Gold Coast.
The Salvadoran population was originally small, but in a common pattern of immigration, the original pioneer scouts invited their relatives. Their numbers grew through the pull of jobs and the push of the intensifying 12-year civil war in El Salvador, which ended in 1992. Their numbers grew, through the push of war and the pull of jobs. Most came from the rural town of Poloros in the province of La Union, where much of the fighting was concentrated.
Italians remain the largest ethnic group in Glen Cove, but now the Loggia Sons of Italyshares the main street downtown with a Hispanic grocery store. The rest of the community also shares a parking lot with a group of immigrant men who gather early mornings in search of day work. But the arrangement is not always amicable; typically police enforcement against such offenses as loitering or disorderly behavior becomes tougher and more unyielding in the months before a mayoral election.
With the start of the spring landcaping season, the same tensions are already starting to surface in other communities like Westbury, where the immigrant day workers and the local police recently met to develop a compromise labor site after complaints increased about the gathering of the men.
But as long as there is demand for their labor, the corners will not be empty. "In suburban communities and the rest of the country, you can expect to see more immigration," said Douglas Massey, a University of Pennsylvania sociology professor who has studied immigration trends. "Immigration goes where the low-wage jobs are. And as those jobs shift from the cities to suburbs, they will be there."
