LENGTH: 1313 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
State's Biggest Residential Renter Keeps Growing

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THREE years ago three senior management partners of Trammell Crow Residential's Mid-Atlantic and Northeast Groups, two of them based in New Canaan and one in Alexandria, Va., decided that given the tortuous process of borrowing money for development in a recession it was worth the risk to go public.
That was a direction that Trammell Crow, the groups' parent and one of the country's largest privately financed builders, did not wish to follow, so an amicable parting was arranged. A new company called Avalon Properties was formed as a REIT, based in Wilton, with offices in Alexandria and Richmond, Va., Braintree, Mass., and Princeton, N.J. 
 In Connecticut alone, the company, which builds, owns and manages rental complexes, has 3,296 units completed or under way in Middletown, Manchester, Hamden, Stamford, Trumbull and Wilton. It is the state's biggest residential landlord.
Avalon Properties is headed by Richard L. Michaux, 52, chairman of the board and chief executive; Charles H. Berman, 42, president and chief operating officer, and Samuel B. Fuller, 34, vice president of development.
They took over the 8,500 rental apartments that they had built under the Trammell Crow banner since 1988 and "the Crow family and I took stock in exchange," said J. Ronald Terwilliger, national managing partner of Trammell Crow Residential in Atlanta.
"We still hold the stock and we're very pleased with their management," he added. "They have been in a dominant position among the top Real Estate Investment Trusts in the Northeast."
(A real estate investment trust is an entity, usually publicly owned, that invests in real estate and pays out at least 95 percent of its taxable income as dividends to investors. The entity essentially pays no taxes.)
Since 1993 Avalon has completed 1,255 units, with 2,500 more under way, and has acquired 2,745 units in addition to those from Trammell Crow. Some of the 2,745 "were in foreclosure with 15 percent occupancy rates," said Mr. Berman, "but with extensive renovation they have outperformed our expectations."
Currently, Avalon's total of approximately 11,807 apartments, reaching from Massachusetts to Virginia, are 95.7 percent occupied. Its revenues for 1995 were $97.2 million, and it recently crossed the $1 billion mark in market capitalization.
In Connecticut, the 400-unit Avalon Grove in Stamford will open in June. Avalon Gates is near completion in Trumbull with 107 of its 240 units already leased -- some to corporations and nearby colleges. And the 102-unit Avalon Springs will l open in Wilton in mid-May. They will variously offer one- to three-bedroom apartments ranging in size from 700 to 1,900 square feet, priced from $950 to $2,575 a month.
T HE development company was named for the Avalon of Arthurian legend -- that final Elysian resting place of heroes. The Avalon system of management is called "Legendary Service," and it seems to work, judging by the high percentage of satisfied customers who live in its low-rise, village-style communities.
At the 238-unit Avalon Glen, which opened in Stamford in 1991, praise from tenants is almost numbingly repetitious. "If something goes wrong you just call up and they come and fix it," said Kathleen Nagle, a tenant who is a retailing director at Nine West Corporation, a women's shoe manufacturer based in Stamford. "Whenever you renew your lease they clean the carpeting and touch up the painting." She is moving into one of the larger apartments.
"We moved in when I was pregnant," said Faith Schachne, a three-year resident, "and my husband travels a lot. The atmosphere here is warm, enclosed, friendly -- especially in summer, when everything is centered around the courtyard and pool. We've made great friends -- that's unusual for apartment buildings." She and many other tenants will attend the imminent wedding of the building's supervisor, Paul G. O'Bday.
Lee Spenadel, a computer networking director for Viacom, the entertainment conglomerate, met a woman in the elevator, he said, with whom he is taking a larger apartment. "I grew up in Manhattan and I didn't want the impersonal, high-rise lifestyle any more. This is unique in the marketplace -- the pool, the workout room, the racquetball court, the parties and events that the management puts on for the residents."
Hotel-style services and amenities are becoming popular within the industry but Avalon was one of the first to recognize their importance in a changing suburban demography. Affluent professionals and managers who wanted service rather than home ownership, empty-nesters and people whose lives were in transition through job relocation, divorce or a new marriage, had little choice in housing.
"People talk a lot about location," said Mr. Michaux, "but timing is very important. We had great timing." By 1993 the Northeast had been virtually written off by developers, most of whom had focused on suburban single family housing.
"The rental market in the Northeast was dramatically underserved and underzoned for the demand," said Mr. Berman. In Connecticut, rejection of Avalon's proposals prompted litigation against the towns of Trumbull and New Canaan. Trumbull settled, but the New Canaan case is still winding its way through the courts.
In both instances Avalon used a state program in which 20 percent of the units are designated for rent at below-market rate. The developer is permitted higher density in return for maintaining the units for 30 years at the lower rate.
"In New Canaan," said Mr. Fuller, "the units would rent for $800 to $1,000 less to people with incomes at 80 percent of the $77,000 median for the area." Resist as they may, towns rarely prevail against judges who are carrying out a state mandate that requires municipalities to show cause why such development is injurious to the community.
"It's a useful way to build in towns that we hope will embrace our complexes," said Mr. Michaux. "When they see that they are just short of a country club there's a more positive reaction."
Libraries, handsomely furnished club rooms with kitchenettes for parties, lifeguarded pools, indoor and outdoor basketball and volleyball courts, fully equipped outdoor playgrounds and indoor fitness centers, and security and fire-alarm systems are standard features, as are decks or patios, heated storage sheds, and soundproof construction. Garage space costs about $75 a month and is the only extra charge.
A RCHITECTS are hired at the local level to insure neighborhood compatibility and focus groups are held with adjacent property owners and prospective renters to determine preferences for everything from siting to appliances to closet sizes, which are 6-by-8 to 6-by-12 feet.
Stamford, with its urgent demand for upscale rentals, has seen the construction of such luxury high-rises as Canterbury Green, The Biltmore, The Classic, and The Fairfield, some with pools, lounges and fitness rooms. Square footage and prices are slightly lower than Avalon's and vacancies are rare.
"Now that Avalon Grove is coming in with 400 new units, and The Fairfield has 95 new units under construction, we may see prices driven down a bit," said Jan Melikan, president of the Stamford Board of Realtors and a broker with Coldwell Banker.
To become residents of an Avalon community applicants for apartments must submit detailed, documented financial histories certifying an income and/or savings equal to 30 percent of a lease, which range from 7 to 16 months. Late rent payments are subject to a 10 to 20 percent penalty. However, if a tenant is unhappy for any reason, the management will terminate the lease after 30 days and refund the security deposit, minus any damages.
"By 2002," Mr. Michaux said, "we expect to grow to a $2.5 billion company, all Northeast and Mid-Atlantic development and acquisition -- and all rental."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Briarwood, Queens;
Where Cultural Diversity Is an Old Habit

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
FRIENDS used to ask Seymour Schwartz why he stayed in Briarwood, Queens, when he could be living in the suburbs of southern Connecticut.
"I could have lived anywhere, economically it was no problem," said Mr. Schwartz, 70, a retired pharmaceutical industry executive and co-president of the Briarwood Civic Association. "But I never felt the need. Here everyone who passes my door greets me. You can't get that in a purely suburban environment." 
 Bordered by four major roadways, the rectangular Briarwood neighborhood is a predominantly middle-income, multi-ethnic community of one- and two-family houses interspersed with five-, six- and seven-story apartment buildings, nearly all now co-ops.
Mr. Schwartz is not alone in placing community togetherness high on the list of Briarwood's virtues. Others remark on convenient subway and bus connections to Manhattan, arrays of stores and shops on Queens Boulevard and bordering roadways, and a relaxed and accepting attitude about cultural diversity, an old habit here.
Realtors say the market for one- and two-family detached and unattached houses is strong. "Briarwood is very desirable, people want it, so there's an excellent market," said Jennifer Dupree, the office manager at Century 21 Big M Realty on Hillside Avenue.
Bill Blumenthal, a sales agent at Mattone Real Estate in Bayside, Queens, said the upper end of the Briarwood market was in Briarwood Estates in the northwest corner of the neighborhood, an enclave where stand-alone, red brick one-family houses, some with Tudor touches, mix with large wood-frame dwellings.
Briarwood was long a part of Jamaica, where English settlers arrived in 1656. In 1905, Herbert A. O'Brien launched a development in the area now known as Briarwood Estates. His wife, Adeline, coined the name because of the briars stuck to her husband's clothing when he returned from forays to the wooded site. Briarwood Estates was well established in 1936 when contemporary classified ads showed houses ranging in price from $3,000 to $9,500.
Many homes on the market today were built during the 30's and 40's. A few were moved from the right-of-way for the Van Wyck Expressway in 1949.
Diane Cohen, district manager of Community Board 8, said recent rezoning protected areas of one- and two-family homes against apartment-house intrusion.
Apartment buildings began rising in the early 50's, followed by an influx of new residents from the Bronx and Brooklyn. The number of apartments increased markedly over the next decade, raising Briarwood's skyline but not, residents insist, obliterating its neighborhood feeling.
A T the Arlington at 139-15 83d Avenue, a 281-unit, 7-story apartment that became a co-op in the early 80's, 2-bedroom units range from $50,000 to $60,000. Monthly maintenance is $500 to $600. Two-bedroom rentals start at about $900. The building has 24-hour-a-day doormen and an underground parking garage.
Parkway Gardens, with 675 apartments in 109 one- and two-story buildings on a 35-acre campus with two private roads, was started in 1946 for employees of the United Nations, which then was briefly based at Flushing Meadows and in nearby Lake Success, L.I. The complex, completed in 1948, is bounded by Main Street, Union Turnpike, Parsons Boulevard and the Grand Central Parkway service road.
Many of the original tenants remained after the U.N. moved to Manhattan, setting the tone for the ethnic diversity that has been a hallmark of Briarwood.
The co-op board chairman, Paul J. Cameron, said that some of the 1,600 trees growing in common areas were planted by the early tenants with seeds from their native lands. "It adds to the international flavor," said Mr. Cameron.
To the south, near Parsons Boulevard and on hilly streets leading down to Hillside Avenue, Archie Bunkeresque wood-frame houses bunch together, impressive in size if cramped by their neighbors. Otherwise, appearances are deceiving. This is not now and never was Archie Bunker's place.
"You always had dozens of languages in the elementary school," said Ellen Hofstetter, the director of the Hilltop Early Childhood Center, a nonprofit community nursery school licensed to care for for 33 children from ages 2 1/2 to six. "Here, kids from everywhere play together, and go to each other's houses."
The 1990 census listed 41.4 percent of Briarwood's residents as white and non-Hispanic and 14.7 percent as black and non-Hispanic. More than 26 percent were of Hispanic origin, including 5.8 percent who were of Puerto Rican origin. Asians and Pacific Islanders accounted for 15.7 percent, including 4.6 percent of Chinese origin.
Briarwood's substantial Jewish population declined in recent years as older Jews retired to Florida, but has recently been revived by Russian immigrants.
At the Briarwood Jewish Center, an Orthodox and Conservative synagogue on 86th Avenue, a Russian congregation now meets in an upstairs sanctuary. The center has programs for children and the elderly.
A Greek community is served the St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church, where 160 pupils from prekindergarten to grade eight are enrolled at the Jamaica Day School. Courses in religion, Greek language and computer literacy are offered. A parochial high school in the church, Archbishop Iakovos, has 42 students. The school offers Regents test preparation, Greek studies and Spanish as a second language.
At the Victoria Congregational Church on 87th Avenue, services are offered in Hindi, Urdu and English.
R ESIDENTS say that in recent years Briarwood's Indian population has grown. On Queens Boulevard, Patel's Food Mart, which opened recently, bills itself as "your one stop Indo-Pak-American Grocery Store." It rents videos and stocks Indian spices. Samosas, deep-fried vegetable patties, are 65 cents each. The Gateway of India restaurant is nearby.
On Parsons Boulevard, students of Sri Chinmoy, a spiritual teacher known for prolific musical composition and espousal of physical fitness, operate a print shop, the Guru Stationary and a meditation center. Sanatan Curchack, a volunteer at the print shop, said many of the teacher's 400 students live in Briarwood.
The Annam Brahma, a nearby vegetarian restaurant at 84-43 164th Street, offers a vegetable curry luncheon special with basmati rice and dal for $2.95. An eggplant Parmesan dinner with salad and garlic bread is $6.95 on Italian night each Thursday. Soy turkey is a Thanksgiving feature
Traditional American fare is served at the Flagship, a popular family restaurant at 138-30 Queens Boulevard.
Briarwood is in School District 28, where most schools are above city and national averages in math and English. P.S. 117 at 143 Street and 85th Drive prides itself on cultural diversity among its approximately 1,150 students in kindergarten through the sixth grade. The school has a computer lab and classroom computers. It stresses cooperation between parents, teachers and administrators.
About 1,237 students attend Intermediate School 217 at 85-05 Jamaica Avenue. The school has programs for gifted and talented, peer tutoring, and peer conflict resolution. Slightly more than half of students scored above national averages on standardized math and English tests.
H ILLCREST HIGH SCHOOL at 160-05 Highland Avenue, the nearest public high school, has about 4,000 students. In a 1994 survey, 56.4 percent of graduates went on to four-year colleges, slightly above the city average. Advanced placement courses are offered in several subjects; average scores on the Scholastic Assessment Test were 360 in verbal and 402 in math, near the city average.
The 500-pupil Roman Catholic St. Nicholas of Tolentine, covering kindergarten through grade eight, offers a computer program and intramural sports. Sixth-grade pupils recently visited Philadelphia as part of a history class.
Nearly all of the 1,550 students at Archbishop Molloy, an all-male Roman Catholic high school at 85-53 Manton Street, go on to four-year colleges according to Brother Richard Van Houten, the principal. He said Scholastic Assessment Test scores were typically 150 points above the city average. The school also offers advanced placement courses and has won city championships in many sports. Admission is competitive. Tuition is $3,630 a year.
The five-acre Hoover Avenue Park, across the street from the high school, has handball and basketball courts.
Ms. Hofstetter of the Hilltop Early Childhood Center, who raised four children in Briarwood, said the local Little League exemplified what was good about the community. "It's a kind Little League," she said. "The parents don't yell at the kids and they have a rule that every kid plays."
She said a manager who screamed at one of his players was not allowed to manage the following season, even though the player was his son.

HOME FOR THE HOMELESS: In a measure of civic character, Briarwood has remained supportive of a shelter for the homeless that opened four years ago at Union Turnpike and 134th Street, even though the community had fought vigorously to keep it out. The shelter, which is run by the Salvation Army, has room for 90 families. Some of the local volunteers had opposed the project when it was frst proposed. "From its opening day, it has never been a problem," said Seymour Schwartz, co-president of the Briarwood Civic Association, which had sued to keep the shelter out of this middle-class area. Members feared drug users, unruly people and a loss in property values. But after losing its case on appeal, "We turned about," said Mr. Schwartz. "We decided to try to make it into a model shelter, and we believe we have accomplished that." Members of the association sit on a shelter advisory board. "After the shovel hit the ground, people said as long as it's going in let's make it the best it can be," said Diane Cohen, the district manager of Community Board 8. "Instead of fighting it, we made it part of the community." Real-estate brokers said the shelter has had no impact on property values in Briarwood.

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Equity 24 Housing in New Jersey
 
Q Is there a state-run program in New Jersey similar to the Mitchell-Lama program in New York City? And if so, whom can I call for more information? . . . Carl Duren, Brooklyn.
 
 A The New York State Mitchell-Lama Housing Program provides affordable housing for middle-income residents. Some Mitchell-Lama residents are tenants while others own their apartments. 
 To be eligible for Mitchell-Lama housing, the income for a family or household of up to three people cannot exceed seven times the annual rent or carrying charge. For families of four or more, income cannot exceed eight times the annual rent or carrying charge.
A few years ago the law was amended to provide that a family with two or more dependents with income less than 25 percent above the income limit could still qualify for Mitchell-Lama housing by paying a rent surcharge. At present, the waiting lists for most Mitchell-Lama developments are closed.
In New Jersey, the program that most closely resembles New York's Mitchell-Lama is Equity 24, a lease-purchase program administered by the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency. Under the program, potential buyers lease homes for up to two years. Their rents are used toward the down payment, and they can then obtain mortgage financing at below-market interest rates.
Potential homebuyers must first obtain a list of approved housing projects from the agency. The list includes single-family detached and attached homes and condominiums. To qualify for the program, applicants must not have any bad credit reports and must have two years of continuous employment.
Generally, total household income may not exceed 200 percent of the median income -- adjusted for family size -- in the county where the eligible housing unit is situated. Moreover, the purchase price may not exceed the higher of 250 percent of the annual maximum income of an eligible buyer or the median sales price of existing single-family homes in the county.
For example, in Hudson County the maximum allowable income for a family of four or more is $78,400, and the maximum purchase price for eligible housing is $196,000. In Bergen County, the income limit for a similarly sized family is $117,000 and the maximum purchase price is $292,500.
Information regarding the Equity 24 program, and various other low-interest-rate mortgage programs, can be obtained by calling the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency at (800) NJ-HOUSE.
 
Exculpatory Clause In a Lease
 
Q What is an exculpatory clause in a lease agreement? . . . Burton Blesko, Manhattan.
 
 A Andrew P. Brucker, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, explained that an exculpatory clause is generally used in commercial leases to insulate a landlord from liability.
"It's like the landlord saying to the tenant: 'If anything goes wrong, you can't sue me for any amount more than my interest in the building,' " Mr. Brucker said.
In many cases, he said, instead of or in addition to using exculpatory clauses, landlords who own multiple properties also form separate corporations to own each property, thereby limiting liability in each building to the value of the landlord's equity in the building.
"Without exculpatory clauses or holding corporations," Mr. Brucker said, "landlords who own several buildings could be liable for millions of dollars."
He added that exculpatory clauses are rarely used in residential leases and that under New York law, an exculpatory clause that would limit liability for a landlord's negligence would be considered void.

HEADLINE: From the Heights of Space to the Fall of an Industrial Empire

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
WHEN the gates opened for shift changes at the Grumman Corporation aerospace plants in Bethpage, neighbors used to complain about the traffic snarls. "You literally could not get out of your own driveway," recalled Linda Mangano, who lived on Route 107, which borders the site.
Today, driving past Grumman is a breeze. The company's 600-acre complex in Bethpage is largely deserted. 
 Now, many people would put up with the traffic frustrations, if only Grumman were bustling again with engineers, welders, designers, accountants, mechanics, secretaries, riveters and test pilots.
But the old Grumman, after decades of fueling the Long Island economy as its largest company, is mostly gone. Only a few divisions have survived.
"The loss of Grumman is horrible," said Gary Bretton, owner of Bretton's Deli in Bethpage. "It's killing us. Our lunch trade is the key, and it's off 25, 30 percent."
Bretton's is lucky. At least it is still in business. Grumman's ripple effect has sunk many other enterprises. "We've been losing stores on a weekly basis -- right now we have 32 vacancies," said Dennis P. Brady, president of the Bethpage Chamber of Commerce. "The whole community used to revolve around Grumman. Places had Grumman burgers and Apollo plates. Now if somebody comes and says, 'Do I get a Grumman discount?' they laugh."
Trying to fill the Grumman vacuum, Nassau County officials are scrambling to lure new businesses to the Bethpage property. The Robert Plan Corporation, an insurance company, is moving there, and Cablevision Systems Corporation is considering it. Suffolk officials are struggling to redevelop 2,900 acres that Grumman formerly occupied at Calverton.
Twenty five years ago, Grumman's demise would have been unthinkable. The company was in its glory after the momentous success of its gawky lunar module, which in 1969 enabled the first human to set foot on the Moon.
In 1970, Grumman again rose to the challenge when Apollo 13's astronauts radioed: "Houston, we've got a problem here" after an explosion in part of their spaceship built by other contractors. Ingenious Grumman engineers on the ground figured out makeshift adaptations of the Grumman part of the ship, which rescued the mission from an outer-space disaster.
More triumphs lay ahead in the 1970's, as Grumman developed orbiting astronomical observatories and the F-14 Tomcat, the rakish, swept-back variable-wing fighter that later co-starred with Tom Cruise in the hit movie "Top Gun."
Grumman's downfall came in the 1980's, with the collapse of Communism. When the cold war ended, so did the arms and space races. As military spending plummeted on Long Island, Grumman shrank drastically and in 1994 was swallowed up by the Northrop Corporation, based in Los Angeles.
Just 10 years ago, Grumman's payroll on Long Island was 25,000. Today the staff of the merged Northrop Grumman Corporation divisions remaining on the island has dwindled to 3,800. Thousands more local jobs were lost by hundreds of subcontractors.
Coming on top of the recession, Grumman's decline dealt the Island's economy a double blow that still reverberates.
"Grumman had essentially held together the manufacturing sector of Long Island's economy," said Matthew T. Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, a business group. Grumman's annual sales peaked in 1990 at $4 billion.
With Grumman's decline, its reputation has faded as a model employer and civic leader whose achievements gave Long Islanders pride and identity.
"In school we were all made aware we had helped put a man on the moon," said Ms. Mangano, publisher of The Bethpage Tribune.
Grumman helped organize the United Way fund on the island and led its corporate givers. Its executives helped found hospitals and supported other causes.
"Grumman was a symbol of Long Island, its stability, its future," said James M. Shuart, president of Hofstra University. "It had a warm, friendly, family image. It might have been an illusion, and when they started behaving like any other business, it was a big disappointment to a lot of people."
Leroy R. Grumman and his partners started their tiny company in 1930, repairing small propeller planes. Despite the Depression, the plucky enterprise grew into a giant that produced the Hellcats and other aircraft that helped win World War II. Then Grumman soared into the jet era and the space age, largely on the strength of Navy contracts.
Nowadays, pride in the company has distinctly lapsed into the past tense. Lawrence A. Feliu, a retired engineer who volunteers in the Grumman history center, a recently exanded archival and display area, said: "Grumman had a magnificent history and still does have a magnificent history -- they can't take that away from Grumman."
For many former workers, their once ardent loyalty to Grumman has soured. At the old Grumman, no unions were needed. Its open-door policy was real; the lowliest worker could walk into the president's office without an appointment. Workers with difficult ailments were sent to the Mayo Clinic, at company expense.
There were turkeys at Christmas, birthday cards, watches after 25 years, bouquets for spouses, scholarships for children, the "green car service" for commuters with flat tires and the world's biggest company picnic, according to the Guinness Book of World Records. No more.
After years of paternalism, the cutbacks came as a shock and betrayal to many workers. Dr. Barbara M. Kelly, a history professor and curator of Long Island studies at Hofstra, said, "It felt more like a divorce than a simple layoff."
Lynn V. McDonald, an engineer who took early retirment in 1990 at 65, said he was treated fairly. "But so many of my friends were bitter and upset at the time of the buyout or sellout or whatever you call it," he said, "especially younger ones who lost their jobs when jobs are tough on the island." Some dismissed workers have gone to court challenging the legality of Northrop Grumman's severance pay.
Could Grumman have avoided its fate? Its attempts to diversify included ventures in solar energy panels, waste disposal, modular housing, fire engines, windmills, refrigeration, organ transplant transporters, motor homes, yachts and ambulances.
Most of the efforts failed, because of poor marketing, unlucky timing or other factors. Defective Flxible buses became a public relations fiasco. There were a few successes, like the Gulfstream corporate jets and the boxy postal delivery vans, but those divisions were sold or shifted off Long Island before they could make any significant impact on the company's balance sheet.
"They could have done more," said Paul Townsend, editor of Long Island Business News. But President Shuart of Hofstra said, "They deserve an A for effort."
In the 1980's, a feisty Grumman fought off a hostile takeover attempt by LTV, an electronics concern with military contracts, with the help of many blue- and white-collar employees who bought Grumman stock to strengthen its resistance.
But by 1989, seeing a limited future in aerospace, Grumman proposed a redevelopment of its Bethpage property into an industrial park with a high-rise hotel. Residents opposed it as excessive, just as they had thwarted an earlier plan to expand airport operations on the Grumman runway.
The company's fortunes continued to decline. In 1990, John O'Brien resigned as chairman after allegations of kickbacks.
Eventually Grumman's top executives decided that the company's only hope was merger, and they huddled over a secret plan called Project X. After their offer was spurned by their first two choices, they flirted with Martin Marietta. When word got out, a bidding contest erupted with Northrop, which bought out Grumman.
The new Northrop Grumman pared even further, leaving four divisions on the Island, for data processing, electronic aviation systems, military planes and research and development.
But after building 33,000 planes and several lunar modules, the old Grumman factories have finally closed. "The last plane made here went over the fence last year," said Richard C. Dunne, a company spokesman. There was no ceremony. The plane, a Hawkeye early-warning radar plane, was destined for Taiwan, which wanted its departure kept confidential at the time.
In the end, the company that helped put men on the moon was unable to save itself. Robert Silver, owner of the Bethpage Medical Pharmacy, who had -- and lost -- many Grumman workers as customers, said, "It's never going to be the way it was before."

LENGTH: 1527 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Worldwide Plaza and Its Neighborhood;
In Hell's Kitchen, Retail Is on the Front Burner

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IN the late 1980's, the first renters at Worldwide Plaza, the condominium and office complex that fills the block between Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 49th and 50th Streets, figured they had the best of all worlds.
Zeckendorf Realty, the building's owner, was offering low rents, individual lobbies and huge contributions to building out the space to those pioneers who would chance coming so far west. Yet the shabby neighborhood seemed ripe for gentrification. 
 "A lot of people believed that Eighth Avenue would develop in the early 1990's the way that Sixth Avenue did in the 1960's," said Thomas J. Brady, director of security at the advertising agency Ogilvy & Mather, the building's first tenant.
The faltering economy tabled such hopes, of course. But the tenants, apparently, have grown to love the neighborhood as is.
"We haven't had any significant problems with crime, and you can get a cab at any time," said Samuel Butler, presiding partner at the law firm Cravath Swaine & Moore, which moved to the building in 1989.
"You don't have the constant crush of tourists, and you don't have to pay Fifth Avenue prices to buy a lunch," said Carolyn Joy Lee, a partner at the law firm Roberts & Holland, which moved from Rockefeller Center to Worldwide Plaza in late 1994.
Indeed, while the neighborhood, known interchangeably as Clinton and Hell's Kitchen, is low on glitz, it is high on bargains. Cineplex Odeon has had such a rush of moviegoers to its second-run, six-screen Worldwide Plaza theater that two months ago it raised its ticket price to $3 from $2.
"It caught on like wildfire," said Howard Lichtman, a Cineplex Odeon executive vice president. "We had more than a million people attend last year, more than quadruple the number we had expected."
He may soon get even more. With the economy reviving, and with 42d Street redevelopment spurring interest in the whole West Side, those who enjoy the lack of gentrification may be in for a shock.
Jack Resnick & Sons is ready to put up an apartment building in the big parking lot it just bought at 49th Street, across Eighth Avenue from Worldwide Plaza. Zeckendorf may do the same on the former site of the Adonis Theater, an X-rated moviehouse between 50th and 51st Streets on the west side of Eighth.
Brokers say that retailers, too, are eyeing the neighborhood, although few agree on whether Eighth, with its large buildings and decent sized stores, or Ninth, with its preponderance of tiny spaces in narrow buildings, is having the biggest resurgence.
"Eighth Avenue in the 50's is already a here-and-now neighborhood, but Ninth Avenue is just up and coming," said Edward A. Friedman, president of Newmark Retail Services, who owns 850-856 Eighth Avenue, four adjoining buildings at 51st Street.
N OT so, counters Howard S. Aaron, a broker at New Spectrum. He says that Ninth Avenue landlords are finally able to turn away locksmiths and delis in favor of pretty little cafes that enhance the value of the walk-up apartments upstairs.
"Ninth Avenue is getting the trendy places you expect to see in the Village," said Mr. Aaron, who says he recently had 10 tenants clamor for a space at 676 Ninth Avenue, near 47th Street. (An Italian restaurant is slated to open there in a few months.)
It is all coming too late, however, to help Zeckendorf Realty realize the gold mine it had expected when it first started building Worldwide Plaza on a site that once held Madison Square Garden. Back then, Prudential Insurance and the developer George Klein were still planning to put four huge office towers on 42d Street. New office buildings were going up on Broadway in the 40's, and the Coliseum on Columbus Circle seemed destined for office or retail use.
"We figured new retailing, hotels and apartment houses had to be on the way," recalled Arthur W. Zeckendorf, Zeckendorf Realty's executive vice president.
They never came. Zeckendorf did get market prices for most of the residential condominiums, but the office space is not bringing the revenues it had expected.
The developer had to give equity in the building to Cravath Swaine, Ogilvy and N. W. Ayer to get them to move in. And it had to offer very low rents. Ogilvy, for example, signed on at an annual rent of $32 a square foot, at a time when rents for far less amenity-rich buildings in midtown averaged about $40. Later tenants, including Polygram Records, Microsoft and Roberts & Holland, also cut sweet deals.
Until recently, Zeckendorf was not as willing to compromise on retail rents. The result is that, while a health club, the movie theater and sundry local service stores have sopped up much of the complex's 90,000 square feet of stores, it still has 25,000 square feet empty.
"The retailing just wasn't well conceived," Mr. Zeckendorf admitted. Added Tom A. Javits, a Zeckendorf managing director: "It is difficult to get retailers to invest in stores in this area."
Mr. Javits says that Zeckendorf is now offering "realistic leases and huge incentives" -- translation: low rents and large contributions to building the stores -- to entice retailers to come. Last year Super Natural Health Foods and Bulbtronics, a specialty lighting store, moved into Worldwide Plaza's Ninth Avenue storefronts, and Mr. Javits says he is negotiating with two restaurants for other spaces.
Z ECKENDORF is also paying more attention to security in an area that, because it often feels deserted at night and full of rowdy students by day, sometimes feels threatening to tenants and visitors alike. Two years ago Zeckendorf's security force teamed up with the police, the Board of Education and the Times Square Business Improvement District to control students at two nearby schools, the High School of Graphic Communication Arts and Park West High School.
Chemical Bank, at the request of several Worldwide Plaza tenants, has increased security around the ATM machine it operates in the building. And Zeckendorf recently converted an empty store on Ninth Avenue into a security office that will be jointly staffed by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Zeckendorf's private security force, to further dispel any feelings -- justified or perceived -- of danger in the tenement-ridden area.
But perceptions are stubborn. "I don't think any of our clients would be interested in coming here," said Richard Seligman, a senior managing director at the Edward S. Gordon Company who specializes in retail brokerage. "The look of the buildings, the nature of the local bars, all of it feels like the bad areas of Brooklyn or the Bronx."
Indeed, a thrift shop that had long operated at 767 Ninth Avenue, at 51st Street, recently moved to more expensive East Side space "because the people who were donating their clothing did not want to come to this area to drop it off," recalled Mr. Aaron. He rerented the space -- for far less rent -- to a druggist who had operated a smaller store nearby for a decade.
More than the lack of surrounding gentrification is bedeviling Worldwide Plaza's attempts to rent its stores. Much of its empty space is on the plaza that separates the office building from the condominiums. Plazas, which are by their nature tucked out of view, have trouble generating much traffic even in a bustling neighborhood. In a sleepy one a plaza can be a ghost town.
"There are still people in the building who don't know we are here," said Richard Barber, who has operated the New World Grill, a 35-seat -- triple that in summer, when he puts tables outside -- restaurant in the plaza for three years.
Like Cineplex Odeon before him, Mr. Barber is now banking on bargain hunters to boost his sales. He lowered his prices last year, and he is thinking of amortizing the cost of his kitchen by opening another small space in the plaza, where he would serve soups, salads and sandwiches.
"We expect that interns on piddling salaries will come down from the offices for a $5 meal," he said.
It may take longer for the local stores to catch on with outsiders -- if, in fact, they ever do.
"This neighborhood will never be like the Upper West Side," said Samuel Mizrahi, who owns Super Natural Health Foods and the Metropolis Drug Store at Ninth Avenue at 50th Street.
Nor is it yet commanding Upper West Side rents. "I haven't seen a lot of dramatic increase in values yet," said Bruce A. Spiegel, a senior managing director of Rose Associates, which owns the Ellington, an apartment building at 260 West 52d Street. A health and beauty aids store that moved in when the building opened six years ago pays an annual rent of about $50 a square foot; Mr. Spiegel doubts he could get a good deal more than that if he rented the store today.
Maybe not -- but a few years from now, if the long-postponed development of the area really happens, he just might.
"Eighth and Ninth Avenues already are getting the benefit of the activity on Broadway," said Faith H. Consolo, a senior managing director of the Garrick-Aug brokerage, who says that discounters and accessory stores are looking in the area. "The neighborhood has always been stable. But now, it is getting chic."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard Barber, owner of the New World Grill, at Worldwide Plaza. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region: New Jersey;
Warehouse and Distribution-Center Demand Rises

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A RELATIVELY healthy demand for industrial space has given rise to a spate of projects being built for specific tenants or on speculation. Most are focused on big boxy warehouse and distribution centers.
As of the first quarter, 14 such projects under way in the state total nearly 3 million square feet, more than double the 1.3 million feet in the similar 1995 quarter, according to the East Rutherford office of the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage. 
 The activity is a response to the reconfigured space needs of today's companies, said Jules Nissim, a Cushman & Wakefield broker. Some concerns are expanding their operations and others, following a trend that began a few years ago, are consolidating from scattered locations to increase efficiency, said Mr. Nissim.
Moreover, brokers say, tenants are passing up many older buildings because their ceiling heights do not allow for modern racking systems for distribution and inventory retrieval. Most new buildings have ceilings at least 30 feet high and are 200,000 square feet in size or more.
Asking rents have risen to reflect the cost of new construction in some markets. As of the first quarter, rates for all types of industrial space have risen from an average of $4.21 a square foot a year ago to $4.56, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Rents vary from market to market.
The activity is expected to continue, albeit more slowly, said John G. Orrico, senior vice president of the New Jersey offices of Grubb & Ellis, a real-estate brokerage based in San Francisco. One factor tempering the pace, he said, is the still-tight lending climate in which developers must contribute 35 to 40 percent of their own equity into projects. The pace will also depend, he said, on continued improvement in the state's economy and job growth.
Since 1992 the state has regained 189,000 of the 261,000 of all kinds of jobs it lost during the recession, 126,000 of them since January 1994. As of March the three distribution-industry sectors -- wholesale trade/ durable goods, nondurable goods and trucking and warehousing -- accounted for 335,600 jobs, or 9.3 percent of the state's total, the state's Department of Labor says.
As new construction moves ahead, 1.5 million square feet of space has come back onto the market over the last six months -- due to, among other reasons, the bankruptcies of some companies. Jamesway, for example, gave back an 800,000-square-foot warehouse and distribution building in Cranbury. That pushed up available space from 58.4 million square feet in the third quarter of 1995. the lowest since December 1990, to nearly 60 million square feet. But much of the space is in older buildings and some of them, brokers said, will never be leased.
L EASING and sales activity in the first quarter, though down from the same time last year, rose by 35 percent to 7.2 million square feet from the end of 1995. Among the largest leases was one for a 175,000-square-foot building on Woodbridge Avenue in Edison by U.S.A. Detergents, an expanding North Brunswick-based manufacturer, for a warehouse and distribution center.
"The last six months is a temporary blip, following 18 months of activity, that will work itself out," said Mr. Nissim of Cushman & Wakefield.
Much of the new construction is centered in the areas around Exits 10 and 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike in Middlesex County, one of the state's main industrial hubs. The Meadowlands, another big market, continues to draw firms that need to be near Manhattan, but land there is limited.
Projects in the county involve build-to-suit distribution centers to accommodate companies consolidating space.
In Sayreville, the Morris Companies of Secaucus is erecting two such buildings at its Morris Industrial Park. One, with 225,000 square feet of space, is for Guest Supply of New Brunswick, which supplies toilet articles to the lodging industry. It will relocate four distribution centers in the state to the building. The other is a 205,000-square-foot building for Nippon Express of Manhattan, where three distribution centers elsewhere in the state that store business equipment will be consolidated.
Both buildings will be completed in November, said Ronald F. Schram, senior vice president at the Morris Companies. He said his company was also seeking approvals for other build-to-suit projects, including an 800,000-square-foot distribution center in the Cranbury area of 8A for Nobody Beats the Wiz.
Among those planning to buy or lease build-to-suit projects under way elsewhere in the region is Tommy Hilfiger U.S.A., the Manhattan-based sportswear manufacturer, which is leasing 340,000 square feet at the 500-acre Forsgate Industrial Center in South Brunswick.
Volkswagen of America is buying a 323,000-square-foot building nearing completion at CenterPoint, a 900-acre business park straddling Monroe and South Brunswick Townships. Volkswagen will move into it from Orangeburg, N.Y., and the Washington area. The distribution center, which is in South Brunswick, is being constructed by the Matrix Development Corporation of Cranbury, the developer of CenterPoint.
"It is not like the mid-80's when the market was crying out for space, but it is tight for the more functional high-ceilinged space," said Alec Taylor, a principal at Matrix.
That factor among others led to Matrix's decision to begin developing a new park farther south along the turnpike at Exit 7A with up to 5 million square feet. The park's maiden project, a 115,000-square-foot build-to-suit warehouse and distribution building, is now under construction, said Mr. Taylor.
I N Edison, the Heller Construction Company has built half of the 300,000-square-foot first phase of a 1 million square foot office and distribution building, the state's largest speculative project. The project, with 37-foot-high ceilings, is rising at the company's 410-acre Heller Industrial Park on Mill Road, near Exit 10 of the turnpike.
Jeffrey J. Milanaik, the Heller vice president, said his company was offering below-market-rental rates in the $3.50-a-square foot range, made possible by a tax abatement from Edison, and the project's location to draw large users consolidating operations. It is also near the crossroads of Interstates 287 and 440, the Garden State Parkway and Routes 1 & 9.
"For tenants today, the focus is price and many are finding value in newer buildings," he said, noting that the space could be divided into areas as small as 70,000 square feet.
The first phase is to be finished by July, said Mr. Milanaik, adding that his company expected to have the entire project completed and leased by the middle of next year.
Not all speculative buildings lease quickly. A 248,000-square-foot building completed more than eight months ago at Forsgate Corporate Center by the park's developer, the local Forsgate Industrial Complex, is still vacant.
"The building, designed as a corporate headquarters, is not for everyone," conceded Anthony J. Scaro executive vice president at the Teterboro-based Charles Klatskin Company, Forsgate's leasing arm. "But with the lack of large blocs of quality space in the region it will lease."
The company is also erecting a 70,000-square-foot speculative building on North Street near Route 80 in Teterboro for smaller tenants needing 9,000 to 18,000 square feet of office and industrial space. "There is a pent-up demand for such space in this area," said Mr. Scaro, adding completion is expected this summer.

HEADLINE: Jump-Starting a Historic District

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
THE sky glowed so infernally on the night of Dec. 16, 1835, that firemen in Philadelphia turned out to fight what they believed was a blaze in their suburbs. What was burning, however, was lower Manhattan.
Former Mayor Philip Hone told his diary the next day that 500 to 700 buildings and their contents, including all of those on Stone Street, had been reduced to "an indistinguishable mass of ruins." Yet only a year later, Hone exulted that "the whole is rebuilt with more splendor than before." 
 Astonishingly, a dozen brick storehouses built on Stone Street after the Great Fire of 1835 survive today in recognizable form, some even retaining their Greek Revival granite shopfronts or the pintles from which window shutters once hung. Complementing these are later structures with Dutch, Gothic, Italianate or Tudor details, arrayed along a crooked, narrow road that was laid out in the days of Nieuw Amsterdam.
If all this sounds like the making of a landmark designation, it is.
But in the proposed Stone Street Historic District -- 14 buildings on two small blocks between Broad and William Streets -- the Landmarks Preservation Commission is trying to set the stage for economic revitalization even as it imposes a regulatory regime. Rather than sparring with business interests, the commission is working closely with the Alliance for Downtown New York, which manages the Lower Manhattan Business Improvement District.
A master plan is being drafted that would specify a range of pre-approved alterations that owners in the district could make to their properties without having to go through time-consuming, expensive and unpredictable review.
For example, the plan would show how the owner of Block Hall, 45 Stone Street, could add windows on the south and east facades to make that seven-story structure more attractive for residential conversion. It would show how the owner of 44 Stone Street, a three-story ersatz Colonial structure on what was once Coenties Alley, could either improve the existing facade or add two stories in keeping with the architectural texture of neighboring structures.
The plan would show owners throughout the tiny district where they might build rooftop additions. And it would specify a variety of treatments that would be permitted for shopfronts and signage. "It was important that we work with owners to show them how they could convert shuttered ground floors into usable retail space," said John Belle, of Beyer Blinder Belle of Manhattan, the architectural firm that is drafting the plan.
Jennifer J. Raab, chairwoman of the landmarks commission, said the master plan would probably be scheduled for a public hearing as soon as the district is designated, probably in June. Because the master plan is to be voted on by the commission. it would have the weight of regulation.
"I didn't just want a suggestion of what you could do," Ms. Raab said. "I wanted something with the force of a pre-approved commission vote. You, the owner, can open the book and say to your contractor: 'This storefront is already approved. You take this over to 100 Old Slip and you'll be in and out of there.' " The commission's Old Slip office is only three blocks from Stone Street, paring more time from the process.
E VEN the Real Estate Board of New York, which generally takes a dim view of historic districts, has endorsed the idea of a master plan. "It minimizes significantly the subjectivity in the approval process for any changes that are required," said Michael Slattery, the board's senior vice president for research.
To encourage development further, the landmarks commission has obtained an $800,000 grant through the Federal Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act toward a $1.43 million street reconstruction project, including bluestone sidewalks, a granite-block roadbed and cast-iron lampposts. The balance of the money is to come from New York City ($480,000) and the Alliance ($150,000).
The Alliance has also underwritten a report by the Praedium Group, a consulting firm based in Manhattan, on the economics of commercial revitalization along Stone Street. The report recommends the development of moderately priced restaurants aimed at the lunch trade, the creation upstairs of residential lofts and one- or two-bedroom apartments, and the use of other retail space for sporting-goods stores, hair salons, dentists' offices, gift shops or bookstores.
Carl Weisbrod, the president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, said that Stone Street had "not only great historical importance but tremendous commercial potential" and that the creation of a landmark district would allow for the cultivation of its character, flavor and economic vitality.
One owner who said he is ready to go is Tony Goldman, of Goldman Properties, who has renovated buildings in SoHo and the South Beach section of Miami Beach. After he opens the Wall Street Kitchen and Bar at 70 Broad Street next September, Mr. Goldman said, he will turn his attention to Stone Street, where he owns No. 53 and leases Nos. 52 and 55. He said he was prepared to open three or four restaurants and create living-and-working lofts.
"It's a magnificent little enclave," Mr. Goldman said. "Being an oasis, it has that much more differentiation, and differentiation is where it's at. You've got to have the only kind of product on the market to give yourself the marketing edge."
O ASIS" is probably not the word that would occur to most visitors to Stone Street today, beholding what is essentially a dingy, ill-kept back alley that serves a few restaurants along Pearl and South William Streets. It is no festival marketplace, although it gained a reputation in the 80's as a drug market.
Stone Street was known first as Brouwers Straet. The brewery of the West India Company was in operation there by 1646 and Oloff Stevensen van Cortlandt had built a brewery sometime before 1656. Brouwers Straet ran only a block, to a canal along the line of the present Broad Street.
Complaining that the street was "becoming more and more unfit for public use," 10 residents petitioned the burgomasters in 1655 "to pave the said street with round stone on the first favorable opportunity." The neighbors pledged themselves "to furnish the stone, the raising and lowering necessary thereto, each to the extent of his house and lot." In Mr. Weisbrod's eyes, that makes Stone Street the first business improvement district.
This being New York City, nothing was done about the street work for another three years. And then, the residents balked at paying the assessment.
Paving stones were eventually laid and Brouwers Straet showed up as "Stony Street" exactly 300 years ago on a map drawn by the Rev. John Miller, chaplain to the King's forces in New York. A century later, Stone Street was merged with the former Hoogh Straet (or High Street), on the east side of Broad Street.
Stone Street underwent its most thorough rehabilitation after the Great Fire of 1835, when a four- or five-story brick storehouse was built on almost every lot. Though these are the most historic of the Stone Street structures, they are the least easy for a casual viewer to appreciate, since they are quite plain and, in numerous cases, considerably altered.
Some distinguishing features, however, include the massive granite piers and lintels at Nos. 51, 53 and 55; the pintles surrounding the windows at No. 58 and the star-shaped tie-rod plates at No. 60 that look like starfish climbing up the brick wall.
In 1854, the Hanover Bank (ancestor of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company) built an elegant Italianate palazzo on Hanover Square. Since 1914, it has been the home of India House, a private club. Over time, the building was expanded to encompass Nos. 60, 62 and 64 Stone Street, all built in 1836. India House was designated an individual landmark in 1965.
Fanciful recollections of Dutch architecture can be spotted at No. 57, an 1830's structure that was given a new facade by C. P. H. Gilbert in 1903, including a stepped gable with a bull's-eye window. (Also known as 13 South William Street, it is now the Cafe du Cervin.)
A remodeling also transformed two older storehouses into a seven-story structure known as the Armitage Building, at No. 54. It was extensively altered in 1919 for the marine underwriting firm of Chubb & Son.
Another marine underwriting firm, William H. McGee & Company, was housed in the most graceful structure in the proposed district: a seven-story office building at No. 59. Its delicate facade is composed of multi-pane leaded glass windows in limestone-framed, neo-Gothic bays, topped by a cornice ringed with lion's heads.
Over the main entrance, at 9 South William Street, is inscribed the name "Lehman Brothers," testifying to the building's role as an annex for the investment banking house when it was across Mill Lane. The building has been empty since the 1980's. The owners, South William Street Associates, contemplate turning it into a 46-room inn.
T HE architect of the McGee building, William Neil Smith, also designed Block Hall, also known as 21 South William Street, which has a plain facade on Stone Street but erupts in half-timbered neo-Tudor fantasy on South William Street. It was built for an affiliate of McGee & Company and originally served as a private clubhouse. Beginning in the 1940's, it was the home of the City Midday Drug and Chemical Club.
Block Hall was purchased in 1960 by Robert Norden, who also operates Fraunces Tavern two blocks away. The Midday Club moved to 140 Broadway in the late 1960's and Mr. Norden leased the building to the Italian Alps restaurant, which closed seven years ago.
Block Hall has been empty since and Mr. Norden said he has no plans for the property at the moment, although he thinks it is a "definite help" that the master plan spells out his options.
Easily the greatest blow to Stone Street since the Great Fire occurred in 1980 when it was "de-mapped" by the Board of Estimate between Broad Street and Coenties Alley to accommodate the development of 85 Broad Street, the 30-story headquarters of Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Although the street itself was eradicated, its route is marked through the lobby and plaza of 85 Broad Street with 4- by-4-inch dark brown paving blocks. The walls of the lobby also make two gentle turns, following the alignment of old Stone Street.
Mr. Weisbrod believes that "having Goldman, Sachs next door is a big plus for Stone Street economically and having Stone Street is a plus for Goldman, Sachs."
But Mr. Norden looks at 85 Broad Street as an example of the city's mercurial approach to land use. "In another administration years ago, we decided to give away half of Stone Street to Goldman, Sachs as a lobby for their building," he said. "Now, you almost can't get to it. It's a back alley of a back alley. And now, the city says, 'Gee, we want to do something good.' Is landmarking going to be the saving grace? I think it's the only thing we have but I personally don't think it's the proper approach to saving buildings."
For one thing, owners are concerned about the development rights attributable to their properties, said Mark A. Levine, of Sive, Paget & Riesel, who represents a group of landlords. With bonuses, existing zoning would permit a building on Stone Street with a floor area as much as 18 times the lot area.
But it is almost inconceivable that the landmarks commission would ever permit such a thing, leaving owners with tens of thousands of square feet of unused development potential. Mr. Levine said one possibility would be a zoning mechanism allowing the transfer of development rights outside the district.
A potential economic advantage of landmark status is the Federal Investment Tax Credit, which offers a credit equal to 20 percent of the money an owner spends in rehabilitating a historic property -- both hard costs like construction and soft costs like professional fees. There are numerous restrictions and conditions, but Anne B. Covell, a principal in the Praedium Group, said it could provide a "big financial kick" along Stone Street.
A S an example, Praedium devised a renovation scenario for Mr. Goldman's building at 52 Stone Street, also known as 85 Pearl Street. In the high range of assumptions, rehabilitation of the facade, basement and first two floors for retail space would cost $856,530; 50 percent of that, or $428,265, being the owner's equity investment. The cash flow (gross rent less operating expenses, debt service, real estate and Federal income taxes) would be $46,334, equal to a return on the investment of 10.8 percent.
The Federal Investment Tax Credit would be $171,306, or 20 percent of the rehabilitation cost. If taken over five years, that would mean an annual credit of $34,261, increasing the cash flow to $80,595 -- a much more favorable return of 18.8 percent.
Mr. Goldman insists he would build with or without the tax credit. But there is a pitfall he hopes to avoid: an overly picturesque reconstruction along the lines of the Rouse Company's treatment of the South Street Seaport.
"Stone Street has to have a sense of grit to it," he said. "I would like a little saltiness to prevail."

HEADLINE: The Visionary Pioneer of Hilton Head Island, S.C.

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE 

DATELINE: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C.

 BODY:
WITH some regularity, Charles E. Fraser used to invoke the age-old Chinese saying of "knocked down 9 times, get up 10." Now, the 67-year-old developer says he would rather avoid being knocked down.
The years may have lessened the fight. But none of the spirit has diminished in the man who 40 years ago began this island's first resort, where bicycles, not cars, were the primary mode of transportation and trees and shrubs were the focal part of a homesite, not a huge, brightly painted house. 
 The 5,000-acre Sea Pines Plantation on the southern tip of Hilton Head Island, 35 miles north of Savannah, Ga., today shows how careful planning -- and strict covenants -- can create a livable community that time does not change.
Mr. Fraser's concept is standard practice in resort developments around the nation, especially here on the South Carolina coast where as many as 35 resorts have applied Mr. Fraser's ideas. The new town of Celebration, Fla., under construction by the Disney Company outside of Orlando and scheduled to open in October, employs many of his theories.
But to Mr. Fraser, his greatest contribution to real estate development is the young men and women who came here to work with him in the early years, many of whom have gone on to develop resorts themselves, such as Spring Island near Beaufort, S.C., and Kiawah Island near Charleston, S.C.
Peter Rummell, head of the Disney Company's worldwide development arm, is a Fraser protege, as is Philip Lader, director of the Small Business Administration. J. Ronald Terwilliger is a managing partner with Trammell Crow Residential, one of the nation's largest apartment builders.
"Mr. Fraser is definitely a visionary," said Peter Pollack, a partner in Dolan & Pollack, which is developing a 40-acre parcel on Hilton Head. "His influence is felt in our project."
Mr. Fraser recruited at the nation's best colleges, drawing from all disciplines because he believes a good project involves 26 specialties, from education to ecology, transportation to finance. Urban planners need not apply. The ever-blunt developer considers them a "weak breed," compiling statistics and reports and lacking an understanding of how to create a viable community.
"I wouldn't give one plugged nickel for all of the places that are called city planning or for their output from the past 25 years," he said. Because of them, many modern developments segregate the various activities of the community. Mr. Fraser believes in "family-friendly planning."
"Planning should be focused on not having missing pieces in a neighborhood, a school you can bike to, businesses, churches, ballfields, parks, a mix of housing types," he said.
It is much like small towns of another day, where residents live near their work and can walk or ride bikes or buses virtually anywhere. He wants communities where residents need only one car.
Mr. Fraser became interested in land use planning while a student at Yale Law School in the early 50's. There, under the tutelage of Prof. Miers McDougal, he became convinced that landowners needed to be bolder in writing deed restrictions and covenants.
"It was a concept that was generally ignored in this country," he said.
A FTER graduating from law school in 1953, he served in the Air Force and then practiced law in Augusta, Ga., 130 miles northwest of Savannah, where he grew up.
His father and a group of investors owned 80 percent of Hilton Head Island. He convinced his father, whose family owned a lumber manufacturing business, to sell him, on a 20-year note, the southern third of the island so he could put his theories into practice.
A bridge to the mainland was built in 1956, and Mr. Fraser moved here, living much like a hermit on an island outpost.
In those days, development along the South Carolina coast consisted mainly of small cottages perched atop cinderblocks. Mr. Fraser began assembling a small city behind gates. Over the years, four golf courses, a town square, 100 tennis courts and 3,400 homes were built at the oceanfront Sea Pines, all under the tight restrictions imposed by Mr. Fraser. Home plans must be approved by an architectural review board, which requires homes in muted colors and varying styles.
Critics said the South Carolina courts would never stand for such restrictions. But the South Carolina Supreme Court ruled in Mr. Fraser's favor.
O UTSIDE Sea Pines Plantation there is an abundance of strip malls and traffic congestion on the William Hilton Parkway, the 42-square-mile island's main thoroughfare. But within Sea Pines, roads meander rather than lunging ramrod-straight through the community. It seems almost an understatement to say landscaping is lush. Azaleas, live oaks and dozens of other kinds of native vegetation, planted decades ago, are mature and flourishing.
Mr. Fraser said skeptics became convinced he was onto something after the first 150 homes were built.
"People liked the idea," he said. "The covenants were copied in 150-200 places. People knew exactly what to expect."
From 1965-75, construction was nonstop and home sales followed suit, former employees remember. Mr. Fraser sent workers on flying trips around the country to see how things were done elsewhere. James Chafin, who worked for Sea Pines and is now developing Spring Island, remembers Mr. Fraser's chartering a DC-9 to send 115 employees to study a Southern California project.
"It was like being around Beethoven, Napoleon and Jefferson all at the same time," Mr. Chapin said of Mr. Fraser. Mr. Chapin left his doctoral studies in psychology to work for Mr. Fraser. He said he was captivated by Mr. Fraser and his ideas at a dinner at Hilton Head in the late 60's.
In the late 60's and early 70's, the Sea Pines Company branched out, buying 3,000 acres at Amelia Island in Florida, 2,700 acres in Puerto Rico, 4,000 acres on the north end of Hilton Head, 2,600 in Richmond.
But then the recession hit. Interest rates rose and the Sea Pines Company fell into trouble. James Light, the new company president who is now Mr. Chapin's partner, started selling off assets. By the time the crisis ended, the company was much smaller and some of the bright young employees had moved on. Mr. Fraser regained control in 1976.
The company was sold in 1983 for $12 million, and Mr. Fraser has been consulting and dabbling in other pursuits ever since. He has worked for the last seven years with Mr. Rummell on Celebration, which will have a 34-building town center, including a town hall, movie theater, churches, neighborhood grocery store and medical complex.
The first phase will have 3,200 homesites. It is one of a few examples of this type of design being used for primary homes.
Mr. Fraser said his ideas are not often mimicked in primary-home construction because huge tracts near cities are expensive to assemble, city planners do not encourage such development and nearby landowners turn out in droves to say "not in my backyard."
"They only want big house developers near them," he said.
Moreover, developers often lack the core group needed to pull off such a complex assignment. That is one of Mr. Fraser's new pursuits -- getting the information needed by developers on the Internet.
Mr. Fraser is about a third of the way toward creating an Internet service to give developers quick and easy access to consultants in the 26 fields he says are needed to plan a town. A master contract will be worked out between a developer and Mr. Fraser, who in turn will pay the consultants. Consultants and developers will be linked by video-conferencing technology.
"I am very optimistic about that," he said. "I am not satisfied with the last 30 years of development. It's time to take what we know, mobilize it and do it."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk
