HEADLINE: While You Were Sleeping

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
At 3 A.M., New Jersey can seem like a lonely place -- almost deserted except for the police officer prowling suburban streets, the night owl huddled over a cup of coffee in a diner, the motorist whizzing through an unattended tollbooth on the parkway.
But if you know where to look, the armies of the night are out there. 
 At midnight the workday is just getting under way for thousands of New Jersey residents -- in bakeries and in emergency rooms, at radio stations and in warehouses, in college dormitories and in supermarkets. AT&T employs an entire staff of network engineers to keep its lines of communication open round the clock. And Atlantic City's casinos, of course, support a 24-hour culture of newsstands, nightclubs, pawnshops and limousine and escort services.
Even when it comes to matters of the spirit, New Jersey never sleeps: the Catholic Youth Organization of the Archdiocese of Newark organized an all-night youth revival inside the C.Y.O. office in Kearny last night, to be followed by an outdoor mass at 5:30 A.M.
No one keeps statistics on whether the number of New Jerseyans working or otherwise active at night is on the rise (though a recent study found New Jerseyans to be more sleep-deprived than the nation as a whole). But the state's relative affluence and population density make it worthwhile for many sectors of the service economy to function round the clock, making it possible for you to have your teeth filled, work out at the gym, get your refrigerator repaired or have your mice exterminated at any hour.
And while there may not be as many factories operating around the clock as there once were, James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, noted that the state's position as a distribution hub insures that commerce never stops.
"Trucking activity keeps the highways bustling at night, much more so than historically was the case," Mr. Hughes said. "In many activities, whether they be manufacturing or service, just-in-time inventory practices mean many more distribution trips."
A week spent touring the state in the wee hours turned up a wide array of nocturnal activities. Next time you can't sleep, you can think about all the people out there keeping you company, by choice or by necessity:
What are 135 people doing in the school cafeteria adjoining St. John Vianney Roman Catholic Church at midnight?
They are playing bingo. But the crowd is small this week, because the progressive jackpot is only up to $952.
Which is fine with Jack Hare.
"One thing a lot of us are tired of is the progressive," says Mr. Hare, a 35-year-old pharmacy worker who plays bingo here in Colonia and elsewhere half a dozen times a week. "Ever since the progressive started last year, it's caused more trouble, more fights, people fighting with each other to get in."
Mr. Hare's main complaint about the progressive, however, is that he's losing money.
"Before the progressive," he says, setting down purple markers on the dozen cards laid out in front of him, "I used to spend $20 a night. Now I spend $40 a night. I've gone into debt $3,000 borrowing money from my employer."
Angel Nieves, the fiance of a friend of Mr. Hare's, wins $150 in the first game of bingo he has ever played. Beginner's luck, Mr. Hare and several others sigh. "It's a good start," Mr. Nieves says.
"That's a bingo," the announcer says after Mr. Nieves's numbers are read back. "Are there any other bingos? Are there bingos in the classroom?"
"No bingos in the classroom," a woman's voice calls over the loudspeaker, like a chiding teacher, from down the hall where the nonsmokers play.
AT 1 A.M. there is a Code Red at Hackensack University Medical Center. The fire alarm bell clangs relentlessly, but John Rowohlt and Michael Evans go right on sleeping, oblivious to the noise and the 17 sets of electrodes glued to their bodies.
This in itself is a useful piece of information to the polysomnographers at the Institute for Sleep-Wake Disorders, who spend the night watching the two men on closed-circuit monitors and tracking their vital signs -- heart rate, blood oxygen, eye and leg movement.
"We are awake at sleep lab to watch people sleep," says the clinic director, Dr. Susan Zafarlotfi.
Both men are in a state of chronic sleep deprivation caused by sleep apnea, a condition that causes their breathing passages to close and disturbs their rest, so that when they do sleep, their slumber is unnaturally deep. "Sleep is very, very fragile," Dr. Zafarlotfi says, "like a crystal."
An hour later, in a tiny studio tucked away in a warehouse in Lodi, Chris Greene steps up to the microphone.
"This is Chris Greene with the hourly forecast as of 2:05," Mr. Greene says. He zips through the one-minute update -- rain today, highs in the mid-60's, small craft advisory -- in one take and hits a button.
What does the weather-hot-line weatherman do when he's not reading the weather?
Not much.
"I probably end up working five minutes out of the hour," says Mr. Greene, whose voice can be heard weeknights from 2 to 10 A.M. by dialing 976-1212. Mr. Greene uses the rest of his time at Sun Dial Productions to watch television and study the sports pages.
Mr. Greene, 27, says his body has never adjusted to three years of working nights.
"It's a treat for me to go to bed on Friday night when it's still dark out," he says. "That's one of the best parts of the weekend."
At 2:25, the bingo players file out of the church cafeteria, faces drained by exhaustion and poor luck. Several groups seem to perk up slightly in the chilly parking lot, however, among the friends of Mr. Hare, who leads an expedition to the Galaxy Diner in Rahway.
 Across the street from the Galaxy, on the second floor of the Pyramid Health Club, Joe DiComo is winding up his nightly workout with a stint on the treadmill, buoyed in part by the knowledge that the people in the diner probably think he's crazy.
"I only need four hours of sleep a night since I started really working out," says Mr. DiComo, 34, adding that he has lost 30 pounds since the beginning of the year on a diet that forbids fresh fruit, among other substances. "I wish I didn't have to sleep at all."
With three hours of weights, abs and cardio under his belt, Mr. DiComo, a manager at a health food company, is more than ready to begin his day. "I'm going to go home and have my protein shake and my oatmeal," he said, "then go to Shop-Rite and get my chicken and tuna and brown rice for the week."
The night manager of the health club, Jay Haddad, says the club's 24-hour operation is "probably its biggest selling point."
"People love it," he says. "It puts your mind at ease. You don't have to rush to get to the gym before it closes."
In Atlantic City, a man who gives his name only as Marcus works on his body-building in a G-string, in time to throbbing dance music against a backdrop of green neon springs. He is a go-go dancer at Studio 6, one of the state's biggest gay bars, "Where Entertainers Are Entertained."
"I basically want to learn how to dance better so that I can do a better presentation," Marcus, a 41-year-old retired Air Force sergeant who has been bodybuilding competitively since 1978, says later. "I know how to pose, but putting together a choreographed routine that's pleasing and natural is very difficult."
Marcus, whose wife and two children think he is at his other job as a nurse, says he does not mind the work environment.
"It's not really a sexual thing," he says. "It's a very practical way to reach my goals and make some money."
On the floor below, the other dancer, Adonis Poulos, is getting more attention and having a slightly more difficult time of things. One man, rather than tuck his bill into Mr. Poulos's waistband, reaches into the pouch of the G-string itself, and Mr. Poulos, a tall blond with magnificent cheekbones and a steady girlfriend, shoots him a dirty look. The man dances away.
Out of doors, in woods and swamps and meadows across the state, the natural world, unaided by electric lights, caffeine and other modern conveniences, more or less shuts down. "The middle of the night is kind of like the middle of the day," said Dave Jenkins, a zoologist for the state division of Fish, Game and Wildlife. "Things pretty much come to a stop." Even nocturnal animals -- raccoons, bats, owls -- do most of their food gathering just after dusk or just before dawn.
Indoor animals modify their schedules, and Ed Gorczynski of E & G Exterminating in South Amboy says he is occasionally summoned to go out in the middle of the night and rid a house of vermin. "A lot of times it'll be women," Mr. Gorczynski said. "They get nervous when they hear mice and rats scratching in the attic."
Underwater, where day and night mean much less than they do on land, life goes on. Striped bass prowl the surf in search of eels. Blue crabs swim in the channels. And in Cape May, the third-busiest fishing port on the East Coast, entire schools of fishing boats crowd the harbor, rushing to make the offshore canyons by dawn.
"Urnngh," John Rowohlt says in his sleep. "Urmmngh, grnnmgh, mmnnng." It is 2:32 in Hackensack, and Mr. Rowohlt, a 53-year-old limousine driver from Lodi, is having an obstructive hypopnea: his throat muscles are relaxing, closing off his air supply.
"It's like breathing through a collapsed straw," explains Donna Marshall, a senior sleep technician. "The harder you breathe the more it collapses."
Mr. Rowohlt does not wake up, but he tosses and pitches in bed, throwing off his covers. Ms. Marshall goes into his room and reattaches a stray electrode.
AT 3 A.M., Angelo B. Brugno Jr. is awakened by a beep of a pager at his home in Hamilton Township. He dresses quickly and meets his boss at the office. Together they drive to the house nearby where a 75-year-old woman has just died of cancer.
Mr. Brugno, a funeral director at Hamilton Brenna Cellini Funeral Home, counsels the woman's grown children for a few minutes, then asks them to go into another room. He and the manager lift the woman's body in her blankets and sheets and set her down on a stretcher. They refold the bedding carefully -- "We always try to leave the room looking nice," Mr. Brugno said -- and carry the body to the hearse and return to the funeral home, where Mr. Brugno begins embalming immediately.
"I've become accustomed to losing a night's sleep now and again," Mr. Brugno said, "but there's a lot of personal satisfaction that I get from this job. You take the good moments with the trying moments."
Frank Cosgrove sits in his car down by the tracks at a quarter past three, watching a towering, insectlike freight loader known as a Packer as it makes its way down a line of just-arrived tractor-trailer containers. The Packer hovers briefly over each 45-foot container, then leans down, wraps an arm around it and hoists it onto a train car.
"They're spooky to look at at night," says Mr. Cosgrove, the night trainmaster at Conrail's South Kearny Intermodal Terminal. "Like a big monster coming at you."
The 50-car Mail Train, filled with containers from United Parcel Service and the United States Postal Service, is bound for East St. Louis, Ill., in the morning.
"The cutoff for this train is at 5 A.M. and it's already 60 or 70 percent loaded," he says. "That makes me happy."
After their shift ends at 4, the go-go dancers, Marcus and Mr. Poulos, sit a table at the bar downstairs and wax philosophical. Mr. Poulos, who plans to quit dancing when he enters the police academy in the fall, says that discipline is the key to successful go-go dancing.
"Dancing is 99 percent mental," he says. "It's like there's cameras on you and you're in a movie. You have to convince yourself of what you're doing, and you have to convince other people that you're enjoying what you're doing."
Marcus, who says he plans to keep dancing until his looks give out, takes a longer view.
"I made less than $100 tonight, but I'm meeting people, I'm networking," he says. "Tonight I met someone who introduced me to another manager. This is all about who I can benefit and who can benefit me."
"We are subhuman life forms of the deep," Stephen Sprague intones over a 4:30 A.M. mid-shift break of cookies, coffee and chunks of fresh tuna. "Lobster man, tuna man, fillet man . . ."
Indeed, the years of carving up fish in refrigerated chambers in the dead of night have given Mr. Sprague and some of his colleagues at New York Fish House in Elizabeth an undeniably subterranean cast. But the place is bustling and cheerful. Gerard Hoff, the fillet man, sings along with the radio at the top of his lungs as he pulls his knife through a striped bass and pulls pinbones out of salmon. And Mr. Sprague, whose oil painting of a fellow tuna man hangs in the office down the hall, seems to have a bottomless passion for his chosen fish.
The business day at New York Fish House, a custom seafood packer that claims to be the East Coast's leading purveyor of sashimi-grade tuna, begins at 8 P.M. when chefs start calling in the next day's orders. By 1 A.M., the company's truck drivers are on their way to airports and the Fulton Fish Market, rounding up snapper and orange roughy from New Zealand, sea urchins from California, tuna, flounder and striped bass from local waters.
In the tuna room, surrounded by enormous slabs of pink and red and maroon, Mr. Sprague opens a box and tips a 160-pound Ecuadorean bigeye onto the metal table. With a few strokes of his knife and a whack of his cleaver, he cuts the carcass in half, then in quarters. He pauses for a second and points to a nearly luminous log of flesh on the shelf across from him.
"That's a beautiful tuna over there," he says. "The meat is translucent. You can't describe it, it's like trying to describe the color red. You can see through it, look into it, it's opulent. It reminds me of Rembrandt's painting of the slaughtered oxen.
"It was somewhat scandalous at the time," he went on. "You didn't paint slaughtered oxen in the 17th century."
As the dawn comes up like house lights over Route 495, the access road to the Lincoln Tunnel, tunnel and bridge agents from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey signal the start of a new day by converting one of the outbound lanes into an inbound bus lane. In a process known as plunking, a worker riding on the side of a slow-moving rig plants yellow plastic lane markers in holes in the road spaced every 20 feet or so.
At the Tunnel Diner in Jersey City, the lull of night has already given way to the morning rush, there is a line at the register and tempers are growing short.
A middle-aged man in a windbreaker orders a cup of tea and a Daily News. The cashier pulls a paper off the stack and slaps it down on the counter. Page one is frayed along the bottom.
"I don't want that raggedy one," the customer says.
The cashier pretends not to hear and rings up the next customer.
The man in the windbreaker does not budge.
"I don't want that raggedy one," he repeats.
The cashier shakes his head at the man even as he replaces the damaged merchandise. "Come on, whaddya want?" he says. "It's a newspaper."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Fish knives fly all night long at the New York Fish House in Elizabeth, a custom seafood packer where workers are specialists in lobsters, tuna or fillets.

Night owls find company at an Atlantic City bar, and a hot -- though solitary -- meal at a Newark restaurant.

Atlantic City, of course, is a city that never sleeps, and there is always some place to go dancing. In Newark, a neon sign cuts through the darkness with the promise of a hot meal.

LENGTH: 2860 words

HEADLINE: L.I. Over 25 Years: Realizing a Dream;
Deep Roots, Broad Changes

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

DATELINE: CALVERTON

 BODY:
THE rooster just outside the door greets every morning with a song of joy. But its small-brained enthusiasm is not shared by Connie Farr, Long Island Railroad commuter, and her husband, Rex Farr, Long Island farmer. Consciousness resurrects thoughts of work.
If the weekday routine whirs along without interruption, Ms. Farr will be in nearby Riverhead an hour later, stepping aboard the 6:07, a mostly empty diesel train bound for Ronkonkoma. There she catches an electrically powered train for Manhattan, where she works as a knit-fabric designer. Her 77-mile morning commute takes 2 hours and 12 minutes. Theoretically. 
 When not reading, or sharing in the fatalistic humor that comes easily to commuters, Connie Farr gazes through Plexiglas windows at the passing Long Island landscape. Since she began commuting from this farm town eight years ago, there have been constants: the remnants of pine barrens, the sadly beautiful headstones of Pinelawn Cemetery. And there have been changes: because of the huge layoffs at the once-mighty Grumman Corporation, fewer people get off now at the Bethpage stop.
By the time Ms. Farr reaches Manhattan, her husband has already fed the couple's eclectic menagerie: a pony, two dogs, three goats, 20 sheep, some chickens, various ducks and about 30 cats. To keep track of their pride of felines, the Farrs have tacked a cat roster to the kitchen wall; thin pencil lines have been drawn through the names of Kitty and Spike.
Then, for the rest of the day, on 55 acres that once produced the famous but low-profit Long Island potato, he now grows organic produce, from gourmet lettuce to yellow zucchini, from heirloom tomatoes to leeks. While his wife toils amid millions of people, Mr. Farr, a former entertainment producer, has days when he wonders how he got here -- standing alone on rich, eastern Island loam, talking to vegetables.
In many ways, the Farrs of Calverton are Long Island today; they represent where the region has been, and where it is headed. And, in more intangible ways, they typify the region's 2.6 million residents: they work hard to realize their dreams while living on a 118-mile stretch of land that juts into the Atlantic Ocean like a snagged bluefish.
The year 1996 finds Long Island the same as ever -- it keeps changing. Just as the various moods of the Atlantic continue to redefine the southern belly of the island, so too do demographics and economics continue to redefine who we are and how we live. Popular culture would have it that we live in one big Levittown; that our sons are Howard Sterns, our daughters Amy Fishers and our parents the Buttafuocos.
In truth, we are the farmers in Southold and Southampton, who trace our Long Island roots back three centuries, and we are the Dominican and Guatemalan emigres in Hempstead, who trace our Long Island roots in terms of months, not years. And we are American Indiansof the Shinnecock and Poospatuck tribes, whose ancestors were here well before 1524, when Giovanni da Verrazano first laid eyes on Suffolk's sandy coast.
We are the commuters, rocked and swayed inexorably toward Manhattan, and we are the engineers and bankers, clerks and laborers, fighting traffic to get from one part of the island to another. We are the affluent of Sands Point to the north, the poor of Patchogue to the south, and the middle class in between, whose heritage of tenement life in Depression-era New York City has spawned pride for the simplest of ranch-style homes.
 
The Mad Dash Down L.I.E. and Onto L.I.R.R.
We are Connie and Rex Farr.
Connie Farr is 48, a macrobiotic vegetarian, and a veteran of many a commuter war. She knows to bring a small blanket to ward off the winds that whip about the feet of L.I.R.R. passengers. She knows that if she misses the 6:07 in the morning, she can race her Geo down the Long Island Expressway to catch the connection at Yaphank. And she knows that if the 5:41, the last train to Far East destinations like Riverhead, leaves without her in the evening, itmeans a $50 cab ride from Ronkonkoma back to Calverton.
Commuting five hours a day, five days a week, can do strange things to a person. Ms. Farr and her buddies have imagined who might play them in a television sitcom about the largest commuter railroad in the nation. They have placed bets on the number of eggs beneath that swan they see every day, the one nesting in the shallow waters of the Peconic River. And, on more than one occasion, Ms. Farr has nodded off, only to wake with her body sprawled across the seat and her head jutting into the aisle. This is one reason why she tries to remain alert, she says: "I try to find a clean window."
However tedious, Ms. Farr's daily commuting carries historical resonance. In the mid-1830's, teams of laborers in Brooklyn and in Greenport began laying track for what became the Long Island Railroad. They carved through the woods and pine barrens that once covered Farmingdale, Deer Park and Brentwood to lay down the original line, the Ronkonkoma line now traveled by Ms. Farr.
 
Working People And Middle-Class Life
From her window, she bears witness to Long Island's continuing development. Many of the houses she sees in Suffolk, the subdivisions of raised ranches, were carved out of potato fields and woods to accommodate the tens of thousands who moved eastward in the last 30 years. Since 1960, Suffolk's population has ballooned by more than a million, to 1.33 million people.
As she continues west into Nassau County, Ms. Farr sees older homes, colonials and Cape Cods set on smaller lots. Some were built before World War II, but many more were built for returning soldiers and military workers who used low-interest government loans to trade city asphalt for suburban grass. In one two-year span, William Levitt, the developer, built 10,101 houses in what became Levittown. No wonder, then, that between 1950 and 1960, Nassau County's population doubled to 1.3 million.
"It became possible," said Barbara Kelly, curator of Hofstra University's Institute of Long Island Studies, "for the working people to have what the middle class had taken for granted. A house. A front yard. A backyard."
Ms. Farr is one of 110,000 people on Long Island who take trains to jobs amid Manhattan skyscrapers. It has been this way for most of the 20th century, ever since train tunnels under the East River connected the two islands in 1910. But time still moves slowly inside those railroad cars; Ms. Farr sees more of her fellow commuters during the week than she does of her husband.
Thousands more commute to Manhattan by car and truck, along the latticework of pavement laid over the island by, among others, uber-planner Robert Moses. Just as experienced L.I.R.R. passengers know every lurch in the approach to Jamaica station, so, too, do Long Island Expressway veterans know every exit. Such knowledge comes not from mnemonic devices, but from hours spent in traffic, staring at green signs in the distance.
But there are dramatic changes taking place in Long Island's work force, as well as within the many homes that Ms. Farr passes every day.
The region's economy continues to reel from the leveling blow it received in the late 1980's, when the recession and Government cutbacks hit Long Island square in its breadbasket: the military and aerospace industries. According to Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, the region's military-related businesses lost more than 43,000 jobs between 1986 and 1994, a loss roughly equivalent to the population of Hicksville. Thousands more lost jobs in related fields.
Today the collapse of those industries are reflected in sobering ways. Grumman Corporation in Bethpage was once the island's largest private employer; now that claim is held by Waldbaum's supermarkets, and Grumman's old headquarters is for sale. And on the grounds of the old Fairchild Republic aircraft factory in East Farmingdale, a "multiplex" movie theater is under construction.
There are some positive signs. "Long Island is reinventing itself," said Gary Huth, a labor market analyst for the New York State Department of Labor. "You see some of the traditional businesses losing jobs -- banking, aerospace and defense -- but you are finding some of those companies related to defense reinventing themselves in some way. Some are going into electronic products, and some will benefit from the upturn in the civilian air market."
Mr. Huth and other economists say the jobs lost at places like Grumman are being replaced piecemeal: 10 jobs in a plant in Hauppauge, 20 jobs in a factory in Plainview. "That's not nearly as visible to people," Mr. Huth said. "But is it encouraging? No question about it."
Dr. Kamer was less sanguine. She said that most of the 44,000 jobs created in the last three years were low-paying positions in health and social services, with few new opportunities in manufacturing and construction.
"The loss of high-paying defense jobs, being replaced by lower-wage retail and service jobs, certainly poses a threat to our living standard if we do nothing about it," she said. "Instead of relying on the one engine of the defense industry, we're going to need several engines of growth. And that's going to help us in the long run."
Dr. Kamer and Mr. Huth belong to a chorus of economists and planners calling for Long Island to improve and match the region's work skills with the needs of emerging businesses. The Long Island Association and the State University at Stony Brook, among others, are working on projects to identify industries, like biotechnology and graphics communications, that should create better-paying jobs for the region.
All this has affected how people spend their money on Long Island. National retailers salivate over the region's general affluence and spending habits. The Wall Street Journal recently ranked the country's metropolitan areas by median household income: Long Island was first, with $70,091, and San Jose, Calif., was a distant second.
It is an island of consumerism, where community pride often blends with retail needs. The mall in Huntington bears the name of the island's most celebrated poet, Walt Whitman, and the mall at Roosevelt Field, the gem in the region's crown of malls, sits on the approximate site where Charles A. Lindbergh took flight for Paris in 1927.
 
The Changing Face Of Consumerism
The success of Long Island's nine regional malls and its sprawling shopping centers has wounded the downtown businesses of Bay Shore, Patchogue, and even Garden City's Franklin Avenue. Once the self-proclaimed Fifth Avenue of Long Island, the avenue now has several empty storefronts; a "for rent" sign hangs in the window of a closed furrier shop.
The reason is Darwinian, said Barry Berman, a business professor at Hofstra University. "I have 250-odd stores at Roosevelt Field," he said. "Why the heck do I want to go to Franklin Avenue to have Lord & Taylor's and Saks Fifth Avenue?"
But 50 miles east of Roosevelt Field, where shoppers can have their cars parked by a valet while they browse the aisles of Bloomingdale's, Wal-Mart has opened two stores in the Town of Brookhaven. Meanwhile, other discount stores, like Caldor and Kmart, have proliferated throughout Long Island.
"One has to bear in mind that the mass market has basically divided itself," Professor Berman said. "You have less than affluent and more than affluent. Kmart wasn't here 25 years ago. Caldor wasn't here 25 years ago. There are plenty of people who are single parents, who have been downsized, who haven't done well for one reason or another."
Economics have wrought other changes as well. Long Island's postwar pioneers are retiring and moving to places like Florida, North Carolina -- and eastern Suffolk. Some of their sons and daughters have been able to buy homes on the island, even in the neighborhoods where they grew up. But many others have been priced out of the market, thanks to the high cost of houses -- averaging close to $180,000 -- and tax and utility bills that are among the highest in the country.
The Levittown dream of yesteryear has proved elusive today. Young adults are having difficulty trying to replicate an experience their parents may have taken for granted: owning a house. And there is some indication that people are moving away. According to the American Movers' Conference, a moving-industry association, Long Island was not among the country's top 10 areas from which people were moving in 1994; in the first nine months of 1995, it ranked first.
But the Farrs have decided to stay. And their attempt to carve a diverse niche in Long Island's competitive farming world represents what economists say is needed throughout the island's business world.
Rex Farr is 49, with dark-blond hair that sticks out like straw from under his John Deere cap. His rural look of today contradicts the more urbane look of his past. In another life, he was an entertainment producer, known among the avant-garde of Greenwich Village and by the waiters at Elaine's.
But his family goes back three generations in Southampton. And in 1984, after several years of living in Huntington, Mr. Farr and his wife decided to move east, with vague plans to buy a plot big enough to rehearse Busby Berkeley-like productions around the swimming pool. They bought a 60-acre farm, built a log cabin on the foundation of an old shed, and soon learned that the water in their well was laced with pesticides.
Perhaps it was the fresh air, or maybe the re-evaluation that comes in midlife. But in 1989, Mr. Farr decided to try his hand at farming organically, using the marketing know-how the couple had acquired in the fashion and entertainment industries. They started slowly, taking classes, growing "high-end crops" like yellow pear tomatoes and zucchini flowers on four acres. Mr. Farr would sometimes truck the produce into Manhattan himself, selling it to restaurants and shops he once frequented.
Today, the Farrs have 55 acres in production, with the choice of vegetables changing with their reading of what is in demand. "Farming is not like having a hit record," Mr. Farr said. "If you have a hit crop, you have to go back."
There have been setbacks. They are still paying debt on problems they had during the 1991 season, and their irrigation pump -- as important as the loam -- broke down last year. And they are aware that some Suffolk farmers, whose families go back generations, first considered the Farrs to be hopeless neophytes (a reputation enhanced in 1991, when two valuable heifers fled the Farr farm and wandered about the area for two months -- including an occasional jaunt down the streets of Riverhead).
Now, Ms. Farr said, "They don't laugh as much."
Joseph Gergela 3d, executive director of the Long Island Farm Bureau, is among those applauding rather than laughing. The region's farmers, once known almost entirely for their potato and cauliflower crops, have been forced by production costs and the market to diversify or hang up their coveralls. Indeed, more than 1,000 acres of farmland are lost every year, mostly to make way for subdivisions.
 
Agricultural Sales Lead the State
But the farming community's ability to shift focus has paid off, Mr. Gergela said. Twenty-five years ago there were no vineyards on Long Island; now there are 16 wineries producing 3 million bottles of wine a year. Where potatoes once grew, there are now sod farms, nurseries, specialty produce -- all of which have made Long Island the state's leader in agricultural sales.
Each weeknight, Connie Farr races to Pennsylvania Station to catch the 5:41 back home. There have been times when she reached the platform just as the train's doors closed, and the urge to scream had to be stifled. Once, and only once, her desperate pleas persuaded an engineer to open the door for her.
She looks forward to the return home, especially on Friday evenings. She and her East End buddies used to be so excited that they'd have Friday-night mixers on board -- one person would bring pretzels, another some beer -- until complaints from other passengers ended the reverie. Still, those nights heading east remain sweet.
With the sun setting, the evening light can set the drabbest of suburban homes aglow, and the possibilities of Long Island seem good and many. The beaches. The parks. The crops. Heck, even the Mets.
"It's a quality of life that you can take for granted, that you only begin to realize when you go to other parts of the country," Dr. Kamer said. "We tend to focus on the negatives, I guess because New Yorkers like to gripe."
Back home in Calverton, Connie and Rex Farr might go to a restaurant, where they have been known to barter for a meal with produce. On Sunday, their only day off, they might go to the beach. Or Connie Farr might just sit at her kitchen table with a cup of herbal tea by her elbow, peering through binoculars to make sure that their animals don't stray from the homestead.
"Duck on the road," she might say.

HEADLINE: L.I. Over 25 Years: Realizing a Dream;
Crossing the Island, A Slice of America

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER 

 BODY:
TO drive the 120 miles from Brooklyn to Montauk, the length of Long Island, is in a strange sort of way like crossing the continent. It is a journey that begins in the great city, moves on and on through what can seem like endless stretches of different landscapes, then culminates in a place of great beauty where the land runs out at the edge of the sea.
Now it is not exactly like crossing the country, of course. There is no Continental Divide, since it is something of a stretch to conceive of the pine barrens as being nature's break between East and West, and obviously it takes somewhat less time to traverse Long Island than the American continent, although on certain Friday afternoons in the summer it is reasonable to think otherwise. 
 But this metaphor is more a matter of state of mind than of any tangible facts about the landscape. After all, the Hamptons really do feel more and more like California all the time, and the Island, like the country at large, is forever being crossed by people who have business at either end, and pay scant attention to what is in between.
Yet what is in between is what truly validates the metaphor, for it is the American postwar world, more fully realized here than anywhere else. Long Island between the city and the East End is the archetypical American landscape, the quintessential expression of all its banal madness, all its boredom, liveliness and strange, humming kind of energy.
Road after road, strip mall after strip mall, a land governed by automobiles and the kind of buildings that are made to accommodate to them. The Island has never been as industrialized as New Jersey, and with the exception of certain parts of the North Shore it has never been as genteel as Connecticut. Until the 1950's, Long Island was mostly small towns and farmland, ready and waiting for sprawl. Sprawl is what it got: from Queens to the middle of Suffolk County, a place that looks like most American places, only more so.
Here is where we see, as clearly as anywhere in the country, precisely what the American landscape will turn into if it is allowed to develop more or less by itself. Some of it is vulgar, some of it is beautiful, and nearly all of it is compelling.
It is a kind of badly compromised version of Frank Lloyd Wright's Broadacre City, that design from the 1930's in which Wright, perhaps the only great modern architect who understood the profound effect the automobile would have on the landscape, tried to pre-empt chaos by prescribing an ordered mix of housing, roads, commercial buildings and farmland.
Long Island is not the Broadacre City of Wright's imagination but the real one, twisted and contorted by the realities of the marketplace and dozens of different municipal jurisdictions so that it seems, to the casual observer, to be less a vision of suburban order than one of anarchy.
Yet there is an order to the Island, and if it is not easy to see, it is very much there, and its effect is vast. Cityscapes do not take their form for no reason at all, and that of Long Island is no exception.
 
A Raw, Blunt Sense To the Sunrise
There is not much beauty to the Sunrise Highway, but there is a certain raw, blunt sense to it: low, sprawling buildings with big signs that can be read instantly from a moving car; lots of arrows telling you where to go, where to turn, when to get onto the service road and when to get off, everything designed to keep the traffic flowing and to ease the movement out of cars and into Waldbaum's or McDonald's or whatever. The green arrow indicating a protected left turn may not be one of the noblest inventions of man, but it is all part of the system that, until it was burdened by a volume of traffic it simply could not take, actually made a certain sense.
That is all a kind of hidden order, a rational underbelly that makes the insipid sprawl, if not easier to take, at least easier to understand. There is another kind of order to the physical form of Long Island, a more visible one. The Island has two great systems of transportation infrastructure: the Long Island Railroad, built gradually starting in the 1830's, and the parkway and expressway system, built largely by Robert Moses from the late 1920's to the 1950's.
Its form is affected by its two great natural resources as well: the waterfronts of the Atlantic Ocean on the South Shore and Long Island Sound on the north, and then by the remarkable system of public parks, also virtually all the product of Robert Moses' career, built from the late 1920's through the 1930's.
The story of Long Island's physical form over the last 75 years is very much the story of Robert Moses, who treated the Island as something of a private fief in which to experiment with public works on a grand scale. Taken together, Moses' projects gave Long Island a set of resources that few areas anywhere have ever had, and they made it a kind of laboratory of American mid-20th-century suburban development.
Long Island is where, thanks to Moses, the metropolitan region did the most to accommodate itself to the automobile, and did it the soonest. And Long Island is where, thanks to Moses, the metropolitan region began to understand the notion that the public realm had to extend beyond urban parks and boulevards, and had to include great rural parks, parkways and public beaches as well.
The Northern State Parkway, the Southern State Parkway, Jones Beach, Heckscher State Park, Caumsett State Park, these are but the beginning; the list goes on and on, an extraordinary system of public works for a relatively condensed geographical area, and all of them built by Robert Moses to make Long Island a prototype for suburban development.
 
On the Road To Utopia?
Why, then, is Long Island not more perfect? There is almost no one who does not admire Jones Beach as one of the great American public works of the 20th century, and Moses' parkways were models for a whole generation of road builders to follow. A place with all this, not to mention the resources nature gave it to start with, ought by any rights to have become utopia. How is it that we identify Long Island today more by the jumbled commercial mess of the now woefully misnamed Old Country Road in Westbury or by the shrill splatter of strip malls on the Sunrise Highway than by the soft, landscaped curves of the Northern State Parkway?
Long Island planned itself more or less the way the hare ran its race against the tortoise: Moses' infrastructure made it seem so far ahead of other places in accommodating to the new, automobile-oriented suburban landscape that by the late 1950's it was ready to sit down and take a rest, unaware that the world was rapidly gaining on it. By then the first parkways were already a generation old, and the Long Island Expressway was being built (at Moses' insistence) without a rapid-transit capacity or much ease of expansion.
Far worse, the Moses infrastructure lulled local officials into thinking that their towns and villages could handle more growth than they really could. Long Island in the postwar years threw its doors open to development. More and more houses and more and more strip malls seemed only to mean more and more tax dollars, and not a lot of people were thinking of the long-term implications.
One who did was Lee E. Koppelman, the longtime head of the Nassau-Suffolk Regional Planning Board, who argued consistently for tighter zoning regulations and for the preservation of more open space, not to mention for a view of Long Island as a whole. No small part of the problem of planning in the post-Moses era was the way it was rapidly becoming Babylon against Hempstead, Oyster Bay against Smithtown, the whole Island a series of competing duchies.
Though his sensibilities were quite different from Moses', Mr. Koppelman was the first public official since Moses to try to see the Island in a unified way, and thanks largely to his efforts, effective programs were established to save thousands of acres of agricultural land from real-estate development, and additional public land was set aside for parks. But compared with the land being turned into tract houses and shopping malls and parking lots, it was a pittance.
 
Growth of Levittown Redefined Landscape
The place it all began for Long Island, and in a sense symbolically for postwar suburban America in general, was Levittown. Over four years, from 1947 to 1951, William Levitt built more than 17,000 houses on 4,700 acres of former potato fields north of the Hempstead Turnpike near Bethpage, and the American landscape was never quite the same again.
Levitt's little houses, Cape Cod-style cottages set on concrete slabs, sold originally for $7,990, making suburban living affordable to vast numbers of city dwellers who yearned for their own backyards. Here, truly, did the American dream open up to the working class. Levitt's suburban boxes were to houses what Henry Ford's Model T was to cars.
Today Levittown remains, not only the seed of Long Island's explosive postwar growth but also a place in which, as firmly as in any city, one can view the passage of time. Levittown has mellowed, mutated, adapted, proving wrong both its critics, who denounced it as hopelessly monotonous, and its creators, who viewed it as a panacea. For the very thing that William Levitt created with such pride, and his critics attacked with such vehemence, is no more: the sameness, the monotony, the dreary repetition of a single house type over block after block after block.
Now it is a struggle to find a house that looks even remotely like the original. (One that has survived virtually unaltered has even been proposed for landmark status, a startling but not unreasonable icon.) The Levittown houses have been embellished with new windows, shutters, porticos, verandas, bay windows, brick fronts, carports or extra rooms tacked onto the sides.
In some cases the whole shape is gone, with the roof raised to create a two-story house, or raised in the rear to turn it into a pseudo-saltbox. There is every which color. There is even one house with its original Cape Cod shape but a facade sheathed in stone and new, diamond-paned windows: Levittown goes Tudor.
Paradoxically, this place that was once dismissed as the ultimate in suburban conformity has now metamorphosed into the most eclectic of suburbs, a place in which personal expression seems an essential part of the experience of home ownership. Yet Levittown, if it has grown into a celebration of personal taste, is hardly a triumph of planning.
Levitt's original design, which included local shopping areas scattered through the development, has mostly given way to the vast machine of strip mall retailing on Hempstead Turnpike. The only thing that makes the streets inside the development attractive is what nearly 50 years of growth has done to the small saplings planted when Levittown was new, for now the streets are protected by a canopy of large trees.
Levittown is the Long Island of the first generation of sprawl. The areas around where the Long Island Expressway intersects with Route 110 in Melville and with the Veterans Highway in Islandia both represent the Long Island of a later generation. It features the new corporate park of low office buildings in funny shapes with fancy curves and mirror-glass fronts, with the strange mix of corporate dullness and glitzy architectural form that you associate with buildings around Houston or Dallas.
Virtually none of these boxes is of any architectural interest (save for Richard Meier's headquarters for Swissair off Route 110, a building of far too much finesse for its surroundings). This is the city without a center, the new downtown for an age that spurns downtowns and streets and prefers to take its office buildings in the middle of acres of parking lots. This new city is anchored by nothing, save for the expressway, which flows by it night and day, the river that, like the rivers of old, gives this city its reason for being where it is.
Long Island over the last 50 years has moved away from urbanity, not toward it. It is not only less connected with New York than it once was (save for those Manhattanites who drive through it to the East End, never seeing the middle), it has become more chaotic in its sprawl, less attuned to any kind of center at all.
 
Too Many People, Too Many Automobiles
Areas like Islandia or the Route 110 corridor could have represented opportunities to develop new kinds of centers, the kinds of agglomerations of office buildings and housing and shopping and entertainment that are increasingly bringing a new, organized kind of density oriented toward the automobile to other suburban areas around the country. But such coordinated development has yet to happen here. There is too much determination to develop each town, each village, each piece of land, by itself to think regionally, and rationally.
The real sadness of Long Island is that it is built around an idea that only works at light densities: taking beautiful agricultural land and chopping it up for houses, shopping malls and an office park or two. Frank Lloyd Wright in his modesty envisioned Broadacre City as covering much of the country, so he could afford to assume that there would be an acre per person, spread thin enough to leave lots of land free.
But the pseudo-Broadacre City we have on Long Island has now become as dense as many cities, with too many people who have too many automobiles which take up too many roads and fill too many parking lots. As cars beget more cars, roads beget more roads, and it is an unending spiral, never enough.
Now, the saddest thing of all is to see small towns disappearing into the overall megasprawl. Where are streets in Long Island? There are a handful: the centers of Roslyn, and Huntington, for example, still possess the qualities of true towns, and a sense of distinct identity. But by and large the landscape of Long Island, once so different from place to place, is increasingly becoming one thing, from Valley Stream to Sayville, from Garden City to Smithtown.
Once, Levittown represented a far eastward leap of development. Now, it almost disappears in the vast march of suburbanization. It is even knocking on the door of the Hamptons now, with megastores and malls pushing their way into what had once been an extraordinary rural stretch of land, those great potato fields running to the sea: the last remnants of the Long Island that was.
But even if the East End towns manage to hold the line on foolish and destructive development, it is too late for most of the Island, which feels ever more like it has sunk into an amorphous sea of cars. Who can tell the difference between the Sunrise Highway and the Hempstead Turnpike, between Old Country Road in Westbury and Route 106 in Hicksville? Every part of the Island becoming all the more like every other: in this sense, Long Island really does prove itself to be all too much like America.
Never mind fish, or sailboats, or Long Island ducks. The only fitting symbol of the Island now is the green left-turn arrow.

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
In Englewood, Restoring a Symbol of the Past, and Future

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
For decades, Englewood has seemed to have two downtowns, roughly divided by the old Erie Railroad. Mansions on the East Hill overlook run-down row houses across the tracks to the west. Palisade Avenue jumps from tony shops to vacant storefronts. And then there's Dwight Morrow High School's famous racial imbalance.
But there is a plan to bring the two Englewoods closer. Civic-minded residents are raising $150,000 to make over the traffic circle at West Palisade Avenue and Tenafly Road, site of the Liberty Pole, first erected in 1766 to celebrate Britain's repeal of the tyrannical Stamp Act. A block away, the city will invest $800,000 to fix up half a dozen houses on Armory Street, one of the most troubled neighborhoods in the city of 24,000 residents. Other money will go for new ball fields and tennis courts. 
 "Politics, that's all it is," said Manuel Ocampo, 29, a mechanic being forced to move off Armory Street under a zoning crackdown. But remarks like that don't faze Mayor Donald Aronson, who spoke recently as he toured the city in his BMW.
Q. Why does the west side need help?
A. We have the most expensive housing stock in Bergen County here. We have one house, I know for sure, that runs in excess of $10 million. Without mentioning them by name, we have 3 of the 10 wealthiest families in the State of New Jersey. And we also have the greatest poverty in Bergen County. So we have this mixture of the very rich and the very poor, and the concern is, of course, that the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer.
The east side of town has become the shopping district for not only Englewood. The folks who live in Tenafly and Cresskill and Dumont, Demarest, Fort Lee have used the boutique-type shopping that we have. There's a certain affluent type of clientele. And the rents are high and the stores are doing well.
And the question became, what do you do with the west side of town? We are one city, we want to live together and not separated. We don't want to be two Englewoods.
Q. Do both sides of the tracks really care what some colonists did when the Stamp Act was repealed?
A. Not at all. But you do need a sense of character. Are both sides of the tracks going to use the soccer field? Are both sides concerned about Armory Street? It's an overall community situation. You don't live by bread alone. And that's maybe what we're in the business of, creating some feeling of community pride. You have to look to the past to understand the future. I'm more concerned about the future and this is a symbol for the future, that there are people who care. I cared enough to give $1,000. If I were not Mayor, would I have given $1,000? Not too sure. Is this the most important thing to happen in Englewood? No. Is it the best publicity we've gotten in a long time? Yes.
Q. But do symbols generate economic activity?
A. What we're trying to do is bring the folks with the bucks in their pocket to this part of town. All you can do is pump up a particular section of town by making certain that the community is kept as clean as it possibly can be and by upgrading the problem areas. Armory Street is the worst street in Englewood.
Q. What are the relations between the two parts of town?
A. There's always an undercurrent of problems with people isolating themselves. It's a constant job of the Mayor to see that there are events in the community for everyone.
Q. And you think the west side projects will alter perceptions?
A. I'm in the perception business. STEVE STRUNSKY

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Donald Aronson says that restoring the Liberty Pole is important for Englewood's character. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 874 words

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Swing Low, Sweet Corporation, and All That Jazz

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
"FIRST you play jazz; then you betray your country," goes an old Soviet slogan, a bygone warning so familiar to Russians that it was easily satirized when the daily newspaper Izvestia reported Bill Clinton's election victory in 1992. ("First You Play Saxophone . . . ," read the front-page headline, atop a photo of America's new President.)
So if jazz is bad for Communism, is it good for capitalism? 
 John Kao thinks so.
Mr. Kao, who teaches a course in creativity at Harvard Business School, is the author of "Jamming: The Art and Discipline of Business Creativity" (HarperBusiness, $23), due at bookstores in about a month.
Once a classical piano student, Mr. Kao woke up to jazz at boarding school when some fellow students introduced him to the music of John Coltrane and Charlie Parker and taught him about be-bop.
He never got over it. These days, the professor plays jazz on his piano. He has taken the idea of the jam session to the corporate world, where, he says, it can be a great tool for creativity.
"Jazz, like business, implies a series of balancing acts," he writes. That is, a successful run happens only when the players are disciplined, but not driven, by formulas.
The metaphor aside, the overarching message of "Jamming," that creativity is a crucial asset, is one we've heard before. The author, however, turns up the volume in this book.
Mr. Kao, who has written variations on this theme in earlier books about entrepreneurship and managing, announces that we have now entered the Creative Age, the fourth and latest "era" of global economic activity. (The first three activities were agriculture, industry and information.)
Information technology has swooped us into this creative era, he says, because it has changed the way ideas flow. Today, a keystroke can bring fresh data and a prism of perspectives to a problem. Think of the Internet, the author suggests, where "a good idea provokes an uninhibited cascade of reactions."
But the digital push is just one reason we've warped into the creativity zone, Mr. Kao says. There are pressures from workers, who increasingly feel entitled to creative jobs (a premise I wish the author had developed more fully). And there are pressures from the economy. With much of corporate America in industries wrestling with turmoil, he says, businesses must reinvent themselves or wither.
So what's the way to creativity if you are a manager who likes employees to stick to the sheet music? First, to borrow a metaphor from the dull old world of accounting, conduct an audit.
Find out where "creativity initiatives" usually come from in your company, and what their usual fate is. (The author defines an "initiative" as any proposal for change that gets a serious hearing from at least one person, not counting the originator's "spouse, friend or office mate.") Figure out what chunk of revenue comes from products that are less than a few years old. And perhaps most important, take a look at the office itself, its architecture and design.
Open spaces foster what is needed in Mr. Kao's universe: polite confrontation and cross-pollination. He points to companies like Oticon in Denmark, an innovator in hearing aids whose employees' offices are just credenzas-on-wheels that even move between floors. Each floor has a coffee bar for schmoozing (another one-word management-book title, if I ever saw one, though it will have to wait for an author who was electrified during his formative years by klezmer music at a stay in a Catskills resort.)
And because Charlie Parker talked about going to "the woodshed" when he needed to perfect a musical concept, companies should have "woodshed" rooms, Mr. Kao says, spaces that give employees a place to refresh their minds.
As for what action to take, the idea is for managers to help find the "sweet spot" between the systematic way of doing things and the free flow of creativity.
To make his point, Mr. Kao offers this hip case study: When Minton's Playhouse, a Harlem jazz club, was wilting in 1940, the manager hired a house band based around the drummer Kenny Clarke and Thelonious Monk on piano. Then he declared "celebrity nights," laid out free food for visiting musicians and watched the big names arrive: Coleman Hawkins, Roy Eldridge, Dizzy Gillespie. When Charlie Parker was added to the mix on alto sax, be-bop was born and the club was saved.
The lessons for corporate managers: Look for a mix of stars and unknowns when matching people with a project. Keep the working space, physical and conceptual, open. Let creative competition flourish. Don't think of mistakes as fatal. Make sure someone is still minding the store. The key is in mixing the fixed and the free.
All this is hard to disagree with, given Mr. Kao's humane impulse to make work an entertaining place, and "Jamming" is more fun to read than most management books. But much of this is familiar: the open spaces, the flexible hierarchies. And some of it may be hopeless. Entrepreneurial creativity almost always sputters out when a company gets established. Employees who are asked to come up with the magic will soon figure out that it's still the higher-ups who reap the biggest rewards. As those jazz musicians knew.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
If You Fly With Vultures, Fasten Your Seat Belts

BYLINE: By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN 

 BODY:
EVEN though Fidelity Investments threw in the towel in January on investing in weak and insolvent companies, Prudential Mutual Fund Management is pushing ahead.
This week, Prudential introduced a mutual fund to invest in the equity and debt of companies that appear on the brink of financial collapse or that are coming out of such a situation, perhaps from bankruptcy protection. Such investments are lumped together under the name "distressed securities," and the people who ply this risky market are often called "vultures" because they pick apart the remains of failed or faltering companies. 
 While Fidelity cited numerous logistical and regulatory problems in trying to run a mutual fund as a vulture fund, the investment opportunities remain tantalizing. Annualized returns for private limited partnerships that buy these securities have ranged from more than 20 percent to more than 30 percent over the last five years, according to Steven P. Galante, editor of the Private Equity Analyst in Wellesley, Mass.
Moreover, the climate seems favorable for such investors, according to Mr. Galante, who cited the surge in both bank lending and junk-bond issuance in the last few years. Junk bonds, with ratings just below corporate grade, are one step above distressed securities. Once a company is in default on its debt or is widely perceived to be near default, its securities are deemed distressed. The perception among vulture investors is that defaults will be back with a vengeance in the next recession, Mr. Galante said.
Contributing mightily to the inventory of distressed securities is the retailing industry, where plenty of companies are struggling under weak sales and increased competition, said Martin Whitman, a well-known vulture investor and manager of the Third Avenue Value Fund.
Bearing all this in mind, the Prudential Distressed Securities fund began accepting money on Wednesday, after garnering nearly $14 million in initial expressions of interest. Prudential pulls no punches about the risk. The fund's prospectus says that investing in securities of financially troubled companies can be speculative and that investors may experience a "substantial loss."
In an economic downturn, for example, teetering companies can be pushed to collapse, rendering their securities worthless.
But that is not the only obstacle for the new Prudential fund. When leaving the business, Fidelity explained that taking big positions in companies and becoming involved in company management -- as is common in distressed investing -- were inconsistent with its approach to money management.
As Mr. Whitman of Third Avenue said, "Mutual fund managers are supposed to be passive." The difficulty most funds face is highlighted by the fact that few fund managers other than Mr. Whitman and Michael Price, manager of the Mutual Series funds, do much in this area. Mr. Whitman invests heavily in distressed securities for his private accounts, and puts about 15 percent of the assets in his Third Avenue Value fund there. Mr. Price has about 5 to 10 percent of his funds' assets in distressed securities, according to Jeffrey Altman, vice president of the Mutual Series funds.
Managing large amounts of distressed securities in a mutual fund raises a panoply of legal, regulatory and operational problems. Investing in distressed companies often means tying up money for some time and becoming involved in management, perhaps by taking a seat on the company's board or on the creditors' committee.
When a company is reorganizing, its shareholders and creditors get together to strike an agreement on how to divide assets. "It is a negotiated process," explained Mark Durbiano, senior portfolio manager for Federated Investors' high-yield, or junk, bond funds. "If you're not at the table, no one is looking out for your fair share."
That can put a mutual fund in a difficult position. If a fund company agrees to sit on such a creditors' committee, the fund manager becomes privy to material, nonpublic information. He may also gain access to inside information on potential acquirers. Once saddled with such inside information, he has severe restrictions on his trading.
The manager may find himself in a jam, limited in his ability to sell securities to meet shareholder redemptions and restrained from fulfilling his duty to act in shareholders' best interests, said Burton Leibert, a partner at the law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher in New York.
Even if the fund manager does not sit on the creditors' committee, owning a big stake in a company in distress leads to other restrictions. Once a mutual fund accumulates a 5 percent interest in a company, it becomes an "affiliate" under mutual fund law. Transactions between affiliated companies are deemed ripe for abuse, and are thus limited. In practical terms, a fund company may not be able to sit down at the negotiating table without an exemption from the Securities and Exchange Commission, said Thomas R. Smith, a partner at the law firm of Brown & Wood in New York.
Finally, becoming involved in a reorganization often requires a fund manager to take an aggressive and confrontational approach, Mr. Whitman said. A manager must be prepared to file lawsuits and fight for his interests. Most managers and their companies simply are not prepared to take such a high-profile position, he said.
The bottom line, said Mr. Durbiano of Federated, is that a mutual fund is not the ideal vehicle for such investing. "You're restricted, you're illiquid, and there is a natural time process that can run from six months to five years to work through," he said.
Fidelity ran into a variety of problems, including bad publicity, and wound up with disappointing investments in several struggling companies, including the Harrah's Jazz Company, Merry-Go-Round Enterprises and the El Paso Electric Company. Since leaving Fidelity, Dan Harmetz, who managed three private investment partnerships there, has begun a new venture called DDJ Capital Management, in Wellesley, Mass., to continue doing this type of work. Fidelity Capital and Income, which invested as much as 40 percent in distressed securities under David J. Breazzano, has reduced its stake to about 5 percent, said its new manager, David L. Glancy.
Prudential acknowledges that its new fund may have to take an unusually active role in the affairs of companies. "This may subject the fund to litigation risks or prevent the fund from disposing of securities," the prospectus states.
But Charles Perkins, a spokesman for Prudential funds, said the company would try to sidestep potential problems by avoiding large, controlling positions and by declining to sit on reorganization committees. "We want to remain free to buy and sell securities without restrictions," he said.
Companies in bankruptcies make up only a third of the fund's investment universe, he said. The remaining investments will be in companies in turnaround situations and companies coming out of bankruptcy.
Staying away from an activist position could backfire, said some of the players in this close-knit market. "I think it's a tough area if you're not prepared to be an activist," Mr. Whitman said.
Prudential conceded as much in its prospectus: "Because other investors may buy securities in order to exercise control or management, the fund may be at a disadvantage."
For investors who want to get a taste of the vulture's life, the minimum investment in the Prudential fund is $10,000. If the fund reaches its goal of $50 million under management, annual expenses are expected to run 1.5 percent to 2.25 percent of assets. The maximum sales charge is 5 percent.
Or if you want a fund with an established record, Third Avenue Value and the Mutual Series of funds offer limited exposure. And for any individual, distressed securities are best kept a small part of the portfolio.

HEADLINE: AT THE SHORE;
Assembling a Season Piece by Piece, From Cape May On Up

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
Lawn chairs are being dusted off. Grills are coming out of storage. Beach badges are being bought. Even though you may not have believed that it would ever get here, another summer season at the Jersey Shore begins on Memorial Day. While students are scrambling for summer jobs and their parents are thinking about vacations on the beach, beachfront towns and merchants are bracing for the onslaught of visitors. Here is a sampling of how the season is shaping up.
 
EARNING: WHERE THE JOBS ARE
In some communities, the season starts with a job fair. In Wildwood, for instance, the city and the public schools are sponsoring their first job fair ever at Wildwood High School next Saturday; job seekers can talk to representatives of the local water park, the amusement piers and the Boardwalk Association, not to mention the municipal government and the Junior Lifeguards Association.
If the local job fair has already come and gone, job listings can be found at offices of the State Employment Service in Wildwood, Toms River, Atlantic City and Ocean City. And the State Department of Labor reports 13,200 openings in the federally subsidized Summer Youth Employment Program, down from 15,000 last summer.
If all else fails, the best bet is to select an area and then "start pounding the pavement," said Jeffrey Watson, manager of the Mad Batter, a popular Cape May restaurant that increases its staff from about 20 to 75 in season. The restaurant never advertises for help but still gets 500 applicants a year. Most of the jobs are filled, he went on, but there is always some turnover, and a few jobs open up when the truly busy season starts at the end of June.
The Lobster House, in Lower Township on the border of Cape May, more than doubles its staff, to nearly 500, says the owner, Keith Laudeman, adding that he also hires dock workers to help market the fish from private boats that dock at Cape May.
Up the shore in Seaside Heights, employers -- 75 to 100 boardwalk businesses, plus the borough -- hire 2,000 to 3,000 young people as waitresses, waiters, arcade attendants, clerks, maintenance workers and lifeguards. Michael Redpath, the borough's director of public affairs, says this year could top the record-setting summer of 1995, depending on weather and water quality.
Municipalities, counties and Island Beach State Park all hire lifeguards, who must pass physical and swimming tests and be able to earn a Red Cross lifesaving certificate.
Getting a job may be easier than finding a place to live for three months. In Wildwood, summer housing for seasonal employees is relatively plentiful; in Seaside Heights, many employers provide housing for their workers, or groups of young people join to rent a house at $4,000 to $8,500 for the season; but in other places, apartments for summer help are scarce.
"It's always been rough," said Connie Kosten, director of the Welcome Center in Cape May. "The price is going to be steep. They have to gang up or get places on the outskirts of the city."
 
RENTING: GET IN LINE
If you don't have a place lined up, you may be out of luck. At Schlosser Real Estate in Lavallette, for instance, only about 10 percent of the rental properties are still available. (For future reference, the time to look is in January and February, with Presidents' Day weekend the peak hunting time.)
A three-bedroom house on the beach in Lavallette goes for $1,500 to $3,100 a week, while an equivalent house a few blocks from the beach might cost $850 a week. The market was good last year and even better this year, said Trudy Slowineski, an agent with Schlosser, perhaps because the economy is still slow and people are not taking longer trips. Carolee Wolfkamp, an agent with Lackey Realty in Ship Bottom, agreed, noting that the recent trend to cleaner water and beaches had drawn more renters to the shore.
 
PUMPING: BIGGER BEACHES
The Army Corps of Engineers' $1.7 billion beach-restoration project has been criticized by environmentalists, who say nature will only wash away the sand the corps pumps there. But it is welcome in towns like Monmouth Beach (two miles of beach) and Sea Bright (3.4 miles), where the first phase of restoration was completed late last year and held up well during the winter storms.
Bids for the next section of work on the beach, in Long Branch, are to be submitted this summer, with work to begin in August or September. Next on the schedule are Deal and Asbury Park. Other potential beach restoration projects in Ocean County are being studied, but financing depends on whether Congress restores money that President Clinton did not include in his 1997 budget.
 
SELLING: USE YOUR NOODLE
These days, Linda Costa, owner of the House of Naomi on Ocean Avenue in Belmar, is busy unpacking beach chairs for sale. During the winter, Ms. Costa, who is about to begin her 17th year as a beachfront merchant, mainly sells lottery tickets and newspapers to a small contingent of year-round residents. But from Memorial Day to Labor Day, her small store opens at 8 every morning and stays open as late as 2 A.M. on weekends, selling everything from shorts to swimsuits to sunglasses to suntan oil.
This year's hot new item, she hopes, is the Noodle, a long, colorful plastic-foam cylinder that can be wrapped around the waist to keep the swimmer afloat ($3.95).
Grueling as the hours can be, Ms. Costa still looks forward to the summer season. "I look at it as the best of both worlds," she said. "I have my quiet time and then I have a few months of lots of people having fun."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDWOOD;
Thanking a College a Million

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
For a fee of $35 per semester, Donald Kramer earned a diploma from Brooklyn College. The year was 1958, and a degree in economics was his ticket from Bensonhurst to the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
Gone are the days when students like Mr. Kramer, now the chief executive of a Bermuda-based insurance company, or the lawyer Alan Dershowitz or the writer Gloria Naylor enjoyed a virtually free education at Brooklyn College. Today, squeezed by state budget cuts, the 15,000 students at the college, part of the City University system, pay tuition of more than $1,600 a semester, compared with $1,225 last year. Faculty and staff levels have fallen by more than a third over the last 10 years, and enrollment is dropping. 
 So it was no surprise that Mr. Kramer's contribution to his alma mater was greeted with much pomp at a glittering celebration at the Plaza hotel last week. His $1 million gift to the Brooklyn College Foundation -- while a drop in the bucket compared with, say, Harvard University's $8 billion endowment -- is the largest individual gift that Brooklyn College, with an endowment of about $15 million, has ever received.
Public colleges in the city have always sought private contributions to attract coveted professors, for instance, or endow scholarship funds. But with the fiscal pinch over the last several years, Brooklyn College has had to turn to private dollars to support basic instruction, said Vernon Lattin, the college's president. "I think we got into fund raising late, as many public institutions have," he said. "We are just now, I hope, turning the corner."
Brooklyn College is not alone. "Public institutions all over the country, for a variety of reasons, are going after private money with increasing intensity year by year," said Eric Wentworth, a spokesman for the Council for Advancement and Support of Education, a national group that monitors trends in higher education.
But among the problems that smaller colleges encounter in fund raising, Mr. Wentworth said, is that lists of alumni, often a valuable donor pool, are not as well maintained as they are at larger universities. That problem was intensified at Brooklyn College when Senator Joseph McCarthy targeted it in the 1950's as a haven for radicals, leading administrators to destroy alumni lists to protect their graduates, said Mr. Kramer, who is a trustee of the college.
Mr. Kramer, 58, sees his gift as a payback of sorts: "I owe just about everything that I am now to the fact that I went to Brooklyn College. The public school system that I grew up in worked. We really got a great education and I hate to see it thrown away or compromised or reduced by neglect on the part of our legislators." SOMINI SENGUPTA
