HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The Spice Route's New York Extension

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
IN 1964, G.L. Soni was an engineering graduate student, newly arrived in Fargo, N.D., from southern India's Kerala state and shocked to find two feet of snow on the ground and no tandoori anywhere on the horizon. It would be years before the Beatles embraced Ravi Shankar, and mainstream America was clueless when it came to Indian cuisine. "Nobody even knew about yogurt," Mr. Soni recalls.
And like most Indian men, he was clueless himself. Meals had always just appeared before him, cooked unseen by female or servant hands. "I never knew a coriander from a cumin seed," he says. "I didn't know a spice from a lentil." 
 Somehow, he and a couple of fellow expatriates mastered ingredients sold in Fargo stores, like yellow split peas, well enough to survive till graduation. A civil engineering job brought Mr. Soni to New York, but it was his continuing hunger for the taste of home that drove him to create House of Spices, one of the city's first stores devoted to Indian food products, with his wife and brother in 1970.
Demographic and cultural revolutions have propelled the store into success, so much so that it was hailed in a recent New York University study as a prime example of how immigrant businesses can help revive the city's manufacturing sector. But the same growth has also encouraged competition, and Mr. Soni says he is fighting to keep his position at the top of a virtual pinnacle of seasonings and comestibles.
"This market is going to go through a tremendous change in the next two to three years," Mr. Soni said. "Some people are going to have to quit. We are going to have to cut some of these things that we do."
What they do is plenty. The business rode the early waves of Indian, Pakistani and Bangladeshi immigration, burgeoning from a single store into an empire of importing, exporting, manufacturing, retail shops, restaurants, warehouses and a distribution network that stretches from New York to Los Angeles.
From fresh mangoes to dried fenugreek, powdered coriander to packaged tamarind, the company either has it or can get it. (Its unofficial motto is "If we don't have a product, you don't need it.") The latest marketing target is the non-immigrant American consumer.
Mr. Soni refused to divulge precise figures for the privately-held company, where he is president, his wife, Sobhana, is secretary, and his brother Kumar is vice president, but allowed that its operations exceed $10 million a year. The Soni family lives in Douglaston, the Park Avenue of Queens, and the 55-year-old Mr. Soni drives a Jaguar, although he says he otherwise has simple habits -- like lounging in front of the Discovery Channel to relax.
Headquarters for the Sonis' company is a sprawling warehouse at 127-40 Willets Point Boulevard in the Flushing section, perched at the edge of a strange land of automobile parts and repair places, a kind of casbah junkyard covered with shattered glass where the dealers and their signs bespeak the borough polyglot -- Spanish, Dari, Tagalog, Korean -- in the shadow of Shea Stadium.
Inside the House of Spices, however, all is cool and orderly. There are pallets piled high with cartons of chickpea flour bound for Houston, and 68-pound boxes of American butter, soon to be transmuted into ghee. There are sacks of the bestselling basmati rice, 817 Elephant, which, like wine, must be properly aged, Mr. Soni insists, and blue barrels of pickled vegetables, awaiting the final secret touches that induce brand loyalty. A thick aroma of spices canopies the air, and imports from India, like the muslin-wrapped, bell-shaped cakes of brown sugar known as jaggery, add to the exotic feel of the place.
Workers clean, mill and package everything from white flour to black lentils. There is a factory where Indian women, their hair tucked inside shower-style caps, churn out Joy brand ice cream in flavors like saffron, rose, banana and fig, and a frying division that turns out snack foods. Last year, the company added a candy kitchen, where more women mix and mold delicacies from condensed milk, cashews and edible sheets of silver.
It's hardly the same field the Sonis entered. "The whole scene has changed completely since 1970," says Madhulika Kandelwal, a historian at Queens College's Asian American Center. With more than 100,000 officially recorded Indians in the city, compared with a few thousand then, many people are electing to go into the food business to supply a distinct ethnic market with a very intense demand.
One major rival is Patel Brothers, another mammoth that started in Chicago in 1974 and landed in New York 10 years later. "We have the lowest prices always," said Harshad Patel, one of the owners. "Their quality is good, and they are expensive."
The American overlay on Indian culture has also shaped the market. Mr. Soni's experience -- perhaps horror -- in discovering just how complicated and labor-intensive Indian cooking can be has created something he says would not sell in the subcontinent: packaged and prepared food, aimed at the busy two-career couples who prevail here.
Take the three-pound plastic jug of Laxmi brand fried onions. "If you don't want to stand there at the stove and brown onions for fifteen minutes, you can use this," Mr. Soni said, adding that browned onions are the base for many curries. "In India, no one uses this. The ladies are home, or if you are wealthy, you have servants. Here most of the women are working. Everyone is too busy making the mortgage payments, the car payments. So that is why we made the prepared foods. You open up a bottle, and everything is prepared."
Mrs. Soni, an accountant's daughter who grew up in Mombasa, Kenya, long a spice portal, remembers women thanking her for such products. With three children to raise and the business to run, she came to rely on them, too.
The prepared foods range from spicy carrots to sweet chutneys and saltytandoori paste. There are ready-made papadom wafers and flat disks of nan bread. The latest twist is Indian meals for the freezer section: microwaveable dishes like palak paneer (cheese cubes in spinach sauce) and beef vindaloo.
Many of the company's foods appear under the Laxmi label, named for the Hindu goddess of wealth. They also market under the names House of Spices, Joy and Shamiana. For a while, the company profited from Chinese, Iranian and other cross-cultural demands for products like rice, star anise and cinnamon.
Now it has another set of consumers in mind. For at the same time the Indian population has grown, so has American interest in Indian food. "The growth is in the main American market, and that is where we are poised," Mr. Soni said. "We are in supermarkets now, like Key Food, A & P, Pathmark, Shoprite and Western Beef."
He still seems a little surprised by all this, considering those early days in Fargo. "We wanted to get a degree, make some money and go back home," Mr. Soni says. "We didn't come here to do business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: G. L. Soni, at his Queens warehouse. Twenty-six years ago, hunger for the taste of home led him into the Indian spice business. Perfect timing. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Shelf Life: BEST SELLERS"
Here are the five top sellers in the House of Spices realm. All prices are retail.

1. Laxmi brand chapathi flour, $7.29 for a 22-pound bag. "It is the exact duplicate of the kind of wheat flour Indians are used to back home," Mr. Soni says. "It is white flour, unbleached, made from durum wheat grown in Canada."
 
2. Laxmi brand premium-grade gram flour, made from chickpeas, $3.29 for a 4 1/2-pound bag. "It is used by every Indian, north, south, east, west," Mr. Soni says. "Everybody uses gram flour for sweets and fritters and other things."
 
3. 817 Elephant brand aged basmati rice, imported from India, $36 for a 44-pound sack. "Lots of cultures like it, and it is the top basmati rice in stores now," Mr. Soni says. Only became available in 1989, when India lifted a longtime ban on rice exports.
 
4. Laxmi brand chunda mango chutney, $4.49 for a two-pound jar. "It is freshly made in America," in the warehouse in Queens, Mr. Soni says.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
As Moonlighting Spreads, It Loses Its Blue-Collar Hue

BYLINE: By EVA POMICE 

 BODY:
FOR Liliana Pumpido, no time is free time. From 8:30 A.M. to 2:45 P.M., Ms. Pumpido, a licensed social worker, is at her job with the West New York, N.J., public schools. In the late afternoons and evenings, she counsels private clients in her Weehawken home.
On weekends, she performs as a singer with a karaoke machine at weddings and birthday parties. And she occasionally travels to New York to record jingles for commercials. All told, she expects to earn more than $45,000 this year from her three jobs. 
 "I started karaoke singing after I was separated from my husband," she said. "But I would do it even if I didn't need the money. It takes a lot of stress out of my life. It's like primal scream therapy."
Moonlighters like Ms. Pumpido are becoming more numerous as companies restructure and the job market becomes more fragmented. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, some eight million Americans, or about 6.4 percent of the employed, reported that they worked a second job in 1995, up from 4.7 percent, or 3.9 million people, in 1975.
"Unlike employees laid off in the shutdown of smokestack America in the 1980's, many of today's workers are not waiting for people to give them a new job," said Ken Goldstein, an economist with the Conference Board. "White-collar and pink-collar workers are making their own jobs. They hustle two or three different situations together to approximate the kind of money they used to bring home."
The trend is particularly pronounced for women. They accounted for 46.9 percent of the multiple job-holders in 1995, up from 24.4 percent in 1975 and 38.3 percent in 1985.
John Stinson, an economist with the Bureau of Labor Statistics, says that as more women enter the labor force, "they've taken on the characteristics of men in terms of job-holding."
One difference among the moonlighters: Women who are trying to balance family and work life are much more likely to work multiple part-time jobs, as opposed to men, who often work one full-time and one part-time job.
Decades ago, moonlighting was most common among blue-collar workers. But the data show that the rates are now high among people with primary jobs in public administration and the service industry.
In terms of specific occupations, "doctors, nurses, protective workers like firemen and policemen and teachers all have a higher-than-average rate of moonlighting," Mr. Stinson says. "A lot of policemen work after hours as security guards, and teachers hold second jobs as coaches or camp counselors. It may just be the structure of the work."
College teachers have the highest moonlighting rate, at 13.7 percent.
While some people moonlight to expand their skills or to balance a well-paying but boring job with another that is more creative, many people do it for the money. When surveyed in 1991, the last year the question was asked by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, only 16.3 percent of moonlighters reported doing it because they enjoyed the work. But 37.1 percent of the men who moonlight, 44.2 percent of the women and 63 percent of the divorced, widowed or separated women said they worked multiple jobs to meet regular household expenses and to pay off debt.
"The textbook reason people take second jobs is because they can't work as many hours as they would like to in their main job," says Christina Paxson, an associate professor in economics and public affairs at Princeton University.
Ms. Paxson found that people with multiple jobs tended to take on low-level, easy-to-find work in the service sector, outside their main field. And with the second jobs, their total hours increased dramatically, by 300 hours a year on average.
While the need to moonlight has increased, so have the opportunities.
"Much of the data on moonlighting is interpreted negatively, but you have to look at it positively," says Audrey Freedman, an economist in New York. "People will work for money, and the work is available. We have longer store hours, more personal service work. People can keep their skills up in all kinds of ways that fit their life styles, not just in 9-to-5 steady jobs, five days a week."
Alan Irgang of Chicago works three jobs in an effort to match the $70,000 he earned as head of human resource systems for a hospital before he decided to change careers. He now works 24 hours a week as a therapist for Columbus Hospital in Chicago, an additional 10 hours at a community group practice and 15 hours as a self-employed computer consultant.
"While money is a big part of it, the biggest advantage for me is the variety," he said. "Therapy is very gray; there are no easy solutions. Computers are very logical. I like operating on both sides of the fence."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Heads You Win, Heads You Lose
 
In an election year, of course, economic news has one overriding role: helping or hurting one candidate or the other. The millions of lives touched by the economy are distant, secondary -- a trifle. But how does this horse-race mentality work in Wall Street's upside-down world, where good news is, by definition, bad because it stirs up demon inflation? Take last week. Great news! The economy, after grumbling to a halt late last year, roared back in the first quarter, growing at a 2.8 percent annual rate. That surely helps the "It's the economy, stupid" President, right? But wait. That "good" news sent stocks reeling -- the Dow industrials plunged 77 points. If this bubbling market collapses, you'd have to call that "bad" news -- and it would have to help Bob Dole. You want logic? Play chess.
 
SUBSIDIZED LIVES
Rugged Capitalists
 
Montana's Freemen, those ultimate rugged individualists, would never accept weaselly capitalist handouts like farm subsidies, would they? Actually, yes -- by the bushel. After drought, hail and fickle prices conspired against the debt-laden rancher Ralph Clark, the Agriculture Department opened its wallet to make it all better. Over a decade, a new study shows, Mr. Clark and his partners got $676,082 in checks from a Government he labels a "corporate prostitute." Even in Garfield County (pop.: 1,300), which received $63 million in subsidies from 1985 to 1994, that raises eyebrows. It seems that Mr. Clark -- described by his brother-in-law as a "natural con man" -- turned his farm into a complex subsidy machine, even arranging for some payments to be made to a trust he had set up to avoid taxes.
 
WHAT'S UP?
 
Cheap Gas? Sound the Alarm!
In 1980, gasoline cost (in 1995 dollars) $2.20 a gallon; last week it cost a little over half that. Clearly, such a crisis demands the full attention of our best and brightest politicians. Because, you see, those voters who in the late 70's were proudly scrapping their gas-guzzlers have in the 90's discovered rugged sport-utility bliss -- and, having bought these New Age guzzlers, have to keep feeding them. So last week, fearing a horde of off-roaders voting with their gas tanks, Bob Dole and Bill Clinton fell all over each other to try to ease their pain. First Mr. Clinton said he'd sell 12 million barrels of oil from the strategic reserve, and Republicans, calling the sale "shameless pandering," quickly vowed relief from a Clinton gas tax. One can only imagine the histrionics if, say, gas cost what it did in 1980.
 
UNABOMBER QUICKIES
 
Fastest Book in the West
Imagine Flaubert writing a book on the Unabomber suspect. He scratches about for agonizing hours for "le mot juste," even as his editors clamor for 50 pages a day. A sorry sight. Now, in one corner of today's publishing world, words aren't pondered, they're processed, like so many widgets or chicken wings. Theodore Kaczynski had barely been led away from his Montana shack when "quickie" publishers were distributing book covers, the words to be crammed in later. The fastest crammer? Warner Books, which last week shipped the first copies of "Mad Genius." It edged out Pocket Books, which has been churning out quickies ever since publishing a book on Franklin D. Roosevelt six days after he died. To be fair, the co-author of Pocket's Unabomber quickie was an ex-F.B.I. agent, so the book got mired in a bureaucratic review. Farewell, haste.
 
NEWSPAPERS
Read All About It!
 
Yes, the nation keeps putting down its newspapers to get its information elsewhere -- on line, over the air, surgically implanted in the brain, wherever. And it doesn't help that the population is aging and newspaper prices are up. But the glass is half full, too: last week came word that circulation at the top dailies is falling a bit more slowly, and there were even gains at The Wall Street Journal, USA Today and The Daily News. Maybe, just maybe, Americans haven't forgotten how to read after all.
 
TOBACCO WARS
Smoke-Free Billboards
 
Free speech. It has a pure, simple ring to it, but it's really a minefield. Bob Grant got a new radio job, and his fans rejoiced at freedom regained -- but the point was never his freedom to speak, it was his employer's freedom not to pay him to do it. And tobacco companies insist it's free speech to advertise on billboards -- even though smoking foes say such ads lure children to light up. But last week 3M Media, the nation's No. 3 billboard company, exercised a freedom of its own -- it said it would stop advertising tobacco products. To be sure, 3M, with over 1,000 billboards in 36 states, acted under pressure from a religious group. But President Clinton applauded the move, saying children were "barraged by messages that glamour and grit can be found in a pack of cigarettes." R.J. Reynolds, saying it was disappointed, raised the free-speech banner, while Philip Morris voiced a familiar industry refrain: that cigarette ads are aimed at "helping adults to make choices."
 
LAWSUITS
Do Gun Makers Kill?
 
Guns don't kill people, people do -- that's the gun lobby's mantra. But is there a third possible culprit -- gun makers? They've been sued successfully for selling defective weapons or selling to illegal buyers. But now a Federal judge has ruled that, for the first time, gun makers can be sued purely for their marketing. A lawyer for the families of two shooting victims said she wanted to prove the industry was "aware of a booming illegal market for guns but did not take adequate steps to prevent illegal sales" -- an assertion the gun makers deny.
 
HEALTH CARE
A.A.R.P., Super-Agent
 
One might logically assume that the American Association of Retired Persons is a selfless advocate for the elderly. But in a very real sense it is also a giant insurance broker. In 1994, it received $146 million in royalties and other fees for endorsing certain auto and homeowner policies -- fully 38 percent of its budget. But what of health care? H.M.O.'s, after all, at times limit or even refuse care -- not something a champion of the elderly would want to condone. But now the A.A.R.P. -- no doubt realizing that if it can't fight the prevailing winds in health care, it had better go along -- will license its weighty name to some managed-care plans. It would, it vowed, constantly monitor the H.M.O.'s it picks -- and it will certainly be in its interest to do so, for it's putting its mighty national brand name on the line. This is "high-risk stuff," said one health researcher.
 
WORKPLACE GRIPES
Stale M&M's? An Outrage!
 
Downsizing. Takeovers. Gloom. Do such thoughts really preoccupy America's workers? Perhaps, but they've also got some far-humbler concerns, says Bloomberg Business News, which last week offered its first "Sound Off" poll. A sampling: do workers pine for the simple pleasure of opening a window? Yes, 21 percent do. Also, 26 percent complain of dirty offices, 43 percent rebel at the idea of giving up frequent-flier miles, 40 percent chafe at having to be politically correct, but just 6 percent mind offices being smoke-free. But to get to a truly pressing matter: 13 percent have had it with stale M&M's in vending machines.

HEADLINE: Tobacco on Trial;
Making a Case for Death

BYLINE: LAURA MANSNERUS 

 BODY:
SO far, it's Taxpayers v. Merchants of Death. Eight states have sued tobacco companies, and more are getting in line, with a new legal theory: since the states incur Medicaid expenses for smoking-related illness, they should be reimbursed by the industry that causes it.
There's a snag, though. The states are probably not losing all the money they are asking for. The inconvenient truth, at least as many economists see it, is that smokers cover their own medical costs, not only by paying cigarette taxes -- now more than 50 cents a pack -- but also by dying before collecting their full share of health and retirement benefits. 
 The tobacco companies aren't sure how to cast what is often called "the death benefit argument," or if they should even raise it. And it may be rejected by judges. But the litigation raises questions for a society obsessed with toting up misery in dollars: How do we calculate what smokers cost everybody else? Should we acknowledge that sometimes death is helpful to the public treasury? And if that's so, where might such an argument end?
"Killing yourself by smoking incurs costs, which for yourself are horrendous and miserable, and for everyone else include higher insurance costs," said Peter W. Huber, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, who has written on product liability. "But there are offsets. It's quite possible that smokers are doing us all a small favor. It's a ghoulish argument -- it's horrible -- but if you're going to have an economic case, you've got to use economics. You can't use sentiment."
Last week Maryland became the latest state to file suit, following Mississippi, Florida, Minnesota, West Virginia, Massachusetts, Texas and Louisiana; more states, including New Jersey and Connecticut, are preparing suits. The states are suing not on behalf of smokers who became ill -- a claim that has been a loser in court -- but for their own expenses. So they must establish that losses have occurred, and then, if they win, establish the amounts due them.
The tobacco companies want an accounting of offsets, which means estimating what the states would have spent treating smokers, had they lived longer.
 
 
 
Economists at Work
 Economists have already done a larger accounting, testing assertions that smoking imposes a big economic burden on society. Their answer, usually, is that it doesn't. A widely cited study conducted for the Rand Corporation by Willard Manning, a health economist at the University of Minnesota, found that smokers had more medical expenses than nonsmokers and died about four years earlier; after they paid cigarette taxes, society came out ahead -- in dollars, anyway.
In a 1994 study based in part on the Manning data, W. Kip Viscusi, a Duke University economist, found that smokers subsidize nonsmokers even without taxes. He put the medical costs attributable to smoking at 55 cents a pack sold, and added much smaller amounts for sick leave, higher insurance premiums and damage from fires caused by cigarettes. Smokers' early deaths cost the public another 40 cents a pack in forgone taxes on earnings. Later, Mr. Viscusi figured health and insurance costs attributable to secondhand smoke, cautioning that his estimate of 25 cents a pack was drawn from highly uncertain data. At the same time, smokers saved taxpayers nursing-home care (23 cents a pack) and pension and Social Security costs ($1.19). The net gain to society: 5 cents for every pack sold. Smokers also contributed 53 cents a pack in excise taxes, 29 cents of that going to the states.
The big savings come from retirement benefits, especially since smoking-related disease usually kicks in as one's working years end. Mr. Viscusi calculates total yearly pension savings nearing $30 billion -- most of which is realized not by the states but by private pension plans and the Social Security system. (Since about 30 percent of Medicare dollars go to nursing home care, the states save money there.) And if no one smoked? "Social Security would go bankrupt," he said. "We'd all have to work to age 80."
The Manning and Viscusi studies have their critics, including the plaintiffs. They prefer the estimates of smoking-related medical costs issued by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which are several times higher than the Manning-Viscusi estimates. Still other research has found that smokers have lower lifetime medical costs than nonsmokers.
The whole discussion disturbs many people. Jeffrey Harris, an economist at M.I.T. who believes most economists underestimate smokers' medical costs, said the real danger is to suggest that government weigh the savings from early deaths in making public policy decisions. Dr. Harris, who is also a physician, said an analysis like Mr. Viscusi's "is not including a key benefit to our society: We value life."
The plaintiffs lawyers working for the states say tobacco companies are exactly the last people who should share in any death benefit. P. Tim Howard, retained by Florida's Attorney General, said: "I don't know that a court is going to say, 'Wow, you need an offset because you killed people.' "
To economists, though, the states' claims of losses fail to make sense without offsets. As Jane Gravelle and Dennis Zimmerman, economists at the Congressional Research Service, wrote in a Washington Post op-ed article: "The alternative to death from a smoking-related illness is not immortality and perfect health -- it is later death, and perhaps from a more costly illness."
 
 
 
Addicted to Taxes
 So far, the defendants are not pushing the argument. "We didn't create this analysis, and we didn't go to court to assert it," said Murray R. Garnick, a Washington lawyer representing Philip Morris in several states, including Mississippi, where the issue has come up in court. There, Mr. Garnick explained, the state had asked the court to prohibit requests by the tobacco companies for documents relating to the state's net Medicaid expenditures for smokers.
The states also want to exclude income from excise taxes, which Mr. Huber of the Manhattan Institute says points up "the biggest paradox of all."
"If the state thought it was being injured by tobacco, it could have banned tobacco," he said. "The state can prohibit four-wheel vehicles, hang-gliding, all sorts of things." But, he continued, "you might say the state is addicted to tobacco revenues."
Legal scholars are loath to see the courts used as arbiters in such tortured political and economic debates. "To leave it to the fantastically uncertain and chaotic process of litigation is a very, very bad way to make public policy," said Jeffrey O'Connell, a law professor at the University of Virginia.
But lawsuits make sense as a means of forcing a better solution, says Mr. O'Connell, who favors workers compensation-like legislation protecting the tobacco companies from liability suits in return for payments into a fund for victims. "So maybe we can use the threat of litigation to accomplish something like this," he said, "instead of having these voraciously competitive people pummel each other, and us in the process."

LENGTH: 1332 words

HEADLINE: The Public Housing That Succeeds

BYLINE: By Nicholas Lemann; Nicholas Lemann is the national correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly.

DATELINE: PELHAM, N.Y.

 BODY:
One of the endearing things about Senator Bob Dole is that he is so quintessentially the consensus-oriented legislator that his forays into the realm of wedge issues always have a tinny, false feeling, as if he isn't emotionally connected to the words coming out of his own mouth. His statement last week that American public housing "is one of the last bastions of socialism in the world" is a good example. It's hard to believe that Mr. Dole was candidly revealing his most deeply held views.
Still, the idea that public housing has failed and should be abolished is something many Americans believe. High-rise public housing projects such as the notoriously dangerous and bleak Robert Taylor Homes in Chicago are the leading visual symbol of the idea that liberal Government programs, especially antipoverty programs, don't work and may actually cause poverty to increase. 
 If public housing were in fact a bankrupt and doomed idea, it would be a very sad end to the oldest and most visible strategy in the struggle against poverty. Jacob Riis's "How the Other Half Lives," published in 1890 and arguably the first American book to propose a plan for improving conditions in urban slums, ended with a call for the construction of "model tenements." If Mr. Dole is right, the whole antipoverty cause would be powerfully undermined.
The truth, however, is that housing for the poor stands out among antipoverty strategies as the area where the most progress has been made over the past generation and where there is the most cause for optimism. Senator Dole's comments were so completely wrong that they could help bring a halt to genuine progress rather than pull the plug on something unworkable.
Before the World War II, public housing in America was considered a great success. It "worked" in the sense of being clean, safe and, for most residents, a huge improvement over the slums where they had been living. There were long waiting lists for apartments.
One reason for the projects' good reputation was that their constituency was not the very poor but people with jobs one notch higher on the economic ladder. (Probably the most famous product of the public housing of that era is Elvis Presley.) Most projects wouldn't admit single parents, and many wouldn't admit welfare recipients. Virtually all maintained strict rules about keeping apartments and hallways neat and about who was allowed to be where when. Those who broke the rules or committed crimes were swiftly kicked out.
Then in the late 1940's, the nation embarked on the course that led to the perception that public housing doesn't work: the construction of enormous high-rise projects. It wasn't just the architecture, or the mere presence of Government subsidies, that caused these places to go so horribly awry. There was also a big change in the tenant population, from carefully screened working people to the very poor. Because of changes in Federal rules, people who got jobs actually had to leave the building, and it became nearly impossible to kick out tenants who were criminals.
Even so, it's not all public housing that doesn't work. It's just the large-scale, all-poor, severely isolated projects that invariably fail. Just a few blocks from the Robert Taylor Homes are pleasant high-rise projects for senior citizens.
"Imagine, the United States Government owns the housing where an entire class of citizens permanently lives," Mr. Dole said, as if this were fantastically improbable. Yet in most industrial countries a much larger portion of the population lives in Government housing. Three percent of Americans live in public housing, as opposed to more than a fifth of the population in Great Britain, Germany, France and the Netherlands. What's unusual about American public housing is that it serves primarily the very poor.
It is paradoxical that Mr. Dole chose to stage his attack on public housing at a realtors' convention, because the real estate industry, by and large, supported the construction of the worst projects. In the 1950's and 60's, African-American migrants from the South were streaming into the big cities, and part of reason for the building of the projects was to contain them within the existing ghettos so as to avoid residential integration.
In any case, the mistake of the high-rise, all-poor projects was fairly quickly realized; in 1968, Congress banned the construction of any more of them. These projects have no defenders except for unaccountably loyal groups of residents. To set high-rise projects up as being the fruits of a real political position, as some critics of public housing have, is to create a straw man.
Under Secretary Henry Cisneros, the Department of Housing and Urban Development has begun demolishing about 30,000 of the worst high-rises. The agency is also trying to reinstate policies of giving preferences to people with jobs and swiftly kicking out criminals.
In his speech to the realtors, Senator Dole called for replacing public housing with a voucher system. But we already have a voucher system, called Section 8, which is perpetually underfinanced (partly because the real estate industry is so effective in lobbying against its expansion) and thus has very long waiting lists. Mr. Dole has repeatedly voted against increasing financing for the program, and he failed to support Mr. Cisneros's proposal last year for a major new housing voucher program.
There is an alternative to old-style public housing. In the decades since we stopped building new projects, hundreds of thousands of units for the poor have been created by local community development corporations, private groups that have sprung up around the country since the 70's. On the whole, this is housing that works. Those who haven't visited the South Bronx lately would be amazed to see how vastly areas thought of as desolate have been improved by the new and renovated housing that community groups have put up.
These groups do exactly what Mr. Cisneros is trying to do in public housing: Screen tenants, create a mix of working and very poor people, oust criminals, maintain security forces big enough for residents to feel safe and keep the overall scale of developments manageably small. It's not an exotic, recondite, high-risk formula.
 Often people point to the success of the community development corporations as proving that the private sector can succeed where the Government has failed. The implication is that any involvement by the Government is fatally corrupting. But the community groups are heavily financed by the Government. More than three-quarters receive Federal dollars (Washington gives them more than $300 million each year) and more than half receive state money. The experiments in tenant management pushed strongly by Jack Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development under President George Bush, were also federally financed.
It should be kept in mind, too, that the disastrous large-scale urban public housing projects were constructed and operated not by Washington but by local housing authorities. In recent years, HUD has begun taking over the management of projects from the most incompetent of the local authorities.
The view that Federal is always bad and state and local are always good just doesn't apply in public housing. The Federal Government pays for virtually all public housing and contracts with local organizations to run it. The key variables are whether the project's rules are sound and whether the local group in charge is competent.
The conditions in the worst public housing projects are horrifyingly bad and constitute a real moral crisis. It is outrageous that week after week children continue to lose their lives to the violence of the projects and we don't do anything about it. It doesn't do public housing residents who live in fear and misery any good to be told that what they're going through is attributable to "socialism" and therefore can't be helped.

HEADLINE: Don't Limit Welfare Without Job Investment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As co-conveners of a coalition of African-American, Asian-American, Hispanic, Protestant, Roman Catholic, Muslim and Jewish leaders, we applaud Bob Herbert's objections to proposals in the New York State Legislature to set time limits on welfare benefits (column, April 26).
Time limits are intended as a way to move people off welfare and into the work force. But where are the jobs? Since 1990 New York City has lost more than 300,000 jobs. Moreover, the Labor Department says 75 percent of the city's major employers require skills for entry-level positions beyond those afforded by a high school education. Compounding these difficulties is the unavailability of affordable, high-quality child care. 
 The Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki should take the steps needed to help individuals and families move into the mainstream of economic life by investing in programs and supports that make self-sufficiency possible.
 
NORMAN H. STEIN
DENNIS M. WALCOTT
New York, May 1, 1996
 
The writers are, respectively, New York chapter president, American Jewish Committee, and president of the New York Urban League.

HEADLINE: Cities Enlisting Private Companies for Sewage Treatment

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
Garbage pickup was one of the first to go, along with paper recycling, jail operations and, in a few cases, firefighting. Now, in the latest nationwide move toward privatizing public services, scores of municipalities are starting to turn over waste-water-treatment plants to private contractors.
Wilmington, Delaware's largest city, is about to sign a 20-year lease with Wheelabrator Technologies. And a string of cities -- Jersey City; Hoboken, N.J.; Toledo, Ohio; Freeport, Tex., and others -- have indicated an interest in turning over some or all of their water operations to private companies. 
 In Wilmington, as in other towns and cities that are opting out of the waste-water-treatment business, the potential benefits are economic: faced with pinched budgets and increasingly stiff environmental regulations governing water quality, local policy makers are looking to the private sector for operating expertise and capital to invest in aging treatment plants.
But the course is politically risky, fraught with the loss of jobs and employee benefits -- which is why most towns and cities are leasing rather than selling their operations and are trying to insure that job reduction comes through attrition rather than dismissal.
Acknowledging the potential problems, Mayor James H. Sills Jr. of Wilmington said, "It is clear that costs will go down, and that is a story that most people can understand and accept."
Indeed, although privatization will mean the loss of 12 jobs through attrition, there has been little public comment on the shift, which has been under discussion for 18 months, Mr. Sills said. "The public does not have the same emotional attraction to waste-water plants that it does to garbage pickup, public works and safety," he said.
Water and sewer services, according to the United States Conference of Mayors, are the single largest expenditure local governments face, totaling $43.5 billion a year nationally.
And the costs are likely to increase as treatment plants built or improved 20 or more years ago with $53 billion in Federal grants are rendered obsolete in the face of more stringent water pollution rules.
The Environmental Protection Agency has estimated that at least $100 billion will be needed to meet the new standards in the next decade, but Congress has greatly scaled back the grants available. Some $1.35 billion will be available to the states in 1997, not nearly enough to complete improvements to the 6,000 waste-water-treatment plants around the nation.
And the plants must be revamped, E.P.A. officials said. "E.P.A. has been supportive of privatization," said Michael J. Quigley, director of the municipal support division of the agency's water office, "but we enforce the regulations regardless of whether the plants are publicly owned or privately managed."
Mayor Patrick J. McManus of Lynn, Mass., a spokesman for a mayoral group on the privatization issue, noted: "Clean water and clean harbors are mandated; they must be done. The question is how to pay for it. In Lynn, we have service contracts to operate our water and sewage plants now, and we are looking into the advantages of a long-term lease."
As they consider turning waste-water treatment over to the private sector, many cities are looking at the handling of solid waste as a model. During the 1980's, many cities and towns hired companies to build waste-to-energy plants to burn municipal garbage as old-fashioned dumps that did not meet environmental standards were closed. Waste-to-energy plants, most of them privately owned, now generate $20 billion in business each year.
Although a handful of city water plants have been operated by contractors for years, the current surge of interest in privatization was helped along by the success of Indianapolis, which in 1994 turned over its two waste-water plants to a private group led by the big French utility Lyonnaise des Eaux. In the first year of operation, the company slashed a proposed budget of $30.1 million to $17.6 million, with further savings forecast for later years. Over the five-year term of the contract, the city expects to save $65 million.
Private contractors reduce expenses through typical corporate strategies: shrinking the work force, subcontracting nonessential services like plant security, and cutting inventories. The Indianapolis contractor reduced the work force to 176 from 328, through retirements and job placement, while improving the plants' compliance with environmental regulations, a report issued by the city last year said.
The small city of Franklin, Ohio, located between Dayton and Cincinnati, went even further last year, selling its waste-water-treatment plant to Wheelabrator Technologies for $6.8 million. Franklin, with a population of 12,500, is using the money to expand its drinking-water plant to meet the needs of new industries and housing developments.
"There are four major benefits of privatization," said John T. Dowd, a senior vice president of Wheelabrator, a subsidiary of the nation's largest trash hauler, Waste Management. "It is an opportunity to turn a fixed asset into cash. There can be significant savings on an operating basis, and it often solves an environmental problem, like odors. The fourth is that it can encourage economic development. Companies like knowing that their rates will be fixed for 20 years."
But the path to privatization is not always smooth. In March, a judge blocked Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani's plan to raise $2.3 billion by selling the New York City water and sewer system to the Water Board, a quasi-independent agency controlled by the state. City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, an opponent of the plan, used his powers last year to block the sale of the bonds that would have financed the project.
Wilmington, a city of about 71,500 people, had originally planned to sell its plant to Wheelabrator for $41.9 million, but the deal went awry because of a clash between the city and the adjacent, and larger, New Castle County. That conflict may point to leasing as a more popular privatization option, particularly where more than one political jurisdiction is involved.
The city built the treatment plant within its borders, but city residents account for only about 30 percent of its use.
When it appeared that Wilmington would get a windfall of more than $17.3 million after paying off obligations, county officials objected. They said they feared that the city's bonanza would come at the expense of county residents, who pay the bulk of the sewerage fees.
So the city backed away from an outright sale in favor of a 20-year lease requiring Wheelabrator to invest in the plant to meet new environmental standards and to limit rate increases using a formula based on the Consumer Price Index and an electric-rate index. City and county officials are negotiating an agreement allowing the county to continue using the plant.
Mr. Sills, the Mayor of Wilmington, said the lease would cut the plant's operating costs to $16 million a year from $19 million, while the city would retain the power to set rates. Officials of Wheelabrator, which already operates the plant's sludge-disposal section, said they had identified ways to operate more efficiently, including reducing the number of workers to 43 from 55 through attrition.
Still, many plant workers remain concerned about how their lives will be affected when control passes from the city to the company. "We worry about how our people are going to be treated by a company that is driven by profits," said Perry Davis, a local official of the union that represents the workers.
But Tom Liddle, who already works for Wheelabrator in the sludge-disposal section, said he saw increased opportunity. "I do maintenance in this building right now," Mr. Liddle said, "but if we get the rest, I expect to be in charge of maintenance for the whole plant."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cities around the nation are turning over waste-water treatment plants to businesses in the latest move toward privatization. A Wilmington, Del., plant will be operated by Wheelabrator Technologies under a 20-year lease. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New School Seeks Students Who Are Music to Its Ears

BYLINE: By MARY B.W. TABOR 

 BODY:
In a stark rehearsal studio just steps from Lincoln Center, four adults with clipboards and evaluation forms tested a clump of 5-year-olds, asking them to march, sing and slap their knees. Occasionally, one evaluator stood hawklike over the group, her head tilted to hear a child's barely audible voice.
Outside the room, parents sat holding shoes and toys and anxiously awaiting the verdicts. Those children who did well would be invited back for further testing, and ultimately perhaps be admitted to the Special Music School of America, a new public school, an only-in-New York kind of place in a city known for its "Fame" school, millionaire child actors and musical prodigies. 
 The idea came in part from the vision of the pianist Vladimir Feltsman, who was trained in Soviet-style institutions that identified and harnessed gifted children from tender ages. The new school will start in the fall with 30 children split between kindergarten and first grade, and will add one grade each year. It is the first public school in the nation to offer intensive musical training from kindergarten through 12th grade in the course of the school day. Since January, more than 300 children have auditioned.
On this morning, when the testing ended for Kareema Nunes's group and the children spilled out of the studio, her father, Kenneth, smiled and hugged her. "I've been very nervous," he said. "This could be very important for her career."
Nearby, awaiting a later session, were Teresa Gomez, her 5-year-old son and her daughter, who at 4 already studies singing, piano and xylophone. Both were being tested. "I'm trying to make sure they get the best education possible," she said.
Such are the ambitions of parents. Earlier this year, one mother tried to qualify her second grader for the test by saying he was not so smart and could easily repeat first grade. Another sent in a printed resume of her child's schooling and activities.
Mr. Feltsman has criticized the way American children learn music: lessons after school or on weekends, an approach he sees as hindering the gifted and minimizing the importance of music. In Soviet Russia, he says, young children were guided from the start into special schools where academic work was mixed with intense training in one field of study.
"If you don't get the basics of the discipline between the ages of 7 and 12," said Mr. Feltsman, "you might be as gifted as five Horowitzes but you will never make it. The beginning of a musical education, the very first musical steps, are crucial. You have to suck it in the way a baby sucks in a mother's milk." He spoke in a telephone interview from Germany, where he was touring.
Although critics suggest that such intense musical training can stunt children in other fields, the Soviet-style academy dovetailed neatly with the expectations of parents who drill their 3-year-olds for admission interviews at the more selective nursery schools.
But compared with their ardent tactics, Mr. Feltsman's sound relatively benign. "We will not cage our children and make them practice five hours a day until their fingers bleed," he said. "That's total nonsense and it won't do any good anyway." He began at a special music school at age 6.
At the new school, children can expect private lessons on piano, then another instrument, in addition to their regular schoolwork. They will also be given group lessons in singing and music theory, and be required to give recitals regularly.
The inspiration for the school came from a newspaper column that Mr. Feltsman wrote six years ago, criticizing the nation's casual approach to music education. Lydia Kontos, who runs a West Side cultural center, read the article and decided to act. She and Mr. Feltsman engineered a public-private partnership, with city money paying for the academic program and with private gifts, from the Annenberg Foundation and other sources, paying for the music. The cost per student is estimated at $10,000 to $13,000 a year, Ms. Kontos said. So raising money remains a concern. The school is based, along with her cultural center, on West 67th Street at the Abraham Goodman House, home of the Merkin Concert Hall.
So far, 21 children have been accepted, and 19 of them have enrolled. The other morning, with the remaining 11 spots at stake, 37 children and their jittery parents arrived -- parents wrestling to get coats unzipped and tights up, dresses straight and socks off. Some mothers whispered warnings to whiners. Others hummed in ears, as if to get in one last rehearsal.
In the audition room, Ms. Kontos and Eteri Andjaparidze (pronounced an jah pah REED zeh), a Russian pianist and the school's music director, debated whether to call back the "maybes" for further testing.
"The ability to sing on pitch and clap correctly is not enough," Ms. Andjaparidze said later. "We are looking for those with a certain possession of music, those for whom music is a native language, those for whom music lives a full life in their brains before they ever touch the keyboard."
Finding a diverse pool of talented children, and picking those with potential, not just training, has proved the school's most daunting task. It is based in Community School District 3, a largely black and Hispanic district whose ethnic and economic makeup the school's administrators wanted to reflect. When most early applications came from middle-class white families, Ms. Kontos dispatched scouts to day-care centers and kindergartens in poorer areas, telling the parents of musically inclined children that the school was public and that the academic and music lessons were free.
"We want the criteria for admission to be musical gift," she said, "not ability to pay."
To avoid bias, instead of asking children to audition on an instrument -- a practice common in Europe's music schools -- researchers and music teachers designed a three-part test. The children repeat rhythms and melodies, move to different styles of music and improvise songs and rhythms. They are given paper and asked to illustrate melodies. And they are asked to identify and sing back the various notes in a chord.
On a recent morning, some applicants were able to identify selections from "The Nutcracker." Others fumbled with the words of "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star." Some performed with bravado but couldn't hold their pitch. Others cowered, but copied rhythms easily with claps. And two boys spent most of their time running back and forth to the bathroom.
"We're looking for a set of aptitudes -- those things the child will use as his musical equipment," said Anne Farber, one of the school's music teachers. "But we are also looking for, well, I don't have a word for it, but 'delight' -- that flash in the eyes, that sign that this child and the adult he becomes will find music necessary in his life."
It is the discernment of such "delight" that often leaves the testers debating long after the children have gone.
Could it lie in the child who sang like a little Maria Callas, raising her arm and warbling, "Will you please stand up? Will you please sit down?"
Or in the boy who could not take his eyes -- or hands -- off a nearby xylophone, inching his way toward it again and again?
Or in the little girl, known to be musical, who balked at the door and wouldn't enter?
Ms. Farber, who conducts much of the testing, says there is a moment in its second phase when musical genius sometimes flickers up. She plays the piano and asks the children to close their eyes and paint the music with their hands and arms.
"Every now and then," she said, "you'll see one child tilt his head, because he hears something in the music that speaks to him. Or a facial expression will suddenly change. We've had some quite moving moments."
One of those who moved the testers was a 4-year-old named Arielle. Her mother, Elise Dixon-Harris, said she was grateful Arielle had been accepted. The child loves music, her mother said; she claps through hourlong country music programs and dances to Weather Channel music. But private lessons would have been beyond the budget.
"I just want Arielle to be able to do what she wants to do," Ms. Dixon-Harris said.
But, with practice, practice, practice, she may become a little Leonskaya. "Not all the children will make it to Carnegie Hall," Mr. Feltsman said. "But for the few who have that special gift, we will give them a chance to grow. Isn't it all about giving, anyway?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anne Farber, a teacher, says the school looks for signs of the child's "delight" in music. Children must audition for admission to the Special Music School of America, a new public school inspired by Soviet education. (Photographs by Carrie Boretz for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 950 words

HEADLINE: Community Of Muslims Finds Desert Fertile Land

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: ABIQUIU, N.M.

 BODY:
An hour's drive northwest of Santa Fe, a gravel road breaks away from the blacktop and swings north across the Chama River, into a landscape that seems to bespeak the transcendent. Red rock cliffs rise above the river, hawks wheel overhead and the bone-dry air imparts a special clarity to everything in sight. The artist Georgia O'Keeffe found inspiration here, setting up her easel in a rocky gulch called the "white city."
Farther up the road, the sense of spirituality takes a tangible form. Atop a hill sits a stucco mosque, focal point of a tiny Islamic community that has struggled to take root, and to make itself known nationally. 
 The community, Dar al Islam, wants to encourage a "moderate, tolerant, articulate and very American" brand of the faith, said Hakim Archuletta, an earnest, California-born convert who serves as its spokesman. "I feel that's the emerging Islam," he said.
Next month, for the fourth time in as many years, Dar al Islam will host believers from across the country at a three-day "Muslim Powwow," an event combining communal prayer, shared meals, discussions and hiking. Last year, about 300 people attended.
Later this summer, the community, organized around a nonprofit educational center, plans two, two-week programs for social studies teachers to learn about Islamic history.
Given that Islam was first proclaimed in the desert, by the prophet Muhammad in seventh century Arabia, the faith's appearance in the dusty uplands of northern New Mexico should not seem so strange.
Yet it is striking to find an Islamic community where the surroundings are so closely tied to Roman Catholicism. The wooden door of the mosque opens outward onto a panoramic view of mountain peaks named by Spanish explorers the Sangre de Cristo, or Blood of Christ. Place names like Santa Fe and San Juan testify to the area's dominant faith.
Dar al Islam was begun in 1979 by a handful of Muslim converts who had a vision of a model religious community and a grant from an American-educated Saudi businessman. Pioneering families put up a community building, a 30,000-square-foot space with classrooms, dormitories and ample space to pray. Once, 25 families lived near the site.
But by the late 1980's the project had faltered, in part because of a weak rural economy. Today, only eight families remain.
"We discovered," said Walter 'Abdur Ra'uf Declerk, a tall, Belgian-born covert, "that you cannot engineer a community, like on a conveyer belt you engineer a car."
"It was a disappointment and a relief," said Mr. Declerk, Dar al Islam's director of finance and administration. "It was a relief because for years we had struggled with something that was impossible."
Rather than try to build an autonomous community, the group now focuses largely on the annual gatherings and teachers courses, which have attracted the attention of academic experts. The sale of about three-quarters of the group's original 8,000-acre property has also let it begin building an endowment.
"It's absolutely fascinating what they're doing," said Yvonne Haddad, a professor of Islamic history at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. She spent a week at Dar al Islam in 1994, helping teach the social studies teachers.
The United States is home to 3 million to 4 million Muslims, most of them immigrants, she said. Mosques can be found in cities great and small, but rural communities like the one here are rare.
Dar al Islam is also unusual on two other counts, Professor Haddad said.
Its residents are largely white, while the vast majority of American converts are black. (The latter are mostly Sunni Muslims, belonging to Islam's major branch, not to be confused with the black nationalist sect, the Nation of Islam.)
Moreover, Professor Haddad said, some of Dar al Islam's residents are Sufis, followers of a mystical tradition in Islam that emphasizes direct knowledge of the divine. Most Muslims, she said, "have distanced themselves" from Sufism, considering it too other-worldly.
But Mr. Archuletta said the group hews to the Muslim mainstream. "And in terms of our programs," he said, "it's definitely not Sufi."
Some prominent Muslims are intrigued by the community's work. "I'm watching it very closely, because it's unusual," said Aslam Abdullah, editor of The Minaret, a magazine published in Los Angeles. "They are more spiritually oriented people."
Mr. Archuletta said that a goal of the annual gatherings is to introduce younger Muslims to American-born converts who can be role models, men and women who have distinguished themselves intellectually or professionally. As an example, he described one convert who was a deep-sea fisherman and made himself an expert on a branch of Islamic law.
Mr. Archuletta, 55, grew up in Manhattan Beach, Calif., his mother a Presbyterian and his father a Roman Catholic of Basque heritage. He became a Muslim while studying at the University of California at Berkeley in the 1960's, inspired by another convert, a Scotsman.
In an interview in the Abiquiu Inn, a motel and restaurant that the community owns, Mr. Archuletta lamented negative portrayals of Islam in the media, where the faith is often linked with reports of violence in the Middle East. And he spoke with feeling of wanting to convey to other New Mexicans the power he finds in his faith.
He said he has found signs of interest among some Navajo Indians, whose vast reservation lies a few hours' drive to the west. "I've distributed almost 1,000 Korans to the Navajos," he said, referring to Islam's holy book.
"Islam's revolution is inner revolution," Mr. Archuletta said. "It's light, it's knowledge. It's not overthrowing governments."

HEADLINE: Rebuilding Bosnia Cannot Wait

 BODY:
Three and a half years of merciless war have left Bosnia's economy and society shattered. Two-thirds of the country's housing lies damaged or destroyed. Half the prewar hospital beds are gone, along with half the doctors and nurses. Roads and bridges are impassable and some four million hidden mines await potential victims. Gas, electricity and telephone lines are ruptured and three out of four adults have lost their livelihoods.
So far too little has been done to address these crushing problems. The large reconstruction effort promised as part of the Dayton peace agreement has fallen badly behind schedule. 
 The delay has potentially severe consequences for sustaining peace in Bosnia. Improvements in the lives of ordinary Bosnians are the most effective way to reinforce the Dayton settlement. If the rebuilding of Bosnia's civil society does not begin in earnest immediately, the peace could start to crumble by the time NATO forces are to depart at the end of this year, creating pressure for the troops to extend their stay. The nearly $2 billion so far pledged in aid must be put to quick and effective use.
To that end, President Clinton and European leaders should shift their focus from military to civilian aspects of the peace settlement and bring a new sense of urgency to bear on such needs as putting people back to work, assuring free and fair conditions for this summer's elections and making it possible for people to cross ethnic boundaries without fear. They must see to it that the international coordinators of civil reconstruction, chiefly Carl Bildt of Sweden and Robert Frowick of the United States, have the determination and resources they need to get the job done.
The best insurance against renewed warfare in Bosnia would be finding jobs for some 300,000 former soldiers now demobilized. Tens of thousands of women who lost husbands in the war also must find ways to provide for their families. International reconstruction aid should be channeled as quickly as possible into job-creating projects rebuilding housing, roads and bridges.
Meanwhile, Bosnia is preparing for elections. For these to be conducted fairly, giving moderates a chance to displace the extremists responsible for the war, independent candidates will need access to print and broadcast media now dominated by ethnic parties and governments. Mr. Frowick, who has chief responsibility for supervising the elections, has been trying to expand election coverage and set up new broadcast outlets, but his efforts have not yet produced acceptable results.
The Dayton agreement also assures refugees, a large proportion of Bosnia's population, the right to vote. But some European countries warn that those who exercise this right could forfeit their refugee status. Mr. Frowick and Mr. Bildt must make sure this threat is withdrawn.
For civilians to move freely throughout the country, they must get past roadblocks manned by armed ethnic militias and survive attack from hostile mobs uncontrolled by local police. Mr. Bildt's civilian monitors should insist that local police secure safe passage for civilians. NATO forces, which have begun accompanying refugee convoys, should prod local military units to respect Dayton's guarantees of free movement.
There is still time to save the civil side of the peace effort if Mr. Bildt and his team move more swiftly in the next eight months than they have in the last four. The unacceptable price of further delay is likely to be new warfare or the long-term commitment of American and European forces

HEADLINE: Colombia's Economy Unsettled by Crisis Involving President

BYLINE: By PAMELA MERCER 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 4

 BODY:
Years of guerrilla warfare, the terrorism of the drug trade and a string of political assassinations have made Colombia one of the world's most violent countries. Through it all, the economy has thrived.
Now, as investigations into allegations that drug money helped finance the President's election campaign in 1994 are threatening to topple the Government, the crisis is unsettling the economy. 
 In recent months, the country's economic growth has slowed as businesses, uncertain about the future, postpone investment decisions.
Banks, in turn, are suffering the consequences of decreased borrowing. Speculation by investors has led the peso to lose ground against the dollar.
Many in the private sector say the criminal investigations facing President Ernesto Samper and his closest aides in connection with the 1994 campaign are to blame for much of the decline. And as the political crisis draws on, business figures are becoming a focal point of opposition to the Government.
"The political crisis has affected the economy," said Javier Fernandez, president of the National Association of Financial Institutions, a private group. "We fear that the Government's lack of legitimacy may affect economic decisions. But we are mainly dissatisfied with the President for moral reasons."
He said there was strong pressure from business for the President to step down.
Discontent among business leaders became evident in late January, when Fernando Botero, Mr. Samper's former campaign manager, accused him of receiving millions of dollars in campaign contributions from members of the Cali drug cartel. As the country grappled with these charges and entered its worst period of political instability in decades, the National Business Council, an association of powerful business groups, asked the President to consider resignation.
In March, economic prospects were further dimmed when, in a punitive measure aimed at countries that are considered to be making insufficient progress in the fight against drugs, the United States withdrew some assistance to Colombia and four other countries.
The opposition became more vocal in the weeks that followed. At the same time, the National Federation of Merchants and the National Association of Industrialists, two powerful business groups, and Fedesarrollo, an influential economic research institute, released reports that cited the political crisis as a key factor in declining profits, low investment and slow growth.
The figure that raised the most concern was Fedesarrollo's forecast of a 3.8 percent increase in the gross domestic product for 1996, far lower than official projections of 4.9 percent and the annual growth rates of more than 5 percent that Colombia has had in the last three years.
Not all of the economic troubles are linked to the scandal. Construction, for example, is suffering the normal effects of a trade prone to cyclical downturns. And part of the central bank's initiative in raising interest rates has come from efforts to control inflation and counter high Government spending.
But analysts warn that the economic consequences of the crisis, which have so far been moderate, will deepen if Mr. Samper remains in power indefinitely. In a recent poll conducted by Dinero, a monthly magazine, 87 percent of business people questioned favored a change in the country's leadership.

HEADLINE: Environment Yielding to Other Worries, U.N. Talks Suggest

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 3

 BODY:
Four years after the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro propelled the environment to the top of the world agenda, the movement seems to have reached an impasse here at the United Nations, where a commission set up to monitor progress since Rio ended two weeks of talks today.
The Commission on Sustainable Development -- dedicated to the notion that nations can continue expanding their economies without destroying their environment -- heard success stories as it prepared for a major review next year of how far the world has come since the 1992 Earth Summit, formally called the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development. 
 A number of national governments, including that of the United States, have prepared plans for environmental protection in the next century. Hundreds of municipalities have also written plans of action, bringing the concept of environmental protection to urban neighborhoods and the grass roots.
Britain's Secretary of the Environment, John Gummer, said at a news conference today that this week's meetings had also taken an important step in bringing the world's oceans and their resources under the scrutiny of United Nations environmental bodies. "We are accepting as a world community that there are to be world rules," he said. "Until this conference, the oceans were untouched by the Rio process."
But hovering over the meeting was the sense that other issues have begun crowding out the environment, as rich and poor countries alike worry about unemployment and economic decline. And in many countries, environment ministries and private organizations say they are frustrated by their inability to make environmental impact a major factor in economic policy-making.
As recent negotiations over a Federal budget agreement in Washington demonstrated, environmental platforms are often subject to compromise, even in an Administration in which the Vice President, Al Gore, has an international reputation as a leader in the movement.
"To a certain extent, after Rio other issues took over," said Nitin Desai, the United Nations' Under Secretary General for Policy Coordination and Sustainable Development. "I sometimes argue that Rio took place in a particular window of opportunity, when, in a way, the world didn't have anything else to worry about."
Mr. Desai said in an interview on Thursday that the next step for the environmental movement must be to broaden its scope to get its issues on others' agendas.
"When we focus only on environmental problems we won't get very far unless we move backward and focus on agriculture policy, energy policy, transport policy -- all the economic policies that affect the environment," he said.
Several speakers called attention to rapidly changing patterns of transportation and the problems these are creating: the explosion in car ownership in some regions of the world, unmanageable traffic and increased pollution in many cities already choked by industrial waste.
Austria's Environment Minister, Martin Bartenstein, devoted a large part of his speech to the growth of vehicular traffic and shortages in public transportation and energy supplies. Several delegates said afterward that they found it ironic that in Washington at the same time, the two major political parties were competing for ways to lower gasoline prices in the United States, thereby effectively adding to the glut of cars burning a finite supply of fossil fuels.

HEADLINE: Pataki to Seek A Sales Tax For Some Items On Tribal Land

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALLEGANY INDIAN RESERVATION, N.Y.

 BODY:
By the hundreds, outsiders flock here each day to load up on the rare goods sold in the small Indian shops of this remote reservation: tax-free cigarettes and gasoline.
"You just can't find this kind of bargain anywhere else," Chuck Fuerst said the other day, after paying $40 for five cartons of cigarettes at the Seneca One Stop on the outskirts of the reservation. "I've been coming here for years." 
 But the days of discount prices and tidy profits for the state's Indian entrepreneurs may soon end, because Gov. George E. Pataki vows to close this loophole. He plans to begin collecting taxes this summer on reservation sales of cigarettes and gas to non-Indians -- despite the tribes' contention that doing so would violate their sovereignty and threaten the stores that form the backbone of many tribal economies.
Indeed, the three stores owned by the Seneca nation alone generate $25 million a year, largely from sales of gasoline and cigarettes to non-Indians like Mr. Fuerst.
The Pataki administration says the state will begin imposing the taxes on July 5, amid growing pressure from non-Indian merchants who have long complained that Indian competitors have been crippling their businesses because of an unfair price advantage, particularly as state sales taxes on cigarettes and gas have risen sharply. Today, Indian businesses routinely sell gasoline for 20 to 25 cents a gallon less and cigarettes for $8 a carton less than stores just outside their reservations.
The taxation issue elicits strong feeling here, where the Senecas fought a similar effort four years ago by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo by shutting down state highways throughout their reservation in a standoff with the police that lasted several days. Mr. Cuomo was using a plan that enabled the state to tax reservation sales of gasoline and cigarettes to non-Indians. Mr. Pataki is now dusting off the same plan, which has been upheld by the United States Supreme Court.
"I think the Governor needs to back off his threat," said J. C. Seneca, the owner of two convenience stores that thrive largely because of sales to non-Indians, "because he's creating problems for the open dialogue that's needed to resolve this situation. We have a right to defend our interests as a people."
About 50 members of the Seneca, Mohawk, Tuscarora and Onondaga nations gathered yesterday in downtown Buffalo, calling New York's tax plan a violation of their sovereignty, The Associated Press reported. The protesters demonstrated for about an hour in a steady downpour, listening to speakers and carrying signs that read "Honor Our Treaties."
Seeking to work out a compromise, the Pataki administration has asked for Federal intervention. This week, an official from the Office of Tribal Justice in Washington scheduled a meeting with Indian leaders in an attempt to avoid confrontations like the one in 1992.
New York is not the only state grappling with the problem of how to tax businesses on reservations without violating the sovereignty of Indian nations. Thirteen states have struck deals with Indian tribes allowing state officials to collect taxes on certain goods sold on reservations.
For New York, the taxation issue has taken on added importance this year because legislative leaders say they can collect about $90 million to $120 million from such taxes annually to help balance the state budget.
Indian tribes have long enjoyed tax-exempt status because treaties that established them as independent nations bar states from enforcing taxation and other laws on Indians. But in 1994 the United States Supreme Court upheld a plan devised by New York State that sought to collect taxes on reservation sales to non-Indian customers without violating Indian sovereignty.
State officials have been under growing pressure to enact the tax-collection plan, as the convenience-store and gas-station lobbies complain that Indian shops have siphoned away millions of dollars in business from non-Indian retailers.
Consider the case of Mark W. Sidebottom, a non-Indian who owns a chain of convenience stores scattered outside the Seneca reservation here in western New York near the Pennsylvania border. In the last two years alone, he said, he has had to close three of his stores as competition from the Indians stiffened.
"We're closing more stores than we're opening," Mr. Sidebottom said. "There's absolutely no way to compete with Indians. I've found that my own employees shop on the reservations. Enough is enough already."
Customers, not surprisingly, oppose the closing of the tax loophole.
James Fisher, a retired trucker who lives about 50 miles from the Seneca people, fumed about the Governor's plan the other day as he made a pit stop at one of the eight convenience stores dotting a busy strip on the edges of the reservation.
He derided the plan as meddling in the affairs of a sovereign nation. "They have treaties, you know," Mr. Fisher said. But in the end he was mostly upset about the prospect of having to pay state taxes, a sentiment expressed by most people living near the reservation. "The Government wants to tax everything," he said as he filled his tank.
The Pataki administration, for its part, is willing to talk with tribal leaders and extend the July deadline if they come up with their own plan for regulating and taxing the sales of cigarette and gas on the reservations by July 5.
But many Indian leaders across the state say they refuse to be strong-armed into compromising with state officials. "We're not going to negotiate with guns to our head," said Raymond Halbritter, leader of the Oneida Indians near Utica.
In the end, tax experts say, it will be difficult to avoid the taxes because of the clever way that New York's tax-collection plan gets around the question of sovereignty.
The plan would compel state officials to collect sales and excise taxes from non-Indian wholesalers of gasoline and cigarettes before they sold their goods to Indian retailers. The cost of the taxes would then be passed along to the retailers and their customers.
But before imposing the tax on the non-Indian wholesaler, the state would estimate the amount of cigarettes and gasoline that would be consumed by the Indians themselves. The tax would be imposed on gas and cigarettes beyond the predetermined limit, on the assumption that non-Indian customers would be buying them.
The Pataki administration's hard line has begun to send waves of anxiety throughout many reservations.
The Senecas, perhaps more than the others, are concerned because the roughly 30 convenience stores scattered along the fringes of their three reservations have helped revitalize the tribe's economy after decades of depression.
The businesses employ about 150 people and have even turned a handful of Seneca entrepreneurs into millionaires. The $25 million a year taken in by the three stores the Seneca nation itself owns helps pay the salaries of 700 workers employed by the tribal government.
The shops are so essential to tribal life that Seneca leaders are hammering out a compromise proposal that would establish the tribe as the only wholesaler allowed to supply reservation stores.
Seneca leaders say the plan would bring money into tribal coffers and enable them to raise gas and cigarette prices closer to those off the reservation while still maintaining part of the current pricing advantage. But some non-Indian merchants worry that the proposal is a ploy to get around the state's tax-collection plan.
Sovereignty-minded, the Senecas are taking a tough stance, some of them even threatening to set up tolls along state highways on the reservation if no mutually acceptable agreement is reached. The Pataki administration has said it would consider any plan that the Indians submit.
"We need to work this out," said Rosemary Patterson, who is on the 16-member Seneca Council, the tribe's legislature. "This is a matter of survival for our people."
Yvonne Cooper's situation typifies the trouble that many Indian merchants face. Just about all her customers are non-Indians and they mob her smoke shop each day in search of bargains. Ms. Cooper is certain they would stop coming if she began charging state taxes.
"Yeah, I'm worried," Ms. Cooper said the other day as she sat in a spare room of her store on Broad Street. "Some people travel 50 miles just to save money. Why would they travel that distance if they could buy cigarettes at the same price in their local convenience store?"
Just down the block at the Seneca One Stop, Kim Hennings spends most afternoons at the register ringing up sales of gas and cigarettes to truckers and other outsiders who have made the store a prime destination.
She says it is about the best job she could find in this economically depressed region of the state.
"There are a lot of people like me who will be out of jobs if these stores go under," she said. "And then what do we do? Go on welfare? I wish the Governor would just leave us alone."
