HEADLINE: 2 Governors Back $130 Million Plan To Deepen Harbor

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
With rising shoals of silt threatening the future of New York Harbor and thousands of jobs, the Governors of New York and New Jersey have endorsed a plan earmarking up to $130 million this year for deepening shipping channels.
But the commitment to spend the money, which is available from capital accounts of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, does not mean the Governors have solved the problem that has dogged this issue for two years: where to put millions of tons of dredged mud that is contaminated with toxic chemicals. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey remains firmly opposed to dumping any of it in the ocean, and the other possibilities -- putting it in covered pits in the harbor, on artificial islands, or on the shore -- are costly, controversial, or too untested to offer an immediate solution. 
 Even so, the plan represents a significant down payment by the two states on a problem that experts say is already costing the area trade and jobs and may soon end New York Harbor's 150-year-old status as the dominant East Coast seaport.
Outlined in a one-page resolution released yesterday by Governor Whitman and Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, the plan would allocate four times as much money for dredging as the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey normally spends each year to maintain its channels and berths. Port Authority commissioners are scheduled to vote on the resolution next Thursday.
The resolution calls the deepening of channels to 50 feet a "top priority" of the states, saying that 166,500 jobs in New York and New Jersey are generated by port commerce, along with $20 billion in annual sales of goods. Calling for a plan stretching to 2025, the resolution says it is vital for New York Harbor to be able to accommodate a new generation of deep-draft ships that is expected to begin carrying cargo from Asia to the East Coast.
If shippers shift operations to existing deep-water ports like Halifax, Nova Scotia, or Norfolk, Va., port experts say, the effects here would include higher costs for consumers and more air pollution and traffic from the trucks that would carry goods here instead of ships.
The prospect of money for dredging cheered a variety of harbor constituencies, but they lamented the lack of specifics in the resolution. Private environmental groups, for example, want some of the Port Authority funds to be used to clean up harbor pollution.
Many of those whose jobs or businesses depend on the port say all they want is action.
"We've gotten a lot of plans over the years, and none have become reality," said Albert Cernadas, president of Local 1235 of the International Longshoremen's Association. "In the meantime, we're losing cargo every day to other ports. And silt accumulates every day." Until mud is scooped and barged somewhere, doubts will remain, he said, adding that the union still intended to hold a demonstration in Trenton on May 30 to press for action.
He criticized Governor Whitman for continuing to refuse to consider the dumping of mud containing even the slightest trace of contamination at the traditional ocean-disposal site, six miles east of Sandy Hook. "In the short term, there's no other place," Mr. Cernadas said.
But representatives of Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Pataki insisted that their unified stance would create the momentum needed to break the deadlock over how to handle the harbor's mud. "This is an absolute commitment to solving the problem," said Peter Verniero, Governor Whitman's chief of staff. The goal is to have a fleshed-out dredging plan by Aug. 1, said Michael C. Finnegan, Mr. Pataki's counsel.
Mr. Finnegan said that the Army Corps of Engineers and Federal environmental officials -- who together regulate channel dredging -- were working with state officials to untangle rules and testing methods for harbor mud, and that the states had commitments from the Clinton Administration for Federal funding to spur solutions.
Mr. Verniero said the 12 Port Authority commissioners were likely to follow the lead of the Governors who appointed them and approve using the money -- which would be taken from the Port Authority's existing capital budget -- for dredging.
The resolution was the product of four weeks of meetings of state, Federal and New York City officials organized by Mr. Verniero and Mr. Finnegan.
Several people participating in the meetings said the states were closing in on a menu of ways to share the burden of handling the tainted mud, but were constrained from providing details. One state official, who declined to be identified, said that it was likely that some of the dormant, weed-strewn piers of Brooklyn -- which lie along a naturally deep channel -- would play a role in reducing the need for dredging altogether by offering a spot for deeper-draft ships to unload their goods.
Lillian C. Borrone, the port director, hailed the move by the two executives, saying, "This is the first time we have both states, the city, and the Federal agencies all saying the same thing: 'We have a crisis.' " She added that the $130 million figure should reassure port businesses that, this time, the commitment is not just another paper plan.
For 80 years, all of the dredged harbor mud was routinely dumped at sea east of Sandy Hook. But when a new set of more sensitive Federal toxicity tests was introduced two years ago, much of the harbor mud was found to contain sufficient traces of certain toxic chemicals to pose a theoretical threat to marine life. According to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, since the change in tests, about 60 percent of mud dredged from channels in New York Harbor fails and cannot go into the open ocean.
Although some disposal options have been proposed, years of testing and study will be required before these methods can be expanded, port officials say.
Private groups pressing to prevent marine and beach pollution are urging the states to find ways to dispose of the mud on land or to decontaminate it using new technology, but these options are even further down the line, dredging experts say.
If the resolution is approved, the Port Authority's commissioners will then target funds for the most pressing dredging projects, Port Authority officials said. The money would be allocated, but not necessarily all spent, this year, they said.
Representatives of some environmental groups said that it was important that some of the money also flow to related environmental projects, including cleaning up the sources of the pollution that tainted the harbor bottom in the first place. "It looks like most of this money is going to the economic-development side," said James T. B. Tripp, a lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund and longtime participant in the dredging debate.
Mr. Tripp and some New Jersey and Federal officials would like some of the money to spur the development of a project in which sand-mining companies create pits near the existing offshore dump site. Most of the sand would be sold for construction projects, the pits would provide a secure repository for harbor mud, and some of the mined sand would be used to seal both the new pits and cover broad areas of contamination created by past dumping.
But many shore communities and New Jersey politicians, including Governor Whitman, refuse to consider such a plan. One official at the Port Authority, who declined to be identified, said that the states must realize that, without the ocean-dumping option, the tainted mud will have to be dealt with where it is produced, in New Jersey and New York. The Governors will have to have the political will to overcome local resistance to dealing with traces of toxic chemicals, he said.
"Every day, this material is coming down the Hudson, Passaic, and Raritan Rivers," the official said. "You can't put it in the ocean and you can't shoot it to the Moon, so that means you've got to put it in the states somewhere."

HEADLINE: Business Schemes Change Dynamics of the Drug War

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
Business was so brisk at S & F Check Cashers, a modest check-cashing concern in West New York, N.J., across the Hudson River from Manhattan, that the dollars it collected were reportedly sometimes hauled to the bank by an armored-car company.
But as Marion Percell, an assistant United States attorney in Newark, observed, "A check-cashing service should be getting money from the bank, not sending it in." 
 The service was part of what law enforcement officials say was a larger conspiracy that sent as much as $60 million in drug profits back to the Cali cartel in Colombia under the cover of such mundane services as selling telephone debit cards and money orders, renting beepers and cashing checks.
"The major problem the cocaine traffickers have is not getting drugs into the country," Ms. Percell said. "It's getting the money out."
She is prosecutor in the trial of 13 defendants in Newark on Sept. 10, the largest money-laundering case brought by the Federal Government in New Jersey.
The New York region offers a prime arena for money laundering -- disguising illegal profits to make them look legitimate. The city itself is a crossroads for heroin and cocaine smuggled into the country as well as a world financial center where $2 trillion can change hands in a single business day.
At least $10 billion in laundered money flows annually through the New York City metropolitan area, according to Kenneth C. Klug, a special agent for the United States Customs Service. Mr. Klug is assigned to Operation El Dorado, a Customs and Internal Revenue Service task force based in Manhattan's financial district that combats money laundering. Drugs generate up to 90 percent of this money, Mr. Klug estimated, with the rest traceable to tax evasion, extortion or illegal gambling.
The intricacies of money laundering have changed the dynamics of the war against illegal drugs in New York. New laws, computerization and growing vigilance over large cash transactions have made it harder for traffickers to move their money in what is predominantly a credit-card economy. As a result, said the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, some traffickers have gone back to "bulking out" drug profits by hiding the cash inside objects like wire spools and bowling balls.
Syndicates like the Cali cartel in Colombia have a harder time sending back the money because of United States Government regulations requiring the reporting of most financial transactions larger than $10,000. Law enforcement agencies have also learned to track money movements by computer. And for the traffickers, it is still a chore to consolidate and convert small-denomination cash accumulated in street sales into a currency that can be moved inconspicuously.
"They've basically set up two organizations now," Mr. Morgenthau said, "one that brings the drugs in and another that takes the money out."
The methods used by traffickers in New York and elsewhere include such diverse schemes as simply hiding the loot and transferring money through a succession of financial institutions and front companies, a process called "layering," to mask its origins. Couriers booked on outgoing flights have swallowed $100 bills rolled in condoms.
Robert H. Silbering, New York City's special narcotics prosecutor, recalled how Drug Enforcement Administration agents in the mid-1980's found a van crammed with $19 million in bills. "There wasn't a bill larger than a $20," he said.
Since then, smugglers have become more inventive. In 1990, Customs Service agents found $6.5 million in 26 Colombia-bound canisters labeled as containing bull semen. Inspectors have also found $7 million in a 40-foot-long refrigerated container.
The case in Newark illustrates how one discovery leads to another. Law officers were alerted by a Customs inspector at Newark International Airport who had found more than $1 million stuffed in stereo systems being shipped to Colombia.
The ensuing investigation led agents to S & F Check Cashers and two other companies: International Services, a travel agency and money transmitter in Jersey City, and Latelco Inc., which offered telephone debit cards and had offices in Miami, Cali and West New York.
According to the indictment, the companies deposited "substantial amounts of money" from drug sales in local bank accounts, then wrote checks to other accounts in Panama's free trade zone, where, investigators believe, the money was remitted in pesos back to Colombia or used to benefit the cartel's other worldwide interests.
Prosecutors say S & F Check Cashers received a commission on money that it laundered. Until recently, the going rate was as low as 3 percent. But with laundering becoming riskier, drug traffickers in New York are now paying up to 8 percent. That was the rate charged by the Drug Enforcement Administration in a sting operation that it ran out of a store in Queens from November 1993 until last March.
Money launderers use telephone and remittance shops catering to immigrants here to wire cash back to Colombia and elsewhere in South America. So the agency set up such a store in Bayside, Queens, with Spanish-speaking undercover operatives and wiretapped telephones.
"We put out word that if anyone was interested in moving large amounts of money, to call a number," said Carlo A. Boccia, the special agent in charge of the Drug Enforcement Administration's New York field office.
After almost two and a half years, the operation, which was financed by the commission paid by drug traffickers, located 20 money-laundering accounts at banks in the United States and elsewhere and made 18 arrests.
To prevent the transfers of large amounts of tainted money, the Bank Secrecy Act requires banks and other financial institutions to report to the Internal Revenue Service any individual transaction of more than $10,000, though this does not include transfers between banks. Travelers carrying more than $10,000 in or out of the United States must file a report with the Customs Service. Anyone paying more than $10,000 in cash for a house or a car must also be reported to the Government.
To evade the $10,000 ceiling, traffickers wire smaller amounts more often, an illegal technique called "smurfing."
Investigators say they are tipped by banks in New York that notice an influx of funds they cannot explain.
Operation El Dorado, which works out of the Customs Service's headquarters in the World Trade Center, uses computers like radar to scan for a pattern of financial transactions consistent with laundering. "Money is allowed to move," Mr. Klug said. "We identify the source or go to the application. And that's a paper trail."
In Operation Polar Cap, which began in California and spread to New York, the El Dorado computers detected more money than usual circulating through Manhattan's jewelry industry a few years ago, and homed in on a half-dozen jewelers who accounted for more than $300 million of the turnover.
"What they saw was a cornucopia of businesses out there that were putting money into the banking system," Mr. Klug said. Closer investigation found that the extra cash was coming from drug traffickers, who had promised the jewelers a commission on what they laundered.
Drug traffickers are also contracting out laundering to shady money managers, who buy or sell drug proceeds like a commodity.
Operation El Dorado is monitoring the activities of an undisclosed number of banks or brokerage firms in New York for evidence of money laundering, though investigators would not give details.

HEADLINE: My Journey Among the Blind

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LEDUFF 

 BODY:
Spring. Somewhere near Union Square Park.
The air is warm and calm now; the rain has moved along. Women daubed with perfume rustle by. The cement is wet, and the sound of afternoon traffic echoes flatly like radio static from an old wireless. Standing at the corner, I wait to cross. The crowd walks and I walk with it. But, being New Yorkers, everyone has jumped the crossing light. This realization comes as I find myself bumbling in the middle of Fourth Avenue while what sounds like a bus barrels down on me like a buffalo. I run, unsure of the curb. A hand reaches out from the darkness and pulls me to safety. He never says a word and I cannot thank him, or her. I cannot because I cannot see. I am blind -- my eyes completely covered by two dark patches covered by dark glasses, only a retractable white cane to guide me. 
 There is a skid, then a crash. "What are you? Freaking stupid?" one man yells. A door slams. Is he yelling at me? Another door opens. "Where do you think you're driving?" the other man snaps. I imagine his wild, indecent gestures. "This is New York for Christ's sake!" This escalates. Horns start to scream. People go on about their ways. Heels go click-clack, click-clack.
New York, indeed. Big. Beautiful, and mean. I wondered what it is like for the blind in the world's fastest city? I asked this of a blind man once as we walked across a street. "It's tough," he said dismissively and walked on.
I stood there stupidly, thinking, "Dumb question, maybe even rude." That was it. Somewhere I had learned to ignore the blind; they were different and lived in another world. If they wanted something, they would ask. That's what that blind man meant: how could I ever understand?
I decided I would try, thinking that actually depriving myself of sight might be a bridge to understanding. So I began with mobility training at Helen Keller Services for the Blind in Brooklyn. They gave me the eye patches and the cane, and Corinne Kuri, a mobility instructor, gave me a cram course on how to get around. Left foot, tap the cane to your right. Right foot, tap cane to your left. Walk slowly. Feel through your feet. Count the blocks. Remember your direction. And most important, ignore all sounds except those you need for navigation. Listen for traffic. Good luck.
I was to stay for a week with a young blind musician named Orlando Fiol, who lives uptown. He would try to show me what it was like to live without sight in an ocular world, he promised, but he would not baby-sit me. No problem I said, I would practice over the weekend.
An instructor of the blind, John Byfield, told me that even though New York is a cramped, suffocating tunnel, it is a sanctuary of sorts for the blind.
"Outside of the mania, Manhattan is laid out in blocks and for that reason it is probably one of the easiest geographical places to live," he said.
But on that first practice run I began to realize that the fine things I've come to love about the city can be grotesque and frightening. I did circles around my block. Over and over I went, certain of nothing. I heard children laughing. Are they laughing at me? I wondered. I could picture their big gaping mouths the size of squashes. Behind every argument, every game, was a lurking, willowy figure ready to harm. It felt dizzy, like vertigo, and I began talking to myself.
 
 
 
The Old Man
 Monday came, an iron church bell tolled 12, and I sat in my apartment, panic stricken, wondering what to do. I had to head uptown to see Orlando. I knew I couldn't make it to the subway alone so I called a friend.
As we walked, my friend described how people stared and then darted their eyes away as if I might see them. Mothers shooed their children. At the subway, people let us cut into the line. I gave my friend a $5 bill that I had folded into quarters and placed in my right pocket. He bought a token for me and gave me my change. I folded the singles in half and placed them in my left pocket.
I made it to the 110th Street station. Disembarking, I stopped to listen, letting the crowd clear. Navigating is mostly a matter of reading signposts of sounds. The flow of shoes and rustling newspapers went off to my right. I figured the exit must be there. Left foot, tap right. Right foot, tap left. Going slowly, I sensed that I was on a two-sided platform. I felt the air flow and heard echoes wafting from the tunnels. It's hard to know if you are walking a straight line. By listening for the turnstiles and traffic, I found my way out.
Now what? I did not remember Orlando's address, or his telephone number, and I had no idea where I was. Vertigo. I stood on that corner for 15 minutes, maybe it was an hour. Eventually, a man asked if I needed help. I said I didn't know where I was going.
It's odd to trust a stranger to root through your bag to find an address. We walked and the man was kind. "How long you been this way," the stranger asked. His voice was old. His name was Sam. "Not long," I told him.
Sam talked about his grandson. He had just been to visit him. The boy has terminal brain cancer.
It must be God's will for a boy that young to have brain cancer, Sam said. His voice was strained.
Sam walked me all the way to the apartment building, and placed my hand on the railing. The old man just needed to talk, I think. A sightless stranger offered him just the right amount of anonymity.
"God bless you, son," Sam said as he walked off.
The doorman said, "You must be here to see Orlando," and put me in the elevator. When the door opened a voice from a distance told me to turn right. I walked toward the sound, and a long, thin hand greeted me.
 
 
 
Orlando
 Orlando Fiol has been completely blind since birth. He was born three months premature and when the doctor administered too much oxygen, it damaged his retinas for life. The medical term for this is retinopathy. Orlando describes it as fried eyeballs. He speaks with a slurred New York Latin accent, like a Puerto Rican Ray Charles. His voice is large and from its direction I would guess he is about six feet tall. Orlando's shoulders are wide, and his hair thinning and cut short. He says it is brown, like his eye. The other eye is a blue colored prosthesis.
The apartment is large, with wooden, uncarpeted floors. There is a leather couch and a grand piano in the living room and a soundproof studio in the back. It is open and uncluttered, and Orlando, 24, whisks around like a chimney sweep.
But Orlando has never seen a chimney, or a lake or trees. He knows how tall trees are because he's climbed to their tops. He knows how wide a lake is because he's swum across them. The darkness isn't black, he says, although what black means exactly, he does not know. Blind friends who once had sight describe the void as shale gray. Still, these things are all abstractions for Orlando. He takes solace in the auditory pleasures. He is a pianist who has played with Stevie Wonder and toured the world with his father's salsa band. He speaks six languages.
"Have you eaten today?" he asks me.
"No, I haven't had time," I say.
"Bull. You were just too afraid to walk into a restaurant and stumble around."
He has seen right through me. If you're going to be blind, you have to re-learn the basics, such as preparing your own hot food, he tells me. We sit down at the kitchen table for juice and sauteed mushrooms that he has quickly and easily prepared. We eat with our fingers. I tell him of my trip over, how New Yorkers were actually helpful.
"You see how much you have to rely on people?" he asks. "I need people but I'm not about to stand on the street corner whining like, 'Somebody please help me!' I won't do it. I'd rather just sit home."
He tries to live a "normal" life but realizes there is nothing normal about it. "When you're defective, when your eyes are broken, you can't be sent back," he says. "You have to learn to tolerate yourself."
Learning to like himself was a slow, painful education. He grew up in Queens Village and attended high school at The Fiorello H. La Guardia School for Music and Art and the Performing Arts, in Manhattan. He dreamed of seeing the lights, but the closest he could get was pretending to see the lights. He dressed up in the finest clothes, got expensive hair cuts and wore designer sunglasses. He ate with a fork and knife. He even had people write notes on his hands so when he walked around he could make it appear as if he could read.
But children still laughed and adults still avoided him. He had few friends in high school. No one wanted to go out with a "crip"; it was a hassle. The girls didn't want him, either. He never had a date and he didn't go to the prom.
Things weren't much better in college. Once, while chatting with a group of women at a bar, he was interrupted by one who said she preferred men who looked her in the eye. Apologizing, he explained his blindness. The women got up and left, leaving him sitting alone. "It was humiliating and I still feel it," he says. "People only see what's in front of their faces. They don't care about the inside."
He quit going to the bars. His days are now spent listening to Wordsworth from an electronic scanner that digests the text and brings it to life in a male voice that sounds as if it is speaking through an electric fan. He gives conga lessons and plays with 20 different bands. Music is his life. It is the way he'll make his name, he said.
"The blind man has to accommodate to a sighted world," Orlando says. "And that's our fault. Most of us are so busy trying to mainstream ourselves that we don't demand that there be simple things like recorded messages announcing street numbers in the subways and buses. We're too busy trying to get sighted girlfriends."
 
 
 
Love
 Orlando has a sighted fiancee, Rachel. She drives us to a gig in Connecticut. We leave early in the morning. I don't think the sun is up because I can't hear rush-hour traffic yet. A blind car ride is like watching black paint dry. The highlight came when I heard a dog bark.
We get to the gig and the band sets up. Rachel helps Orlando, and I sit in the corner. She looks out for me, too, arranging an escort to the toilets. We listen to the band warm up; the tenor sax sounds like an old man blowing his nose. Rachel tells me how good she feels with Orlando. "He's taught me how to hear the canon and a fugue in operas," she says. "He's taught me to listen, and I've taught him to trust."
When we return home from the concert, she lets me feel her face. Rachel Grossman is a 30-year-old with a tall, imperious voice. She has vision and wears moon-shaped glasses on her round face. Her hair lopes down to her big shoulders. When I first heard her voice, I thought she was Latina, but she is white. Orlando knows because she told him. They met through a telephone dating service.
Meeting through the phone became a habit of Orlando's. He's met many women in his time -- "they were all the wrong kind." A very popular musician and student at Columbia, he always had a coterie of admirers, but never lovers.
"It's like, who wants half a man?" Orlando says acidly. Through the telephone he could engage women and reveal the fact of his blindness at his own pace.
He found companionship and depravity but never love. Once he arranged to rendezvous at a woman's apartment. When he arrived, she reeked of alcohol and was 10 years older than she had implied. "She was psychotic," Orlando recalls. Regardless, he stayed the night. He removed his false eye when it began to irritate him. Later, he found it gnarled on the floor. Her dog had made an afternoon snack of it.
That's the way it is, he says: when you're blind you're vulnerable. Rachel paces when Orlando goes out alone. Once he was late coming back from a party and she ran outside in a panic. She found him wandering around across the street, frightened. He didn't know where he was. "The cabbie dropped him off on the wrong side of the street," she says.
Even the routine can be dangerous. The worst places in New York are 72d Street where Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue intersect, Union Square and Times Square. All very Byzantine and congested streets. Then there are muggers. And punks.
Orlando reminds me of my status. "You always have a way out. When it comes down to it, you're going to defend yourself." He is right, I know. I have a way out.
 
 
 
Wendy
 They are a nice couple, Orlando and Rachel. But sitting around with nothing to do but eavesdrop wears thin. I'm no voyeur and I had to go.
I'm on my way to visit Wendy Miller, a blind woman who is training with her new guide dog. She lives in midtown and I sweep the subway station, not sure where my train is. A young man helps me. His arm is damp and hot. I say so. "Yeah, I just been playing. I'm Larry, the dude who plays buckets in the Levi's commercial." Yeah, I know him. He puts me on the train. Cool guy. It's nice to meet decent, well-meaning people.
The conductor announces my stop and the door opens. From the darkness an unsolicited hand tugs on my wrist, intended to help me out. Caught off guard, I tumble to the platform. I hear a crowd gather. "Oh my God! Are you alright?" a woman screams as if I'm deaf. Yes, I say, picking myself up. I'm embarrassed. The indignities of a moment like this makes it all the more difficult to be blind, I'm understanding. Angry, I find my way to the stairs swinging my cane like a weed whacker. I do not want company. I do not want help. I am capable.
I buy some cigarettes at a newsstand. The man helps me with the change. I cannot tell my nickels from quarters. Trying to calm down, I smoke one until it burns to my fingertips. Then I slowly feel my way toward Ms. Miller's apartment.
When I arrive, she is with her new dog, her sixth. The first died of old age, the last developed epilepsy and the one before that had a nervous breakdown from living in the city. He lives in the suburbs now.
A dog is important for Ms. Miller: the cane is a sign of helplessness, the dog a sign of power.
"It's untrue that New Yorkers are indifferent," she says. "In fact, they try to help too much. That's why I have the dog."
Ms. Miller, a social worker, moved here six months ago when her brother died. There were too many memories in Kansas City. She was married back there, to a sighted man. They divorced five years ago. They were never in love. "I always wanted to have a sighted husband," she said.
Growing up, she wanted to appear normal. She wore makeup, and nodded her head in appreciation of art she could not see. Her sister taught her that nod, and the latest dance steps.
She was married for five years, and there were good parts: the sex was nice and he bought the groceries. "I like being told I look beautiful," she says. "I like taking car rides. But I wasn't considered part of his world. He was the nice guy and I was the poor little blind girl. When we ate out, they asked him what I was eating like I was retarded. I hate that."
Wendy Miller is ornery about her independence. She has to be. When you're blind, people grab your arms and cane. They pull at you like the Boy Scout did the reluctant old lady. I think about the person in the subway who pulled me to the ground. Ms. Miller tells me about the guy who dragged her around a sleeping wino, like she was a piece of luggage.
"Damn it -- just leave me alone," she says.
She is not in New York to conquer it. It's the hum, the flow, that she loves. To her, New York is a square dance, one arm to the next, a dos-a-dos. It occurs to me that maybe it's not the lights that attract the moth, but the buzz.
 
 
 
The Party
 I've gone home to live alone. I've learned to find the door to my apartment building: it is the spot with the rubbled sidewalk. I can feel it through my shoes. It is a quiet space where house martins chatter outside the window. Besides listening to the birds, there's not much for me to do except practice the flute. I play the whole afternoon.
A friend calls and invites me to a party. It is supposed to have all that buzz. The Glamour. The Style. The Hip Set. Very New York, she says. And plenty of cocktails.
It is in SoHo and I wait for a long time as a string of cabs blow by. I hear other people get in and out, but I stand there. Someone flags one down for me. The driver is fair, and doesn't rip me off. I pay him and get out of the cab. A dog barks from an alleyway. It is windy, and I realized he's left me somewhere far away.
I wait until a stranger offers to help me to the address. Arriving, I walk up some linoleum steps and I hear the party. It is smoky and reeks of stale body odor. The scene is unemployed models and European hepsters. My friend is there. When I walk by, people fall silent. I think my friend is smiling.
I am placed in the corner, among the coats. A tonic and something is stuck in my hand. I smoke, ashing on the floor and I listen to empty conversation about the latest night clubs and the droop of someone's buttocks. "She's never going to make it without surgery," a woman says.
Periodically, a woman comes to fill my glass. She is sweet and smells nice. "I see you're ready for another," she stammers, embarrassed that she's reminded me that she can see and I cannot. She never returns. I was half-right: she was sweet, but sweet like saccharine.
Coats come and go, but no one says hello. I cannot see, and somehow I am also invisible. I don't ask for chips and I don't go to the bathroom. I don't want to be a spectacle. So I sit and think about Orlando. He doesn't go to parties anymore. Why suffer the indignity?
Without someone to initiate the conversation, you're considered for about as long as a cheap painting. As for myself, I've seen dogs get more attention.
It goes this way for many cigarettes. People get drunk. I get bored. These are the beautiful people, but for me, there is no attraction, no eye contact.
One man, a German, grows increasingly sloppy. The blowhard knocks something over. "Glasses, ashtrays, china! Ha! Who cares about these things. Let's go somewhere and do things men do." I think people find him handsome. He sounds ugly.
I take my cane and go home, taking care to spank a few ankles on my way out.
 
 
 
Dusk
 Near my apartment is Stuyvesant Square Park, where I go to practice my flute. I like it there. I feel safe.
Sitting on a bench the next afternoon. A man comes up beside me. He starts a conversation. His voice is nasal and grizzled. He is drinking sour-smelling malt liquor.
He seems alright. We talk and I put the flute in my bag. A few minutes pass when there is a twitch, a rustle of my bag. Strange. The old gentleman is sitting too far away. Again, a tug.
I leap up, tearing off the blinders. There is another old tramp with his nasty hands on my bag. He knows he is done for and his eyes go wide. I whip him hard with the cane and he bolts like a spooked nag. I stand and glare at the man with the beer. He sits there with his rotten mouth hanging open, his bottle half-empty. We say nothing. I fold my cane away and walk home through the bitter odor of the ailanthus trees.
As my eyes refocus, after five days in the dark, the city comes back. The long solid lines, the molded cornices. Dusk. The artificial lights are coming on now, reflecting off the glass like a flock of burning birds, and I walk in the shadows of buildings. I see myself in a window, and I look a little different than I remember. Maybe a little taller. When you see through your eyes, you sense things as they appear, and in the glass I'm feeling confident, looking self-assured.
When you see through your ears, in some ways you sense things as they really are and that is both the most wonderful and horrible thing in the world. Perceptions change. In my mind's eye I know that we are all vulnerable in some way. That is the horrible part.
But it is good to remember the beauty. I hear the heels of my boots go click-clack.
 
Using Your Head When Offering a Hand
BLIND people are usually grateful for gestures of goodwill. Here are some suggestions to remember when helping a blind person.
 
AT THE CROSSWALK -- If you see a blind person waiting to cross the street, ask if you may provide assistance. If the answer is yes, do not grab him. Instead let him take your elbow. Be sure to walk him all the way across the street.

HOW TO GET THERE -- When giving directions, be specific as to length and where to turn left or right. Be sure he knows whose left and right you are talking about. Remember pointing does not help.

ON THE STAIRS -- When climbing stairs, guide the blind person's hand to the banister. It is not necessary to count all the steps for her. On an escalator, put her hand in front of her on the rail, before she steps on. In a revolving door, let her go ahead of you, guiding her hand to the rubber flange.

AT THE CAR -- When helping a blind person into a car, guide her hand to the roof just over the door. If the door is closed, guide her hand to the handle. Check to see if she is in before you close the door.

IN A NEW PLACE -- When accompanying a blind person into a room, do not leave him standing there. Try to orient him, leading him to a chair and placing his hand at a point of reference like the wall.

WHO YOU ARE -- Speak when you enter a blind person's room. Identify yourself. Only take her hand if she offers it to you. Let her know if you are leaving.

SEATING ARRANGEMENTS -- When showing a blind person to a chair, place his hand on the back. He will seat himself.

CASH TRANSACTIONS -- When changing a blind person's money, let her know what each bill is.

GUIDE DOG ETIQUETTE -- A guide dog walks to the blind person's left. You should walk to his right. Do not pet the dog.

WHAT TO SAY -- Most blind people are not hard of hearing. You do not need to shout. It is O.K. to use the words "see" and "blind." You do not need to censor your speech. CHARLIE LEDUFF

HEADLINE: Route 6: About Manny And an 11.5-Mile Query

 BODY:
The article was an admirable effort of capsulating a portion of the Route 6 issue and presenting it in a clear, concise and coherent manner.
One major aspect of the article that was less than clear, however, was the fact that the 11.5-mile stretch of highway under consideration is not blazing a new road in a "Westward Ho!" fashion through northeast Connecticut, but merely connecting two existing four-lane limited access highways. 
 The 11.5-mile connector highway would complete a major highway system connecting the deteriorating city of Willimantic with the state capital of Hartford.
Willimantic officials, the Willimantic Chamber of Commerce and the Windham Regional Planning Agency all support and eagerly await its completion.
In 1963 the Willimantic Chamber of Commerce led an ox-cart parade to Hartford to plead with the General Assembly for a highway between the two cities.
Today the issue being debated and discussed by the regulatory agencies is not whether or not to build a highway but rather which highway route would be the least environmentally damaging, practicable route.
The construction of any highway requires that many rules and regulations be satisfied and permits be obtained at all levels. To assist the regulatory agencies during the selection process, hundreds of reports and studies have been compiled and issued.
The Route 6 corridor has been looked at, poked at, analyzed and scrutinized by agencies, committees, groups and sub-groups, environmentalists, activists, economists, lawyers, engineers and doctors of science.
If the solution to the Route 6 dilemma was simple or easy, it would have been applied years ago.
 
DIANNE F. GRENIER
Andover

HEADLINE: Citizens, Start Your Pumps;
How America Perpetuates Its Gas Crisis

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DRIVING may be a little more expensive these days, but the main reason is not the price of gasoline. It's because of changes in the drivers and their cars.
Or rather, it is the changes in their vehicles, because what pulls up to the pump these days is often not a car. This year an estimated 4 in 10 new "light duty vehicles" sold will be vans, sport utility vehicles or pickup trucks. This is up from 1 in 10 in 1973, when the Arab oil embargo caused the first gas crisis, in an era when pickup trucks "actually saw hay, instead of worsted suits," as Daniel F. Becker, a spokesman for the Sierra Club, put it. 
 And car or not, they all cover more miles. In 1973 the vehicles traveled 5,350 miles per person; by 1994 they did 7,900, according to Dr. Lee Schipper, an energy researcher at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory in Berkeley, Calif., who is currently on leave at the International Energy Agency in Paris.
 
 
 
Feed Me, Seymour
 Working with data from the Transportation and Energy Departments, and Lawrence, Mr. Shipper calculated that the actual miles per gallon were 13.11 in 1973. The rate rose to 20.22 in 1985, under pressure from rising prices and the Federal law, the Corporate Average Fuel Economy standard. But by 1994, with the changing mix of vehicles, it dropped to 19.31 -- drivers were trading in their early 1980's compacts for mid-1990's behemoths. And where they used to drive 59 miles an hour, a hair above the speed limit, at 69 miles an hour, a hair above the new limit on some roads, those miles per gallon will continue to decline.
For a long time the two other important trends tended to cancel each other out: Fuel economy rose in the early 1980's, canceling out the increase in prices. Gasoline prices fell in the late 1990's, more than canceling out the decline in fuel economy. As a result, the cost of driving a mile peaked in 1979, at 51 percent higher than it was in 1973, but then it started to fall. By 1994, it was one third less than it was in 1973.
Now, fuel economy is falling and the price per gallon increasing, so the cost per mile is climbing steeply, although it is no way near what the cost per mile was in 1973, Mr. Schipper said. "In terms of the cost curve, we're back to 1987," he said, referring to the recent fuel price increases. "And the world wasn't falling apart when we were paying that much."
 
 
 
Careful What You Ask For
 People today work and shop farther from home, and have grown used to static gas prices even as the cost of everything else has risen.
The price of a kilowatt-hour of electricity, which is the second most common form of energy purchased by consumers, has risen 105 percent since 1978; gas is up 87 percent. But gas prices are always visible at the pump. How many people figure their energy costs by the kilowatt-hour?
Taking inflation into account, the price of gasoline is startlingly low; gas in 1995 was at its lowest in 77 years, said the American Petroleum Institute, a trade association.
Americans reacted to that price predictably. They bought 7.79 million barrels of gasoline a day last year, up from 6.54 million in 1974.
As far as the pinch created by driving big cars for more miles and at higher speeds, Mr. Schipper said, "My sense is, we asked for this."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 12, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Charts last Sunday with an article about gasoline prices misstated the average number of miles driven per person in 1960 and 1965 and the average number of gallons of gasoline used per person in 1960. Miles per person were 3,357 in 1960 and 3,833 in 1965. Gasoline consumption in 1960 was 237 gallons per person.
