HEADLINE: KEEPING TO THE CENTER LANE

BYLINE: By Lisa Belkin; Lisa Belkin is a contributing writer for the Magazine. Her last article, "Showdown at Yazoo Industries," about labor organizers, appeared in January.

 BODY:
TWO DAYS AFTER she told Bob Dole absolutely not, thank you very much, the attention is flattering, but I'm very happy right here in New Jersey, Christine Todd Whitman was on her way to North Dakota. It was a messy exercise, starting with a freaky spring storm at home, where the crocuses were buried in slush, and ending with an even freakier storm in Bismarck. Visibility was a half mile, a foot of ice and snow threatened to close the airport's one main runway and Whitman was scheduled to give the keynote speech at the state Republican convention.
A less-determined person might have turned back, but Christie Whitman didn't become the country's only female governor without determination, and she was particularly set on making this trip. She had given her word to the state's Governor, Edward T. Schafer, a friend and a like-minded moderate in a party where, to her horror, candidates are falling over themselves trying to prove that they are conservative. When you have a goal, it makes sense to keep your promises to people who see things the way you do. And Whitman, who less than three years ago had held no elective office other than local freeholder and who today is one of the most visible politicians in the country, clearly has a goal. 
 Her aim is not, in spite of all the ink and gossip, to be Bob Dole's running mate. If you spend enough time with her, you come to believe that her very public phone call to the presumptive nominee, asking to be taken off the "short list," was not a tactic but a statement of fact. Whitman does not want to be Vice President, and she has long known what she wants. From the time she was married, 22 years ago, she made it clear to her husband that being Governor "was out there as a kind of goal." Five years ago, she rejected advice that she run for the House of Representatives, in a race that she could have won easily, because, she says, "I just didn't want to be a Congressman." Instead, she ran for a Senate seat she had little chance of winning, figuring, "Why not run for a seat I would at least like to have?" She lost that race, but proving nearly everyone wrong, she came spectacularly close to victory.
Her trip to North Dakota, in a less obvious way, was also about showing the doubters. On the charts political pundits carry in their heads, North Dakota is a conservative state. Its Republicans are not supposed to elect social moderates like Schafer. And they are not supposed to welcome an Eastern Governor who, though an emblem of fiscal conservatism, also supports abortion rights, proclaimed a Lesbian and Gay Pride Month and does not support school prayer, instead favoring a moment of silence. In what Dole and Patrick Buchanan are calling "the fight for the heart and soul of the Republican Party," her social views are not supposed to play in North Dakota, or elsewhere in the country for that matter.
Whitman bristles at talk like that. In fact, it is one of the only subjects that can crack the calm, polished air -- envision a Talbots catalogue with a sense of humor -- that she has perfected since she took office in 1994. "I think I am reflective of the true nature of the Republican Party," she says. "Where I am on issues is where so many of the voters want to be." She is mainstream, she says, and the others -- the Christian Coalition, the anti-abortion movement, Buchanan -- have their place under the umbrella but have been getting too much attention.
At times, she seems ready for direct combat with the right. "As the party of Lincoln, the Republican Party ought to respect the personal as well as economic liberty of all people, regardless of race, religion, ethnic background or sexual orientation," she has said. "Intolerance of any group has no place. Discussions on issues of conscience do have a place -- at the family dinner table, in churches and synagogues and between doctor and patient. There is always something a little strange, to put it kindly, when politicians preach morality. I am not so sure we, or anyone else for that matter, have the standing to be the arbiter of values for everyone."
But more often, her prodding of the party is quiet, subtle, patient. Moderate in temperament as well as ideology, she even talks middle-of-the-road. "The bottom line for me is I, as a Republican, have lots of room in my party for people who don't agree with me" on the issue of abortion rights, as well as other social issues, she says, returning to her charming, can't-we-all-be-reasonable tone. "I would hope that those people who don't agree with me have room for me in their party."
To make sure that they do, to persuade them to, is why Whitman makes trips like the one to North Dakota to support like-minded Republicans like Schafer and to drive home the point, with her presence more than her words, that the pendulum is ready to swing away from the right and to stop more or less where she is standing.
In 1996, where the pendulum stops could mean success or failure for the Republican Party. For Dole to win, says Roger Stone, a Dole campaign adviser and a veteran of all three of Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaigns, his party has to be seen as a compassionate party that cares about people. "You've got to demonstrate that there's a diversity of opinion in the party and that we tolerate diverse views," he says. Whitman "is conservative where the country is conservative," adds Stone, who, not incidentally, is making a case with others in the campaign for her selection as the Vice-Presidential nominee, despite her telephone call. "It is where the party should be, too."
After 1996, the track of the pendulum could mean success or failure of a more personal kind. Only if she is right, and her party is what she is betting it is, will she get a chance at another job, one that is not available at the moment but will probably be open in 2000. If you ask her if she plans to run for President, she shrugs, smiles and says: "I don't have the fire in my belly right now to be anything other than what I am. I honestly have not thought about it." But ask those who are close to her, those who are watching her closely, those who have a front-row perspective because they are closer to home, and the answer is yes, that certainly looks like what Christie Whitman wants.
"I honestly believe that she is most interested in being President," says Stephen A. Salmore, a New Jersey consultant to Republican candidates. "That's her real goal."
State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak, a former head of the New Jersey State Democratic Party, agrees. "Her long-range plan," he says, "is to be the savior of the Republicans, after they've seen the error of their ways."
CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN MIGHT NEVER have been born were it not for the Republican Party. Her parents, Eleanor Schley Todd and Webster Bray Todd Sr., met after all four of her grandparents got together during a Republican National Convention and speculated that their children might be a good match.
There is probably not a family in the country with Republican roots deeper than Whitman's. Her maternal grandfather, a banker and Mayor of Far Hills, was a chairman of the New Jersey Republican State Finance Committee. Her paternal grandfather, a builder who oversaw construction of Colonial Williamsburg and Rockefeller Center, was also a chairman of the Republican State Finance Committee. Her maternal grandmother was a New Jersey National Committeewoman for nearly 20 years and the chairwoman of the New Jersey Federation of Republican Women.
Her parents were even more involved in politics than their parents had been. Her father, who was the chairman of the Republican State Committee for 11 years, knew personally every Republican President since Dwight Eisenhower. Her mother, who attended every Republican convention between 1940 and 1976, was the chairwoman of the New Jersey Federation of Republican Women and was a Republican National Committeewoman for 10 years. During the 1950's, The Star-Ledger of Newark ran an article speculating on who might be qualified to run if New Jersey were to elect a female governor. Whitman's mother made the list.
Politics, not surprisingly, was one of two central themes of Whitman's childhood. The other was horses. Born on Sept. 26, 1946, Whitman grew up at Pontefract, a 232-acre working farm with woodlands and a swimming pool, in a neighborhood of farms and estates. Young Christie -- no one ever seems to have called her Christine -- learned to hunt and fish there and to milk a cow, mow a field, bale hay. Today it is still her home, where she raised her own children, Kate, now 19 and a college freshman, and Taylor, 17, a prep-school junior.
When she was 6, her parents were among those who persuaded Eisenhower to run for President, and when Richard Nixon, Eisenhower's Vice-Presidential nominee, made a campaign stop in New Jersey, young Christie and her even-younger friend and neighbor, Steve Forbes, presented Pat Nixon with dolls for Julie and Tricia. When she was 9, she attended her first Republican National Convention, where her mother was active on the organizing committee. While Eisenhower gave his acceptance speech, Christie stood under the podium and clutched a leather golf-tee holder, which she had sewn, and she handed it to the President as he left.
In 1960, a political veteran at the age of 13, she had a philosophical crisis. Going door-to-door with her mother, collecting signatures for Nixon, she began to worry that she was a Republican only because her parents were. "It wasn't a popular thing to be a Republican," she remembers of the time, when young people were supposed to be drawn to John F. Kennedy. "But I decided, after looking at it, that yeah, I believed in the approach of solving problems closer to home."
She did rebel a little. In 1964, as a junior in high school, she threw her support not to Barry Goldwater but to Nelson Rockefeller, over the objections of her father, who felt Rockefeller was too liberal. "We had some heated discussions at the dining-room table," she says. It is a choice she still finds herself defending. At one point during this year's primaries, when Whitman's name was being widely mentioned as a potential Vice-Presidential candidate, Buchanan sneered that he would walk away from a convention that would give that nomination to an abortion-rights supporter and "Rockefeller Republican." Her reaction to that attack is mostly amused, but also defensive.
"I don't regret it for an instant," she says. "My image of Nelson Rockefeller is as someone with whom people identified. He came through town in an open car, and men ran out of a barbershop with lather still on their faces just to wave at this guy. And he really cared about people and you could see it. That's what I mean when I say 'Rockefeller Republican.' I hope I stand for that same connection with people."
After graduating from Wheaton College in 1968 with a degree in government, Whitman spent several months working for Rockefeller's second bid for the Presidential nomination. This time around, her father was supporting him, too. When the nomination went to Nixon, she found a job in Washington, and one day, when her father was in town, he invited her to tag along to a state party luncheon with Rogers Morton, the new head of the Republican National Committee.
Somewhere between salad and dessert, Whitman, not yet a year out of college, told Morton that the Republican Party was not listening closely enough to the needs of the elderly, the newly enfranchised youth and minority groups. As she remembers it, she told Morton, "I'd like to go around and find out from people in these groups what the party can do to attract them."
At the party's expense, she spent three months traveling to 16 cities in seven states and talking with 350 people. The report she helped to put together in 1970 is striking in its conclusions. Twenty-six years ago, Whitman was telling her party much the same thing she is telling it today -- become more diverse and include more points of view "if we want to continue as a viable party."
It is almost too perfect that Whitman's own marriage came about because of the Republican Party. For a few years after she wrote her report -- which, she says, was put in a drawer somewhere and never acted upon -- she worked for the Republican National Committee and then for the Nixon re-election campaign. She needed a date for Nixon's inaugural ball in 1973, and she asked John Whitman, an acquaintance from New York. A young banker at the time, Whitman was the son of a Republican New York City judge, Charles Whitman Jr., and the grandson of a former Republican New York Governor, Charles Whitman Sr. The couple were married a year later.
Sometime before they were married, they discussed their future. "Our marriage vows," her husband has joked, "should have said 'in sickness and in health and in politics.' "
Whitman is careful to say that she and John did not sit down in 1974 and sketch a path to the state house. "It wasn't 'I'll run for this, and then I'll be appointed to that, and then I'll be Governor,' " she says. "You just can't do that in politics. You've got to take advantage of the opportunities when they open up for you."
But though it might not have been a plan, it was always a possibility. "I always knew I was going to be involved in politics," she says, weighing her words, seeming not to want this anecdote to make her look calculating and ambitious. "John always wants to 'go for the gold,' as he says. And we talked about it in just kind of a general way that the ultimate thing would be Governor if that were ever possible. Did I always in the back of my mind think being Governor would be the greatest job in the world? Yes. I thought it would be wonderful."
Her friends, however, are not quite as guarded. "She did want to be Governor from the beginning," says one of her oldest friends, Nancy Risque Rohrbach. "She won't say it that way, but she always knew what she wanted to be."
IN THE HOURS BEFORE WHITMAN'S PLANE landed in Bismarck, the main hall of the Civic Center filled slowly as delegates trickled in. Speakers came and went on the podium, where they stood before the huge, bobbing elephant constructed of red, white and blue balloons and took care of party business. Some delegates paid attention, while others wandered among the dozens of folding tables set along the back walls of the room, staffed with believers and stacked with pamphlets: "Buchanan for President." "Dole in '96." "Dina Butcher for Ag Commissioner."
At the table for the North Dakota Christian Coalition, the central piece of literature read: "Governor Whitman is a tall, elegant woman with style who claims to be a Rockefeller Republican. Newsweek calls her the purest example of a Volvo Republican -- trendy and on the road. In the mid-1960's she joined a demonstration . . . to protest the arrest of birth-control activist Bil Baird. The 'old line feminist' now calls on the G.O.P. to remove the anti-abortion plank from the party platform."
The party Whitman's grandparents helped shape has grown decidedly more conservative. In 1976, 48 percent of delegates to the Republican National Convention identified themselves as "conservative," and in 1992, 63 percent chose that description. In exit polls so far this year, 21 percent of Republican primary voters described themselves as "very conservative" and 37 percent as "somewhat conservative."
The conservative base is what gave the Republicans the majority in the House and Senate in 1994, for the first time in 40 years. But polls show that voters -- particularly women -- are becoming alarmed by some of the actions of those they sent to Congress two years ago. A New York Times/CBS poll last month found that if Congressional elections were held today, women would favor Democrats by a 16-point margin, compared with a 3-point margin in 1994. Similarly, while Clinton and Dole are favored equally among men, Clinton leads Dole by nearly 20 points among women. Because of his weakness with female voters, Dole lags behind Clinton by 10 percent overall.
The need to win back the moderates, and the women, creates an opportunity and a dilemma for Whitman. The single issue that has come to stand for the cluster of issues on which the gender gap is based is abortion. "The abortion issue has become symbolic of the power of the religious political right over the Republican Party," says Tanya Melich, a longtime Republican who writes of her disillusionment with the party's move toward the right in her book, "The Republican War Against Women."
Whitman says the Republican platform would be more inviting to all voters without an anti-abortion plank. In 1992, that plank stated that "the unborn child has a fundamental individual right to life which cannot be infringed" and called for "a human-life amendment to the Constitution" and the "appointment of judges who respect traditional family values and the sanctity of innocent human life." Such language, Whitman says, must be changed. It need not be replaced by an abortion-rights statement, she says, realistically, but "something that recognizes that you can be pro-choice and still be a good Republican."
"Because of the last convention," she says, "where women really felt that there wasn't a place for them, and where you had Pat Buchanan on prime time saying some things that were pretty divisive, if there isn't some change to the language, it's going to make the job of the candidate so much more difficult going into the fall elections."
But from where she sits, her next move is not as simple as forcing a platform fight at the Republican Convention in San Diego in August and becoming a hero, as many party members who support abortion rights say they expect her to do. It's not that she has doubts on the issue itself. She believes, unequivocally, in a woman's right to choose, a belief so longstanding that the only protest she ever attended was the one in the 1960's, when Bil Baird was arrested for tossing packets of birth-control pills to an audience on a college campus.
As telling as that story is, what's equally important is the fact that she spent most of that protest trying to stay out of the newspaper pictures. "I was like, 'Please, don't let Dad see me. Hold the sign here,' " she recalls, putting her hand in front of her face.
The grown-up Whitman will face the cameras head on and say she supports abortion rights. "I believe it's a very personal decision between a woman and her doctor," she says. "I don't think the Government has any business telling me what to do with my body. It's actually a very conservative position."'
But at the same time, she tries not to say it all the time, for fear of becoming a one-issue candidate. She declined an invitation to serve on the advisory board of the Republican Coalition for Choice, said the group's chairwoman, Susan R. Cullman. When the subject of abortion comes up with members of Whitman's press staff, they are all careful to say, "Remember, abortion is not her central thing." Ask her about it directly and she says: "While it's an issue of importance to me, it's not my major issue. It's not the definition of who I am."
That hesitancy is magnified by the fact that while the majority of American voters are supporters of a woman's right to abortion -- as even the majority of Republican primary voters are -- Bob Dole is not. He has said, through a spokesman, that he "supports a constitutional ban on abortion with exceptions for rape or incest or when the life of the mother is in danger" and that "he will fight for a pro-life plank in the 1996 Republican platform that will reflect the Republican Party's historic commitment to protecting the rights of the unborn."
But the last thing he wants is a brawl over the issue at the convention, which is supposed to be a televised demonstration of party unity. "I don't think Bob Dole wants abortion discussed at the convention," Salmore, the consultant, says. "And I don't think she wants to be the person who defeated Bob Dole because she waged an ugly floor fight in prime time."
So what will she do? Whitman, who can be very precise when she wants to be, is currently being quite vague. "I intend to be part of the discussion," she says. "There are a lot of different ways to skin this cat, and you can do it very quietly." She has not yet spoken to Dole about her views, she says, although she intends to. She is still deciding when the best time would be and whether to do so "by phone or in a letter."
"There are a lot of discussions going on behind the scenes," she says, declining to be more specific. "I don't think it serves anybody's best interests to get into a shouting match if we really want to make a difference."
It is hard to imagine, however, that the shouting can be avoided. If the "behind the scenes" discussions somehow result in an agreement to eliminate the plank, then Buchanan has pledged to make a lot of noise. "I'm going to San Diego," he told a cheering audience last month, "and if you think you're going to take that plank out of there, I'll tell some of those liberals up in Washington, 'You're going to have to come over me and my people.' "
And if, as is more likely, the discussions fail and the language remains, there will be another kind of fight. Groups like Cullman's have sworn not to go quietly in the name of unity, and a few politicians, most recently George Pataki, the New York Governor, who also has close ties to Dole, say they will push the issue, too. They assume Whitman will join them. She probably will.
"If there comes a point where there's going to be a floor fight, I'll be there," she says. But the statement clearly troubles her. As strongly as she believes in a woman's right to choose, she believes just as strongly in the Republican Party, and the trick here, as in everything else she does lately, is to find a way of supporting one without jeopardizing or abandoning the other.
THE PLANNERS OF THIS YEAR'S ST. Patrick's Day parade in Somerville, N.J., decided -- poorly, as it turned out -- to place Whitman behind the float of the parade's main sponsor. As a result, the crowd's view of the Governor was blocked by a huge, tethered, hot-air balloon that urged, "Reach High With Summit Bank." Most onlookers could not see her until she had all but walked past, at which point they yelled, "Hi, Christie!" and "Come back here, Christie!" So she detoured to the curb and shook countless hands, slowing the parade to her pace.
She was having a wonderful time. She has long had a soft spot for Somerville; it was where she first held elective office, in 1982. In the years before that, she had become a trustee of a local community college and a member of the Upper Raritan Watershed Association, and with time, she let the local party leaders know that she would be interested in bigger things.
Then the county chairman asked her to run for the Board of Freeholders of Somerset County, of which Somerville is the seat. Even she credits her family's name for her nomination. Whitman served one three-year term, was re-elected and served two years of that second term. She left in 1988, when Gov. Tom Kean appointed her to the three-member Board of Public Utilities, where she stayed until 1989, when she decided to run for the United States Senate.
She planned that next step much the way she does everything else -- methodically, analytically and with an eye on the long-term goal. "I'd really come to the conclusion that I wanted to get back to elected office," she says, adding that the "presumption" was she would run for a vacant Congressional seat in her district.
"I knew that I could win that," she says, but adds: "I didn't have the patience for that kind of legislative process on the House side. I didn't want to have to get into office and immediately have to start to run again, with an election in two years.
"So I looked at it and said, 'O.K., if I want to be taken seriously, if I want people to know that I do want to be in this ball game, I've got to run for something.' I said, 'Look, why not run for the seat that I'd at least like to have, which is the Senate?' "
The race was hers without a primary because no other Republicans thought they had a chance. The two-term incumbent was Bill Bradley -- Princeton all-America, Rhodes scholar, former star forward of the New York Knicks, a formidable fund raiser who had won his previous race with 64 percent of the vote, even while Reagan won the state.
"I knew it was a long shot," Whitman says. "But I looked at it as a golden opportunity. It would give me statewide exposure. It would be a lie to say I didn't realize this was a good way to prepare" for a gubernatorial race. What no one knew, however, was that Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, would incur the voters' wrath by increasing taxes by $2.8 billion and that Bradley's refusal to condemn, or even comment on, that increase (a decision he now describes as a mistake) would become the dominant issue of the Bradley-Whitman campaign. "Get Florio. Dump Bradley," pro-Whitman bumper stickers read, and the voters almost did, giving Bradley a third term by only 50 percent of the vote.
Nearly all analysts believe Whitman would have won had she received enough support from her own party. It is a subject that still rankles her. Bradley outspent Whitman $12 million to $1 million, and the Republican National Senatorial Committee gave her $420,000 for her race, $180,000 less than it had promised. The state Republican Party, which her father and both grandfathers had run, donated $5,000. George Bush, whom her mother considered a friend and for whom her mother had given fund raisers at Pontefract when he ran in '80 and in '88, would not go to New Jersey to campaign for her.
GOVERNOR SCHAFER AND HIS WIFE MET THE Whitmans' plane (on loan from the Republican National Committee) at the airport and rarely left their side after that. Bringing such a big name to such a small state was a coup for the Schafers, and they escorted the Whitmans to Bismarck's Civic Center, where 200 people had paid $250 apiece to support Schafer's re-election bid and to shake Whitman's hand. An hour later, the hosts guided the guests of honor into a room where 900 people had paid $96 each to support the state's Republican Party, to eat three kinds of starch donated by Dakota Growers Pasta and to shake Whitman's hand.
The next morning, Schafer introduced Whitman to the 1,250 delegates in the convention hall. He said that in 1993, "Christie Whitman made a campaign promise to lower New Jersey's income tax by 30 percent. Two years later she fulfilled that promise." As he shook her hand himself, the crowd cheered with an enthusiasm that Whitman is getting used to.
Whitman is a star in the Republican Party because she kept a campaign promise. Wherever she goes, she is introduced as she was in North Dakota, as the Governor who kept her word. What is forgotten in all the applause is that she was a last-minute convert to the tax-cut cause, unveiling her plan only weeks before Election Day, in a desperate attempt to save her campaign.
While everything seemed to go her way during her race against Bradley, nothing did in her fight with Florio. She was criticized for everything. Some of the attacks were over things she did: she had hired two illegal aliens to care for her home and her children. (She was spared on that issue only because her primary opponent had committed the same offense, as had one of Florio's top aides.) Other criticism was caused by what she said: while defending a homestead rebate program that gave a maximum of $500 to property owners, she noted that "as funny as it seems, $500 is a lot."
So, six weeks before Election Day, when the most favorable polls showed the race to be dead even and the least favorable said she was 9 points behind, she proposed a 30 percent tax cut -- 10 percent a year for three years -- for taxpayers with total taxable income of not more than $80,000. Developed in part by Steve Forbes, it was supposed to be the single stroke to turn the voters around, but one week after she announced it, polls showed she was losing by 21 points. Florio dubbed the plan a "voodoo redo," economists said it was vague and ill advised and even members of her own party described the tax cut as unlikely to happen. Now pollsters were finding that voters saw her not only as rich and removed but also as dishonest.
Indirectly, however, the proposal did have a revivifying effect. It brought the focus back to Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase, where it had been during the Bradley race, and because Whitman had nothing to lose, it made her more relaxed when she campaigned. Slowly her numbers began to improve. On the Sunday before Election Day, Dole campaigned with her from morning to night. That Tuesday, she beat Florio by one percentage point.
Whitman saw the election as a tax-cut mandate, and minutes after she was sworn in as the 13th female governor in the history of the country and the first female Governor of New Jersey, she started to keep her promise. She announced that she would ask the Legislature to make the first stage of the tax cut retroactive to Jan. 1, which was 17 days before her inauguration. In effect, it was a numbers game -- instead of a 10 percent cut effective in July, she was asking for a 5 percent cut effective all year. "I said I would put $1.4 billion of your tax dollars back in your pocket," she said, in the quiet, understated tone that she uses in speeches as well as in conversation. "Why wait until the next fiscal year starts in July? . . . Let's not keep economic growth waiting another minute."
When Whitman unveiled her first budget in March, there were more surprises. In spite of a drop in revenues because of the tax cut, there were few corresponding drops in spending. The proposed budget was about 1 percent smaller than the final budget of the Florio administration, and most of the nearly $2 billion gap she inherited was to be closed by fiscal maneuvering, particularly by changing the funding formulas and reducing the amount the state contributed to the pension and benefit funds of state workers. The latter device, she argues, is not as risky as it can be made to sound, because, she says, the pension funds were overfi-nanced.
Groups like the New Jersey Education Association and the Communications Workers of America, the state's two largest public-employee unions, disagree. The Whitman changes are a time bomb set to detonate more than a decade from now, they say, when there will not be enough money to pay promised benefits. "What the Governor calls pension reform jeopardizes the security of hundreds of thousands of workers," says Lynn Maher, a spokeswoman for the education association. "And when it crashes, she won't be here."
Whitman responds that she is confident of the analysis of her actuaries, that the pension system is adequately financed, and she is unconcerned by the analysis of other actuaries that it is not. "Sure, you can say 5 years, 10 years, 15 years, maybe the world is going to come to an end, and something bad might happen," she says. "But you know, everything might not come to an end and it might be good."
Most of the state's voters, as well as most of the Legislature, seemed equally unconcerned. The budget passed easily and attention followed. Dole told Mirabella magazine, "Christine Whitman is a rising star in the party, with virtually unlimited potential." People magazine listed her as one of the 25 Most Intriguing People of 1994.
A good soldier during the 1994 midyear elections, she campaigned for 22 candidates all over the country -- many of whom had views she disagreed with -- and raised $3.5 million. Eighteen of those candidates won. In January 1995 she delivered her second budget address to the Legislature, saying she would schedule the last third of her tax cut a year ahead of schedule. The next day, she delivered the Republicans' response to President Clinton's State of the Union message, the first woman and the first governor to do so. House Speaker Newt Gingrich, who had selected Whitman, said "she is clearly just a very articulate and attractive advocate of our cause." Everyone politely ignored the fact that when she is asked if she would have signed the Contract With America had she been running for Congress, she says: "I don't usually sign things like that. I don't get into that kind of stuff."
ON A RECENT Saturday morning, Whitman awoke early, dressed in hunting camouflage and waded through thigh-deep snow near the Delaware Water Gap, looking for bears. For the third time since she took office, she was joining the state's park rangers to place ear tags on the bear cubs born during the winter. There were no paths on this trip; even so, she easily kept pace with the rangers as they located a still-hibernating mother bear who was wearing a radio collar, approached her silently from behind and immobilized her with a syringe attached to a long metal pole.
Then, as the rangers weighed, measured and poked at the grown-up bear, Whitman did what she had come to do. She swaddled the pink-nosed cub inside her jacket so only the cub's head peered out. "It's fun being Governor," she would say later in the day. "The bennies," as in benefits, "of this job are great. I've gone up in an F-16. I've driven a Humvee, a Cobra helicopter." And when the New Jersey Devils won the Stanley Cup, "we went down on the ice."
The cub stayed in her coat for quite a while but at one point reached up and cut her on the lip with a tiny but impressive claw. "Bear mauls Governor," she joked, unfazed, making no move to wipe at the slight stream of blood. "Are you a Democrat?" she asked the cub.
In the year and a half since her State of the Union response, Christie Whitman has suffered a few political scratches. Her tax cut, while still hailed as a promise kept, has not solved the state's financial problems. When she introduced the plan during the campaign, she said it was designed to bring 450,000 jobs to New Jersey, the number of jobs she estimates were lost to Florio's policies. So far, however, the state has seen an increase of 116,000 jobs, one-fourth of which, critics say, are in the retail trade category that economists label "eating and drinking," meaning fast-food workers and table waiters.
"Those are hardly the kinds of jobs you would want to create to underpin a strong economy," said Neil Upmeyer, president of the nonpartisan, nonprofit Center for Analysis of Public Issues. Whitman agrees, to a point. "As far as the mix is concerned, you always want higher-paying jobs," she says. "But I do believe you also need entry-level jobs, because you're not going to move people off of welfare and into middle-level management."
She has also been the object of sharp criticism for her environmental policies. Whitman identifies herself as an environmentalist. She clearly glories in the outdoors, and shortly before she started her hike to find the bears, she stood in the snow with the park rangers and talked about the laws of nature and the fact that the coyotes around Pontefract are trying to kill her sheep.
She does not believe, however, that love of nature and respect for the environment are incompatible with easing toxic-cleanup restrictions and cutting the budget of the Department of Environmental Protection. Those actions, among others, led a coalition of 18 environmental lobbying groups to give her some failing grades on a "Midterm Report Card on the Whitman Administration and the Environment," released early this year.
She is angry at the slap from a group she claims to feel kinship with, on an issue that New Jersey voters feel particularly strongly about. But the environmental lobby, she says, will have to accept the fact that the rules of engagement have changed. "Environmental protection doesn't have to be confrontational with business," she says. "Confrontation is the way they carved out their niche in life. But it is not the only way."
Lately, as she gets closer to the end of this first term, there are also signs that the Legislature, which in 1994 was willing to pass her tax cut before she had even unveiled her budget, is not as eager to grant whatever Whitman might ask. Last year, for instance, neither the State Senate nor the Assembly, both with Republican majorities, even voted on her proposal to rescue the failing charity health-care system by increasing the tax the state collects on cigarettes.
The Legislature's new willingness to take on the Governor is either a reflection or a cause of a dip in her job-approval ratings that is beginning to show up in opinion polls. It is possible to make too much of the change. She still has favorable ratings that would thrill most politicians. But whereas in February 1995, the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University found that 56 percent of voters thought she was doing an "excellent" or "good" job, by this Febuary, the figure had dropped to 49 percent.
Shortly after this last poll was being taken, Cliff Zukin, an Eagleton professor of political science who conducts focus groups for The Record, a Hackensack newspaper, was listening to a group of voters, who were supposed to be talking about the Presidential election. They started discussing Christie Whitman instead. They were not pleased with her, nor was a second group that Zukin gathered a week later.
"The tax cut is starting to turn against her," Zukin said. "They feel there's no follow-up to the tax cut. The rest of the country is wowed by it, but here there was a feeling that there was no second act."
Or maybe the fact that the rest of the country is "wowed" is the problem. During the session, Zukin asked, "Does she have an agenda?" meaning, he says, "Does she have a clear idea of what she wants to do for New Jersey?" The group reacted with sarcastic chuckles. "Yeah, she has an agenda," Zukin says they answered. "She has her own agenda."
WHITMAN DID NOT SPEAK long in North Dakota. Shorter, she has learned, gets you invited back. Through much of her 20-minute speech, George Schubert, a professor from Grand Forks, nodded energetically, causing his Uncle Sam stovepipe hat to bounce on his head.
"She's young, mature, vibrant, a go-getter," he said. "She's going places."
Around the audience, the reaction was generally the same. "When they say, 'What kind of Republican are you?' I say, 'I'm a Christie Whitman Republican,' " said Ellie Schafer, the Governor's 28-year-old-daughter, not at all apologetic about slighting her own father with that declaration.
"She's the future of the party," gushed Sandi Tabor, executive director of the State Bar Association of North Dakota. "I was disappointed when she took herself out of consideration for Vice President."
Whitman says she carefully thought about how she would phrase things when she placed her phone call to Bob Dole: "I didn't want to sound like a conceited, pushy broad, saying, 'I know you have a list and I'm sure I'm at the top of it, but no thanks.' Nor did I want it to seem personal, like a decision against him."
The words she says she decided on were: "I know there's probably no list at all, but I just wanted you to know that I absolutely mean what I have been saying about wanting to remain here doing the job I'm doing. This is not a reflection on you, or on your campaign, and I wish you every success, but I love being Governor."
Dole's response, she says, was: "No, I don't have a list. They're telling me I ought to have one. I appreciate your call."
The reason she decided to make the call, her aides say, was that the speculation about her place in the Vice-Presidential sweepstakes was getting in the way of everything else she was trying to do. "Everywhere she went," says her chief of staff, Peter Verniero, "every press conference she held, all people asked was the question."
But as with every high-profile political decision, there is talk that it was more complicated than that. First, there is the question of whether she really meant it. Forbes, whose aides hint he is still annoyed at Whitman for telling the press he should drop out of the Presidential race before she told him, says she took herself out of the running only "theoretically," adding, "I'm sure if Senator Dole calls, she wouldn't turn him down."
Which leads to the question of whether she would have been offered the job at all. Roger Stone, the Dole adviser, says she not only did have a chance but still does. Others disagree.
"Given Dole's age, the person who becomes the Vice-Presidential nominee really is the representative of the Republican Party in the 21st century," says Tanya Melich. The religious right, she says, is "not going to let an independent-minded woman who is pro-choice become the leader."
Lyn Nofziger, a former Reagan aide and a friend of Whitman's who helped her with her gubernatorial and senatorial campaigns, says, "I don't think that anyone's going to ask her to be the Vice President, because I don't think the party is moving in her direction."
If no one was going to ask her to be Vice President, the theory goes, Whitman acted to turn down the nomination before Dole could turn her down, a political move with its own benefits. "Look at the league she puts herself in," Stone says. "Look at the only two people in the country who are issuing statements taking themselves out of the running" he adds, referring to Colin Powell.
Then there's the argument that even if the nomination were offered, accepting it would be a political misstep. "With only two years in office, she is vulnerable to questions of experience," says Zukin. "If she completes a term or two, that's less of an issue."
If that is the plan -- to wait until her experience catches up with her ambitions -- it requires a faith in her policies, a belief that they will help her rather than blow up in her face in four years. And Whitman has no shortage of faith in herself. "I don't second-guess myself," she says. "I make a decision carefully, and I am comfortable with it."
It also requires a belief that given four more years to wrestle with its identity, her party will have nudged itself a little farther toward the middle. Whitman seems to have that belief, too. "Margaret Thatcher once told me: 'Political parties are like a bird. They have a right wing and a left wing, but the heart and the brains are in the center.' "
Finally, such a plan also requires forethought and patience, and the same woman who decided 20 years ago that the Governor's mansion was a reasonable goal doesn't seem to lack those qualities, either.
Does she think she would be a good Vice President?
"Yes," she says. "I could do that job."
"President?"
"I think I need more experience before I step up to that."
What does she plan to do when she's finished being Governor?
 "There are times I think, 'Gee, I'd love to just go off with the kids. I think of all the places I'd love to travel.' "
Travel? Not run for President? She leans forward in her chair, as if to tell a secret. And she almost does.
"There are times, there's a twinge, when people say, 'Don't you get mad that the only time they mention you is for Vice President, while all the guys are talked about as President?' And I'll think, 'Yeah.' I'll think, 'Why not?' "

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 5 about Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, which discussed her support of abortion rights, referred incorrectly to the 1967 arrest of a birth control advocate in Massachusetts, and misspelled his given name. He is Bill Baird, not Bil. He was arrested on charges of providing a college student with birth control devices -- it was illegal in Massachusetts to distribute such devices to unmarried people -- not for tossing packets of birth control pills to an audience on a college campus.

HEADLINE: Patents;
Backyard summer heat got you down? Feeling as if you're in a daze? Hey, get into a fog instead.

BYLINE: By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
IF the backyard is too sweltering for a barbecue this summer or the state fair offers no respite from the sun, never fear -- two California inventors have patented a device that can cool a hot day.
Mark Hensley and Michael Jones invented a system that reduces the heat outside with fog made from water that is sprayed along with forced air into outdoor areas. They say the mercury will dive as much as 25 degrees, even in humid areas, and without getting people wet. 
 When the system is working, it looks as if spray nozzles are directing streams of fog into outdoor space. The temperature is lowered because an exchange of heat takes place between the evaporating fog and the outside air. The fog evaporates even in humid areas because forced air coming from the system increases the volume of dry air outside.
"The use of fog or mist for evaporative cooling has been around for 50 years," said Jim Nagourney, president of Cool Zone Products and Promotions Inc., the California company that holds the patent. "But it never worked outside desert areas. If you have 70 percent humidity, there's not a lot of room left for that air to absorb water. If you add water to the air where there is already water in the air from humidity, it can't evaporate."
The Cool Zone system eliminates that problem by adding dry air to the atmosphere.
"That does three things," Mr. Nagourney said. "It increases the total volume of air in a given space, it helps spread the fog so one area is not just saturated with water, and it causes more rapid evaporation."
"So it cools without dampness," he added.
The invention uses a high-pressure pump to force water through a hose and out a series of nozzles placed at intervals along the hose. The water can be ordinary tap water. The nozzles reduce the water to a fog so fine that the unit goes through only a gallon and a half of water an hour. Encircling each nozzle are air holes. Forced air is pumped from those holes as fog is sprayed from the nozzle.
"After the combination of fog and air travels about six to eight feet, all the fog evaporates and the air is cooled," Mr. Nagourney said. That means the nozzles must be placed at least six feet away from people. The system can cool a radius of about 10 to 20 feet, he added, and operates with about one-fifth the energy required for a conventional air-conditioner. It cools only as long as it is running -- there is no cumulative effect.
The company has designed a 7-foot tall backyard model with a pump in its base and a tube that inflates to 19 inches in diameter. The tower-like unit has fog nozzles and air holes around its circumference.
"In about a year we'll get to the point where we can economically produce these towers for backyard use," Mr. Nagourney predicted. "If you put that unit on your patio, within 15 feet in any direction the temperature would drop 25 degrees using an ordinary garden hose and a 110 outlet."
For now, however, the company is focusing on selling its system to factories where workers need spot cooling. One pump can generate cooling fog for several hose-and-nozzle units. Cool Zone has also licensed the system to the Coca-Cola Bottling Company for exclusive use at Coke operations in amusement parks, festivals and zoos. Mr. Hensley and Mr. Jones received patent 5,497,633.

The Look of Neon Without the Cost
The bright, colorful sign on the pastry department at the supermarket may not be neon, but dry gel on a panel. A Canadian company has patented a sign-making system using a luminous gel that it says glows as brightly as neon at a fraction of the cost.
"It's an acrylic gel, a liquid plastic that is fluorescent," said Michael Ivezic, chairman and chief executive of Luminart Inc. The gel, called Luminite, comes in three forms, each with 10 colors -- a fluorescent designed for use with black lights and indoor- and outdoor-quality versions.
"It has the consistency of toothpaste and is an ultraviolet-curable material," Mr. Ivezic said. "You have the ability to create intricate graphics and patterns with the gel. It will stay in its soft state until exposed to ultraviolet light and then it cures to a hard, durable plastic."
When light is shined from behind the hardened gel, it glows like neon.
"The light passes through the Luminite and gives it that unique glow," Mr. Ivezic said. "The material doesn't have its own glow or light-retaining characteristics. It needs a light source to work."
Mr. Ivezic said Wal-Mart reported a 30 percent increase in sales in departments where Luminite signs were used.
Luminart has already sold Luminite sign-making equipment around the world. The company received patent 5,512,122.
Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

HEADLINE: Treasury Has Busy Auction Schedule This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week consists of auctions on the first four days of the week, starting today with the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Tuesday the Treasury will auction a 3-year note; on Wednesday, a 10-year note, and on Thursday, a 36-day cash management bill.
At the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.99 percent, traders said, and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.12 percent. In when-issued trading the 3-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.33 percent and the 10-year note at 6.87 percent.

HEADLINE: An After-School Job That's Not Kids' Stuff;
Wanted: Web Designers and Programmers; $25/hr.; Need Parents' Consent

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: BROOKLINE, Mass.

 BODY:
When the school day ends at 2:15 P.M., Jascha Franklin-Hodge ambles out of the red-brick edifice of Brookline High School and makes the uphill trek on Tappan Street, heading for work. In another time, his after-school job probably would have been delivering newspapers or pumping gas.
But the 17-year-old junior in high school works at a local Internet access company, Software Tool and Die Inc., doing programming and maintenance for $8 an hour and unlimited Internet time. At school, Mr. Franklin-Hodge has learned French, but he has taught himself the vernaculars of computing like Basic, C, Perl and Java. He speaks of computer languages with the familiarity of a carpenter discussing his hammer and saw. "They're like a box of tools," he said, "and you have to choose the tool that is most effective for the job at hand." 
 Mr. Franklin-Hodge also runs a popular site on the World Wide Web, called Laughweb, a smorgasbord of jokes plucked off the Internet. That's for fun, but besides working for the local Internet company he has done contract jobs, for $15 to $25 an hour, that range from computer repairs to sophisticated programming assignments. His tax return for 1995 listed income of $6,000.
As computing has been transformed in the last generation, from the microprocessor to the World Wide Web, the youngest segment of the industry's work force has undergone a transformation as well. Young people with impressive computer skills are no longer simply prodigies, pushed, like young musicians or gymnasts, to excel at an early age. They have moved into the mainstream and their numbers are rising steadily. Mr. Franklin-Hodge is one of many teen-agers who labor on the entrepreneurial fringes of the information age.
Since the 1970's, there have been precocious young computer enthusiasts looking to make money from their skills. And the handful of teen-age success stories, like William H. Gates of the Microsoft Corporation and Michael Dell of the Dell Computer Corporation, both college dropouts at 19, are part of the industry's folklore.
Yet today's high-tech youth movement, by all accounts, is a broader phenomenon, as more young people become computer literate and as the reach of personal computers and the Internet grows. "There are lots of kids doing this kind of part-time work now," said Dennis Allison, a programmer who teaches software engineering at Stanford University. "The level of skill and comfort that young people have with computers today is much greater."
For the young people, the jobs are more fun and generally pay better than working at McDonald's or the corner gas station. For companies, especially small ones, teen-agers offer a bargain-basement work force to experiment with new but unproven high-tech forays like putting up a company Web site.
"Sure, these young people come cheaper," Mr. Allison said. "But this is also a new medium and these young people are the ones who really understand this medium. It's a generational thing."
Advances in technology like multimedia, which includes graphics, music and artwork, have also made computing more appealing and accessible to more young people. Traditionally, computer software has attracted people skilled in "minute precision thinking," noted Seymour Papert, the Lego professor of learning research at the M.I.T. Media Lab. "But it's becoming more flexible and suiting people with different cognitive styles."
Rachael Cannara, an 18-year-old senior at Menlo School, a private high school in Atherton, Calif., developed a taste for computing only recently, even though her mother is an executive at a computer software company. Yet an interest in astrophysics forced her to become familiar with computing, because her senior project has been to make a multimedia textbook about the search for habitable planets.
For the project, Ms. Cannara has had to master the rudiments of multimedia software and hypertext, which links pages of related text and graphics. She says she has enjoyed her labors, and they have paid off. She has landed a summer job making an educational CD-ROM for NASA's Ames Research Center in Mountain View, Calif.
As computing has become more diverse, its image has been altered among teen-agers. The stereotypical notions of "nerds" and "geeks" are passe to the Nintendo generation. Today, students immersed in computers are called "techies" and they may well dress in black, or wear Doc Marten boots and sport ponytails as Mr. Franklin-Hodge does. It is a far cry from the days of the plastic pocket protector.
"When I was younger, people who were really into computers were considered weird," Mr. Franklin-Hodge said. "But that's not true anymore. The Internet has made all this cool."
The explosive growth of the Internet has also opened up the industry to teen-agers in a way not seen for more than a decade, when the personal computer business was starting to take off. The demand for Web sites and other Internet software is enormous, and fulfilling that demand is often best done by skilled individuals instead of large companies.
"Whenever there is a huge shift in the industry, it creates opportunities for new people, and age isn't a barrier," said Will Harvey, who was once a precocious techie.
To Mr. Harvey, who is now 29, the situation today has a familiar look. He got into computing as a teen-ager in the early 1980's, taking money from his paper route to buy an Apple II and writing his first program, a grade-tracking data base for teachers, when he was 15.
Those were the scrappy "zip-lock" days of the software business, he recalled, before shrink-wrap packaging, when many applications programs were published on shoestring budgets. Mr. Harvey sold his first program, a simple music notation product called Music Construction Set, to a big company, Electronic Arts Inc., when he was 16.
For years afterward, Mr. Harvey was a contract game designer mainly for Electronic Arts, earning a six-figure annual income since he was 18. He continued his education, and recently received his Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford University. Today, he has a two-bedroom condominium in Palo Alto, a Mercedes in the garage and a small Internet software start-up company, called Sandcastle.
Now an industry veteran, Mr. Harvey recalls his entrepreneurial teen-age years with fondness. For him, as for today's teen-agers, the appeal of computing was in the satisfactions of craftsmanship, building something that is logical and controllable. His parents, both professionals, were aware of his interest, he said, but never prodded him. "I think you'll find that most kids push themselves," he said. "Computing isn't like baseball or figure skating, where the parents think they know a lot about it."
Indeed, there is a digital generation gap in many such families. Parental reaction ranges from amusement to amazement, but there is often scant comprehension. Dustin Rodriguez is a 17-year-old high school junior who lives in Moundsville, W. Va. He programs in Basic, Assembly and is working with C.
Mr. Rodriguez earns about $60 a week, working after school for a local mail service company. He has written a program to automate the company's billing, accounting and data base ledgers, and he has also fashioned Web pages for businesses.
Mr. Rodriguez lives in what was traditionally a coal-mining region, which suffers from high unemployment as it struggles to find new industries. His father, Larry, works in a chemical factory, and his mother, Susan, works in a greenhouse. Their son's interest was stimulated by a computer literacy program at the Moundsville Junior High School. "We didn't encourage Dustin at all," Mrs. Rodriguez said. "My husband and I don't know much about computers. What he does just amazes us."
The business side of being a teen-age computer consultant can be daunting. Age may not be a barrier to getting into the business, but it can limit the compensation. "People take one look at me, and they figure they're not going to pay this kid $50 an hour," said Benjamin Kallos, a 15-year-old at the Bronx High School of Science, an elite public school in New York City.
So the high school sophomore, whose home page on the Web proclaims "Kallos Consulting" in bold red letters, charges $15 or $20 an hour.
Some businesses in New York seem to regard the high school as a job shop for Web site work. Steve Kalin, an assistant principal, says small companies occasionally call the school looking for a student to make Web pages, and more are calling all the time.
"Even the kind of kids who would have worked on the school newspaper in the past are often more interested in electronic publishing now," Mr. Kalin said. "They're making Web sites."
In Phoenix, Laurence Hartje, a 15-year-old sophomore at Thunderbird High School, has taken on a partner to help with price negotiations -- his father, Will. "I think businesses feel more comfortable with an adult there," the teen-ager explained.
At 13, Mr. Hartje became a certified product specialist for Windows, the popular Microsoft operating system, by passing a standard test given by the company. The certification amounts to corporate approval that Mr. Hartje is a Windows expert.
Recently, he has begun making Web pages, including a site for a local travel company to advertise tour packages. And at 15, Mr. Hartje is concerned about upgrading his skills to stay in step with market demand. So he is learning Java, a programming language developed by Sun Microsystems that can add animation to Web sites.
"If I continue to develop Web sites, Java will be very important for me," Mr. Hartje said.
In this fast-changing field, it is perhaps only natural that today's skilled teen-agers must worry not only about new technologies but also about competition from an aspiring crop of younger newcomers. Like Jeremy Liebs, a 12-year-old sixth grader from San Mateo, Calif. He has done some programming, and says he has thought about making money from it but hasn't yet.
His father, David, is a software programmer and recognizes the early flair that his son has displayed. "I'm certainly not pushing him to be a programmer," Mr. Liebs said. "But I suppose the thing we've got to guard against is him quitting school at 16 or 17 to go off and make money in the industry."

HEADLINE: MAJOR CRIMES FELL IN '95, EARLY DATA BY F.B.I. INDICATE

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
Serious crimes dropped across the nation in 1995 for the fourth consecutive year, led by an 8 percent decrease in homicides, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
President Clinton was quick to issue a statement taking some credit for the decline. "Because of our tough and smart decisions to put more cops on the street and get kids, guns and drugs off the street, we are now beginning to reverse the trend in violent crime," Mr. Clinton said. 
 But some experts cautioned that the reasons for the drop are unclear and that it is still too early to conclude whether the country has finally broken out of a pattern of consistently high crime rates since an explosion of violence in the late 1960's.
Among the possible explanations for the recent decline are more aggressive police tactics, an increase in the number of criminals in prison and a stabilization of turf battles between drug dealers that began with the epidemic of crack cocaine.
The experts also warned that the new figures, while heartening, mask a continued rapid rise in violent crime among young people that could soon lead to an increase in crime rates because the number of teen-agers in the population is expected to grow 20 percent in the next decade.
"I think we can now say a trend has been established," said James Q. Wilson, a leading criminologist and professor of management at the University of California at Los Angeles. "But I'm not sure we know why, and I don't think this pattern will last," Mr. Wilson added, because of the coming growth in the number of teen-agers.
In fact, Alfred Blumstein, a criminologist at Carnegie Mellon University, noted that the report included an ominous hint of the projected increase in crime that may accompany the rising teen-age population. Of the eight crimes measured by the F.B.I., only one, larceny, showed an increase in 1995, up 1 percent. Larceny includes minor thefts like shoplifting and bicycle stealing, which are typical first crimes committed by teen-agers.
"This is the first visible sign of the anticipated new wave of crime by the future generation of kids," Professor Blumstein said.
The report showed that crime was down in all regions of the country, with the largest declines in the Northeast, which had a 4 percent overall decrease and a 15 percent drop in homicides.
Among cities, those with a population of more than a million showed the largest decline in overall crime, averaging 6 percent. Overall crime in New York City dropped by 14.5 percent, according to the F.B.I. figures, and the city had one of the largest declines in homicides, to 1,170 in 1995 from 1,561 in 1994. In Los Angeles, overall crime fell by 4 percent, in Detroit by 2 percent and in Dallas also by 2 percent, according to the figures.
In the past, some experts expressed skepticism that police figures sometimes undercounted crimes, but in recent years the specialists say there have been serious efforts by the F.B.I. to make the data as accurate as possible.
Franklin Zimring, director of the Earl Warren Legal Institute at the University of California at Berkeley, said the most significant statistic in the report was the 8 percent decrease nationwide in the number of homicides last year, the third year in a row murders have fallen.
Murder figures are important because homicide is by far the best measured crime, given the difficulty of hiding bodies, Professor Zimring pointed out, and also because homicide is the crime that most alarms the public.
"The good news is that this decline in murders for three years is a trend," Professor Zimring said. But he added that homicides have followed a cyclical pattern for the last 20 years, and that every time the rate drops for a few years, it then rises again.
In fact, after a long period of decline, the national homicide rate doubled from 1965 to 1974, to about 10 per 100,000. It then dropped in the mid-1970's only to rise again to a peak of 10 per 100,000 in 1980. The early 1980's was another period of decline before the crack cocaine epidemic helped trigger another increase in the late 1980's. The F.B.I. said last year that the murder rate in 1994 was about 9 per 100,000.
A question many criminologists are asking is whether the current decline will prove as ephemeral as that in the early 1980's.
"When push comes to shove, nobody has an ability to explain the increases any better than the decreases," Professor Zimring said. "Criminologists are like weathermen without a satellite. We can only tell you about yesterday's crime rates."
The new report is based on crimes reported to the police and forms part of the F.B.I.'s Uniform Crime Reporting Program. It measures eight serious crimes, including the violent crimes of murder, rape, robbery and assault, along with the property crimes of burglary, larceny, motor vehicle theft and arson.
Over all, these serious crimes decreased 2 percent nationwide in 1995 compared with 1994, the F.B.I. found. Besides the 8 percent drop in homicides, robberies were down 7 percent, rapes declined 6 percent, and assaults dropped 3 percent. Among property crimes, in addition to the 1 percent increase in larcenies, automobile theft was down 6 percent, and burglary and arson fell 5 percent.
The number of homicides declined in other cities besides New York. Murders in Houston dropped to 316 in 1995 from 375 in 1994, while in Detroit they fell to 475 in 1995 from 541 the previous year.
In these two cities as well as New York, the police have carried out active new strategies. But overall crime also declined in Los Angeles, where the police have been making fewer arrests, Professor Wilson said, perhaps as a result of demoralization after widely publicized cases including the beating of the motorist Rodney G. King and the O. J. Simpson murder trial.
If crime is down in Los Angeles, as well as in New York, with such different police programs, Professor Wilson said, "something broad is happening."
James Alan Fox, the dean of the college of criminal justice at Northeastern University, said the figures for 1995 "are certainly encouraging, but no reason for celebration."
The reason, Professor Fox said, is that the statistics obscure the fact that "there are two different crime trends in America, one for the young and one for adults, and they are moving in opposite directions." From 1990 to 1994, he said, the homicide rate among adults above 25 years of age declined 18 percent but the rate of killing by 14- to 17-year-olds rose 22 percent.
One reason for the decline among adults may be that more adult criminals have been incarcerated as the number of prisoners has tripled in the last two decades, Professor Fox said. But there is no evidence that the threat of prison deters young people, he added.
Lawrence M. Friedman, a professor of law at Stanford University and an authority on the history of crime in America, said that "the historical records suggest that fluctuations in crime rates are largely independent of changes in the criminal justice system" and may have as much to do with large social, economic and cultural trends.
He noted that although some people credit the tripling of the prison population with the recent decrease in crime, the United States had much lower crime rates in the 1940's and 1950's when many fewer people were sent to jail.
"The honest answer," Professor Friedman said, "is that no one knows why crime rates go up and down."

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1271 words

HEADLINE: Rights Panel For Europe Stirs Anger In Britain

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: STRASBOURG, France

 BODY:
Seven years ago, the British Board of Film Classification banned Nigel Wingrove's video "Visions of Ecstasy," saying its graphic scenes of Jesus having sex with a Carmelite nun violated Britain's centuries-old law against blasphemy.
What could Mr. Wingrove do? Having exhausted his legal remedies in Britain, he did what more and more of his aggrieved countrymen are doing when they find themselves on the wrong side of a British law. He took his case to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, where his lawyers argued in February that Britain's blasphemy statute was arbitrary, anachronistic and illegal under the broader laws of Europe. 
 "This film's banning by Britain constitutes a direct infringement of the protections in Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights," Mr. Wingrove's lawyer, Geoffrey Robertson, told a panel of judges from 12 countries, including Iceland, Malta and Estonia. "Is the law any different in principle from the laws against blasphemy in Iran?"
If history is any indication, Mr. Wingrove may well prevail when the court makes its ruling in the next several months. Eighty cases have been heard against Britain in the court's 36-year history, more than against any other country except for Italy. And, in what many Britons see as yet another example of Europe confounding Britain's efforts to rule itself, the court has found Britain guilty of human rights violations 41 times.
"In the United States, people have protection under the Constitution, which enshrines many of the basic human rights in law," said Duncan Lustig-Prean, deputy director of Liberty, a British civil rights group. "With the U.K., there is no constitution and no bill of rights. There isn't anything."
What in Britain is referred to as the constitution exists not as a written document, but as the accumulation of common law and precedents.
The cases that come before the European Court are brought under provisions of the 1950 European Convention on Human Rights, which Britain signed, and involve speech, privacy, the press, religion, sexuality, corporal punishment and the rights of suspects, immigrants, prisoners and the mentally ill.
Because countries risk expulsion from the 38-member Council of Europe if they ignore its rulings, many of the cases have required the British Government to revise the country's laws, fueling anti-Europe sentiment and often embarrassing Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Government.
Rulings in Strasbourg have, among other things, forced Britain to outlaw corporal punishment in state-run schools, to pay damages to women fired from the armed services after becoming pregnant and to provide terrorism suspects with speedier access to lawyers.
The court has also limited the ability of the Government to wiretap telephones, expanded journalists' rights to use confidential sources, declared that the Home Secretary could no longer set jail sentences for juvenile offenders, and increased protection for homosexuals.
"From the point of view of human rights lawyers, there are very few of the decisions with which one could take issue," said Sir William Goodhart, a member of the executive committee of the International Commission of Jurists, a human rights group. "What this says is that we're not nearly as good at human rights as we think we are."
Mr. Wingrove's 18-minute "Visions of Ecstasy" video, which portrays in explicitly erotic terms the mystical rhapsodies of the 16th-century Carmelite nun, St. Theresa of Avila, was denied a rating by the film board in 1989, making it illegal for Mr. Wingrove to sell or rent it.
In refusing to rate the film, the board said that it was not pornographic but that it violated Britain's blasphemy law, which forbids ridiculing symbols of Christianity.
The law, which dates back to medieval ecclesiastical courts, does not apply to other religions and has been applied only twice before in this century.
By taking his case to Strasbourg, Mr. Wingrove, now a distributor of horror and B-movies, hopes the court will find that Britain violated his right to freedom of expression, which is guaranteed by the European Convention on Human Rights. He also wants the court to strike down the blasphemy law.
"Either you extend it to cover all faiths," Mr. Wingrove said, "or you abolish it altogether."
But even as Mr. Wingrove hopes for relief, many Britons are profoundly unhappy with the court at a time when European institutions are seen as meddling more and more in Britain's internal affairs.
The human rights court is regularly ridiculed by Conservative politicians and newspapers, who like to point out, for instance, that one of its judges, a Canadian-born lawyer who represents Liechtenstein, is named Ronald MacDonald.
To the conservative Daily Mail, the court is an "unrepresentative and unaccountable body" whose rulings "veer crankily from the tragic to the farcical, giving comfort here to terrorists, drug barons, gypsy squatters and transsexuals."
Last fall, the court provoked a furor when it ruled that the killing in 1988 of three unarmed Irish Republican Army members by British security forces in Gibraltar who suspected that they were on a bombing mission had violated the suspects' right to life.
In a follow-up order that Michael Heseltine, the Deputy Prime Minister, called "ludicrous and incomprehensible," the court also ordered the British Government to pay $60,000 in legal costs to the suspects' families.
"This really is the last straw," said Patrick Nicholls, a member of Parliament and the chairman of the Conservative backbench legal committee. "It's yet another example of countries, many of whom have a deplorable record on human rights, presuming to lecture our Home Secretary and our courts. The British people are fed up with our courts being overruled by a bunch of academic civil servants in Strasbourg who do not understand our legal system."
Perhaps as a way to appease the anti-European wing of his own party, known as the Euroskeptics, Mr. Major recently dispatched Malcolm Rifkind, the Foreign Secretary, to Strasbourg to ask the court to reform its system of selecting judges and to consider each country's legal traditions.
"Account should be taken of the fact that democratic institutions and tribunals in member states are best placed to determine moral and social issues in accordance with regional and national perceptions," Mr. Rifkind said in a memo to the court.
Meanwhile, despite some Euroskeptics' demands that Britain drop out altogether, Mr. Major in January renewed Britain's membership in the convention for five more years, saying that while Britain was "profoundly dissatisfied with some of their judgments," pulling out would set a bad example to other countries.
The judgments against Britain have given rise to a radical suggestion from the Labor Party, human rights lawyers and many members of the judiciary: why not incorporate the European human rights convention into British law, they ask -- as every other member of the Council of Europe, except Ireland, has already done.
"A British bill of rights would make redress easier and cheaper," the Economist said in October, "and thus restore at least some popular respect for Britain's own system of justice." Some conservatives agree, but for different reasons. Incorporating the convention into national law, they say, would restore British affairs to British control and offer a chance for more Government-friendly judgments.
Then, Sir Ivan Lawrence, a member of Parliament, said recently, Britons could "wash our dirty linen here, rather than in Europe."
