HEADLINE: Essay;
The New Casey

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Whom the political gods would destroy, they first make power-grabbing Directors of Central Intelligence.
I saw it happen with my friend Bill Casey, a patriot of intellect and energy who thought he could dominate the Reagan Administration as an activist policy maker, and whose hubris hurt him and his country. 
 It's happening again with John Deutch, the former M.I.T. provost who now bestrides the National Security Council like a Colossus.
Like only Casey before him, Deutch demanded a place at the President's Cabinet table. Whether as host at elegant black-tie dinner parties at Blair House for foreign ambassadors, or leading an entourage of 37 on a tour of Africa, Mr. Clinton's Director of Central Intelligence makes clear that he is the man of greatest influence in the Clinton Administration.
Time magazine's Douglas Waller, in a devastating expose last week, wrote that Deutch was "becoming the most powerful spymaster Washington has ever seen" who "ostensibly refrains from advocating policy with the President."
That qualifier "ostensibly" is on target: Deutch's colleagues have heard him boast, on more than one occasion, "I am a policy maker."
You ask -- what's wrong with that? Why shouldn't Clinton get advice on what to do from a brilliant, take-charge D.C.I.?
Here's what is wrong: When the nation's top intelligence officer goes beyond providing impartial facts and starts offering policy judgments, he abuses his office. Career-conscious analysts, evaluators and even agents then provide facts and estimates backing-up what become known as the boss's views. Necessary dissent is chilled, and the books become cooked.
Deutch concealed from Congressional oversight for a year his knowledge of a secret White House Intelligence Oversight Committee investigation into Clinton's personal, tacit cooperation with Iran to arm the Bosnians. (As Casey would say, "You never asked me"; now, belatedly, Deutch is handing over material the White House wishes he would not.) And yet Congress rewarded him with control of all intelligence budgets, a vast expansion of one man's power.
He maintained the "right" of the spy agency to endanger all journalists by using some as spies; insisted that officials outside the community submit to the discredited polygraph for access to data; talked big and delivered little on declassification. And yet Deutch gets a great press.
He sits at the Cabinet table, absorbing face time from the President, while often replacing his deputy at deputies' meetings, thereby keeping personal control of the sub-Cabinet bureaucracy. And yet -- because Clinton had to beg him to take the job -- nobody dares to tell the President his cosseted D.C.I. is building an empire.
That empire, should Clinton win a second term, would probably see Deutch returned to the Defense Department as Secretary; his subservient C.I.A. top staff running the agency but still beholden to him; and with Strobe Talbott of State, his squash partner, guaranteeing Oval Office access as national security adviser.
To bring off that political coup, Deutch needs a dramatic success. Speculation is rife in Washington that a Presidential "finding" has been signed authorizing a covert action, duly reported secretly to Congress, to support an indigenous Iraqi uprising to topple Saddam Hussein. If true, it may be Clinton's "October surprise"; if untrue, and if Saddam is secretly building mass-destruction weapons, what has the C.I.A. been waiting for?
Deutch is savvy enough to employ tactical retreats. When Republicans saw politics in 'Deutchland' -- seeing red in his agency's airy brushoff of a need for missile defense -- he agreed to a re-evaluation to head off an investigation. When the F.B.I. wanted to treat economic espionage as criminal, thus compromising C.I.A. sources, Deutch caved in, knowing his agency is vulnerable to an aggressive F.B.I. mole hunt to find the Russian spy who protected Aldrich Ames.
Nobody doubts his smarts. Is he smart enough to anticipate, like a professional intelligence officer, the fall he is riding for?
Much depends on his reaction to the unflattering Time article, today's gentle pop, and others likely to follow. His remaining well-wishers hope the criticism will help him restrain his ego and discipline his desire to dominate.
But if past is sadly prelude, Director Deutch will seethe, and blow his stack, and hunt for leakers, and vow to get even -- and, like Casey, come a cropper.

HEADLINE: House Republican Leaders Return D'Amato's Salvo on Strategies

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich and his loyal No. 2, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, returned fire today at criticism leveled against the policies and practices of the House Republicans they lead. They were not, however, responding to some partisan salvo from Democrats but to the rather blunt criticism last week from Alfonse M. D'Amato, New York's Republican Senator.
On Friday, Mr. D'Amato complained that Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, was being hurt by his association with Mr. Gingrich. Today, Mr. Gingrich said Mr. D'Amato was "just wrong." 
 "I don't know why he is wandering around saying these things," Mr. Gingrich said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
On another talk show, Mr. Armey, the House Republican leader, was far harsher, suggesting a motive for Mr. D'Amato: that the Senator was trying to shore up his political standing in New York, where he faces re-election in two years.
Mr. Gingrich, returning to the talk-show circuit after an absence of several months, used the occasion to attack President Clinton as well. On the balanced budget, he said Mr. Clinton "postures, says things that are false and has zero interest in a real agreement."
And in vetoing a bill that would ban certain late-term abortions, Mr. Gingrich said, "Bill Clinton has taken an extraordinarily extreme position, that it is O.K. to kill children in ways in which no American could tolerate if they knew about them."
David Eichenbaum, communications director of the Democratic National Committee, said: "Nasty Newt is back, and he's nastier than ever. The better the economic news, the nastier Newt gets."
With polls showing Mr. Dole trailing President Clinton by wide margins, it has been a season of discontent for Republicans with the sprouting of intraparty feuds.
But unlike the disagreements among Republicans over issues like the minimum wage and the gas tax, the D'Amato-Gingrich argument is over how Mr. Dole should shape his case to be President and how closely he should be identified with Mr. Gingrich's aggressive approach.
Mr. D'Amato is a leading figure in the Dole campaign, and his criticism reverberated throughout Republican circles. His complaints that Mr. Gingrich misread his mandate from the 1994 elections were explicit and frequent in New York on Friday.
Mr. Gingrich said: "I would simply say to Al D'Amato that we favor balancing the Federal budget so that our children aren't crushed by debt. I think 80 percent of the American people favor that." He said most people also endorsed the House Republican efforts to enact death penalty laws and tax cuts.
Mr. Armey, speaking on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," said Mr. D'Amato's "mama apparently didn't teach him not to bite the hand that feeds him." He said the Contract With America, the House Republicans' campaign manifesto from 1994, gave the Republicans majorities in both the House and the Senate, making Mr. D'Amato chairman of the banking committee.
"I'm sorry he doesn't recognize that," Mr. Armey said. "But he's behind in the polls, and you know when politicians get behind in the polls they get desperate, and Al obviously wanted to endear himself to big labor. They're spending a ton of money in New York."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Self-Made, Made-Up Superstar of the Bulls

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
ON the eve of the big playoff series here, Michael Jordan's back, Scottie Pippen's ankle and Phil Jackson's brains played second fiddle to Dennis Rodman's cosmetics and Dennis Rodman's frocks.
On the eve of the second round of the National Basketball Association playoffs between the Bulls and the Knicks, the front page of the Sunday Chicago Sun-Times ran this headline: "The Rebounder Wore Rouge." The Sunday Chicago Tribune's lead headline was: "Rodman Rings This City's Bell/Eccentric Bull Transcends Even Jordan's Popularity." 
 Elsewhere on those front pages, you might find stories about the economy or trouble in China, but the photographs of the Bulls forward in his eyebrow-raising coming-out garb at a book-signing for his more-or-less autobiography, "Bad As I Wanna Be," relegated possible injuries to Jordan and Pippen, and strategy by Jackson, to, well, the sports pages.
Perhaps it is an indication of the man that when he showed up for Saturday's event on a Harley-Davidson -- as a crowd of 1,500 waved and screamed -- he came roaring down the one-way Pearson Street the wrong way. He was heavily made up, with silver hair, silver eyeshadow, silver lipstick, silver nail polish. He wore a silver tank top that showed off a goodly portion of his 11 tattoos, tight black-leather pants and silver motorcycle boots and topped it all with a fuchsia boa scattered with black feathers. He was arrayed like Grace Jones, or Little Richard on a bad day.
Whether he might catch a cold flying through the Chicago streets in a tank top on a chopper in 45-degree weather, or whether he might fall off the cycle and break something, like a head, and render himself less able for his team's run for the championship, seemed of little concern. After all, it's all part of being bad.
But if "bad" can be "good," as some parlance has it, then the league's leading rebounder was his nasty self last night against the Knicks, pulling down 12 boards, even hitting 3 of 4 free throws in the waning minutes of the game, and then diving headlong to save a loose ball on virtually the last play of the game as the Bulls won, 91-84.
Dennis Rodman, however, has become as brilliant at gathering attention as he is at getting rebounds. It is a phenomenon. But Dennis Rodman learned long ago that doing something outrageous makes people look at you and talk about you and, eventually, earns you money. Doesn't matter if it makes sense or not. If it is rebelliousness for rebelliousness' sake. If it's making funny faces behind the teacher's back just to make your classmates giggle.
In his book, Rodman says he met his best friend at a camp where Rodman walked around with quarters in his ears. "Made people think I was crazy," he wrote, with what seems an air of satisfaction.
In his book, every page has phrases in bold type, just to let the reader know how important this passage is. One wonders about the reader he believes this will attract. The book seems an insight into the thought process of Dennis Rodman. He says: "Fifty percent of life in the N.B.A. is sex. The other 50 percent is money." That leaves precious little time for basketball. He says, "When you talk about race in basketball, the whole thing is simple: A black player knows he can go out on the court and," paraphrasing from here, kick a white player around. That wraps up the race issue, all right.
But there are deeper things that he touches on. Like the fact that his father left his mother when he was 3, and he still yearns for a father figure. And when Chuck Daly, his coach with the Pistons, left, he was so distraught at this and some other matters, he sat with a rifle in his lap in a parking lot and contemplated suicide. He recalls stealing watches when he was employed as an airport janitor after high school, and giving them to friends because he was "looking for acceptance."
He talks about wanting to be "normal," and that he might like to go back to that $6.50 an hour job. On the other hand, he has stated recently that he will demand $7 million a year from the Bulls next season.
He discusses being a lost, funny-looking young man with big ears -- who grew nine inches the summer after high school, from 5 feet 11 inches to 6-8 -- and finally at age 20 beginning to develop some confidence through basketball, though he hadn't played on the team in high school.
His two younger sisters had been outstanding basketball players, and he bridled at the attention they received. He talks about being sent twice to psychiatrists who told him, "There's nothing wrong with you."
But throughout the book, he says he just wants to be "normal." He talks still about ending his life with suicide. Those psychiatrists should be investigated.
For all his "badness," Rodman rarely seems comfortable with himself. He seems to be always trying to be someone else. But he's performed a magic trick that even Michael Jordan might envy. He has learned to make quarters from his ears become piles of cash.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dennis Rodman, pulling down a rebound in yesterday's playoff victory over the Knicks, is equally adept at grabbing attention off the court. (Doug Pensinger/Allsport)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
National Holidays Curb Trading And Dollar Ends Little Changed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesteday in light trading caused by national holidays in Britain and Japan.
Most trading was between the German mark or the Swiss franc and the Japanese yen, rather than the dollar, traders said. Traders were using these cross-rates to bet on lower interest rates in Europe and an eventual increase in Japanese rates. 
 "There seems to be more interest than usual in the cross-rates, particularly against the yen," said Michael Faust, portfolio manager at Bailard Biehl & Kaiser in San Mateo, Calif.
The effect of traders selling marks and francs for yen was to give the dollar an indirect increase against the European currencies, and a nudge lower against the yen.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.5254 marks, up from 1.5245 marks on Friday. The dollar slipped to 104.88 yen from 105.05 yen. The British pound edged up to $1.5087 from $1.5070.
Japanese markets were closed yesterday in observance of Children's Day, while London -- normally the busiest center of foreign-exchange trading -- was quiet because of a national holiday.
Speculation that a rebounding United States economy could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates later this year is likely to bolster the dollar against European currencies in the days ahead, traders said, particularly after the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, suggested this weekend that the German central bank might lower interest rates.
Speaking at the opening of a new Bundesbank branch in Leipzig, Mr. Tietmeyer suggested that there was room for a German rate reduction.
And yesterday, a council member of the Bundesbank, Wendelin Hartmann, welcomed the dollar's recent gains against the mark in remarks in Leipzig.
The latest Bundesbank comments backed views already held in the market, rather than giving any new impetus to prices, traders said. Still, some traders expect the dollar to rise as high as 1.55 marks.
"The dollar's in a little bit of a consolidation mode," said Ricardo Gomes, head of foreign exchange at Republic National Bank of New York. "But this market's turned heavily bullish."
In other currency dealings, the Mexican peso slipped against the dollar in active trading yesterday. The peso fell to 7.505 pesos to the dollar from 7.475.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
On Slow Day, Bond Prices Rebound a Bit

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, lifted by covering of short positions and by bargain hunting after the sharp selloff on Friday that was prompted by the April employment report. But trading was light, exaggerating the gains, as the market braced for a flood of new securities this week.
The Treasury is selling $73 billion of securities in auctions that will be conducted nearly every day this week. As a result, traders and investors are moving cautiously and large buyers have become scarce. 
 The concerns over supply come amid signs that an economic rebound is picking up speed, raising worries that inflation could accelerate soon and that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates to try to control price pressures.
The bond market has already begun to price in a move by the Fed to tighten credit, traders and analysts say. The Federal Open Market Committee of the Fed, which determines monetary policy, meets on May 21.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 19/32 yesterday, to 86 30/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 7.05 percent, from 7.11 percent on Friday. Some traders covered short positions, profiting by buying back, at a lower price, shares that they had borrowed and sold earlier.
At the regular weekly auction of Treasury bills yesterday, the rates were higher than they were last week. The average rate at auction for a three-month bill was 5.02 percent, up from 5 percent, while the rate on a bill with a six-month maturity was 5.14 percent, up from 5.08 percent.
The auction served as a prelude to the Treasury's quarterly refunding of debt this week. Today the Treasury will auction $19 billion of 3-year notes, and tomorrow it will sell $14 billion of 10-year notes. On Thursday, 36-day cash management bills will be sold to take care of short-term borrowing needs not covered by the regular schedule. In when-issued trading yesterday, the 3-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.34 percent and the 10-year at a price to yield 6.88 percent.
Dealers and sellers were positioning themselves yesterday for quick distribution of the new securities into the hands of investors so that they would not end up holding too many of the securities and being exposed to losses if prices continued to drop.
The report on employment for April continued to nag at market participants yesterday. While it showed that only 2,000 jobs were added to payrolls last month, far fewer than the 117,000 that had been expected, the data also showed wage pressures and were in line with other reports pointing to faster-than-expected economic growth.
Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist of the DKB Securities (USA) Corporation, said that if not for the confusion over the significance of recent economic reports, bond yields would have topped out long ago. He said that the sale of 3-year and 10-year notes this week would only fuel the market's anxiety.
Some additional data on prices will be reported this week. The Federal Reserve will release a survey of regional business activity tomorrow, and the Labor Department will report on producer prices for April on Friday.
In the futures market, Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research of Boston, said that "a test toward a price of 108 on the June bond futures contract looks likely."
"But given the overall bearish structure of the market and this week's quarterly refunding," she said, "the level is a selling opportunity. You can't have a bullish bias in this market until we see a recovery above a price of 109 11/32."
Yesterday the 30-year bond contract for June reached a high price of 1079/32 and closed at 107 5/32 .

HEADLINE: Criminals of the Balkan War

 BODY:
Dusan Tadic goes on trial today in The Hague for war crimes in Bosnia, the first defendant to face the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. Mr. Tadic, a Bosnian Serb, is accused of specific acts of murder and torture, but not of masterminding the brutal human rights abuses that were the signature of the Balkan war. That distinction belongs to other men, and the work of the tribunal should be measured by whether it is given the support necessary to pursue and prosecute them.
Political and practical obstacles make it unlikely that many of those who engineered the ethnic slaughter in Bosnia will be captured and brought to trial. The unspoken price of the Dayton peace agreement seems to be indifference about the atrocities committed by all parties during the war. But while the United States and other nations may be defeated in the end by these impediments, they should be stubborn in the pursuit of justice. 
 The individuals who carried out the Bosnian war's worst crimes -- like "ethnic cleansing," torture, rape and mass execution -- should be held accountable for their actions. Otherwise, surviving victims will be tempted to retaliate indiscriminately against innocent members of the ethnic groups these criminals claimed to serve. Such vendettas would decrease the chances that Bosnia's Muslims, Croats and Serbs can once again learn to live together.
To date only 3 of the 57 indicted war crimes defendants -- one Serb and two Croats -- are in custody in The Hague. None of them were arrested by Serbian or Croatian authorities, despite their obligation under the Dayton agreement to assist in the investigation and prosecution of war crimes. In contrast, the Bosnian Muslim authorities promptly arrested two of the three recently indicted Muslim defendants, and the third is in custody in Germany.
Almost all the other defendants remain at large, including Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb military commander.
The West has considerable diplomatic leverage with Franjo Tudjman, the Croatian President, who is eager to see his country accepted by Washington and integrated into European institutions at the earliest possible date. Serbia is subject to the automatic reimposition of costly economic sanctions if President Slobodan Milosevic fails to comply with the war crimes requirements of the Dayton accord.
Western governments have so far preferred not to use their leverage. Carl Bildt, the chief international civilian representative in Bosnia, has not made war crimes a high priority. The NATO peacekeeping forces, while rightly hoping to avoid reckless manhunts, have gone too far in the other direction, leaving the impression that they have no interest in supporting the investigation of war crimes or the pursuit of war criminals.
This behavior is shortsighted. Credible war crimes prosecutions are not only important to the prospects for long-term peace in Bosnia, but also bear on the country's civil tranquillity in the coming months. That may affect the climate at the time of NATO's scheduled withdrawal at year's end.
Of all the aspects of the Bosnian peace, the prosecution of war criminals may be the most sensitive and politically charged. Presidents Milosevic and Tudjman would no doubt like to avoid trials of defendants that might expose suspected links between their own military forces and Bosnian ethnic militias.
But the difficulty inherent in holding people accountable for the terrible crimes of the Balkan war is no reason to brush off the job. Western governments must insist that the Serbian, Croatian and Bosnian Governments live up to the commitments they made to bring war criminals to justice.

HEADLINE: A Better Senate Bill on Immigration

 BODY:
The Senate passed a sensible immigration bill last week, providing for strengthened enforcement of immigration laws at the nation's borders and workplaces, tighter requirements for immigrants to receive certain public benefits and the development of a new national database for verifying the immigration status of prospective employees.
The Senate's version is superior to the harshly punitive bill the House passed in March, which would deny due process to asylum applicants and permit states to deny public education to the children of illegal immigrants. House conferees should follow the Senate's lead on both issues. The House bill's public education provision, which ignores a contrary Supreme Court ruling, has rightly drawn a veto threat from President Clinton. 
 The original Senate immigration bill, submitted last year by Alan Simpson of Wyoming, would have done more harm than good. Responding to a perceived popular anger against foreigners at a time of economic uncertainty in America, it sought to cut legal as well as illegal immigration. The bill would have needlessly hurt employers' ability to recruit workers with special training and skills and imposed gratuitous hardships on immigrant families. Senators Spencer Abraham, Republican of Michigan, and Edward Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, led a successful effort in the Judiciary Committee to remove most legal immigration restrictions from this bill.
Then Senator Patrick Leahy, a Vermont Democrat, amended provisions that would have unrealistically required refugees to arrive with a full set of valid travel documents and denied them any appeal from unfavorable rulings by immigration officers at the point of entry. The House bill still contains these denials of due process. The Senate bill contains regrettable restrictions on other kinds of immigration appeals, but keeps asylum accessible.
The Senate reasonably required, as did the House, that immigrants count the incomes of their sponsors as well as their own when applying for means-tested benefits. That is less generous than the current standard, but America's underfinanced welfare system should not have to bear the burden of those not genuinely in need. Public education is different, as the Supreme Court has ruled and the Senate recognized. Children here because their parents came to this country illegally should not be barred from public schools.
The Senate bill also requires the government to establish a national database so that employers can verify the status of job applicants. The American Civil Liberties Union and the new libertarians of the Republican right oppose this provision as an expansion of Big Brother government. But excluding illegal aliens from employment requires an identification less open to fraud than current paper documentation systems. The Senate made its pilot programs for the database mandatory. The House made them voluntary. Either is acceptable, provided that Congress insists that the final program protect immigration data from abuse.
Both the Senate and House bills usefully provide for nearly doubling the number of Immigration Service enforcement agents.
Immigrants have historically enriched America and still do so today, especially when they bring entrepreneurial energies and valuable technical skills. The United States is also a better country for admitting those who flee persecution abroad. Still, those people whom immigration law excludes should be kept out as effectively as possible. The Senate has come up with a bill that can help do that. The House should drop its unacceptable education and asylum provisions and go along.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Dole '96 Button Not Necessarily Business Attire

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
As a longtime supporter of President Clinton, John H. Bryan, the chairman of the Sara Lee Corporation, is used to having his politics questioned by other chief executives, most of whom are staunch Republicans. "Every now and then, someone will check in and ask if I still back him," Mr. Bryan said last week. "I always profess my loyalty."
Lately -- and surprisingly -- Mr. Bryan has been getting less ribbing. 
 The political mood in the nation's executive suites is showing signs of subtle change. Mr. Clinton, despite irritating business leaders with what they perceive as broken promises and policy flip-flops, appears to have put himself back in the race. Many executives, lacking enthusiasm for Senator Bob Dole, are giving Mr. Clinton a second look, or at least remaining uncommitted.
That, in itself, is quite a turnaround. A few months ago, Republicans did not know whom their Presidential nominee would be, but they figured they could count on support from the leaders of big business, almost regardless of whom the party nominated. Now, Mr. Dole is the all-but-certain candidate, but -- based on more than a score of interviews with top executives who frequently talk politics with their colleagues and with political analysts -- his hold on the nation's executive suites is no sure thing.
Mr. Dole's support among top executives is wobbly for several reasons, including what some of them see as his fumbling on economic issues. Some are upset by the just-resolved, highly partisan fight over the 1996 budget, which they believe made the Republicans look extremist. And others have been put off by the sway the party's right wing often exerts on social issues like abortion.
"Right now, I'm worrying," said David R. Goode, chief executive of the Norfolk Southern Corporation. "Five or six months ago, I would have been stronger for Dole. If I had to vote today -- well, I'll take the Fifth on that."
For both parties, corporate chieftains like Mr. Goode are much bigger quarry than their numbers would suggest. They are trophies -- important because they are symbols and because they give money, raise yet more funds and often wield influence in their communities and industries.
For the Clinton campaign, they represent even more. By wooing chief executives in 1992 -- winning more business support than any Democratic nominee since Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964 -- Mr. Clinton bolstered his credentials as a "New Democrat" who would not tax and spend the way that Republicans contend traditional liberals do. Silicon Valley executives in particular came out in force. Republicans like Lawrence J. Ellison of the Oracle Systems Corporation and Edward R. McCracken of Silicon Graphics Inc. endorsed Mr. Clinton because he offered policies to aid high-technology companies.
By last fall, though, many chief executives had returned to the Republican fold. Mr. Clinton's veto in December of a bill limiting shareholder lawsuits was the coup de grace for many. Mr. Ellison even wrote a check to Mr. Dole's campaign.
Now Mr. Clinton may again be living up to his reputation as "the comeback kid," thanks to yet another reversal by executives like Mr. Ellison, whose anger has subsided. "I intend to wholeheartedly support the President this year for the same reasons I supported him in 1992 -- his commitment to education and technology," Mr. Ellison said.
Neither candidate seems to have an edge when it comes to money. Each party is expected to raise $120 million this year, mostly from business interests, according to Josh Goldstein, research director at the Center for Responsive Politics, which tracks contributions. "Business always gives to both sides," Mr. Goldstein said. "Their giving is not ideological but pragmatic."
And as of now, six months before Election Day, support from top executives for Mr. Clinton is by no means as widespread as it was in 1992. Indeed, "there may not be as many as the last time, when a lot were voting against Bush," cautioned Paul A. Allaire, the chief executive of the Xerox Corporation and a Clinton backer. Then, with the economy stagnating, business leaders were frustrated by what some saw as President George Bush's lack of vision and inability to work with the Democratic Congress.
Some of Mr. Clinton's executive backers, of course, will come from traditional Democratic bastions like Hollywood, where Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chief executive of Seagram, is a supporter, and Wall Street, where Robert E. Denham, the chief executive of Salomon Inc., has stepped forward.
But, as in 1992, a share of Mr. Clinton's executive support is likely to come from Republican turf, where some backers and analysts say Mr. Dole's troubles are compounded by his uninspiring performance on the hustings. Indeed, some executives who would normally be expected to voice public support for Mr. Dole are reluctant to do so publicly, which is read as a sign of his weakness.
"Most chief executives will probably vote for Dole, but I don't see any enthusiasm for him," said the head of one large company, who insisted on anonymity. "I wish I did, because I'm a Dole supporter."
Donald B. Marron, the chief executive of Paine Webber Group Inc. and a fund-raiser for Mr. Dole, said he had not heard such complaints. "When I talk to business people," he said, "they see in Bob Dole a very experienced person who has strong feelings about having less government and more economic growth" -- which, Mr. Marron said, is exactly what big business wants.
Even if Mr. Dole gets executives' votes, he will have to contend with a subtler issue. "People don't feel that if Clinton gets re-elected it's the end of the world," the anonymous Dole backer said of the business community.
Based on the soundings he has taken, Tony Coelho, an informal adviser to Mr. Clinton and chief executive of a financial services firm that bears his name, agreed. "Executives are not out to defeat him," Mr. Coelho said. "They think Republicans will lose and it's not worth it for them to try to make a difference."
Executives like to back a winner, and the most recent national opinion polls show Mr. Dole trailing Mr. Clinton by some 20 percentage points. "Everyone said it was the Republicans' to lose," Mr. Allaire said, "and my colleagues now feel that they will."
These are, of course, early days in what could be a volatile campaign. Springtime polls often prove wrong by fall. "This time in 1992, President Bush was ahead by 12 points, and in 1988 at this time he was trailing by 30 points," noted Lodwrick M. Cook, the chairman emeritus of ARCO. Mr. Cook is a deputy chairman of Mr. Dole's national finance committee, along with Mr. Marron and Henry R. Kravis, the leveraged-buyout investor. "I think the support is there," Mr. Cook said.
Pendleton E. James, an executive recruiter who is on the finance committee for the Republican Eagles, a group of top contributors, said that chief executives "are waiting for Dole to give some leadership, which he hasn't."
"I'm optimistic," he added, "and I think that will change."
Yet some Republicans worry because on balance, they admit, Mr. Clinton has not been bad for business. The economy is growing. The President has not been tagged with responsibility for any foreign policy fiascos. In trade, he pushed for approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement despite labor union opposition, and he personally helped win foreign contracts for companies like the Raytheon Corporation, which landed a big electronics contract in Brazil.
Executives are also quick to acknowledge their debt to Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary who died in a plane crash on April 3 while leading one of his many trade missions. Others praise Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary.
On the minus side, big business faults the Administration for failing to ease the burdens of regulation and litigation. And they recoil at the criticism that Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich has heaped on companies that have cut their work forces.
But even in the worst of times -- during the debate on health care, for instance -- many acknowledge that Mr. Clinton kept channels open, playing host at lunches for chief executives, among other things. "Clinton has never given up on the business community," Mr. Bryan, the Sara Lee chairman, said.
In one typical example, the President met stony faces last October when he gave the dinner speech at a meeting of the Business Council, a prestigious group of chief executives. But afterward, he went from table to table, listening to the concerns of each chief executive.
Lately, he has picked up the pace of his business courtship, especially in Silicon Valley. Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore have been busy trying to rebuild bridges throughout California, a key state.
Mr. Ellison aside, they have not been completely successful. Mr. McCracken of Silicon Graphics, who is considered a key swing vote in the computer industry, is remaining mum for the moment. Even if Mr. Clinton wins more support, it is unclear if he can turn it all public. "C.E.O.'s are not comfortable supporting a Democrat publicly, and that's a fact," Mr. Bryan said.
Meanwhile, a few Dole supporters are complaining about Republican efforts. "No one in the Dole campaign is reaching out to the business community," one supporter said, adding that the campaign seems only to ask for money. "It's a failing of the Dole campaign."
The Dole campaign did not respond to several requests for comments.
At this point, there is no telling whether an issue will arise to push executives in one direction or the other, the way the North American trade accord sealed a lot of business backing for Mr. Clinton. In the end, the split will probably depend on Mr. Clinton's moves before November.
"There's no question President Clinton is an outstanding campaigner," said Mr. Cook, the Dole backer. "It'll be an interesting race."

HEADLINE: David Lasser, 94, a Space and a Social Visionary

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
David Lasser, an immigrant's son whose vision of the future inspired men to build and fly rockets to the heavens and whose concern for life on earth impelled him to champion and organize the unemployed during the Great Depression, died on Sunday at the Remington Senior Care Facility in Rancho Bernardo, Calif., a San Diego suburb. Mr. Lasser, who lived in Rancho Bernardo, was 94.
Mr. Lasser's pioneering sense of the potential of rocketry was expressed in a 1931 book "The Conquest of Space," and it led him to form the organization now known as the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics. But his vision grew from an unlikely source: Mr. Lasser, as managing editor of a magazine called Science Wonder Stories, grew dissatisfied with the propulsion imagined by his authors for their space ships. Drawing upon his background in engineering, he conducted his own research and realized that the rocket -- the very same instrument used against the British in the War of 1812 and embodied in the lyrics of the national anthem -- would make space travel possible. 
 As the Depression deepened, Mr. Lasser's socialist sympathies prompted him to turn to labor organizing, a campaign that rallied hundreds of thousands to his Workers Alliance of America, later the American Security Union. After earning the respect of statesmen like President Franklin D. Roosevelt and W. Averell Harriman, Mr. Lasser fell victim to the Red hunts after World War II, when he was smeared with a baseless charge of Communism that barred him from Federal service.
In 1980, President Jimmy Carter expunged the canard with a letter that said: "This nation has a deep and abiding commitment to human rights. When lapses occur, it is important that they be corrected. I am glad that my Administration has had the opportunity to correct the record in your case."
Mr. Lasser, a son of Russian immigrants, was born in Baltimore and grew up in Newark, where his father, Leonard, cleaned and repaired clothes in a small shop.
A high school dropout who went to work to help his family, David was almost 16 when he lied about his age to enlist in the Army in World War I.
After returning to the United States, he was accepted by the Newark College of Engineering with the proviso that he attend high school and earn a diploma. But within a year, he decided that his electrical engineering course was too narrow to pave his way into management, so he presented himself at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and asked for a chance. In 1924, he was awarded a bachelor's degree in engineering. For a few years, he worked in small factories, and then, in 1927, impulsively, he answered an advertisement for managing editor of Science Wonder Stories.
Arthur C. Clarke, now the dean of science-fiction visionaries, described "The Conquest of Space" as "the first book in the English language to explain that space travel wasn't just fiction." He credited his encounter with the book as being "one of the turning points in my life -- and I suspect not only of mine."
Indeed, not.
One night in 1929, Mr. Lasser convened a group of writers in his Greenwich Village apartment. The organization they formed to promote space travel by means of rocketry called itself the American Interplanetary Society. Mr. Lasser was its first president. In the 1930's, the organization became the American Rocket Society, and in 1963, after merging with the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences, it became the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, now a 41,000-member organization based in Washington.
When World War II brought an end to joblessness, Mr. Lasser resigned his union post, worked for the War Production Board, and briefly served Mr. Harriman as a consultant for the Marshall Plan until he was effectively blacklisted. From 1950 until his retirement in 1969, Mr. Lasser was the economics and research director of the International Union of Electrical Radio and Machine Workers.
Mr. Lasser was also the author of the 1945 book "Private Monopoly: The Enemy at Home," in which he argued that economic policies motivated by greed were the source of nearly all modern distress.
Mr. Lasser, who was married three times, is survived by his wife of 32 years, the former Amelia Tolbert, of Rancho Bernardo; and Daniel Lasser of Rockville, Md., a son by his first marriage, to Florence Glassberg.

HEADLINE: Trenton May Pay Health Cost Of Uninsured by Payroll Tax

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 6

 BODY:
In the latest attempt to end a five-month standoff over how to pay for hospital care for the uninsured, the State Assembly approved legislation today that would cover the costs by continuing to rely on unemployment payroll taxes.
The bill was approved by the Assembly on a vote of 55 to 17, with 6 abstentions, with some Democratic support. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco support the new two-year plan, but the measure still faces uncertainty in the Republican-controlled Senate. 
 Several Republican senators oppose using payroll taxes designated for the unemployment insurance fund. Senate Democrats support another bill that would use more state budget dollars to finance the plan. Without Democratic support, said Mr. DiFrancesco, a Republican from Scotch Plains, the legislation is not likely to win approval when it comes up for a vote next week.
New Jersey's hospitals have continued to provide more than $100 million in medical treatment for the uninsured since the first of the year. Without state reimbursement, several hospitals have delayed payments to suppliers and warned that they would lay off workers and shut down clinics unless state reimbursements resumed.
"We're pleased that a bill has finally been heard," said Peter J. Lillo, vice president of the New Jersey Hospital Association, which has filed a lawsuit against the state seeking reimbursement. "We would have liked to have seen more money."
Under the proposal, the bill would distribute $310 million to hospitals this year and $300 million next year. The bill directs the State Department of Health to set up a managed care network so that fewer people would rely on emergency rooms for routine medical care, but lawmakers said today that it was unclear how managed care would work.
"That is still evolving," said Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, a Republican from Salem County.
Since 1992, the state paid for charity care by diverting $1.6 billion in payroll taxes earmarked for the unemployment fund. The authority to continue using the fund expired on Dec. 31, and both organized labor and the business community objected to the state's continuing to rely on unemployment payroll taxes to cover the cost of charity care.
To win support from labor, the Assembly agreed and voted today to extend unemployment benefits from 26 weeks to 39 weeks through the end of the year. The Assembly also voted to eliminate unemployment payroll taxes for employees for the next two years and reduce unemployment taxes to employers by $300 million.
But the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, which represents 14,000 businesses around the state, remains adamantly opposed to the measure and is working to defeat it in the Senate because it is concerned that the pressure on the fund will mean that employers will pay higher unemployment taxes.
The Assembly also voted only $10 million to be appropriated for the state's subsidized health insurance program, Health Access New Jersey, which covers the cost of the 22,000 people now in the program but provides no funds for new applicants.

HEADLINE: It's See No Evil, Have No Harassment in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 6

 BODY:
Kiyomi Kikuchi, a new saleswoman for Central Finance, was visiting clients with a male deputy branch manager, when the man suddenly turned their car into the parking lot of a "love hotel," an establishment, common in Japan, that rents rooms to couples by the hour.
"I said, 'You must be joking,' " Miss Kikuchi recalled. Her strong protests got the man to turn back that day, but his advances continued for months. The branch manager ignored her complaints, she said, but finally realized they were true and gave her a new sales partner. 
 But not long after that, the branch manager came to her again. "He said the deputy had been discredited," Miss Kikuchi, now 29, recalled last week. "And in order to restore his reputation I had to help him" by becoming his partner again.
What happened to Miss Kikuchi, experts say, is not unusual in Japan, where women play subservient roles in the workplace and where men openly read pornographic comic books on the subways. In a survey two years ago by the Tokyo city government, 26.5 percent of women workers reported having had some unpleasant sex-related experience on the job, mainly being told lewd jokes or being touched.
What is unusual is that Miss Kikuchi, who quit her job, sued the Nagoya-based company and the deputy branch manager for sexual harassment. Lawyers for both denied the charges; the case is pending.
Unlike in the United States, where sexual harassment lawsuits against an American subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation have captured headlines, few women in Japan even complain to their companies, perhaps because of a tradition in society of persevering through problems or because they feel that it would do no good. And in this generally nonlitigious society, only a handful of women file sexual harassment lawsuits each year.
Hence sexual harassment has not pervaded the social consciousness of Japan. The term used here, "sekuhara," is derived from English, suggesting that Japan did not have much of concept of it before.
Companies in Japan think of it as a problem involving individual women, said Masaomi Kaneko, deputy director of the Tokyo labor economic bureau. "They do not consider it a moral issue or think about why it happpens or of improving the work environment."
Plaintiffs in the case against Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America think such attitudes might have contributed to a tolerance of sexual harassment by the top Japanese executives at the factory in Normal, Ill., which is now being sued by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and by some current and former female employees. The workers who are actually accused of having scribbled lewd graffiti on walls, groped their female co-workers or shown them pornographic photos are American, however.
Mitsubishi's managers have said they do not tolerate sexual harassment and that the Japanese executives sent to the United States are trained in American values.
Certainly, Japanese companies have run into conflicts when they have tried to impose their traditional business practices on American subsidiaries. There have been many lawsuits accusing the Japanese companies of discriminating against women, minorities or Americans in general. But some executives of other Japanese companies say that by now any Japanese company setting up shop in the United States should be aware of these problems.
Experts say the root cause of sexual harassment in Japan is that women have a secondary status in society over all. Behavior that would be considered politically incorrect in America is accepted here.
At computer trade shows, the latest components are demonstrated by legions of models in miniskirts. Late-night TV often features shapely young women in bikinis who engage in mud wrestling or other mindless contests that seem designed mainly to make their tops fall off.
Entertaining clients and associates is an important part of doing business here, and it can involve women. Japanese executives talk business in "hostess bars," where women pour their Scotch and water and flatter them with idle chatter.
One Japanese businessman who has been stationed in New York and Asia said it was not unusual to arrange prostitutes for a client or a visiting big shot from headquarters, though the guest would be expected to pay for himself.
In Japan, clients might be taken to a "soapland," an establishment in which a naked woman bathes a male customer. In New York, the Japanese businessman belonged to a members-only club, 30 to 40 percent of whose members were Japanese, that featured a sauna, swimming pool and prostitutes. "I would take my guests there and let them do as they liked," he said.
Mitsubishi Motors trainees from America were taken to striptease bars when they visited Japan, and Japanese visiting Illinois were taken to parties involving prostitutes.
In Japanese companies, women often work as "office ladies," serving tea and doing low-level clerical work. They usually are not eligible for promotions and are expected to retire after being married.
With women often being considered "workplace flowers," perhaps it is not surprising that one bank a few years ago told women coming to its welcoming party for new employees to wear swimsuits, according to Mizuho Fukushima, an lawyer handling sexual harassment cases. Kyoko Ode, a secretary at a law firm, said her boss at a previous company had drawn pictures of an outfit he wanted her to wear -- one containing transparent parts.
Men in particular work long hours in Japan, so often the chance for socializing is in after-hours drinking with co-workers or on company trips.
Yuko Yamada, who once worked for a small design firm, recalled one company trip at which everyone played a drinking game requiring them to chug alcohol or sing a song when they made a mistake. After she made three consecutive mistakes, the company president, a grandfather in his 60's, chirped, "Those who make three mistakes in a row have to kiss me."
"The other people, mostly middle-aged women, started yelling I should kiss him," Miss Yamada, who was only 18 at the time, recalled. "I couldn't really get away so I kissed the president on his cheek.
"Then he sat next to me and began to touch me all over," she recalled. "He started putting his hand inside my robe and proclaiming, 'Yamada is my girl.' I felt really nauseated."
Miss Yamada, now 27 and an employee of a software company, said the president's behavior continued after the trip. "But I tolerated it because I was quite broke at the time and I couldn't quit my job," she said.
Since the first sekuhara lawsuit was filed in Japan in 1989, awareness of the problem, especially among young men and women, has grown, said Ms. Fukushima, the lawyer. "There were problems before that but there was no word to describe it, so it was difficult to raise social consciousness," she said.
Still many men, and even women, think it is not much of a problem.
"We hear about the lawsuits in the States and that makes us feel like people there are too sensitive," said Kenji Fukuda, a 49-year-old trading company employee. Mr. Fukuda said that mentioning a woman's looks or even patting her gently on the behind was no problem and that some women even liked it. "The Japanese don't get so disgusted by that kind of behavior," he said.
Nikkei Woman, a magazine for working women, has never done a story on sexual harassment, one male editor said. "The issues we deal with are promotions and the glass ceiling, or how to get along with female co-workers," he said. "In other words, issues and problems that are more closely related to their daily lives."
Keiko Takei, a 27-year-old office lady at a big trading firm, said that for many of her co-workers "marriage is the goal of their lives." She added:"They sweat to decide what to wear to the office because they know their appearance will be commented on. They would be distressed if no one makes a remark."
But some comments, she said, go too far. "I've been told I have big breasts, and I really hate it," she said.
There is no specific law against sexual harassment, so those suing must use general civil law. Suits can take years in the courts, and awards are typically only a few thousand dollars. And victory can be difficult.
"Many of the recent cases regard harassment that happened behind closed doors," said Reiko Nakamura, a lawyer who handles such cases. "In such cases, the assaulters all deny the accusation. The judges question why the woman did not escape from the room, why she did not cry out."
Rather than suing, women complain to a local labor commission, which typically arranges an apology and a payment of a few thousand dollars.
One recent "victor" is a 55-year-old elementary school teacher in Hachioji, a western suburb of Tokyo, who sued her principal. Like most women who file sexual harassment suits in Japan, she declined to make her name public because it would bring unwanted attention and shame to her family.
One night in 1991, when she and the principal were returning from a late-night function that involved dinner and drinking, he suddenly unzipped his pants, grabbed her hand and rubbed it against his penis. When she resisted that and subsequent approaches, she said, the principal removed her from her classroom and gave her a minor job.
Last month, the court ruled the principal had wronged her by exposing himself but rejected her claim that her job change constituted harassment. The principal, who is appealing, was ordered to pay $5,000, a quarter of what she had sought.
"What I really wanted was to have him fired," said the woman, who now teaches at another school. "But he's still there."

HEADLINE: Study Details CUNY Successes From Open-Admissions Policy

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The open-admissions policy that 25 years ago transformed the City University of New York by guaranteeing entry to almost all New York City high school graduates was far more successful in educating needy students than earlier research suggested, according to a new long-term study of thousands of students.
The study, which surveyed students who entered the City University under the open-admissions policy, found that more than half received bachelor's degrees, sometimes more than a decade later, and they went on to better-paying jobs as a result. These students would have been denied entrance to CUNY under the selective admissions policy in force until 1970. 
 Earlier studies had suggested that only about one-third of students who began college under open admissions, and less than 25 percent of minority students, actually received degrees.
While a multitude of critics have contended that open admissions had lowered standards and failed to educate its students, the researchers, David E. Lavin and David Hyllegard, concluded that the ambitious effort to promote educational opportunity paid big dividends.
"Our data indicate that it provided opportunities that students used well, and that translated into direct benefits in the job market and clearly augmented the economic base," said Professor Lavin, who teaches sociology at the university's Graduate School and at Lehman College and who has been studying the effects of open admissions since the policy began. "These people would be in significantly worse shape if it weren't for open admissions."
The new research, which was reviewed by an independent academic panel, will be published by Yale University Press this month in a book, "Changing the Odds: Open Admissions and the Life Chances of the Disadvantaged."
The open-admissions program, adopted after politically charged debate in 1970, allowed any student with a high school average of 80 or more or a rank in the top half of a graduating class to enter one of the university's four-year colleges. Students with an average of 70 were allowed into the two-year community colleges. In September 1970, as open admissions went into effect, 35,000 freshmen poured into CUNY, up from about 20,000 a year earlier.
Out of a sample of roughly 35,000 students that they had originally studied in depth, Professor Lavin and Mr. Hyllegard followed up on about 5,000 students 12 to 14 years after they first entered the university as members of the first three open-admissions classes. Of the 100,000 students who entered CUNY's two- and four-year colleges from 1970 to 1972, about 48,000 would not have qualified had it not been for the open-admissions program.
Where earlier studies found high dropout rates among open-admissions students, the researchers found that given time, many of them did eventually graduate. And they estimated that more than 5,000 eventually went on to receive master's degrees or doctorates.
Some social scientists see the findings as important evidence in the debate over assistance to poor students, which until now has centered on whether CUNY has watered down the curriculum.
While this study addressed the issue of quality, finding that both employers and graduate school admissions committees still regarded the university and its graduates highly, it looked in greater depth at the long-term achievement of open-admissions students and the impact on the local economy.
"Public perceptions since the Reagan era are that we have been too loose and have let in too many unqualified people and should tighten our standards," said Gary Orfield, a professor of education and social policy at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. "But the costs and the benefits have not been debated carefully enough."
Some critics of open admissions, like Herman Badillo, a City University trustee, are skeptical of the findings.
"On the face of it, these data are just not believable," he said. "What is the evidence that the students who drop out go on to another college? You can have all kinds of charts, but if you think about it, it is just not rational. The students don't have the money to transfer. That is why they are going to CUNY."
Other critics of open admissions say the new book may add useful information but should not be taken as the final word on the policy.
"I take Lavin very seriously," said James Traub, author of "City on a Hill: Testing the American Dream at City College" (Addison-Wesley), which chronicled the struggles of some open-admissions students at City College to master basic English and mathematics skills and stay in school. "He is a very good scholar. But Lavin looks at the numbers, not at the texture of what's going on, and he misses something very important.
"What I found is that an enormous number of kids going through got a substandard education because their preparation was so poor that the college was forced to stoop to their level."
Professor Lavin and Mr. Hyllegard, who is director of institutional research at Manhattan Community College, acknowledge that some students are held back by poor preparation and that there are now sizable parts of the university dedicated to remedial classes.
But what is more important, they said, is that the basic education being offered is still sound and that a large number of students do succeed.
But Mr. Badillo, a former Congressman, said CUNY has inordinate numbers of unprepared students.
"As of now, 83 percent of all students coming into CUNY's community college require remediation," he said. "I don't know of any other college that takes in that many. You're not doing them a favor if you admit them to college and they're not ready. The reality is that they drop out."
The Lavin-Hyllegard research found that since open-admissions students -- and particularly minority students -- were typically poorer than other students, they often worked full time while they went to college and took much longer than four years to graduate.
"It was not unusual for black and Latino students to take up to 8 to 10 years to graduate," Professor Lavin said. "It is a monument to their persistence, but almost a lethal factor to their getting a postgraduate degree."
Among other important findings about open admissions were these:
*Minority students entered the university's freshman class in the same proportions that they had graduated from high school; they went from 9 percent of the entering class in 1969 to 24 percent from 1970 through 1972.
*The number of minority graduates rose. Of the 23,381 black and Hispanic students who entered CUNY in those years, more than 13,000 received degrees, including almost 2,300 who got graduate degrees.
*While the number of minority freshmen jumped to more than 8,000 in 1970, from fewer than 1,700 in 1969, the number of whites also mushroomed, from fewer than 16,000 in 1969 to an average of almost 26,000 from 1970 to 1972.
*The study estimated that during one year in the 1980's, graduates admitted under open admissions earned a total of almost $67 million more than they would have if the university's program had not been instituted. Their additional lifetime earnings were estimated at about $2 billion.
"The benefits of the policy flowed to a broad cross section of New York City's ethnic communities, both minority and white," the authors wrote.
They contend that the benefits are so clear that decisions by New York and other states to cut support for public universities are bad public policy. Over the years, various budget crises have led CUNY to tighten its admissions, making it harder for poorly prepared students to get into the four-year colleges. Typical of the changes are new requirements that students admitted to senior colleges master remedial work in one year, not more.
"What's going on now makes our findings even more relevant," Professor Lavin said. "Any policy that makes it more difficult for students to stay in college diminishes their earning power and detracts from the taxes they will pay and the tone of New York City and New York State."
While open admissions helped deliver higher education to disadvantaged students, the university did not collapse its own standards or lose its standing in the process, Professor Lavin said.
"There's no way you could say that CUNY turned into a diploma mill when more than 40 percent of the open-admissions students never earned bachelor's degrees, and two-thirds of the minority students never earned more than an associate's degree," he said.
At the same time, he added, the university remained one of the largest sources of undergraduate students who went on to earn doctorates in the United States.
He pointed to a National Research Council study of doctorates, which showed that from 1983 to 1992, 3,877 City University graduates -- about 15 percent of the total for all of New York State -- went on to earn Ph.D's. City College alone provided 860 and Brooklyn College, 947, while Columbia, less than half the size of those two colleges, turned out 798 and New York University, nearly 50 percent larger than Brooklyn College and more than 25 percent larger than City College, produced 934.
"It's clear that the CUNY system is still doing what higher education is supposed to do," Professor Lavin said. "You can't just laugh these numbers off."

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1800 words

HEADLINE: William E. Colby, 76, Head of C.I.A. in a Time of Upheaval

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
William E. Colby, who as Director of Central Intelligence chose to disclose some of the nation's darkest secrets to save the spy service he loved, drowned on April 27 in a tributary of the Potomac River in Maryland. He was 76 and lived in the Georgetown section of Washington.
The Charles County Sheriff's office said Mr. Colby's body was found today, nine days after he set out for a solo canoe trip from his weekend home in Rock Point, Md., not far from where his canoe washed up on the shore of the Wicomico River about a quarter-mile from his house. 
 Mr. Colby spent most of his adult life as a cold warrior in his country's clandestine service, "a soldier-priest," as a colleague called him, on a covert crusade. He perfected the look of an invisible man: gray suits, graying hair, glasses with translucent frames the color of pale white skin. More than one interlocutor noted that when asked a question he did not care to answer, he would tilt back his head so light reflected off the lenses of his glasses, turning his eyes into blank white disks.
But as the nation's chief spy, he helped reveal the Central Intelligence Agency's hidden history and confessed to its sins. In his eyes and in the eyes of many historians, he kept the agency from destroying itself or being destroyed by outsiders. And when the cold war was over, he proposed beating swords into plowshares, arguing that half of the billions for the Pentagon should go to education, economic competitiveness and programs for the poor.
This transformation began on April 27, 1973, 12 days before Mr. Colby learned that President Richard M. Nixon, then deeply enmeshed in the Watergate scandal, was about to nominate him as Director of Central Intelligence.
That day, the Federal judge at the trial of Daniel Ellsberg, a former Defense Department official charged with espionage after the Pentagon Papers, a secret history of the Vietnam War, were provided to The New York Times, disclosed that the office of Mr. Ellsberg's psychiatrist had been burglarized by White House operatives -- with technical assistance from the C.I.A.
"This was a shocker," Mr. Colby recounted in his 1978 memoir, "Honorable Men" (Simon & Schuster). His immediate predecessor, James R. Schlesinger, had vowed to tear the agency apart if necessary to "find out if there were questionable or illegal activities hidden in the secret recesses of our clandestine past that we didn't know about and that might explode at any time under our feet."
Many such land mines existed, but no one knew how many, or how explosive they were. Mr. Schlesinger ordered all agency employees and veterans who knew about such activities to report them -- and then departed to become Defense Secretary.
Mr. Colby, the agency's director of covert operations, was left with a task that violated every precept of a secret agency: compiling a list of the deepest secrets. And the list went on and on, growing to 693 single-spaced pages. The agency had violated its charter by spying on Americans, tapping their telephones, reading their tax returns and opening their mail. It had plotted to assassinate Fidel Castro and other foreign leaders. It had conducted LSD experiments on unwitting human guinea pigs.
The agency's clandestine officers called the list "the family jewels," or "the skeletons." It stayed secret -- for a while.
Mr. Colby's confirmation hearings that summer were excruciating, in part because of his past in Vietnam. From 1968 to 1971, under the aegis of the Agency for International Development, Mr. Colby had run programs that included Operation Phoenix. Conceived by the White House and supported by the C.I.A., that program sought to expose Vietcong agents working in South Vietnam.
Phoenix killed 20,587 Vietnamese. Mr. Colby told Congress in 1971 that these deaths included "illegal killing." As the confirmation hearings convened in July 1973, antiwar protesters plastered Washington with wanted posters emblazoned with Mr. Colby's face, a skull and crossbones and the ace of spades, a symbol of death, his home telephone, which he insisted remain listed, rang with angry calls throughout the night.
After the hearings, conducted largely in private sessions, Mr. Colby was confirmed as the nation's 10th Director of Central Intelligence. Before the vote, he decided to share the family jewels with a few select members of Congress. That was how the C.I.A. did business with the legislative branch in those days.
The secrets did not keep. In December 1974, The New York Times reported that the agency had spied on Americans, and Mr. Colby was a source for the article. Now the pressure for a full Congressional investigation grew irresistible. Mr. Colby cooperated, and the skeletons began tumbling out of the closet.
Senior agency officers called him a traitor. Some hinted that he was a Soviet agent. Those hints grew darker in January 1975, after Mr. Colby dismissed James J. Angleton, for 20 years the agency's chief of counterintelligence. Obsessed with a search for a Soviet spy inside the agency, Mr. Angleton had developed ornate theories of Soviet plots to subvert the United States. Few outsiders understood them -- "possibly because Angleton's explanations were impossible to follow, or possibly because the evidence just didn't add up," Mr. Colby wrote in his memoir.
Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence from 1991 to 1993, recalled that 1975 was the worst year in the agency's history. Mr. Colby spent the year testifying before Congressional committees, and the essence of his testimony became public: the assassination plots, the coups and the spying on Americans. Mr. Colby "had no choice in 1975 but to cooperate," but the agency's pride, "however based on a fiction, took a blow from which we never recovered," Mr. Gates recounts in his just-published memoir, "From the Shadows," (Simon and Schuster).
To save the agency, Mr. Colby believed, he had to confess to its sins. He felt it crucial to educate Congress, the press and the public about the agency. "The agency's survival," he wrote in his memoirs, "could only come from understanding, not hostility, built on knowledge, not faith."
Even after his dismissal as Director of Central Intelligence in November 1975 by President Gerald R. Ford, who believed that Mr. Colby had been too forthcoming, Mr. Colby insisted that he had done the right thing by throwing the cloak off the cloak-and-dagger business.
The end result of his decision was a permanent system of Congressional oversight of the agency -- and a public understanding that the C.I.A. was a tool of Presidential power, not a rogue elephant. When it trampled people, the blame was on the elephant rider: the President of the United States.
By demanding that understanding, Mr. Colby was "playing a very heavy card, trumping the White House by bringing the American people into the secret world," John Ranelagh wrote in his history of the intelligence service, "The Agency" (Simon & Schuster, 1986). But Mr. Colby "got what he wanted: no President could put the C.I.A. in a bottle and throw it away."
His calm in this crisis -- his enemies called it cold-bloodedness -- was composed in equal parts of his grounding in espionage, the military and the Roman Catholic Church. He thought spying for one's country an honorable task, he followed legitimate orders to the hilt and his public confessions took the form of atonement and redemption.
William Egan Colby was born on Jan. 4, 1920, in St. Paul, the son of Elbridge and Margaret Egan Colby. His father, a sensitive nonconformist who wrote and taught literature, became a career Army officer. His family moved constantly, living everywhere from Tientsin, China, to Burlington, Vt.
He enrolled in Princeton University in 1937 and graduated in 1940 with a liberal education and outlook, a Phi Beta Kappa key, R.O.T.C. experience and a deep antipathy to Fascism and Communism. He entered Columbia Law School, but left to join the Army and serve in World War II. He cheated on an eye examination to become a paratrooper, unwittingly taking a path that would lead him into the clandestine world.
In 1943, answering a call for officers who could speak fluent French, he became a member of the Office of Strategic Services, the wartime American espionage agency.
In 1944, he parachuted behind German lines to link up with a French resistance group. In 1945, he commanded a squad of saboteurs who blew up German rail lines in the snows of northern Norway. For these missions, he earned the Silver Star and the French Croix de Guerre.
After the war, he returned to Columbia and received a law degree in 1947. He then joined the Manhattan law firm then known as Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Lombard, run by the founder of the Office of Strategic Services, William J. Donovan. But the law, frankly, bored him, and he joined the fledgling C.I.A. in 1950.
Posing as a diplomat, Mr. Colby served in Stockholm from 1951 to 1953; in Rome from 1953 to 1958; and, fatefully, as the C.I.A.'s station chief in Saigon from 1959 to 1962. He was responsible for all the agency's covert operations in Asia from 1962 to 1967, as the United States went to war in Vietnam. He returned for some of the worst years of the war there, in the doomed cause of winning the hearts and minds of the people.
Mr. Colby left Saigon and returned to Washington in 1971, in part to care for his eldest daughter, Catherine, who was slowly dying of anorexia nervosa. At headquarters, he took on desk jobs that led two years later to the directorship.
In retirement, Mr. Colby lectured, practiced law and worked as a risk consultant to clients that included New York investment banks. In the 1980's, he began speaking out against the nuclear arms race. He argued, along with old hawks like former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara, for deep cuts in nuclear weapons stockpiles. Those cuts are slowly becoming a reality in the 1990's. And he founded the American Commitee for a Free Vietnam, which sought to strengthen human rights and democracy in Vietnam.
In recent months, Mr. Colby became senior editor of Strategic Weekly Briefings, a faxed newsletter, and embarked on a quintessential post-cold-war endeavor: marketing a computer CD-ROM game about espionage and counter-terrorism he created with Oleg Kalugin, a former top Soviet intelligence officer.
Mr. Colby's marriage to the former Barbara Heinzen ended in divorce. He is survived by his wife, Sally Shelton-Colby, an assistant administrator for global programs at the Agency for International Development and a former Ambassador to Grenada, Barbados and eight other eastern Caribbean countries; his children from his first marriage, Jonathan, Carl, Paul and Christine, and six grandchildren.
