HEADLINE: U.S.-Mexican Border: A Shifting Line in the Mud

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: LOS ALGODONES, Mexico

 BODY:
Some people in Washington want to seal the border completely, while some in Mexico City want to use it as a pretext for condemning imperialistic brutality. Alton L. Goff and Alfredo Martinez Orantes only want to know exactly where that emotionally charged line between the United States and Mexico really is.
"I think it's right here, the center of the normal flow channel," said Mr. Goff, chief of the Yuma, Ariz., office of the International Boundary and Water Commission, a quiet warren of engineers and surveyors who for more than a century have watched over the line. He was standing on the western end of the Morelos Dam, where the Colorado River forms 24 miles of the 1,952-mile border between the two countries. 
 "The line? It's over there, above gate number 19," said Mr. Martinez, who runs the dam for Mexico. He pointed across the dam to a spot about 100 yards away where the 19th of 20 floodgates in the international dam is stuck deep in river mud.
That kind of imprecision is not uncommon along this bit of border, where the meanderings of the Colorado and an awesome 1993 flood instantly made obsolete the careful markings of the frontier. In some spots, the raging flood waters moved the channel hundreds of yards into American or Mexican territory.
The waters have long since returned to their former levels, but not to their former channel. That has left most of this area an international question mark, with no real definition. The situation has not yet caused serious problems, and it is unlikely to do so in the future.
But with a covey of Cabinet members from Mexico and the United States gathering in Mexico on May 6 to discuss a range of sensitive issues, the difficulty in precisely defining the line is a small symbol of the many conflicts raging over the border, especially illegal immigration and drug trafficking.
By treaty, the boundary here at the western end of the old Gadsden Purchase is the point where the east-west boundary line separating Arizona from Sonora meets the normal flow channel of the Colorado. Problem is, the river has been dammed at several places, and so much water is diverted into reservoirs, canals and irrigation ditches in both the United States and Mexico that the mighty Colorado is bone dry miles before it gets to this point. With no normal flow, defining a normal flow channel becomes tricky.
"If we say the Border Patrol fence comes out along this line to here, and this is more or less where the normal flow channel used to be, you could say the border is somewhere around here," Mr. Goff said, mustering as much precision as he could.
The forerunner of the International Boundary and Water Commission was established with the signing of the 1848 treaty that ended the Mexican-American War and gave the United States control over a third of what had been Mexican territory from New Mexico to California.
"We really are engineer diplomats," said Rene A. Valenzuela, spokesman for the American side of the binational commission. "The problems we deal with are engineering problems and the solutions usually are very clear."
But some solutions take incredible patience. In 1967, the commission finally resolved a 100-year dispute that arose when a flood sent the Rio Grande on a new course, adding about 600 acres to El Paso at the expense of its Mexican neighbor, Ciudad Juarez.
By the time the Mexicans complained loudly, Anglo settlement had spread to the tract of land, known as Chamizal.
The negotiations between the two sides dragged on for years. "The Mexican Revolution was going on with shots being fired right across the river, but the Chamizal dispute negotiations continued in a courtroom here and were not affected at all," Manuel R. Ybarra, secretary of the American side of the commission, said in his office in El Paso.
Finally, Mexico agreed that it did not make sense to demand that El Paso surrender the Chamizal. The United States in exchange gave up an equivalent amount of land downriver. And to make sure such problems did not arise again, the commission decided to straighten 4.4 miles of the recalcitrant river and line the bed with concrete so the Rio Grande, and the border, would not move.
The commission may end up doing something similar along the Colorado. Mexican surveyors are now studying the flooded areas and preparing a swap proposal that would divvy up the disputed lands.
But even though heated words from Washington and Mexico City often make it appear that the two neighbors want to build a good, sturdy 2,000-mile fence between them, most of the line exists only on paper.
For instance, in San Luis Rio Colorado, the steel fence put up by the Border Patrol a few years ago ends abruptly not far from the official border crossing and is replaced by three-foot high sand dunes.
Mexicans cross the border at San Luis, Ariz., regularly to shop at a new K-Mart or work in the irrigated alfalfa fields on the American side. Americans cross at Los Algodones to visit dentists and cut-rate drug stores including Farmacia Uno, which invites passers-by to "Check Ours Prices."
The pressure of course comes not from the people who live at the border but from the desperate farm workers and unemployed young people in Mexico's poor south, whose perception of the border is of a magical gateway to a place they have only imagined.
But that place often turns out to be as imaginary as the line itself. Even the steel walls can deceive. One scorching afternoon in San Luis, Alfredo Camacho, a local art teacher, was out with five children from the local community center painting scenes on the wall.
"At least this way the wall will have some purpose," said Mr. Camacho as he helped one young boy paint a dove. "Otherwise, why have it here to separate us?"

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Claim Rejected on Dismissal At Metallgesellschaft Unit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 6

 BODY:
Metallgesellschaft A.G. said today that a panel of arbitrators in New York had rejected a claim by the company's former chief oil trader that he was unfairly dismissed after more than $1 billion in trading losses that brought the German company to the brink of bankruptcy.
The arbitrators concluded in a 34-page opinion that W. Arthur Benson, the former president of MG Refining and Marketing, an American unit of Metallgesellschaft, had significantly damaged the company through reckless trading. The panel rejected Mr. Benson's argument that Metallgesellschaft and its banks had caused the losses by scuttling his trading strategy. 
 After being dismissed in February 1994, Mr. Benson sued the MG Corporation, the company's main United States subsidiary, in Federal District Court in Baltimore. The case went to arbitrators after a court ruled that Mr. Benson's contract required arbitration.
In an opinion filed on Friday, the arbitrators said that Mr. Benson had exposed the company to heavy cash losses by selling long-term oil contracts at fixed prices, then securing the contracts by buying short-term futures. The arbitrators criticized his refusal to waver from the strategy even as oil prices fell.
Metallgesellschaft, a conglomerate whose largest businesses are mining and engineering, was criticized in 1994 after it liquidated its oil futures positions. Articles written by Merton H. Miller, a professor at the University of Chicago who is a Nobel laureate in economics, and others contended that Metallgesellschaft had bailed out of Mr. Benson's strategy too soon.
"MG's position has been vindicated," the president and chief executive of MG, Thomas A. McKeever, said in a statement today.
Metallgesellschaft has said it had no choice but to pull the plug on an operation that had become unauthorized speculation.
Mr. Benson said he was shocked by the ruling. "I hope that the panel's ruling will not impede innovation by other individuals who see a way to market products in a manner that is not traditional within the industry," he said in a prepared statement.
Mr. Benson declined to comment on whether he would seek to appeal the ruling. Arbitration decisions usually can be appealed only under limited circumstances.
The arbitration panel has yet to rule on a defamation claim that Mr. Benson has filed against Metallgesellschaft.
Mr. Benson was hired by the company in November 1991 to run the oil marketing business of MG.

HEADLINE: U.N. Extends Iraq Oil Sanctions As a Prod in New Round of Talks

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 6

 BODY:
A fourth round of negotiations on a deal that would allow Iraq to sell a limited amount of oil to pay for urgent civilian needs opened here tonight, hours after the Security Council extended for 60 days the blanket sanctions that have severely damaged the Iraqi economy.
Although the two issues are not directly linked, diplomats said that the unanimity with which the sanctions were renewed should dissuade the Iraqis from letting the oil-for-food talks fail, since it is unlikely that the unrestricted sale of Iraqi oil will be possible any time soon. 
 Madeleine K. Albright, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, said after the sanctions renewal vote this morning that President Saddam Hussein should realize that the restricted oil-sale plan was "the best route for the people of Iraq to get what they need."
Under the plan, proposed by the Security Council last year to counter criticism that sanctions were hurting the poorest and most vulnerable Iraqis, Iraq would be permitted to sell $1 billion in oil in renewable 90-day periods. The sanctions have prevented Iraq from selling oil on the world market in any significant way since its invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
Under present restrictions, Iraq is allowed to export some oil for medicines and food. American officials say that the new oil plan would merely enhance the existing arrangement substantially. But they charge that President Hussein seemed to think he could rewrite the arrangements to give the Iraqi Government greater power over the money raised by larger sales and over the methods of distribution of food and other supplies bought with the income.
Iraq is very closely monitored now by American and other forces in the Persian Gulf area. American and United Nations officials say that while some oil is smuggled to markets with the help of Iran, the amount does not come close to undermining the 1990 sanctions.
Over the weekend President Clinton sent Congress a report on the clandestine sales, saying that ships carrying $1.1 million in petroleum products and $1.4 million in dates had been intercepted in recent months. The Presidential report was one of a series routinely submitted to Congress to keep legislators up to date on Iraqi compliance with sanctions.
After three rounds of talks here on the new oil offer, negotiations broke down last month over an Iraqi demand that Baghdad could choose the bank to handle the money raised and over what the United States and Britain regarded as loopholes that President Hussein had written into a memorandum of understanding that would allow his Government to restrict delivery of emergency supplies in northern territories inhabited by the Kurds or set political conditions for the receipt of goods.
The last-minute intervention by the British and Americans led to charges in Baghdad that the Security Council was rewriting the rules illegally. Americans say that while the Secretary General or his negotiators are not required to seek Security Council approval as they conduct talks with Iraq, the Council will not allow the intent of its oil plan to be subverted in any way.
Broader sanctions against Iraq cannot be lifted by the Council until Baghdad has eliminated or otherwise accounted for all its weapons of mass destruction. Disclosures last year that Iraq had consistently lied in its accounting, and several incidents of noncooperation with United Nations arms inspectors this year, have cost Iraq what limited sympathy and support it was beginning to find in the Security Council.

HEADLINE: Russia's Communists Have New, Mixed Manifesto

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 6

 BODY:
Yuri D. Maslyukov took another puff from his cigarette and smiled about his recent meeting with a senior official from the International Monetary Fund.
"It was like people from the Hawaiian Islands trying to talk to Eskimos," chuckled Mr. Maslyukov, who is a top adviser to the Communist candidate for President of Russia, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, and is also the chairman of Parliament's Committee for Economic Policy. 
 With the election just a month away, Mr. Zyuganov has painted his economic program in generalities and platitudes to avoid unsettling non-Communist voters.
But a Communist brain trust is beginning to assemble. And while Communist economists have yet to produce a master plan, they have deep-seated assumptions about how to redirect the economy away from President Boris N. Yeltsin's reform path and toward greater state control.
They disdain the International Monetary Fund and its tough demands that Russia limit the printing of money and lower barriers to free trade.
In a reflection of their Marxist training, they see stimulating industrial and agricultural production as a cure for Russia's economic problems, even though Western economists warn that this would mean propping up inefficient enterprises.
They argue that Russia's history, its blend of European and Asian cultures -- and even its climate -- make it an exception to the normal laws of economics.
The specialists are an unusual group. Mr. Maslyukov, the former head of the Soviet Union's state planning agency, Gosplan, and a military industrial planning committee, is a key player.
The team also includes a former economics professor from the Rostov Railroad Transport Engineers Institute, and an ethnologist who argues that Russia should follow India's 1969 plan to nationalize leading banks. Another prominent Communist in the group is a nightclub owner and banker who aspires to be Russia's next Economics Minister.
The Communists have also begun to draw on Gorbachev-era economic advisers and academicians who have been languishing in Moscow's research institutes.
Seeking to reassure Russian and Western business executives, the Communists insist that they will support a mixed economy of private and Government-controlled enterprises if they win the election.
"Everyone expects us to wave sabers left and right," said Igor M. Bratishchev, the former Rostov professor and a member of Parliament who is running a policy planning team for Mr. Zyuganov. "We will not make impulsive moves."
But critics assert that the Communists do not speak the language of modern economics and that their inexperience, as much as their ideological commitments, will lead them down the path to an inefficient and rigidly administered command economy.
"None of them knows how the modern economy works," said Vladimir Mau, an economist with an economic institute headed by former Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, a supporter of President Boris N. Yeltsin. "They want to make the economy old-style so that they will know how to deal with it."
 
I.M.F. a Target Of Communist Ire
In trying to hammer out an economic plan, the Communists are more clear about what they are against than what they are for. For many, the International Monetary Fund has become a symbol of heavy-handed Western intervention that has made life harder.
With the strong encouragement of the fund, the Yeltsin Government has restricted the money supply, lowered tariffs and carried out free-market reforms.
The monthly rate of inflation has fallen from 18 percent in January 1995 to less than 3 percent. And the monetary fund recently approved a $10.1 billion loan, which will help Russia pay back wages and finance much of its budget deficit.
But the Russian election is also taking place before the spurt of economic growth projected by the fund. Unemployment has increased. Privatization of Government-owned enterprises has been tainted by reports of favoritism and corruption.
While Mr. Yeltsin has boasted of his ability to obtain loans from the fund, the Communists have sought to convert the President's close association with the fund and its Western leaders into a political liability.
Peering over the piles of papers in his office in Parliament, Mr. Bratishchev said that Russia might need the fund's money in the short term, but that the fund's long-term reforms were incompatible with Russia's unique economic and political culture.
Russia, he argues, is not receptive to major land reform and other extensive free-market measures because it is a mixture of European and Asian cultures and has a collective heritage and a harsh climate.
"Russia is the most northern civilization, and we have to act quite cautiously in our conditions," he said. "This is not being taken into consideration by the I.M.F. We should not be evaluated by commonly accepted measures."
 
Old-School Marxists Accorded Respect
Dislike for the monetary fund among the Communist rank and file has been reinforced by old-school academicians at the Russian Academy of Sciences like Leonid Abalkin.
A former top aide to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mr. Abalkin insists that he is not taking sides in the election. But the academicians are spoken of in almost almost reverential terms by the Communists.
In an interview, Mr. Abalkin complained that "Russia is losing its independence to carry out its internal economic policy."
"Its policy is not being decided by Parliament, but by the I.M.F.," he said.
By way of example, Mr. Abalkin said that one important move supported by the fund, the elimination of tariffs on oil and gas exports, was wrongheaded.
The fund has put the Communists on notice that the new $10.1 billion loan will be revoked if a new Communist government does not stay the course and follow the fund's three-year program of capitalist reforms.
But Mr. Abalkin has written that Russia needs to undertake free market reforms incrementally over a period of decades. And he says that by improving tax collection, Russia could make do without the fund's loans.
Mr. Maslyukov took a more politic line, suggesting that the need to funnel Government funds to needy enterprises might require a new Communist government to seek a new accommodation with the fund to loosen the money supply.
The Communists' complaints have drawn fire from Western specialists, who say the fund's blessing is critical to maintain the confidence of foreign governments and investors.
Instead of stressing the need to press ahead with reforms, the Communists underscore the importance of using subsidies and tariffs to stimulate industrial and agricultural production.
By increasing production, they often argue, Russia can boost employment, revive ailing factories, generate tax revenue and increase the supply of goods, thus driving down inflation.
The Communists have also coupled their promises of aid to ailing industries with populist pledges of guaranteed employment, free education, free health care and cheap housing that far exceed Mr. Yeltsin's campaign largesse, adding to their burden if they come to office.
"What really irks them is, it is true a lot of factories are empty, and it seems illogical to them that a country that once produced 160 million metric tons of steel now produces closer to 80 and 90," said Jeffrey D. Sachs, an economics professor at Harvard University and a former adviser to the Yeltsin Government. "They can't see that the reason is nobody wanted all that steel."
 
Looking East, To India's Example
Citing the need to increase production, the Communist policy team is turning to the East, specifically to India.
Oleg V. Malyarov, a member of the policy team working under Mr. Bratishchev and an ethnologist by training, cited India's experience in nationalizing major banks in 1969 and introducing high tariffs.
By following the Indian example and establishing new Government banks, Mr. Bratishchev and Mr. Malyarov argued, Russia could dispense credits in economically depressed areas.
Western economists consider these Indian policies to be major blunders and say the Indian economy began to take off when they were changed. Western economists also insist that increasing the supply of goods will not lower inflation unless Russian factories succeed in making high-quality consumer items that people want.
Private property is also a sensitive issue for businessmen worried about renationalization, and one that the Communists have not addressed in detail.
The Communists say they will allow the privatization of some state-owned property. But they say they will renationalize those enterprises whose privatization, in their view, was not lawful or socially useful.
Vladimir V. Semago, a Communist member of Parliament, banker and nightclub owner, said in an interview that a Communist victory "does not mean at all that we will switch to a 100 percent controlled economy."
 
Compensation Promised to Owners
The owners of any enterprises that are nationalized will receive compensation, said Mr. Semago, who added that he hoped to become the Economics Minister in a new Communist government.
Sergei Glazyev, a left-leaning Parliament member and a member of the party known as the Congress of Russian Communities, said he expected the Communists to "intervene in the so-called basic industries" -- energy, transportation, telecommunications, military production and foreign trade -- and put them under strict state control.
But Anatoly B. Chubais, a former Deputy Prime Minister who headed the Government's privatization program and who is backing Mr. Yeltsin's election team, said there was not enough money in the Russian budget to buy back privatized enterprises at fair market prices.
Mr. Chubais warned that the Communists would essentially resort to confiscation, which could lead to unrest. And he charged that Mr. Maslyukov and other Communist specialists had failed to master the economic facts.
"When I was in the Government I had 20 to 25 high-level people I could trust," Mr. Chubais said. "They were super-skilled macroeconomists. But not one of them will work under the Communists. There is no one of such type within the economic team of the Communists."
But those sort of statements are dismissed as elitism by the Communist rank and file.
Mr. Malyarov, the policy team member, noted proudly that he had recently completed a book on Mr. Chubais's privatization program entitled "The Crime of the Century Will Be Stopped by the People."
"The bad thing about economists ruling the country is that they consider that only they know the right way," he added.

HEADLINE: Behind the Cloak of Office, Clinton's War Room Hums

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
The settings are tailor-made for Bill Clinton's shadow campaign.
Beginning Friday, Mr. Clinton will don academic robes for a flying series of commencement addresses that put Mr. Clinton the President, not the candidate, on display, trying for a tone high above the charge and countercharge of political combat. 
 Yet even as Mr. Clinton takes care to give no hint of the consuming re-election drive under way, his White House is already humming like a well-oiled political machine. Clinton-Gore headquarters on M Street is filling up, and the President's political strategists are planning to have at least 40 state Democratic campaign coordinators in place by Memorial Day.
The White House has become relentless in its opposition research, answering Senator Bob Dole's call for a repeal of the 4.3-cent-a-gallon tax on gasoline with a list of gasoline tax increases that Mr. Dole, the presumptive Republican nominee for President, has supported in his Capitol Hill career. And the Democratic National Committee has become so quick that within 24 hours of Mr. Dole's recent attack on judges appointed by Mr. Clinton as soft on crime, it had a 30-second commercial on the air boosting the President's crime-fighting credentials.
This combination of outward incumbent serenity and an internal staff war footing is the key to Mr. Clinton's re-election strategy.
Mr. Clinton is in a personal drive to push his positive ratings ever higher before the Democratic National Convention in August by using all of the rhetorical, ceremonial and majestic possibilities of incumbency. The goal is to appear Presidential, not merely political. To this end, Mr. Clinton has even forsaken the traditional formal announcement of his candidacy.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton's aides are waging an ever-more public campaign designed to insure that the President's approval ratings translate into victory in November.
So far the linked strategies -- along with Republican disarray -- appear to be producing the desired result. Mr. Clinton, so soundly repudiated in the 1994 Congressional elections, is showing some of the highest approval ratings of his Presidency and maintaining a lead of 15 to 20 points over Mr. Dole in national polls.
Congressional Democrats, who once fled joint appearances with the weakened President, now clamor to stand by his side, and Democrats are increasingly optimistic about their chances of winning back control of the House. Around the nation, Mr. Clinton is running better than expected in Republican-leaning states like Arizona, Florida, North Dakota, Oklahoma and Virginia, states that Mr. Dole cannot afford to lose.
All this could prove evanescent, particularly with a volatile electorate increasingly disconnected from party allegiances. "The good news is we're doing a lot better," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the general chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "The bad news is the election isn't tonight.
Republicans insist that the race will tighten and that traditional Republican voters and states will come home to the party. At this time four years ago, they note, President George Bush was 16 points ahead of Mr. Clinton.
But Mr. Clinton's current margins, Democrats counter, mean that the Republicans could be forced to divert money and resources from the major battleground states to those they had expected to win easily. "Your base usually does come back," said Mark Mellman, a Democratic strategist. "But if you start out without your base intact, it's an indication of how far you have to go."
For months the President's political advisers have assumed that Mr. Clinton's drive for re-election would be divided into two distinct periods: a "referendum" period in which the public judges whether it approves of Mr. Clinton, followed by the head-to-head contest after the party nominating conventions this summer.
In this first period, the goal is to pull Mr. Clinton's approval ratings up so high before the conventions that he will have the aura of invincibility that President Ronald Reagan had in his 1984 re-election campaign. "You don't win the campaign for votes in the fall," said Ann F. Lewis, the President's deputy campaign manager, "if you don't win the campaign for public opinion first in the spring."
This effort began a year ago when Mr. Clinton moved to the political center and embraced the Republicans' goal of a balanced budget.
The next step was to paint the Republicans as "extremists" out of sync with the nation in their efforts to scale back spending on Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment. The President's budget vetoes and his decision to send American troops to Bosnia also helped combat the earlier impression of Mr. Clinton as reluctant to stand up for his principles.
This year, the President moved to take over some of the Republicans' cultural issues, advocating school uniforms and school competency tests, fighting tobacco use by teen-agers and supporting use of a television chip that would allow parents to screen out programming they find unacceptable for their children.
Now, Mr. Clinton's aides say, the President will use a series of commencement speeches on foreign policy, economic policy and social values to define his views sharply, hoping to answer critics who say he still has not painted a full vision for a second term.
Since last fall, a steady $1 million-a-week television advertising campaign has been amplifying the President's themes in the third of the country that the Clinton campaign considers to be the true battleground for November. Paid for by the Democratic National Committee, the campaign has largely sidestepped the Northeast and stayed out of big cities like New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, where Mr. Clinton is considered safely ahead and television time is expensive.
Instead, the commercials have been running in other parts of California, across the Pacific Northwest, in Colorado and New Mexico, which both voted for Mr. Clinton in 1992, and even Arizona, which last voted Democratic in a Presidential election in 1948.
In the South, the campaign has focused on Florida, which Mr. Clinton narrowly lost in 1992, North Carolina and Tennessee, Vice President Al Gore's home state. And they are running all across the states of the industrial Midwest as well as in Iowa and Pennsylvania.
Recently, the tone of the commercials has changed, painting a negative portrait of Mr. Dole. In a commercial on crime, color pictures of Mr. Clinton signing bills were contrasted with black-and-white shots of Mr. Dole, always side by side with Speaker Newt Gingrich, whose popularity ratings plummeted last year. The message was, "Their old ways don't work." Mr. Clinton's crime plan was called, "The new way."
The Democratic National Committee has now spent nearly $25 million on this campaign, none of which is charged against Federal spending limits on the Presidential campaign, since it revolves around legislative issues. With the Clinton-Gore campaign still hoarding more than $20 million in unspent primary-season money, a multimillion-dollar onslaught of new Clinton spots is scheduled before the August party conventions.
While Republicans agree that current polling makes the picture look bad for Mr. Dole, they say voting trends show that the Republicans have a natural advantage on the electoral map and predict that states will ultimately stay true to their voting histories. They also believe that some economic issues will work to their benefit.
Eddie Mahe Jr., a Republican political strategist and former deputy party chairman, mocked the idea that Republicans would have to use any resources to win in Arizona.
"If we have to spend 7 cents to save Arizona," Mr. Mahe said, "then let's cancel the election and just have an inauguration." Democratic contentions that such a state was up for grabs, he said are "pure mind games."
Several Democratic stratetgists admit privately that they are worried, for instance, about the potency of a Republican appeal based on tax cuts. Significantly, in the recent sparring with Mr. Dole the White House has not closed the door on a repeal of the 1993 gasoline tax.
As Clinton aides prepare to send out a fleet of political veterans to coordinate the state-by-state campaigns, they say they are casting a broad net.
"We don't want to create a self-fulfilling prophecy where everybody says that you can't win a certain state," said Douglas Sosnick, the President's director of political affairs. "We want to make sure that if in September we might very well be able to win Arizona, we've done the things needed to enhance our ability to win."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Study Backs CUNY Admissions
The open-admissions policy that 25 years ago transformed the City University of New York by guaranteeing entry to almost all New York City high school graduates was far more successful in educating needy students than earlier research suggested, according to a new long-term study of thousands of students. The study, which surveyed students who entered the City University under the open-admissions policy, found that more than half received bachelor's degrees. [Page A1.]
 
Helmsleys Are Sued by Partners
Two of Harry Helmsley's longtime partners in the Helmsley-Spear realty firm have sued the Helmsleys, alleging that Leona Helmsley was stripping the company of its assets and essentially rendering it insolvent to avoid paying the partners millions of dollars. But the dispute is not just about money. The quarrel is more about control and ego and bonds of loyalty being unwound. [A1.]
 
Joycean Saga of an Exhibition
The rare book dealer Glenn Horowitz is holding an opening night party in his East Side shop to celebrate a $2.4 million exhibition of first edition works by Joyce, including two copies of "Ulysses" signed by the author. Mr. Horowitz acquired the bulk of the collection from his longtime client, Dennis M. Silverman, the former president of Local 810, who was ousted by the Teamsters for misappropriation of funds. [B1.]
 
Church Worker Is Accused
An employee in the accounting and pension operations of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn was accused by the head of the diocese of stealing more than $1 million in church money. Since 1990, the employee managed the diocesan pension office and its system of benefits to 3,600 retired lay employees. [B1.]
 
Transit, the Good and the Bad
Subway lines on Manhattan's West Side took a bath, literally, when a geezer of a water main became a geyser, yet the Transit Authority resumed normal runs within 16 hours. Not bad. But that fine performance does not diminish rider dissatisfaction with overall service. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Labor Chief in Political Spat
A meeting between New York City's labor leaders and Congressional Democrats was shaping up as a lovefest, but then Stanley Hill, executive director of the city's largest municipal employees union, stunned everyone by lauding Mayor Giuliani and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, while criticizing Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. [B3.]
 
Pataki on School Spending
Governor Pataki called on the agency that builds public schools in New York City to stop spending money to buy art for schools, contending that the nearly $12 million that the agency has spent over five years should have been used for repairs. [B5.]
 
Budget Stalemate Intensifies
With the state's budget now six weeks late, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, stepped up his attacks against Governor Pataki, accusing him of trying to undermine public schools. [B5.]
 
Studying Pesticides and Cancer
Women's groups, which have charged that extensive use of pesticides may be a factor in the high rates of breast cancer on Long Island, and farmers have come together to endorse a proposal by State Senate Republicans that would address the issue of pesticides and cancer. It would not, however, impose restrictions on usage. [B5.]
 
Book Symposium Is Canceled
New York University abruptly canceled a long-planned symposium of Holocaust scholars after an author whose book on the Holocaust has been sharply criticized in Germany withdrew because of fears that the event would attract hostile German press coverage. [B6.]
 
Trees and Air Pollution
A group of scientists working in the mountain forests of New York and New England has found new evidence that toxic heavy metals in polluted air can contribute to the death of trees. Science Times. [C4.]
 
CONNECTICUT
 
A Welfare Proposal Stalls
Gov. John G. Rowland's proposal to withhold welfare checks from families whose children skip school has apparently stalled after his own task force concluded there was no evidence that children from welfare families skipped school more than other children. A report suggests that such a measure may be premature and that schools had failed to enforce truancy laws. [B1.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Voting on Care for Uninsured
In the latest attempt to end a five-month stalemate over how to pay for hospital care for the uninsured, the State Assembly approved legislation that would cover the costs by continuing to rely on unemployment payroll taxes. The measure still faces uncertainty in the Republican-controlled Senate. [B5.]
 
Water Agency Head Is Indicted
The head of Newark's water and sewer agency, Carol Gardner, was indicted in a scheme in which officials said he pocketed thousands of dollars from businesses dealing with the city. [B5.]

HEADLINE: Looted of Art, German Town Now Feels Economically Plundered

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: QUEDLINBURG, Germany

 BODY:
Six years ago, word reached this medieval town in eastern Germany that its fabled stolen treasures, lost since World War II, had been found in Texas. But people were preoccupied then: their land was about to be reunified.
Now, the trial of the people accused of selling the stolen treasure back to Germany is to open in Texas later this year. But this news finds people still preoccupied, not with the excitements of German reunification, but with its legacy: this town may boast royal treasure, but it does not have too many jobs. 
 "Unemployment -- that's what people talk about," said Friedemann Gosslau, a former Protestant minister here who was one of three people to bring the treasure back to Germany from Whitewright, Tex., in 1992.
In 1945, when American troops briefly occupied the town, Lieut. Joe Tom Meador mailed parts of the Quedlinburg treasure -- golden reliquaries, Fatimid crystal, gospel texts bound in gold, even King Henry's ivory comb -- back to Texas.
Lieutenant Meador died in 1980, and his brother and sister -- Jack Meador and Jane Meador Cook -- tried to sell the treasures in the medieval art market.
In negotiations from 1990 to 1992, the new German state paid $2.75 million to get the treasures back, but now the brother and sister, and their lawyer, John S. Torigian, face trial in Sherman, Tex., for dealing in stolen goods.
"If you look at it from the legal standpoint, it's right to do it," said Werner Bley, the custodian of the Quedlinburg treasures. "But what will it achieve?"
Mr. Gosslau, the former pastor, said: "Those people hurt us. They could have returned the treasure without payment. But, in German, we say: this is snow from yesterday."
The more immediate preoccupations are evident.
Across this part of Germany, in the state of Saxony-Anhalt, unemployment runs at more than 20 percent, more than twice a national average that is itself the highest in postwar German history.
But while for some in the western part of the country there is still a prospect of the economic pendulum swinging back in their favor, here in the former East Germany, permanent joblessness has become the grim legacy of reunification.
Take, for instance, the town of Eisleben, 30 miles from here, where the copper mines that drew Martin Luther's father to settle more than 500 years ago still provided work for some 22,000 miners until reunification in 1990.
Even though they had long been economically unviable, the Communist authorities put greater stress on jobs than efficiency.
With the western capitalist system that has since taken root, most of the mines have been closed; only 2,000 of the miners now have steady work.
Here the story is the same. With reunification in 1990, economic principles from the west forced the closing of most of the town's inefficient industries, including a steelworks, and the notion of guaranteed work, a pillar of Communist society, died with them.
Some in this town have come to question whether, treasure or not, the process of reunification has been to their advantage.
"Everything is so expensive," said Mr. Bley, the custodian of the Quedlinburg treasures. "The party used to rule. Now money rules."
"It's the system," he added. "It's as bad as Communism. It exploits the poor. It's unsocial."
Referring to the year the Berlin wall fell, he added, "We should have thought more deeply in 1989."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Real Bosnia Debate

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina

 BODY:
For the past few months U.S. and NATO officials have been saying how pleased they are at how well the cease-fire and separation of forces in Bosnia has been implemented, but how upset they are that the political clauses of the Dayton peace agreement -- such as the return of refugees and the holding of elections -- have not been carried out. This is not an accident. This is a structural contradiction at the heart of Dayton. And it may soon become the foreign policy issue in the U.S. election.
The very reason the Bosnia cease-fire holds so well is the very reason the political clauses are not being implemented. The cease-fire holds because each of the Bosnian factions is led by authoritarian-nationalist figures, who can give an order to halt the fighting and it will be obeyed right down the line. The reason the political clauses are not being implemented is because they threaten the power bases of many of these same leaders, who have an interest in keeping Bosnia divided and the conflict defined in nationalist terms to insure their hold on power. When it comes to implementing the cease-fire, says Lieut. Gen. Michael Walker, commander of NATO ground forces in Bosnia, the Serbian, Muslim and Croatian leaders give all the right orders. But when it comes to the political clauses, "What we are getting is not only a failure to instruct" but rather "instructions in the opposite direction." General Walker said the actions of Serbian, Croatian and Muslim leaders "indicate a preference for partition." 
 NATO can live with partition. It just wants a quiet Bosnia until it leaves. But the diplomats believe that the West must try to achieve the unification of Bosnia that Dayton promised. That's only possible if NATO removes Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic, the two indicted Serbian war criminals who remain in charge in the separatist Bosnian Serb Republic. Because if elections were held now Mr. Karadzic would be re-elected as president, giving him a democratic mandate sanctioned by the international community -- the last thing the West wants to promote. The NATO allies had been hoping that the Serbs themselves would eliminate Messrs. Mladic and Karadzic. But that's not happening. So the pressure is rising on NATO to capture them to promote unity, and NATO doesn't want to do that for fear of upsetting stability -- and for fear of making NATO a party to the conflict.
What to do? That depends on what you believe is really possible in Bosnia. I believe that the best that is possible, for the next few years, is a stable but loose partition into Serbian, Croatian and Muslim cantons. In this scenario, Bosnia does not need elections right now, but just an ongoing NATO presence to keep the peace, as the parties themselves figure out how, and how much, they want to live and trade together. Any faction that doesn't turn over war criminals should be diplomatically and economically isolated.
But the Clinton Administration's view is that, if possible, Bosnia should be unified into a single federal state, beginning with elections by September for a revolving presidency. But you cannot realize that vision for Bosnia without removing Messrs. Karadzic and Mladic. Ejup Ganic, Bosnia's Muslim Vice President, told me that after NATO recently tracked down an Iranian terrorist center in Bosnia and seized it with helicopters and tanks he told NATO "that was a perfect dry run for how you should go in and get Mladic and Karadzic." Added Mr. Ganic: "Could you have succeeded in developing democracy in Germany if Hitler were allowed to stay around? You Americans told us Bosnia is a single state and we stick to that sentence."
But in the Bosnian Serb capital of Pale, Momcilo Krajisnik, the president of the Serb Republic's parliament, told me: "The people here really do not believe Mladic and Karadzic are war criminals. NATO is a great force, which only a foolish leadership would ignore. But if I could give any advice, I would advise NATO never to try taking Mladic and Karadzic by force. Some things have to remain taboo."
This is the real issue that President Clinton and Bob Dole are going to have to debate this fall -- not the phony issue of Iranian arms transfers. If the U.S. is committed to elections in Bosnia and to its unification, then it must remove the Serb war criminals still in charge. If it is ready to accept de facto partition as the least bad option then it will have to forgo elections. Mr. President, Mr. Dole, which will it be?

HEADLINE: Fleet Agrees to Settle Accusation of Loan Discrimination

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 7

 BODY:
The Fleet Financial Group Inc. agreed today to pay about $4 million to hundreds of black and Hispanic customers to settle United States Justice Department allegations that minority borrowers were charged more for loans than whites.
The Fleet Mortgage Group unit of the bank agreed to pay 600 minority borrowers in Westbury, L.I., and Woodbridge, N.J., up to $15,000 each to compensate for higher interest rates and fees on mortgages they received in 1993 and 1994. Fleet Mortgage, the third-largest mortgage company in the country, also agreed to develop a uniform mortgage pricing and monitoring system to prevent discriminatory lending practices. 
 "Loans should be based on risk, not race," said Deval Patrick, Assistant Attorney General for civil rights. "By changing their practices, Fleet has stepped forward and done the right thing."
The settlement ends a Justice Department investigation that began last year, after the Federal Reserve expressed concern that Fleet Mortgage charged more to minority borrowers than to whites at its Westbury and Woodbridge offices from August 1993 to June 1994.
Fleet Mortgage, in settling charges that it violated fair-lending and anti-discrimination laws, denied engaging in any discriminatory practices.
"We want to make sure that discriminatory lending practices are not occurring," said Gerald L. Baker, chief executive and chairman of Fleet Mortgage, which is based in Columbia, S.C.
The investigation centered on the practice by Fleet Mortgage of paying bonuses to employees who charged customers rates or fees above the company's base lending rate. Although bonuses tied to higher rates, known as overages, are legal and used by many banks, Federal officials said the practice encouraged bankers at the two Fleet Mortgage offices to charge minority customers more than others.
The settlement is the first of its kind to set a standard that banks can use to avoid allowing their bonus programs to lead to discrimination, Mr. Baker said. Fleet has now set up a system to monitor rates and fees charged to customers based on their race. The company plans to use it to identify cases in which lending officers might be charging black or Hispanic borrowers more than whites who are of equal credit risk, he said.
Fleet agreed to pay $3.8 million, or an average of $6,000 to the 600 affected customers, plus $200,000 for a community education program on home mortgages.
Fleet halted the bonuses at all mortgage offices when the Federal Reserve first expressed concern. With the new monitoring system in place, Fleet Mortgage plans to resume the bonus system, Mr. Baker said.
The Government has gone after other banks suspected of using overages to charge minority borrowers more for loans. Last fall, Huntington Bancshares Inc., a Columbus, Ohio, bank, agreed to pay $420,000 to black customers who were charged more than white borrowers for their mortgages. The Justice Department blamed overages for the problem.
Fleet Financial, the nation's ninth-largest bank, faced charges of discriminatory lending practices in its lending units before. In 1992, the bank's Atlanta-based consumer finance unit, Fleet Finance Inc., settled claims by Georgia's Attorney General and a class-action lawsuit that it overcharged minority borrowers. Fleet Finance set up a $38 million fund to restructure such loans nationwide.
Fleet Financial is hoping to sell Fleet Finance in the next few months.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
3-Year Note Fares Poorly At Auction

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved lower yesterday, hurt by a weak sale of new three-year notes.
The sale was the first part of the Treasury's $33 billion quarterly refunding this week, and the results raised concerns over how well today's auction of new 10-year notes would fare. Still, bond prices came off their lows yesterday, and some analysts were impressed that the market did as well as it did, given the worries over absorbing new supply.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended down 4/32, to 86 26/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 7.07 percent, from 7.05 percent on Monday.
The Treasury sold $19 billion in three-year notes yesterday, with an average yield of 6.39 percent -- the highest since Feb. 7, 1995, when it was 7.34 percent. Wall Street had been expecting yields that high, said Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of government bond trading at Cowen & Company.
But "the bid-to-cover ratio was not good," he said, referring to the ratio that compares the dollar amount of bids with the securities sold. The ratio yesterday was a weak 2.03, down from 2.67 at the last auction.
"I think what saved the auction from disaster was the fact that the yield on a three-year note is up 130 basis points since the last auction," he added. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, noted that there was interest in the notes from foreign investors, but "for the most part, domestic investors did not have a whole lot of reason to jump into it."
Yet while the results of the auction were far from stellar, he said that "the Street did a great job by backing up yields to make them attractive."
"The spot where the Street bought the auction turned out to be a reasonable place to buy them, at least temporarily," he said.
Matthew Alexy, chief market strategist for CS First Boston, said that what helped the market yesterday was that prices had cheapened over the last couple of days. "The Street managed to back yields up nicely," he said yesterday, adding about today's sale of 10-year notes, "but where the 10's are cheap enough will be determined by the results of tomorrow's Fed beige book report."
The Federal Reserve is to release today its survey of regional business activity, known as the beige book.
Regardless of whether a Fed report comes out on the auction day, the 10-year notes are often more difficult to sell than shorter-term notes.
The market shrugged off several economic reports, including weak weekly retail sales data from Bank of Tokyo/Mitsubishi Schroder Wertheim and Johnson Redbook. Market participants are waiting for clearer indications on the pace of inflation, possibly in Friday's report on producer prices in April.
Investors are also keeping close tabs on possible shifts in asset allocations by portfolio managers. In the last few days, Merrill Lynch and Smith Barney announced that they were maintaining current levels in bonds, but had reduced the stock portions of their recommended portfolios.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Fidelity is developing an office complex in Rhode Island as the state rolls out the red carpet.

BYLINE: By Susan Diesenhouse 

DATELINE: SMITHFIELD, R.I.

 BODY:
THE FMR Corporation, the parent of Fidelity Investments, is developing a new office complex here as the mutual fund giant continues to expand outside its home state of Massachusetts.
The move has coincided with efforts by Massachusetts to give tax breaks to certain businesses to keep them operating and growing in the state. 
 In March, Fidelity received the zoning variances it needed from this town to start construction in the Island Woods Commerce Center, about 55 miles southwest of Boston. The first phase consists of a 200,000-square-foot office building, with a 1,000-car garage, and a second building with a garage is also being considered. The complex will at first house 1,000 employees.
Last year, a package of real estate development and tax incentives prompted Fidelity to move its growing institutional services business to Smithfield. In exchange, the state expects to get about 300 new jobs.
With similar tax incentives being planned for other financial service sectors, Rhode Island hopes to attract new industries and jobs.
"We're in a better position than Massachusetts because we're more interested in jobs than corporate revenues and we didn't have to give up anything," Gov. Lincoln C. Almond said in a telephone interview.
Since 1994, Rhode Island has enacted laws that permit the state to exempt Fidelity from sales tax on building materials, equipment, computer hardware and software for the 30 years of the lease, said Marcel A. Valois, director of the state Economic Development Office. Under a new law, mutual fund companies pay corporate income tax only on in-state sales. For Fidelity, that should be less than 5 percent of the business it handles through the new office complex, Mr. Valois said.
The state will award the company a credit against its rent of $2,000 a year for each Rhode Islander hired above the initial 1,000 workers. Fidelity will relocate at least 400 workers from Massachusetts and hire an undetermined amount of Rhode Islanders. The state may also pay 50 percent of the cost to train those workers up to $5,000 each.
In addition, Smithfield signed a 30-year tax agreement that fixes Fidelity's property assessment at $100 a square foot for the first 300,000 square feet, with values to rise 15 percent every five years, the Town Manager, Jeffrey Minor, said.
The state owns the 130-acre Island Woods center. It bought the land in 1992 for $3.3 million from a private developer who tried to lure biotechnology companies from Massachusetts. The state has invested $2 million in roads and utilities and will issue about $25 million in taxable bonds to purchase and improve 200 adjacent acres.
Fidelity will lease about 325 acres and its rent will equal the debt service on the bonds, about $1.5 million a year.
In Massachusetts, where land and operating costs are higher, the administration of Gov. William F. Weld has also made an effort to keep and attract jobs.
Still, the move by Fidelity shows how some of the state's companies have chosen to expand in other states. In 1990, about 65 percent of Fidelity's 7,000 jobs were in Massachusetts; now only 50 percent of the company's 19,138 jobs are there. Much of the company's growth has been in Kentucky, Ohio, Utah, Texas and New Hampshire.
Last year, Massachusetts agreed to give its largest private employer, Raytheon, a tax break and is now considering one for Fidelity.
But the use of costly tax-break incentives has its critics.
Herman Leonard, professor of public management at Harvard University, said that he worried that even with tax breaks, New England might still lose jobs. "I don't think Rhode Island will be Fidelity's last stop," he said.

HEADLINE: A Top Economist Switches His View on Productivity

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
In the endless debate over whether companies in the huge service sector are becoming more efficient and productive, Stephen S. Roach is famous as the economist who says, flatly, they are. No skeptic can challenge that proposition without facing down Mr. Roach. He has preached his case on talk shows, before Congress, in academia and on Wall Street. But now he is changing his mind.
"I must confess that I am having second thoughts as to whether we have reached the promised land," Mr. Roach said, in the opening paragraph of a circular that will be faxed tomorrow to the media and to hundreds of clients of Morgan Stanley & Company, where he is chief economist. "These doubts have caused me to rethink many of the glorious conclusions that I have long argued would be part of the sacred productivity-led recovery." 
 The conversion of Mr. Roach, who is 50, reflects a growing national debate over the downsizings and revampings that have characterized corporate behavior for 15 years. Most economists now say that the process has fallen short of its goal of greater productivity and thus an economy that can grow ever more vigorously. Mr. Roach had been one of the few prominent holdouts from this view. "And now I am not a holdout," he said.
What Mr. Roach thought had happened, in his revised view has not. He had thought that big investments in computers and other technology at the array of stores, banks, railroads, airlines, law firms and the like that make up the service sector had allowed employees to do more work. This coupled with wave after wave of mergers and layoffs left fewer workers doing the same amount of work. That showed up as more output for each hour worked by the surviving employees, which is the definition of improved productivity.
What made Mr. Roach so famous was that he had maintained this view with energy and logic -- and all the authority that being the chief economist at Morgan Stanley gave to his pronouncements -- even though the rising productivity that he envisioned did not show up in the Labor Department's statistics. Investors took his views as encouragement to buy. After all, rising productivity in the service sector, which generates so much national wealth, should mean a strong economy and strong profits. An airline clerk who, with a computer, doubles her output to 10 ticket sales an hour raises the airline's revenues and profits.
It is true that the economy has grown and profits have indeed been strong. But for Mr. Roach this is no longer a proper measure. A higher level of productivity must be a permanent improvement, he says, and what has been happening is only temporary. The airline, instead of selling more tickets, has simply kept cutting back the number of clerks selling them.
"If it turns out that all we have done is squeeze out labor," Mr. Roach said in an interview, "then I have to reverse what I have built a reputation on. And it is increasingly clear to me that the improvements in operating performance and profits have been built on a steady stream of downsizings and cost cutting that is just not sustainable. If all you do is cut, then you will eventually be left with nothing, with no market share."
He still thinks, however, that the Labor Department's productivity numbers are "screwy," the result of mismeasurement. The Government says that while productivity among manufacturers rose by 3.2 percent a year in the 1990's -- suggesting considerable gains in efficiency in that area -- for the economy as a whole the annual rise has been only 1.1 percent, which means that the service sector has really been a drag on the data.
Mr. Roach had argued that productivity for the economy as a whole had risen in the 1990's at a 2.25 percent annual rate, but now he is scaling this estimate back to between 1.5 percent and 2 percent. Very probably, he says, no one is counting all the extra hours that people on fixed salaries work, including his own 15-hour days traveling constantly, with a computer on his lap as his office.
Mr. Roach, who holds a Ph.D. in economics from New York University and served as a chief forecaster at the Federal Reserve before going to Wall Street in 1979, drew attention to his productivity views in a 1991 article in the Harvard Business Review.
He argued there, and in subsequent writings, that the service sector had invested heavily in computer technology in the 1980's, and then in the 1990's made increasingly efficient use of this investment through mergers and downsizings. A year ago, he began to sense that workers were restive, and as that awareness grew, Mr. Roach began to talk of a "worker backlash," a perception that gradually brought him to his latest view.
The steady economic growth, the low inflation and the strong profits have been real, he says, but they do not reflect a sustainable rise in productivity, as he once thought. "The fatal flaw," Mr. Roach said, "is that they are built on the back of hollowing out labor." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Signs Pact on Telling Mexico About Certain Migrant Cases

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 7

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher signed an agreement here today pledging that American officials will notify Mexican diplomats in the United States whenever pregnant Mexican women or Mexican children are detained as illegal immigrants.
The agreement, signed at the close of an annual Mexico-United States meeting, also spells out more explicitly than previously the rights of Mexican consular officials to interview Mexicans detained in the United States and to attend their trials if they are prosecuted for crimes. 
 The agreement, titled the "Memorandum of Understanding on Consular Protection," largely reaffirms rights recognized by both countries in earlier treaties. But an official of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service said the agreement would nonetheless oblige Border Patrol officials to be more consistent in communicating with Mexican diplomats about the detention of illegal Mexican migrants, and would most likely mean a significant increase in the Border Patrol's work load in some border areas.
The meeting came at a time of rising Mexican concerns over the treatment of migrant workers in the United States, with fears aroused by the videotaped beating of undocumented Mexicans on April 1 by two California sheriff's deputies and more recently by the passage in Congress of an immigration law that will double the size of the Border Patrol.
As a result, the Mexican Government was under considerable pressure from its domestic critics to negotiate forcefully with the Clinton Administration over immigration issues. Foreign Minister Angel Gurria said today that he considered the migration agreement to be a considerable triumph for Mexico.
Taking part in the 24-hour meeting, one in a series of annual encounters dating to 1981, were Mr. Christopher, Attorney General Janet Reno, Interior Minister Bruce Babbitt, four other members of President Clinton's Cabinet and a combined total of 300 other American and Mexican officials. The Governments discussed hundreds of issues, in 16 working groups, everything from trade disputes over tuna to pollution along the 2,000-mile border to ways of counting each nation's unemployed.
Mr. Christopher said the talks had brought special progress in combating money-laundering. Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, who spoke for the United States in one of two working groups that discussed the topic, said the United States had agreed to help Mexico set up a computerized system for mandatory reporting by banks of suspicious transactions.
The tone of this year's meeting was almost celebratory, with a great deal of back-slapping and well-wishing. Outlining a series of nettling disputes, however, Mr. Gurria spoke with special vehemence against the Helms-Burton Act, the law signed on March 12 that tightens the United States's 34-year-old embargo against Cuba by trying to restrict non-American investment there.
The uncertainty that the law has aroused has already hurt a Mexican company that last year bought 49 percent of Cuba's national telephone system and had hoped to find an American partner. And many other Mexican entrepreneurs are worried about how the measure may affect them. Mr. Gurria told Mr. Christopher on Monday that Mexico "firmly rejects" Helms-Burton.
Mr. Christopher sought to smooth those ruffled feathers this morning. Clinton Administration lawyers who are currently writing the regulations that will give teeth to the law, he said, are seeking to "maximize the pressure on the Cuban Government to change, and to minimize the effect on business in friendly countries."

HEADLINE: AT LUNCH WITH: Raoul Peck;
Exporting Haitian Culture to the World

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
RAOUL PECK'S big, bright, brown eyes draw you toward him and grip you as you listen to his soft English, accented by a Parisian lilt. It is through those eyes that Mr. Peck, 43, a Haitian-born film maker, shows the world his world. Haiti. Zaire. France. Germany and the United States.
But for a few hours on a recent afternoon, Mr. Peck's world was reduced to a small Italian bistro in Greenwich Village, where he discussed his dual roles as independent artist and Haiti's new Minister of Culture. 
 "This is not my favorite hangout," Mr. Peck said, sipping a glass of the house white at Ennio & Michael. "It's the closest one to my apartment."
As one of Haiti's few film makers, Mr. Peck is a primary exporter of Haitian films to the rest of the world. Since he was appointed Minister of Culture in February, he has also had the challenge of improving the cultural image of a country that has been tarnished by decades of political turmoil.
Mr. Peck's most recent film, "The Man by the Shore," is a dark movie set in a seemingly sleepy, run-down fictional town during the middle of the dictatorship of Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier. It is told through the struggle of Sarah, an 8-year-old who has to remain in Haiti with her grandmother after her father, a discredited army captain, flees the country. Sarah's recurring nightmare of a family friend's torture vividly captures the personal impact of tyranny and brutality that thousands of Haitians faced during the 30 years of the Duvalier regime.
"It was not until after I finished the film that I realized how much of it came from my own memories," Mr. Peck said.
Raising his voice above the cacophony of the lunch-hour crowd, Mr. Peck, dressed in a navy blue sports jacket and a gray shirt, clasped his hands and explained that the music, colors and atmosphere in his films provide audiences with snapshots of his life.
The Haiti of Mr. Peck's childhood was a place where henchmen would storm into government offices and remove workers simply for not being vocal supporters of Mr. Duvalier. And Mr. Peck's father, Hebert, like the father of the movie's heroine, was arrested and spent some time in prison. Mr. Peck's crime was trying to unionize farmers.
That incident set in motion a life in exile for young Mr. Peck and his two younger brothers. Mr. Peck moved with his family to Zaire at age 8. His father, an agronomist, worked for the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization and Unesco. His mother, Giselle, who died about 10 years ago, was an aide to several mayors in Kinshasa, the capital. His family was one of a coterie of highly educated Haitians who went to francophone Africa during the early 1960's to help build the newly independent nations.
By his own account, Mr. Peck lived a privileged existence, having attended boarding school in Paris. He was set for a life in international affairs after he graduated with degrees in economics and engineering from the Technical University of Berlin.
But he said he never clung to the ideals of the young Haitian elite of espousing an unhealthy dose of disdain for the majority of the Haitian people who are wretchedly poor.
"I was lucky enough to be exposed to other influences abroad," Mr. Peck said. "I had friends that were involved in a lot of solidarity movements for different struggles around the world."
He admitted, though, that the temptation was difficult to escape. He came to New York in 1980, awaiting a job with the United Nations, but the agency was facing a severe budget crisis and was not hiring. Meantime, he took up driving a cab and began to realize that his true calling was in film making, not in settling international disputes. He returned to Germany in early 1981 and enrolled at the competitive German Film and Television Academy.
"My father is a camera buff," said Mr. Peck, explaining that his choice of career was not at all that unusual. "He always had a camera with him, and I grew up with it."
"The Man by the Shore" received respectable reviews from the 1993 Cannes Film Festival, but it failed to attract a distributor in the United States. Mr. Peck thought distributors would have lined up to bid for his movie, particularly since it was shown at a time when diplomats shuttled between New York, Washington and Port-au-Prince, trying to restore to power the ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and Haiti commanded the front pages of daily newspapers across the country.
But it took about two years before Mr. Peck found a small New York entertainment group, KJM3, to distribute the film. Its premiere is set for Saturday at the Brooklyn Museum, about a week before the film opens at the Quad Cinema in Manhattan, on May 17. The premiere is being organized as a benefit event by a community group, the Haitian-American Alliance of New York.
"I think my film is powerful and very difficult," Mr. Peck said. "Distributors are not particularly looking for films that are important. They're looking for films that can make money. You are not seeing the best films the world has to offer in this country, and I think that's a shame."
Mr. Peck, who was a visiting professor at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts for two years, until 1995, has received several awards for "The Man by the Shore," including best film at the Milan African Film Festival in 1994.
His other movies include "Haitian Corner," which chronicled the life of Haitian immigrants in New York, and "Lumumba: Death of a Prophet," about Zaire's first Prime Minister, Patrice Lumumba, who was assassinated in 1961.
While many of his films are about Haiti and Haitians, Mr. Peck said that the stories transcend his sun-drenched island nation and that a person who has lived through Franco's Spain, Tito's Yugoslavia or Castro's Cuba can relate to the story. Haiti, he said, provides the backdrop for a story about humanity.
"I try to portray characters that are people we know," he said. "We know a grandmother like this, a little girl like this."
Part of his struggle to promote Haiti's almost nonexistent cultural institutions, he says, stems from an elite whose members would rather fly to Miami or New York to attend the theater.
"We have inherited a very decadent bourgeoisie, incapable of defending its own rights," said Mr. Peck, who is single and has a 22-year-old daughter, Fiona, a senior at Drexel University in Philadelphia.
"It's important for me to show Haitians as human beings and not just as objects," he continued. "We have a very heavy legacy in that we are seen as either voodoo followers or AIDS carriers. The least I can do is show people as people and not as marionettes or exotic bodies."
His future projects include expanding the accessibility of films in Haiti and raising Americans' awareness of daily Haitian life.
Mr. Peck recently bought the Eldorado Cine, an old colonial movie theater in Port-au-Prince, and has fanned across Europe and the United States, raising $500,000 to create a center where artists can meet and discuss and create. And he has purchased the rights to the Russell Banks novel "Continental Drift," which traces the path of a Haitian family and an American family as they pursue the American dream.
"I see too many Haitians living in the expectative mood of 'when we go back,' " Mr. Peck said of his countrymen who often muse about the day when they will permanently return to their island nation. "It is paralyzing because you don't do anything. You just wait. And knowing the situation in Haiti, there is no guarantee that you will ever go back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Raoul Peck fulfills two roles: he is a film maker and the new Minister of Culture for Haiti. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bennington College Sued by Professors

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: RUTLAND, Vt., May 7

 BODY:
Nineteen former and current members of the Bennington College faculty have taken the college to court, seeking reinstatement and back pay two years after the college, facing financial trouble, made wide cuts in the faculty and curriculum.
In a suit filed today in Superior Court here, the faculty members contended that Bennington and its president, Elizabeth Coleman, violated their contracts and wrongfully dismissed them in 1994 after the trustees ordered the restructuring. 
 A spokeswoman for Bennington, Debra Townsend, said: "We were anticipating this. Bennington College believes it acted openly and legally."
As part of the restructuring, the faculty was cut by one-third and full-time jobs in some disciplines, like foreign languages, literature, politics, economics, sociology and art history, were eliminated. The trustees also did away with Bennington's academic job security -- an unusual form of tenure called "presumptive," in which faculty members received five-year contracts that guaranteed future employment unless "the contribution to college life" by the faculty member deteriorated or the college declared financial hardship, which it did in 1994.
One plaintiff regained his job. Most others are still unemployed. One of their lawyers, Richard Cassidy, said the layoffs were a contract violation because the trustees had improperly declared hardship.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Loving Las Vegas

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
If anyone is still wondering whatever happened to the 60's, the answer may be here, in a pristine patch of desert a short drive from the Liberace Museum. The Hard Rock Casino has an autographed Bob Dylan guitar above the window where you cash in your chips, a handwritten Jim Morrison lyric sheet along the corridor where you weave your way to the bathroom, and four slot machines whose profits (a flashing sign announces) are proudly dedicated to saving the rain forest. You hear John Lennon sing "Imagine" while you lose your shirt at craps.
Peter Morton, owner of the Hard Rock empire, reports that his first venture into gambling, now a year old, is "out of the ball park," exceeding revenue projections by 50 percent; the adjoining Hard Rock Hotel, which turned away 10,000 customers last month, is already planning to expand. You might ask: Who would have guessed that the Woodstock generation would trade in peace and love for video poker and Keno? But a more realistic question might be: Why should the boomers be different from anyone else? 
 America is punch-drunk with gambling. At $40 billion a year, the self-described "gaming" industry is rapidly catching up to our most profitable addiction, tobacco ($45 billion). In 1994, more Americans gambled than went to movies, theater, opera and concerts combined -- and spent six times as much money on gambling as on all spectator sports combined. Casinos, limited to Nevada and New Jersey only eight years ago, are now legal in 24 states; lotteries are now ubiquitous in 37.
With such growing competition, you might expect Las Vegas to suffer. Far from it. It's the fastest-growing city in America. Hotel occupancy is at a staggering 90 percent, and new resorts can't be built fast enough on the Strip. One of them, the half-complete New York-New York, is in the shape of a Crayola-colored Manhattan skyline. Its marketing executive, Martin Moore, explains: "What we're seeing is a more relaxed attitude about gambling. People who'd never think about Las Vegas come out now because they've tried it locally and say, 'Let's try the real thing.' "
What does this mean for American civilization as we know it? No one is sure. Already such gambling-saturated towns as Biloxi, Miss., are looking like Jimmy Stewart's nightmare vision of Bedford Falls in "It's a Wonderful Life." The stench of influence-peddling suffuses some state governments where gambling rules. In the Midwest, riverboat casinos can be an economic boon but sometimes suck local retail businesses dry. Statistics suggest that crime, domestic abuse and alcoholism rise in gambling's wake -- while the poor get most conspicuously poorer.
No wonder the House, with a bipartisan unity stretching from religious conservatives to secular liberals, unanimously passed a bill creating a commission to weigh gambling's national impact. But the bill now languishes in the Senate, where Richard Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, and G.O.P. allies have worked to weaken the commission and could yet kill it.
Surely, you'd think, Bob Dole, our foremost scourge of cultural depravity, would help speed and toughen this legislation. To do so, however, he'll have to buck the No. 1 casino potentate, Stephen Wynn of Mirage Resorts, who raised $477,000 for Mr. Dole at a luncheon here last year, the very day after the Senator's famous speech excoriating Hollywood. Gambling may also have an ally in Newt Gingrich, who had his own, private dinner with Mr. Wynn here last week and promptly declared himself sympathetic to an emasculated commission, shorn of subpoena powers.
My libertarian side says that if Americans want to throw their money away, that's certainly their right. But taking in the "new," corporate Vegas, which swallows up one new generation at the Hard Rock and befriends still younger ones with wan theme-park attractions, I wonder where the national addiction will lead. Even Don Rickles, the hilariously misanthropic comic who's outlasted Elvis and Sinatra as a headliner here, laments the dehumanization of a town where the hotel lounges once synonymous with live entertainment have been razed to meet the insatiable demand for more gambling acreage. The onetime capital of sin is now a prototype for the mall of the future, destined to be replicated on a strip of highway near you.
