HEADLINE: Lauded Holyoke Must Work to Lure Students

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

DATELINE: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass.

 BODY:
Since its founding 159 years ago, Mount Holyoke College has attracted idealistic young women seeking a rigorous education on the way to public service or academic careers. Its officials point with pride to alumnae like Frances Perkins, the nation's first female Cabinet member, appointed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Wendy Wasserstein, the playwright.
But while Mount Holyoke shows up regularly in national rankings as one of the top liberal arts colleges in the United States, it is caught in a paradox: despite its reputation, it has to stretch for students. It generally accepts 65 percent of applicants -- better than the 76 percent it took in 1992, but less selective than it used to be and than its closest competitors, Wellesley, which took only 39 percent of applicants last year, and Smith, which took 53 percent. And by next year, what the college pays in student financial aid is expected to exceed what it pays for instruction. 
 As Holyoke's new president, Joanne V. Creighton, told a student forum on April 30, a few days before her inauguration: "We have significant challenges. But I have confidence that we can face them if we don't get paralyzed."
Ms. Creighton, an English scholar who served as provost and acting president of Wesleyan University in Connecticut, arrived on campus in January and created a long-term planning committee of faculty, students and staff.
Holyoke's problems are not unique, of course. Many liberal arts colleges have had to contend with a growing skepticism about the value of a liberal arts education in an increasingly job-oriented society. And over the last decade, most colleges have had to grapple with the decline in high school graduates.
For women's colleges, that shrinkage is even tougher since they draw from only half the population. Only 84 women's colleges remain, down from 228 in 1969, when the Ivy League and other prestigious men's colleges started going coed. Those that remain fight strong preferences for coeducation as well as perceptions that they are either convents or largely lesbian.
But they have seen renewed interest in recent years since Hillary Rodham Clinton -- a Wellesley graduate -- moved into the White House and a study by the American Association of University Women in 1992 showed that boys were favored over girls in many American classrooms. The number of full-time undergraduates at women's colleges is now 7 percent higher than it was in 1970, said Jadwiga S. Sebrechts, executive director of the Women's College Coalition.
For Holyoke, two selling points are its beautiful 800-acre campus in southern Massachusetts and its participation in a five-college consortium that includes Amherst, Smith, Hampshire College and the University of Massachusetts. And with fewer than 2,000 undergraduates, Holyoke tries to nurture its students in tutorials and small classes. More than 60 percent of its graduates go on to advanced degrees, many in areas like science or economics where women are underrepresented.
Still, many Holyoke students say they were sold on the college only after visiting it and seeing its friendliness. It is a closeness cultivated through traditions like milk and cookies every night (known as M and C), an annual procession to the campus grave of Holyoke's founder, Mary Lyons, followed by an ice cream social, and gifts from older students to first-year students.
"I was a little apprehensive about a woman's college," recalled Julie Poore, a Russian major from Woburn, Mass. "But when I came to look at the college, I really fell in love with it."
Like many other Holyoke students, Elizabeth Cook, a history major from Des Moines who is the former editor in chief of the student newspaper, recalled that her friends felt threatened by her choice. "They were convinced I was going to become a lesbian," Ms. Cook said. "A colleague of my father's told me she wouldn't have wanted to go to a women's college because college is where she met her husband."
But despite the student good will, Holyoke does less well in selling itself beyond the campus. As Ms. Creighton put it at the student forum: "Once you get here you love it. But what can we do to tell more students about us?"
Applications have climbed above 2,000 again -- from a low of 1,782 in 1992 -- but they are still lower than administrators would like. The improvement has come in part through a renewed emphasis on recruiting in traditional strongholds like the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic States, areas it neglected in the late 1980's when declining numbers of high school graduates led it to focus on the faster-growing West and South.
"We've moved away from the edge, but not enough to make us feel secure," said Richard Johnson, a professor of English and a member of the new Educational Priorities Committee.
Yet another problem is the spiraling burden of financial aid. Like other colleges that accept students without regard to their ability to pay, Holyoke guarantees that once admitted, no one will then be turned away because of a lack of tuition money. As a result, Holyoke is paying out more and more, giving aid to 70 percent of its students. Financial aid is the college's fastest-growing expense -- more than 8 percent a year.
For now, its financial aid policy will remain unchanged, and the college will use gifts and income from its $272 million endowment to cover it, running a small deficit as a result. Ms. Creighton has assured students that their aid will not change, but she will not promise that there will be no change. She believes that Holyoke ought to be putting more of its investment income into endowment -- which at $147,000 per student is below that of competitors like Wellesley -- and less into current operations.
Many observers believe Holyoke has the strengths to remain a top college and even to build.
"I think they can turn it around," said Morton Schapiro, dean of the College of Letters, Arts and Sciences at the University of Southern California who has consulted for Holyoke and other colleges. "They are small, and they have a lot of money in the bank. If they emphasize their career connections, they will draw even more students."
And the faculty at Holyoke seem willing to work with Ms. Creighton.
"We've just finished 10 faculty teas and dinners at the president's house," said Harriet Pollatsek, a mathematics professor who is on the priorities committee, "and everyone seemed pleased, excited and encouraged. Joanne is very plain-spoken and down to earth, and the faculty value her candor."
The one group that seems most uneasy is students. The student newspaper, The Mount Holyoke News, recently called Ms. Creighton too corporate in her approach, and a survey of 360 students by the newspaper last month found many fears that Ms. Creighton might turn the college coed, cut financial aid or seek out a wealthier student body that might be less diverse.
Others have rallied to her defense. "Having an Educational Priorities Committee re-examine the college puts us all on edge," said Stephanie Jones, an English major from Maine and the new editor in chief of the Holyoke News. "But it's exactly what we should be doing."

HEADLINE: Impasse on Wage Issue Stalls Effort to Lower Gasoline Tax

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Republicans in the Senate tried briefly today to roll back the 4.3-cents-a-gallon gasoline tax that Congress enacted in 1993, but Democrats once again ensnarled them in a debate over raising the minimum wage. So the tax repeal -- and the Senate -- ground to a halt again.
Democrats said they would keep tying up the Senate until Republicans granted them an up-or-down vote on raising the base wage. Republicans tried to link such a vote to a measure that Democrats oppose, a labor-relations bill criticized by unions, but Democrats did not take the bait. 
 The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, scolded the Democrats, saying, "Your leader is telling us the only way we can move the Senate on anything is to vote on your version of the minimum wage. We have the majority in this body."
A few minutes later, the Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, concluded, "We're obviously in a situation now where nothing is going to get done."
Not a lot has been done for six weeks, since the minimum-wage standoff began. It was not clear when the impasse would break. Some suggested that the tug of war was being driven by election-year politics, particularly Presidential politics.
"All this is obviously and clearly -- but it needs restating -- a struggle that is under way to define the terms of debate in the campaign," Tom Mann, a Brookings Institution scholar who is an expert on Congress, said in an interview today. "It really matters what's on the agenda and how it's framed, and there's no easy way to cut the differences."
Indeed, both parties' unanointed Presidential candidates were in the thick of the day's inaction.
Mr. Dole made an impromptu appearance this morning at Internal Revenue Service headquarters to advocate the repeal of the gasoline tax and, in passing, to note that it had been part of a five-year, $265 billion tax package that President Clinton orchestrated in 1993. That, Mr. Dole said, was "the largest tax increase in American history."
Mr. Clinton's campaign struck back by fax. A statement charged that Mr. Dole "more than tripled the gas tax in the 1980's" by backing two such increases of 5 cents a gallon, and added that it was Mr. Dole who "pushed through the largest tax increase in U.S. history" in 1982.
Yes, and no. Adjusted for inflation, the $214 billion tax increase that Mr. Dole supported in 1982 totals $320 billion in 1993 dollars. That eclipses the $265 billion increase that Mr. Clinton sponsored in that year as part of a deficit-reduction package.
Still, the 1982 increase was effectively a partial rollback of a 1981 tax cut of $750 billion, which Mr. Dole also backed. In 1993 dollars, the 1981 cut totals $1.19 trillion.
"It's basically a useless argument," said David Wyss, research director for DRI/McGraw-Hill, a Boston economic forecasting company. "Both passed tax increases, and both were probably justified."
As the Senate stood idle, Republicans tried to juggle the budget to offset the loss of gasoline-tax revenues. They elected to lift the tax temporarily, until November, and to pay the $2 billion cost by cutting the Energy Department budget and selling another slice of the broadcast spectrum. Mr. Dole said the next Republican budget, to be sketched out on Wednesday, would propose a permanent tax repeal.
Democrats, meanwhile, tried to decide whether to bow to the tax cut, which Mr. Daschle has called inevitable. Mr. Clinton had been poised to send Mr. Dole a letter accepting the repeal in exchange for a minimum-wage increase and a guarantee that oil companies would not pocket the tax cut's proceeds. But he held off after Democratic senators debated their position over lunch.
Mr. Daschle was mum. But another Democrat, Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, said later that he believed there were enough Democrats to filibuster the tax repeal.
That did not occur. As a bill dubbed the Taxpayer Bill of Rights came up, Mr. Dole tried to amend it to repeal the gasoline tax and increase the minimum wage 90 cents, as Democrats have sought. But he also put in something Democrats oppose: a separate bill expanding businesses' right to hold discussions with employee groups.
Democrats argued that the bill's true purpose was to permit businesses to create rump unions, run by companies. So Mr. Daschle rejected the offer, calling the labor amendment a "poison pill."
Mr. Dole affected befuddlement, saying the Democrats were opposing their own minimum-wage increase.
"I didn't think we'd be rejected when we offered our colleagues what they wanted," he said.

HEADLINE: Consumers Trimmed Debt Rise in March

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Consumers restrained their buying on credit during March, the Federal Reserve said today, as installment debt grew at the slowest rate in six months.
Total consumer installment credit rose by $6.4 billion, at a 7.3 percent annual rate, little more than half the February jump of $12.2 billion, at a 14.1 percent rate. 
 It was the smallest monthly increase in installment debt since September of last year, when it was up $4.1 billion, at a 5 percent annual rate.
Every major category of credit buying in March was off from February's pace. Auto loans were the most striking, with no increase at all in dollar terms from February's $360 billion, as they rose only two-tenths of 1 percent at an annual rate. Auto credit had risen in February by $3.8 billion, a 12.6 percent annual rate.
 The overall March slowdown was steeper than anticipated by analysts, who had expected that relatively high levels of consumer confidence and strong job gains during the first quarter would buoy credit-buying.
But Friday, the Labor Department said April job growth virtually stalled, with only 2,000 new jobs created, raising questions as to whether the economy was headed for sustained stronger growth or whether it will settle back later in the year.
During March, credit-card buying increased by $4.8 billion, at a 14.1 percent annual rate, still a fairly brisk expansion though down from the $5.3 billion rise in February, at a 15.9 percent rate.
Robert Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said credit-card use was expanding robustly because it was increasingly used as a means of payment to take advantage of incentives like free airline miles.
"It's not only a means of extending credit anymore, but also a substitute way of paying," Mr. Dederick said.
With interest rates rising, the pace of monthly borrowing increases was likely to slow, he said, adding, "But by any measure people are still willing borrowers, albeit not as eagerly as before."
A category of credit simply labeled other, which includes consumer loans for such purposes as buying a boat but does not count home-equity loans, posted a $1.5 billion rise in March, a 6.5 percent rate.

HEADLINE: 10-State Swath of West Will Soon Hit 75 M.P.H.

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, May 7

 BODY:
Eastern drivers mapping out routes for Western vacations this summer can plan on the shortest driving times in a generation.
Over the next month, five states -- Colorado, Idaho, Nebraska, New Mexico and Utah -- will phase in 75-mile-per-hour speed limits on rural Interstate highways. Five other states -- Arizona, Montana, Nevada, South Dakota and Wyoming -- recently raised their limits, so the new additions will create a solid bloc of 10 Western states where the speed limit will be at least 75 m.p.h. 
 Moving faster than desert roadrunners, Western legislatures raced to raise speed limits after President Clinton signed legislation last November that abolished the 21-year-old national maximum speed limit.
Critics say accidents will soar as drivers cope with speed limits sharply higher than the 55 m.p.h. that was the rule less than a decade ago.
While proponents argue that the higher speed limits will merely legalize existing driving speeds, highway patrol officers across the West report that they are issuing double and triple the volume of tickets they once did as drivers test the new limits. Officers say they have eliminated the old "fudge factor," where they stopped only those drivers going more than 10 miles an hour over the speed limit. And state legislatures have beefed up fines for speeding.
To advocates of fast driving, today's Westerners are recapturing a way of life their parents lost in 1974, when Washington braked drivers nationwide in an effort to save gasoline after Arab oil-producing nations imposed an embargo on the United States for supporting Israel in its October 1973 war with Egypt and Syria.
Indeed, for six of the states, the new 75-m.p.h. speed limits simply mark a reversion to the pre-1974 status quo. "This is the first step in devolution of power from Washington," said State Representative Ron May, a Republican who sponsored Colorado's new speed limit law.
But this spring, with higher speed limits and gasoline prices at their highest levels in five years, fuel bills are likely to soar in the West.
"Going 75 instead of 55 results in an average 50 percent increase in fuel consumption," said John M. DeCicco, senior research associate for the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy, a nonprofit research group in Washington.
With great distances to travel, Westerners are particularly sensitive about gasoline prices. Last year the average Wyoming resident spent $734 on gasoline -- slightly more than double the amount paid by the average resident of New York State or Washington, D.C., where distances are shorter and public transportation is widespread.
With a small population scattered over wide-open spaces, Westerners regard fast driving as a quality-of-life issue.
"Going from 65 to 75 adds 110 hours to my year," said Tom Polk, a salesman operating out of Omaha who drives 50,000 miles a year to cover his seven-state territory. Noting that some overnight road trips are now day trips, he added, "When you have a family, being home an extra three or four nights a month -- that's a big deal."
Ten years ago, it would take a Wyoming driver who obeyed Washington's 55-m.p.h. limit nearly six hours to drive the 322 miles separating Cheyenne and Sheridan. Today, at 75 m.p.h., that drive takes 4 hours and 20 minutes.
In Montana, where new daytime speed limits carry no number and are defined simply as "reasonable and prudent," a driver last week could sail down Interstate 94, though the flat, empty eastern half of the state, with the cruise control set at 85 m.p.h. and not worry about a speeding ticket.
Critics, including Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety, a group based in Washington, note that of the 10 Western states with 75-m.p.h. limits, eight, including Montana, were on a Federal Department of Transportation list of the 10 states with the highest number of fatal crashes per hundred million miles traveled from 1990 to 1994. The high number of fatalities was attributed largely to high speeds, low use of seat belts, and alcohol.
Reflecting a regional undercurrent of apprehension, The Arizona Republic contributed to the state debate with a cartoon that depicted a smoking car wreck, overshadowed by a sign that read, "75 -- the age you probably won't reach once they raise the speed limit."
But, after six months of higher speed limits, there is little sign of increased highway carnage in the West's three pioneering states, Wyoming, Montana and California.
In Wyoming there were 26 traffic fatalities in the first four months of this year, compared with 34 in the same period last year.
In Montana during the same period, there were 50 traffic fatalities this year and 49 last year. But in the first three months of this year, the Montana Highway Patrol investigated 2,703 accidents, 25 percent more than in the same period last year.
California increased speed limits on some highway sections to 65 m.p.h. on Dec. 17, and on other sections to 70 m.p.h. on Jan. 7. The total number of collisions increased 3 percent and fatal crashes increased 13 percent from Dec. 17 through the end of March, compared with the same period a year earlier, according to the California Highway Patrol.
But analysis of the fatal accidents showed that alcohol-related crashes had increased by 44 percent, while crashes where unsafe speed was the primary factor had dropped by 15 percent.
Independent and government safety experts say results are too preliminary and too subject to seasonal weather fluctuations to draw definitive conclusions.
Still, said Albert E. Goke, safety director for Montana's traffic department, "the doom and gloom that was predicted is not occurring."
Votes in state legislatures this spring were lopsided in favor of higher limits.
Fighting a rear-guard action in Colorado, safety advocates noted that 37 of Colorado's 100 state legislators had received speeding tickets. The driver's license of Ray Powers, the Senate sponsor of the new speed limit bill, was revoked in the 1970's because he had an excessive number of speeding tickets.
The bill easily swept through both houses of the Colorado Legislature. Gov. Roy Romer signed it on April 25 before television cameras in the sign shop of the state Department of Transportation. Then he took off his coat and hand-stenciled Colorado's first 75-m.p.h. speed limit sign.
In Nebraska, only 22 percent of people polled last December supported raising the speed limit to 75 miles an hour. Nevertheless, the Legislature overwhelmingly approved the new limit, which will go into effect on June 1.
Preparing for an influx of summer tourists, state officials in the West are stressing common sense and individual responsibility in advertising campaigns.
In Montana, "reasonable and prudent" speeds depend on a number of factors, like traffic conditions, road conditions, the car and the driver, said Mr. Goke, who stressed that Montana did not want to attract tourists addicted to speeding.
And two weeks ago in Colorado, as Governor Romer washed the black ink from his hands at the sign shop, Capt. Larry Tolar, spokesman for the state Highway Patrol, warned reporters, "If you are traveling faster than 75 miles an hour, the face you see in your rearview mirror won't be a friendly one."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Colorado is joining other Western states in raising its speed limit, and that left Domingo Martinez with some new signs to tend to at the state Department of Transportation last month. He had to make 280 of them. (Ellen Jaskol/Rocky Mountain News)
 
Map: "Update: The Speed Belt" shows the five states that are expected to phase in a 75, 70 and 65-mile-and-hour speed limit.

HEADLINE: SOFTWARE PIRATES GROWING IN NUMBER IN CHINA, U.S. SAYS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials said today that they had discovered evidence of a large number of previously undiscovered Chinese factories producing pirated versions of American software, videos and music, and that they are preparing to announce retaliatory action next week against more than $2 billion in Chinese imports to the United States.
If the Administration goes ahead with its long-threatened sanctions, the action seems bound to increase tensions in a relationship still mired in disputes over China's reported shipments of nuclear weapons material, its continued repression of dissidents and its efforts to intimidate Taiwan. 
 Several of Mr. Clinton's top advisers have said in recent days that they are worried about the steady deterioration of the relationship with Beijing. But they added that they had no choice but to impose sanctions in the piracy dispute because China had repeatedly ignored warnings that it must fulfill its commitments under a major accord signed in March 1995.
White House officials say that by retaliating against China in a dispute that is costing American companies billions of dollars in lost sales, the Administration hopes to defuse a broader movement in Congress to terminate China's preferential trading status, which is up for renewal next month. Ending those trading privileges, a senior Administration official argued today, "would essentially terminate our economic relationship" with China and wipe out whatever leverage Washington has over Beijing.
The Administration reiterated its support for China's broad trading rights -- which President Clinton "delinked" from Beijing's human rights record in 1993 -- during a meeting today between Vice President Al Gore and the British Governor of Hong Kong, Christopher Patten. Mr. Patten is visiting Washington to warn that terminating China's most-favored-nation trading status in the United States would devastate Hong Kong, the transit point for most of the goods made in China. Mr. Gore "told Patten that unconditional renewal of M.F.N. was fundamental to our policy of engagement with China," said David Johnson, a White House spokesman.
But that argument has failed to persuade many Democrats and Republicans in Congress, where a major argument over extending the trading privileges is already shaping up. A coalition of conservative groups said today that it would begin a lobbying campaign to revoke Chin's trading rights, declaring that the Administration's policy of "comprehensive engagement" had failed to change China's treatment of dissidents or its trading practices.
Caught in the middle is Senator Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican nominee for President, who has scheduled a long-delayed speech about American policy in Asia for Thursday. Mr. Dole has a long history of supporting most-favored-nation treatment for China, but in recent weeks some of his advisers have been pressing him to modify that position. They are urging him to support a rollback of some tariff reductions extended to China by the Clinton Administration.
"This is a straddle position for people who don't want a disaster for American interests in China," Douglas Paal, a Republican foreign policy strategist and informal adviser to the Dole campaign, said today.
The Administration's warning today that a sanctions announcement is imminent appears to be part of a last-minute effort to get Chinese officials to respond to a four-part "action plan" presented to them in Beijing last month by Charlene Barshefsky, who was recently appointed acting United States trade representative. She set a deadline of May 15. One of Ms. Barshefsky's deputies, Lee Sands, is on his way to Beijing in hopes of getting a response from Chinese leaders, but a senior Administration official said today that "there are no signs of action."
China has publicly threatened to issue counter-sanctions against American goods. Shen Guofang, the spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, repeated that warning today in Beijing. The more pressure the United States applies, he said, "the less opportunities the United States will have in the Chinese market."
The hardening of positions on both sides has led to warnings in the United States that American relations with Beijing are in a downward spiral that may only accelerate.
"Unfortunately, there is no plausible scenario to get out of this," said Jeffrey Garten, the dean of the Yale School of Management and, until a few months ago, the Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade.
"We are in a destructive routine," Mr. Garten said after returning from a recent trip to China. "We accuse the Chinese, they balk, we threaten sanctions, they threaten retaliation. And no one really has a plan for arresting this."
The United States could find itself imposing several sanctions simultaneously. Secretary of State Warren Christopher is still contemplating a limited set of penalties for China's reported shipment to Pakistan of ring magnets used in the production of nuclear weapons. He has pressed China for a commitment to restrict any shipments to Pakistan but has received unsatisfactory responses, a senior official said today. "We're approaching a critical moment on that issue as well," the official said.
But the evidence in the proliferation case is still murky. In the area of piracy, it is much clearer: For months, American officials have pressed China to act against the 31 "official" compact disk factories in China, some of which operate under the aegis of the Chinese military. This year those factories are expected to produce upward of 200 million illegal copies of compact disks and the far more profitable CD-ROM's, used in personal computers.
Under last year's agreement, China committed to closing the factories or entering licensing or joint venture agreements to make them legitimate producers. So far only a handful have been closed.
Now American officials say they have discovered about 13 more factories, called "underground" operations because they operate without Chinese Government permission. It is unclear whether those were opened since China signed its agreement with the United States, or whether they have previously been missed by American businessmen and intelligence agencies surveying the scope of the piracy.
Chinese authorities argue that they cannot keep up with the opening of the plants, and thus cannot be held responsible for their operation.
A senior trade official described that argument as nonsense. "If these plants were turning out videos for dissident groups they would have been closed in two days," he said.
When Ms. Barshefsky traveled to Beijing last month, she told her Chinese counterparts that they had to take four steps to avoid sanctions: close the plants or turn them into legitimate producers; extend enforcement efforts deep into Guangdong Province in southern China; implement new customs rules, and improve access to the Chinese market for American movie makers and software companies. "So far, we have not heard back on any of those issues," a senior official said.
It is possible that China is simply waiting to the last minute, betting it can cut a better deal after American companies warn about the damage they will suffer if they have to pay far higher prices for Chinese goods. China only agreed to last year's accord on the day $1 billion in threatened sanctions went into effect.

HEADLINE: Conde Nast Is to Move to a New Times Square Tower, Officials Say

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In yet another sign of the fast-paced resurgence of Times Square, city and state officials said yesterday that Conde Nast, the publisher of Vanity Fair, Vogue, Architectural Digest and 11 other magazines, will move its headquarters to a building planned for the northeast corner of 42d Street and Broadway.
The plan, which effectively will jump-start the long-stalled effort to build huge office towers at the south end of Times Square, was described yesterday by five people directly involved in the negotiations, including senior economic advisers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki. The officials asked that their names not be used because a formal announcement is to be made today by Steven T. Florio, Conde Nast's president, and Douglas Durst, the developer who is to build the new Times Square tower. 
 Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, the Mayor's development agency, was the only official to openly confirm the plan. He did so indirectly, crediting John S. Dyson, the Mayor's departing Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, with having "made this thing happen."
The deal is unusual in several respects, not the least of which is that Conde Nast, which is part of Advance Publications, is to receive $10.75 million in "corporate retention" tax breaks from the city and the state, even though its corporate identity is so closely aligned with Manhattan that real estate executives say it is an unlikely candidate to leave.
But one state official directly involved in the negotiations said Conde Nast had threatened to move close to half of its 1,570 Manhattan workers, who are now divided among more than 10 office buildings, to one or more locations outside the city.
The official said the exodus would have involved "back office workers," perhaps including circulation personnel, advertising sales staffs and others not directly involved in the magazines' editorial content.
Under the terms of the deal with Mr. Durst, the city and the state, Conde Nast is to consolidate all its Manhattan workers in the Times Square building. It was not clear yesterday whether the staff of The New Yorker, whose owner, S. I. Newhouse, also owns Conde Nast, would move from its offices at 20 West 43d Street. Conde Nast officials would not comment on the move.
Conde Nast is to occupy at least 500,000 square feet of office space, with an option to take over an additional 150,000 square feet, in the building that Mr. Durst is expected to begin erecting by the end of the year. The building would have a total of 1.6 million square feet of office and retail space and be ready for occupany by the beginning of 1999.
By signing Conde Nast as a large tenant, the officials said, Mr. Durst has all but assured himself of support from the city and the state in his bid to buy the Times Square site, which stretches from 42d Street to 43d Street and is best known to many as the site of the boarded-up Nathan's Famous restaurant. Mr. Dyson had said he would not approve the transfer from the current owners, a group headed by the Prudential Insurance Company of America, to the Durst Organization unless a large tenant were in place.
The Prudential group was selected in 1981 as the principal builder of what government officials envisioned as four huge office towers that would surround the intersection of 42d Street and Broadway, paving the way for a Times Square renaissance.
But the Prudential plan became bogged down by dozens of lawsuits by civic groups that considered the proposed towers too large, and later by an office glut that resulted from large-scale construction around the north end of Times Square in the late 1980's.
Although neither Prudential nor Mr. Durst have disclosed what he is to pay for rights to develop the Times Square site, Mr. Durst is known to have circulated his building plans among several civic groups and city agencies in an attempt to allay fears that his proposal would have the overbearing impact that many had feared in the Prudential plan.
Mr. Durst plans to build an office tower with almost precisely the same amount of office space as had been envisioned by the Prudential group, but he has said he will do it on a lot that is 30 percent bigger, adding adjoining property that he acquired during in the 1980's. That means his building would be neither as high or as bulky as the one planned by the Prudential group.
City and state officials said yesterday that they considered Conde Nast an ideal tenant for Mr. Durst's building. Although it would not be the first internationally known corporation to move to the once-seedy blocks of Times Square -- Morgan Stanley completed its move to a new headquarters at Broadway and 47th Street in January -- they said the publishing house would complement the revitalization already under way along the city's historic Great White Way.
"It is hard to imagine anything better than a publisher of fashion, entertainment and literary magazines for a street corner that is going to meld the city's fashion industry to the south with its newly energized entertainment district along 42d Street," one senior official said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Warns Children About Smoking

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., May 7

 BODY:
President Clinton dropped in on a New Jersey high school today to urge tobacco companies to stop aiming advertising at children, and he went on to a series of receptions expected to raise $2 million for Democrats in the state as well as his own re-election bid.
It was the President's third visit to New Jersey this year, with many more expected, underscoring the importance of the state in his own effort to stay in office. Republicans and Democrats consider the state's voters a fickle group that has leaned Republican but that can be wooed back to the Democrats. 
 At Woodbridge High School today, Mr. Clinton met with 10 students who had fanned out across the community to find cigarette advertising that appealed to children and to show that laws banning the sale of cigarettes to minors were poorly enforced. It was part of Kick Butts Day, an effort organized by Mark Green, the public advocate for New York City, at 40 schools in 12 cities.
Mr. Clinton, addressing 3,000 people in the high school gymnasium, reminded them that his own mother had died of cancer at age 70 after smoking two packs a day for most of her life. He noted that of the 3,000 teen-agers who started smoking every day, 1,000 would eventually die from it. "A 1 in 3 chance that you will end your life sooner -- that is a lousy bargain for no benefit," he said.
He also urged the cigarette companies to be more responsible. "You in the tobacco business now surely see the clear emerging consensus in America that advertising billboards and promotions should not appeal to the children."
While the crowd roared and stomped their approval inside the gym, young smokers outside professed themselves unimpressed. "If you smoke, you are not going to stop because the President says so," said Jessica L. Omoletski, a junior who was barely off school grounds before she pulled a lighter and cigarettes from her backpack. "It's an addiction."
After his speech, Mr. Clinton left for a private reception at the New Vernon home of Arthur Goldberg, chief executive of the Bally Entertainment Corporation; 30 couples had each donated about $25,000. In an impromptu moment as he was leaving the reception, Mr. Clinton stopped his motorcade along a country road to play a few notes of "Take Five" on a saxophone that a young boy was flourishing.
He later flew by helicopter to Liberty State Park, where he attended another private reception and where more than 800 Democratic contributors attended a $1,500-a-plate dinner with the comedian Whoopi Goldberg serving as master of ceremonies.
Mr. Clinton used much of his speech, inside the restored Central Railroad of New Jersey Terminal, to talk about social and economic problems. "We have to figure out what to do about all these people who get downsized from big companies but who still have a lot of good years left," he said.
The President said he would soon hold a meeting on the subject to find ways to get companies to focus on how to help such workers. He also discussed economic security, aid to inner cities, trade, crime and racial harmony.
The $2 million raised at the two events will be divided in about equal proportions among the Democratic National Committee, the New Jersey Democratic Party and Representative Robert G. Torricelli's campaign for the Senate seat being vacated by Bill Bradley.
Both Mr. Clinton and Senator Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican nominee, will visit New Jersey frequently between now and the November election, political experts say.
"New Jersey has a large suburban population and those are often the voters who make up the difference in presidential races," said Joe Lockhart of the Clinton campaign. "If you can convince those people to come to your side, you are well placed to prevail on Election Day."
Part of the interest in the state is purely numerical. New Jersey has 15 of the 270 electoral votes needed to win the Presidency. Part of the interest also lies in free advertising: visits to New Jersey produce news reports in New York and Philadelphia, two of the four largest media markets in the country.
"Doing a little bit better in Wyoming wouldn't do much," said Steve Salmore, a professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.
Ed Gillespie, communications director for the Republican National Committee, said: "New Jersey is a bellwether state -- it swings, you can't count it in either column and it is always hotly contested. We have a few seats there to pick up."
Mr. Dole's forces believe he has a natural following among the large number of veterans in the state, and they solidly back their Republican Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, in making income tax cuts.
On two previous visits to New Jersey, Mr. Clinton also highlighted family concerns. On Feb. 15, he visited a public school to announce that he was setting aside $2 billion over the next five years to improve the use of technology in public school education. On March 11, he used a visit to a Superfund cleanup site to stress his concern for environmental issues. His next scheduled visit, June 4, is to deliver the commencement address at Princeton University.
New Jersey is also critical state in the makeup of the next Congress. The race for the seat being given up by Senator Bradley is considered to be one of the nastiest in the nation, pitting Mr. Torricelli against a Republican Congressman, Richard A. Zimmer. Both need to raise $6 million to $8 million.
The Democratic Party also needs to pick up 20 seats nationwide to regain the majority in Congress and it considers gaining at least one seat from New Jersey a possibility.
Woodbridge's Mayor, James E. McGreevey, a Democrat, said he mentioned to President Clinton today that the last President to visit was George Washington, who went on to re-election.
"Yeah, but he didn't have any opposition," the President quipped to the Mayor.

HEADLINE: Dole Says He Has Plan to Win Votes of Women

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Bob Dole tonight directly confronted for the first time one of his greatest weaknesses in his campaign for the White House -- his lack of support among women.
"I've seen some poll numbers, and you've seen the poll numbers that say, well, there's a gender gap," he said to a group of Republican women tonight. "Does this bother me? You bet it does. I don't believe there should be a gender gap; I think that gap will close. Do I have a plan to eliminate it? Yes I do." 
 His plan, Mr. Dole said, was to start discussing his support of certain pieces of legislation of particular interest to women. He noted first that he had sponsored a measure to make it easier to convict repeat rapists. However, that measure was part of the 1994 anti-crime bill, which Mr. Dole ultimately voted against because it contained a ban on assault weapons. The bill passed anyway.
The second item for which he took credit was "leading the Senate" to fund the Violence Against Women Act. That, too, was part of the anti-crime legislation that he opposed.
The Senate majority leader, who is the presumptive Republican nominee, then turned to other issues that Republicans hope to use as part of their appeal to women. He said his record also included "fighting for a balanced budget, for lower taxes, for better schools, for a strong national defense and for building a brighter future for all our citizens."
The second part of his strategy to woo women's votes, he said, would be to point out the "credibility gap" between President Clinton's words and his actions. He pointed to Mr. Clinton's promises to balance the budget and restructure welfare, only to veto Republican measures that Mr. Dole said would have done so.
In Woodbridge, N.J., today, President Clinton focused on an issue the Democrats have identified as a family concern: teen-age smoking. [Page B1.]
Mr. Dole did not make even passing reference in his remarks to the current debate within his party over abortion. Moderate Republicans, including some prominent governors and members of Congress, have vowed to wage a fight at the Republican National Convention this August over the party's platform, which calls for an outright constitutional ban on abortions.
The candidate's speech, and his decision to confront his problems with women voters, came as a new national poll made public today showed Mr. Dole trailing Mr. Clinton by 25 percentage points. The Harris poll, which had a margin of sampling error of three percentage points, said Mr. Clinton would beat Mr. Dole 53 percent to 28 percent.
While surveys show Mr. Dole trailing Mr. Clinton among almost all demographic and economic groups, he does the worst among women voters.
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll found that in a two-way race, men were divided evenly between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole, 45 percent for each, but 52 percent of the women favored Mr. Clinton, while only 34 percent said they would vote for Mr. Dole.
As they try to confront this problem, some Republicans, including House Speaker Newt Gingrich, are describing the sex gap as a problem merely of perception.
Speaking earlier today to the same group of women addressed by Mr. Dole, Mr. Gingrich promised "a tidal wave of communications" to correct what he said were false impressions of the Republican agenda created by President Clinton's "shameful performance of systematically misleading the American people." He said Mr. Clinton's false characterizations of Republicans had been fueled by a "passive conspiracy" of the liberal media.
"Liberals love to divide us," Mr. Gingrich said. But the Republicans, he said, can argue that "it is the welfare state which has been the most systematic oppressor of young women in the last 30 years."
Tony Blankley, Mr. Gingrich's spokesman, said in an interview later that the Republicans "have the challenge of explaining, not in shorthand for those inside the Beltway, but in human terms, what our policies intend to do."
But Ann Lewis, deputy manager of the Clinton/Gore campaign, said Mr. Dole had been "wrong on every major issue" affecting women, including, perhaps most symbolically, opposing the Family Medical Leave Act," which President Clinton signed.
She said Mr. Dole had displayed "an eagerness to cut back sharply at the expense of issues and policies that make a difference in family lives. It's the kitchen-table issues. I don't know how he turns it around, unless he's prepared to detach himself from the Congress of which he is a leader."
Mr. Dole said tonight that the Republican Party was "just as caring and just as compassionate as the other party." His solutions to the problems facing women were similar to those he has been offering on the campaign trail -- cutting spending, balancing the budget and returning power to the states.
Like Mr. Gingrich, Mr. Dole also said the press sided with President Clinton and distorted what the Republicans were doing. "We need to convince the media that we have a message too," he said.
Until now, the Dole campaign has done little to address women directly. By way of expressing support for working women, Mr. Dole frequently tells audiences that if he is elected President, his wife, Elizabeth Dole, will take a job outside the White House -- returning to her post as president of the Red Cross.
But then he seems to undercut that message by adding that his wife would "not be in charge of health care," a dig at Hillary Rodham Clinton that some perceive as meaning that Mr. Dole thinks women cannot handle important jobs.
This is obviously not what Mr. Dole believes, since his chief of staff and his top fund-raiser are both women, and his wife has had a high-powered career of her own. Nonetheless he has had trouble conveying that he is sympathetic to the concerns of ordinary women.
Perhaps hurting him the most, pollsters say, is that Mr. Dole is linked with Mr. Gingrich and the Congressional Republican agenda, which many women have told pollsters goes too far in dismantling the safety net that Government traditionally has provided.

HEADLINE: A Hit Season for Broadway;
Seems Like Old Times With Influx of Theatergoers

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Last Wednesday evening, the same night the 33d and final opening-night curtain of the Broadway season went up (on "The Ideal Husband" at the Ethel Barrymore Theater), Arnie and Ronnie Malasky waited beneath the marquee at Royale Theater on West 45th Street, where they would soon go inside to see George C. Scott in "Inherit the Wind."
The Malaskys -- he is an actuary, she works in retailing -- live in Westport, Conn., and they are regular theatergoers, venturing into the city, they said, even during the lean recent seasons, maybe a dozen times a year for dinner and a show. But they have been unusually active lately, part of the throng that is suddenly enlivening business around Times Square. In the month before they came to see "Inherit the Wind," the Malaskys said, they attended "A Midsummer Night's Dream," "Seven Guitars" and "The Night of the Iguana." 
 "And we're standing here talking about what other tickets to get," Mrs. Malasky said. "I want to see 'Master Class.' He doesn't really like musicals, but he just said he wants to see 'Rent.' And I think I can talk him into 'A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.' "
Her husband added: "We've been debating about 'A Delicate Balance.' It does seem there are more good shows than usual. There are suddenly a lot of things to see."
You know what? The Malaskys are right.
That Broadway is dead is so often repeated that it is conventional wisdom, a truism without being true. But after a spate of openings in the last six weeks -- 17! -- and an unusual rash of spectacular reviews, it is untruer right now than it has been in a long time. In the final week before the Tony Award nominations deadline last Thursday, Broadway shows sold $10.6 million worth of tickets, about 30 percent higher than the average for the year. About 9.2 million people are expected to see Broadway shows this season, the highest total for the decade.
"There's a surge of energy all across the Street," said Rocco Landesman, for the last 8 1/2 years the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns five Broadway houses. "It's the most exciting season since I've been on the scene."
Actually, the excitement is not so much the raw numbers: attendance and receipts for the season, which begins and ends officially with the Tony Awards ceremony in June, are up over last year, but last year they were up over the year before; and the number of shows up and running, 28, is actually one fewer than at this time a year ago. What is extraordinary is the range and quality of the offerings.
"Not in years has a theater season closed with the last-minute arrival of such a variety of first-rate productions," the chief critic for The New York Times, Vincent Canby, wrote in his season-concluding review of "The Ideal Husband" last week.
Such vigor on Broadway translates, of course, into money, for the theater district in particular and New York City in general.
"Certainly, what's going on hasn't been lost on anybody," said Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Times Square Business Improvement District. "We've been hearing it from hotels. We've been hearing it from restaurants. I just got out of a meeting with 12 mayors from Russia, and the first thing they asked me was, 'Why is it so hard to get a Broadway ticket this week?' " She added that the Broadway season has dovetailed nicely with the recent openings in Times Square of the Virgin Records megastore and the All Star Cafe.
"When the theater is going great, it feeds into everything," she said.
The Tony Award nominations, announced on Monday (the winners will be declared on national television on June 2), served as a reminder that Broadway has reassumed the theatrical supermarket look it had decades ago when there were routinely 50 or more openings in a season. There are now two one-man shows, the bevy of long-running megamusicals, three new dramas (alas, still a short supply) and a formidable list of musical and dramatic revivals.
Most notably, unlike last year, when "Sunset Boulevard" was the only full-fledged book musical to be Tony-eligible, this season there were seven eligible musicals, five of which are currently running. And in a startling reminder that the nominating committee does not always think the audience is right, the two others, "Swinging on a Star" and "Chronicle of a Death Foretold," received nominations for best musical, while more lavish and commercially successful current shows, like "Big" and Victor/Victoria" did not.
In addition, it has been a season that has been remarkable for, among other things, its recognizable stars: Carol Burnett, Carol Channing, Jason Robards, Mary Louise Parker, Ellen Burstyn and Patrick Stewart have all appeared on the boards, and Julie Andrews, Elaine Stritch, Zoe Caldwell, Nathan Lane, Lou Diamond Phillips, Matthew Broderick and Sarah Jessica Parker, not to mention Mr. Scott, are still around.
"What's happened is that three elements are coming together," said John Breglio, an entertainment lawyer who specializes in the theater. "You have your long-running shows, your shows that opened early in the season and the usual spring rush." The long-runners have remained strong, he said; the early-opening shows, like "Victor/Victoria" and "Moon Over Buffalo," and some shows that opened late last year, like "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying" and "Smokey Joe's Cafe," have hung on with surprising tenacity.
And the new shows -- the hip new musicals "Rent" and "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk" -- have bucked a longstanding Broadway problem by making use of theaters often deemed undesirable. "State Fair," for example, a fairly sizable musical, has squeezed itself into a fairly small theater, the Music Box; "Rent" is in the Nederlander, which, away from the madding crowd on the usually deserted and downbeat West 41st Street, has never been considered a welcoming spot. But the show itself is about a, well, low-rent district, and the thematic fit has thus far worked in its favor.
"Rarely has it been the case that all these things have come together in such a powerful way," Mr. Breglio said. "It's all happenstance, all serendipity. In the middle of the season, I was concerned because there seemed to be no way of getting new shows in, and now the spring has hit us, and we've gone from a booking jam to euphoria."
It is probably too soon to assess the dimensions of the boon that the current surge of hits has been to local business, particularly because spring is generally a spurt period for restaurants and hotels. But try walking through Shubert Alley at 7:45 P.M., grabbing a precurtain drink at Sardi's or an early table at Orso and the frisson of a happening in the theater district becomes palpable.
"It hasn't been easy lately to get into my pet parking garage," said Mrs. Malasky on Wednesday night, a bit of a good-natured grumble.
The Marriott Marquis Hotel in Times Square has been running at an occupancy level throughout April of 85 percent, 2 points higher than a year ago. And citywide, said Steven J. Morello, president of the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau, hotel occupancy rates should be up over 80 percent for the summer and into the fall, also up from a year ago, even without the events like the Pope's visit and the 50th anniversary of the United Nations that swelled the tourist ranks.
"It appears we have another demand generator," said Jonathan Tisch, president of Loews Hotels, which operates four hotels in New York City. "Broadway is booming and so is the hotel business."
Business on Broadway and business in restaurants have long gone hand in hand. Indeed, restaurant owners in the theater district have fought successfully in the past to keep producers from moving to curtain times earlier than 8 P.M. Why? So people will have enough time to eat. But Fred Sampson, president of the New York Restaurant Association, said new shows were particularly good for the restaurant trade.
For the first year or so of a show's run, he explained, theatergoers tend to be city denizens and individual tourists who take time to eat either before or after. Once a show has been around awhile, he said, it begins to attract the economy bus tour trade, in which people are ferried in and out on too strict a schedule to enjoy a meal.
"Big," which opened on April 28 at the Shubert Theater on West 44th Street, Mr. Sampson said, "is a perfect example of a show that's great for us." The musical it replaced at the Shubert, "Crazy For You," had been ensconced there for four years.
"For a while there it seemed like Broadway would become a living museum." said George C. Wolfe, referring to the long-running musicals and revivals that have dominated the Broadway fare for years. It was a good sign, said Mr. Wolfe, the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, that new shows developed in the smaller nonprofit theaters -- like "Rent" and "Bring In da Noise" have landed in the theater world's most prominent commercial venue.
"The more Broadway can embrace complexity, the more it's going to become alive," said Mr. Wolfe, who is the director of "Bring In da Noise."
So for the moment, optimism reigns. But the theater is always, of course, an iffy proposition. No one is willing to swear that the lingering drought of the last several years is at an end. Some shows are likely to vanish after the Tony Awards hoopla is over next month (one, "Jack," a one-man show starring Nicol Williamson, closed on Sunday) and others will struggle to last out the year.
And there are other questions: Will "Rent" -- which began life last winter at the New York Theater Workshop in the East Village -- sustain the initial enthusiasm that accompanied its surprising emergence as an Off Broadway hit? Will "Bring In da Noise" tap into a black audience with its rendering of the history of black culture in America? If the two shows do not begin to attract a new audience to Broadway, many theater professionals feel, the future is dubious.
"It's really urgent that they succeed, and scary that they might not," said James B. Freydberg, the producer of "Big."
The cautious optimism is probably best expressed by Mr. Wolfe. Can the good times last?
"My romantic self says yes, of course," he said.

HEADLINE: TV Notes;
Talking to the People

BYLINE: By Lawrei Mifflin 

 BODY:
Late last year, while making plans to cover the 1996 Presidential campaign, ABC News producers discussed how to get more depth into the usual polling and interviewing of ordinary Americans on the hot topics of the political season. But there turned out to be no primary season to speak of, as Bob Dole quickly became the Republican candidate opposing President Clinton.
"We decided we didn't need primaries, didn't need candidates or a campaign to explore in some depth how American voters, and nonvoters, were feeling about this country," said Kathy Christensen, the executive producer of "World News Tonight." 
 The result was an unusual project for network news. Ms. Christensen sent 10 reporters out to various parts of the country, without camera crews or even producers. They were told to roam across a state or region and to spend a week or two talking to people, discovering their concerns.
"We determined that what they found is what we'd explore, rather than what we thought were the hottest topics based on polls or the legislative agenda," Ms. Christensen said. The correspondents then returned to the same communities with cameras, to tape segments for "Listening to America," which will appear each night for two weeks, starting on Monday, on "World News Tonight."
The reports are not confined to one theme, the economy, for instance. Some are personal, like a divorced mother's regrets about how she raised her children, and some address broader issues, like how government helps or hinders a community project.
"It's been a very long time since we dispatched this many reporters to cover a single story that was not a major disaster," said Peter Jennings, the program's anchor. Overall, he said, "we found less anger than we expected, but every bit as much anxiety."
Around the same time, NBC News reporters were also out talking to ordinary Americans, but with a very different focus. "Lie, Cheat and Steal: Dishonest in America" will appear in segments on "Nightly News," "Today" and "Dateline," for one week beginning on May 19. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S., Citing Chinese Piracy, Weighs Retaliatory Action
Clinton Administration officials said that they had discovered evidence of previously undiscovered Chinese factories pirating American software, videos and music, and that they were preparing to announce retaliatory action against $2 billion in Chinese imports next week.
Sanctions would increase tensions in a relationship already troubled by China's shipments of nuclear weapons material, its continued repression of dissidents and its efforts to intimidate Taiwan. [Page A1.]
 
Cantor Partners Settle Feud
The partners of Cantor Fitzgerald, a leading institutional broker of Government securities, settled their bitter succession battle. B. Gerald Cantor, the 79-year-old founder, and his wife, Iris, will retain a 20 percent limited partnership stake, while Howard Lutnick, the president, will keep control. [D2.]
 
Deal for British Utility
Facing increased competition at home, two American utilities, General Public Utilities and Cinergy, agreed to acquire a big British energy distributor, Midlands Electricity, for $2.6 billion. [D6.]
 
Dow Tumbles to 3-Month Low
The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 43.36 points, to a three-month low of 5,420.95. Rising interest rates troubled traders. The Nasdaq composite fell 3.64, to 1,182.67. [D8.]
 
Treasury securities fell in price, following a weak sale of new three-year notes. The 30-year bond's yield edged up to 7.07 percent. [D18.]
 
An Economist Sees Service Flaws
Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist of Morgan Stanley, who is famous for contending that service-sector companies are becoming more efficient, says in a circular to be faxed today to news organizations and hundreds of clients, "I must confess that I am having second thoughts as to whether we have reached the promised land." [D2.]
 
Growth of Consumer Credit Slows
Installment debt grew at the slowest rate in six months in March, the Fed said, climbing $6.4 billion, or a 7.3 percent annual rate. Demand for new-car loans, with virtually no growth, was particularly weak. [D5.]
 
Fleet Settles With Minorities
Fleet Financial Group agreed to pay about $4 million to hundreds of black and Hispanic customers to settle Justice Department complaints that minority borrowers were charged more for loans than whites. [D4.]
 
Conde Nast Hits Broadway
Conde Nast, the publisher of Glamour, Vanity Fair, GQ and Allure, will move its headquarters to a building planned in Times Square. Walt Disney and Morgan Stanley are already attracted to the area. [B3.]
 
Broadway shows are drawing throngs of theatergoers. Some 9.2 million are expected this season, the most in a decade. [B1.]
 
Premiere Magazine Editors Quit
The top editors of Premiere, a film magazine, resigned after a column that was to have examined the business dealings of the actor Sylvester Stallone was killed. [D7.]
 
Ban for Former Barings Executive
Peter Norris, who ran investment banking at Barings P.L.C. when it collapsed last year after $1.3 billion in trading losses, was banned by British authorities from holding a senior securities post for three years. [D6.]
 
'The Phantom' Opts for Milk
"The Phantom" is joining the string of celebrities sporting a milk mustache, as Paramount undertakes an unusual tie-in with the ad campaign for milk to entice moviegoers to its film of the same name. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
New Berkshire Hathaway Shares
Berkshire Hathaway's offering of "junior" shares, which will be worth a fraction of the regular ones, is expected to be priced at around $1,200 a share. Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slides Against the Mark, But Stocks and Bonds Lend Aid

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar slid against European currencies yesterday after remarks by two German central bankers incited a big demand for marks, but the dollar partly recovered on rising American stock and bond prices.
European traders, who have been betting on further weakness in the mark, had to scramble to buy the currency and sell dollars after Hans-Jurgen Koebnick, a member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council, told a news conference in Germany that he believed the mark's depreciation had run its course. 
 Traders have been figuring that Germany's frail economy would prompt the Bundesbank to ease interest rates again, which makes mark-denominated holdings less attractive. The German central bank lowered rates last month.
The mark rally was reinforced by remarks yesterday from another Bundesbank council member, Hans Jurgen-Krupp, who suggested to a Spanish banking conference that there wasn't likely to be further German rate cuts. On Tuesday, another Bundesbank council member, Edgar Meister, expressed similar sentiments.
Victor Polce, foreign exchange manager at the New York branch of Commerzbank, said: "You had a lot of people who were long on dollars. So when a couple of Bundesbank officials opened their mouths, they ran for the exits."
The mark's strength hurt the yen, and the dollar gained against the Japanese currency.
The dollar fell as low as 1.5143 marks before settling in New York at 1.5163 marks, down from 1.5253 marks on Tuesday. The dollar also traded at 105.20 yen, up from 105.13 yen on Tuesday. The British pound rose to $1.5235 from $1.5100.
The dollar began to recover in New York trading on strong buying demand at the Treasury's auction of $14 billion in 10-year notes.
The results prompted a broader rally in the United States bond market that snapped a two-day decline, and helped turn around the faltering stock market as well. The rallies strengthened the dollar by increasing demand for the currency needed to buy the American securities.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which had fallen more than 78 points in the morning to the lowest level in three months, rebounded to close with a gain of 53.11 points.
"The mark's strength was the feature of today's trading," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst with Smith Barney in New York. "But the rebound in stock and bond markets in the United States sort of helped the dollar."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A supercomputer deal pits buying American vs. fair trade.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
AMERICANS make the best supercomputers in the world. Or at least they did. Two Japanese electronics giants, Fujitsu and NEC, are challenging the supremacy of Cray Research, the Minnesota supercomputer specialist that was recently bought by Silicon Graphics. The three are bidding to sell a supercomputer to the National Center for Atmospheric Research, an agency of the National Science Foundation. Should Washington come to Cray's rescue and lean on the foundation to buy American?
The Clinton Administration, which has yet to express an opinion, is under pressure to view the question through a parochial political lens. Supercomputing, after all, is a glamorous frontier of high technology, the sort of industry where American business must excel if President Clinton's vision of global capitalism powered by Yankee ingenuity is to become reality. Besides it is an election year in America, and the folks who make Fujitsu and NEC computers don't get to vote. 
 But economists see another issue at stake. How can we ask Tokyo to play fair on trade issues if Washington doesn't? asks Robert Lawrence of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "If we make an exception for protectionism in high technology," he argues, "we'll all be worse off in the long run."
Supercomputers occupy a modest niche in the computer market, and a not very profitable one. But the prestige of making dazzling machines that can perform tens of billions of calculations a second has kept a number of major hardware manufacturers, along with a handful of specialized producers, in the supercomputer game. And after years of Byzantine maneuvering to defend their home markets and penetrate foreign ones, America and Japan called a truce in 1990. They agreed to open both public and private procurement to the lowest bidders.
Japan's commitment to a free market is a matter of debate. Kenneth Flamm, an economist at the Brookings Institution, suggests that public procurement is still uncompetitive in the sense that nationality counts a lot. The Japanese Government, however, has purchased seven of its last 13 supercomputers from American makers, while Japanese companies have yet to make a sale to a government agency in America.
American makers, among them Cray, arguably hold the technological lead in specialized supercomputers for military purposes like the simulation of nuclear explosions. But in peaceful uses, Japanse equipment is competitive on cost, performance and reliability. Fujitsu and NEC have recently sold machines for weather simulation in third markets (Europe and Canada) where the buyers have no particular reason to play politics with supercomputers. That is why the stakes in the current case are so high: it apparently represents the first clear test of Washington's will to honor the supercomputer agreement.
In theory there is a slender economic rationale for protecting the domestic American supercomputer market. The world may have room only for a handful of efficient supercomputer makers, just as there is room only for a handful of efficient jet aircraft manufacturers. Giving Cray a preference in the largest piece of the market may thus make it possible for it to survive, even thrive, among the more diversified computer makers.
But Mr. Lawrence is skeptical. "Are there really infant industries in mature economies?" he asks. Even Laura D'Andrea Tyson, director of Mr. Clinton's National Economic Council, has argued that other approaches will work better than a guaranteed government market. In her book "Who's Bashing Whom" (Institute for International Economics) she wrote that "if a strong American supercomputer industry is itself a policy goal, some direct public support, preferably funds for cooperative, generic R&D programs is warranted."
Cray has raised another issue, letting it be known that NEC would lose $3 million on a proposed three-year lease to the atmospheric research center. Below-cost sales by foreigners (but not by Americans) are illegal if they injure American competitors. It is hard to imagine, however, that a single sale would result in injury under the standard usually applied. In any case, Mr. Lawrence says, it would be inappropriate for the science foundation or the center to weigh this untested allegation in the procurement decision.
Representative Martin O. Sabo, a senior Democrat from Minneapolis, where many Cray workers live, and recipient of $5,500 in campaign contributions from Cray executives, urged the White House last month "to stand behind our vital supercomputer research and industrial sector at this critical time." But Rick Anthes, the head of the nonprofit corporation that directs the atmospheric research center in Boulder, Colo., insists that the buck has not been passed. "With the National Science Foundation's encouragement, we are playing it straight," he said.
Cray seems to have overplayed its hand, making a very public issue of a decision more likely to go in its favor if it were made in secret. But appearances can deceive. By making a fuss over a choice in which it is still unlikely to prevail, the company may at least be able to turn attention back toward the Japanese Government, which will also be buying a supercomputer in the near future. Sometimes you win even when you lose.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Cold Weather and Expectations Of Shortages Raise Grain Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Grain prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, propelled by continued cold, wet weather and anticipation that a Government report tomorrow would detail robust worldwide demand but low grain stocks and poor yields.
On other commodity markets, crude oil prices fell, hurt by reports that United States reserves are more than had been believed and uncertainty about talks between the United Nations and Iraq on a limited sale of Iraqi oil. 
 Grain prices gained as investors squared positions before the scheduled release tomorrow of the Agriculture Department's supply-demand report, said Robert Lekberg, an analyst with Goldenberg, Hehmeyer & Company in Chicago. Traders say they believe the report will show continued strong demand and dwindling American stockpiles.
July wheat futures and prices of nearby months jumped the limit on the Chicago Board of Trade. Daniel Basse, research director at the Agresource Company in Chicago, said the move came partly because wheat stocks are at 50-year lows. He also said that buying by investment funds and continued concern about planting delays in the northern spring wheat area were factors.
Mr. Lekberg said wheat prices also gained on a report by the Federal Reserve Bank in St. Louis, which estimated that Illinois farmers might have to plow under half of their soft red winter-wheat crop because of poor weather.
July wheat rose the maximum 20 cents, to $5.91 a bushel; July corn rose 12 cents, to $4.74 a bushel.
Crude oil prices dropped slightly because traders believed that the price had stabilized. Traders are also awaiting signs of progress as Iraqi and United Nations negotiators continue a fourth round of talks on a plan to let Iraq sell as much as $2 billion of oil over six months to pay for food and medicine.
The market is "not moving much until we find out if they will reach an agreement," Tim Evans, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group in New York, said.

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Shows Marked Pickup in the Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
A survey by the Federal Reserve pointed today to a marked pickup in the economy during March and April, more evidence that expansion is solid again in most parts of the country.
"Activity advanced at a moderate pace," the Fed's survey found, while price increases remained mostly subdued and there was "only scattered" upward pressure on wages despite a tight job market. 
 One exception, however, was the New York district, which the Fed singled out as having "weakened somewhat" in the last two months. Among the poor performers were factories in the Buffalo area and the housing market in Albany, the latter continuing to suffer from state job cuts.
Job creation picked up in both New York and New Jersey but the unemployment rate still climbed in New York because of a sharp increase in the number of people seeking work. A clear bright spot, however, was tourism, which the survey found "continues to boom," with the hotel occupancy rate in New York City reaching a 16-year high in the first quarter of the year.
The Fed's survey of its 12 districts was part of the preparation for the May 21 meeting of the interest rate-setting group, the Federal Open Market Committee. Today's report seemed to increase only slightly the chance that the Fed would soon raise short-term rates to prevent inflation from accelerating.
The Fed's latest anecdotal survey, which was issued at noon, had little effect on the financial markets today. While bond prices surged, the rally was largely attributed to unexpectedly strong demand for 10-year bonds at a Treasury auction.
In a separate report, the Conference Board said its index of economic indicators, which tend to move at the same time as the economy as a whole, edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in March, less than the eight-tenths of 1 percent gain posted in February.
Last week, the business-sponsored research group reported that its index of predictive indicators, formerly compiled by the Commerce Department, also moved up for the second straight month.
The Fed's survey, titled "Current Economic Conditions" but widely referred to as the beige book after the color of its cover, said in its summary that all 11 districts other than New York showed expansion and that several of them reported that the pace had "quickened" recently. It noted a pickup in both retail sales and in manufacturing and suggested that factory inventories were no longer higher than desired.
"Activity also picked up in nonfinancial services, commercial and consumer lending and real estate," declared the summary, written this time at the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond. On the other hand, "mortgage loan activity slowed, as did tourism in several districts and agriculture suffered from adverse weather."
The survey found minimal the effect of a 17-day strike in March against General Motors. Even in Buffalo, where 6,000 were idled, the deterioration of manufacturing was "not directly related" to the strike, the Fed stated. And the Cleveland district reported that the strike seems to have had "only a small effect" on sales.
Despite a low unemployment rate, averaging 5.5 percent during March and April, most districts saw "little upward pressure" on prices other than for energy and grains, the Fed also found. And wage pressures were "only modest" over all despite several industries in the St. Louis district reporting higher costs and Minneapolis reporting pay increases of 4 to 5 percent.
One striking example of how tight labor markets have become in the upper Midwest, especially for blue-collar workers, was the decision by the Minneapolis-St. Paul transit system to reduce the minimum age for bus drivers to 19. A restaurant in the St. Louis district was reported to have delayed its opening for two months for lack of help, while a Tennessee hotel was forced to recruit workers from overseas. Atlanta reported that filling entry-level positions "has become a challenge."
On the other hand, the Dallas district reported fewer wage pressures or labor shortages than earlier in the year while Kansas City said "employers report few wage increases" despite a continuing tight job market.
The word from Chicago was that the area economy "remained at relatively high levels" despite pockets of slowing or actual decline. "Labor market shortages continued to be the main concern of businesses despite softening demand for workers from the manufacturing sector," the Fed survey found.
