HEADLINE: Minding More Than the Bottom Line;
Two Companies and Two Different Views of Corporate Responsibility

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
When President Clinton convenes a White House conference planned for next week on the nebulous but politically charged issue of corporate responsibility, the list of those reaping his praise will not include Caterpillar Inc. or its chief executive, Donald V. Fites.
Mr. Fites, after all, is accused by many of his own employees of busting unions, closing plants and grabbing for huge paychecks -- the kind of managerial behavior that politicians are condemning in an election year punctuated by themes of economic insecurity. 
 By contrast, Sidney Harman, the chief executive of Harman International Industries, will be one of the corporate managers Mr. Clinton holds up as a model of how treating workers well is not only the right thing to do, but good for business, too.
To keep workers at his speaker-manufacturing company employed during business downturns, Mr. Harman pays them to make parts he would otherwise buy from suppliers, or to build clocks out of scrap material. He also offers extensive training programs. And Mr. Harman, whose wife, Jane Harman, is a Democratic Congresswoman from California, has tried experiments such as allowing workers to share in the proceeds of cost savings they propose.
The reputations of Mr. Fites and Mr. Harman may be at opposite ends of the spectrum in the debate over corporate responsibility, the concept that managers must have a commitment to the welfare of their employees and communities -- the company's other stake holders, apart from investors -- as well as to their bottom lines.
But, economists and business executives argue, the widely varying approaches can obscure the fact that managers are often attempting to do much the same thing: taking action, based on their companies' circumstances, to protect jobs in an environment of ever-intensifying competition.
Mr. Fites might have caused considerable pain by beating back a strike and holding down wage increases. But viewed as part of an effort to turn around a company that a decade ago was in real danger of collapse, his strategy could be seen as helping preserve tens of thousands of high-paying American jobs when many manufacturers were shifting employment to low-wage sites abroad.
"The first and most important responsibility of any corporation is to be economically viable, because if it's not it will eventually die," said Peter Feuille, the director of the Institute of Labor and Industrial Relations at the University of Illinois.
"That's the issue Cat sees itself as addressing -- to press for the protection of its economic interests so it can remain viable over the long haul," Mr. Feuille said. "The issue is what kind of balance do you strike among a company's stake holders as you do it."
The business world has long argued that the corporate-responsibility debate -- with its focus on layoffs and worker insecurity -- has all but ignored the American industrial renaissance of the last decade or so. Caterpillar is just one example among many that have helped the United States recapture its standing as the world's most competitive and innovative economy.
Just a few years ago, American business was being attacked for failing to meet the challenge posed by Japan and other nations. Yet now, its defenders complain, it is being cast as callous by politicians and the news media for undertaking the cost-cutting and efficiency-enhancing steps needed to make it competitive.
The success of that effort, they said, has bestowed the most tangible of benefits to workers: a healthy pace of job creation -- more than eight million in the last three years -- and a low unemployment rate, currently 5.4 percent. At the same time companies are generating higher profits, which make more capital available for investment in new enterprises, better equipment and new jobs.
"During this last 10 years we have literally transformed American industry and by any standards it is the most competitive in the world," said John Snow, the chairman of the CSX Corporation and the head of the Business Roundtable, a trade association for the nation's largest companies.
But, Mr. Snow said, that transformation raises other questions. "The trick here -- and it's one of the major public-policy issues of our time -- is how to achieve the benefits of this aggressive, competitive economic system that is advancing our interests and creating so much wealth, while also addressing the anxiety that is almost a natural consequence of the change," Mr. Snow said.
The arguments of chief executives can obviously be self-serving. Wage stagnation and other economic problems continue to afflict workers. Layoffs at some companies are caused by the need to clean up strategic mistakes by top managers -- who later earn huge salaries and bonuses by taking credit for solving the problems they created.
Some chief executives have had reputations as ruthless cost-cutters for years. John F. Welch Jr. of General Electric long ago earned the nickname Neutron Jack for eliminating people but leaving the buildings standing. More recently, Robert E. Allen of AT&T, Walter V. Shipley of Chase Manhattan and Albert J. Dunlap of Scott Paper have been condemned for jettisoning tens of thousands of workers and collecting huge paychecks for their trouble.
But for the most part, their companies are now better prepared to compete and preserve the jobs of remaining workers than they would have been otherwise. G.E., for instance, has not cut jobs in recent years, but has been stable or even added jobs as it has taken the lead in many of its markets.
The Caterpillar case is particularly telling. In the mid-1980's, Caterpillar was at risk of falling to an onslaught of Japanese rivals. The construction-equipment company, based in Peoria, Ill., developed a survival plan based on heavy investments in more productive factories and cost-cutting that included taking on its powerful unions over wages and benefits. That confrontation -- and especially Mr. Fites's success in breaking a long strike by the United Automobile Workers union last year -- left many employees reviling him. Mr. Fites's paycheck last year of $4.07 million, up 53 percent from 1994, did not help his reputation, and neither did his recent decision to close an inefficient plant in York, Pa., eliminating 1,000 jobs.
"Cat used to be a good corporate citizen," said Jerry Brown, the head of the United Automobile Workers local in East Peoria, Ill., which led the strike. "Now it's all about arrogance and greed."
But in the end, Caterpillar thrived, giving remaining employees more job security than they had a decade ago.
Harman's experience does not yield any outright heroes, either. At Harman's main speaker-manufacturing plants in Northridge, Calif., and Martinsville, Ind., Mr. Harman said, treating workers well has paid off. Productivity at the Martinsville plant, for example, has roughly doubled in the last five years, largely because of increased training and other incentives, he said.
Still, Mr. Harman added, even a passionate commitment to employees' welfare can not shield them from every exigency. In 1990, the company had to eliminate around 150 jobs in Northridge. Several months ago, it laid off 250 workers there, out of 1,800, because of soft demand.
Most of those 250 are back on the payroll, employed in what Harman calls its Off Line Enterprises, making wiring that would otherwise be purchased from suppliers, doing jobs such as security and gardening that would otherwise go to outside contractors and building clocks out of leftover materials. Once demand picks up, the workers will go back to their regular jobs producing the company's JBL, Harman-Kardon and Infinity brand stereo equipment.
Keeping 250 workers on the payroll costs his company $130,000 a week, Mr. Harman said. But most of that cost is made up by savings on what the company would otherwise be paying outside suppliers for parts and services, he said. If there is a direct cost, Mr. Harman said, it may be that jobs at suppliers are endangered.
Indirectly, there is a danger that such policies "move into an area where people confuse it with entitlement," he added.
Despite his enthusiasm, many executives are skeptical about the benefits of doing more for employees, especially when funds for investment are tight and pressure for improved earnings is intense.
There is also the question of how far Harman's resolve would extend if the company entered a prolonged downturn, when the price of principle might not be so easily absorbed by growing sales and profits.
Mr. Harman, though, is convinced he is on the right track. "What I absolutely believe is that honoring the people who do the work can produce stunning results for the company," he said. "If the people in the factory believe there's a real effort to help improve their skills, provide opportunities for advancement and job security, they can do things that will blow your mind."
On the political front, the thundering denunciations of executive greed issued by Patrick J. Buchanan during his unsuccessful campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination have largely died out. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, after engaging in some tentative corporation-bashing early in the primary campaign, rarely mentions the issue anymore.
The Clinton Administration is taking a moderate approach limited mostly to giving public plaudits to companies that combine innovative employment and training programs with strong bottom-line performances.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich has dropped his suggestion that "good" companies could be rewarded through tax breaks or other government largess. The Administration line now is that good employment policies are their own reward, by generating worker loyalty, productivity and creativity, and ultimately in helping improve profits.
Whether a commitment to corporate responsibility takes root or fades when the next hot political issue comes along is itself a subject of debate among corporate managers.
"Most executives at most companies come out of a traditional experience and see this as a lot of talk," Mr. Harman said. "Companies that think it's a lot of bull will respond poorly to feeling pressured. But if the President eloquently makes the case in favor and offers examples of companies that are successful, it might arouse some interest. The best inducements to do it are the results."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Prices Soar

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday after an auction of new 10-year notes received strong demand.
Bonds were bolstered on the long end by short-covering from investors who had bet on a drop in prices and on the short end by buying from investors fleeing early losses in the stock market. 
 While the rally pushed the yield of the benchmark 30-year bond below the psychologically important level of 7 percent for the first time since May 1, market participants remain cautious. Many are waiting for further clues to the direction of the economy -- and inflation -- in particular, tomorrow's report on producer prices in April.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended up 1 8/32, to 89 2/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.95 percent, from 7.07 percent on Tuesday. For bondholders, the day meant a gain of $12.50 for every $1,000 invested in bonds.
The release of the Federal Reserve's survey of regional business activity encouraged buying only because it contained no surprises. The survey, known as the beige book, showed a pickup in economic growth in March and April, but with only scattered reports of wage pressures despite continued tightness in the labor market.
Traders and dealers spent much of the morning yesterday setting up for the Treasury's $14 billion auction of new 10-year notes, the final leg of the Government's quarterly refunding. Dealers maneuvered yields a bit higher to find a level that would be attractive and bring in the most investors. Many were hoping that yesteray's results would not turn out as weak as the three-year auction the day before.
But the 10-year note sale was well received, resulting in an average yield of 6.902 percent, below the 6.91 percent the market had expected. And while retail interest from small investors was a little weaker than expected, the bid-to-cover ratio was better than expected at 2.39, well above last auction's 2.01, but still average. The bid-to-cover ratio that compares the dollar amount of bids with the securities sold.
The boost to the market from the auction then prompted buying from short-sellers seeking to limit their losses.
P. Christopher Leary, senior vice president and portfolio manager at SunAmerica Asset Management, noted that a number of short positions -- or sales of borrowed securities, made in hopes of buying them back at a cheaper price -- were established last Thursday, after a report on first-quarter gross domestic product showed a faster pace of growth than had been expected. These short-sellers were betting that prices would fall.
But when Friday's employment report was not as strong as feared, "the market built a foundation relatively close to where it had bottomed out," Mr. Leary said.
"And thus today once the supply of the 10-year was handled with ease, a short squeeze occurred giving the market a lot of its forward momentum," he said.
Mr. Leary also noted that there was much speculation about asset shifts from mortage securities into Treasury securities and stocks into Treasury securities, shaking an already nervous market. "I think to a certain degree the market traded as if it were surprised at the moderate economic growth the beige book report suggested," he said.

HEADLINE: Competition May Thin Profits In Sport Utilities

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 8

 BODY:
From pint-sized Jeep Wranglers to Chevrolet Suburbans the size of a garage, sport utility vehicles have been the mainstay of profits at Detroit's Big Three auto makers since the late 1980's. But now a small traffic jam of new models is emerging in the market, and auto executives predict that the profits, while still enormous, will start to erode.
The Ford Motor Company plans to display its largest offering, the three-bench, nine-passenger Ford Expedition, at its annual meeting in Kansas City, Mo., on Thursday. In the last four months, Toyota has introduced the small RAV 4 sport utility and the Lexus LX 450, Nissan has completely redesigned its Pathfinder and Chrysler has come out with a new Jeep Wrangler. 
 Stock analysts predict that the new models, particularly the Ford Expedition, should initially be big money makers, even though rising gas prices are making them more costly to drive. The Expedition, selling for as much as $36,000 with options, could easily prove to be the nation's most profitable auto, adding up to $1 billion a year to Ford's after-tax profits by 1998, predicted David Bradley, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities Inc.
"I haven't been a huge, rah-rah supporter of Ford stock," Mr. Bradley said, referring to the fact the No. 2 auto maker's shares had performed poorly until recent ly. "But this could make a difference." Ford has not officially priced the Expedition, which goes on sale in September as a replacement for the Ford Bronco, but it is likely to sell for $30,000 to $36,000.
For hot-selling, full-sized sport utility vehicles like the Suburban, profit margins now approach $10,000 apiece, but that is likely to shrink, auto executives say, as more models go on sale.
"Clearly the profits will come down in that segment -- there's a lot of capacity coming in," said G. Mustafa Mohatarem, the chief economist at the General Motors Corporation.
Executives are concerned, even at the Chrysler Corporation, which has the advantage of owning the Jeep trademark and posted record sales for several models last month from a year earlier. "To say that Jeep is not looking over its shoulders at some of the people coming into the market would be incorrect," said Ed Brust, the general manager of Chrysler's Jeep and Eagle division. "The competition is coming and it's going to be a real dogfight."
J. D. Power & Associates, the auto consulting company, calculates that the number of sport utility vehicle models on the market grew by only one, to 30, over the last five years. But over the next several years there will be a net increase of 18 models, to 48 models in 2000.
A few analysts say that is a recipe for trouble for the Big Three. "You're talking about flat sales and increased competition," said Paul D. Ballew, the chief economist at J. D. Power, who estimates that sport utility vehicles accounted for half the profits at Detroit's Big Three last year.
But executives at domestic and foreign auto makers said that they expected the sport utility vehicle market to continue growing over the next several years, as new, more comfortable models entice more customers to make the switch from cars. "What we're still seeing right now is an increase in that market," said Brad W. Larsen, United States manager of trucks and sport utility vehicles for the Toyota Motor Corporation.
Only one of every 16 cars and light trucks sold in 1990 was a sport utility vehicle. But by last year, the figure was one in nine.
Japanese auto makers invested heavily in the late 1980's to make midsized luxury sedans like the Acura and the Lexus LS 400, while Detroit placed its bet on a rising sport utility vehicle market. Having initially bet wrong, Japanese car makers are now developing many more sport utility models.
Auto executives and dealers said that rising gas prices seem to have had little affect so far on the demand for even the biggest, fuel-thirsty sport utility vehicles, which get as little as 13 miles to the gallon in the city -- less than a Cadillac. "These are expensive vehicles, more than $30,000 a vehicle, and for the people who buy these vehicles, 10 cents a gallon or more doesn't have any effect on them," said Henry Valencia, a GMC, Pontiac and Buick dealer in Santa Fe, N.M.
The California market may be an exception, G.M.'s Mr. Mohatarem said. Gas prices are likely to stay high in California because of the state's requirement for specially formulated gasoline to reduce air pollution, he said, and that will eventually discourage some sport utility sales.
"You will begin to see the mix of sport utility vehicles in California is less than in Texas, say," Mr. Mohatarem said.
While advertised for their rugged ability to ford streams and charge up hillsides, sport utility vehicles are mostly used by affluent families hauling children around the suburbs. The larger models are surprisingly rare in rural areas, where many people cannot afford them.
Don Smolek, a farmer in Monterey, Ind., said that while he and his wife would like a larger sport utility vehicle to replace their 1993 Ford Explorer, they were unlikely to buy the Expedition because of the price. "Mid-20's is about as high as I'd go," he said.
But the recent experience of auto makers has been that while many middle-class customers pinch pennies on car purchases, affluent buyers have been snapping up the most expensive mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles without even waiting for rebates and other incentives. Dianne C. Craig, the marketing plans manager for the Expedition and Explorer, said that Ford expected only 10 percent of the Expedition sales to come from Explorer sales, while the rest would come from various other companies' sales of luxury cars, expensive mini-vans and very large sport utility vehicles.
The Expedition will challenge the near monopoly that G.M. has had until now on very large sport utility vehicles. The Chevrolet and GMC Suburban, which is in tight supply, has three rows of seats, like the new Expedition, a feature that has drawn buyers with large families or with children who participate in car pools or group outings. Last year, G.M. introduced the strong-selling GMC Yukon and Chevrolet Tahoe, which are big enough for three rows of seats but not currently engineered to hold them.
The Ford Expedition is roughly the size of a Yukon or Tahoe and is designed to be easier to park than the mammoth Suburban. Mr. Bradley at J. P. Morgan said that with the market for very large sport utility vehicles growing briskly, G.M. was unlikely to be hurt very seriously by Ford's entry into the market.

HEADLINE: Clinton Approves Plan for Sanctions Against China Over Piracy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
President Clinton, meeting with his top foreign policy and economic advisers about rising tensions with China, approved a plan today to go ahead with sanctions on Chinese exports to the United States if Beijing fails to stop producing pirated American software, movies and music, the White House said.
Mr. Clinton told the acting United States Trade Representative, Charlene Barshefsky, to proceed next week with the publication of a list of goods totaling about $3 billion annually that could be subject to 100 percent tariffs on June 15 unless China complies with an accord it signed with the United States a year ago. 
 Before the sanctions are imposed, the list is likely to be winnowed to about $2 billion, roughly equivalent to the damage that the Administration estimates is being done to American software producers and entertainment companies by pirates each year. That would represent only about 5 percent of China's annual exports to the United States.
"The President reaffirmed that if we don't get satisfaction, we have no choice but to go ahead with the sanctions," David Johnson, a White House spokesman, said this evening.
While the session focused on the dispute over China's failure to protect intellectual property, White House officials said that far more was at stake. The meeting also discussed a growing concern that relations with Beijing are slipping further, with no clear strategy for ending the cycle of threats and counterthreats.
As a result, nearly all top Cabinet members took part in the meeting: Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who is considering separate sanctions against China for its shipment of nuclear materials to Pakistan; Defense Secretary William Perry; Gen. John Shalikashvili, the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff; Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, and Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor.
But participants said there was little discussion of a grander plan for dealing with China. Instead, the meeting discussed how to design the sanctions list so that it is likely to have the maximum impact on Chinese companies, especially those close to the Government and the military, while causing the least disruption to American retailers and others who might protest the action.
Administration officials said that the list will be sent to Lee Sands, a trade negotiator who is to be in Beijing on Monday and Tuesday, just before the May 15 deadline that Washington set for action by China on a plan to carry out last year's accords. Presumably Mr. Sands will brief Chinese leaders on the contents in the hope of extracting a last-minute settlement.
But even if, the Chinese made some accommodation that prevented the list from being published, China will still have 30 days to act before the Customs Service begins applying the 100 percent duties.
"We expect they'll take this to the wire," one senior Administration official said today.
The negotiations will coincide with a bitter, annual Congressional debate over whether to extend the so-called most-favored-nation trade privileges to China that has already divided both the Democratic and Republican parties.
The Administration has said that it would be self-destructive to cancel the trading privileges, which give China the benefit of low tariffs in the United States. Senator Bob Dole, the Republican frontrunner for the Presidential nomination, is expected to address the issue on Thursday morning in his first major policy speech about Asia, and is expected to support renewing the trade benefits with some conditions.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Wall Street's Moody Day: Prices and Predictions Swing

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Asked yesterday which way stock and bond prices were going, Wall Street traders responded like the confused posse in a slapstick Western, shouting "Thataway!," and pointing in every direction at once.
Thus began a day of extraordinary volatility on the New York Stock Exchange. Less than an hour after the start of trading, sharply falling stock prices triggered the Big Board's 50-point "collar," which attempts to quell volatility by restricting certain types of computer-driven trading. 
 Then, late in the day's session, the collar was triggered again by rising prices, as the Dow raced more than 50 points above Tuesday's close. It was the first time that the collars had been used in both directions on the same day since the so-called circuit-breakers were put into effect in the wake of the market crash of 1987.
The sharp turns in stock prices followed a similar move in the bond market, where prices headed higher in early afternoon. Analysts cited a stronger-than-expected auction of 10-year United States Government notes in the bond market's reversal. Some also mentioned the Federal Reserve Board's release of its beige book survey of the economy, which said the economy's continued strong growth last month brought with it only moderate signs of rising inflation. [Page D4.]
In the end, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell below 7 percent for the first time in four days, finishing at 6.96 percent. The Dow industrials, meanwhile, which were down more than 78 points at one juncture, ended the day with a gain of 53.11 points, at 5,474.06.
But if professional traders are uncertain about the markets' direction, individual investors appear steadfast, at least when it comes to stocks. According to estimates released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, cash flow into equity mutual funds in April totaled $23 billion, up slightly from March and the second-highest total ever.
Bond funds, meanwhile, recorded no net gain or loss in assets last month, the trade group estimated.
Those cash flows, of course, reflect in part money committed to mutual funds before the April 15 tax deadline, and some companies that track mutual fund cash flows have reported that inflows slowed late last month and in early May. In the meantime, market gurus at some of Wall Street's biggest investment banks have grown increasingly cautious.
For example, Byron Wien, a closely watched investment strategist at Morgan Stanley, recently penned a report titled "The Coming 1,000 Point Decline," a prophecy that, if true, would result in a fall of nearly 20 percent in the Dow industrials.
And Barton Biggs, Morgan Stanley's global strategist, startled Wall Street on Monday with his recommendation that investors take a smidgen of their international holdings and invest in gold, the traditional haven of inflation-hedging pessimists.
Some market observers saw in yesterday's trading activity a clear rejection of that bearishness, which appeared to be gaining speed after four straight declines in the Dow industrials.
Ralph Acampora, a technical analyst at Prudential Securities, said that traders were closely watching the Dow as it moved below 5,400 yesterday. The bellwether index last closed below that level on Feb. 2.
As a technical analyst, Mr. Acampora tries to forecast the stock market's direction based on past levels of prices, volume and other market indicators. When the bond market started to move higher, he said, buyers quickly appeared for stocks that had been beaten down in recent sessions.
"That tempered the bearishness that has been building up for several days," Mr. Acampora said. "I think this will serve as the bottom for more sustained advance in stock prices later on."
Mike Niedermeyer, chief investment officer at Wells Fargo Investment Management, which manages $56 billion in mutual funds and similar accounts, took similar solace in the economic data from the Federal Reserve. "The risk of rates going up from here is very diminished," he said.
"We've felt that while the economy is on strong footing, it's not that strong," Mr. Niedermeyer said, adding that long-term rates should fall back below 6.5 percent by the end of the year.
Other market indicators also reversed course yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index finished the day up 6.52 points, or 1.02 percent, at 644.78, a gain slightly stronger than that of the Dow. The Nasdaq composite index rose a mere 0.59 point, to 1,183.57, however, as technology stocks had a more difficult time recovering from an early selloff.
Yesterday's volatility was the most extreme example of a tendency for wide short-term swings that the stock market has exhibited all year. So far, individual investors have been unshaken by the trend, a fact further amplified by the mutual fund cash flow estimates released yesterday.
For the fourth consecutive month, equity mutual funds took in more than $20 billion in new money. Before this year, monthly flows into stock funds had never reached the $20 billion level. The $23 billion April total was up from $20.5 billion in March, and the Investment Company Institute estimated that most of the growth came from greater flows to global and international funds.
And while bond funds recorded neutral flows last month, that continued a slowing trend in place for two months -- one that probably owes less to the recent decline in bond prices than to the strong performance of stock funds, many of which are outperforming the S.& P. 500 this year, as opposed to last year, when most stock funds trailed that benchmark.

HEADLINE: Leelanau County Journal
<HEADLINE>When Winter's Grip Wouldn't Let Go

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

DATELINE: LELAND, Mich., May 8

 BODY:
Each fall, the weekly Leelanau Enterprise promises $100 to the reader who comes closest to estimating the final winter snowfall on this peninsula famed for its breathtaking views of Lake Michigan and miles of cherry orchards.
On April 25, 34-year-old Donna Thomas was declared the victor with a guess of 217 3/4 inches, 70 inches higher than normal. Winter, though, was not yet over. Six days later it snowed 4 inches more, bringing the official total in Leelanau (pronounced LEE-lan-awe) County to 231 inches, surpassing the previous record by two feet. 
 "Everybody was fine until those last couple of snows," said Wendy VerSnyder, a clerk at the newspaper. "We've all had enough."
With weeks of zero and below-zero temperatures, and snow that often falls at the rate of a foot a day, Leelanau and its neighboring counties in northwestern Michigan are accustomed to hard winters and chilly, reluctant springs. Normally, though, April means putting away the boots and heavy coats, and early May's warm winds prompt lakeside homeowners to put their boat docks in the water.
Not this year. Beginning with the first snow in late October, people in this region of farms and forests near the northern end of Lake Michigan have endured six straight months of snow, ice and shivering.
On May 1, motorists were still brushing snow off their windshields.
Grand Traverse Bay, on the east side of Leelanau County, froze over on Feb. 3, and did not melt until April 20, the longest frozen stretch in 70 years, according to the Coast Guard.
In Antrim County, a record 245 inches of snow fell, seven feet more than normal. "It's been a lot of battle fatigue," said Fred Hunt Jr., the manager of the Antrim County Road Commission, describing the mood of his 35 snowplow drivers. "It was constant pounding. They even got tired of the overtime."
Just about the only people not complaining are the ski resort owners. The long season and Michigan's surging economy are credited with helping to shatter every record for customers and revenue. As late as Sunday, as daytime temperatures fell again to the 30's, the slopes remained open at Boyne Mountain in Charlevoix County, capping the longest ski season in the resort's 48-year history.
Even old-timers have marveled. "In 1921 or 1922 we had a heck of a snow in April. It blocked the railroad for six weeks," said Edward Kahrs, an 89-year-old retired farmer who has lived in Leelanau County his entire life. "That's about the last time I can recall any winter this long."
The unforgiving winter is part of an unusual period of erratic weather in the upper Midwest. Last summer, near-record heat turned normally frigid northern Lake Michigan so warm that swimming in it was actually enjoyable, residents say. The colors of fall, usually a palette of brilliance, were muted and short-lived as temperatures plunged below freezing in October, weeks earlier than usual. The cold air and warm water combined to produce blizzards of "lake effect" snow in November and December.
Climatologists say the jet stream in the upper atmosphere is the source of the severe weather, especially during this lost spring. Normally, the jet stream begins to move north by March or April, bringing with it warming temperatures. This year, it remained fixed well south of the Great Lakes.
The talk on the street is that global warming, ozone depletion or the Pacific phenomenon known as El Nino is producing the unusual weather.
Michigan's climate specialists say that El Nino is not a culprit and that there is no way to confirm whether man-made global environmental influences are involved.
"What we know for sure," said Dr. Fred Nurnberger, the state climatologist, "is that until the jet stream moves north, we will have below-normal temperatures."
It has been so cold that the usual harbingers of spring have been three weeks late. Morel mushrooms, a regional delicacy coveted for their flavor and meaty texture, have not yet popped up among the matted leaves on the forest floor. Only in the last day or so have the buds on the cherry trees begun to swell. Even the bees at Kirk Jones's Sleeping Bear Apiaries in Benzie County, south of here, were not flying until after May 1. "It was too chilly in April for the flowers to open," Mr. Jones said.
So alternative messengers of spring sufficed. The ice fishing shacks were hauled off Crystal Lake in Beulah, although the ice did not melt completely until April 19. Like the return of the swallows to Capistrano, the seasonal restaurant owners came back. Jim Barnes, who spent the winter in Australia, has been cleaning out Northern Delights Cafe, his hilltop restaurant in Benzonia, in time for opening to the summer trade later this week. Down the hill, Jonathan Clark returned from Texas to reopen his L'Chayim Delicatessen, serving corn beef and pastrami to overflow crowds.
"I have traditionally opened the first day of May, and this year we had three inches of snow," said Mr. Clark, who was raised in Benzie County and is nursing a bad spring cold. "That will tell you one reason why I want to go back to Texas.
"It's been lousy."

HEADLINE: Down 78 Before Noon, Up 53.11 at Close

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks rebounded sharply late yesterday in a rally touched off by a drop in interest rates.
After tumbling as much as 78.39 points before noon, the Dow Jones industrial average closed up 53.11 points, to 5,474.06. 
 The New York Stock Exchange said that yesterday's session was the first time it had ever invoked both uptick and downtick rules in the same session. The rules, which take effect when the Dow rises or falls 50 points, limit some computer-guided trading in an attempt to stabilize the market.
Among the broader indexes, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.52 points, to 644.78, and the Nasdaq composite index edged up 0.76 point, to 1,183.43.
The stock market took its cue yesterday from the bond market, where surging prices drove the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- an important benchmark for interest rates -- down below the psychologically important level of 7 percent, to 6.95 percent from 7.07 percent on Tuesday. The rally in bond prices, which move in opposite directions from yields, was prompted by a stronger-than-expected Treasury auction of new 10-year notes.
The drop in yields helped bank and other financial issues pace the stock market's recovery. Shares of J. P. Morgan rose 1 5/8, to 84 3/8, and American Express gained 1 3/4, to 47 7/8, helping lead the Dow industrials' advance.
"Investors are clearly worried about inflation, but most don't understand what they're looking at," said Philip J. Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management. "There is no inflation in this economy."
Banks in particular benefit from declining yields because they let them pay less to depositors. Nationsbank rose 1 7/8, to 79 1/8; Banc One rose 7/8, to 34 1/8, and Wells Fargo jumped 3 1/4, to 237 3/4.
Semiconductor issues were mixed in anticipation of a report, subsequently delayed until today, that is expected to show demand for computer chips remained weak in April. Intel rose 7/8, to 68 3/4, while Motorola was unchanged at to 61 1/4, and Atmel lost 1 1/4, to 38 1/2. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index of 16 stocks rose 1.21 points, to 208.86.
Mr. Orlando of Value Line said the outlook for technology stocks was good. Microsoft and Intel will have new products this summer. Microsoft will offer new Windows software while Intel will offer a new version of its Pentium chip.
Microsoft jumped 1 1/8, to 114 1/4; Cisco Systems rose 1/2, to 52 3/4, and Hewlett-Packard fell 1/4, to 103 3/4.
America Online slumped after the company disclosed a pricing plan that some analysts said could cut into future profits. The stock fell 5, to 65.
Associates First Capital, a unit of Ford Motor, jumped 5 3/4, to 35 3/4, in its first day of trading. Shares of Ford Motor fell 1/4, to 35 3/4.
Another initial public offering, Nova, climbed 10 1/8, to 29 1/8.
Eastman Kodak contributed 5.7 points, the most of any company, to the rise in the Dow industrials, as shareholders gathered for the company's annual meeting in Rochester. Kodak rose 2, to 75 7/8.
Equitable rose 1/4, to 23 1/8, after it reported first-quarter earnings that were better than expected.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Offers A Fresh Budget With New Cuts

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Discarding the financial plan he submitted only three months ago, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his 1997 budget would eliminate many of the financial gimmicks and overly optimistic assumptions that led to repeated criticisms from fiscal monitors in the first half of his term.
But the price of what he called his "more realistic" budget, to be unveiled today, was steep: significant new spending cuts by city agencies that have already endured two years of reductions, and a retreat from most of the tax cuts the Mayor proposed on Jan. 31. 
 As a result, the Mayor told a small group of reporters, the yawning deficits projected for the end of the century, which had reached more than $5 billion, have now been cut in half.
Mr. Giuliani's statements yesterday were an acknowledgment that those deficits have now become his paramount fiscal priority, well above his desire to cut property and income taxes. And with his third annual budget, one that takes him into an election year, the Mayor suggested for the first time that he has begun to listen to the complaints from budget monitors and bond raters.
"It seemed to me with the criticisms of the monitors and the rating agencies, it made much more sense to take out some level of tax reduction that wasn't going to happen anyway, to create a better effect on structural balance," he said.
Unlike the preliminary financial plan he proposed in January, the 1997 budget will contain much smaller estimates of state and Federal aid, and will not rely on gimmicks that cannot be repeated in future years, like selling the city's parking meters for a quick infusion of cash. January's ambitious package of tax cuts has been reduced by 75 percent, meaning among other things that the 12.5 percent income tax surcharge may no longer expire at the end of the year. As well, city agencies will have to cut another $450 million from their spending, on top of the $691 million estimated earlier.
The details of the $32 billion budget will not be released until today. But based on the sketchy information issued yesterday, it appears that his new budget is much more likely to be be greeted favorably by fiscal watchdogs than his previous efforts.
"If all this comes to pass, he'll get a strong congratulations from us," said Raymond B. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a business-financed group that has often criticized Mr. Giuliani's financial planning. "We'll have to see the details, of course, but we may be able to say that we're very pleased he's seen the light, albeit a bit slowly."
The nature of the new cuts, however, remains unknown, and they could affect city services in a way that would lead to more criticism. Mr. Giuliani promised yesterday that spending for child welfare and education would be increased. And as he has for two years, the Mayor said his spending cuts would not affect city services. A survey by The New York Times last fall, however, found that many residents and civic organizations believe that city services have been reduced.
In his first two years, Mr. Giuliani, like most recent mayors, used a variety of one-time cash infusions, or one-shots, to get himself through the year's budget. The practice is roundly criticized by fiscal monitors here and in other cities because it does not solve the underlying deficit, allowing it to grow each year.
The Mayor's January financial plan included six one-shots for 1997 that would bring in $300 million -- including selling the city's parking meters, the Brooklyn Army Terminal and a variety of vacant lots.
Administration officials said yesterday that all six of those one-shots would be dropped in the 1997 budget. Several cash infusions that have drawn criticism will be in the budget, though the administration does not consider them gimmicks.
The city, for example, is moving ahead on a plan to borrow $500 million over 30 years and give it to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in exchange for $250 million in cash this year. It plans to spend $207 million from the sale of WNYC-TV for operating expenses. There are also likely to be assumptions in the budget on pension savings that may not happen, and back rent for the two city airports which may not be paid.
In previous years, the city has also relied on overly optimistic forecasts of state and federal aid, only to cut spending later in the year when those forecasts didn't prove accurate. For the 1996 budget, for instance, the administration first counted on nearly $1 billion in state aid, including $700 million in cuts to the city's share of state health care and welfare spending. The city received only a third of that amount.
In January, Mr. Giuliani estimated that the city would get $750 million in similar savings from the state next year, a figure that fiscal monitors immediately called unrealistic. Yesterday, the Mayor said that figure had been trimmed to $300 million, one of the lowest assumptions of state aid in recent years.
"When you look at the budget from the point of view of how is it viewed by the rating agencies and the monitors, there'll be much more reliance on actual cuts in government, and much less reliance on state aid," the Mayor said. "This is probably the least amount of reliance on state aid the city has ever had, which, given the fact that there isn't a state budget still, seems like the most prudent thing to do."
The Mayor said forcefully that he remains committed to carefully targeted tax reductions in order to stimulate the economy and noted that he had earlier cut the hotel tax and the commercial rent tax, reductions that remain in effect. But 1997 was to have been the year when the tax cuts began to directly affect city residents, rather than tourists and businesses. The 12.5 percent personal income tax surcharge was to have expired at the end of 1996, the sales tax on clothing purchases under $500 was to be dropped, and the property tax on co-ops and condos was to have been reduced.
The deficit has drastically changed those plans. The Mayor said yesterday that the co-op and condo tax reduction would be deferred for at least a year, the clothing sales tax would be cut in half rather than dropped, and the income tax surcharge would continue, pending state approval. Those tax cuts, he said, were more ambitious than realistic.
"I knew we weren't going to enact all of those, but the more aggressive I make the number, the better chance I have of doing many of them," he said, adding that the sales tax cut would stimulate the economy more than the income tax cut, possibly producing more revenue for the city.
He also acknowledged that proposal by the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, to use the income tax surcharge for rebuilding schools had proved too popular in Albany to stop, so he decided to include it in his budget. He refused to commit himself to using the money for school rebuilding, however, saying the subject will be negotiated with Mr. Vallone before being submitted to the State Legislature.

HEADLINE: Peace Plan for Liberia Seeks to Demilitarize the Capital

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ACCRA, Ghana, May 8

 BODY:
West African leaders, in a last-ditch attempt to avert full-scale civil war in Liberia, approved a sweeping peace plan today that is intended to demilitarize the capital, Monrovia, and restore the country's fractured governing council.
Liberia's four principal militias grudgingly approved the plan, which calls for an immediate cease-fire, the removal of weapons and ammunition from the capital, and the return of an estimated $20 million worth of vehicles and equipment looted from international relief agencies in Monrovia in a month of fighting. 
 To help achieve this, the committee of the Economic Community of West African States called for the restoration of Roosevelt Johnson, a militia leader and former Minister of Rural Development, to his Cabinet post. Mr. Johnson's chief adversary, Charles Taylor, a deputy chairman of the governing council and initiator of the civil war in 1989, said his group would accept Mr. Johnson's reinstatement.
[Fighting resumed today in Monrovia, and aid workers returning to the city after fleeing the violence said they feared an outbreak of cholera, The Associated Press reported.]
Momolu Sirleaf, Liberia's Foreign Minister and a Taylor appointee, said: "We have all paid a terrible price for this fighting. We underestimated the volatility of the situation, and all of the players have suffered."
If many involved in Liberia's peace effort came out of today's meetings with renewed initiative, for others the new plan's weaknesses loom as large as its objectives.
Once those objectives are met, the plan calls for Liberia's Council of State to organize elections, which delegates here said would choose a new government this year based on proportional representation.
The plan also calls for stronger international support for the demoralized and underequipped 8,500-member West African peacekeeping force in Liberia.
Diplomats said today that Belgium and Denmark had offered to pay for additional peacekeeping battalions from Ghana and Burkina Faso, which has not so far taken part. The United States reiterated its willingness to provide as much as $30 million in new support, which would be used for equipment and training.
Particularly bitter criticism of the United States was expressed at the meetings here by West African leaders. Because Liberia was founded in 1822 by freed American slaves, there has always been a connection between the countries, but many in West Africa consider that Washington has been uninvolved in the crisis, other than in providing relief shipments and some financial aid. Unless it becomes more deeply involved, the West Africans and many Liberians say, no settlement can work.
While various aspects of the plan will be overseen by different agencies, the real teeth in it may come as much from an implicit threat by the region to abandon Liberia. Participants in the two-day meeting here said that could happen in July, when leaders of the Economic Community of West African States meet again, if by that time the country's militias have not cooperated fully.
"Few of us are prepared to spend time and resources on conferences on the same subject time and again," said Ghana's President, Jerry John Rawlings, who is chairman of the group.
Explaining the absence of several heads of state who had been expected here, Mr. Rawlings said: "The sub-region has grown tired of this issue. We should be grateful that so many high-level delegations have decided to come."
The meetings were conducted at the foreign minister level by the 16-member committee, made up of representatives of nine countries.
By repudiating the model of a collective presidency, the foreign ministers who worked out the settlement cast heavy responsibilities on Wilton S. Sankawulo, a grammarian who is the nominal chairman of Liberia's governing council.
Since taking office in September, Mr. Sankawulo has been seen by many observers as ineffectual, and since the start of the latest crisis, there has been a growing perception that he is controlled by Mr. Taylor.
Mr. Sankawulo reinforced that impression in a rambling speech to the conference today in which he made an unambiguous attack on Mr. Johnson and militia leaders who have supported him in the fighting.
A dismayed Ghanaian diplomat said of Mr. Sankawulo: "This man lives with Taylor, he is fed by Taylor, and he even gets his pocket money from Taylor. By his very speech he has made clear that he is not the kind of person the situation calls for. We are going to have a very hard time ahead."
By relying on the peacekeepers to play a greater role in enforcing the peace in Liberia, the plan also glosses over the force's own role in precipitating the crisis.
In the weeks that led up to the fighting, diplomats say the peacekeepers seemed to wink as Mr. Taylor and allied militia leaders moved weapons and fighters into Monrovia.
When the fighting began, the peacekeeping force, which had repelled fierce offensives against the capital in the past, melted away from its positions, and its members often watched complacently as the city was overrun with fighters and given over to wholesale looting.
For many, the latest unrest in Liberia has its roots in fighting between Nigerian units in the peacekeeping force and Mr. Johnson's faction over control of diamond fields near the town of Tubmanburg.
Most of all, however, the peace plan fails to explain how the atmosphere of venomous distrust separating one militia from another, and some of the factions from the peacekeeping force, can be cleared.
Nowhere was this distrust more apparent than in the attitude of Mr. Johnson, who appeared not to be mollified by the offers to reinstate him. After the latest fighting, Mr. Johnson said that to entrust his security to the West African peacekeeping force was tantamount to accepting the slaughter of his own men.
Referring to a previous peace plan, he said: "Last year these very same diplomats gave us a formula, and that formula has failed. Now, rather than honestly looking at the reasons for the failure, they are saying, 'Hey, guys, go back and apply the same formula.' They might as well be saying, 'Go back and fight it out.' "

HEADLINE: In New 6-Year Budget Plan With Gentler Reductions, Republicans Ease Toward Center

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans moved toward the moderate center in the balanced-budget debate today, offering a new six-year plan to erase the Federal deficit that assumes a far smaller tax cut and gentler reductions in popular programs than they had demanded even six months ago.
Many of the plan's major proposals for savings are close or identical to those in a compromise budget-balancing plan that 20 moderate Republicans and Democrats released last week, and that President Clinton has praised. 
 The Republicans also bowed to Mr. Clinton's position on an important part of the politically sensitive Medicare program, accepting a decline in insurance premiums that automatically took place last year even as the program's cost mushroomed. Republicans had sought last year to hold premiums at what was then their current level.
Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader and presumptive Republican Presidential candidate, called the plan "a very reasonable and very responsible budget which will be in balance by 2002."
Of the President, he added, "We think it's one he might be inclined to accept."
That said, the proposal also resembles in some ways the last budget deal that Republicans offered, and Mr. Clinton rejected, in negotiations that collapsed in February.
Indeed, the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, issued a statement later today saying the new proposal "looks like more of the same," and calling the spending levels for Medicare and other benefit programs unacceptable. He again called for new budget talks between Mr. Clinton and Congressional leaders.
At least one Republican principal in the earlier talks, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, said that even if the two sides could agree on the savings in specific programs, they were worlds apart in their ideas of what policy changes were needed to make those savings occur.
Mr. Kasich, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, said the Republican proposal sought to take Federal control of welfare, Medicare, education and other major programs and "send it home" to the states and to individuals. By contrast, he said, Mr. Clinton's budget seeks to preserve those powers in the Federal bureaucracy.
"I don't know how you reach agreement when the level of disagreement is over whether you trust people or not," he said.
The new Republican plan is the starting point for the 1997 budget that Congress intends to write and send to Mr. Clinton by fall. It proposes to cut $77 billion from domestic discretionary programs like road building and environmental protection. Defense spending would rise by a total of $13 billion from the current year's level.
Spending on welfare and benefit programs like Medicare and Medicaid would still grow, sometimes sharply, but the rise would still be smaller than if the programs were left unchanged.
Medicare spending, for example, would increase from $209 billion in 1997 to $279 billion in 2002, but that increase would still save $158 billion over six years. Medicaid spending would be $72 billion less than is now forecast; welfare spending would drop $53 billion below projections.
The Republican plan proposes $122 billion in tax cuts over six years, all of which would be devoted to a $500-a-child tax credit. That compares with $245 billion in tax cuts that the party demanded in legislation that passed Congress last November, and which Mr. Clinton vetoed.
But Mr. Kasich and others made it clear that Congress's tax writing committees would be free to tack on additional tax relief if they could find the money to pay for it by closing tax loopholes. In particular, Mr. Kasich said the legislation that Congress eventually passes would also include a cut in the tax rate on capital gains.
"My feeling is you'll have a gross tax cut that approaches $180 billion -- gross," he said.
Congressional leaders said they stuck, by and large, to the changes in policies that were the foundation of the 1996 budget, and which contributed heavily to the impasse with Mr. Clinton last winter.
The plan still envisions handing most responsibility for welfare programs to the states and ending the Federal entitlement to Medicaid benefits, although Mr. Kasich said the poor would still receive some form of guaranteed medical care.
Like Mr. Clinton's proposal, the plan would further open Medicare to managed care plans like health maintenance organizations; unlike his plan it would give retirees the option of setting up tax-free savings accounts to pay medical bills.
The House version proposes to eliminate both the Energy and Commerce Departments; the Senate would leave Energy somewhat intact. The House proposal would eliminate the Goals 2000 education program and end direct lending to college students by the Federal Government, programs close to Mr. Clinton's heart.
But the plan also addresses some of the Democratic attacks on spending cuts that have cost the Republican Congress dearly in political support. The Senate version would raise spending for space exploration above Mr. Clinton's proposed 1997 level, and raise 1997 spending on two environmental programs, the Superfund hazardous-waste cleanup effort and the Safe Drinking Water Act, by a total of $1.2 billion.
The latest numbers cannot be compared directly with the figures in the budget that Republicans sent to the White House last November, because that proposal spread tax cuts and savings over seven years. The latest plan would take effect a year later and would achieve balance in six years.
Many of the new spending proposals nevertheless are less dramatic than those first offered by Congress last fall, for reasons ranging from calculated politics to pure fate.
The switch from a seven-year to a six-year plan has made it easier to reach balance, because it means that the tax cuts have one less year in which to rack up revenue losses.
Also, a better-than-expected economy has softened the forecasts of welfare spending and bolstered estimates of tax revenues.
Republicans also benefited from their success in cutting spending in this year's budget. Domestic discretionary spending for the year that ends on Sept. 30 will have dropped $20 billion below the previous year, the first such decline in decades; those savings will multiply over the next six years.
"Their spending cuts are lower because they actually accomplished a good deal last year, although nobody seems to have recognized it," Robert O. Reischauer, the Brookings Institution scholar who headed the Congressional Budget Office until 1995, said in an interview.
Mr. Reischauer said he was familiar with the broad outlines of the latest proposal. "It's a credible means of achieving their objective of a balanced budget," he said. "But it would be more credible if the tax cuts were scaled back and their assumed reductions in discretionary spending were moderated."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economic Expansion Is Solid, Fed Survey Finds
The economy picked up at a moderate pace in March and April, a survey by the Federal Reserve found, more evidence that expansion is generally solid again, except in the New York area. Furthermore, price increases were subdued, the central bank said.
The Conference Board said its index of economic indicators edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in March, less than February's eight-tenths of 1 percent gain. [Page D4.]
 
Buffett Seeks to Sell USAir Stake
Warren E. Buffett, who has already written down Berkshire Hathaway's $358 million investment in USAir, now wants USAir to buy back his investment company's 10 percent stake. Barring that, he said, he would look for other buyers. The carrier did not comment. Separately, Berkshire Hathaway increased the offering of its new class B common stock to 450,000 shares from 350,000 and priced them at $1,100 apiece. [D5.]
 
America Online Earnings Rise
America Online announced third-quarter earnings that exceeded Wall Street expectations, a rise to nearly six million subscribers and a new partnership in Japan. Even so, its stock fell $7.25 to $62.75. [D2.]
 
Swiss-French Merger Is Planned
A $2.3 billion merger to create the world's largest temporary-help company, surpassing Manpower, was agreed to by Adia S.A. of Switzerland and Ecco S.A. of France. [D6.]
 
Stocks Rebound as Rates Fall
Stocks recovered sharply in late trading, thanks to a drop in interest rates. Bank stocks led the advance. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 53.11 points, to 5,474.06, rebounding from a slide of 78.39 points before noon. The Nasdaq composite index edged up 0.59 point, to 1,183.27. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities surged, sending the yield on the long bond below the psychologically important 7 percent barrier to 6.95 percent. An auction of new 10-year notes received strong demand. [D19.]
 
G.E. and United in Joint Venture
General Electric and United Technologies are putting aside their rivalry for one project -- joint development of an engine for a new, larger model of Boeing's 747 aircraft. The partnership was prompted by the $1 billion-plus investment needed for an engine. [D21.]
 
Drug-Pricing Settlement Advances
A Federal judge gave preliminary approval to an amended $351 million settlement of a lawsuit over pricing by the biggest drug companies, but analysts said consumers were unlikely to see major price changes right away. Retail drug stores had complained that they were charged more than H.M.O.'s. [D2.]
 
Market for Contemporary Art is Hot
The market for contemporary art has not only bounced back from its 1990 collapse; it is running a fever. At Christie's auction on Tuesday night, sales reached $15.2 million, and two works -- one by Willem de Kooning and one by Jackson Pollock -- topped the $1 million mark. Mr. de Kooning's "Mailbox," a 1948 painting, fetched $3.7 million. [C16.]
 
'Crazy Eddie' Antar Enters Guilty Plea
Eddie Antar, the co-founder of the giant "Crazy Eddie" discount electronics stores who was arrested in 1992 in Israel, pleaded guilty to a single Federal charge that he had defrauded shareholders of more than $74 million. His previous convictions on a number of charges were overturned by an appeals court. He could serve three to five years in prison beyond his four years already served. [D8.]
 
Conviction a First for the S.E.C.
A Florida executive has been convicted in what the Securities and Exchange Commission called the first criminal case involving a scheme to avoid registering securities under Regulation S, which governs sales to foreigners. [D8.]
 
Drug-Free Ads With an Edge
In a new television ad, the Partnership for a Drug-Free America juxtaposes a graduate with a crackhead -- a "man"-"slave" comparison that gives the spot an edge. Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Fewer File First Claims for Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
The number of first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 12,000 last week to the lowest level in four months, the Labor Department said today. New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 336,000, down from 348,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, when claims fell by 24,000.
Last week's total is the smallest number of new claims since 316,000 were filed in the week that ended on Jan. 13, when the blizzard along the East Coast and severe weather elsewhere kept many laid-off workers from visiting unemployment offices. 
 Many analysts had expected a slight increase last week to about 355,000. They contend the current range of claims indicates modest job growth.
The Labor Department earlier reported that after jumping to 624,000 in February, the number of new jobs slipped to 140,000 in March and just 2,000 last month.
The four-week moving average of new weekly jobless claims fell by 3,500, to 353,750, from 357,250 the previous week. The latest total is the lowest since the average was 348,250 during the period ended last Sept. 2.

HEADLINE: Prices and Hopes Rise As Spring Art Auctions Reveal a Robust Market

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
The 1996 spring auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art in Manhattan will not be remembered for their high prices. Nor will many blockbuster paintings stand out in anyone's mind. Still, these sales have made a significant impression on the art world because of the increase in the number and enthusiasm of buyers at every level.
Even the market for contemporary art, which has been trying desperately to pull itself out of a five-year slump, got a big boost this week. 
 Call it a pent-up desire to spend money, a decision that the time is right to invest in art again or simply a positive feeling about the economy -- whatever the reason, the percentages of art that sold at every auction were higher than either Sotheby's or Christie's had seen since the art market soured at the end of 1990. And for the first time in five years, the middle range of the market was suddenly hot.
This was quite a change from the last two seasons, when buyers were so discerning that only the top end -- the priciest works, with a pristine past -- was desirable. Those works that did not pass the test would, more often than not, remain unsold. But as the buying pool grew this spring, so did the price range of the art that was bought.
"Now, there is a market for everything, if it is estimated properly," said Christopher Burge, chairman of Christie's in New York. "There's definitely more confidence in the market."
Diana D. Brooks, chief executive officer of Sotheby's worldwide, agreed. "There's clearly a desire to buy art, and this season there were a lot of new buyers."
Maybe the overheated prices at the recent Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis sales at Sotheby's made art buyers stop and think: after watching a set of golf clubs sell for more than $700,000, and a rocking chair bring nearly $500,000, perhaps an Impressionist painting for under $500,000 suddenly seemed reasonable.
"It's true that a lot of attention was drawn to the art market as a result of the Onassis sale," Mrs. Brooks said. She also reported that several buyers from the Onassis sale, who were new to Sotheby's, came and bid at its Impressionist and modern sales.
In taking stock of the last two weeks, art experts were quick to point out that the market was performing in a traditionally cyclical fashion. "We're mid-cycle," said Mr. Burge, who predicted that the market, which hit bottom in 1991, could reach another peak in about three years.
Even the buyers are beginning to form a predictable pattern. This season, for the first time in five years, buyers from Asia were supporting the Impressionist and modern art sales. At the Christie's sale, 16 percent of the buyers were Asian; at Sotheby's the following evening, that grew to 20 percent. But in contrast to the boom years of the late 1980's, when Asians often paid gigantic prices for second-rate works, this season's buyers tended to bid with a fair amount of caution.
Gone are the Asian dealers investing in mid-range Impressionist paintings as though they were cashing in a speculative stock; while dealers were still bidding, both auction houses said the dealers tended to be working on behalf of collectors. Japanese collectors still tended to dominate the Asian buying, as they had during the late 1980's, but this season there were also bidders and buyers from Indonesia, Korea, Singapore and Malasia, countries experiencing an economic boom.
Impressionist paintings have long been popular in Asia. At Sotheby's, the evening's most expensive work, Monet's "Grain Stacks at Giverny, Morning Light" (1889), went to an unidentified Asian buyer for $7.1 million, just above its $7 million high estimate.
(Final prices include the auction house's commission, 15 percent of the first $50,000 plus 10 percent of the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.)
As a whole, Impressionist paintings sold more solidly than they have in years, but prices tended to hover around their estimates. At Christie's, David Nahmad, a Manhattan dealer, bought Monet's "Contarini Palace" (1908), a view of the Venetian palace with its reflection in the Grand Canal, for $4.2 million, just above its $4 million low estimate.
Many bidders at Christie's also fought to own Monet's "Charing Cross Bridge," which finally fetched $3.9 million, above its high estimate of $3.5 million. At Sotheby's, Vuillard's "Square Berlioz (La Place Vintimille)," a 64-by-90-inch painting of a small square seen from the artist's balcony in Paris, sold to David Tunick, the Manhattan dealer, for $3 million, right at its low estimate.
This season's most expensive painting was also bought by a dealer. James Roundell, from London, bidding on behalf of a client, purchased van Gogh's "Interior of a Restaurant" (1887-1888) for $10.3 million, right at Christie's estimate. The painting had belonged to the Danforth family from Rhode Island and had been in private hands for generations.
Such multimillion-dollar sales were harder to come by at the contemporary art auctions. But if a painting, drawing or sculpture was well priced, bidders were hungry to buy it.
And buy they did, often at prices well above the works' estimates. Of the two auction houses, Christie's had a leaner sale, with only two paintings selling for more than $1 million. Both were new to the market. Topping its sale, held on Tuesday night, was Willem de Kooning's "Mailbox," a 1948 gem, which sold to an unidentified American collector bidding by telephone for $3.7 million, above its $3 million high estimate. Christie's sale totaled $15.2 million, in the middle of its $13.2 million-to-$17 million estimate. Of the 46 works offered, 9 failed to sell.
Sotheby's offered five paintings with prices above $1 million, but three of them did not find buyers. "We were disappointed," Mrs. Brooks said. "But some of these works had been offered around. On other works, there were still many strong prices."
Sotheby's sale, held on Wednesday night, brought a total of $13.4 million, below its $23 million-to-$31 million estimate. Of the 59 works for sale, 14 did not find buyers. The evening's biggest disappointment came when de Kooning's "Woman as Landscape" (1954-55) failed to sell. Bidding never passed $4.9 million, way under its estimated price of $6 million to $8 million. Works by Franz Kline and Jasper Johns also failed to sell.
But when something was fresh and priced right, buyers responded. Gorky's "Study for Agony" from 1947, for instance, sold to an unidentified bidder for $2.4 million, just under its $2.5 million low estimate.
The property that outshone everything else at Sotheby's on Wednesday night was the group of 17 works from the estate of Helen W. Benjamin, a New York philanthropist. Sixteen sold, many for well above their estimates. Among the highlights were Kline's "Acute Accent," a 1957 black-and-white abstract painting, which sold to a telephone bidder for $717,500, just below its $800,000 low estimate, and Agnes Martin's "Tree," a 1964 grid painting, which sold for $525,000, well above its $350,000 high estimate and a record price for the artist.
Because contemporary art collectors tend to be younger, estates like the Benjamin one are rare. "But when you do get one, there are often 10 bidders for every lot," Mrs. Brooks said. "People go crazy for estate property."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Monet's "Grain Stacks at Giverny, Morning Light," which sold for $7.1 million, was the most expensive work at Sotheby's Impressionist sale. (Sotheby's)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Yield Climbs Back Over 7% On Long Bond

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Concerns that new price data will show a pickup in inflation dragged down Treasury prices yesterday, pushing the yield on the long bond back above 7 percent.
A report on jobless claims caused more jitters for a market already nervous about inflation. The Labor Department said that the number of Americans filing for state unemployment benefits for the first time fell 12,000 last week, to 336,000 -- the lowest level since the week that ended Jan. 13. The report reminded market participants a day before the Government reports on producer prices in April that labor and inflation pressures had not faded. 
 James Padinha, an economist with MMS International, San Francisco, said a substantial increase in the cost of gasoline during April could be reflected in today's Producer Price Index and next week's Consumer Price Index, which may ratchet up the market's fears about inflation.
"However prepared the market is for the possibility of painful P.P.I. and C.P.I. numbers, it will still wince when the headline figures hit," he said. "But anything more pronounced than only a short-term reaction is probably not justifiable."
Yesterday, the inflation concerns kept many buyers on the sidelines and caused others to sell long maturities and seek refuge in the shorter maturities.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 23/32 , to 8712/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 7.02 percent, from 6.95 percent on Wednesday.
The market received some support from an auction of 36-day cash management bills, which saw strong investor demand. The Treasury sold $13 billion of the bills at an average rate of 5.05 percent. Cash management bills are sold to meet the Treasury's short-term borrowing needs beyond the money raised through the Government's regularly scheduled auctions.
In bond futures trading, which can affect cash market trading, "the technicals look pretty clear-cut," said Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research of Boston.
"The market looks biased to trade between a price of 10731/32 and 1078/32 on the June bond futures contract," she said. "A caveat would be if the market tries to break and reverse the pivotal 1088/32 level and that would trigger a further rally up to 1092/32 to 11/32 ."
Yesterday, the June bond futures contract hit a day session high of 10812/32 , with the low set at 10717/32 , as it closed at 10718/32 .
In the corporate bond market, the Chrysler Financial Corporation, through its Premier Auto Trust 1996-2, sold $1.5 billion of asset-backed securities in four parts through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. The issue is backed by automobile loan receivables.
The $300 million class A-1 issue was not reoffered to the public but retained by Chrysler while the $735 million A-2 class, which has an average life of 0.96 years was price to yield 5 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- more than the one-month London interbank offered rate, or Libor, which was about 5.44 percent by late in the day. The Libor is the rate that large international banks charge each other for loans in dollars.
A $435 million A-3 class, with an average life of 2.07 years was priced to yield 6.45 percent, or about 32 basis points more than a two-year Treasury note. For $264.4 million of an A-4 class with an average life of three years, the yield was 34 basis points more than a Treasury three-year note.
The class A securities are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's and Duff & Phelps.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark's One-Day Rally Fades, Improving Value of the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher yesterday, deriving strength from a selloff in the mark that traders attributed largely to profit taking from a short-lived rebound.
Ambiguous comments from the German central bank's chief economist about the risks of creating a single European currency by the end of the decade may also have contributed to mark weakness and dollar strength, some dealers said. 
 In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.5200 marks, up from 1.5163 on Wednesday. The dollar traded at 104.72 Japanese yen, down from 105.20 yen. The British pound eased to $1.5231 from $1.5235.
The mark had risen sharply on Wednesday and early yesterday after some members of the policy-making council of the central bank, the Bundesbank, said that the currency's gradual depreciation had run its course and that interest rates were not likely to fall further. Those remarks were seen as a signal to buy marks.
But the lack of any follow-through comment from senior bank council members about the mark's value helped convince traders it was time to take profits from the currency's rally.
By late afternoon in Europe, they were buying Japanese yen and selling marks. That indirectly helped the dollar against the mark and other European currencies.
"The lack of any Bundesbank remarks helped us recover in the dollar," said Elena Shperling, senior currency trader at the Banco di Sicilia's New York branch.
Although no council member of the German central bank made any market-moving remarks yesterday, some traders said that a speech by its chief economist, Otmar Issing, to the Bavarian state parliament might have contributed to renewed speculation that German rates would come down. Lower rates would weaken demand for marks by making mark-denominated deposits less attractive.
Mr. Issing said high deficits and other financial problems among European Union countries might require a delay in the plan for a single currency. Such a delay might create some leeway for these countries, led by Germany, to lower interest rates in order to combat economic sluggishness.
"It appears to me they could be setting up the market for a rate cut in the near future," said Hugh Walsh, vice president at ING Capital Markets in New York.
