HEADLINE: Market Place;
Without an economic cycle, those high-flying cyclical stocks may be in for a hard landing.

BYLINE: By Reed Abelson 

 BODY:
INVESTORS in cyclical stocks have already discovered significant relief from the recent slide in the stock market. Although the broader market has fallen nearly 3 percent since its peak in mid-February, cyclical stocks have withstood much of the turbulence. So far this year the Morgan Stanley Cyclical Index has climbed 13 percent, compared with a 5 percent gain for the Standard & Poor's 500 Stock Index.
Because the economic picture has improved, the fortunes of cyclical companies like Caterpillar, Ford Motor and Union Carbide, which typically move in tandem with the general economy, have brightened considerably. Wall Street strategists have gone from predicting a possible recession to arguing about how fast the economy is growing. 
 But the Federal Reserve's apparent victory in engineering a soft landing and quick takeoff for the economy may prove less a blessing than many investors expect. While some cyclical stocks should continue to do well as the economy expands, the lack of a cycle may actually make them less attractive. Many have already run up in price and may well serve as a harbinger for a sharp market downturn, Thomas McManus, an investment strategist for Morgan Stanley, contends.
"I'm convinced there will not be a big move in cyclicals," Mr. McManus said. He argues that individual investors considering a bet on cyclical stocks might do well instead to consider traditional growth stocks like American Home Products and Gillette as long-term holdings. "For all but the most sophisticated investors, it's probably not going to be a good time to own cyclicals," he said.
The best way to make money buying cyclical stocks is to scoop them up at or near the bottom of the cycle, Mr. McManus noted, but recognizing such a bottom is nearly impossible for most individuals. Still, those prescient enough to have bought shares of Chrysler at $9 in late 1990, for example, are looking at tremendous gains. "You get one big trade per economic cycle," he explained. "All you have to do is hold your nose and buy them in a recession." By preventing a deep and prolonged recession, the Fed denied investors the opportunity to buy cyclicals at their lows.
To be sure, investors with good timing have been able to make some money by investing in cyclicals, and Mr. McManus sees an opportunity for some further profits. But many of the cyclical stocks that do well at the beginning of an economic expansion, like auto or housing-related stocks, have already recovered nicely and moved on to substantial gains. Chrysler, for example, bottomed at $38.25 in early 1995 before reaching a new high of a shade over $65. It closed yesterday at $64.50, up 37.5 cents.
The lack of a cycle may also hurt some of these companies by encouraging the competition. Companies are far less likely to expand or enter new markets if they are in the throes of an economic downturn or worried about an impending recession. Nissan and Toyota, for example, might not have been as busy as they have introducing new sports utility vehicles if the economic cycle had not been as smooth. "At least a good thing about cycles is it keeps your competitors at bay," Mr. McManus said.
Investors should now be focusing on what Mr. McManus calls late cyclicals, companies that tend to benefit from the last stages of an economic expansion like Champion International, the paper and forest-products company, and Alcoa, by providing manufacturers with raw materials. "It's almost like a relay race," he said, describing the passing of the torch between the two groups. Mr. McManus is also bullish on the Canadian stock market because of the preponderance of Canadian mining, energy and forest-products companies.
If the Canadian market, as measured by Morgan Stanley's own index, does better than the United States market this year, it could also signal a coming stock market decline. Since 1980, the Canadian market has outperformed domestic stocks in only three calendar years -- 1983, 1987, and 1993 -- each of which preceded a rate increase by the Fed and a subsequent stock market drop. This time could be no different, Mr. McManus suggested, noting that late-cycle stocks tend to be the last group of equities to do well before a downturn, although they may hold up better in a decline. Morgan Stanley is forecasting a 1,000-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average, or a roughly 20 percent decline, in the second half of 1996.

HEADLINE: Price Increases: First They Have to Stick

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Dennis Russell, a home builder in San Diego, has been waiting a long time to charge more. The strong interest in the last three homes in his latest project -- 45 tract houses priced at $118,000 each -- seemed like a perfect invitation to add several thousand dollars to the sale price. But he passed up the opportunity.
"Why do that and anger people?" he asked. Maybe next time he will try building similar three-bedroom houses to sell at $125,000, but they will be slightly bigger and fancier. "I'll gingerbread them up and add 100 square feet," he said. "People are awfully resistant to a price increase without some extra value." 
 That stiff resistance to higher prices is showing up across the country, suggesting that despite the recent burst of economic activity and sharply rising grain and oil prices, inflation is unlikely to get much of a foothold. Still, there is a visceral fear that it just might. Many people, watching gasoline prices, are starting to worry whether the relentless rise in inflation that plagued the 1970's and early 1980's can return. Two powerful oil shocks fed the spiraling inflation of those years, and now the rising gasoline prices are making nerves jangle.
But times have changed. When a hint of inflation has shown itself, the Federal Reserve has stepped in, raising interest rates to discourage the credit-based spending that might keep prices rising. Right now, such intervention does not seem necessary, the Fed suggested on Wednesday in its beige book survey of the economy. "We still don't see definitive reports of higher inflation," the report said.
Even without action from the Fed, intense competition is helping to insure abundant resistance to price increases. Grain prices are up, but the Kraft Foods unit of the Philip Morris Companies cut the price of Post Raisin Bran and other cereals by 20 percent this month, hoping to take sales away from competitors. American auto companies raised 1996 model prices by 2.5 percent on average, but rebates are more than offsetting the increases for many vehicles.
Coca-Cola replaced its 16-ounce coke with a 20-ounce version, in the process quietly raising the price for an ounce. But stiff competition has forced the company into discounts that have cut the price of an ounce to below what it was for the 16-ounce bottle, according to Government data. And even as rising petroleum prices make the raw material for plastic more expensive, Rubbermaid Inc., maker of numerous plastic household items, insists that the price of its basic 32 gallon garbage can will remain under $10.
"We are going to resist any price increase, for the garbage can or any other product," said William Pfund, a Rubbermaid vice president. "Consumers have developed a disinflationary mind-set, and they have come to expect more for less."
On Wall Street, a debate is under way between those who say that resistance to price increases will continue to keep inflation low and those who argue that the economy is entering a new phase in which prices will begin to climb higher.
"The basis for a long-term buildup in inflation is already present," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a bond trading firm. "For more than a decade we have seen commodity prices and wages moderate, and now for a decade, we will see commodity prices and wages go up, with each reinforcing the other."
Such concerns, embraced by many stock and bond traders, help explain why some interest rates have risen by as much as a percentage point this year. As the inflation hawks see it, rising grain and energy prices will force Americans to dig deeper into their wallets, prompting workers to press for higher wages. With unemployment already at relatively low levels and the economy going strong, employers will have little choice but to pay more. The spurt in labor costs in the first quarter, rather than being a temporary blip, was just the first of more to come, this argument goes.
Once wages begin to rise, Mr. Jones and others say, employers will be forced to pass along the increases in the form of higher prices, ushering in a new era in which wages and prices chase each other higher and higher.
To be sure, consumer prices -- which have been rising at an annual rate of under 3 percent for the last four years -- may well move a bit higher in the months ahead, mainly in response to the higher gasoline prices. The increases so far could add three-tenths of a percentage point to the national inflation rate, raising it to 3.1 percent, from 2.8 percent in 1995, according to Patrick Jackman, chief of the division at the Bureau of Labor Statistics that plots the monthly changes in the Consumer Price Index.
But many economists are convinced that the spurt in oil prices will not last. And even if it did, they say, such price spikes can no longer be counted on to create the price and wage pressures that in the past have been the sine qua non for spiraling inflation.
"Labor costs remain restrained, rising at the slowest rate in 40 years," said Bruce Steinberg, a Merrill Lynch economist. What's more, he argued, the jump in wages in the first quarter was narrowly based, focused mostly in retailing.
As for higher petroleum prices working their way into other products, Mr. Pfund of Rubbermaid insists his company will hold the line on its plastic cans and kitchenware. Plastic is made from a resin that emerges from a petrochemical product made largely from oil. The price of this raw material soared early last year, partly as a result of temporary plant closings. Rubbermaid, to offset the $200 million increase in its costs, raised the prices of its houseware products by 4 percent in April 1995, the first price increase in five years.
But ever since, Rubbermaid has achieved enough cost savings in other areas, Mr. Pfund said, to avoid further price increases, for the time being, although the price of resin, having fallen sharply late last year, has begun to rise again.
Similarly, the nation's airlines have used the expiration of the 10 percent Federal ticket tax as an opportunity to actually cut fares despite rising aviation fuel prices. Instead of cutting fares back by the full 10 percent, airlines reduced them by only 7 percent, one study showed, keeping the difference to fatten profits and pay higher fuel bills.
In other industries, most attempts to push through higher prices have met with skepticism. The International Paper Company, for example, recently put out a feeler -- an announcement that it would try in June for a $50 a ton increase in the price of linerboard, which is used to make cardboard shipping containers. That was greeted with little enthusiasm at the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation, another big linerboard maker.
"Candidly," said Timothy McKenna, director of investor relations, "there are mixed views as to whether a price increase would be successful."

HEADLINE: What Do Angry Women Want?

BYLINE: By Mary Beth Cahill; Mary Beth Cahill is executive director of Emily's List, a group that supports Democratic women candidates.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Faced with the prospect of a mass desertion by female voters in the fall, some Republicans have acknowledged the gender gap and are trying to do something about it, including softening the hard-right anti-abortion language in the party platform. Not even a wholesale revision of that plank seems likely to help. According to the latest New York Times/CBS Poll, President Clinton currently leads Senator Bob Dole among women by a whopping 18 points.
Democrats may well be feeling complacent. But that would be a mistake. There is a critical bloc of women -- angry, working class and focused on economic issues -- who may aid the Republican cause, as they did in 1994, simply by deciding not to vote. 
 The gender gap will no doubt shrink in the days leading up to the election. Last month, a poll by our group of about 1,000 registered voters found a strong preference for Mr. Clinton among professional women and a similar tilt among suburban women. Even Roman Catholic women supported Mr. Clinton over Mr. Dole by double digits.
Meanwhile, an astonishing 32 percent of women who described themselves as evangelicals said they were thinking of not voting in November.
The potential bright spot for the Republicans is the volatility of voter turnout among women, particularly those who are not college graduates. Indeed, 59 percent of the people who voted in 1992 but abstained in 1994 were women, according to a Democratic Leadership Council poll. There was more than hype to the notion that "angry white men" were the deciding factor in the 1994 Republican rout.
Democrats hope that the "drop-off" voters -- mostly women who did not graduate from college -- will be a boon to them this year. But voter turnout isn't the only question mark. According to a new Emily's List survey due out next week, a third-party candidacy by Ross Perot would undercut Mr. Clinton's margin among these female voters by 14 points, while shaving only seven points from Mr. Dole. Equally important, their support for Mr. Clinton is wide but shallow: 25 percent say they would also consider voting for Mr. Dole. Their support for Congressional Democrats is even shallower, with 36 percent saying they would consider voting Republican.
The volatility of this group stems in part from anger, in part from fear. One year ago, Emily's List conducted focus groups of women who were not college graduates. For the most part, they saw nothing for them in the Republican "revolution" and little more from the Democrats.
The willingness of these voters to turn out for President Clinton depends largely on the Democrats' ability to remind them of the unpopular Republican positions on the environment, education and Medicare. The drop-off voters were repelled by the Republican Congress, but these disaffected voters were also skeptical of the Democrats' ability to improve their lives.
So the Republicans may yet succeed in either luring away drop-off voters or, more likely, in depressing their turnout. If a Democratic message fails to mobilize these easily disappointed voters, it won't be hard to convince them that politics is a dead end and voting is pointless. As a Chicago woman said in one of our focus groups: "Sometimes you feel it just doesn't matter."
If that sentiment prevails, then once again we'll be hearing lots of post-election talk about the "angry white man" -- and little mention of his angry wife and sister, daughter and mother.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: U.S. and North Korea Agree On Joint Search for Missing

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
The United States and North Korea announced today that later this year they expect to begin their first joint effort to search for the remains of thousands of Americans soldiers missing from the Korean War.
The announcement, which could signal a broad improvement in ties between the two countries, means that Pentagon investigators could soon be wandering the North Korean countryside, searching for evidence of the burial sites of Americans missing since the war ended in 1953. 
 Under the agreement, reached after six days of negotiations in New York City, the United States will pay $2 million to North Korea for its earlier efforts to locate the remains of the more than 8,100 Americans and United Nations personnel, most of them Americans, reported missing in the Korea War.
In a joint statement, the United States commended North Korea for "its past sincere efforts in recovering and returning U.S. servicemen's remains," and both countries expressed "their belief that this agreement will contribute to the improvement of relations."
The United States and North Korea first discussed the search for the remains of lost American soldiers in 1987, and the dialogue is scheduled to resume next month when the two countries will discuss details of the joint search. "Both sides expect this meeting will result in joint recovery operations this year," the statement said.
Defense Department officials said today it was unclear how much freedom of movement American investigators would have in the search for burial sites. But any degree of freedom would provide the United States with a remarkable opportunity to gauge economic and political conditions in one of the world's most closed societies.
A similar agreement with the Vietnamese Government several years ago produced a significant diplomatic breakthrough between Washington and Hanoi, with Defense Department investigators allowed to roam the Vietnamese countryside in the search for burial sites. Since 1992, the remains of 110 Americans previously listed as unaccounted for in the Vietnam War have been identified and returned home.
The North Koreans have so far delivered more than 200 sets of American remains across the demilitarized zone separating North and South Korea. Of those, 46 were returned between 1990 and 1992, with the United States paying $897,000 to reimburse the North Koreans for the cost of search and recovery. Another 162 were returned in 1993 and 1994. Only five of those sets of remains have been positively identified.
The North Koreans asked for $4 million for the remains returned in 1993 and 1994, but the United State balked at the figure. The North Koreans are known to be desperate for hard currency, with foreign diplomats posted in North Korea reporting a wealth of anecdotal evidence, including food shortages, that suggests that the country is in an economic crisis.
North Korea has long sought direct talks with the United States on a formal peace treaty between the two countries, but Washington has maintained that such talks must be held first between the two Koreas. The Korean War ended with an armistice, not a peace treaty, and technically, North Korea is still at war with the United States and South Korea.
Alan Liotta, a Defense Department official who was a member of the American negotiating team in New York, said that today's agreement on a $2 million payment removed what "had long been a stumbling block" in negotiations with North Korea.
"With this agreement, we are now prepared to move into detailed discussions to begin joint recovery operations," he said.
Robert Gallucci, a former State Department official who helped negotiate an agreement two years ago to halt North Korea's nuclear program, said that any agreement that allowed American investigators access to North Korea would be "significant, although I'm very cautious not to overstate it."
"This is a step in the right direction toward having the North Koreans begin to re-engage with us and therefore with the rest of the international community," he said.
In January, Pentagon officials revealed that at least two American soldiers reported missing in Korea were apparently alive and living in North Korea. The two men, members of the Second Infantry Divison, had defected in the 1960's, after the Korean War. Defense Department officials said they were revealing the information to quash false reports in the South Korean press suggesting that American war prisoners were alive in North Korea.

HEADLINE: Bankers Trust Settles Suit With P.& G.

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Paying a steep price to end a bitter battle, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation agreed yesterday to forgive most of the nearly $200 million the bank contended it was owed by Procter & Gamble over two complex transactions in 1993.
Bankers Trust said the agreement, which settles a lawsuit brought by Procter & Gamble, resolved the last major dispute over losses incurred by its clients in 1994 from derivatives, which are based on various financial markets, like stocks, bonds or currencies. When interest rates rose sharply in 1994, all sorts of investors -- not just Bankers Trust clients -- ranging from some of Piper Jaffray's mutual funds to Orange County, Calif., racked up huge losses on derivatives that were sensitive to interest rates. 
 Procter & Gamble was perhaps the most prominent corporation to contend that it did not understand the risk of derivatives after its two deals with Bankers Trust lost value very rapidly in 1994.
Yesterday's agreement calls for Procter & Gamble to pay Bankers Trust $35 million in cash and to void a separate contract in which Procter & Gamble was owed money by Bankers Trust.
Bankers Trust said the value of the voided contract was $14 million, while Procter & Gamble said it was only $5 million.
The ambiguity of the actual value of the settlement allowed both sides to claim some manner of victory. Procter & Gamble said that the bank forgave 83 percent of the debt. People close to Bankers Trust say the bank calculates the settlement at 74 percent.
In other similar disputes, Bankers Trust has forgiven between 40 and 70 percent of the amount owed, people familiar with the bank said. Over all, Bankers Trust has charged off about $300 million for losses related to disputes with clients over derivatives.
In either case, analysts and lawyers said the settlement appeared to be more favorable to Procter & Gamble than had been expected. But they presumed that Bankers Trust was willing to settle in order to avoid a potentially embarrassing trial, which was scheduled to begin in Federal District Court in Cincinnati on May 20.
"The settlement seems high," said Judah Kraushaar, an analyst with Merrill Lynch. "But it eliminates the risk to their reputation from a trial and the prospect of damages had things not gone their way."
While preparing for the trial, Procter & Gamble discovered a number of taped conversations between traders boasting of how much money they were making from these deals and how little Procter & Gamble understood they were at risk. In an unusual case of press restraint by a court, Business Week magazine was prevented for several weeks last fall from printing excerpts from those tapes it had obtained from sealed court documents.
The tapes recorded Kevin Hudson, the trader who sold Procter & Gamble the two contracts, saying, "It's like Russian roulette, and I keep putting another bullet in the revolver every time I do one of these."
Other than for these tapes, many legal experts argued that Bankers Trust had a strong case that Procter & Gamble was a sophisticated company and fully able to evaluate the risks of its dealings.
Nonetheless, Bankers Trust has been trying to settle the case for months, people familiar with the bank said. Until the last week or so, Procter & Gamble had insisted that Bankers Trust forgive 100 percent of its losses. Negotiations began recently culminating with a meeting Wednesday night between Bankers Trust's new chairman, Frank N. Newman, and his counterpart at Procter & Gamble, John E. Pepper, at a New York law firm.
People familiar with Bankers Trust's legal case said they believed that Procter & Gamble might have considered settling after the judge, John Feikens, ruled against the company on several key points over the last month.
Indeed, after the settlement was reached, Judge Feikens yesterday dismissed the company's allegations that Bankers Trust engaged in deceptive trade practices, that it breached fiduciary duty and that it engaged in misrepresentation and negligence. That ruling pleased the banks and brokerage firms that sell derivatives because the judge asserted that the derivatives were not securities and thus not subject to more stringent securities laws. And he ruled that Bankers Trust did not have a fiduciary obligation to look after Procter & Gamble's interests in the transaction.
Bankers Trust said the settlement would have no financial effect on its earnings as it had already charged off a large portion of the Procter & Gamble transactions. Procter & Gamble said that as a result of the settlement, it would take money out of a reserve, increasing its pretax earnings by $120 million.
Bankers Trust still awaits a Government-mandated report from an independent counsel that will evaluate whether it has instituted the proper procedures to prevent future problems. The report, due in June, will also look at whether charges should be brought against some of the Bankers Trust employees involved in the disputed transactions.
Even with the Procter & Gamble suit behind it, analysts say that Bankers Trust faces a long, hard road to restore its profitability and credibility with customers. In the first quarter, the bank earned $138 million. While that's better than the $157 million loss it faced a year earlier, it represents half the profit level of the heady days of 1993. And the bank's derivative business, once its flagship, barely broke even in the first quarter.

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: A NEW COURSE;
An Apocalyptic Deficit Doomed the Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Ever since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, New York City mayors have been required to employ a warning system for budget gaps, predicting deficits four years ahead. Those numbers had never been large enough to cause much concern until Jan. 31, the day Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani put out his financial plan for the years leading into the next century.
In that plan, the Mayor predicted that the budget deficit in the year 2000 would exceed $5.2 billion, by far the largest gap forecast in city history. That number set off alarms in the office of every fiscal monitor and bond rater in the city. The ringing grew so loud that, finally, Mr. Giuliani issued a 1997 budget yesterday strikingly different from any other in his term. 
 The looming deficit left the Mayor with no choice but to reverse course, his aides said yesterday, producing a retreat both from his proposals for new taxes and from a series of financial maneuvers roundly criticized by the monitors. His 1997 budget is a recognition that the deficit posed a much bigger problem for the city, and potentially for him, than high property and income taxes.
"The deficit issue had been raised to the point where we had to come up with a plan to bring it down dramatically," said Peter J. Powers, the First Deputy Mayor. "A lot of people had raised questions about it, so we needed to show the world that we could get there and shrink that deficit."
For the first two years of his term, Mr. Giuliani derided the warnings of the city's budget watchdogs that New York City's fiscal health was teetering dangerously out of balance. He was cutting both spending and taxes, he argued, and should be given more credit for reversing decades of municipal wastefulness.
But for all his cuts, the long range deficit only grew larger because of tax cuts and expensive agreements with labor unions, among other things. So the warnings grew louder with each budget. This year they became too disturbing to ignore. By dropping the new tax cuts and gimmicks and slashing the budgets of many agencies, the Mayor's new budget reduces the long-term deficit by nearly 50 percent, according to his estimates. By doing so, Mr. Giuliani finally won grudging praise from the bond raters and budget monitors.
"All in all, we'd have to say that we were pleased he recognized some of the big problems that we've all been making a fuss about," said Rosemary Scanlon, the deputy state comptroller for New York City. "He has started to pay attention to the issue of long-term balance with a more realistic plan."
The Mayor was able to cut the annual growth of city spending, largely by reducing the city's work force by 22,000 over the last two years. His methods for balancing each year's budget, however, had the effect of pushing the larger fiscal problems into the future. The municipal unions, for example, have been granted long-term contracts that increased wages beginning in 1998 while imposing no cuts in benefits. The administration also used several techniques to borrow against future revenues in exchange for short-term infusions of cash.
These and other tactics bought labor peace and got the Mayor through each year's budget. But they also inflated the long-term deficit beyond any in the past. The labor contracts alone were 44 percent of the $5 billion deficit for the year 2000, according to an analysis by the Citizens Budget Commission. The tax cuts, many of which have now been dropped, were another 32 percent.
Because the contracts couldn't be changed, the Mayor chose instead to drop proposed tax cuts that were close to his heart, and to make further deep reductions in spending. He even agreed to keep a surcharge on personal income, due to expire in December, that his own administration said was the equivalent of a tax increase. Many budget watchers said the Mayor had no choice.
"It was pure necessity, the force of simple arithmetic," said Eugene Keilin, the former chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. "Looking out to the years ahead, he could see that he had to really cut it now or he'd wind up with a problem he couldn't deal with."
Mr. Keilin argues that this year's budget is a vindication of the forecasting mandated by the fiscal crisis in 1975, forcing mayors to see the results of their actions down the road. The fiscal monitors, had seized on the $5.2 billion deficit.
"When you saw the $5 billion in absolute terms, it really blew a lot of people's minds," said Raymond B. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a business-financed group that has been monitoring budgets since 1932.
The new budget hardly eliminates the year 2000 deficit. It is simply reduced to $2.9 billion, larger than the projected deficits during the Dinkins administration. The Mayor and his aides say they can reduce that figure by further budget cutting, especially if the economy improves.
But by most reckonings, $600 million to $1 billion in one-shot financial maneuvers remain in the new budget, techniques that provide only a year's worth of cash without helping the long-term problem. That is less than the average $1.9 billion of one-shots in each of the Mayor's first two budgets, but enough that bond raters remain wary.
"The Mayor appears to have removed from his budget some of the one-shots, although I wouldn't want to suggest that they're not still an issue," said Robert Kurtter, a vice president of Moody's Investors Service, which has considered downgrading city bonds. "The new positions of the city on the tax cuts provides a firmer foundation for the city's revenue base, and gives the city more time to close the structural gap."
Some advocates for city programs, angry at the $450 million in new cuts the Mayor announced yesterday, accused him of giving in to the demands of the bond raters. But in the complex political calculus of city budgets, Mr. Giuliani undoubtedly knew he would encounter such criticism no matter what he did. What he didn't need, heading into an election year, was a group of conservative financial monitors howling about a massive deficit. With one stroke yesterday, he did much to mute those voices.

HEADLINE: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against Moody's Service

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service, the bond-rating agency, received some good news yesterday when a Federal judge threw out a lawsuit over its unsolicited rating of bonds that a Colorado school district sold in 1993.
But the decision in the Federal District Court in Denver did not address the school district's recent contention that Moody's violated Federal antitrust laws. The Justice Department's antitrust division is investigating whether Moody's, in effect, threatened bond issuers with unwanted ratings to insure the issuers hired the agency. 
 Judge William Downes dismissed the three claims brought last year by the Jefferson County, Colo., school district, which said that Moody's interfered with and damaged its bond sale.
Moody's argued that its ratings were opinions, protected by the First Amendment. "We are pleased with the court's ruling, as our livelihood depends on such protection," William O. Dwyer, president of Moody's, said in a statement.
The firm, which is a division of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, said it rates the creditworthiness of bonds -- without being asked -- to protect investors. The bond issuers generally pay for the ratings and investors rely on them to judge the riskiness of securities they plan to buy. Some big investors limit their purchases to the top-rated issues.
The ruling "is really good news for Moody's," Joe Mysak, editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer and an expert on the municipal bond, or muni, market, said. But because the Justice Department investigation is continuing, and includes other bond issues as well as the school district's, he added, "Moody's is still in the soup, so to speak."
In 1993, the Colorado district hired two other bond-rating firms, the Standard & Poor's Corporation, a unit of the McGraw-Hill Companies, and Fitch Investors Service but did not engage Moody's, the biggest and most expensive service. On the day of the sale, Moody's announced that it planned to rate the bond issue and "made statements that reflected badly on the school district's creditworthiness," W. Stuart Stuller, a lawyer representing the school district, which covers a large area west of Denver, said.
The school district contended that Moody's was retaliating because other firms were hired, and was trying to insure that the district used Moody's in the future.
Moody's subsequently rated the bonds Baa1; both Fitch and S.& P. had given them higher ratings of double A, Mr. Stuller said. The district asserted that because of Moody's action, it paid a higher interest rate, which cost it $769,000.
The school district plans to appeal Judge Downes's ruling after the court takes some action on the antitrust claims that the district filed on April 30, Mr. Stuller said. Moody's said its lawyers believe the court's dismissal of the original lawsuit effectively bars the antitrust claims.

HEADLINE: Wooing the Seniors at the Prom;
They're Older and Wiser and Vote on School Budgets

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: BELLEVILLE, N.J., May 8

 BODY:
Marie Capparelli, 75 years old, joined her four 18-year-old classmates in Pamela Hagerty's word-processing class at the high school today for a lesson in pulling images from the WordPerfect program's memory. A retired secretary, Mrs. Capparelli sits in twice a week to freshen her keyboard skills and update her grasp of technology.
On Friday night, Mrs. Capparelli and about 350 friends her own age -- give or take 10 years -- have reservations at the high school for the second annual "senior" prom, courtesy of the Belleville school board. A 17-piece swing band will play wartime melodies in the gymnasium, which will be decorated in pinwheels of blue and gold, the school colors. A caterer will serve finger sandwiches, sodas, pastries, tea and coffee. And teen-age students will be on hand to chat and dance with the strangers of their grandparents' or, maybe, great-grandparents' era. 
 With this prom and an open invitation to the elderly to attend high school classes at no cost, Belleville, a tidy middle-class community of 34,000 just north of Newark, joins a growing list of New Jersey school districts that are reaching out to the elderly and trying to draw them closer to schools and students.
Superintendents talk about the value of opening communication lines and building bridges to the elderly, particularly in these straitened economic times. For years, the fact of fixed incomes and childless homes have made the older citizens wary of ever-increasing school spending and taxes, and they have been a potent voting bloc against education budgets.
In Belleville, taxpayer anger has hobbled the school budget for years. Over the last 30 years, only three annual budgets have won voter approval. Property taxes here seem relatively high: $4,548 on a house with the average assessment of $40,000. Of that sum, $2,108 goes to the schools and $2,440 to local and county governments.
But last month, the 1996-97 budget of about $32 million -- up only 2.45 percent -- passed by 52 votes from about 2,000 cast. To school officials here, that was a landslide.
Michael Lally, Belleville's School Superintendent, said he believes last spring's first annual prom for the elderly helped win some crucial "yes" votes, although some of the promgoers grumble at the notion of trading votes for a dance. Nonetheless, as Mr. Lally and his staff reviewed final details for Friday night's event, he said: "The 'senior' prom last year went a long way in causing this budget to pass. It didn't hurt this community, and it sure didn't hurt this education system. It produced more good will in three hours than all our budget-instruction meetings."
This year, Mr. Lally told his aides, he wanted 15 to 20 students from each class at the prom. And he wanted them to mingle and dance with the elders. In his youth, he said, he could talk more easily with his grandparents than with his parents, and he wants more generational interaction at Belleville High.
"Each generation can learn from the other," Mr. Lally said. "Children benefit from the wisdom of grandparents, and grandparents benefit from the vitality of a child."
This theme has taken root in other school districts.
In Hamilton Township, outside Trenton, retired people have served as volunteer aides for teachers for 16 years, handling all sorts of chores. School officials call the helpers "robins." About 80, ranging in age from 40 to 86, turn out most days. Earl Mason helped in a first-grade section five days a week. But he cut that to three days after his wife complained that he was no longer mowing the lawn. In one kindergarten, the children call their volunteer "Grandma Cook." She is really Mary Cook, age 82 and the retired tax assessor in Hamilton.
"They're all just wonderful people," Elaine Szul, the program director, said of the robins. "Often they say, 'I get more out of this than the kids do.' "
Livingston High School began holding annual "senior" proms in the mid-1980's. Merchants donate everything for the hot buffet; some students serve the "seniors" and dance with them, while others offer dramatic skits and musical presentations during breaks in the dancing. Livingston's board also sponsors four luncheons a year for the elderly, and the high school drama club gives one performance of its annual musical exclusively for them, after serving them a spaghetti dinner.
In Totowa, in Passaic County, the School Superintendent, Viktor Joganow, created the Education Foundation, a fund for good-will programs, when he took office in 1990. Golf outings, auctions of donated merchandise and other activities raise about $50,000 for the fund each year. The money is spent on educational programs, medical clinics, seasonal theme dances and craft workshops.
"It's great for our kids without grandparents, and for our seniors without grandchildren," Dr. Joganow said. Since creation of the Education Foundation, all six annual school budgets have passed, and Dr. Joganow said he believes the programs the fund finances have swayed some voters.
Belleville's school board will spend about $3,000 on Friday's prom, Mr. Lally said. Some of the elderly complain about tax money paying for their dance, but more say that last spring's was a delight and that they will go to this one.
"Seniors built this town, this state and this country," said Joe Fornarotto, a member of the Tuesday club, an elders' group. "We deserve something."
Dorothy Barbig, 82, said she hoped this prom would be as nice as last year's.
"It was amazing; it was beautiful," she said. "They treated us like royalty. We danced all night long."
As Ms. Hagerty's word-processing class ended today, her four teen-age students wished Mrs. Capparelli a good time at the prom.
Beaming, she replied, "Come and see us."
She has a new black chiffon gown with red and yellow roses for the dance, she said. "But I don't have a date," she added, with a little frown.
It was mock dismay. Mrs. Capparelli, whose husband died in 1972, has reserved a table with nine other widows. They will not be the only ones. Many of the women in Belleville's three senior citizen clubs have outlived their husbands, and they outnumber the men in the clubs by about 15 to 1. Line dancing is popular, especially to tunes like "Winchester Cathedral," "New York, New York" and the occasional polka.
Many of the elderly belong to all three clubs. They spend most mornings and early afternoons at the clubhouse on Franklin Avenue, playing cards or bingo, planning trips and raising money for charity.
They seem a spunky bunch. They frown on talk about pills, sickness, raising children and baby-sitting their grandchildren, said Betty Barr, 72, the president of the Friday club. "And you rarely hear anybody talk about what they did before," she said. "We lean to the future. It's important who you are, not what you were. There is a life after 60. We've had a few marriages. We've got a lot of boyfriend-girlfriend stuff."
The clubs hold dances on Mother's Day, Valentine's Day and St. Patrick's Day, and seem eager for any excuse to hold a party.
This year's prom theme is "Remember When: In the Make-Believe Ballroom." But few seem nostalgic for a long-gone era or ready to plunge into reminiscence. Most club members were teen-agers in the Depression in the 1930's and during World War II and never got to their own high school prom, including Mrs. Capparelli, who was in Belleville High's Class of '38.
"Whoever went to proms then?" she said. "Only the rich kids."

HEADLINE: Race, Mortgages and Statistics;
The Unending Debate Over a Study of Lending Bias

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
These statistics don't lie: Black and Hispanic home buyers have a harder time getting mortgages.
But why? If lenders discriminate by race, it is up to bank regulators and the Justice Department to enforce anti-bias laws. If, however, minorities are less likely to obtain mortgages mostly because they are more likely to suffer from poverty, the cure -- allocating credit by skin color -- is arguably worse than the disease. So thoughtful policy makers were delighted when the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston set out in 1990 to answer the question using sophisticated statistical methods. 
 But four years after the 1992 release of the Boston Fed's findings -- which concluded that racial discrimination was still widespread in the banking industry -- otherwise mild-mannered academic experts have gotten into mudslinging matches over the research's implications. Detractors attack the study as defective in its methodology and tainted by ideological preconceptions. Supporters dismiss their concerns as overblown and wrongheaded.
The publication of the full study in March in the American Economic Review, the flagship journal of the American Economic Association, seems only to have escalated the rhetoric. "I am extremely worried that economics is becoming like other social sciences -- not very scientific," said Anthony Yezer, an economist at George Washington University and a Boston Fed critic.
The study has had an enormous impact on the banking industry. Both the Justice Department and the Massachusetts Attorney General began investigations of lending discrimination in the Boston area shortly after its dissemination. In December 1993, for example, the Justice Department settled a lending-discrimination case against the Shawmut National Corporation, then New England's third-largest banking institution, after it agreed to take steps to prevent discrimination and pay at least $960,000 to black and Hispanic applicants who were denied loans.
And the Clinton Administration intensified not-so-friendly efforts to persuade lenders to serve minorities. In one celebrated case, the Justice Department forced a suburban Washington bank that had few black mortgage applicants to open an office in a black neighborhood.
The biggest loser in this no-win battle was Alicia Munnell, whose name appeared first among the study's authors because she was the Boston Fed's head of research in 1992.
Last year, Ms. Munnell, then a senior Treasury official, was widely expected to be nominated to the Federal Reserve Board by President Clinton. But bankers, angered at the housing-discrimination study, lobbied heavily against her, and Mr. Clinton, his popularity then at a low ebb, last summer decided to duck the fight. Ms. Munnell was named instead to the White House's Council of Economic Advisers.
Flawed or not, the Boston Fed's investigation had a noble purpose: leveling the mortgage playing field for minorities. Racial discrimination has been a fixture of the American housing market since Colonial times, and continues in the 1990's despite state and Federal fair-lending laws. It takes many forms, from "redlining" -- the refusal of lending institutions to make loans to residents of deteriorating neighborhoods -- to charging minorities higher interest rates and fees.
Newsday recently reported that its examination of almost 100,000 mortgage-loan applications on Long Island showed blacks had been rejected almost three times as often as whites, even when they had the same income. And this week, the Fleet Financial Group of Boston agreed to pay about $4 million to black and Hispanic customers to settle allegations of overcharging them for mortgage loans.
Unequal treatment of minorities isn't necessarily motived by racism; it can also reflect lesser creditworthiness or other economic disparities. Indeed, while the Boston Fed's finding that racial discrimination is a significant problem has stiffened regulators' resolve to police lending practices, skeptics see little in it to justify new efforts to bully banks into lending more to minorities.
The Fed study's authors would like to declare victory and vacate the battlefield. "I really believe the debate has to move on," said Geoffrey Tootell, now an assistant vice president of the Boston Fed.
That is wishful thinking. But the debate is worth a closer look, both because it revolves around the burning issue of racial discrimination -- and what government should do about it -- and because it offers an unusual window into the cloistered world of econometrics, a field of research that uses mathematical principles to test economic theories.
This story really begins in 1989 with amendments to the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act that required banks to keep records of rejected mortgage applications, along with details about the applicants' race, sex and income. The early data suggested that black applicants were twice as likely as whites to be rejected, a fact that made headlines.
Minority groups interpreted the numbers as proof of discrimination in lending. Bankers argued that the results showed only that minority applicants generally had lower incomes, smaller savings and less-certain job prospects -- making them less qualified borrowers.
Most economists operated on the assumption that competitive pressures would induce banks to approve loans to all creditworthy customers. Even if some banks discriminated against qualified black applicants, their reasoning went, others would step into the breach to make a profit. Indeed, this thought was never far from the minds of the research team at the Boston Fed. "Our guess was there was little or no discrimination," Mr. Tootell recalled.
To settle the matter, the Boston Fed leaned on 131 mortgage lenders in the Boston area to provide detailed information about all black and Hispanic applicants, along with comparable data for a random sample of whites. From the data, they devised a "rejection equation" in which standard statistical methods were applied to isolate the impact of applicants' income, savings, credit history, employment, and collateral in the prospective home purchase.
The researchers determined that these purely economic factors partly explained the difference in the probability of an application's rejection. But they found that race mattered, too. Before adjustment for creditworthiness, minority applicants in Boston were 2.7 times as likely to be rejected as white applicants. After the adjustment, the ratio became a lower, but hardly trivial, 1.6.
The Boston Fed concluded that lenders themselves, rather than regulators, were in the best position to eliminate bias because discrimination was subtle and probably had more to do with the unconscious attitudes of loan officers than with bank policy. Richard Syron, then the president of the Boston Fed, testified before Congress that "as long as lenders sincerely believe their procedures are beyond reproach, efforts to get them to change will have limited success."
But even as liberals debated alternative approaches for eliminating the bias found by the Boston Fed, some economists were questioning the quality of the research. First at bat was David Horne of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
The F.D.I.C. used its independent authority as a regulator to obtain records from 70 banks that accounted for half the loan applications reviewed in the study. Mr. Horne found what he considered serious inconsistencies. As just one example, he identified several cases in which the grounds for rejecting relatively affluent minority applicants had nothing to do with their race and everything to do with their ineligibility for the subsidized Government mortgages they were seeking.
He noted, moreover, that a minority-owned bank specializing in lending in black neighborhoods was responsible for half of all the minority rejections in the F.D.I.C. sample.
Ted Day and Stan Liebowitz, economists at the University of Texas at Dallas, also uncovered what they considered flaws in the study. They found large numbers of applications in which the interest rates apparently were either far above or below market rates. Eliminating these implausible cases from the sample, they found, sharply reduced the extent of discrimination that could be inferred with statistical methods.
Messrs. Day, Liebowitz and Horne all noted, too, that the method of judging applicants' creditworthiness could make a big difference in the determination of bias. Using the banks' own credit standards rather than those in the Boston Fed study, for example, seemed to eliminate race as a significant factor.
Not everyone who took a second look at the Boston Fed study has found it wanting. James Carr and Isaac Megbolugbe of the Federal National Mortgage Association's Office of Housing Research eliminated application records they believed were polluted with inaccurate data and still found strong statistical evidence of bias. John Yinger, an economist at the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University and the author of "Closed Doors, Opportunities Lost" (Russell Sage Foundation) wrote that "despite a few extreme claims about data errors or omitted control variables, the results of the study have held up very well."
The divergence of opinion is not surprising. Most economic research based on statistical inference is vulnerable to second-guessing because the evidence it uses is less reliable than data from controlled scientific experiments -- say, the effects of new drugs on laboratory animals.
Moreover, most econometric results are open to interpretation. In this case, it is exceptionally difficult to tease out the impact of discrimination by race, which is illegal, from discrimination based on purely economic factors, which is how banks serve capital markets. "Doing the best you can with the available data sometimes isn't good enough," argues James Heckman, an econometrician at the University of Chicago.
What makes the duel between respected economists unusual in the Boston Fed case is the open belligerance of the combatants. Mr. Liebowitz of the University of Texas, for example, went so far as to question the motives of the authors. "Before any study is considered definitive," he wrote in The Wall Street Journal in 1993, "it should be checked far more carefully than this study was checked. Unless, of course, truth is not the goal."
Mr. Yinger was no less restrained in attacking the arguments of Mr. Horne of the F.D.I.C. "Horne's critique was irresponsible," he said.
The study's authors took a subtler dig at their accuser -- but, by the etiquette of their profession, an even harsher one. "Horne," they wrote in the American Economic Review, "was unable to replicate" the data underlying the errors he claimed to have found in their work -- a thinly veiled charge that he had fudged his research. They also reiterated their conclusion that "a serious problem may exist in the market for mortgage loans."
For his part, Mr. Horne says that the Boston Fed used an incomplete draft of his work provided on condition it not be cited for publication.
The moral to this tale, suggests Mr. Heckman of the University of Chicago, is the need to treat empirical research on sensitive issues of public policy with greater caution. "There is a common misunderstanding," he explained, "that there is objectivity in numbers."

HEADLINE: Chip Index Dips for 6th Month in Row

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator declined in April for the sixth consecutive month, a trade group reported today.
But the drop was moderate compared with the revised March figure, a sign that prices and demand for chips might have begun to stablize. 
 The Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 0.78, down from a revised figure of 0.79 for March. The April figure surpassed March's as the lowest in the nine years that the association has been keeping track.
The numbers were reported after the close of the stock market. Analysts had expected April's ratio to be somewhat flat to slightly higher compared with the figure for March, which the association initially reported as 0.80.
The book-to-bill compares orders against shipments. Thus, a ratio of 0.78 indicates that for every $100 worth of products shipped, only $78 worth was ordered, an indicator of declining sales.
But because the ratio measures dollars, not units, it had been skewed in recent months by a rapid decline in the price of dynamic random access memory chips, or D-RAM's, the most common chip. So, some analysts argue, the decline in the ratio may not accurately indicate a decline in demand.
The industry association, which will soon release its midyear forecast, said it still expected positive growth for 1996. April's numbers suggested that the chip market had stabilized after a sluggish first quarter, the group said. The numbers also signaled that 1996 would be a year of slower growth than was 1995, when the world chip market grew 42 percent, the association said.
Orders and shipments both declined in April. At $3.13 billion, orders declined 2.8 percent compared with March. Versus a year ago, however, the pace of new orders in April decreased 22.5 percent. At just above $4 billion, shipments declined 2.6 percent compared with March, but were up 15 percent from $3.49 billion in the corresponding period a year ago.
Jonathan Joseph, an analyst with Montgomery Securities, said orders were substantially below expectations, while shipments were off slightly.
"The only saving grace in all this is that it looks like sales of finished goods remain decent," he said, referring to strong results from personal computers and networking companies.

HEADLINE: After a String of Dictators, Ugandans Get to Vote Again

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 9

 BODY:
For the first time in 16 years, Ugandans stood in line this morning to vote for a new president, ending a bitter race that became a referendum not only on President Yoweri Museveni's tenure, but also on his vision of a democracy without political parties.
Turnout was heavy as nearly eight million registered voters walked to crude polling stations and waited in line for hours, sometimes in the rain, just for the chance to mark a paper ballot with an indelible pen and push it into a metal lock-box. 
 "This is an historic election, if it goes well," said Hamid Galabuz, a 40-year-old vegetable vendor, as he stood in line at a Kampala school. "We don't know what will happen."
The polling was peaceful across most of the nation, officials said. The military stayed away, leaving security to local constables. Though there were reports of voters being turned away because they were not on official lists, the problems were not widespread enough to invalidate the results, election officials said.
Diplomats and opposition leaders maintain that with the short campaign season of one month and the ban on party activity, Mr. Museveni had such a heavy advantage that he cannot lose, whether the election is fair or not.
One diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: "This election falls short and does not meet international standards of free and fair. Still, it's a step forward."
That an election is being held at all is a watershed in Uganda, a once-prosperous land that became independent in 1962 and has suffered under a succession of murderous dictators.
Ten years ago Mr. Museveni's guerrilla army won a civil war, marched into Kampala and seized power, ending nearly 20 years of brutal oppression under Idi Amin, Milton Obote and Tito Okello.
Since then, Mr. Museveni has been widely credited with restoring stability and moving Uganda toward economic recovery, but he has repeatedly put off elections. He argues that political parties have done nothing but brew chaos here, dividing the country along racial and religious lines.
Parties are not allowed to field candidates, meet, organize or raise money. But Mr. Museveni's National Resistance Movement, the political branch that grew out of the rebel army, has essentially become the ruling party.
"Political parties are spoilers," Mr. Museveni told tens of thousands of supporters at a rally on Tuesday. "By this vote, you will be able to show the world that Africa is Africa, Europe is Europe and America is America. I do not go to Europe to lecture them on how to run their countries."
The main opposition candidate, Paul Ssemogerere, the leader of the old Democratic Party, has promised to bring back party politics, cut the military, increase social spending and negotiate peace with rebel groups in the north.
After campaigning ended on Wednesday, Mr. Ssemogerere said the election had been neither free nor fair. He complained that his supporters had had only one month to campaign in 39 districts. They had been harassed by the authorities, he said, and prevented from organizing, while Mr. Museveni had essentially been campaigning for nearly two years, relying on the power of incumbency and Government largess.
Still, the race is expected to be tight, partly because of the ethnic tensions that always lie under the surface here.
Mr. Ssemogerere is a scholarly man, a former Deputy Prime Minister who has spent his whole life in Government, either as a party leader or as a bureaucrat. In 1980, his party narrowly lost a parliamentary election to Mr. Obote's party.
Now Mr. Ssemogerere has put together an unlikely and fragile coalition. He mended fences with Mr. Obote's party, the same people who engineered his defeat in 1980. He enjoys support among his own tribe, the Baganda, as well as among northern ethnic groups like the Langi and Acholi, which lost power when Mr. Museveni's army, made up predominately of southerners, swept into Kampala.
One problem for Mr. Ssemogerere is that the only issue uniting the opposition is their belief that Mr. Museveni has been in office too long and has frozen out other parties.
For his part, Mr. Museveni has accused Mr. Ssemogerere of plotting to bring back Mr. Obote from exile in Zambia and of colluding with a Christian fundamentalist rebel group in the north.
Mr. Museveni, who still retains a military man's gruff candor on the hustings, has lost no opportunity to remind voters of Mr. Ssemogerere's alliance with Mr. Obote's party and his promise to hold peace talks with the northern rebels.
One of Mr. Museveni's newspaper advertisements shows a pile of skulls and bones from a mass grave during the Amin era. "THINK," it says. "Don't forget the past. One million Ugandans, our brothers, sisters, family and friends lost their lives. Your vote could bring it back."
The strategy has worked well. Many Museveni supporters say they would have backed Mr. Ssemogerere but for fears that Mr. Obote would return. Repeatedly, they say they will vote for Mr. Museveni because he has brought peace to a country where people had lived in fear of being killed by the Government.
But Mr. Ssemogerere has played on the resentments of the unemployed, especially demobilized soldiers and civil servants who lost jobs when Mr. Museveni pushed through an economic austerity program in the late 1980's.
In northern towns, Mr. Ssemogerere has hammered away at Mr. Museveni for allowing the north to lag behind the south in development.
Some of Mr. Ssemogerere's supporters say they see Mr. Museveni as an autocrat at heart. A few expressed fears that he would not give up power, even if defeated.
"Ten years is too long," said Sunday Mutumba, 27, a mechanic. "When African leaders stay in power too long they become dictators."

HEADLINE: Minimum Wage? As One Man Finds, It's Really a Matter of Perspective

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE: The differences in a paycheck.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: NORTH CANTON, Ohio, May 9

 BODY:
Robert Bobbitt Sr. is a past president of the board of the Canton Urban League. For much of his life, civil rights have been the most important political issue for Mr. Bobbitt, who is black.
Even as he moved upward in the corporate world, becoming a vice president for Pepsi-Cola in Detroit, he continued to vote for the party he felt was best for him and for black people, the Democrats. 
 But in the mid-1980's, Mr. Bobbitt changed his life. He jumped off the corporate ladder to become his own boss, buying his first McDonald's restaurant, in a Canton suburb. He worked long hours, did well, bought a second McDonald's in 1989 and, last week, bought two more.
Being the boss changed Mr. Bobbitt's politics. Nearly a decade ago he began voting Republican. The Democrats' current push in Washington to raise the minimum wage to $5.15 an hour from $4.25 illustrates why.
"Before, I would have thought of the minimum wage as a social issue," he said. "Then you start working for yourself, and all the risk and responsibilities are on you."
"Raising the minimum wage will take money out of the entrepreneur's pocket," he said. That would include Mr. Bobbitt's pocket. He says the Democrats' effort to raise the minimum wage would drive up his labor expenses, cutting his annual profit by $20,000 a restaurant, $80,000 altogether.
While the think-tank economists debate the cost versus benefits of a minimum-wage increase, on Main Street people are quite clear about where their self-interest lies.
Mr. Bobbitt did not want a reporter interviewing the workers at his McDonald's on North Main Street here, but he has no doubt as to how they feel. "We do our surveys," he said. "Most people will always tell you they're not making enough money."
Indeed, national polls indicate that nearly 80 percent of Americans favor President Clinton's plan to increase the minimum wage. Standing at the corner of another nearby Main Street, in the Canton suburb of Louisville, a dozen people who were asked all favored raising it.
"It ought to go to $10," said Wilma Brunner, a crossing guard. "No matter where I've worked, I had to start at minimum wage -- Kmart, Camelot Music. I listen to Rush Limbaugh. I know he's against it, but I don't go along with Rush on this one."
Ask people about the minimum wage, and you often hear the anger they feel for their jobs. Tammy Green, 30, who until recently worked at a nursing home earning $7.48 an hour, does not worry that businesses could be hurt.
"Business people made their million -- they have more than I do," Ms. Green said. "To fill up your tank costs $16. You're working the first four hours for gas."
Francis Lilly, 21, was mowing the lawn in front of Jim Edwards Ford, where he is a lot manager earning $5 an hour. "If I'm having a hard time at $5," he said, "I can imagine what it's like making $4.25."
Sara Frock earns $8 an hour in a sales office and gets no health benefits. Indeed, a recent study by the Job Training Partnership in Canton shows that none of the fast-food places surveyed here in Stark County -- McDonald's, Burger King, Wendy's, Hardee's, Pizza Hut, Dairy Queen -- provide health benefits.
"It's minimum-wage people and the people like me who have to carry the people on the top," Ms. Frock said.
About 2 percent of the nation's 107 million workers earn the minimum wage, while an additional 9 percent earn between $4.25 and $5.15 and so would also be affected directly by the President's proposal. The typical worker in that pay range is a white woman over the age of 20.
But if the minimum is lifted, millions more not directly affected would most likely see their wages rise as employers adjusted pay scales upward.
Wages in Ohio are low by East Coast standards, and wages in the Canton area are low by Ohio standards, ranking near the bottom among the state's dozen largest urban centers. Yet even here, most companies must pay above $4.25 to attract workers. Unemployment is close to the national rate of 5.4 percent; everywhere there are "now hiring" signs for entry-level jobs at drugstores, nurseries, restaurants.
The Job Training survey indicates that McDonald's, Burger King and Wendy's restaurants in Stark County pay up to $4.75 to start, with small non-restaurant businesses like Buckeye Paper, Chips Enterprises and Electric Melting Services paying $6 to $6.50.
Last week Mr. Bobbitt and Tom Schervish, who owns interests in seven local Burger Kings, two Fudd ruckers restaurants and two Pancho's Southwestern Grilles, met with their Congressman, Ralph Regula, a moderate Republican, seeking his support.
They explained that 60 percent to 70 percent of their employees were suburban teen-agers, many living at home and working to pay for a car and insurance. "The idea that people are living off the minimum wage is a totally false scenario, a bleeding-heart ploy," Mr. Schervish said.
They said that if the minimum rose, their menu prices would, too, hurting poorer families the most.
When they had finished talking to Mr. Regula, who has not yet taken a stand on the issue, Mr. Bobbitt felt they had a chance to defeat any increase. But Mr. Schervish, who has been battling minimum-wage bills much longer, did not. "I got the feeling from Ralph it didn't matter what the arguments are," Mr. Schervish said. "The Republicans don't want to be outmaneuvered by Clinton. It's the popular thing, it's going to happen, the Republicans will go along, and there's not a hell of a lot that can be done about it."
Mr. Bobbitt had wanted to own a business all his life. Though he rose to the level of regional vice president at Pepsi, he felt there was a ceiling on how high he could go because he is black. (Larry Jabbonsky, a Pepsi-Cola spokesman, said, "I can't speak for Mr. Bobbitt's experience, but I can assure you we are unswerving in our commitment to diversity in the workplace and there are no limits to this commitment.")
Mr. Bobbitt left Pepsi to take a management position at Coca-Cola in the early 1980's, but had something else in mind.
He started secretly training in a McDonald's ownership program in May 1984, ultimately putting in 2,000 hours at one of the restaurants. "I'd get to my job at Coke at 7 in the morning," he said. "A typical day went until 6 or 7 at night. Then I'd drive to a McDonald's an hour away -- I didn't want to run into anybody I knew -- and I'd be there until midnight making hamburgers. I'd get home at 1 and have to be up at 6."
After a year and a half, he had qualified for ownership but did not have the money to buy a franchise. A McDonald's costs $500,000 and requires a $200,000 down payment. McDonald's accepted Mr. Bobbitt in a lease program that gives qualified people three years to assume ownership. McDonald's created the lease option to diversify its ownership ranks, bringing in more members of minorities, Mr. Bobbitt said.
His first restaurant was in Jackson, a Canton suburb. By taking a salary of only $25,000 in the beginning, he said, he saved enough money to buy the restaurant in a year.
He was impressed that McDonald's did not try to steer him toward an inner-city location. Today all four of his restaurants are in the suburbs, and, like those suburbs, his 250-person work force is virtually all white.
Mr. Bobbitt says part of what made his conversion from Democrat to Republican easier was that at McDonald's he felt he was associated with a corporation that treated him without bias.
There are still times he feels pulled two ways. He belongs to a black church, United Christian Faith, and most of his friends there and at the Urban League are Democrats. Indeed, the National Urban League supports increasing the minimum wage.
Nor does he have the venom toward Mr. Clinton that fellow businessmen like Mr. Schervish feel.
"Being a a black person, from the standpoint of social policy I'd vote for Clinton," Mr. Bobbitt said. "I like the cultural diversity in his Cabinet. I see him giving more opportunities to minorities and women. But I have to turn to the Republicans because of my business interests."
He has also gone to his Republican representatives for help on issues like workers' compensation and employee health benefits. He voted for George Bush in 1988 and 1992, and he expects to vote for Bob Dole this time.
Before he could finish an interview at his restaurant here the other day, the manager on duty, Brenda Anderson, rushed over, her drive-thru headset all askew. "We're in trouble!" she said. One worker had left for home early because her son had been beaten up; another had finished at 11. The lunch rush was backing up. They were three deep and five across at the front counter. Seven cars were backed up at the drive-thru.
Mr. Bobbitt, the entrepreneur, shot out of his seat, rushing behind the counter.
"I'll take the drive-thru!" Ms. Anderson said. "You be the runner." He looked up at the computerized screen for drive-thru orders. "Two McChicken combos, two 22-ouncers, two large fries!" he said, stuffing them into a bag, then handing it off.
"A Happy Meal!" he called, picking up a little Robin Hood toy, then moving toward the fries.
 
Throughout the Presidential election year, articles in this series will examine Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County, a political bellwether for decades.

HEADLINE: Democrats Reject a Dole Plan to Cut Gas Tax

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Thwarted all week by a Democratic filibuster, Senator Bob Dole today proposed legislation that would reduce the Federal gasoline tax by 4.3 cents, without other provisions of the sort President Clinton has called "poison pills."
Mr. Dole contended that his tax reduction proposal, coupled with a plan supported by the Clinton Administration to force commercial banks to pay more of the cost of the savings and loan bailout, met Mr. Clinton's demand on Wednesday for a "clean" gas tax bill. The President said then that he would sign such a bill. 
 "It could almost have come from the White House," Mr. Dole said, "and we are pleased to accommodate the White House when we can."
But Democrats said they would not go along until Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader and presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, guaranteed them an equally uncomplicated vote on increasing the Federal minimum wage to $5.15 from $4.25 an hour.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, rejected the Dole proposal, saying, "The President offered to break the logjam, repeal the gas tax, plus increase the minimum wage. The majority leader has left off an important part of the equation. Instead of a win-win, it's still going to be a lose-lose."
Mr. Dole's continued pressure for a reduction in the gasoline tax is part of a broader strategy on taxes that the Senator is considering. Believing that Mr. Dole had picked up momentum with the issue, a senior aide to him said today that the Dole campaign was considering a much more dramatic call for an across-the-board cut in income taxes in an economic plan it is drafting.
But Mr. Dole got nowhere in the Senate today. After a four-day stalemate, the chamber adjourned for a long weekend, and no votes will be held until Tuesday.
Before he offered his new proposal, Mr. Dole failed in an effort to break the Democratic filibuster against his last package of legislation, a combination of the gasoline tax cut, the minimum wage increase and legalization of some kinds of meetings between employers and workers, which are now held illegal as violations of collective bargaining laws. Democrats contend that the last provision will weaken unions, and it is the target of their filibuster.
It takes 60 votes to end a filibuster, and Mr. Dole mustered only 52, all of them from Republicans. Forty-three Democrats and 1 Republican, Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado, voted against cutting off debate.
Then Mr. Dole put forward his new approach and filed a cloture motion to end debate on it. "Do you want to vote for lower gas prices?" he asked. "Then you vote for cloture on Tuesday. Want to vote for lower travel costs, lower inflation, better job protection for employees in the transportation industry? This will be an opportunity."
Mr. Dole said that "in the spirit of the President's press conference yesterday asking for cooperation, I have decided to offer the gas tax repeal, which he said he would sign, and pay for it with a measure that he wanted desperately."
Mr. McCurry agreed that the Administration wanted the measure requiring banks and savings and loans institutions to pay more of the costs of the failures of savings institutions in the 1980's, but he said it wanted it separately.
The vote on ending debate on the newest approach by Mr. Dole is scheduled for Tuesday. But Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, made it clear that he would fight that motion, as he fought today's.
Of the latest Dole plan, Mr. Daschle said: "It is more of the same. It is similar to many of the other proposals we have been presented over the last several weeks, and obviously it is unacceptable.
"We have indicated our desire to have a vote on the gas tax, and we are prepared to accept that. But we also obviously feel the need to have the same vote on the minimum wage."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the chief sponsor of the proposed increase in the minimum wage, joined in the criticism. He complained that the Senate was now in the "Doledrums," quoting a dictionary definition of the word with its usual spelling of "doldrums." He termed it "a period of inactivity, listlessness or depression."
"The American people look to the Congress for action on the minimum wage," Mr. Kennedy said "and all they see are cloture petitions, quorum calls and procedural gymnastics to avoid taking action."
