HEADLINE: Dole's Views on U.S. Asian Policy: Lost Credibility and Weak Leadership

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech today by Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a nonpartisan research organization, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:
 
 I believe America's global future will soon be an important issue in this election. And I believe that President Clinton's foreign-policy track record of weakness and indecision, and double-talk and incoherence, has diminished American credibility and undermined American interests. 
 Failures of leadership in Asia, such as coddling North Korea, lacking a strategic policy toward China, and a conspicuous absence of the President from the debate over most-favored-nation status for China have eroded American power and purpose in the Pacific.
The bottom line is that American credibility in Asia is low and still declining, and American interests are challenged throughout the region. As a direct result of the weak leadership, vacillation and inconsistency, which are the hallmarks of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy, the world's sole super power finds itself drifting and defensive, with an uncertain course and an untrusted voice in the Pacific Basin.

Policy Changes
 Last month President Clinton announced a four-party peace initiative in North Korea involving the United States, China and the two Koreas. The initiative surprised the Chinese. No mention was made of resuming North-South talks.
North Korea has not responded.
The administration also undertook, "missile non-proliferation," talks with North Korean leaders despite the regime's blatant -- and I would repeat, blatant -- violations of existing arms control agreements.
President Clinton should cease bilateral contacts with North Korea on proliferation and on diplomatic normalization until North Korea resumes direct discussions with South Korea as it committed itself to do five years ago. . . .
It's time for the United States to work with South Korea and Japan as well as other Asian allies on the development, testing and deployment of ballistic missile defenses: a Pacific Democracy Defense Program, if you will. And our three countries have territory or military forces under direct threat of missile attack today.
Our three countries have the resources and experience to work on missile defense programs today. And with American leadership, our three countries can have the political will and technological means to defend our territory and our people tomorrow.
Japan and Korea face a clear and present danger from ballistic missiles and should be our top priority under the Pacific Democracy Defense Program. It's time to move past paper studies to the deployment decisions.
And let me move briefly to Japan because the most important security relationship America has in Asia is with Japan. With a solid security alliance between the U.S. and Japan, there can be peace and stability in Asia. Without such an alliance, there most likely will not be peace.
In 1994 the Clinton Administration provoked a trade war and lost, and then declared victory, even though President Clinton received nothing. The Clinton Administration chose uncoordinated and contradictory tactics and did not work with the forces in Japan favoring deregulation, competition and economic reform.
The result has been an increase in both the bilateral trade deficit and in Japanese trade and nationalism.
Japan must open its sanctuary market and level the playing field. We must start by resolving ongoing commercial disputes that cost U.S. companies millions and millions of dollars in lost sales. If negotiated solutions are not reached, swift action under U.S. existing trade laws will be required. If our trade disputes are not resolved, American public support for U.S.-Japan security relationship will inevitably decline, to the detriment of both countries.

 China and Trade Policy
 And let me turn now to U.S.-China relations. I don't believe there's a more complex relationship in the world than our relationship with China, and not one that will have ultimately greater historical consequences.
Our strategic goal should be clear: a China which does not threaten its neighbors and a China which plays by the rules of the international system of nonproliferation and trade, a China which is peaceful, prosperous and free.
If our goal is clear, so, too, is the path to achieve it. We should prioritize our interests, communicate our priorities to the Chinese leadership, and implement a policy, implement our policy in a confident and a consistent manner. . . .
China's leadership must be convinced that undermining the stability of regional balances of power will carry an international price. And as far as Taiwan is concerned, I think we must make our commitment for the peaceful resolution of differences between China and Taiwan clear.
The Clinton Administration's policy of ambiguity in my view sends a signal of uncertainty to Taiwan and to China and to all of our Asian allies. Our policy should be unmistakably resolute. If force is used against Taiwan, America will respond. That is the strategic bottom line in the Taiwan Relations Act, which I was proud to help shape. And during the debate on a critical section of the act concerning efforts to address the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means, I argued for clarity. And on March 17, 1979, I said on the Senate floor it was vital to convey the assurance that specifically spelled out our nation's commitment to aid the Republic of China in resisting aggression. . . .
There's no more clearly defensive and clearly necessary weapon system for Taiwan than effective missile defense. The current policy of not sharing information on missile threats or missile technology with Taiwan must be changed. . . .
I think we also ought to be very forthright, right out front, right out in the open about our commercial relations with China. President Clinton was right in 1994 when he finally decided extension of most-favored-nation status was the best way to promote our long-term interests in China including greater respect for human rights and the rule of law.
We should extend M.F.N. to China not because it is in our economic interests but because it's in our national interest, and there's a big difference. . . .

China's Immense Promise
 Now, President Clinton has never clearly articulated a strategy for dealing with China or how M.F.N. extension fits into that strategy. Consequently, President Clinton faces a tough sell for M.F.N. on Capitol Hill.
And let me also add that extending M.F.N. is not in itself a China policy. It's not even a China trade policy. Over the last decade, U.S. exports to China have tripled, but Chinese exports to the U.S. have increased nearly tenfold. Our current trade deficit is $34 billion a year and climbing. And China holds immense promise as a market for U.S. goods, services and agriculture products, but China is mortgaging that promise through protectionist policies. Intellectual property rights piracy, for example, costs American companies at the cutting edge of global competitiveness about $2 billion annually -- $2 billion annually -- because of the I.P.R. problems.
And China must live up to the trade agreements it has freely entered into, whether on intellectual property or on textiles and apparel. . . . And we should move to a targeted and proportional response, including proposing an immediate list of sanctions under U.S. trade law. China enjoys liberal access to our markets, but a wide array of barriers inhibit American exporters.
And American policy should be clear about the Chinese membership in the World Trade Organization. China will enjoy the fruits of W.T.O. only after -- let me underscore "after" -- it demonstrates a willingness to play by the accepted rules of the GATT system. And I hope the Administration will work with the Congress on this issue, so it will not be necessary for the Congress to work on legislation itself.
This should not be a unilateral U.S. effort, and for an Administration which prides itself on assertive multilateralism, the Clinton team has been woefully inadequate in building coalitions on international issues. Unfair Chinese trade practices affect Japan, South Korea, the European Union, Asean, Australia, New Zealand, and each of these have parallel interests to the United States. . . .
Many argue that M.F.N. should not be extended to China because of its terrible record on human rights. China's record on human rights and tolerance of political opposition is indefensible. No doubt about it, you can't defend it.
But China is by no means alone. There will be a debate on M.F.N. for China this year, but not on M.F.N. for Russia, where 30,000 Chechens have been slaughtered; on M.F.N. for Syria, which has no political freedom, occupies Lebanon, and provides safe haven for terrorists. Trade is not a panacea, and freer trade does not always lead to democracy. . . .
But in China, continuing trade offers the prospect of continuing change. Capitalism has already corroded central government control. Some provincial governments in China control resources in excess of most Third World states. Market forces will predominate as China needs to import food and energy and capital and technology. . . .
Economic liberalization has bloomed while the seeds of political liberalization have only begun to be planted.
But as a rule of law emerges for commercial transactions, demands for individual rights will increase. Democracy breeds calls for more democracy. And U.S. policy should encourage the fragile opening in China through continued exchange programs, the National Endowment for Democracy, through Radio Free Asia, and through continued trade support for freedom and democracy with all the tools in our arsenal.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

China Volleys Back In Trade Dispute
Beijing warned that it planned to retaliate heavily if the United States imposed $2 billion worth of trade sanctions on China for failing to reduce copyright piracy. A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said that China would respond with sanctions even bigger than those proposed by Washington. [Page A9.]
 
Independence Vowed for Mazda
Henry D. G. Wallace, a former Ford executive who will become president of Mazda, said that the Japanese auto maker, in which Ford has increased its stake, would remain independent. [D2.]
 
Ford said it would not risk missing profit targets simply to insure that its Taurus would again be the best-selling car in the United States. Partly because of heavy incentives, it has held that position for four years. [D2.]
 
Chip Indicator Fell Again in April
The computer chip industry's leading indicator fell for the sixth straight month in April. The book-to-bill ratio was 0.78, down from a revised 0.79 for March. [D3.]
 
Apple to Repair Flawed Computers
Apple said it would fix problems with some of its desktop and laptop computers. Analysts said the flaws may hurt Apple's image, already battered, more than its pocketbook. [D3.]
 
The Case Against Cyclical Stocks
While the overall market has fallen from its mid-February peak, cyclical stocks have withstood much of the turbulence. Because of that, and the Fed's apparent feat of engineering an economic soft landing and takeoff, cyclical stocks may now be less attractive. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Calm After a Market Storm
After a volatile Wednesday, trading in stocks was more subdued. The Dow rose only 1.08 points, to 5,475.14. [D6.]
 
The yield of the 30-year Treasury bond bounced back above 7 percent as traders' fears of inflation were revived. [D5.]
 
Suit Against Moody's Is Rejected
A Federal judge threw out a lawsuit against Moody's over its unsolicited rating of bonds that a Colorado school district sold. [D2.]
 
Internet Link for TV's Is Planned
Zenith Electronics said it planned to market a television that could connect to the Internet without using a computer. [D3.]
 
Penalties in Insider Trading Case
The wife of a former Intuit executive agreed, along with five other people, to pay fines for insider trading connected to the company's failed deal to be acquired by Microsoft. [D6.]
 
Nasdaq Names a New President
Alfred R. Berkeley 3d, a managing director of Alex. Brown & Sons, was named president of the Nasdaq Stock Market; he vowed to defend investors' interests. [D2.]
 
Kennedy Rail Link Approved
The Port Authority's commissioners approved a plan to build a $1 billion rail line from Manhattan to Kennedy Airport. [B1.]
 
Big Mac Gets a Big Brother
McDonald's is going after consumers who may have outgrown Big Macs. The fast-food giant, betting $200 million that older consumers want more sophisticated fare, introduced the Arch Deluxe, a sandwich on a soft potato-flour roll with a beef patty, cheese, lettuce, tomato and, of course, a secret sauce. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]
 
Trading in Penny Stock Suspended
The National Association of Securities Dealers suspended trading of stock in Comparator Systems, a fingerprint identification company, pending results of an investigation into its operations. The stock, a penny stock, had set volume records on Monday and Tuesday as investors bid up the price. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Oil Company Profiteering Fuels Price Increase

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your May 6 editorial on whether the Clinton Administration should impose oil sanctions over human rights abuses in Nigeria: The White House is unlikely to do anything to risk a further fuel price increase. When Nigerian oil workers went on strike two years ago to protest military rule, world oil prices went up. Until Americans are in the streets protesting the situation in Nigeria, why would any politician risk a measure that, while proper, could fuel more bad election-year news?
 
NICK SIMEONE
McLean, Va., May 7, 1996

HEADLINE: Dole Attacks Clinton Asia Policy Although He Supports Part of It

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
In a blistering election-year attack on President Clinton's policy in Asia, Senator Bob Dole lacerated the Administration today as incoherent and naive and said the President's "double talk" had undercut American authority abroad.
"As a direct result of the weak leadership, vacillation and inconsistency, which are the hallmarks of Clinton Administration foreign policy, the world's sole superpower finds itself drifting and defensive, with an uncertain course and an untrusted voice in the Pacific Basin," Mr. Dole, the presumed Republican Presidential nominee, said in a speech today. 
 Nonetheless, while Mr. Dole asserted that his would be a different kind of Presidency, he appeared to back many Administration positions.
Most prominently, Mr. Dole reaffirmed his support for renewing preferential trade privileges for China, lining up solidly behind the Administration and spurning the conservative wing of his own party. Still, he said, Mr. Clinton's weak leadership on the matter threatened its prospects on Capitol Hill.
"As we have seen in Bosnia, Iran, Cuba and elsewhere, when President Clinton is faced with a fork in the foreign policy road, he takes it," Mr. Dole said. [Excerpts, page A8.]
As Mr. Dole continues to sink in the public opinion polls, the five-term Senator from Kansas drew today on one of his perceived strengths -- his toughness on foreign policy -- to counter the President on one of his perceived weaknesses: his lack of firm footing on the world stage and his reputation for changeability.
Mr. Clinton has "squandered the rich foreign policy legacy he inherited by making inconsistency, confusion and incoherence the common features of American diplomacy," Mr. Dole said. He said the President's track record "of weakness, indecision, doubletalk" had undermined American interests.
The speech, delivered at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a nonpartisan research organization, took months to draft and nearly an hour for Mr. Dole to read.
"There's a lot more than simply 'Dole announces support for extending M.F.N.'," a Dole aide said, a reference to continuing the so-called most-favored-nation trade status for China. But his position on this issue has been a central question since Mr. Dole -- under pressure from conservatives who want a tougher stand toward China and eager to distinguish himself from Mr. Clinton -- appeared last month to waver in his long-held support for special trade status for China.
The Dole team provided a background briefing for reporters and offered advance texts of the speech; the Clinton team responded by making top officials available for interviews and using no less than Vice President Al Gore to answer Mr. Dole.
Mr. Gore praised Mr. Dole for "courage" in supporting the President's policy on trade with China and for backing President Clinton's announcement this week that he would impose significant sanctions on some of China's exports -- while continuing the preferential trade status -- if China continued to pirate American software, music and videos.
"I think he showed courage in rejecting the growing forces of isolationism and know-nothingism in the Republican Party" in the middle of a campaign, Mr. Gore said.
As for the rest of Mr. Dole's criticism of Mr. Clinton's Asia policy -- the Senator accused the President of "coddling" North Korea, slighting South Korea and "amateurish posturing" in trade disputes with Japan -- Mr. Gore was dismissive, calling it "fluff and dust" required by partisan politics to disguise the fact that he generally agreed with Administration policy.
A White House official said Mr. Dole appeared desperate in employing a strategy of "slandering" the President. "Their strategy is to use foreign policy as a character issue because they can't fight us any other way," the official said. "They are grasping at straws to find something to criticize us about, when it's basically an endorsement of our policy."
Conservatives, led by Patrick J. Buchanan, Mr. Dole's erstwhile rival for the Republican nomination, have been railing against renewal of trade privileges for China, citing Beijing's human rights abuses, forced abortions, and selling of nuclear technology to rogue nations. Mr. Buchanan could not be reached today after Mr. Dole's speech.
But American businesses with a stake in China have favored a deepening of economic ties.
Defending his long-held support for renewing most-favored-nation trading status with China, Mr. Dole said: "We should extend M.F.N. to China, not because it is in our economic interest, but because it is in our national interest. To deny M.F.N. for China would set back our relations more than two decades and send a disastrous signal of American withdrawal to our strategic allies."
He quoted Mr. Clinton as saying in 1992, when he was a candidate for President, that he would "link China's trading privileges to its human rights record and its conduct of weapon sales." Mr. Dole noted this promise had "an unusually short shelf-life" once Mr. Clinton was elected, "collapsing in about six months under the weight of its own naive and contradictory purposes."
In response to conservatives, Mr. Dole said: "Denying M.F.N. would not free a single dissident, halt a single missile sale, prevent a single threat to Taiwan or save a single innocent Chinese life."
Although China's record on human rights was indefensible, he said, it is not the only country committing abuses while enjoying most-favored-nation status, citing Russia and Syria. "In China," he said, "continued trade offers the prospect of continued change."
Administration officials said they expected that Mr. Dole's backing would help ensure the measure's success on Capitol Hill.
Still, many expect a fierce struggle when the Administration formally notifies Congress of its intentions to renew the trading privileges, which it must do before June 3. Unless both houses vote to cancel it, it is automatically renewed. The House is expected to cancel it or at least attach conditions the Administration would find unacceptable. But the Senate, especially now with Mr. Dole's support, appears likely to favor renewal.
As for other matters that Mr. Dole discussed today, Mr. Gore refused to respond in any detail to many of them. To Mr. Dole's demand for the deployment of missile defenses for Taiwan, Mr. Gore said the Administration had already deployed some missile defenses to the Asian region and would provide more, including "a recent agreement with Taiwan" to give it a Patriot antimissile system of medium technology by 1998.
"I'm not sure Mr. Dole's aware of what's going on," Mr. Gore said. "He talks about 'paper studies.' We've gone a long way past that."

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Sound of Money

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
In today's exploding Times Square -- where mobs jam the new Virgin Megastore and Conde Nast just joined Disney and Madame Tussaud's on the bandwagon of new tenants -- Julie Andrews's loverly display of primadonnaism this week seemed a quaint relic of the past.
It was 40 years ago that this star triumphed on Broadway in "My Fair Lady" -- and most of the Wednesday matinee audience who witnessed her curtain speech at "Victor/Victoria" knew her from way back then. The speech itself -- in which Ms. Andrews declined the dubious distinction of a Tony Award nomination -- was a rare throwback to the time when Americans cared so much about the Broadway theater that a well-executed publicity stunt could become a national event. 
 For Ms. Andrews, her Tony fit was certainly her shrewdest career move since she bared her breasts in the movie "S.O.B." in 1981. Her pique landed her on the front page of The New York Post for days, with such priceless headlines as "Tony Baloney" and "Mary Poppins Hoppin' Mad," and soon the international press chimed in. Tony Adams, a "Victor/Victoria" producer, reports that the show's box-office receipts have jumped 50 percent. So sweet was the "controversy" that some Broadway hands dreamt aloud that this June a TV audience might actually tune in the Tony telecast, whose Nielsens have hit rock-bottom.
Yet it's hard to imagine that one show's P.R. bonanza will lift the rest of the theater. Even as Ms. Andrews made news by lamenting how her musical had been shut out of every Tony category but her own, the half-price ticket booth told another story of Broadway in 1996. The highly acclaimed shows that received all the Tony accolades that "Victor/Victoria" did not -- "Bring In Da Noise," "Master Class," "Seven Guitars," "A Delicate Balance," among many others -- were all dumping seats for that night at steep discounts.
What's the problem in what is widely regarded as Broadway's best season in years? It's surely not that "Victor/Victoria," a lackluster star vehicle at best, was a victim of rank injustice -- especially given the real Tony competition this year. Even so, the awards have long been a joke. Only last season Broadway's most acclaimed performance, Nathan Lane's in "Love! Valour! Compassion!" failed to be nominated; three years earlier a Tony nominating committee was purged (as this year's no doubt soon will be) after it ignored plays that were running to nominate those that had closed. Variety long ago exposed still-rampant fraud in the voting process, and the hapless Tony show itself, network TV's sole celebration of live theater, will this year have more pre-recorded segments than ever before.
But the mere fact that such unprofessional nonsense has gone on so long without reform -- devaluing the Tonys to the point where even a big winner like 1994's "Passion" still flops -- is, as the prominent theatrical lawyer John Breglio puts it, "symptomatic of the underlying chaos in this business." The Tonys are the least of the crises in a leaderless industry that can't slow the rising production costs and ticket prices that, "Rent" notwithstanding, deter audiences younger than Ms. Andrews's and are likely to leave most of this season's "hits" drowned in red ink.
Earlier this week the legendary producer David Merrick, untamed by a stroke, got so angry he wheeled without warning into the theater's trade association, the increasingly fratricidal League of American Theaters and Producers, less to plead for his own "State Fair" than to berate the "imbeciles" he feels are destroying Broadway. Like Ms. Andrews, he is a survivor of Broadway's golden age -- and wrote the book on turning a mediocre musical into front-page news when he announced the director Gower Champion's death at the opening-night curtain call for "42nd Street" in 1980.
But such stunts by veterans of another Broadway, fun as they may be, cannot repair an industry so fractious that its management can't even muster a united bargaining front for this year's crucial union negotiations. If the Broadway theater is to be the jewel, not the perennial economic invalid, of the new Times Square rising all around it, it had better worry less about whether a venerable star will turn up for the Tonys than about whether it can attract a new generation of customers to turn up for its shows.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Middle-Aged Vigilantes: The Gang Has Grown Up

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
From the macroeconomic and sociological perspective visible through its litter of corpses, the muddled Middle Western "Original Gangstas," which opened yesterday, has a lot to say about what is wrong with America. And when it comes to what's wrong with movies, this tale of generational vengeance also speaks eloquently.
Filmed in Rust Belt towns like Gary and East Chicago, Ind., "Original Gangstas" resurrects many of the stars of the so-called black exploitation movies of the 1970's -- among them Fred Williamson, Jim Brown, Pam Grier, and Richard Roundtree -- to tell the story of a depressed community that rises from the oppression of youth gangs to take back its streets. 
 Before "Original Gangstas" descends into the sort of ill-conceived bloodbaths and settling of accounts that owe more to the conventions of movies than the demands of logic, this film, directed by Larry Cohen and written by Aubrey Rattan, builds on the vast technological and economic tides that have swept away Gary's steel industry, devastated black blue-collar workers and reduced many of their children to angry, disaffected dropouts.
Against this backdrop, the film tells its story of a promising young basketball player slain for hustling a gang, of a decent grocer beaten and shot for trying to help the police, and of the middle-aged heroes who band together, as they did in their youth, to try to set things right when the white authorities, including the mayor and the police, prove inept and impotent. The subtext that glorifies middle-aged vigilantes reflects a climate that has nourished private militias that regard government with a disillusioned, hostile eye.
Along with its murders, drive-by shootings, loathsome villains, keen sense of gang fashion and plentiful trash talk, "Original Gangstas" deals knowingly, if glancingly, with out-of-wedlock pregnancy, children growing up without fathers, fathers who never know their children and the generation gap that separates the putative good old days of rock- and bottle-throwing gangs from those of gangs armed with knives, pistols, Molotov cocktails, dynamite and the latest in automatic weapons.
Mr. Williamson, who produced the film, plays a former professional football star who returns to Gary from his comfortable life in Los Angeles after his father, the grocer, is shot and decides to take on the gangs. Mr. Brown, as a former boxer who is the father of the young basketball player, is, like Mr. Williamson, a founder of the Rebels, the gang now preying on their neighborhood. Ms. Grier portrays the mother of the slain young man who brought up her son alone.
Thicker of waist and longer of tooth these days, Mr. Williamson, 58, and Mr. Brown, 61, still pack plenty of panache and handle the action with authority and dispatch. The rekindled romance between Mr. Brown and Ms. Grier receives perfunctory handling, and a rock, rap, gospel score accompanies the violence.
Plenty of sense underlies "Original Gangstas," but this film takes the easy route when it trains its guns on the box office and turns its back on originality.
 
ORIGINAL GANGSTAS
 
Directed by Larry Cohen; written by Aubrey Rattan; director of photography, Carlos Gonzalez; edited by David Kern and Peter B. Ellis; music by Vladimir Horunzhy; production designer, Elayne Barbara Ceder; produced by Fred Williamson; released by Orion Pictures. Running time: 99 minutes. This film is rated R.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 32; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 680 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
After Much Ado, Japan Passes '96 Budget

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 10

 BODY:
After months of bitter wrangling, the Japanese Parliament today approved a $715 billion budget for this fiscal year, which began on April 1.
The budget, which reflects an increase of 5.8 percent over the previous year's figure, widens the Government's financial deficit. In an illustration of its recent economic woes, Japan has now moved from a country that had a financial surplus four years ago to a country with one of the biggest deficits in the world. 
 The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development estimated that the financial deficit of the Government represents 3.9 percent of gross domestic product in 1995, compared with 1.6 percent in the United States.
In a magazine article published today, Masayoshi Takemura, the former Finance Minister, calls the budget issue one of the biggest crises facing the Japanese Government, referring to it as a "budgetary breakdown."
"Frankly, I had thought the budget deficit was a problem faced by the U.S. and European nations," Mr. Takemura said in his article, published in a magazine called Chuo Koron. "But by fall last year, I came to seriously realize that it was Japan that has slipped into the worst state."
"Japan's budget deficit is a domestic issue, but it will receive attention as a serious issue affecting the world economy," he added.
Some analysts, however, discounted the seriousness of the budgetary problems, and a Ministry of Finance official, Kazumi Akiyama, dismissed the criticisms.
"I don't think Japan will collapse because of the budget deficit," Mr. Akiyama said.
With today's passage, debate will now turn to the real source of the delay, a controversial plan to use about $6.5 billion initially in taxpayers' funds to pay for the liquidation of ailing mortgage companies, called jusen. In a compromise struck between the ruling coalition, led by the Liberal Democratic Party, and the New Frontier opposition party, taxpayers' funds will only be used once a detailed framework has been worked out.
But the plan, which had originally seemed assured of passage when it was first proposed by the Ministry of Finance late last year, faces such strong public opposition that it is still uncertain whether outright use of taxpayers' funds will take place.
The New Frontier Party, which had staged a sit-in protest in Parliament, opposed the use of taxpayers' funds. And recently Government officials, including Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, have called for certain banks to take some of the financial burden off taxpayers.
A number of Japan's large commercial banks helped found the jusen, lending money to them and playing a role in management. The banks have agreed to write off those loans, but they have refused to contribute more money to pay for the liquidation of the jusen.
"What the banks are fearing is taking on the role of savior of the financial system," said James Fiorello, a banking analyst at ING Barings Securities (Japan) Ltd. "In that role, their liabilities could be limitless."
The ailing jusen represent only a small portion of the overall bad debt debacle. Financial institutions are expected to have written off about $145 billion in bad debt in the year ending March 31, but according to some estimates, there still remains about $500 billion more in bad debt.
Earlier this week, Moody's Investors Service issued a pessimistic assessment of Japan's financial system. Under its financial strength ratings for banks around the world, Japan has the largest number of banks with weak ratings, and in its report, Moody's said there continued to be "growing uncertainty regarding the Japanese authorities' ability to provide safeguards for overall stability in the banking system."
Moody's said that certain big banks were well positioned to weather financial difficulties, including the effect of land prices, which continue to slip. But it had doubts about certain smaller institutions, and forecast that with capital adequacy slipping below international standards, some institutions would be forced to increase capital or reduce loan assets.
